description: American Cyanamid Company and Japan Catalytic International, Inc., working together in a newlyformed partnership, have been awarded a threeYear contract by General Motors Corporation to supply part of the company's auto exhaust supply needs, it was announced yesterday.

title: Text of Memo From Colson to Haldeman on Kleindienst Nomination
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1Following is the text of a March 30, 1972, memorandum from Charles W. Colson, then a special counsel to President Nixon, to H. R. Haldeman, then the President's chief of staff, regarding ongoing hearings before the Senate Judiciary Committee on the nomination of Richard G. Kleindienst to be Attorney General. The critical issue before the committee was an allegation that Justice Department officials had decided an antitrust case involving the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation to the advantage of the company after the company pledged $400,000 toward expenses for the Republican National Convention originally scheduled for San Diego.

title: Plan Set for LIP Company
description: PARIS, Aug. 1The French Government made public today its plan to settle the nearlytwomonth old dispute between the management of the LIP Watch Manufacturing Company and its workers, who took over the factory and its production to protest the sale of the company to Swiss interests.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 70yearold Brooklyn woman, charged with poisoning two wolves, was ordered in Criminal Court yesterday to undergo psychiatric examination. The woman, Pauline Hollinger of 1201 Avenue K, pleaded not guilty to charges of burglary and criminal mischief. She had been arrested her home the night before on the basis of information from an anonymous telephone caller who said he had witnessed the crime.

title: FRAUD IS LAID TO 4 IN HEALTH PROJECT
description: Four men involved in the operation of a nowdefunct medical center in Freeport, L. I., were arraigned yesterday on charges of raising $600,000 through the fraudulent sale of securities.

title: The Great Howcum
description: WASHINGTON  President Eisenhower used to have a benign enemies list of his own. Whenever somebody irritated him, he would write that person's name on a scrap of paper, crumple it up and throw it in a bottom drawer, thereby ridding himself of what later came to be called hangups.

title: A.F.L.C.I.O. Unit Says Phase Could Cause Economic Recession
description: OAK BROOK, Ill., Aug. 1The Executive Council of the A.F.L.C.I.O. said today that the failure of the Administration's economic stabilization program and the tight money policy of the Federal Reserve Board could lead to a recession.

title: The Screen: 'Dillinger':Oates Plays Title Role in Film by Milius
description: John Milius, the 29-year-old enfant terrible who wrote and directed "Dillinger," appears to be confused in his loyalties in this latest focus on the legendary Public Enemy No. 1, which opened at the Cinerama and other houses yesterday. His gangsters are larger, funnier and fuzzier than life as obviously monstrous killers. But they also leave the impression of having been slightly martyred as they are just as monstrously mowed down by G-men and others.In making his debut as a director, Mr. Milius gives us a "Dillinger" that is fascinating for its speed, action and firepower. But as character studies of decidedly interesting types out of explosive history, "Dillinger" shoots blanks most of the time.A viewer is frequently reminded of the likes of "Bonnie and Clyde" and "The Wild Bunch" as Dillinger and company rob banks and get shot up in dashes across the Depression countryside in vintage cars to vintage music "We're in the Money," etc.) on a gory road that ends in Dillinger's bloody finish outside that Chicago movie house in 1934.There is, however, no full explanation of why or how Dillinger or the others took that path. They often seem to be caricatures rather than real characters. "I sure am happy. I just want to steal people's money," says Dillinger in an observation indicative of some of the film's surface, tongue-in-cheek dialogue.As depicted in scenes shot in and around Enid, Okla., members of his gang (Pretty Boy Floyd, Baby Face Nelson, et al) are callous but equally happy in their work. "This just isn't my day," says one of the members before he is killed. And slaughter is the order of the day as they are cut down in their pastoral hideout, Little Bohemia, by G-men led by the gang's nemesis, the cigar-smoking Melvin Purvis, who also serves as the off-screen narrator.The Dillinger portrayed by Warren Oates is tough and homespun, if little else. He can push Baby Face Nelson around. He is sentimental about visiting his folks, and he is roughly affectionate with his girl, but the full character of the man or gangster rarely emerges.Ben Johnson comes across more vividly as the indomitable Purvis, who longs for the kind of recognition Dillinger gets. Michelle Phillips (formerly with the singers the Mamas and the Papas) is mildly effective in her debut as Dillinger's ever-loving girl. And, like most of the principals, Cloris Leachman, as the "lady in red" informer who helped trap Dillinger, is hardly on screen long enough to impress a viewer."Dillinger" does capture the look of the nineteen-thirties, but its violence dominates the scene and the players, who remain largely undefined figures on a bloody landscape.

title: SAMUEL FEINGOLD
description: Samuel Feingold, who was a Republican alderman under Mayor Morello H. la Guardia in 193435, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at 165 East 72d Street.

description: New Jersey has decided to put off approval of any abortion clinics until the fall, and at least one physician awaiting permission to open a clinic maintains that the delay is unreasonable.

title: Vitamin Sales and Labeling Face Tighter Regulationby the F. D. A.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 The Food and Drug Administration took final action today on a subject that has caused nationwide debate and controversy for at least a decade the labeling, promotion andsales of vitamins and minerals, The drug agency announced regulations, to become effective in 60 days, that will require prescriptions for highdosage forms of vitamins A and D, Smaller units of the same vitamins will still be availableover the counter. New regulations governing all other vitamins in current use were also announced, but F.D.A. officials emphasized that none would be forced off the market and none would be restricted qqqexclusively to prescription use.

Reed had been warned twice previously by the police before he made his attempt before hundreds of spectators. Mr. Reed told newsmen he considers the alligator a pet.

Mr. Crabiel said he had received more than $51,000 and had spent $35,635 before he dropped his candidacy to support Mr. Byrne in last June's primary election.

title: GFOING OUT Guide
description: ABC OF DO RE MI If the millionaire had learned to write, the old joke goes, he'd still he caretaker in a seminary. Well, the Chase Manhattan Bank Money Museum, 1254 Avenue of the Americas, on the ground floor of the RCA Building at 50th Street (5521047), has put cash on the letterhead in a new exhibition that tells of the long relationship between writing and money. The exhibition is a small part of what is to be seen in this extensive twogallery museum that belongs to the bank of the same name, but it dwells on alphabets and ancient documents about money. The museum also has specimens of prehistoric and historic money in the shape of tzourds, coins, hills, Confedgrate currency and counterfeit currency (on the last, you may play a game guessing the good from the fake).

title: The Tirvelda Redcoats Bring Back the Ribbons
description: Ask almost any Irish setter fancier to think or a leading kennel of redcoats and invariably the reply is Tirvelda Farms. Tirvelda (T for Ted, Iry for Irving and Eld for Eldredge) is the property of Mr. and Mrs. Irving (Ted) Eldredge of Middleburg, Va. When Tirvelda Fortunata gained her title this year, she was the 88th champion Ted had owned or bred. I had my first Irish setter when I was 10 years old, said Eldredge. He was a 6weekold pup and we called him St. Patrick. News of Dogs

title: Books of The Times
description: It's a heavy duty, reading Noam Chomsky's latest book, a collection of nine essays gathered under the title For Reasons of State (which is taken from a statement by Michael Bakunin excoriating the inhuman deeds committed under no other pretext than those elastic words, so convenient and yet so terrible: for reasons of state ). Heavy dutybecause, for example, in an essay examining the conduct of the Berrigan brothers, On the Limits of Civil Disobedience, Professor Chomsky's logic seems irristible. One may wish to protest that while one disapproved of the war, one had other prioritiesthere was the family to look after, the mortgage payments to meet, the garbage to be put outbut Chomsky leaves one feeling like a moral pygmy for not having gone out and destroyed a few draft files.

title: People in Sports: Computer Throws Aaron a Curve

title: ' Sssssss' and 'Werewolf' Blend Horror
description: Skip "The Boy Who Cried Werewolf," the standard, slapdash half of a new horror double bill that includes something called "Sssssss" (as in snake). There is some amusing business in "Werewolf" toward the end, as the thrashing werewolf (Kerwin Mathews) tangles with a bunch of Jesus Freaks. Bob Homel, who plays the leader, also wrote the picture.See "Sssssss," a ss-surprise. Were it not for the lurid, starkly flapping windup, this would be recommended in toto as a gripping, quietly imaginative hair-curler. It is the only movie fiction I have ever seen that sustains a scholarly, informative attitude toward the world of snakes. This aspect is fascinating and chilling, as a gentle old venom researcher, Strother Martin, putters around with cobras and pythons in a country lab. His aides are his daughter and a smitten student.That's the set-up, adroitly blended into a low-budget canvas of small-town characters and a visiting carnival by Hal Dresner's script (from a story by the producer, Dan Striepeke) and by Bernard L.Kowalski's direction. About midpoint, the effective color and music subtly signal that something perfectly horrible in the human department is also uncoiling on the doctor's premises.Toned down, without the final fireworks, the picture would have emerged as a real sleeper for thriller fans, who should catch it anyway. It's certainly original. Mr. Martin does well, so does young Dirk Benedict, but the best are Jack Ging as a sheriff and Heather Menzies, a perfectly charming daughter. As for those snakesOoooooo.

title: Music: Pianistic Bach
description: What was once known as the Mozart Festival became the Mostly Mozart Festival five seasons ago, a hedge that makes it possible for Lincoln Center's summertime series to offer, as it did Tuesday night at Philharmonic Hall, a program of undiluted Bach. The big hall is certainly not the ideal place to hear 18thcentury music, but an enthusiastic audience virtually filled the place to hear Rosalyn Tureck give her famous piano versions of works that Bach wrote for harpsichord and/or clavichord.

title: Very Young Love Story, 'Jeremy,' Is on Screen:The Cast
description: Well over two years ago, when "Love Story" first began making everybody connected with it rich and famous, there was a lot of talk about a romantic revivalor a revival of romancein movies. We were about to face the legions of the children of "Love Story." The offspring never materializedor if they did, they were so pale that you couldn't see them.But now there is one, full blown, blushing and very unashameda genuine "Son of Love Story." Its name is "Jeremy," and it opened yesterday at Loews Tower East.It's a smaller movie than its sire, and, of course, much younger. The scene is not Harvard/Radcliffe, but something like sophomore-year High School of Music and Art. The boy is Jewish, middle-class, a musician a cellist. The girl is gentile, middle-class, a dancer.Their problem is not how to get married and live together, but rather, how to work up nerve enough to say hello to each other in public. And when they do, and when they finally acknowledge that they are in love, it is not the Grim Reaper Death who ends the tale. It's her dad, who yanks her off to Detroit with him, on his way to a better job. "Jeremy" is touchingly awkward, pleasantly sad. It is not exactly a desperate movie.However, it is a movie of rather heavy calculation, indulging almost every clich available to young love in Manhattanthe city at night, rainy afternoons, the camera floating over Park Avenue, or looking up through the sun-dappled leaves of Central Park. Like the advice of Jeremy's wise old cello teacher (e.g. "The music expresses life! Play it that way."), they deal not so much with experience as in preordained states of mind.But in the long run "Jeremy" is less committed to its clichs than to its kids. It may be dull about the glamour of the city strets, but about the agony of calling up a girl for the first time just to make a date it is right on target. It specializes not in tragedy, but in a kind of bittersweet discomfort  which is true and moving, in spite of all the efforts to jack up its appeal.An aura of not-quite professionalism surrounds "Jeremy," generally saving it from its own slickness, and validating a number of decent, tentative performances like that of Glynnis O'Connor as the girl, Susan.As Jeremy, Robby Benson faces the problem of any clever kid playing a klutzy kidbright, sensitive, original, and rather a jerkand I think he handles it admirably. I don't know how complete an actor he'll be one day, but in this performance he virtually shapes everything that matters in the movie.Arthur Barron is the writer and director of record for "Jeremy," but there has been notice given in the trade press to an assertion by Joseph Brooks, a New York film and TV music composer, that the movie is in some measure his. I can't pretend to sort out the claimsnot too unique in the busines of movie makingbut it seems fair to suggest that in whatever proportion, both men were involved in the authorship of the film.

title: ' Maurie,' Basketball Star's Story, Opens
description: As a potentially inspirational saga that respects the awesome truth that generated it, "Maurie," now at Loews State and Cine Theaters is, unfortunately, rarely moving as drama. The heroism, tragedy and friendship of Maurice Stokes, the black basketball star destined to die, and his white teammate, Jack Twyman, formerly of the Cincinnati Royals, evolves on screen with largely soap-opera effects.Fans, of course, will recall that Stokes was incapacitated and hospitalized after a head injury, and Jack Twyman selflessly spent 10 years raising the many thousands of dollars for the attempts to rehabilitate his friend before he finally succumbed three years ago.But Daniel Mann's direction is uninspired, and the script by Douglas Morrow, who won an Oscar for another story stemming from the sports world, "The Stratton Story," has not effectively transplanted much of what was real and affecting in the Stokes-Twyman story into touching movie terms.His principals are characters obviously injured by the fates, but they are rarely equal to the shattering true circumstances into which they have been plunged.Further explanations are called for from the script that doesn't develop its characters completely and seems pointed mostly toward tear jerking. Bo Swenson as Twyman, is sincere and stalwart in his devotion as Stokes's official guardian and Bernie Casey is dignified as the stricken Stokes.Janet MacLachlan is pretty and unassuming as his persevering girl, and Stephanie Edwards is natural as Twyman's understanding wife. But as a dramatization of unusual, affecting real human drama, "Maurie" only occasionally stirs the heart or mind.

title: Butz Favors, Early End to Ceiling on Prices
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. ISecretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz gave some encouragement today to beef processors who were meeting here to protest price ceilings, despite conflicting positions taken by the Cost of Living Council and the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers.

title: A King and a Queen, but There Are No Princes or Princesses in Sight
description: Stewart Mott, the 35yearold bachelor philanthropist, rode down Fifth Avenue in a hansom cab yesterday, wearing a crown of laurel leaves. No, he was not celebrating making another million to go with the five he already has. He had just been named male National NonParent of the Year.

title: Butz Favors Early End to Ceiling on Prices
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz gave some encouragement today to beef processors who were meeting here to protest price ceilings, despite conflicting positions taken by the Cost of Living Council and the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers.

title: INMATE WITH CANCER PAROLED BY JUSTICE
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Queens, admitting he; might be violating the law, yesterday vacated the sentence of a woman prisoner because she has terminal cancer and has at most a year to live.

title: National Geographic Series Moving to A.B.C. Network
description: The awardwinning series of National Geographic Society documentary specials will move to the television network of the American Broadcasting Company this season, with the first program to be shown Sept. 6 from 8 to 9 P.M.

title: BIDS FALL SHORT ON U.S. BOND ISSUE
description: The United States Government obtained public subscriptions for just over half the $500milion it sought to raise through an auction of 7 per cent bonds due in 20 years, the Treasury announced last night.

title: Giants Jacobson Hopes To Be Able to Face Jets
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., Aug. 1The New York Giants received another encouraging report at their training camp today: Larry Jacobson may be ready for the opening game of the regular season.

title: MAYOR TO REVIEW PARKING PERMITS
description: Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that he would review standards for granting special parking privileges to the handicapped and seek to shrink designated midtown parking spots for cars of diplomats and the press.

title: Football Transactions
description: CLEVELANDSigned Ben Davis, cornerback; Placed Randy Mattingly, quarterback and No. 7 draft choice from Evansville (ind.) University, on waivers.

title: Orange County Show
description: Small Junior Working Hunter StakeMegin Milford's Something Special.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS DOWN ANSWER TO PREVIOUS PUZZLE

title: TonDaLay Delayed
description: In rejecting a developer's plan to build second homes for some 20,000 recreation  seekers in the heart of the Adirondack Park, the state's Commissioner of Environmental Conservation did precisely what he had to do as head of a department charged with preserving the state's natural resources.

title: fury Chosen in Gainesville 8 Trial
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Aug. 2A jury with an average age of 31 was empaneled today in the trial of the Gainesville 8, and Federal District Judge Winston E. Arnow immediately ordered them sequestered.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Tickets matching the number above win $50,000. Tickets matching the last five numbers win $5,000. Those matching the last four numbers win $500 and those matching the last three, $50.

title: ' Le Sex Shop' Sells the Devil's Merchandise, Purely
description: With two growing kids, a loving wife who nevertheless likes to spend money and a public that seems to have called it quits on reading, Claude (Claude Berri) doesn't need much persuading to close down his bookstore and, on a successful friend's advice ("Proust or 'Positions,' a book's a book"), to reopen it as a sex shop.So he finds himselfthis small, quiet, balding Parisianthe chief proprietor in a world of potency pills, personal vibrators, leather goods and specialized magazines catering to a number of preferences and peculiarities that are 90 per cent news to him.His horizons expandinto one embarrassment after anotherwith a wife-swapping dentist (Jean-Pierre Mariello) and the dentist's swappable wife (Nathalie Delon), at a group-sex night spot, on board a Mediterranean cruise sponsored by a love club, with his father-in-law and mother-in-law, as companions. Here, through the entire course of a petit-bourgeois Walpurgisnacht, he never does quite manage the infidelity it seems his social obligation to commit.These adventures, an hour and a half of them, make up Claude Berri's "Le Sex Shop"a French name, like "Le Drugstore"  which opened yesterday at the Fine Arts Theater.As a nonfan, from way back, of Claude Berri ("The Two of Us," "Marry Me! Marry Me!"), I was interested in seeing how he would treat material not as susceptible to the sentimental sweetness that has been his trademark and, for me, his greatest liability. On the whole, he treats it very respectfully.But he hasn't really dropped the sweetness. He has only modified it to encompass sadism, masochism, fetishism, voyeurism, old men who like young girls and young girls who like other girls  the whole sexual revolution that is greeted by some with rage, by others with delight and by Claude Berri with a kind of gentle, sympathetic tolerrance.This may sound like transcendent virtue, but it is not. Berri's cinema, never sharp enough for satire, is also never exalted enough for transcendence. If you were to reduce Blake's "everything that lives is holy" to something like "everybody is ultimately a nice guy," you would have a reasonable formula for the drabness of Berri's film.There are moments of real pleasure in "Le Sex Shop." There are a lot of really marvelous girls, including Juliet Berto as the wife, Beatrice Romand as the sex-shop salesgirl and the excellent Nathalie Delon. As a type, Claude Berri must be just what he wanted in a leading manthough I wish he had better ideas for what to do with himself, how to turn himself into the deadpan comedian he isn't but apparently means to be.The X rating that accompanies this film is an absurditybased on a few bared breasts, one (simulated) position, 10 vibrators and a chastity belt. "Le Sex Shop" may deal in the Devil's merchandise, but its soul is as pure (too pure) as the driven snow.

title: A FloodSwollen Brook Causes Heavy Loss in North Plainfield
description: NORTH PLAINFIELD, Aug. 2  Green Brook, swollen by heavy rains, overflowed its banks here today, leaving four persons dead, 80 families in temporary shelters after removal from their homes, several hundred automobiles destroyed or damaged and private and business property losses put at least $2million.

title: Astronauts Waited Eight Hours for Word on Trouble
description: For nearly eight hours yesterday, from about 6:45 A.M. to 2:40 P.M. Eastern Daylight time,the Skylab 2 astronauts waited for word on whether the steeringrocket oxidizer leak that had awakened them early signified a general difficulty that would mean they lacked a reliable spacecraft for returning to earth.

title: Freight Traffic Up 9.5%
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 15.9 billion tonmiles, 9.5 per cent above the corresponding week last year. Carloading rose 6.8 per cent to 534,614 cars. The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 6.9 per cent above last year.

title: FASHION TALK
description: The sequins are there, shimmering as seductively they have for the last three decades. So are the minimal jersey dresses and the tailored coats, curving into the waist or falling squarely from the shoulders. The Norman Norell look remains intact, despite the designer's death almost a year ago.

title: Hen's Egg Is Numbered
description: STUTTGART, Ark. (AP)M. C. Koonce is wondering if one of his eight Silver Laced Wyandottes has developed a fondness for mathematics, The hen recently produced an egg with a neatly imprinted figure, 6, on one end.

title: SKYLAB TROUBLES SET OFF PLANNING FOR SPACE RESCUE
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 2Skylab 2 ran into further trouble today with leaking steering rockets, and project officials ordered aroundtheclock preparations of a rescue ship that may have to be dispatched to bring the three astronauts back from the nation's first orbiting space station.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation has received a $76.1million Navy contract for nuclear reactor components for attack submarines.

title: Nixon Signs Veterans Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UPI) President Nixon signed a five year, $408million bill today expanding medical care for veterans and their families.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: OUT BACK The backyard, or Sculpture Garden, of the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street (9566100), is usually thrown open for quiet summer relaxation free to the public Fridays through Sundays from 6 to 11 P.M. (you go right in through 8 West 54th Street). Fridays and Saturdays they usually have some modest entertainment at 8, along with light refreshments. But today and tomorrow from 8 to 10, the fare for the Stunmergarden program is taking on the dimensions of an avantgarde Cecil B. de Mille production.

title: Levitt Reports Tax Collections 163Million Higher for 4 Months
description: ALBANY, Aug. 2Controller Arthur Levitt announced today that tax collections for the state were running $163million higher for the first four months of this fiscal year than a similar period last year and that conditions continued to indicate that New York State will have a very good year.

title: Westchester Golf Is Rained Out
description: HARRISON, N. Y., Aug. 2The first round of the $250,000 Westchester golf classic was started twice today before it was officially washed out by rain.

title: About the Yankees:
description: The Yankees skipped batting practice because of the rainy weather. In line with the faint trend noticed in baseball lately, however, they pass it up now about one day four on the road. Carl Yastrzemski, 0 for 9 in the first three games, held a private session of batting practice after the game Wednesday afternoon. Manager Eddie Kasko watched his $167,000ayear first baseman while the coaches shagged the baseballs. Rough series? Carlton Fisk, who outscored Thurman Munson in the recent voting for the AllStar game, was hit by a pitch from Mel Stottlemyre in the second inning Wednesday. The night before, he blocked the plate and then tagged out Roy White, who had missed it. He was finally outnumbered in the big fight, though, by Munson and his roommate, Gene Michael, fellow alumnus of Kent State Add oldtimers for the annual reunion at Yankee Stadium on Aug. 11: George Selkirk for the 1934 Yankee team, Elston Howard for 1963, Stottlemyre for 1969 and Vic Raschi and somebody named Casey Stengel representing the Class of 1949.

title: State Said to Ask Drug Arrests Be Held Down to Avert Flood
description: The city's Corporation Counsel said yesterday that the administrator of the new state antinarcotics program had appealed privately to the police not to make too many arrests under the program to insure against flooding of present and new [court] parts.

title: People in Sports: Rams Tune Up
description: Convinced that some changes were needed in view of the Los Angeles Rams poor record last season (six victories, seven losses and a tie), Carroll Rosenbloom, owner of the club, changed coaches, quarterbacks and uniforms. Now he's even changed the team's fight song.

title: Boy Held in Rape Of Girl Is Suspect In Several Cases
description: A 15yearold boy from Jamaica, Queens, was arrested yesterday and charged with the rape on July 26 of a 14yearold girl who said her assailant had forced her into a driveway with a gun at her head.

title: Back to I.T.T.
description: In March and April of 1972, when Watergate was a household word only to those who lived there, the big issue was a suspicious coziness between the Nixon Administration and the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation. From this relationship came the dropping of an antitrust action against the mighty conglomerate and a convenient commitment of as much as $400,000 from I.T.T. to help pay for the Republican National Convention.

title: Wednesday's Fights
description: Palma De Mallorca, SpainJose Legra, 123 pounds, Spain, outpointed Jimmy Bell, 125, Scotland, 10 rounds.

title: Deaths
description: Memorial Service. In Memoriam

title: Inouye Says. Thank You, To Senatorsin Hawaiian
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2Senator Daniel K. Inouye was saying mahalo and aloha todaybut not to John J. Wilson, the laNer who referred to him yesterday as a little Jap.

title: Equity Financing
description: Smith, International, Inc., sold yesterday 1.5million shares of common stock at $19.25 a share through an underwriting network managed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc. The company, which makes drilling equipment, had sales of $103.3million and earnings of $5.95million, or 90 cents a share, last year.

title: 2 SPRINTERS SAID TO CHARGE BIAS
description: DAKAR, Senegal, Aug. 2 (AP)  Two black sprinters who left the United States track and field team that meets Africa this weekend reportedly have accused American officials of giving preferential treatment to their white; teammates.

title: FATHER TESTIFIES AT PATRICK TRIAL
description: A father who tried to res.; cue his son from the conservative New Testainent Missionary Fellowship testified yesterday that he had informed the State Attorney General's office about the planned attempt though not in detail  hours before it occurred and was wished good luck.

title: Red Sox Trounce Yanks, 100, as Moret Hurls 4Hitter and Cepeda, Fisk Homer
description: BOSTON, Aug. 2The New York Yankees, who threw lot of punches around Fen way Park yesterday, were absolutely punchless tonight as they absorbed a 100 mauling from the Boston Red Sox and left town in second place.

title: Refugees Back in Area North of Hue
description: HAI LANG, South Vietnam, July 28After more than a year as a refugee, a 62yearold farmer returned home today to the Street Without Joy.

title: Stage: Absurd Person Singular, a London Delight
description: LONDONYou used to be able to tell a country by its cuisinenow I suspect its humor might provide a safer guide. Much of the humor in London and New York is admittedly identical, and many people in both cities feel perfectly at home with whatever brand of AngloAmerican humor comes along. And yet there can be wide and deep differences.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The state grand jury in Trenton has indicted an Atlantic City detective on bribery charges in what law enforcement officials indicate may be the beginning of a major investigation of the police in the resort city. State law enforcement officials declined to comment on the scope of the investigation, but the state's Criminal Justice Director, Evan W. Jahos, said: The investigation is continuing.

title: Saratoga Vichy Cites Safety of Its Water
description: ALBANY, Aug. 2Alarmed about a 50 per cent drop in business following reports that water in five springs at the Saratoga Spa reservation contained radium levels exceeding Federal limits, the Saratoga Vichy Spring Company has begun a campaign to notify its customers about the source of Saratoga vichy.

title: BUNKER NOMINATED AS ENVOYATLARGE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UPI) Ellsworth Bunker, the former United States Ambassador to South Vietnam, was nominated by President Nixon today to be an ambassadoratlarge.

title: A BANKRUPTCY. STEP TAKEN BY BESTLINE
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Aug. 2 (AP)Bestline Products, a soap marketing concern reporting $100million in annual sales, has filed a petition for reorganization under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: A Station Owner, Angered by the I.R.S., Gives Away All His Gasoline
description: CROMWELL, Conn., Aug. 2 An angry station owner here finished giving away 4,000 gallons of gasoline to hardpressed consumers this afternoon to satisfy an Internal Revenue Service judgment that he had overcharged his customers $1,729 during the 60day price freeze by illegally raising his prices 2 cents a gallon.

title: SKYLAB TROUBLES SET OFF PLANNING FOR SPACE RESCUE
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 2Skylab 2 ran into further trouble today, with leaking steering rockets, and project officials ordered aroundtheclock preparations of a rescue ship that may have to be dispatched to bring the three astronauts back from the nation's first orbiting space station.

title: Excerpts From Testimony Before the Senate Committee Investigating Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2Following are excerpts from a transcript of testimony today by Richard Helms, Ambassador to Iran and former Director of Central Intelligence, on the 34th day of hearings on the Watergate case before the Senate Select Committee on Presidential Campaign Activities:

title: SENATE VOTES END TO PRICE FREEZE ON BEEF, 84 TO 5
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2The Senate voted, 84 to 5, today to end the freeze on beef prices immediately to avert shortages.

title: OTB to Open 112th Office
description: OTB will open its 112th branch office today in Staten Island, Howard Samuels, president and chairman of the New York City OffTrack Betting Corporation, said yesterday. The office will be located at 1410 Forest Avenue.

title: U. S. Promises Cambodia All Help Allowed by Law
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2The Nixon Administration said today that the Cambodian Government, faced by an end of all American bombing support on Aug. 15, would continue to get from the United States all the economic, military and diplomatic assistance still possible under the law.

title: Jack Lesser, President Of a Jersey Health Center
description: BROWNS MILLS, N.J., Aug. 2 (AP)Jack Lesser, president of the Deborah Heart and Lung Center here, died today at the Einstein Medical Center in Philadelphia. He was 71 years old and lived in Wyncote, Pa.

title: Hockey Transactions
description: CLEVELANDSlimed Billy Heindl, left wing, formerly with Rangers Providence farm club.

title: Satyajit Ray Finds A Freedom in Film
description: CALCUTTA, India  To American and European filmgoers, Indian movies mean Satyajit Ray. To most Indians, however, the director's delicately textured tapestries of Calcutta life and village families ??? odd and unsettling.

title: The For Life
description: Watkins Glen apart, Woodstock still has the magic name, and even Latin music is taking advantage of the vibrations. On Monday, Woodstock's Latin Festival takes placeat the Playhouse there although it is primarily an excuse to film one of New York's top Latin bands, Eddie Palmieri's orchestra.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: KANSAS CITYPlaced Paul Scheel, third baseman, on 15day disabled list; Recalled George Brett, third baseman, from Omaha farm club in the American Association.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J.When Elliott. Denman, the former New York University track captain and Olympic race walker, came here to live in 1960 he was disturbed by the lack of interest in track and field above the high school level.

title: South Side Blues Come to the East Side
description: South Side mainstream, the tough urban Chicago blues, arrived this week at Kenny's Castaways, East 84th Street, under the gentle patronage of Willie Dixon, bass player and composer of many classic Chicagostyle blues.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL FOOTBALL GOLF HARNESS RACING TENNIS THOROUGHBRED RACING

title: DR. L. NELSON BELL, CHURCH LEADER, 79
description: MONTREAT, N. J., Aug 2 (UPI)Dr. L. Nelson Bell, immediate past moderator of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S. and father  in  law of the Rev. Billy Graham, died in his sleep today a few hours after addressing a mission conference.

title: GERMANS ADMIT TAPPING FOR U.S
description: BONN, Aug. 2The West German Government reported today that it had tapped civilian telephone conversations in West Germany at the request of United States intelligence agencies.

title: First Store Opens at Big Mall on L.I.
description: MASSAPEQUA, L.I., Aug. 2  The first unit of a major regional shopping center opened here today when a 200,000squarefoot Gertz department store officially began doing business.

title: Weeden & Co. Omits A Quarterly Dividend
description: Weeden & Co., a leading securities firm, said yesterday it would omit its, regular 10 cents quarterly dividend ordinarily paid in September.

title: C.I.A. Study Said Ellsberg Viewed Action as Patriotic
description: WASHINGTON, Aug, 2The Central Intelligence Agency's initial psychological assessment of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg concluded that he was motivated by what he deemed a higher order of patriotism in turning over the Pentagon papers to the press in 1971.

title: Commonwealth's Leaders Meet in CrisisFr. Mood
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 2Government leaders from the 32 Commonwealtli countries, exhibiting a generally friendly mood today opened a nineday meeting that is scheduled to cover a broad range of social, economic and political issues.

title: Westinghouse Expands Unit
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yesterday plans for spending $1.7million to expand its color television picture tube production capabilities at its Elmira, N. Y., plant. Westinghouse recently completed a $3million expansion at the facility.

title: Rosetta Pampanini, Soprano In Italian Repertory, Dead
description: ROVIGO, Italy, Aug. 2 Rosetta Pampanini, a lyric soprano who won fame with her interpretations of Puccini and Mascagni, died this morning at her home in Corbola, about 20 miles from here. She was 72 years old.

title: Measure Allowing Regional Contracts Is Signed by Cahill
description: TRENTON, Aug. 2  Governor Cahill today signed al bill that permits local governmental units to enter into joint contracts for services.

title: Golf Tourney Shortened
description: SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Aug. 2The Women's New Jersey Golf Association's 54hole championship became a 36hole event today when rain washed out the scheduled second round. Officials decided that the round scheduled for tomorrow would be the final. Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood took the firstround lead yesterday with a 79 over Mrs. Edward Probert of Somerset Hills, who had an 80.

title: House Panel Backs Strict Curb on Strip Mining
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2  A large bipartisan majority on the House Interior Committee gave tentative approval today to a proposal to impose strict Federal environmental standards on the strip, or surface, mining of coal.

title: Records Show Key Kalmbach Role in Work on Nixon Estate Unrelated to Security
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2Records of public funds spent on President Nixon's estate at San Clemente, Calif., show that Herbert W. Kalmbach, Mr. Nixon's former personal attorney, played a controlling role in plans for renovating the home.

title: American Club in Bonn Will Not Accept Dollars
description: BONN, Aug. 2  The United States Embassy club will no longer accept dollars for dues, meals or drinks, club officials announced this week, carrying the dollar to what may be a new low.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Nixon Administration said that the United States would continue to give the Cambodian Government all the help it could after the American bombing stops on Aug. 15. Though the Administration was repertedly studying just what kind of assistance it could legally render under the bombing cutoff law, President Nixon has left open the possibility of calling a special session of Congress that would be held during the summer recess. I Page 1, Columns 67.1

title: Builder of The Wall
description: For Walter Ulbricht, to be a Communist was to be loyal to the Soviet Union and to develop the satellite state which calls itself the German Democratic Republic precisely along the lines Moscow desired, regardless of the moral and economic costs to the Germans involved.

title: A.B.C. TO TELEVISE TENNIS BATTLE
description: The American Broadcasting Company will televise the $100,000 winnertakeall tennis match between Bobby Riggs and Billie Jean King in prime evening viewing time Sept. 20 from the Houston Astrodome.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, Aug. 2 (UPI)America's entry in the fours with coxswain event at the world junior rowing championships was publicly lectured on sportsmanship today. The young men from Philadelphia's Vesper Boat Club, along with Coach Bob Madden, stood silence before spectators while the international federation president, Thomi Keller of Switzerland, accused them of making fools of their opponents.

title: Nixon: Progress on Japan
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2  President Nixon has made good progress in his meetings here with Premier Tanaka of Japan in removing the serious misunderstandings of the last couple of years in the relations between Washington and Tokyo.

title: West German's Talk Printed In East German Party Paper
description: BERLIN, Aug. 2The East German Communists today opened their party newspaper, Neues Deutschland, to a young West German politician and his call for more freedom of travel and the exchange of ideas and information.

title: Citizens Without Standing
description: I have been measuring the pile of briefs concerning the proposed transmission line from Gilboa in Schoharie County to Leeds near Catskill in Greene County. The pile of paper measures seven and onehalf inches; it weighs twelve pounds. It documents four years of public opposition to a 33mile transmission line on lattice towers that the Power Authority of the State of New York plans to build across the shoulder of Pisgah Mountain and through the Durham and Catskill valleys.

title: Basketball Transactions
description: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION NEW YORKSigned Henry Bibby, guard.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: A Treasury of Modern Mysteries (Doubleday, twovolume set, $8.95). Nineteen detective stories.

title: Books of The Times
description: Like a great Iron wrecker's ball, Prof. A. L. Rowse attacks the immense and ancient edifice of Shakespeare scholarship, which he sees as a sort of tourist trap, crudely tricked out by nearsighted bookworms. Crustily confident, snorting with impatience, too full of the excitement of his subject to be polite, he announces that he has just uncovered new facts that put out of court all other Shakespeare biographies, as well as all other editions of the Sonnets.

title: Anniversary Is Staged By a New Company Here
description: Bill Macllwraith's The Anniversary is a 1966 British play (in 1968 it was made into a Bette Davis horror movie) about a tyrannical mother and her three weakwilled sons, all of them allied in a successful, somewhat shady homeconstruction business.

title: JOSEPH HEALEY, 63, EXMAYOR OF KEARNY
description: KEARNY, N. J., Aug. 2Joseph M. Healey, who became the first Democratic Mayor in this town's history in 1949 and held the post for 20 years, died Tuesday of heart and blood disorders in West Hudson Hospital. His age was 63, and he lived here at 244 Forest Street.

title: HERBERT O. DAVENPORT
description: SPARTA, N. J., Aug. 2 Herbert G. Davenport, an architect who had been with Abraham & Straus, the Brooklyn department store, for the last 37 years, was among those killed in the jetliner crash at Boston's Logan Airport on Tuesday. He was 60 years old and lived at 64 Springbrook Trail.

title: PETER B. BADER
description: Peter B. Bader, a deputy associate general counsel of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, died yesterday of leukemia in New York Hospital. He was 30 years old and lived at 2245 Randall Avenue, the Bronx.

title: Abductors Said to Ask $1 Million for Getty Boy
description: ROME, Aug. 2  The kid flappers of J. Paul Getty 3d, 16yearold grandson of the American oil magnate, who mysteriously disappeared in Rome almost a month ago, have asked for a $17million ransom, the family lawyer here said tonight.

title: Court Backs Ehrlichman Lawyer's View
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2The theory that President Nixon had the right to authorize national security wiretaps without a warrant, raised in behalf of John D. Ehrlichman in the Senate Watergate hearings, has been endorsed in a Federal District Court ruling here.

title: Saigon Might Send Cambodia Troops if Asked
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 2 (UPI)  South Vietnam has no plans to intervene in the Cambodian fighting but may do so if Phnom Penh asks for help, a South Vietnam Government spokesman said today.

title: Station in Saigon Ends Coverage of Watergate
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 2 (AP)The AmericanRadio Service Vietnam has discontinued verbatim coverage of the Watergate hearings because listeners wanted to hear more music, a spokesman for the United Statesdefense attachs office said today.

title: Helms Says He Resisted Pressure by White House For C.I.A. CoverUp Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2The former head of the Central Intelligence Agency told the Senate Watergate committee today that he had to resist White House pressures in order to keep the agency clean of involvement in the Watergate coverup.

title: People and Business
description: Just two days after the Walter E. Heller International Corporation consummated its purchase of Chicago's American National Bank, the financial holding company announced sweeping changes in its leadership.

title: ISMAIL ABDUL RAHMAN
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Aug. 2 (UPI)Dr. Ismail bin Datuk Abdul Rahman, Minister of Home Affairs and acting Prime Minister, died tonight at his home in Jalan Maxwell, Government spokesman said. He was 57 years old.

title: Court Grants Boys a Stay On Fingerprinting Order
description: NEWARK, Aug. 2More than 40 eighth grade boys who had been ordered to be fingerprinted tomorrow in connection with a murder investigation won a stay of the order today in State Supreme Court.

title: HAROLD A. LEY 3D
description: Harold Alexander Ley 3d, leader in the travel industry, died Tuesday in the jetliner crash at Logan International Airport in Boston, in which 88 persons were killed. He was 34 years old and lived in Upper Montclair, N. J.

title: BEEF DEALERS GET ROLLBACK ORDERS
description: Internal Revenue Service agents, finding violations of price ceilings, have ordered onthespot rollbacks in more than half of the Manhattan and Bronx beefwholesaling establishments checked in compliance sweeps this week.

title: Saratoga Race Track
description: Today's Entries Roosevelt Results Monmouth Results Monmouth Entries Monmouth Jockeys

title: RECORDS OF I.T.T. DISCLOSE EFFORTS TO BAR TRUST SUIT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2Corporate documents that the White House feared would come to light last year disclose a wellorchestrated effort by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation to enlist the aid of top Administration officials in blocking an antitrust suit against the company's merger with the Hartford Fire Insurance Company.

title: BAN ON PHOSPHATES DECRIEDIN HARTFORD
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 2 (AP)The soap and detergent industry today urged the Connecticut Environmental Protection Department to avoid a total ban on phosphate detergents.

title: Skylab Scare
description: For several agonizing hours yesterday, it appeared that the Skylab 2 astronauts might be in more serious trouble than any American spacemen since the nervewracking flight around the moon of Apollo 13. Even though it finally proved unnecessary to order the three men back to earth immediately, two points did emerge with special clarity from this shortlived scare situation.

title: Secretariat's Popularity Puts N.Y.R.A. Chief on a Spot
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 2Jack Krumpe has been stallwalking for almost a month, in anticipation of the Whitney Stakes on Saturday. And after that he'll be stallwalking for at least two more weeks, waiting for the Travers on Aug. 18.

title: President at Camp David For a RestWork Weekend
description: CAMP DAVID, Md., Aug. 2 (AP)President Nixon flew by helicopter today to his mountaintop retreat here for a weekend of rest and work.

title: Dialogue With Japan
description: Although the communiqu summing up the talks between President Nixon and Premier Tanaka of Japan has the ambiguity usual in such documents, Mr. Tanaka's visit should help to establish a more healthy relationship between the two countries.

title: Television
description: Television

title: 5 Die as Floods Strike Towns in North; Roads, Power and Phone Service Cut
description: A torrential rainstorm killing at least five persons in the metropolitan area yesterday and forcing hundreds of families to leave their homes in dozens of towns in northern New Jersey.

title: A Different Kind of InnerCity Community
description: ST. LOUIS, July 31The players came back from the dusty softball field late in the afternoon and 50 or 100 neighbors joined them, drifting by twos and threes out of the apartments and houses into the open heat.

title: Currency Crosscurrents Hit Bank of China
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 2The Bank of China, which handles Peking's foreign currency transactions and recently established a correspondent relationship with the Chase Manhattan Bank, acted with uncharacteristic imprecision during the dollar crisis last month.

title: Major League Baseball

title: Tanaka, Visiting City, Asks Varied U. S.Japanese Ties

The shares sold represent 54 per cent of the outstanding stock.

title: Metropolitan Briefs

J., won a stay of the order in the New Jersey Supreme Court. The court also ruled that the Appellate Division immediately hear the appeal the order. A hearing has been scheduled for Tuesday.

title: THE HARLEM MEER BEINGREVITALIZED
description: This project is important to the East Harlem community, Mohammed Coner said as he watched the brigade of residents working to transform the old Harlem Meer boathouse yesterday.

description: A gallery of disarmingly original citizensshown at play, pursuing novel avocations and making music Makes up a rewarding documentary hour at 9 tonight over the Columbia Broadcasting System network.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The testimony given on July 24 and 25 by Mr. Ehrlichman and by his counsel, Mr. Wilson, suggesting that legislation on national security matters made legal the burglary of the offices of Daniel Ellsberg's psychiatrist is by far the most frightening, and enlightening, thing to come out of the Watergate hearings.

title: The Truman Way
description: VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass.In the, spring of 1950, having been commissioned to write a series of magazine articles on the President of the United States, I ask'd Mr. Truman's permission to walk with him for a few days, as it were,. through various chambers of the Presidencyto observe him in a number of official conferences, to see him through some hard decisions, perhaps also to watch him at ease away from his desk in the Oval Office, and so to picture him not simply as routine journalistic biographee but rather as a living and working President. He turned me down, saying that if he allowed me special access of that sort beyond the walls of the White House press room, he would have to afford it later to other reporters.

title: U.S. Export Bookings Up For Corn and Soybeans
description: The big news in the grain and soybean trade yesterday came after the close of the markets. It was then that the Government reported sharply nigher export bookings of American corn and soybeans and a slight dip in wheat sales. This closely watched weekly eport, which was due last Tuesday, showed that exports of corn booked as of July 13 totaled 920 million bushels, compared with 841 million registered the week before. Total exports of corn for all 1972 aggregated some 1.2 billion bushels of 56 pounds each.

title: Ladies Tearooms Are a Dying Breed
description: The restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Loans and Interest Rates Still Rising, Fed Reports
description: Business loans continued to expand and interest rates to soar during the week ended Wednesday, according to Federal Reserve figures, heightening the probability of yet another rise In the rates banks charge for loans.

title: RIKERS SUICIDE WHEN PUT IN JAIL
description: The youth who hanged himself in the Men's House of Detendon on Rikers Island Wednesday was disclosed yesterday to have been 15 years cld at the time of his arrest, too young; to have been sent to any stitutions of the city's Department of Correction.

title: Oilers Highlight of 72, Starring New York Jets
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 2  A friend of Richard Neal's has seen the Houston Oilers 1972 highlights film and there is no surprise ending.

title: Advertising. Tests on Cable TV
description: For some time the thinkers, dreamers and planners in cable television have been giving forth with seemingly bluesky concepts.

title: SALES RISE AGAIN FOR CHAIN STORES
description: Sales volume reported yesterday by the country's leading chain store organizations indicated a continuation of the substantial gains registered in June. The large chains showed increases over July of 1972 ranging from 11.7 per cent to 23.3 per cent.Sears, Roebuck & Co., the largest merchandising company in the country, reported sales of $1billion in July, an increase of 14.8 per cent compared with July of 1972. For the 26week period, Sear's volume, at $6.19billion, was 15.7 per cent over the level of sales in the 1972 period.

title: The Screen: Sun-Drenched 'Lady Ice':Donald Sutherland and Jennifer O'Neill Star Lot of Smiling, but Not Much Communicating
description: To put Jennifer O'Neill, Donald Sutherland, Robert Duvall and Patrick Magee into a movie and come up with nothing must take some kind of ability  though not the kind of ability you would search out too often at your neighborhood theater, which is where Tom Gries's "Lady Ice" has opened.Duvall, a Miami police inspector, merely walks through his part. Magee, a big-time Miami sports-car dealer, merely squeezes a few more drops of self-pitying rage  like something left over from his role in "A Clockwork Orange." As for Miss O'Neill, as Magee's daughter and Miami's most important trader in hot diamonds; and Donald Sutherland, as the happy-go-lucky insurance investigator who tracks her down  well, they mainly smile a lot and look very healthy. But the look of healthdewy tan for Miss O'Neill; blue-eyed bronze for Mr. Sutherland  might have been poured out of a bottle. So might everything else in "Lady Ice," which carries the American feature movie a bold step closer to the condition of a Florida orange-juice commercial.I'm not really opposed to synthetics, however, and every so often, when it gets far enough away from its characters, "Lady Ice" takes on the mute, appealing pathos of a travel poster. But when it gets close to its characterseven to the spectacularly beautiful Miss O'Neill  who talk without communicating and touch as if without ever making contact, it gives up everything to the development of a plot that makes no sense and the intimation of a lifestyle that you couldn't keep fresh even under Saran Wrap.Everything in the film leans to the conventionalthe sex, the violence, the thrills, the anger, the cool. Some nice conventional movies have been made in this way. But "Lady Ice" never discovers how the conventions live, only that they die, and so it becomes kind of a sun-drenched, breeze-swept, palm-laden, sea-sparkled reminder of lost delights and failed powers.

title: About the Mets:
description: Felix Milian, who has been the most consistent Met day after day, was voted Met player of the month for July. His 386 average for the month will earn him a watch from Tug McGraw's other employer, Clive Jewelers, which reports that McGraw's problems in the bull pen this year haven't affected his talent as a vice president. Millan's 18game hitting streak, which was halted in the second game of the doubleheader with Pittsburgh Wednesday night, has been surpassed only three times in Met history. Cleon Jones holds the record, 23 games, and Tommie Agee had strings of 20 and 19. When it comes to hitting, George Stone hasn't done a bad job himself. The pitcher has hit safely in nine of his 10 starts and his 11 hits and 367 batting average top all Met pitchers. Tom Seaver has 10 hits, but he's batted twice as many times as Stone and his average is 169.

title: Gulf & Western Adds Bulova Shares
description: Gulf & Western Industries, Inc. announced yesterday it had acquired 384,800 shares of the Bulova Watch Company, or slightly under 10 per cent of the 3,741,000 common shares outstanding of Bulova, in the open market in the last two years as strictly an investment.

title: U.S. Promises Cambodia All Help Allowed by Law
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2The Nixon Administration said today that the Cambodian Government, faced by an end of all American bombing support on Aug. 15, would continue to get from the United States all the economic, military and diplomatic assistance still possible under the law.

Howard Hunt Jr. regarding aid for a mission from the Central Intelligence Agency. Blanks apparently indicate incomprehensible sections.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2Despite the possibility of a Presidential veto, the Senate voted 62 to 28 today to increase the minimum wage to $2.20 an hour for most workers by next July 1.

description: The city's Corporation Counsel said yesterday that the administrator of the new state antinarcotics program had appealed privately to the police not to make too many arrests under the program to insure against flooding of present and new [court] parts.

title: Bridge: Greedy Doubles Are Inviting, But Almost Never Worth It

Unless they are seriously out of line they will not fail by more than matics of the situation are clearly against the doubler. Moreover, the double will sometimes help the declarer make his contract.

title: Notes on People
description: Mrs. Jill Ruckelshaus, a White House consultant, feminist activist, and wife of the former Environmental Protection Administrator, William D. Ruckelshaus, disclosed at a Washington luncheon how she first recognized discrimination against her as a woman: It occurred to me when I was 13 and wearing white gloves and Mary Janes and going to dancing school, that no one should have to dance backward all their lives.

description: MOSCOW, Aug. 2 (AP)The Soviet Union broke a long silence on Watergate today, declaring that former Government officials and White House staff members had sworn that President Nixon was blameless.

Last night, though, the Mets 51 victory over Pittsburgh at Shea Stadium revolved around two singles by Mays orie that bounced about 25 feet into the air and another that rolled about 30 feet along the ground.

title: WILLIAM SWINGLE, A TRADE OFFICIAL

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $886million, up 12 per cent from the yearearlier $794million, Total retail store sales were about $9.65billion, up 14 per cent from last year's $8.5billion.

title: Text of Study on Ellsberg
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 Following is the text of the Central Intelligence Agency's first psychological study of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg. It was prepared in early August, 1971, at the request of the White House In connection with its investigation of the disclosure of the Pentagon papers. This study was found unsatisfactory and a second was prepared.

title: Seizure of a Jetliner Used by a Smuggler Of Drugs Is Ordered
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn ordered the United States Attorney there yesterday to seize a DC8 jet airliner in which narcotics were smuggled from South America to Kennedy International Airport last spring. The prosecutor, however, said he would not act on the judge's orders until he received guidance from Washington.

title: DOLLAR IS MIXED IN SLOW TRADING
description: LONDON, Aug. 2 (UPI) The United States dollar fluctuated on European money markets today, making small movements as traders marked time. The price of gold generally fell.

title: Memorial for Rickenbacker
description: A memorial service for Capt. Eddie Rickenbacker, the World War I aviator and longtime executive of Eastern Airlines, will be held Tuesday at 2 P.M. in the Marble Collegiate Church, Fifth Avenue, at 29th Street. Floyd D. Hall, chairman and chief executive officer of Eastern Airlines, and Lowell Thomas, the explorer and news commentator, will speak. Captain Rickenbqcker died July 23 in Geneva at the age of 82.

title: G. MINOT D'ARCY
description: G. Minot D'Arcy, an investment counselor, was one of the 88 victims of the crash of a jet plane at Logan International Airport in Boston on Tuesday. He was 43 years old and lived in Bristol, N. H., and New Canaan, Conn.

title: Iranian Oil Find Reported
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 2 (AP) The National Iranian Oil Company officials announced today the discovery of a new major oil reserve at Maharlu Salt Lake in southern Iran. No statement was made about the size of the reserve, experts explained it would take some months before it, could be determined.

title: Atomic Plant Accused
description: SPOKANE, Wash., Aug. 2 (UPI)A court hearing will be held Aug. 20 on efforts by a conservationist organization to stop operations at a fuelprocessing plant at the Hanford, atomic works. The Natural Resources Defense Council filed suit yesterday against the Atomic Energy Commission, and Judge Marshall A. Neill scheduled the hearing. John E. Bryson, council attorney, said the A.E.C. had failed to file the required environmental impact statement and alleged violations of safety requirements in waste management.

title: Cambodia Refugees Flee What Was Once a Haven
description: KOKI, Cambodia, Aug. 2This market town was fast emptying today. By noon nearly all the houses were deserted and the shops shuttered and padlocked  the contents and residents on their way to relative safety in Phnom Penh, about 10 miles to the northwest. The handful of people left in town were packing as fast as they could.

title: Police, in a Shift of Policy, Drop Award for Shooting
description: In a historic change of emphasis, the Police Department from now on will present a plaque and a $100 scholarship award for academic achievement to Police Academy graduates and eliminate the traditional marksmenship award of a revolver.

title: RIFLE SQUAD GUARDS OKLAHOMA RIOTERS
description: McALESTER, Okla., Aug, 2 (UPI)  Sharpshooters with rifles stood on rooftops and in guard towers today at the Oklahoma State Penitentiary with orders to kill if necessary to prevent further bloodshed among 750 rebel prisoners in the yard below.

title: Senate Passes Increase In Pensions for Veterans
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) The Senate passed and sent back to the House today a bill that would provide a 10 per cent costofliving pension crease for elderly veterans and their widows.

title: 2 SPRINTERS SAID TO CHARGE BIAS
description: DAKAR, Senegal, Aug. 2 (AP)  Two black sprinters who left the United States track and field team that meets Africa this weekend reportedly have accused American officials of giving preferential treatment to their white teammates.

title: Suit Filed Against City in Hiring of Phony Doctor
description: Four young women who say (they were assaulted by a man posing as a gynecologist at two of the city's familyplanning clinics filed claims against the city yesterday for damages totaling $50million on behalf of themselves and all other women  as many as 40  whom the nan examined.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 2 The Standard Oil Company of California is appealing to its employes and stockholders to foster the aspirations of the Arab people and their efforts toward peace in the Middie East.

title: I.B.M. GAINS STAY IN CONTEMPT CASE
description: A daily $150,000 fine against, the International Business Machines Corporation was blocked temporarily yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals.

title: Area Fishing Outlook
description: Operators of fishing stations from Sandy Hook to Cape May yesterday were wondering what had happened to the bluefish. Few hungry choppers were being taken along the New Jersey coast. What happened to them? They have headed north and are now being found in quantity anywhere from Long Island Points to the more popular retreats off the Connecticut shore. Off Montauk Point, the word was that they were being seen by the acres as far out as 20 miles.

title: Convict Thanks Judge for 3Year Drug Sentence
description: An inmate in a state prison has written a letter to the judge who sentenced him to three years for selling and using drugsand has thanked the judge.

description: NORTH PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 2  Green Brook, swollen by heavy rains, overflowed its banks here today, leaving four persons dead, 80 families in temporary shelters after removal from their homes, several hundred automobiles destroyed or damaged and private and business property losses put at at least $2million.

The young men from Philadelphia's Vesper Boat Club, along with Coach Bob Madden, stood in silence before spectators while the international federation president, Thomi Keller of Switzerland, accused them of making fools of their opponents.

title: Red Smith

That afternoon the Major's Yankees tried and failed to squeeze the winning run home in the ninth inning, ran their wonlost record with the Red Sox to 310, lost first place the American League East and got no better than a draw a rumble joined by all uniformed personnel on the premises.

title: Mr. Nixon, the Tapes, and Common Sense
description: NEW HAVEN Mr. Nixon is dead right in refusing compliance with subpoenas, whether issued by a committee of the Senate, by a grand jury, or by any other authority, commanding the production of written or taped records of consultations held by him as President. I think this refusal is not only his lawful privilege but his duty as well, for it is a measure necessary to the protection of the proper conduct of his office, not only by him but, much more importantly, by his successors for all time to come.

description: Strong and generally unexpected demand for the new Treasury 7 per cent bonds ignited a furious rally in Government and corporate bonds yesterday, one of the most hectic sessions in years, traders declared.

title: GEORGE W. DAVIS

Colson, the former special counsel to the President, instructed another member of the White House staff to ask the Internal Revenue Service for the names of contributors to the National Council of Senior Citizens, according to a deposition filed today in United District Court here.

title: American Standard Quarter Profit Rises 41% as Sales Gain 12%
description: American Standard, Inc., realized a 41 per cent increase in secondquarter earnings on a sales gain of 12 per cent, making the halfyear profit 70 per cent greater and sales 10 per cent ahead of last year, the diversified plumbing, construction and industrial products manufacturer reported here yesterday.

title: 58 Due at Nonaligned Talks
description: PARIS, Aug. 2 (UPI) The governments of 58 countries have agreed to attend a conference of nonaligned nations in Algiers from Aug. 28 to Sept. 3, an Algerian Embassy spokesman said today. The last such meeting, attended by 29 African and Asian nations, was held at Bandung, Indonesia, in 11.55.

description: Stock prices declined yesterday for the fourth successive day, but reduced their losses in the final 90 minutes as volume remained modest on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: An Escaped Convict, Held in Shoplifting, Released by Judge
description: A man arrested on a shoplifting charge and released without bail by Judge Bruce Wright of Bronx Criminal Court was discovered yesterday to be an escaped convict, a heroin seller and a bail juniper.

description: Frank ("Funzi") Tieri, the 69yearold reputed acting boss of one of New York's five Mafia organizations, was arrested on loansharking charges yesterday for the second time in the last six months.

title: Cynthia R. Rossbach, an Artist, Wed to James Flood Stebbins
description: In the Dana Chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church here yesterday afternoon, Miss Cynthia Richards Rossbach, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Rossbach of New York, became the bride of James Flood Stebbins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore E. Stebbins of Syosset, L. I.

title: Women Soothsayers: The Vietnamese Want to Know Their Fate
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam  In the crowded side entrance of one of Saigon's pagodas, the Minh Huong, a woman with a black birthmark on her right cheek sits telling fortunes.

title: C.I.A. Study Said Ellsberg Viewed Action as Patriotic
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2The Central Intelligence Agency's initial psychological assessment of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg concluded that he was motivated by what he deemed a higher order of patriotism in turning over the Pentagon papers to the press in 1971.

title: Roundup: Orioles Slip on Perry Pitches
description: Gaylord Perry of the Cleveland Indians could be called the Houdini of the major leagues. The famed magician was noted for his underwater escapes from a glass tank, though he was handcuffed and shackled in chains and irons.

title: OKKER, RIESSEN UPSET IN TENNIS
description: LOUISVILLE, Aug. 2 (AP) Secondseeded Tom Okker and fifthseeded Marty Riessen were upset today in the third round of the Pro Tennis Classic.

title: Roller Derby Star Drowns
description: CANOGA PARK, Calif., Aug. 2 (UPI)Shirley Hardman, 34 years old, manager of the Los Angeles Thunderbirds roller derby team and a skating star with the team for 13 years, drowned in her swimming pool yesterday. The police said she had been floating on a raft in the pool during a party.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., Aug. 2 (AP)Local lawmakers are preparing a 120day ban on large musical concerts in Schuyler County, a measure designed to head off a repeat of the massive Summer Jam rock festival.

title: Meany, Citing Disillusionment, Will Not Invite Nixon to Speak
description: OAK BROOK, Ill. Aug. 2George Meany, who remained neutral in the 1972 Presidential campaign, emphasized today his dissatisfaction and disilluSionment with President Nixon and the performance of the Republican Administration.

title: 30 Killed as Flash Fire Sweeps A Packed Resort on Isle of Man
description: DOUGLAS, Isle of Man, Friday, Aug. 3 (Reuters)At least 30 persons, many of them children, died last night when a flash fire swept a packed, multistory entertainment center on this British holiday island.

title: MILITARY OPPOSES DRAFT EVADER PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UPI)  The armed forces have strongly opposed a Justice Department proposal to save draft evaders from jail by allowing them to join the services, Administration sources said today.

title: Man Seized on Possession Of 5,000 Marijuana Plants
description: LOCKPORT, N.Y., Aug. 2 (AP)  The Niagara County sheriff's narcotics officers arrested a Royalton man Tuesday and accused him of growing an estimated total of 5,000 marijuana plants on his property:

title: LARRY GORE, SATIRIST AND PRESS AGENT, 50
description: Larry Gore, satirist, publicity man, contributor to Mad magazine and author of Larry Gore's Thing in Newsday from 1967 to 1972, died Wednesday of a heart attack after surgery, in London. He was 50 years old and lived at 6 Manor Lane, Woodmere, L. I.

title: RALPH HOWER, 69, OF HARVARD, DIES
description: BOSTON, Aug. 3  Dr. Ralph Merle Hower, emeritus professor of business administration at the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administra tion, died Wednesday. He was 69 years old and lived in Weston.

title: Back to Kent State
description: August 1971 was the heyday of the plumbers, that undercover Presidential brigade dispatched to deal with enemies of the White House. Two agents named E. Howard Hunt and G. Gordon Liddy had just come on board. With a couple of forged diplomatic cables to their credit, the plumbers were busily laying final plans for a burglary at the office of a psychiatrist in hopes of getting the goods on someone they thought had leaked confidential documents.

description: Table for High Tide for Water Adjacent to New York

title: ARGENTINE SENATE ACTS ON U.S. AIDE
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 3 The Argentine Senate unanimously adopted a resolution to day calling on the Government to consider expelling the United States Embassy's charg d'affaires, Max V. Krebs, for releasing documents critical of economic legislative bills.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: OAKLANDOptioned Jay Johnstone, outfielder, and Rich Mcatney, infielder, to lucson of Pacific Coast League.

title: Sales of Big Stores Show Only Minor Gains for July
description: New York department stores last month achieved only minor gains both in their branches within the city and those operating in the suburbs, a survey by The New York Times showed yesterday.

title: Malt Liquor Is Dropped
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 3 (UPI)AnheuserBusch, Inc., said today it would cease sale and production of Budweiser maltliquor effective Aug. 17 because of a recent labor disturbance and certain liquid supply shortages, The company said the decision was necessary in order to protect its beer brands and to avoid undue dilution of sales efforts.

title: Sports News Briefs.
description: SPRINGFIELD, N. J., Aug. 3  The Women's New Jersey Golf Association's 54hole strokeplay championship was washed out again today. It was rescheduled for later this month at the Baltusrol Golf Club. The second round will be played Aug. 27 and the third on Aug. 29. Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood, with a 79, took the firstround lead Wednesday in her bid for a sixth title.

title: $22Million in Tax Liens Filed Against Nixon Friend
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 3 (AP) C. Arnholt Smith, a confidant of President Nixon, was assessed nearly $22.9million in back taxes and interest today by the Internal Revenue Service.

title: House Unit Delays Nixon's Trade Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) The House Ways and Means Committee has recessed its sessions on President Nixon's trade bill until September, formally acknowledging there is no chance of completing the measure until after Congress's summer recess.

title: MAX I. ALIMANSKY

description: CAZENOVIA, N. Y.The other day, Mrs. William Davis of the Cazenovia Garden Club sent a letter to The Cazenovia Republican, the weekly newspaper here, in which she wrote:

title: 9 Cars Derail Near Buffalo
description: BUFFALO, Aug. 3 (UPI) Nine cars of a 27car Penn Central Railroad freight train derailed at the Vermont Hill Road crossing in the Buffalo  area town of Holland early today. No injuries were reported. About 500 feet of track were torn up in the incident, deputies said.

title: The Riviera Thin Is to See and Be Seen (if the Crowd Permits)
description: ST.TROPEZ, France, July 29This is the time of year when Frenchmen taking August holidays talk about prices and vacations and sex and vacations and traffic and vacations and food and vacations.

title: Tests Give Space Officials Hope For Complete Skylab 2 Mission
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 3  The crisis atmosphere at Mission Control eased today as tests showed that Skylab 2's Apollo ferry vehicle should be able to return the astronauts safely to earth with only two of the four sets of steering rockets in operation.

title: FloodTip Booklet Available
description: TRENTON, Aug. 2 (AP)  A Federal booklet giving homeowners information on what to do when returning to stormdamaged homes is being distributed in floodravaged areas in Central Jersey. Single copies are also available from the New Jersey Division of Civil DefenseDisaster Control, Eggerts Crossing Road, Box 979, Trenton, N. J. 08625.

title: VIETCONG DENOUNCE CANADA TRUCE ROLE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 3 (UPI)  The Vietcong Foreign Ministry has charged that Canada's delegation to the International Commission of Control and Supervision acted as a cover for United States truce violations in Vietnam, Hanoi's Vietnam News Agency said today in a broadcast monitored here.

title: Football Transactions
description: LOS ANGELESAcquired Greg Slough, line backer, from Minnesota for 1974 draft choice.

title: 2 UNITS ASK DROPPING OF ATTICA CHARGES
description: BUFFALO, Aug. 3 (AP)Two black civilrights groups in Buffalo and in Rochester, have demanded the dismissal of all charges against the men accused of committing crimes Wring the 1971 rebellion at Attica state correctional facility.

title: JOBLESS RATE OFF TO A 3YEAR LOW
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3Unemployment in the nation dropped last month to the lowest rate in more than three years, the Government said today.

title: Byron Dexter, 72, Editor Of Foreign Affairs, Dies
description: SOUTH WOODSTOCK, Vt, Aug. 3Byron Dexter, former managing editor of the quarterly Foreign Affairs, died at his home here last evening. He was 72 years old.

title: Church Council Aide Defends Zealous Faith Group
description: An official of the National Council of Churches testified in Manhattan Criminal Court yesterday that there was nothling bizarre about the conservative New Testament Missionary Fellowship and that such groups were important for certain people who might otherwise turn to drugs, or alcohol.

title: With All My Love, (Signed) Mama
description: LONDONIf I had written a piece a few years ago declaring that children were my greatest pleasure, many people would have assumed that I was simply being polite, dutiful, womanly and deceitful. Now, thank goodness, I may well be considered grossly irreponsible and wicked, and may therefore be believed. I have been accused several times in recent years of encouraging others irresponsibly to reproduce, and would like to make it clear that such is not here my intention. I am well aware that recommending other people to have babies may be as dangerous as recommending that they take up other unrespectable antisocial habits like drinking, buying new fast cars, smoking or property speculation. All these pleasures are bad for the environment in one way or anotherdrinking least so, but even drinking produces nonreturnable bottles. And babies are certainly bad for the environment. They, too, are nonreturnable.

title: But July Car Totals Fail to Penetrate Million Mark
description: DETROIT, Aug. 3Newcar sales in July were at record levels, but for the first time in five months they did not top the millionunit mark.

title: Great Dane Named Best At Perkiomen Dog Show
description: GILBERTSVILLE, Pa., Aug. 3 The form ran true at the silver anniversary show of the Perkiomen Valley Kennel Club today, when Dr. and Mrs. James A. Gribbin's Great Dane, Ch. Heidere's Kolyer Kimbayh, from Trenton, was named best in a field of 1,195 dogs on the grounds of the Chukker Valley Polo Club.
