title: Dean's Grandfather Dies
description: MARTINSBURG, W. Va., Aug. 3 (UPI) John Wesley Dean, grandfather of the for mer White House counsel, John W, Dean 3d died yesterday at a Charles Town nursing home, He was 90 years old, a lifelong resident of Martinsburg and had been a merchant and in surance executive before his retirement in 1959.

title: Improved Auto Ignition System Is Devised
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3The Chrysler Corporation received a patent this week for its electronic ignition controller, and put the equipment on display as part of a monthlong industrial exhibit at the Patent Office. Chrysler regards the invention as an automotive breakthrough because of its low cost and availability as standard equipment. Already installed in all 1973 Chrysler models, it is said to reduce engine misfiring and maintenance expense.

title: Bloodhounds Lose the Scent Of Suspect in Upstate Murder
description: WELLS, N: Y., Aug. 3State police bloodhounds picked up the fresh scent of Robert Garrow Sr, early this morning and followed the fugitive's trail through the dense woods for about a mile and a half, finally losing it in a creek near the Sacandaga River.

title: Justice Department Petitioned To Seal Computer Crime Files
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. (AP)  A coalition of Congressmen and lawyers demanded today that the Justice Department seal its computer files on criminal offenders until it can impose new restrictions to protect individual rights.

description: Deaths

title: WINE TALK
description: James Campbell, an English writer, would like to see his countrymen drink their way to good health. Taking note of various plans to reorganize Britain's National Health Service, he rejects them all and offers his own instead.

title: Death Toll at 46 in Isle of Man Fire
description: DOUGLAS, Isle of Man, Aug. 3 (Reuters)The death toll in the Isle of Man amusement center fire climbed to 46 tonight as five more bodies were found in the burnedout shell of the building.

title: Franklin N. Y. Sets Offering.
description: Franklin New York Corporation yesterday filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering an offering to stockholders of rights to subscribe to 1,320,099 additional common shares. The offering will entitle stockholders to one right for each share held, and three and onehalf rights will be required to purchase one new share.

title: Fire to Delay Ship's Sailing
description: An engine room fire, caused by a faulty connection admitting fuel into one of her boilers, was quickly extinguished yesterday morning aboard the 455foot naval cargo ship Victoria at her berth at Pier 46, in the Erie Basin area of Brooklyn. The fire, which started at 7:37 A.M. and was declared under control at 8:09 A.M. Damage caused by the fire is expected to delay the ship's sailing for about two weeks.

title: Park Concert Is Better If Grumbling Stomach Is Pleasantly Silenced
description: Chicken and Wine end, place in a pan with cold water and heat slowly to simmering or have the eggs at room temperature and use warm water. Drain off hot water and place under cold running water. When cool enough to handle crackle the shell all over by gently rolling the egg back and forth and peel starting at the wide end.

title: HIM. IS ORDERED TO RELEASE FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI) Federal judge ordered the (Health, Education and Welfare Department today to release more than $52million in impounded funds intended to establish community mental health centers. He said that the impoundment was unconstitutional.

title: NIXON PROPOSES MAJOR CHANGES IN BANK SYSTEM
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3President Nixon proposed to Congress today legislation that would eventually bring major changes to the nation's banks, and savings institutions and could lead to higher interest rates on consumer savings.

title: Pension Hodgepodge
description: The task of rationalizing the crazyquilt of pension protection that now covers public employes in this state has been left unfinished by the State Legislature. The revisions put through by the special session under Governor Rockefeller's whip play one unionized group against another in such cynical fashion that the courts may well upset them as capricious.

title: GUNMAN IS DEFIED BY GRANDMOTHER

description: President Nixon appointed 14 members to the Commission on Financial Structure and Regulation June 16, 1970, and asked the new body to improve the functioning of the private financial system.

title: Getting To Know Anyone
description: LA JOLLA, CalifIntimacy is a declining national resource. We don't grow up together as we once did, and we change addresses so often that really knowing another person, and being known, is nearly impossible.

title: BURNS INSISTENT ON FISCAL CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, stuck today to his view that additional restraints should be put on the economy if inflation is to be stopped and foreign confidence in the dollar restored.

title: Bay State Governor Vetoes Bill Allowing School Prayer
description: BOSTON, Aug. 3 (AP)Gov. Francis W. Sargent vetoed legislation today that authorized silent prayers in public schools. Attorney General Robert H. Quinn ruled yesterday that the measure was unconstitutional.

title: F.C.C. STAFF BACKS CHANGE AT WPIX
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3The staff of the Federal Communications Commission recommended today that the present operators of television station WPIX in New York City be denied a renewal of their license.

description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 3John Phillips, rock musician, filed a $21million civil suit in Los Angeles Superior Court today charging Dunhill Records, a subsidiary of the American Broadcasting Company, with fraud and breach of contract.

title: NIXON PROPOSES MAJOR CHANGES IN BANK SYSTEM
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3President Nixon proposed to Congress today legislation that would eventually bring major changes to the nation's banks and savings institutions and could lead to higher interest rates on consumer savings.

title: A Dedicated Deputy of the C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3An angry, jeering mob surrounded the limousine, beating on the roof and chanting antiAmerican slogans, Inside the car that hot May afternoon in Caracas 15 years ago was Richard M, Nixon, Vice President of the United States, who was on a good will tour of Latin America. Sitting in the front seat was an American Army colonel, Dick Walters, who was serving as his interpreter. Recalling his harrowing experience four years later, Mr. Nixon wrote in his hook Six Crises: One of the ringleadersa typical tough thugstarted to bash in the window next to me with a big iron pipe. The shatterproof glass did not break, but it splattered into the car. Walters got a mouthful, and I thought for an instant, There goes my interpreter.

title: ExAstronaut Gets Post
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 3 (AP) David R. Scott, a former astronaut, who was commander of the Apollo 15 lunar mission, has been named deputy director of the space agency's flight research center at Edwards, Calif. Mr. Mr Scott, 41 years old, will i assume the new position I later this month, space officials said.

description: She was having a chicken sandwich. I was gonna have a drink. I heard this loud explosion. Mamma, I think the subway just exploded, said.

title: Builder Loses Bribe Appeal
description: TRENTON, Aug. 3 (UPI)  A state appeals court today upheld the bribery conviction and prison sentence of Michael J. Stavola of Middletown Township, a contractor, and an associate in an alleged attempt to fix an assault case. Stavola, an executive of Trap Rock Industries, and an employe, Joseph Martinelli, were convicted of trying to persuate a state police detective to settle a charge of assault and battery on a policeman lodged against Stavola in Monmouth County in 1970.

title: Gorman Tops Fillol After 32Game Set
description: NORTH LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 3 (AP)Tom Gorman of Seattle broke the service of Jaime Fillol of Chile in the 32d game of the first set and defeated Fillol in the American Zone Davis Cup finals, 1715, 64, 46, 63. His victory gave the United States a 1.0 lead.

title: DOCTOR AND NURSE FOUND MURDERED
description: JERSEY CITY, Aug. 3  A 55yearold physician was found bludgeoned to death and his 21yearold nurse strangled in his office here yesterday. The police said robbery was the apparent motive in the double murder, even though the killer overlooked some $600 hidden in the doctor's sock.

description: A Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday and accused of terrorizing and shaking down the families of ChineseAmericans in Queens and Brooklyn. He usually demanded $500 payments of his victims, the police said.

description: The Xerox Corporation said yesterday it has filed new patent infringement action against the International Business Machines Corporation in this country and Canada. The new complaints involve I.B.M.'s Copier II.

But this weekend and next, you'll be able to go there and buy pottery, candles, jewelry, edibles, textiles, much of it right from the curbside creator to you, from 150 exhibitors who will line Fulton between Water and South Streets (on the East River), flowing over into the side streets too.

description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 3 (Reuters)United States Air Force liaison flights ??? Saigon and Hanoi resumed today after a seven week halt caused by the refusal of North Vietnam and Vietcong officials to sign flightsafety documents.American sources in Saigon said the four sides on the Joint Military Commissionthe United States, the Vietcong, the South Vietnamese and the North Vietnamesehad agreed to read and sign a receipt for a copy of the standard United States Air Force flightsafety regulations, a move that would cover all liaison flights.

title: Residents Start Cleanup, Recall Rapidity of Flood

description: HOUSTON, Aug. 3With the help of three field goals by Bobby Howfield, their Britishborn, soccerstyle kicker, the New York Jets managed to turn back a determined Houston Oiler team, 1613, before any Astrodome crowd of 45,775 to night in the first preseason football game for both teams.

title: U.S. Computers May Run Soviet Plant
description: NABEREZHNYE CHELNY, U. S. S. R.Soviet officials expect an American company to be chosen to install a computerized management and automated control system for what will be the world's largest truck factory, under construction here as the main crash project in the current Soviet fiveyear plan.

title: New Push On for Phnom Penh; Infiltrators Are Hunted in City

title: Commodity Price Index Up 6.4 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 195.1 from 188.7 last week.

title: Notes on People
description: The Rev. Pedro Arrupe, the Superior General of the Society of Jesus, will become one of the highestranking Roman Catholic officials to visit Cuba during the Castro years when he goes there this month. In Rome, Father Arrupe's purpose in visiting Cuba was said to be to make contact with the 27 Jesuit priests on the island. There was speculation that he might also confer with Government officials. Two years ago, Father Arrupe was the first Jesuit official to visit the Soviet Union.

title: NATHANIEL COLEMAN
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., Aug. 3 (UPI)Nathaniel T. Coleman, a soil and plant nutrition expert, died Wednesday apparently of a heart attack. He was 53 years old.

title: Indians Obtain Sanders
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 3 (UPI) The Minnesota Twins sold a reliever, Ken Sanders, who had the highest earnedrun average on their pitching staff, to the Cleveland Indians on waivers today. Sanders, a right hander, had a 24 wonlost record and eight saves in 27 appearances.

title: Prime Rate Raised To New High of 9% By 3 Major Banks
description: Three major banks, led by the Franklin National Bank, yestoltday raised the interest rate they charge on loans to big corporations to 9 per cent highest on recordeffective Monday.

title: Laotian Solution?
description: An American correspondent in Laos last spring described a battle in which Laotian Government and Communist Pathet Lao forces exchanged automaticweapons fire furiously for five hours. When it was all over, it was discovered that the only casualties were two cows that had strayed into the battle area. They didn't intend kill us, explained one Government veteran, So why should we kill them?

title: People and Business
description: Leon J. Levitz, 58 years old, who resigned under fire as president of the Levitz Furniture Corporation in June, 1972, and left as a director three months later, has returned to the board of the company. Gary Levitz, his son, who also left his directorship at the furniturewarehouse chain last September, was also renamed to the board.

title: The Latest Word On Poor Spellers
description: A problem of today's youth, some of their critics are convinced, is that they don't know a which from a witch. There has been an outpouring of complaints from employers, teachers and parents about the spelling habits of teen agers and young adults.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: SPRINGFIELD, N. J., Aug. 3  The Women's New Jersey Golf Association's 54hole strokeplay championship was washed out again today. It was rescheduled for later this month at the Baltusrol Golf Club. The second round will be played Aug. 27 and the third on Aug. 29. Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood, with a 79, took the firstround lead Wednesday in her bid for a sixth title.

title: TV's Late Show Tonight: Sneak Preview of Giants
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 3Another exhibition season be gins for the New York Giants here tomorrow night, with fewer question marks than usual. Since the home folks will be able to see it live on television at 11 P.M. in New York (Channel 2), a natural question arises: What can one look for in the first of six exhibition games, to be followed by 14 regularseason games, to be followed, the Giants hope fervently, by as many as three playoff games?

title: Screen: Undersea Tale: Neptune Factor' Opens at Neighborhoods
description: With the subtitle "An Undersea Odyssey" and with a musical score that sounds as if it might have been written by a brother-in-law of Richard Strauss's chambermaid, "The Neptune Factor" isn't exactly shy about claiming its parentage. Like many other claims of parentage, this one should be taken with a grain of salt.What "The Neptune Factor" is really about is a search and rescue mission to save three aquanauts trapped by an undersea earthquake on the ocean floor somewhere off the coast of Nova Scotia. Down, down the rescuers descend  Ben Gazzara, Yvette Mimieux, Ernest Borgnine and Donnelly Rhodes  led by the faintest ray of hope (and rather forcibly pushed by Miss Mimieux, who plans to marry one of the aquanauts), until at last. . . .Until at last they plumb the nethermost ocean depths and enter what I do believe is an oversized tabletop aquarium. Gargantuan goldfish, enormous sea horses, earth-shaking lobsters, man-eating softshell crabs  from every side the terrors of the sea approach them, torment their submersible craft, the Neptune, until at last. . . .Until at last  they either find their colleagues, or they don't. Anyone willing to sit through 90 minutes of this in order to find out probably does not really know and shouldn't have his suspense ruined. My own pleasure in "The Neptune Factor" begins and ends with the miniature photography  as nutty as anything I've seen in recent movies  and with the eliciting from Ben Gazzara, as the steely leader of the mission, Comdr. Adrian Blake of Atlanta, what may be filmdom's most confidently unconvincing Southern accent.Directed by Daniel Petrie, "The Neptune Factor" is largely the work of Canadian film makers. It opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: One man was critically hurt and four other persons suffered minor injuries yesterday when an explosion collapsed a twoandahalfstory frame house at 619 East Third Street in Plainfield. The explosion at 7:15 A.M. blew out the side walls of the building, and the roof and upper level fell straight down before pitching forward onto a porch.

description: ATHENS, Aug. 3The Greek Government freed three prominent political prisoners today but took action against politicians and newspapers openly asserting that Sunday's constitutional referendum was rigged.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3The Justice Department reopened today its investigation of the shootings at Kent State University on May 4, 1970, in which Ohio National Guardsmen killed four students and wounded nine others during a campus protest against expansion of the Vietnam war into Cambodia.

title: Election Finance Reform: Idea Whose TirneCame
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3One of the mysteries about the cyclical history of reform is: Why now? Why, for example, when a number of cogent ideas on reforming the American electoral system have been kicking aroundand flopping regularlyfor threequarters of a century should anyone seriously believe they are about to have a great revival? The answer, of course, is Watergate. But only indirectly. Few, if any, of the campaign finance reforms that passed the Senate on Monday, for example, would have had a direct bearing or a deterring effect on the Watergatestyle horrors that have come to light so far, assuming the Senate version of a strong new campaign spending bill had become law long ago.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI) A Federal judge upheld today the legality of the Nixon Administration's transfer of several programs from the Offic of Economic Opportunity to other Federal agencies.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Five Coast Guard enlisted men were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of conspiring to murder a Coast Guard intelligence agent who was investigating drug dealings in the service. The five, who have been held in $50,000 bail, were accused in a twocount indictment of trying to arrange the murder of the special agent, Dennis Morgan. The F.B.I. said on July 25 that a $100 advance payment was made to an F.B.I. undercover agent who had posed as a professional assassin the day before. If convicted the five could receive prison sentences of up to 21 years and $5,000 fines.

title: Tests Give Space Officials Hope For Complete Skylab 2 Mission

But, knowledgeable sources here say, an officer appropriated the chickens, sold them in the market and used the money for a party for fellow officers.

Y., Aug. 3 (AP) An Army reservist in training at nearby Camp Drum was injured fatally early today when his military pickup truck and an automobile collided at an itersection off the military reservation. title: Secretariat Aims Today For MillionDollar Mark
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 3  Secretariat goes tomorrow, and some 30,000 persons will be out to see him run. He will compete in the Whitney, at 1 miles for 3yearolds and upward, and the Meadow Stable star, the winner of the Triple Crown this year, will be 1 to 20 to finish first in the field of six. There will be win betting only. Described as fast and fit by his trainer, Lucian Laurin, Secretariat is expected to have no trouble against his rivals, despite the fact that four of them are older than he is. The winner's share of the gross purse of $54,100 will be $34,460 and Secretariat, should be register the expected victory, will lift his earnings over $1million. The Whitney marks the first time in his career that Secretariat opposes older horses.

title: In the Summer, West Yellowstone Exists for the Tourists
description: WEST YELLOWSTONE, Mont., July 31Most of the time there are no more than 700 persons in this 640acre town in southwestern Montana. In fact, most of the time the townspeople are well outnumbered by the coyotes and bears that roam the surrounding pine forests or inspect the local garbage cans. But suddenly each summer, at if on a signal from some colossal travel agent, 2,500,000 people drop in to West Yellowstone for a visit.

title: Douglas Hears Cambodian Case And Promises a Decision Soon

title: Cambodian Debacle
description: President Nixon grossly distorts the facts when he accuses Congress of abandonment of a friend because it ordered funds for United. States bombing in Cambodia cut off after Aug. 15. The President himself acquiesced in that cutoff date. Indeed, when it was set in late June, he sent a message to Congress praising the legislators cooperative spirit in putting off for six weeks the deadline for an end to military action throughout Indochina.

title: Bridge:
description: Opportunities are often missed to make a suicide playone that sacrifices an important honor to tie up the declarer's communications. A fine example of an opportunoty occurred in the recent summer nationals in Washington, and the hero was Leonard Harmon of New York, one of the country's greatest players.

title: Shell Canada Lifts Price

Similar price increases were announced earlier by Imperial Oil, Ltd.

title: Summer Jam 1973
description: There were reported to be 600,000 people at the Summer Jam in Watkins Glen last weekend. It is a metaphysical number, of course. Nobody counted the hordes of young people that descended upon that tiny town, created historic traffic jams, heard the music, and then finally departed in all directions. Relative magnitude is what counts in these matters, so one may take it for granted that Watkins Glen in 1973 attracted more visitors many morethan the Woodstock festival of four years ago. By all accounts Watkins Glen was a more peaceful scene than Woodstock. Its promoters had also prepared more adequately for the human avalanche than did those responsible for the 1969 original.

title: Weiskopf, as Usual, Leads by 3 Strokes
description: HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 3 Tom Weiskopf is leading again. The $250,000 Westchester golf classic began today under cloudy skies following yesterday's firstround rainout and Weiskopf lost little time in asserting himself this afternoon with an eightunderpar 64 for a threestroke lead.

title: Cahill Seeks U.S. Disaster Aid In Flood That Killed 6 Persons
description: TRENTON, Aug. 3Governor Cahill asked President Nixon to declare six New Jersey counties a disaster area today as Raritan Valley residents turned to the dreary business of mopping up after the flash floods that left six dead, possibly three missing and millions of dollars of property damage.

title: LENA V. OVESEN, 72, OF COMMUNITY UNIT
description: Lena V. Ovesen, who retired as director of information services of the Community Council of Greater New York in 1971, died yesterday at her home, 333 East 53d Street. She was 72 years old.

title: Dogs Used in Hunt for Youth
description: PATTERSON, N. Y., Aug. 3 (AP) The state police used bloodhounds today to search for Allan Ashkenas, a 19yearold mentally retarded Bronx youth, who disappeared yesterday evening from a summer camp near here.

title: THOMAS RETURNS; REDSKINS BEATEN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI)  Duane Thomas, a dropout from pro football last year, returned to action tonight but wasn't enough to prevent the Detroit Lions from upsetting the Washington Redskins, 1714, in an exhibition contest featured by Mel Farr's 47yard touchdown run.

title: Inquiry Slated on Responsibility Of Braniff in Cocaine Smuggling
description: William Ryan, chief of the Justice Department's Narcotics Section, ordered an investigation yesterday to determine if Braniff International played a role in the smuggling of cooaine aboard one of its planes last spring.

title: Ervin Hopes Committee Won't Go Over Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Aug, 3 (UPI)Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., chairman of the Senate Watergate committee, said today that he hoped the committee would not need more money to supplement Its $1million budget.

title: WILLIAM E. SIEGEL
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 3William E. Siegel, since January senior vice chairman of Security Pacific National Bank, died Monday at his home in Pacific Palisades. He was 63 years old.

title: Basketball Transactions AMERICAN ASSOCIATION
description: SAN ANTONIOSigned Robert Gords, forward from Stephen F. Austin University.

title: Events Today
description: LIGHT OPERA OF MANHATTAN, Gilbert and Sullivan's The Pirates of Penzance, Jen Hus Playhouse, 4 and 8:30

title: Reynolds to Drop List Price
description: The Reynolds Metals Company announced yesterday that it would no longer publish an international list price for primary aluminum sold outside the United States and Canada. Accordingly, it withdrew its recent list price of 27 cents a pound.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on bill establishing controls on campaign contributions, which passed, 82 to 8, July 30.

title: Business Records
description: FALCHICK DRESS CO. INC., manufacturing dresses, 1385 Broadway, N.Y. Signed by Irving FalchIck, president, No statement of liabilities and assets at this time.

title: Broadway Central Hotel Collapses
description: The University Hotel, which as the Broadway Central was a city landmark for about century, collapsed yesterday, injuring at least a dozen persons, halting subways and bringing scores of policemen and firemen to the scene to begin digging in the debris.

title: Magma Cuts Shipments
description: The Magma Copper division of the Newmont Mining Corporation declared yesterday a 15 per cent force majeure reduction in August and September shipments of refined copper. The company traced the cutback to technical problems at its smelting and refining facilities. Normally, Magma delivers about 17,000 tons of refined copper a month.

title: Joseph Alvarez Is Dead at 58; WNBCTV Editorial Manager
description: WALDWICK, N.J., Aug. 3Joseph Alvarez, manager of editorial services for WNBCTV in New York, died today in Ridgewood Valley Hospital after a Jong illness. He was 58 years old and lived at 41 Stuart Street in this community.

title: Watergate or no Watergate, Nixon would have won
description: You can see what American politics is getting to be when the fourth quadrennial study of the Presidential election, by the distinguished Theodore H. White, is reviewed by a novelist, which is to say, a professional liar as opposed to the typical amateur who holds or runs for public office. You can see what American politics is getting to be when the fourth quadrennial study of the Presidential election, by the distinguished Theodore H. White, is reviewed by a novelist, which is to say, a professional liar as opposed to the typical amateur who holds or runs for public office.

title: Along the Straw Hat Trail
description: Along the Straw Hat Trail

title: JULIUS GOEBEL JR., LEGAL HISTORIAN
description: Dr. Julius Goebel Jr., a prominent legal historian and professor emeritus of legal history at the Columbia University School of Law, died yesterday after a long illness. He was 80 years old and lived at 21 East 90th Street.

title: Man Held in Two Montclair Murders
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J., Aug. 4A 26yearold window washer was charged here today with the murder of two women who were found hanged last May 14 in the basement of their 20room home in Upper Montclair. The man, Robert D. Petrarca of 569 South Orange Avenue In Newark, had been a suspect in the double murder since the early stages of the investigation, the police said. It was determined at the time, they said, that he had washed windows at the house the day before the women were killed.

title: SUSAN'S GIRL WINS LIBERTY BELL RACE
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4Fred W. Hooper's Susan'S Girl raced to a convincing 3 length victory today in the fifth running of the $55,500 Susquehanna Handicap at Liberty Bell Park.

title: Community Revives Park in Woodside
description: A 16yearold youth who wanted to play basketball and an attorney who believed the boy's promise that he would protect a devastated park in Woodside, Queens, against vandals have combined to make the facility a community asset once again.

title: R. A. Dubbs Fiance Of Anne Wightman
description: STONINGTON, Conn., Aug. 4Miss Anne Wightman and Richard Andre Dubbs, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andre Dubbs of Atherton, Calif., plan to be married on Nov. 24 at the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: For Brooklyn, the Beef Is Rare
description: From the wholesalers at the Fort Greene market, who supply Brooklyn with 75 per cent of its beef, to the scattered, small processors, whose kielbasa, pastrami, kosher hot dogs, Italian sausage and spare ribs contribute to the borough's tangy ethnic diversity, there was a chorus of dismay last week over the skyrocketing prices of pork and poultry and the shortage of beef.

title: FEWER STUDENTS PREPARE TO TEACH
description: Enrollment of college students preparing to be teachers has, begun to decline throughout the United States, according to the National Education Association.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONThe death of four Kent State Uinversity students at the hands of the Ohio National Guard in May, 1970, will stand as a bloody monument to the domestic crisis brought on by the war in Vietnam. For the families of those killed and wounded, as well as for many other Americans, there has always been an additional burden: the strong suspicion that in the investigation following the event, justice was not fully done, and perhaps not even fully sought.

title: Skylab 2
description: HOUSTON  Shortly before 6:45 A.M. last Thursday, the three Skylab astronauts were still asleep in their space station. It was the sixth day after their departure from earth for a planned twomonth mission orbiting the earth. The stomach queasiness and nausea they had been suffering, the result of motion sickness, were gone, and the men were finally ready to begin their scientific work after their sleep.

title: Old Troupe in New Home
description: LAWRENCEVILLEWhen fledglings become old enough to fly, the mother bird forces them to leave the nest. The same thing happened to the group of actors and directors who made up last year's Summer Intime Theater at Princeton University. They have found a new homeit is at nearby Rider College and they have been producing plays there this summer.

title: Visitor Tanaka
description: WASHINGTON  President Nixon and Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka laid the basis last week for their first real effort to stop the worsening of relations between the United States and Japan that began two years ago with the Nixon shocks in Pacific diplomacy and trade.

title: School Donates Kidney Machine
description: UNIONDALE, L. I.Months of hard work by the students of Uniondale High School culminated earlier this summer when the student council presented a check at the school here for $3,000 to Nassau Hospital for the purchase of a renal dialysis machine.

title: Making Money Earn More
description: The recent rapid climb of interest rates has brought with it many questions about where to receive the best returns.

title: Judge Curbs DriveIn
description: COVINGTON, Ky., Aug. 4 (UPI)Kenton County Circuit Judge Robert O. Lukowsky has baned xrated movies at the Dixie Gardens DriveIn because they were distracting motorists on nearby Interstate 75.

title: RIZZO IS SAID TO USE POLICEMEN AS SPIES
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4 (UPI) Mayor Frank Rizzo has been employing a squad of more than 30 policemen to spy on his political enemies, two Philadelphia newspapers reported in their Sunday editions.

title: Headliners
description: It's a common practice for law enforcement authorities to seize cars and other private conveyances used to transport arugs. Last week Judge Jack B. Weinstein in Brooklyn carried the practice to a higher level: He ordered the seizure of a $9million Braniff airliner in which a passenger, William Ochoa of Colombia, smuggled into the United States some cocaine in, his hollow artificial leg. The United States Code exempts common carriers from seizure unless it can be shown that the owner was a consenting party or privy to a violation, but Judge Weinstein said he was taking the action to prod airlines into doing something about the use of their planes for drug traffic. I don't say that they are actively cooperating with the smuggling, but they are not taking steps to notify young people of the dangers, he said. By the end of the week the Braniff plane had not been seized. The United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York, Robert A. Morse, was under orders of the Justice Department to investigate what Braniff knew, or should have known, about the Ochoa smuggling.

title: California
description: California in California seems to be a matter of hiding from Everything Elsefleeing to the Cities of the Plain and the BayEverything Else is out there in the great Central Valley, where the San Andreas rift bulges up like a gigantic ulcerated wound and where Bakersfield is an omphalos of Okiedom, Nashville West, close neighbor (in California terms) to Folsom Prison.

title: Congress Fights Back
description: Congress in recent months has made repeated efforts to assert its influence on numerous national and international questions. In part, these efforts reflect the views of the voters who placed Democratic majorities in control of both houses; in part, they represent a broadly bipartisan determination to defend and restore Congress institutional perogatives.

title: Gardens
description: MANY of the world's uniquely beautiful succulent plants, with thick, juicy leaves or stems, ornament gardens. Hardy species of the Orpine or Crassula family (Crassulaceae) are indispensable in the landscape. Tender kinds are popular as houseplants. Neither group requires much care.

title: Lynn P. Vialotti Bride Of Dr. Robert Harper
description: Miss Lynn Pamela Vialotti, daughter of Dr. Charles P. Vialotti, a physician, and Mrs. Vialotti of New York and Westhampton Beach, L. I., was married here yesterday afternoon to Dr. Robert Bruce Harper, a resident in anesthesiology at St. Vincent's Hospital. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Harper of Somerset, Mich.

title: Trends
description: WASHINGTON  The computer's implacability is familiar enough: is there anyone who has not been dunned by a department store, month after weary month, for something never purchased or long since paid for? But a justreleased government report warns that, unless safeguards are enacted soon, this nuisance may become a tyranny.

title: Kuhn Can Punish Those Who Undermine Baseball
description: The office of the Commissioner of Baseball in New York moved four blocks this year from 680 Fifth Avenue to 15 West 51st Street. But people have been arguing for years whether it has moved far enough in a changing society.

title: SPANISH CLASSES ORDERED BY JUDGE
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Aug. 4School officials of the eastern New Mexico city of Portales were ordered by a Federal judge here this week to institute special curriculums to meet the educational needs of students of Mexican descent, who constitute 27 per cent of the total enrollment, and to recruit and hire more qualified Spanishspeaking teachers.

title: PENTAGON TIGHTENS RETIREMENT RULES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 Physical disability retirements from the military services have been drastically reduced since new guidelines were issued in January, according to a recent report by the Department of Defense.

title: Detroit Edison Turns Tough
description: DETROIT  The Detroit Edison Company no longer wants to be loved. It would rather be respected.

title: Military Aid Bill
description: WASHINGTONIn its battle of the budget with the White House, the Democratic leadership in Congress has been assembling its forces behind a broad political strategy: Demonstrate both social responsiveness and fiscal responsibility by augmenting the President's domestic programs, cutting back on his military programs and winding up with a budget smaller than the Administration's.

title: Sharon Diane Lyon. Is Bride of Paul F. Emmanuel
description: BROOKVILLE, L. 1., Aug. 4 Miss Sharon Diane Lyon and Paul Frederick Emmanuel were married here this afternoon in the Brookville Reformed Church by the Rev. John Hascup. The Rev. James F. Ryan assisted.

title: Pasarell Reaches Ohio Tennis Final; Connors Advances
description: GROVE CITY, Ohio, Aug.4 (UPI)Unseeded Charles Pasarell of Los Angeles advanced to the final of the Buckeye tennis tournament today with a 76, 36, 63 victory over Haroon Rahim of Pakistan.

title: ALABAMA LAW BODY LOSES ON DISTRICTS
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 4A Federal Court has turned down a last ditch effort by the Alabama Legislature to reapportion itself and ordered that a courtdevised plan be put into effect in time for next year's elections.

title: Frances McNeil Engaged to Marry
description: PINEHURST, N. C., Aug. 4 Mrs. J. Robert McNeil has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Frances McNeil, to Carmen Fiorentino of San Diego, son of Mrs. Carmen A. Fiorentino of Conshohocken, Pa., and the late Mr. Fiorentino. A September wedding here is planned.

title: New and Recommended
description: NINETYTWO IN THE SHADE, by Thomas McGuane. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $6.95.) The author of The Sporting Club and The Bushwhacked Piano resumes the pursuit of his favorite theme, the perilous testing of man against man, this time between a young newcomer and a reckless master guide down on the Florida Keys.

title: 200 Bronx TeenAgers Bring Joy to Retarded
description: Leo Gagion, a 15yearold high school student, takes care of a little retarded girl from lithe South Bronx three days a week as part al Project Hand, a summer recreation program for 130 deaf and retarded children that stresses a onetoone relationship.

title: Chain. Buys Carolina Paper
description: SANTA ANA, Calif., Aug. 4 (UPI)Clarence Holies, board chairman of Freedom Newspapers, Inc., announced today the purchase of the chain's 20th daily publication, The Kingston Daily Free Press in southeastern North Carolina.

title: Connecticut Minister Murdered, Examiner Rules Alter Autopsy
description: MIDDLEFIELD, Conn., Aug. 4  The Medical Examiner's office here ruled on the basis of an autopsy today that a fundamentalist minister who was found dead Thursday night in Wadsworth Falls State Park here had been murdered.

title: Lynn Gould Betrothed To Peter James Eppel
description: UPPER BROOKVILLE, L. I., Aug. 4The engagement of Miss Lynn Myerle Gould, daughter of Mrs. Frank Hamilton of Upper Brookville and the late Theodore Gould, to Peter James Eppel, son of Mrs. Simeon Louis Eppel of Lighthouse Point, Fla., and the late Mr. Eppel, has been announced. An October wedding is planned.

title: S.I. Ferry Is U.N. Boat For a Day
description: No, a Staten Island ferryboat did not lose her way into the Hudson yesterday. The boat purposely veered off her usual coure for a trip in other Manhattan waters. The occasion was the annual boatride held for diplomats and their families by the New. York Commission for the United Nations and for the Consular Corps.

title: Hawks Drop Guerin, Hire Pat Williams as Manager
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 4 (UPI)The Atlanta Hawks of the National Basketball Association dismissed General Manager Richie Guerin today. The Hawks said Pat Williams, 33yearold executive of the Chicago Bulls, would replace Guerin.

title: GIANTS WIN, 3 TO 2, ON HOMER IN 11TH
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. (AP)Tito Fuentes drilled his fourth home run of the season with one out in the 11th inning today, lifting San Francisco to a 32 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers and keeping the Giants unbeaten in nine extrainning games this year.

title: James Nolan, ExPolice Official Who Headed P.A.L., Dies at 79
description: James B. Nolan, former Deputy Police Commissioner and executive director of the Police Athletic League, died Friday at his home, 10 Holder Place, Forest Hills, Queens, after a long illness. His age was 79.

title: Ruchell Magee Hearing Set
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 4 (UPI)  The California Court of Appeal ordered an Aug. 23 hearing today for Ruchell Magee, a San Quentin prisoner, to determine two issues in connection with his second kidnapping trial. The court will determine whether Magee's second trial for his part in the gun battle at the Marin County Courthouse Aug. 7, 1970, should be transferred to Santa Clara county. It will also hear evidence on Magee's request that he be allowed to change his plea. Magee, whose first trial in San Francisco for murder and kidnapping ended in a hung jury is scheduled to be retried only on kidnapping charges.

title: Patricia A. Taylor Becomes Affianced
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Aug. 4 Miss Patricia Ann Taylor and William Flinnant Mosier plan to be married in September. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. James Bradley Taylor Jr., parents of the future bride, whose fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Willis Mosier of Greenville, N. C.

title: Strangers; And Journeys
description: Two generations of New Zealanders crisscross time and again in this exasperating family sagaexasperating because the oases of its fine writing disappear into deserts of tedium. The main threads in the novel unravel from the families of Ned Livingstone, a pioneering farmer, and Bill Freeman, a Communist laborer. Livingstone returns from World War I to hack out a living from the wilderness. Freeman comes out of jail (for antiwar activities) to take up the life of a crusading navvy.

title: The sound and soundness of symphonic music in America
description: On the surface, Orpheus in the New World seems a curious title for an exhaustive study of the history, current status and outlook of the symphony orchestra in America. But if you look up the original Orpheus legend, which differs from the happyending versions we know from the operas of Monteverdi, Gluck and Offenbach, you'll find that the sweet singer's fate, after his return from Hades and the second death of Euridice, was death and dismemberment at the hands of a band of overamorous women. For Maenads read symphony boards, and suddenly Philip Hart's title makes more sense than even he probably realizes.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Here's something different, THE BILLION DOLLAR SURE THING (Scribner's, $6.95) by Paul E. Erdman, an exconvict who is beginning to make a reputation for himself in a highly unusual way. Other genre authors deal with espionage, political maneuvering, the criminal subculture. Erdman has put together a mlange that contains all of this, plus one factor largely ignored in suspense or mystery novels the world of international high finance. Everything comes together there, guided from elegant board rooms in Zurich, Basel, London, New York and Moscow.

title: FUNDRAISER SETS A $1BILLION GOAL
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Aug. 4The United Way of America, the world's largest nonprofit fundraising organization, expects to raise more than $1billion this year for philanthrophy a record.

title: Black Influx In Brooklyn Is Evident In Schools
description: The rapid change in the ethnic makeup of Brooklyn's 18th School District (East RatbushCanarsie) is reflected in new figures showing that blacks predominate in half of its 18 elementary and junior high schools.

title: News of the Stage
description: Playgoers attending matinee or evening performances today at the American Shakespeare Theater in Stratford, Conn., may watch some 80 graduate students partake of a typical Elizabethan feast, complete with roast pork, spring lamb, boiled cabbage, ovenbaked bread, oriana gingerbread mince pie, fruit bowl and medieval mead or alesans eating utensils or napkins.

title: Mets Lose, 43
description: As if the Mets injury problems were contagious to whoever steps onto the field at Shea Stadium. Bob Gibson. the dean of the st. Louis pitching staff suffered a knee injury yesterday that could turn the Cardinals pennant dreams into a nightmare.

title: Sept. 2 Wedding Set By Flori Blumberg
description: LAKE SUCCESS, L. I., Aug. 4Dr. and Mrs. Arnold Blumberg have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Flori Blumberg, to David Schwartz, son of Dr. and Mrs. Albert Schwartz of Utica, N. Y. The wedding is planned for Sept. 2.

title: Boston Air Crash
description: There is a disturbing quality to many airliner accidents of recent years: a fourengine 707 jet plummets into an apple orchard while approaching a Cincinnati runway  a twinengine turboprop crashes while trying to land in a snowstorm at Bradford, Pa . a sister plane virtually duplicates the disaster two weeks later a twinjet bringing a football team home from a game smashes into a hill on the final landing approach into Huntington, W. Va.

title: CHURCHILL, STALIN MADE POLISH DEAL
description: LONDON, Aug. 4 (AP)Wartime papers of Sir Winston Churchill made public this week show that he agreed in 1944 to Soviet domination of Poland in exchange for Stalin's support of British interests in the Far East and the Mediterranean.

title: Robert Ried Weds Susan G. Rowland
description: TENAFLY, N. J., Aug. 4Miss Susan Griffith Rowland and Robert Jeffery Ried were married here this afternoon in the Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Harry Chase.

title: Plan Offered to Purify All Waterways in State
description: TRENTONThe idea of going fishing in the lower reaches of the Passaic River, or perhaps boating on the Arthur Kill, would seem preposterous to most people today, given the grossly polluted condition of both waterways. But the state's Department of Environmental Protection envisions just that, along with a number of other major improvements that are designed to upgrade the quality of New Jersey's rivers, lakes and tidal bays.

title: Glasgow or Dublin? No, It's Kearny
description: KEARNYAt the western end of Hudson County is touch of Glasgow and Dublin rolled into one. It is in the crowded community of Kearny, where the lilt of the language clearly reflects the Scottish and Irish heritage of many of the 37,600 residents, and haggis, fish and chips and cakes from Aberdeen are prominently featured in the windows of retail shops along the main shopping streets. The origin of the population also shows in the work they do in the factories in town: the manufacture of thread, linoleum and wiring for household needs.

title: Planning Commission Picks 60 Projects for Capital Budget
description: More than 60 new projects involving the construction of parks, sewers and highways will be recommended by the City Planning Commission for the 197475 capital budget from priorities submitted by the city's 62 community districts.

title: News of the Screen
description: Local filmgoers can expect something new next month in the way of Finnish movies, about as rare here as they come. The Library and Museum of the Performing Arts in Lincoln Center, in conjunction with Cinema Dimensions, Inc., will offer what is called the first festival of Finnish movies ever presented in this country. At least a dozen features, only one of which has been screened previously, will have premiere showings for the benefit of the library in its 212seat theater from Sept. 17 through Sept. 29.

title: Art Mailbag; Do Kids And Museums Mix?
description: JOHN CANADAY bared some disturbing criteria for a museum in his otherwise tongueincheek article, 'Hey, Look! And Other Principles of Esthetics (June 24). Mr. Canaday notes the intrusion of school groups on adult enjoyment at the museum and that kids even at their best behaved are out of harmony with the idea of the museum as a refuge. The museum as a refuge? Hmmm.

title: Highway Takes Its Toll of Engine Going to Fire
description: Madrid, Aug. 4A fire engine rushing to a forest fire near Barcelona was not allowed through a highway toll booth until the toll was paid, according to Diario de Barcelona.

title: Broadway's Vitality Is Black Vitality
description: IN a recent article in The Times Magazine, Walter Kerr asked some pertinent questions and made some very revealing comments. The main  question was, What's happening to Broadway? This was followed by the nostalgic cornment that there is no Broadway in the old sense. Mr. Kerr suggested that Broadway needed to undergo a facelifting, or to be shifted to the East Side, the presumption being that the theatergoing audience either resides on or frequents the East Side.

title: Six More Chagall Windows
description: ISRAEL has speeded up the second part of the issue devoted to the stained glass windows that Marc Chagall created for the chapel of the Hadassah Hospital in Jerusalem, so that the last six stamps of the set are now coming out on August 21.

title: The World
description: SANTIAGOFaced with the threat of another general strike, like the one that nearly wrecked the Chilean economy last fall, President Salvador Allende Gossens received the resignations of his entire cabinet last Friday but decided to turn it down. He did acknowledge, however, that political circumstances might force him to make a cabinet change.

title: Christine A. Stevens to Be Wed Sept. 8
description: ARDMORE, Pa., Aug. 4 Mr. and Mrs. John William Murray have announced the engagement of Mrs. Murray's daughter, Miss Christine Agnes Stevens, to John William Johnston, son of John M. Johnston of New York and Mrs. M. Kelly Johnston of Glen Cove, L. I. The couple plan to be married in New York on Sept. 8.

title: Inflation Spurs Drop In College Entrants
description: TRENTON  The effects of inflation and the end of the Vietnam war have reduced this year, for the first time since 1966, the ntimber of New Jersey high school graduates going on to college. Instead, a greater proportion of the students are entering the job market, particdarly in semiskilled trades and whitecollar positions.

title: Murders in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (UPI)  A total of 486 persons were mut dered in Chicago in the first 6 months of 1973, an increase of almost 36 per cent over the like period in 1972, the police said today. Statistics showed 10 per cent, increase in all major crimes for the first half of the year.

title: What do we have left in common except proximity?
description: I have for many years felt from chance, indeed haphazard, encounters with him that Wilson Carey McWilliams is a singular presence in America. His oratorical eloquence, if it is not legendary in the academic communities he has inhabited, tells us dire things about the deafness of the modern ear. Now he brings out this huge book, an elaboration on his dissertation, which is also eloquent, insistent, probing, sad. It is, really, a cri de coeur, though it presents itself as cultural history and cultural criticism. It is a lament for the lost idea of fraternity.

title: Today's T.V.A. Is Assailed As Threat to Environment
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn. Aug. 4The Tennessee Valley Authority, created 40 years ago by a generation of conservationists, now finds itself under attack by the new environmentalists.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Lindsay administration has warned savings banks the city that if they continue to restrict the granting home mortgages, the city will deposit its money elsewhere. Finance Administrator Richard Lewisohn said yesterday that he had issued the warning to many of the 46 banks in which the city maintains a total of about $24million in deposits.

title: Visitor Whitlam
description: WASHINGTONIn the mid1960's Australian Prime Minister Harold Holt delighted and amused many Americans by summing up his country's relations with the United States with the Lyndon Johnson campaign slogan, All the way with LE. It was said humorously, but it was also a pretty accurate reflection of the state of Australian foreign policy. What was good for Washington had to be good for Canberra.

title: War on Cancer
description: WASHINGTON  A short sentence President Nixon spoke two years ago has achieved a certain immortality in the minds of men and women who are fighting mankind's war against cancer: To the extent money is needed it will be provided.

title: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
description: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York

title: FUNDRAISER SETS A $1BILLION GOAL
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Aug. 4The United Way of America, the world's largest nonprofit fundraising organization, expects to raise more than $1billion this year for philanthrophy a record.

title: Ancient Crown Unearthed in Korea
description: KYONGU, South Korea, Aug. 4A Governmentsponsored excavation team has unearthed an elaborately ornamented gold crown believed to be at least 1,400 years old.

title: Sunday Observer By Russell Baker
description: America has had a bigotry revolution.

title: Harvest of Profits for Continental Grain
description: If you ask the top officers of the Continental Grain Company to name the largest privately owned business in the nation, they reply with the name of their chief rival, Cargill, Inc.

title: Education
description: When the people who run the Interstate United Vending Machine Company in Detroit were looking for summer help this year, they went to Bishop Foley High School in suburban Madison Heights and asked not students but teachers if they were interested.

title: Chess. Ljubojevic Throws All Caution (and Timid Foes) to the Winds
description: PETROPOLIS, Brazil The only gambler among the staid is reaping the spoils in the Interzonal Tournament here. Ljubomir Ljubojevic, a 23yearold Yugoslav grandmaster, risking a dangerous pawn capture, survived to win after adjournment against Oscar Panno of Argentina in Round 5.

title: USAC Plans Measures For Drivers Protection
description: Three days after the fatalityriddled Indianapolis 500 of May 30, the United States Auto Club held an allday meeting of car owners, chief mechanics, officials and other appropriate interests to adopt emergency safety procedures. The measures were admittedly hasty and they were not total answers to serious problems. But there was no time for pussyfooting  something had to be done right then and there.

title: Best Seller List
description: Best Seller List

title: Helping Parents Decide If Children Need Care
description: GLEN OAKSA psychological evaluation service here is helping parents resolve the question of whether their troubled youngsters need psychiatric treatment or are just going through phase.

title: Brookhaven Mandates Moratorium on Housing
description: PATCHOGUE, L. I.  The Brookhaven Town Board last week called time out in the contest between builders and those who want to avoid the piecemeal development of the state's largest town.

title: COMMUNITY UNITS TO EXPAND HERE
description: A new park opened, last month in the WakefieldEdenwald section or the Bronx along the abandoned roadbed of the Bronx River Parkway. It required no tedious discussions and no bickering in the Board of Estimate.

title: Dawn Over Saratoga
description: The campaign of Gen. Gentleman Johnny Burgoyne was the most significant and colorful of the Revolutionary War, and in this little volume Fred J. Cook gives us a splendid account. The author is adept at describing the heroism, stupidity and ebb and flow of action which ended in Burgoyne's capitulation at Saratoga, an event that impelled France to aid the Americans. Designed for young readers, and without maps (alas!), notes, or bibliography, the book can still be read with pleasure by adults. The sequence of events is clearly presented; the cast of characters, faithfully drawn and alive; the writing, vigorous.

title: Former Director of the Grosvenor. House Appeals His Dismissal.
description: William Burnes, who was dismissed last year as program director of the Grosvenor Neighborhood House on West 105th Street, has appealed the findings of the City Commission on Human Rights, which found no probable cause that he had been discriminated against.

title: Miss Mumford Bay State Bride
description: WELLESLEY, Mass., Aug. 4Miss Elizabeth Herrick Mumford and Richard Hoyt Forshay Jr., seniors at Franklin and Marshall College, were married here this afternoon in St. Andrew's Episcopal Church by the Rev. William Turner.

title: Gail M. Erway Plans Nuptials
description: ELMIRA, N. Y., Aug. 4Miss Gail Marie Erway, an architect with the New York firm of Justin Henshell, plans to be married on Aug. 26 to Richard Avery Gerard, a lawyer and associate with the New York law firm of Parker, Chapin & Flattau.

title: Donald Dryden Weds Mary Thompson
description: Miss Mary Emma Thempson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Caldwell Thompson of Lincolnton, N. C., was married here yesterday afternoon to Donald Richard Dryden, proprietor of the Dryden Gallery, which deals in contemporary graphics. The Rev. Charles Underhill Ouinn uerformed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour.

title: For East Hampton, A Political Novice
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I.,  By professional political standards Judith Hope is a novice. She has only been active in Democratic party politics for a year now, but that is not keeping her from attaining potential starstatus.

title: $25.000 Voted for Survivor Of Falsely Accused G.I. Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UPI) The Senate passed a bill yesqerday that would award $25,000 to Dorsie Willis, believed to be the sole survivor of an allblack infantry unit unjustly discharged in 1906.

title: Park User Fees Curbed
description: WASHINGTON, Aug, 4 (AP) President Nixon has signed legislation prohibiting Federal agencies from charging user fees for use of recreational areas that do not offer specialized facilities, the White House has announced.

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: BrooklynAn exhibition of drawings by Yeh Yung Ching, today through the month of August, Monday to Friday, 10 A.M. to 7 P.M., Saturday and Sunday 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. L.I.U. Brooklyn Center, lobby gallery of Metcalfe Hall.

title: Michael Findlay And Naomi Sims Are Wed Here
description: Miss Naomi Sims, a fashion model and international magazine cover girl, was married here yesterday morning to Michael Alistair Findlay, owner of an art gallery in lower Manhattan.

title: The Family: Holding Its Own in a Period of Changing Values
description: From talk show to cocktail party to professorial symposium, it may well be second only to Watergate as the most fashionable topic of the moment the future of the family.

title: Saratoga Race Charts
description: Saratoga Race Charts

title: Projects to Learn About Insects
description: GARDEN insects which seem a nuisance to adults can become fascinating to children. Interest may be aroused when a child notes his parents alarm over aphids and beetles, or when he discovers a spectacularly large or pretty creature. Or a clever parent may say when there is little to do, Why don't you count how many different insects are out in the garden? Let's each make a guess first.

title: Baseball Fan Hoisted With His Own Petard
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Aug. 4 (UPI)  Reggie Jackson of the Oakland A's was trotting in from right field to congratulate Vida Blue for his 21 victory over the California Angels last night. A crumpled beer can, tossed from the stands, struck him on the side of the head.

title: DOUGLAS UPHOLDS HALT IN BOMBING BUT IS OVERRULED
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4Justice William 0. Douglas of the Supreme Court today ordered an immediate halt to the American bombing of Cambodia. Hours later, the Court overruled him in an order issued by Justice Thurgood Marshall and supported by the seven other members.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court ordered an immediate halt to the American bombing of Cambodia. Hours later, the Court overruled him in an order issued by Justice Thurgood Marshall and supported by the seven other justices. Justice Douglas's decision upheld an injunction ordered in Federal Court in Brooklyn on July 25. On Wednesday, Justice Marshall ruled against that injunction by refusing to vacate a stay. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Pelicans Gain on Texas Coast After Drop in Use of Pesticides
description: ROCKPORT, Tex.  The byown pelican with its sevenfoot wingspread, one of the nation's largest birds, may be starting a comeback along the Texas coast. Experts say that a decline in the use of certain pesticides may help.

title: REFUGEE STEPUP STIRS GERMANYS
description: BERLIN, Aug. 4A mounting flow of East German refugees fleeing to the West on West Berlin's vulnerable transit routes has become a controversial issue between the two Germanys.

title: Miss Rosemary H. O'Malley Is Married to Mark C. Tinker
description: DARIEN, Conn., Aug. 4The First Congregational Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Rosemary Helen O'Malley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. O'Malley of Riverdale, the Bronx, to Mark Christian Tinker, son of Grant A. Tinker of Malibu, Calif., and Mrs. Richard 1. Fricke of Darien.

title: Effort Is Renewed to Build a Haven for Pets
description: MIDLAND PARK  The 500 members of Bergen Animal Rescue, Inc., after a fruitless eightyear struggle and steady rebuffs from four Bergen County towns, hope to receive this borough's approval soon to construct a haven for stray and abandoned pets.

title: Sports Week Highlights
description: The Mets are home today through Tuesday against the St. Louis Cardinals, leaders of the National League Eastern Division. Doubleheader today (1 P.M.), Monday (8 P.M.), Tuesday (2 P.M.). See WORTV, Channel 9, for today's games. WHN Radio will broadcast all games.

title: Vonder Scholl Is Wed on L.I.
description: GLEN COVE, L. I, Aug. 4 Miss yonder Ann Scholl, daughter of Thomas Francis Scholl of Glen Cove and the late Mrs. Scholl, was married here today to John Charles Knily Jr. of Snowmass, Colo., son of Mr. and Mrs. Knily of Cummaquid, Mass. The ceremony was performed in the First Presbyterian Church, by the Rev. W. Cameron Allan, the minister.

title: Institute in Florida Planned to Train News Executives
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Aug. 4A communications institute to develop young newspaper executives is being founded by Nelson Poynter, the owner of The St. Petersburg Times and The St. Petersburg Independent.

description: Glistening makeups

title: Josiah B. Keeney, Served Editor & Publisher Magazine
description: WATERFORD, Conn., Aug. 4 Josiah B. Keeney, a retired marketing and research manager of Editor & Publisher, the newspaper trade publication, died yesterday at New London Convalescent Home, He was 87 years old.

title: EXNIXON WRITER REPORTED TAPPED
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4The Nixon Administration ordered a telephone wiretap on William Safire, when he was one of the President's three speechwriters, as part of a twoyear effort to find and stop leaks of classified Government information to the press, according to Federal officials.

title: Ken Kotiza Fiance Of Leslie E. Blake
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 4Mr. and Mrs. Norman P. Blake of Greenwich and London have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Leslie Eleanor Blake, to Ken Edward Kotiza, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Kotiza of St. Louis. The couple will be married Sept. 1 in St. Louis.

title: Trouble Besets Krishna Sect
description: The Hare Krishna sect may be spreading the message of love and understanding across the nation and the world, but there seems to be little love  and even less understanding  between the group and neighbors living near its current headquarters in Brooklyn.

title: Mary Segers Is Wed Here
description: Dr. Mary C. Segers, an assistant professor of political science at Rutgers University, was married here yesterday afternoon to Dr. Jerome A. Travers. Both are of New York. The Rev. Jeremiah Sullivan performed the Roman Catholic ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University.

title: After 3 Nuclear Explosions, A.E.C. Is Leaving Amchitka to Wind and Fog
description: AMCHITKA, Alaska  The horizontal rain, riding the cold, rough wind, whips across the airstrip this time of year, cut'ting through a visitor's clothes.

title: Television This Week
description: Television This Week

title: Goldberg Asserts Compromise Is Needed on Presidential Tapes
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 Former Supreme Court Justice Arthur J. Goldberg said today that the constitutional confrontation over the Watergate case imperatively calls for compromise.

title: Numismatics
description: To date, more than 1,300 members of the American Numismatic Association have mailed in paid registrations for the 82d annual convention to be held in Boston Aug. 2327. According to Arthur M. Fitts III, general chairman, this is the largest number of registrations ever received a month in advance of a convention. With this early outpouring of enthusiasm, officials are projecting a final paid attendance in excess of the record 10,501 set at the 1971 A.N.A. convention in Washington.

title: Carolyn H. Brown Bride of Biologist
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., Aug. 4 In the Presbyterian Church of Westfield this afternoon, Miss Carolyn Hunt Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Woodbury Brown, became the bride of Richard David Costlow, son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard Dale Costlow of Frederick, Md.

title: What's Doing on CAP COD
description: FISHING DEMONSTRATION Phil Schwind, a salty local character and one of the leading authorities on fishing on the Cape (he's written six books and contributes a fishing column to The Cape Codder), will give surf casting and shelifishing demonstrations under the sponsorship of the National Seashore beginning Aug. 7 and concluding Aug. 29. He's terrific. For times and places inquire at the National Seashore visitors centers at Salt Pond in Eastham or Province Lands in Provincetown. This is just one of many encounters with nature sponsored by the National Seashore.

title: Soviet Spurs Settlement Near China, Apparently to Affirm Claim to Lands
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 4  The Soviet Government has adopted a new policy on internal migration, designed in part to settle more farmers in agricultural lands along the Chinese border.

title: After Fatal Fires, New Code Starts To Bring Changes
description: At about 6 P.M. three years ago today a fire started on the 33d floor of the nearly completed 50story office building at One New York Plaza, opposite Battery Park.

title: Miss Nancy Rauch Is Married on L.I.
description: BROOKVILLE, L. L, Aug. 4  Miss Nancy Frances Rauch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis J. Rauch of Old Westbury, was married here this evening to Konstantinos Douzinas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Spiro Douzinas of Piraeus, Greece, The Rev. Robert Weiskotten, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony in the Brookville Reformed Church, assisted by the Rev. Jack Hascup.

title: Case Arrest Seen
description: WASHINGTON, Pa., Aug. 4 (UPI)Special Prosecutor Richard Sprague says he hopes to make one more arrest within the year in the slayings of Joseph A. Yablonski, the United Mine Workers dissident, and his wife and daughter. Mr. Sprague refused, however, to say who the suspect might be.

title: Most Marinas in the Area Can Still Fill er Up
description: Despite the gasoline shortage, marinas in the New York area seem to have enough fuel to satisfy thirsty yachts, whose owners may buy as many as 150 gallons a week without flinching. Elmer Smith, manager of the Glen Cove (L. I.) Marina, said last week: So far we've been able to get by News although they [Mobil] cut us of back 10 per cent Boating around Jime. Now they gave us 5 per cent back. Smith said that he sold between 160,000 and 180,000 gallons a season.

title: Princeton Receives Aid for Laboratory
description: PRINCETON  Princeton University has announced the receipt of a $200,000 grant from the Haas Community Fund of Philadelphia. The money will be used toward modernization and renovation of the Henry C. Frick Laboratory, home of the Departments of Chemistry and Biochemical Sciences.

title: Student Loan Act Said to Help Poor Rather Than Middle Class
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) A law Congress passed last year to make loans more easily available to middleincome college students may have had the opposite result, a Congressional report says.

title: Karl Richter Leads Two Choral Works In Mozart Festival
description: Much of Mozart's sacred choral music is a vast uncharted area still to be discovered by today's musicians. In a way it was a pity that Karl Richter did not choose some of the real rarities for his stint with the Mostly Mozart Festival in Philharmonic Hall Friday and Saturday nights  the Vespers (K. 339) and Coronation Mass are among the few works that do turn up every now and again  but it was nonetheless a pleasure to hear these sunny statements of faith so intelligently performed.

title: When Egos Rock the Groups
description: WE LIVE in an age of groups, and nowhere has the herd instinct manifested itself more forthrightly than in the world of pop music. Crowds gather in huddled masses to watch their favorite actsthe National Lampoon hasn't called its nowgeneration revue Lemmings for nothing. And those acts themselves, likely as not, are supraindividual phenomena: collective entities with names that mean more to their fans than those of the actual members, who may in any case change frequently without threatening group survival.

title: Trade Group Sees a Shortage Of Oil for Horne Heating on L. I.
description: HICKSVILLE, L.I., Aug. 4 The Long Island Heating Institute, a trade association representing more than 200 independent oil dealers on Long Island, warned last week that fuel oil might not be available during the heating season unless the dealers were permitted to increase their prices.

title: Lindsay Honors Newsman
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday presented the city's Bronze Medallion in a City Hall ceremony to Bert Kindig, recently retired City Hall correspondent for United Press International, for his public service to the city. Mr. Kindig, president of the Inner Circle, an association of political writers, gave the Mayor in return the original program cover drawing for the Inner Circle's 1973 show, Jokers Wild, drawn by John Pierotti, a political cartoonist of The New York Post.

title: Home Improvement
description: When we turn on the cold water faucet in one of our showers, and only when just barely open, we get a loud vibration in the pipes. It only happens with the one faucet, and the problem has only started recently. Can you suggest what causes this, and what we can do to alleviate the problem? J.L., Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Secretariat Is Beaten
description: Secretariat, the Triple Crown winner and a 1.10 favorite, was upset by Onion, a 51 shot, yesterday in the Whitney Stakes at Saratoga. Secretariat was second, a length behind the winner, in the field of five. Section 5.

title: BREWERS WIN, 94; 6 HITS FOR BRIGGS
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 4 (UPI)Johnny Briggs became the first American League player since 1969 to get six hits in a nineinning game, and Pedro Garcia capped a fiverun ninth with a tworun homer to power the Milwaukee Brewers to a 94 victory over the Cleveland Indians tonight.

title: Yanks Top Tigers, 32 In 14 Innings
description: DETROIT, Aug. 4Matty Alou's long double to leftcenter field with two out in the top of the ninth scored Hal Lanier from first and sent the game between the New York Yankees and Detroit Tigers into extra innings tonight before a crowd of 48,120.

title: Modern Problems Are Visiting Placid Paraguay
description: ASUNCION, Paraguay, Aug. 4 (AP)President Alfredo Stroessner gets out his wellworn inaugural clothes this month, but this term may mean something new for Paraguay: change.

title: The World
description: ATHENSAs the organizer of last Sunday's referendum, the Greek regime had a lot going for it: Athens remained under martial law, the regime monopolized radio, television and billboards for its yes campaign, and nobody except those cleared by the Government were around when the votes were counted.

title: the Dominion of Psychiatry
description: SYRACUSEIn proposing that politicians be examined by psychiatrists, and promising that this would help protect us from evil rulers, Dr. Arnold Hutschnecker (OpEd Page July 4) offers another noble lie, such as Plato considered necessary for the proper government of an ideal society. Plato looked to wellselected and welltrained guardians to protect the people from the perils of powerpolitics; Hutschnecker looks to politicians whose sanity is guaranteed by psychiatrists.

title: Wendy Singer, Law Student, Wed
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 4  Miss Wendy Michele Singer, who plans to enter her third year at the Harvard Law School in the fall, was married here this afternoon to Henry C. Pinkham, a candidate for a Ph.D. in mathematics at the Harvard Graduate School of Arts and Sciences.

title: Defendant Denied The Presumption Of Innocence Here
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn ruled that a defendant indicted by a grand jury need not be presumed innocent for administrative purposes.

title: Watergate
description: WASHINGTONFrom H. R. Haldeman, the crewcut former straw boss of the Nixon White House, came general denials but forgetfulness on key points. From defenders of the Central Intelligence Agency and the Federal Bureau of Investigation came evidence of early warnings to President Nixon. And from Mr. Nixon himself came renewed determination not to bend the line behind which he has encamped himself and his declared Constitutional prerogatives.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Harold Ickes was only half right when he remarked that the President was neither a monarch nor a descendant of the Sun Goddess. In fact, he is a monarch.

title: Catholic Center Helps Retarded in Brooklyn
description: I wish I were a movie star. Every time I dream, dream about being a movie star.

title: Cramped Slate Is Team Tennis's Growing Pain
description: Unless some semblance of order is instituted, organized tennis may be headed for organized mayhem in 1974.

title: Gas Found Off Ireland
description: LONDON, Aug. 4 (Reuters)The Marathon Petroleum Company announced today that it had discovered significant amounts of natural gas 29 miles off the coast of southeastern Ireland. The American company declined to say whether it considered the discovery to be a major find. Marathon has been drilling near Ireland's oast in the expanse of water that stretches southwest England and south Wales.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: Crawford Woods's review of my novel Sleeping Beauty contains three grotesque distortions. In each case, the distortion is accomplished with thimblerigged quotationand total suppression of its context.

title: Photography
description: AN RAY did not take all of the photographs at the Metropolitan Museum's current exhibition of his photographs. One of them, a picture of a herd of bulls running up a street in a Spanish town, is plainly labeled as taken by Ernest Hemingway using Man Ray's camera.

title: EXPRISONER OFFERS TO AID GARROW HUNT
description: WELLS, N. Y., Aug. 4  A Syracuse man, who says he spent three and a half years with Robert Garrow Sr. in Auburn State Correctional Facility, arrived at a roadblock near here this morning and said he would help search for Garrow, who is being sought on murder charges and is believed to be hiding in the woods near here.

title: North Vietnam and Iran Reported Forming Ties
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 4 (AP) North Vietnam and Iran decided today to establish diplomatic relations at the ambassadorial level, officials reported.

title: PROBLEMS PLAGUE SKYLAB CREWMEN
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 4The Skylab 2 astronauts had more than their share of malfunctions and false alarms today as they entered the second week of their planned two  month mission aboard the orbiting space station.

title: MISS BYRNE VICTOR ON EAST SIDE DRIVE
description: MENDHAM, N.J., Aug. 4East Side Drive, owned by the Homestead Stables of Sparta, N. J., and ridden by Pat Byrne, scored 13 points to win the open jumper championship today at the Audley Stables Horse Show.

description: Dan Millstein, head of the coat and suit manufacturing company bearing his name, does not consider himself an oldtimer on Seventh Avenue.

description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 4 (UPI)A fourrun seventh inning today gave the Kansas City Royals a 64 victory over the Minnesota Twins and their seventh straight triumph, a club record.

title: U.S. Opens Talks Thursday On East Germany Relations
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (Reuters)United States and East German officials will open talks here next Thursday aimed at establishing diplomatic relations between the two countries, a State Department spokesman said today.

title: Inoperative Document
description: It is time a defense in behalf of Liddy, Hunt and the other saboteurs is registered. The selfrighteousness and its concomitant, senseless accusations have obscured the real issue. Like many Americans, I am surprised at the obvious neglect.

title: No Voices, But What Faces!
description: Movie buffsespecially those who feel the medium lost some of its magic when it gained soundare in for a rare treat tomorrow night at 8 when WNET/13 begins a series of silent classics from the MGM vaults. Among the golden silents to be shownon 13 consecutive Mondayswill be The Scarlet Letter, left, Victor Seastrom's 1926 drama with Lillian Gish and Lars Hanson, and Love, Edmund Goulding's 1927 version of Anna Karenina, starring Greta Garbo. John Gilbert, who played Count Vronsky to Garbo's Anna will also be seen in tomorrow's feature, King Vidor's 1925 The Big Parade.

title: Why Canada Wants Texasgulf
description: The startling $290million bid by the Canada Development Corporation for control of Texasgulf, Inc., is more a political act than a commercial transaction. American businessmen, who now hold assets of more than $50billion in Canada, should read the signals carefully.

title: Herrmann Wins Net Title

title: Letters
description: Anyone would have to admit that planning in many suburban communities has been lacking. These are problems with storm drainage, sanitary sewer facilities, water supplies and inadequate roads. These problems should be faced and solved.

title: Palmer Defeats Red Sox Orioles Remain in First
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 4 (UPI)Andy Etchebarren rapped a tworun single to help Jim Palmer to his sixth straight victory tonight as the Baltimore Orioles beat the Boston Red Sox, 41, and clung to first place in the American League East.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 Senate investigators have concluded that the Watergate breakin last year was only one small part of a prolonged and massive White House effort to influence the Democratic party's selection of a nominee to run against President Nixon in the 1972 election.
