title: HOTEL WAS FINED BEFORE COLLAPSE
description: The major tenant and the representative of the owner of the old Broadway Central Hotel were each fined $100 for an unrepaired structural violation three weeks before a segment of the building collapsed into rubble, the Buildings Department said.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  A construction worker is accidently knocked off a scaffolding, falls two stories and breaks both legs. Luckily, he will recover and will be back on the job in three or four months. Also, he is entitled to workman's compensation of up to 66 per cent of his state's average wage.

title: Miss Corroon To Be Bride
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Aug. 4Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Corroon have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Donna Ann Corroon, to Richard Barry Shore, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Shore, of Massapequa. An early fall wedding is planned.

title: REPORT ON M'GOVERN TO BE INVESTIGATED
description: FORT WAYNE, Ind., Aug. 4 (AP)A Federal judge has given limited approval for check of illegitimatebirth records here in connection with the Fort Wayne story mentioned during the Senate Watergate committee hearings.

title: City to Condemn Amusement Park
description: The city has announced plans to condemn the Great Adventures Amusement Park in the College PointWhitestone section of Queens early next month following two years of complaints of noise, increasing traffic and vandalism from residents of a nearby housing complex.

title: The breaking of the President
description: Impeachment is the unthinkable subject about which we are thinking because of Watergate. This book is not, however, one of those instant volumes created by a publicist in response to a particular political event and rushed through production by a publisher anxious to capitalize on the daily headlines and momentary fashions. This is a serious, scholarly effort, nonetheless highly readable even by those who want to know what they want to know only because of its implications for current events.

title: State Seeks To Stop Car Buyers Tax Evasion
description: TRENTONMotorists who buy used cars from individuals, but escape paying the stateimposed 5 per cent sales tax on the full value of the vehicle, may be in for a surprise.

title: Miss Yovonovich Scores In New Hope Horse Show
description: NEW HOPE, Pa., Aug. 4Debbie Yovonovich, a 22yearold professional rider, scored a double at the Peacefield horse show today when she piloted The Cheetah to the novice working hunter title. Both horses are owned by Leslie Lambert of Wayne, Pa., The Cheetah also took reserve honors to Mrs. F. Bruce Miller's Rebel in the limit working hunter competition.

title: Folly Compounded
description: Even though both houses of Congress have passed bills intended to speed the proposed transAlaskan oil pipeline, prospects for proceeding with that dubious project are almost as cloudy as they were before the legislative branch came into the picture. Not content with giving the oil consortium permission to build a wider rightofway than present limitations allow, the legislators have involved the project in a constitutional issue that may well take many months to resolve in the courts. They have likewise succeeded in undermining the National Environmental Policy Act without offering any assurance of providing more oil in the near future.

title: Chain Buys Carolina Paper
description: SANTA ANA, Calif., Aug. 4 (UPI)Clarence Hones, board chairman of Freedom Newspapers, Inc., announced today the purchase of the chain's 20th daily publication, The Kingston Daily Free Press in southeastern North Carolina.

title: SAMARA LEADER IN THE DECATHLON
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Aug. 4Fred Samara won the first three events and set a personal record in the fourth today to take the firstday lead in the decathlon at the World University Games American track trials at Penn State's Beaver Stadium.

title: CORTLANDT HANDY, METALS PROCESSOR
description: SOUTHPORT, Conn., Aug. 4 Cortlandt W. Handy, former president and chairman of Handy & Harman, a leading processor of precious and specialty metals, died last night at his home here. He was 84 years old and also lived at 770 Park Avenue in New York.

title: OKLAHOMA INMATES RETURNED TO CELLS
description: McALESTER, Okla., Aug. 4 (AP)National Guardsmen and Highway Patrol troopers swept today into the industrial yard of the riotshattered Oklahoma State Penitentiary, moving the last of the inmates back into their cells.

title: Mr. So Turns War Waste To Folk Art
description: DA NANG, South Vietnam, July 29When the sun rises across the Da Nang River, Nguyen Van So's solid brass vases, lamps and candlesticks begin to gleam.

title: ELKHOUND NAMED PENN RIDGE BEST
description: HILLTOWN, Pa., Aug. 4A Norwegian elkhound, Ch. Valdemar's Winter Storm, owned by Nelson and Yvonne Huber, from Fayettville, Pa., scored the biggest victory of his career today. He was named best of 1,482 dogs at the Penn Ridge Kennel Club Show on the Civic Association Field.

title: S.I. Ferry Is U.N. Boat For a Day
description: No, a Staten Island ferryboat did not lose her way into the Hudson yesterday. The boat purposely veered off her usual coure for a trip in other Manhattan waters. The occasion was the annual boatride held for diplomats and their families by the New York. Commission for the United Nations and for the Consular Corps.

title: 3 Persons Drown at Fire Island, And 25 Are Rescued From Surf
description: Three New York City residents drowned and more than 25 persons were rescued off Fire Island yesterday as an unusually treacherous undertow swept a 10mile section of the shore during the afternoon.

title: Prices Making Beef A Gift Item in Japan
description: TOKYO, Aug. 4 (UPI)Beef prices are so high in Japan that prime cuts are the in gift for big spenders.

title: Abplanalp Defends Role in Nixon Deal For Coast Estate
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 Robert Abplanalp defended today his role in the financial dealings surrounding the purchase of President Nixon's residence, at San Clemente, Calif.

title: Miss Rosita Noyes Murray Married to Jerome Caulfield
description: HEWLETT, L.I., Aug. 4Miss Rosita Noyes Murray and Jerome Joseph Caulfield were married here at noon today in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Robert Cloney, a professor of chemistry at Fordham University.

title: David Brockman Keefe Weds Miss Leslie Ruth Hurmence
description: STATESVILLE, N. C., Aug. 4  Miss Leslie Ruth Hurmence, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Howard Henry Hurmence of Statesville, formerly of Morristown, N. J., was married here this afternoon in Trinity Episcopal Church, to David Brockmann Keefe, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Evans Keefe of Short Hills, N. J. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Clay Howard Turner.

title: DR. JOHN P. GILLIN, ANTHROPOLOGIST
description: CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Aug. 4Dr. John P. Gillin, cultural anthropologist, author and specialist in LatinAmerican problems, died today at his home here. He was 66 years old on Wednesday.

title: That Stories Should Not Be Their Own Reward
description: It is a favorite jape of mine that all poets have better characters than any novelist.

title: Utah Protests Army Plan To Transport Nerve Gas
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 4An Army proposal to ship more than one million gallons of nerve gas from the Rocky Mountain Arsenal outside Denver to the Tooele. Ordnance Depot 35 miles west of Utah's capital has stirred protests from the Utah residents and officials concerned by the hazards they see in such a 600mile rail movement. Secretary of the Army Howard H. Callaway, visiting here Thursday, told Goy. Calvin L Rampton that the Army was many months away from a final decision on shipping several trainloads of canisters containing GB nerve gas from Colorado to Utah. He promised full public hearings and safety studies before shipments would be authorized. The planning to move the gas came after intense public pressure in the Denver area, where the risk of storing thousands of metal containers of toxic materials near the flight paths of that city's Stapleton Airport have long been questioned. The reaction in Utah against dumping Colorado gas on us stems in part from bitterness following the death in 1968 of 6,400 sheep at the Army's Dugway Proving Grounds in western Utah. Those deaths, first disclaimed by the military, were belatedly proved to have been caused by a poorly placed drop of a nerve gas called VX from a low flying plane during tests 30 miles from Tooele.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Perch in Canal
description: The scrappy, fecund and highly adaptable white perch moved up the MohawkHudson Valley in the nineteenforties and fifties and through the canal system to Lakes Ontario and Erie, according to the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation.

title: The Future Is About To Happen
description: ing to this political reality, Mr. Nixon took the occasion to warn Congress of the dangerous potential consequences of its act. This abandonment of a friend, he said, will have a profound impact in other countries, such as Thailand .

title: R.O.T.C. Cadets Drilling With Verve; Realism and Toughness Emphasized
description: FORT BRAGG, N. C.More than 7,000 Reserve Officer Training Corps cadets from 293 colleges and universities have just been sweating through the rudiments of leadership here and at other posts in preparation for commissions in tomorrow's Army.

title: Weiskopf's Lead Cut to Shot in Classic
description: HARRISON, N. Y., Aug. 4 They were closing in on Tom Weiskopf today. But the British Open champion, who has won in five of his last eight starts, led by one stroke at the halfway mark in the $250,000 Westchester golf classic with a 36hole total of 133.

title: Drive in and Turn The Radio On
description: HOW do you test the acoustics of an abandoned church? One way is to drive your Mustang inside, turn on the radio and see how the music sounds. This is what Philippe Entremont did when he was looking for a place for students at the Ravel Academy in SaintJeandeLuz to perform. The French pianist directs the music school in the Bay of Biscay bathing resort adjacent to Ciboure, where Ravel was born. It has no particular building but utilizes various places in the town. There are performance facilities, but the church looked like a distinct improvement, seating about 1,000 people. On the basis of his experiment, Entremont has pronounced the acoustics superb. With time, money and a threading through the redtape labyrinth of French bureaucracy, he expects to have the church in musical order by 1974.

title: E. 121st St. Block Tries Again To Clean Up and Restore Pride
description: Laurance Rockefeller Jr. moved from East 121st Street during the spring of 1970. The nephew of Governor Rockefeller and a vista volunteer for three years left behind an active block association, a clean, treelined street, a community center and a children's playground.

title: Lawyers Criticize Lawyers at the Nader Counterconvention
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4It was billed as verdicts on lawyers and 250 people came to listen. What they heard, though, as Ralph Nader's counterconvention on the legal procession began here today, was one verdict only: Guilty.

title: Nancy Jo Coffman Married to Lawyer
description: PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., Aug. 4Miss Nancy Jo Coffman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Barton C. Coffman of Belle Terre, was married here at noon to Thomas Ronald Toothaker, son of Mrs. Thomas Kaisinger Toothaker of Los Altos, Calif., and the late Dr. Toothaker. The Rev. William Causey performed the ceremony in the First Presbyterian Church.

title: Transit Bond Issue
description: ALBANY  Like Sisyphus pushing his rock up the mountain, Governor Rockefeller is again attempting to roll his transportation bond issue back up the slippery gradient of taxpayer resistance.

title: Planners Adopt the Showman's Style, and It Works
description: Perhaps some of you here tonight are thinking: Who needs an expert to tell us how our town should look? Now, you all know what an expert is, said the planning consultant, pacing his punch line. An expert is somebody who lives 50 miles away!

title: And Awaaayy Gleason Goes Again
description: JACKIE GLEASON descended into the sunken bar in his magnificent 14room house in Inverrarya 1,000acre residential and recreational complex near Fort Lauderdale, Fla.  looking for all the world like a svelte 199pound Joe the Bartender.

title: Lester's Back and the Musketeers Have Got Him
description: SEGOVIA, SPAIN WE don't allow journalists on the set in case they give away secrets that can be stolen for the other three films being made in Europe now of The Three Musketeers.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: John W. Brooks, the chairman of the Celanese Corporation, has always felt his company had a growth strategy. The problem was just that little had been done about it.

title: Fern C. Randelman Is Betrothed
description: TRENTON, Aug. 4Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Randelman have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Fern Chabrow Randelman, to Robert Carlson Leventhal, son of Judge and Mrs. Samuel Leventhal of Ewing Township, Trenton. An autumn wedding is planned.

title: Nixon's Critical Decisions
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4The big question here now Is how President Nixon oan govern the country until 1977, and much depends on how he approaches this critical task of reconciliation in the next few months.

title: World News Briefs
description: DOUGLAS, Isle of Man., Aug, 4 (Reuters)The death toll in Britain's worst postwar fire disaster reached 51 today as local authorities began an inquest into the blaze that gutted a big holiday complex Thursday night.

title: Japan's Young Found Highly Dissatisfied
description: TOKYO, Aug. 4A survey of the attitudes ses of youth in Japan and 10 other countries, conducted by Premier Kakuei Tanaka's office with the help of international research agencies, has shown that young, Japanese are strikingly different from their contemporaries elsewhere in their outlook on many subjects.

title: Wac Is Assigned To the M.P. Unit At Fort Hamilton
description: It was difficult at first, but the military police of the Fort Hamilton Provost Marshal's office are learning to say, Yes, ma am,, instead of yes, sir, to Lieut. Mary Salerno, the first woman M.P. in the metropolitan area and one of the first 20 of her sex in the nation's armed forces police.

title: Pornography
description: Shortly after Paul E. Rothenberg moved his porno film laboratory from 29th Street and Sixth Avenue to a larger location at 75 Spring Street about 18 months ago, he was visited by two strangers.

title: WRECKING HALTED IN PHILADELPHIA
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4 Demolition of condemned buildings in the path of the Vine Street Expressway in Philadelphia's Chinatown has been halted pending the resolution of objections from the Chinese community.

title: 3 Connecticut Men Seized On Narcotic Charges Here
description: Three young Connecticut men were arrested early yesterday at the Port Authority Bus Terminal as they prepared to board a bus back to their home state with a large quantity of alleged heroin and marijuana in their luggage, the Port Authority police said.

title: Major League Averages
description: National League

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The Otis Elevator Company has leased about 124,000 square feet of office space at 750 Third Avenue as the first of several steps over the next few months to move out of its present location on the West Side.

title: LMIT ON MOVING CUTS RENT RISES
description: The city's Department of Social Services has found that new regulations limiting welfare clients to one move every two years has slowed their moving rate and curbed rent increases under vacancy decontrol.

title: Electrically Driven Runabouts Give Hope for Amsterdam's Traffic Ills
description: AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Aug. 4What is to happen to the world's big cities if traffic congestion and air pollution from automobiles continue at the present rate?

title: Legality of Indochina War Still Unsettled
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4The swift sequence of events in the Supreme Court today left open the thorny legal question of whether the American combat involvement in Indochina was ever constitutionally justified.

title: Television
description: LOW finances, high ideals, snobbery and indifference caused me to pass the first 30 years of my life without a television set. It was just last summer, in part because I had moved to a new apartment and felt I deserved a housewarming present, and in part because I was getting, in every sense, curiouser and curiouser, that I bought a set and began to experience the medium as something more than a flicker over the end of a bar or en oddity stared at at a friend's house. As I near the end of my first year as a former television virgin, I have been profoundly altered in one way: I have come to know what it means to have a habit.

title: Save the shacks!
description: The mansions and minimansions going up on our coastlines make one wonder whatever happened to the little shack on the beach. Forlorn and decaying, many still exist. Cosmetic changes can help them continue their traditional function of a modest summer retreat. Zoning complications and economy were the factors that saved this beach shack from the bulldozers. Architect Hobart Betts had purchased the little house (water poured in through the roof when it rained, he remembers, and it was near collapse) primarily for the property. It is a stretch of ocean dunes in the Hamptons. But the existing lot was too small to conform to the current zoning requirements and a variance would have been needed to build on it. Then too, says the architect, the children loved itthey liked the idea of its being a shack and became upset when it started to become neat and precise. Betts resurfaced the roof, exterior and interior surfaces throughout but stayed strictly within the shell of the existing building. Modest from the exterior, the house boasts cedarpaneled walls offset by white woods insidecool and inviting in summer, cozy and Intimate through fall and winter.

title: M. A. Greene Fiance Of Audrey de Jonge
description: TENAFLY, N. J., Aug. 4Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Curt E. de Jonge of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Audrey Frances de Jonge, to Mark Andrew Greene, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ellis Greene of New York. A Dec. 16 wedding is planned.

title: What's New in Art?
description: What's New in Art?

title: Bitterness and Sadness Grip 150 Hotel Victims
description: As they talked yesterday about the sudden disruption of their lives, the mood among many of the former residents of the University Hotel was one both of bitterness and sadness. For some residents, at least, the hotel's collapse meant that life would have to be started all over again.

title: All RollCalls in 20 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP)  Representative William H. Natcher, Democrat of Kentucky, on Wednesday completed 20 years service in the House without missing a roll call. Mr. Natcher's colleagues gave him a standing ovation.

title: HANOI IS SEEKING AID FROM UNICEF
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 4North Vietnam has begun negotiating for assistance from the United Nations Children's Fund following a visit to Hanoi by two senior officials of the aid agency.

title: Seek a Patio Long Enough, and Thou Shalt Find
description: Contentment is relative. At one time I was quite happy in my secure, unterraced apartment. It was on the 15th floor of an East Side highrise, but it had an outdoor feeling, mainly because of its double exposure.

title: Photography On View
description: Photography On View

title: San Francisco Marks 100th Anniversary of Cable Cars, Often Criticized but More Popular Than Ever
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 4 Last Saturday, Sarah Beth Gorwitz, 7 years old, of Oshkosh, Wis., was nearly squished as she attempted to board a cable car near Ghirardelli Square, a scenic complex of shops, restaurants and art galleries built around an old chocolate factoryclose to Fisherman's Wharf here.

title: Judge Curbs DriveIn
description: COVINGTON, Ky., Aug. 4 (UPI)Kenton County Circuit Judge Robert 0. Lukowsky has baned xrated movies at the Dixie Gardens DriveIn because they were distracting motorists on nearby Interstate 75.

title: Powers of the Commissioner
description: 8.13 (A) Whenever the Commissioner, after notice and hearing, decides that an owner, shareholder, partner or holder of an interest in a member club, or any player, coach, officer, director or employee thereof, or an officer, employee or official of the League has either violated the Constitution or ByLaws of the League, or has been or is guilty of conduct detrimental to the welfare of the League or professional football, then the Commissioner shall have complete authority to:

title: For a Freckled Brooklyn Girl, Pool Is No Game
description: The quiet, freckle  faced teenager from Brooklyn stared at the green expanse of the billiard table, stretched her cue toward the surface, and snapped her arm, sending an orange No. 5 ball slamming into a corner pocket. Her father smiled; she did not.

title: She's a Diamond's Best Friend
description: Not every Little League player goes into professional baseball, but one Little League mother has. Mrs. Bobbie Montgomery of Anderson, S. C., became interested in baseball eight years ago when her son, Wayne, entered the Little League. In 1970 a Detroit Tigers farm club came to Anderson and Mrs. Montgomery applied for a In job. She started Sports out as a ticketseller, was promoted to secretary and in May became general manager of the team in the Western Carolina League.

title: Has the Supreme Court Saved Us From Obscenity?
description: In its recent antiobscenity rulings, the Supreme Court gave the individual states the right to pass laws banning publications, films or plays that appeal to the prurient interest in sex, which portray, sexual conduct in a patently offensive way, and which, taken as a whole, do not have serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value.

title: Governor's Club Quietly Raises Political Funds in Dues
description: On Sept. 14, Governor Rockefeller and his wife plan to spend several hours on the terrace overlooking the pool at their Pocantico Hills mansion near Tarrytown greeting hundreds of state officials, lobbyists, bankers, businessmen, campaign contributors and possibly one reputed organizedcrime figure.

title: C. M. Coughlin Weds Elizabeth S. Walker
description: RIVERSIDE, Cnn., Aug, 4Miss Elizabeth Spence Walker, daughter of Mrs. Walter Taft Walker of Raleigh, N. C., and the late Mr. Walker, was married here this afternoon to Christopher Maher Coughlin of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Brennan Coughlin of Riverside.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. St. Louis Cardinals, doubleheader, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 1 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 9, 1 P.M.) (RadioWHN, 1 P.M.)

title: Company Criticized by A.E.C. On Leak of Radioactive Waste
description: SEATTLE, Aug. 4A leak of 115,000 gallons of radioactive wastes from a buried holding tank at the Atomic Energy Commission's Hanford nuclear plant near Richland, Wash., has led to a report sharply critical of waste management at Hanford and also an environmental lawsuit seeking continued closing of the nuclear fuel reprocessing plant.

title: Dave Anderson
description: In protesting his suspension by Pete Rozelle, the commissioner of the National Football League, Lance Rentzel said:

title: Disabled Veteran Challenges Housing Income Rule
description: A disabled World War II veteran, hoping to set an example for other veterans in publicly assisted housing, is refusing to report as income his disability pension that would make him liable for a rent surcharge on his Coop City apartment in the Bronx.

title: SILENT THIEF STEALS $176,650 IN JEWELRY
description: A thief who walked away unnoticed stole jewelry worth an estimated $176,650 yesterday from a showroom on Third Avenue near 57th Street, the police reported.

title: Music
description: JOHN PHILIP SOUSA, of all people, is in the news this summer, what with a revival of his operetta, El Capitan, rumors that the New York City Opera is considering it for 1976, and just off the University of Illinois Press, a descriptive catalogue of his works compiled, with notes and biographical material, by Paul E. Bierley. (Too bad the catalogue does not also contain the actual themes of the marches and other works, but we can't have everything.) I was unable to attend the Capitan revival, though I did hear a student performance some years back at Columbia University. Everybody, of course, knows the march, El Capitan, just as everybody knows Sousa's most famous work, The Stars and Stripes Forever. But the man composed lots and lots of music.

title: Delgado, Miss Babashoff Set 1973 Swim Records
description: MISSION VIEJO, Calif., Aug. 4 (UPI)Jorge Delgado broke the South American, Ecuadorian and meet 200meter butterfly records last night to highlight the second day of the transplanted Los Angeles invitation swim meet.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: IN their quest for a way out of their industry's baffling financial maze, some prominent Wall Street officials are beginning to embrace a provocative proposal that surfacedrather casuallyin times past. It is a call for a new governing body for the embattled securities industry.

title: Review 1  No Title
description: If these books tell us one thing, they tell us that California has always been that way, more or less, from the time the first Spaniards explored the coast and thought they had found an island, which California has remained ever since, one vast elongated state of mind, folded discreetly back against the continental belly, counterpart to obscenic Florida, its rival on the Other Side. Fra Junipero Serra, fondly nursing an ulcerating wound in hopes of sainthood, rode north from Mexico to found a string of adobe missions, converting the Indians by enslaving them, saving them for the Gringos to eradicate a hundred years later in one vast genocidal convulsion. If California is the Land of New Beginnings, it is also the Vanishing Dream and though it won't, promises Peter Briggs, Fall into the Sea, it isn't because the damned place doesn't deserve to. Insanity and greed, according to David Lavender, is the California of life.

title: 4th Star for Gen. Phillips
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) The Senate on Wednesday confirmed President Nixon's nomination of Lieut. Gen, Samuel C. Phillips for a fourth star. General Phillips is succeeding Gen. George Brown, the new Air force chief of staff, as commander of the Air Force Systems Command.

title: Apollo Nine Rallies to Beat 501 Shot on Chicago Grass
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (AP)Apollo Nine, ridden by Chris Rogers, charged from behind to win the $29,100 Chicago Handicap by 1 lengths today at Hawtjiorne Park.

title: Harry? He's Lost in the Woodwinds
description: AT first glance, if ever there ever seemed an odder pair of albums review together it would be Harry Nilsson's A Little Touch Of Schmilsson In The Night (RCA APL 10097) and Joel Grey Live! (Columbia KC 32252). What does one of our most talented young songwriters have in common with the Oscarwinning representative of showbiz tradition? On his new album, rather than using his own material, Nilsson plunges into the past to sing his favorite standards with Gordon Jenkins arrangemeats that are as contemporary as World War IL On paper it might look like a good, or at least amusing, idea, but on record it's a bore. And to see where Nilsson's gone wrong one need only listen to Grey. Even though Grey may not suit my particular musical tastes, he is being true to himself whereas Nilsson is not. Before I attack Nilsson's latest effort, let me say that I enjoy hearing the standards he does like It Had To Be You and You Made Me Love You just as much as songs by Leon Russell or Carly Simon or Chuck Berry. Frank Sinatra, Nat King Cole and Fred Astaire take frequent rides around my turntable, and that probably explains why I don't appreciate A Little Touch of Sclunilsson In The Night As skilled a writer as Nilsson is, he just doesn't have the vocal ability to do As Time Goes By or What'll I Do justice.

title: Frozen Beef
description: WASHINGTONIt was perhaps the sharpest turnaround of consumer psychology in history. The spirit of the April Fools Day boycott when housewives across the country joined forces and nearly brought the redmeat industry to its knees, reversed itself last week when many shoppers fearing scarcity and rising prices, sought to snap up all the beef they could before their neighbors got to it.

title: COWBOYS TRIUMPH OVER RAMS BY 247
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 4 (UPI) Charlie Waters intercepted two passes, returned one 54 yards for a touchdown, and lotto Stowe caught two touchdown passes last night as the Dallas Cowboys defeated the Los Angeles Rams, 247, in a preseason opener. A crowd of 75,461 at Memorial Coliseum booed the Rams for much of the game.

title: The Good Word: Dirty Business
description: I fancy I can handle that, Miss Phipps. No, me me! I'm the one, dearie. The subject of pornography has been assigned, and all the columnists are busting their buttons to have a go at it. The reader will just have to put up with this for a while, although, truth to tell, he would probably rather be writing about this fundamentally dull subject himself.

title: The Text of Douglas Decision on Bombing
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 Following is the text of the decision by Associate Justice William 0. Douglas of the Supreme Court reinstating a Federal District Court order halting the bombing of Cambodia by American forces:

title: Sylvan Setting for Sand and Sea Club Show
description: Few shows can match the site of the Sand and Sea Kennel Club's fixture. The show, which next Sunday stages its eighth edition, is held at Ocean County Park in Lakewood, N. J., the former John D. Rockefeller estate. The 325acre park, given to the county by the Rockefeller family, has three lakes and large picnic areas. Towering pine trees make it particularly appealing for a summer show.

title: Parrish Museum Displaying 22 Centuries of Art
description: SOUTHAMPTON. L.I. Twentytwo centuries of art on loan from private Southampton collectors is on display this month at the Parrish Art Museum in one of the most comprehensive shows ever assembled on Long Island.

title: Even the Musica Rocks Gently On the Metro in Mexico City
description: REFUGEE from the subways of New York City rides the Metrd in Mexico City with a growing sense that while comparisons are odious, they're also irresistible. For a straphanger beaten to an apoplectic pulp by the daily struggle with noise, dirt, gloom, tension and overcrowding on the IRT, BMT or IND, exploring the Metro is a wonderful experience: The trains invariably run on time, the rides are quiet and serene, the stations are restful to the nerves and pleasing to the eye, and the passengers are, for the most part, calm and relaxed. There is something to be said for a city that builds its subway with the comfort of the public in mind.

title: LUDWIG S. BICKHARDT
description: Ludwig S. Bickhardt, a retired partner in the Sol Mutterperl Company, women's handbag manufacturer here, died Friday in Palm Beach, where he lived. His age was 66.

title: To defend Man and the Aging Lob
description: His hair hangs boyishly over the forehead. The eyes sparkle behind thick glasses. The compact little body is slim, strong, skippy, to use his word. Does he like girls? Yes. He likes women. He likes rich women. He likes poor women. He likes young women. Only now, these days, he's a little busy; the training, the contracts, the lawyers, the appointments.

title: Morton Tells of Proposals To Promote Energy Saving
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) The Federal Government's efforts in promoting energy conservation have consisted so far of mostly jawboning, says Secretary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton. No one has taken an overall look at energy field and developed a system for conserving the supplies, he indicated.

title: Jennifer Brown Wed to John Ward
description: WYCKOFF, N. J., Aug. 4Miss Jennifer Lorraine Brown, daughter of Sherwood Gilbert Brown of Franklin Lakes and the late Mrs. Constance Queen Brown, was married this afternoon to John Bessom Ward, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph E. Ward of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Lake's Odd Tenants Identified
description: DENVILLEBryozoa have been around for 500 million years or so, and that's a long time to be taken for granted.

title: REPORT SAYS APATHY CAUSES ROAD DEATHS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4  A Congressional report has coneluded that thousands of persons die in traffic accidents each year because the nation lacks the will to apply its wisdom and technology to highway rafety.

title: The Fans Reaction: Ridiculous to Fair
description: Depending on which football fan you ask, the Rentzel suspension is everything from tough but fair to ridiculous or incredible.

title: The Adirondacks
description: The Adirondack controversy, the New York State Commissioner of Environmental Conservation, Henry Diamond, said last spring, is one of the first battles in the new front line of environmentland use. Last week, Mr. Diamond took this stand in the controversy: He rejected the first application for a major development of new vacation homes in Adirondack Park.

title: Radio
description: Radio

title: Eddie Condon, Jazz Leader for 50 Years, Dies at 67
description: Eddie Condon, the jazz guitarist who performed with most of the outstanding jazz musicians of the last half century, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital at the age of 67. He lived at 27 Washington Square North.

title: Onion Upsets 110 Secretariat, Winning Whitney by a Length
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. Aug. 4Secretariat of the Meadow Stable attracted a crowd of 30,119, a record for Saratoga racing, to the $53,850 Whitney Stakes today, but the Hobeau Farm's Onion won the race.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: James Jones's quick trip through Vietnam seems to have allowed him barely enough time to transcribe the propaganda releases of the United States and Saigon intelligence and psych war services. His treatment of the alleged Hue massacre of 1968 (In the shadow of peace, June 10) is scandalous in its lack of the slightest critical analysis of official handouts or independent investigation or knowledge of events or literature.

title: Laos
description: VIENTIANEThe champagne that was broken out last weekend by foreign diplomats in this warweary capital bubbled prematurely: Reports that five months of stalemated talks between the Government and the Communists had produced an agreement on the future of Laos gave way to the realization that some significant details remained to be settled. All the same, the champagne could flow again soon, and this time officially.

title: Music Plays A Key Role In Life Of Surgeon
description: SOUTH ORANGEDr. Conrad A. DeFilippis never had any doubts about going into medicine. He is now chief of surgery at St. Mary's Hospital in Orange and a staff surgeon at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston. But even before he began to think about medicine, he was surrounded by musicand music is still a key factor in his life.

title: 14 City Food Spots Listed as Violators Of the Health Code
description: The Health Services Administration has disclosed the names of 14 restaurants and food stores it had accused, after two inspections, of having violated the Health Code.

title: Mrs. Abzug Says City Gets Slighted on U.S. Drug Aid
description: Representative Bella S. Abzug charged yesterday that the city would receive only 7 per cent of the Federal funds allocated in fiscal 1974 for drug addict education, training and rehabilitation programs although half the nation's addicts live here.

title: Queens Motorcycle Club Is Etching a New Image
description: When 19 motorcyclists roared through the streets of Northern Queens on a scavenger hunt on a recent weekend night, there were no frantic calls to the police stationnone were expected.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: IHAVE just read, for the second time, Vincent Canby's review of Live and Let Die. I read it twice not because it is admirable, but because it is incredible. Perhaps I am unduly naive because I am just off the boatthe Queen Elizabeth 2, that is; the July 10 crossing from Southampton provided the passengers with the opportunity (if it can be called that) of seeing that film. I am not, a, Bond fan, but on shipboard one tends to go to all the films because one has the delusion that one is seeing them for free. Under no other circumstances would spend money on a Bond film.

title: Churchill Called It an Iron Fence at Potsdam
description: A T about, the same time that Leonid Brezhnev was in Washington and San Clemente, putting an end to the Cold War, I was in Potsdam, where the Cold War began. Whatever the atmosphere may be in Washington and Moscow, the Cold War is still being waged in Potsdam, where East Germans continue to mutter about neoFascists and West German munitions plants.

title: Refugees and Arms Flow Into Worried Phnotn Penh
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Aug. 4As American weapons and ammunition were pouring in by airlift yesterday at Pochentong airport on the western side of Phnom Penh, thousands of new refugees were streaming into the already swollen capital from the opposite side, fleeing from enemy assaults four miles from the city's edge.

title: Surgery Set for 2 Redskins
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) The Washington Redskins announced today that a safety, Roosevelt Taylor, and a quarterback, Sam Wyche, would undergo surgery tomorrow at Georgetown University Hospital. The two Redskins were injured in last night's loss to the Detroit Lions. Taylor suffered a fracture of his left elbow, and Wyche a broken cheekbone.

title: New Jersey
description: New Jersey

title: Murder Rate for Blacks in City 8 Times That for White Victims
description: A black resident of New York City is eight times more likely to be murdered than white resident  of the city, computer analysis of police records indicates.

title: Philippines Vote
description: MANILA  Ten months ago, Philippine President Ferdinand E. Marcos declared martial law as a temporary measure, a last desperate step to save the country from Communism and to institute drastically needed reforms.

title: LIBYA IS STRIVING FOR PURE SOCIETY
description: BENGHAZI, Libya, Aug. 4 (AP)The Arab woman places her hand in that of the Arab man to achieve the historical action of the Arab masses in going from backwardness to progress, proclaims an editorial on the women's page in a local newspaper.

title: The Circus Comes to Town On an OldFashioned Tour
description: SEA GIRT  Somewhere in New Jersey every clay this month and most of September, a band will be blaring and elephants parading as an oldfashioned circus comes to town.

title: Met Games This Week
description: TodaySt. Louis at Shea Stadium, 2, 1:05 P.M.

title: Clive Barnes is on vacation.
description: TO THE EDITOR: Rosemary Tauris's nice tribute to Cynthia Gregory, To Become a Star, AU You Need Is One Good Rival (July 8, 1973), contains a rather jarring statement to the effect that she is the first American ballerina to rise to stardom from within the ranks of the Ballet Theatre.

title: Sleep Cheap: New Budget Motels Save Travelers a Bundle
description: WHEN William Becker retired from his building business in Santa Barbara, Calif., in 1958, he loaded his wife and two children into a new Cadillac Coupe de Ville and headed east for a twomonth drive around America.

title: Paterson Hopes Rising With New Tower
description: PATERSONA $7million, 15story office tower is rising above the blighted downtown section here, and local officials hope that the new glassandsteel structure signals the resurrection of a dying city.

title: Remund Drives Pay n Pak To 2 Hydroplane Records
description: SEATTLE, Aug. 4 (AP)The Pay n Pak, badly damaged in the Gold Cup two weeks ago, warmed up today for the Seafair world championship regatta by setting two unlimited hydroplane records.

title: NEW BOOKS
description: A thoroughly documented book that sets forth a thinking atheist's position in the world today.

title: Late Listings for Today's TV
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available, in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Interrogation in Athens
description: THURSDAY, JUNE 15, 1972: At 7 o'clock in the morning I was called out to go to the Special Interrogation Center of the military police (E.S.A.). The prison director assured me that there was a warrant. I was handcuffed and put into a Black Maria. At 8:15 we arrived, and I was taken into an office which said Major Hadjizissis Nik. After a little while, a pockmarked individual in civilian clothes came in and introduced himself: Theophiloyannakos, Officer in Command. Would you like a coffee or a cool drink?

title: Surprise From Puerto Rico
description: THE Art Heritage of Puerto Rico is a smallish, interesting new show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where it has settled after a stay at the admirable Museo del Barrio in Spanish Harlem. Jointly assembled by the two museums, it is a survey of art in Puerto Rico from preColombian times to the present, augmented by slide shows documenting the island's scenic and historic beauties and, a little winsomely, by a sizable exhibit of postage stamps. Though hardly consistent in either quality or esthetic character, it contains some fine works and some surprises, and it's something to think about.

title: Child Bora to the Badens
description: A daughter was born to Dr. and Mrs. Michael Baden on July 13 at New York University Medical Center. Mrs. Baden, who is known professionally as Dr. Judianne DensenGarber, is founder and executive director of Odyssey House. Her husband is deputy chief medical examiner of New York City. The child, the couple's fourth, has been named Sarah.

title: Who Makes Music
description: Who Makes Music

title: Acrostic puzzle
description: Acrostic puzzle

title: Clustering Faces Test In Catholic Schools
description: Parents, teachers and parish priests involved in the financially strained Catholic elementary schools of the twocounty Boman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn will test a new neighborhood approach to Catholic education, called clustering, when school opens in September.

title: High Hopes or Exports
description: In Galveston, Tex., a giant cargo ship laden with grain carefully noses away from the leading dock and points its prow toward the Atlantic shipping lanes.

title: Bronx Judge Bars Devil Film, Reversing a Manhattan Jurist
description: The Devil in Miss Jones, a movie found not to be obscene in Manhattan just two weeks ago, was ordered seized as obscene by a judge in the Bronx last week, setting up the kind of geographic difference of opinion that lawyers say will become epidemic under the Supreme Court's recent pornography rulings.

title: Scott, Weld Reach Final In Manhasset Net Tourney
description: MANHASSET, LI., Aug. 4 Gene Scott of New York, the defender, and Ned Weld of Weston, Mass., reached the final of the $4,200 United States men's 35 years division clay court tennis tournament today at the Shelter Rock Tennis Club.

title: PARTY WARDS OFF AUSTRIAN DISPUTE
description: VIENNA, Aug. 4 (Reuters)Austria's smallest political party has headed off a potentially explosive national issue by disavowing a party official who said publicly that he disliked Jews.

title: NoFault Bill Supported
description: BLOOMINGTON, Aug. 4 (UPI)The nation's largest auto insurer, State Farm Mutual, has announced its support of the nofault standards bill approved by the Senate Commerce Committee.

title: Bridge
description: For most purposes, in bridge as in war, one avoids advertising the distribution of his forces and his strong points. For example, a declarer at notrump with a king  queen combination should win with the king if a low card is led and the jack is played on the right. To win with the queen would advertise possession of the king, since the opening leader would know that his partner would not play the jack from kingjack.

title: Herbert P. Vaningen Jr. Marries Janet Simmons
description: LOCUST VALLEY, Aug. 4Miss Janet Ainsworth Simmons, daughter of Mrs. Wheeler Simmons of Corpus Christi, Tex., was married here this afternoon to Herbert Pratt Van Ingen Jr., on of Mrs. Edwin F. Russell of Locust Valley and Herbert Pratt Van Ingen of Glen Cove and New York.

title: A Brooklyn Coop Settling Down
description: With only a cramped twobedroom apartment for themselves and their three children, Robert and Nancy Schiffman put down $6,500 for a sixandahalfroom apartment in Brooklyn Heights cooperative apartment called Cadman Towers that was still under construction.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Like Janus, the Roman god, the multinational enterprise is often viewed as having two faces.

title: One Good Round Doesn't Make White a Winner
description: HARRISON, N. Y., Aug. 4 Larry Who? They asked the question two years ago when Larry White led the Westchester golf classic at nine holes with a 32. They asked the same question today when Larry White combined a 31 on the back nine with a 33 on the front nine for an eightunderpar 64.

title: Governor Picks 10 to Screen Candidates for New Judgeships
description: ALBANY, Aug. 4Governor Rockefeller announced today the appointment of a 10member screening panel to review the professional qualifications of candidates recommended to the Governor for appointment as judges to handle cases under the state's new narcotics law.

title: New Arts Chief Plans Innovations
description: TRENTONBrann Wry, the new executive director of the New Jersey State Council on the Arts, brings to his post a background that few individuals can match.

title: Art
description: HE Museum of Modern Art hasn't been making much noise lately, which only proves that in spite of an error here, an error there, and a couple of bangup bloopers in its recent history, everything is under control again. Quiet is the best thing museum can be, just now.

title: Interest Grows for Drive To Save Battery's Pier A
description: Sentiment is growing among those interested in the waterfront for a formal and concerted campaign to save the Battery's Pier A. The oldfashioned structure at the tip of Manhattan Island is distinguished in several ways. It is the only remaining pier in the city that rests on a stonearch foundation. All others are built on piles. It also is one of the oldest active piers in the port, dating back to 1885. It contains in its clock tower the first World War I memorial ever dedicated in this country. And, the clock in the 70foot tower is distinguished by the fact that it tells time by pealing ship's bells every hour on the hour.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: I think he's first rate. He took over a situation that had deteriorated quite a bit, held the staff together and strengthened the office.

title: Stamps
description: LINDON SON rode Air Force One like a stallion, galloping over the plains of the airways, a reporter once noted with deep insight, for in a special sense, to his mind and manner, the nation was his range.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Shipping/Mails

title: Mugged Police Decoy Helps Seize
description: Eight youth gang members who were reported to have been harassing mostly older people were arrested shortly before 1 A.M. yesterday after they attacked a decoy police officer near a Queens subway station, the police said.

title: NEW INQUIRY URGED ON JACKSON STATE
description: The Justice Department was urged yesterday to follow up its reopening of the investigation into the Kent State University shooting on May 4, 1970, by ordering a new inquiry into the killing of two black students at Jackson State College in Mississippi 11 days later.

title: The spirit is sublime
description: Grand Marnier, that sublime orangeflavored liqueur, was named by the famous Cesar Ritz, founder of the Paris Ritz. A wealthy vineyard owner, one Marnier Lapostolle, who concocted the liqueur, brought a sample to M. Ritz and asked him to taste it. M. Ritz did  and liked it. Lapostolle then posed his big question. He wanted to market the drink and needed a name for it. Ritz considered the vineyard owner, whose lack of stature was compensated for by his outsize ego, and suggested dryly that he call it Le Grand Marnier. The pouding given below is one of the best desserts made with the liqueur. It is superb served either with a crme anglaise oreven betterthe Grand Marnier sauce that is a specialty of New York's La Grenouille restaurant.

title: Charles Winstead, F.B.I. Agent Who Shot Dillinger, Dies at 82
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Aug. 4 (UPI)  Charles Winstead, who was credited with firing two of the bullets that killed John Dillinger outside the Biograph Theater in Chicago, in 1934, died yesterday at the Albuquerque Veterans Hospital. He was 82 years old.

title: Maker of Roof Water Tanks Goes Straight to Top
description: When Harry Dalton, an immigrant from Ireland, died in 1896, he left behind a struggling barrelmaking business on the Lower East Side. His wife, Mary, who had no knowledge of the craft, sold the business to her husband's assistant, Harris Rosenwach, for $55, the price of her hu'sband's funeral.

title: Presidential Homes
description: SAN CLEMENTEWhy did he want it at all? Five bedrooms, ten rooms in all. Badly in need of repair. All that land. In fact, he couldn't really afford It.

title: Travel by Rail on the Rise, But Poor Service Persists
description: Rail travel is surging across the country this summer.

title: U.S. Families in Singapore Act on Youth Drug Abuse
description: SINGAPORE, Aug. 4 (AP)The American community in Singapore has formed a council to fight drug abuse among its children.

title: RESCUERS SEARCH DESPITE DANGERS
description: For the firemen and policemen who searched for survivors amid the rubble of what was the University Hotel, the threats that faced them were no deterrent.

title: Prophets of the sawdust trail
description: Faith healers, tent prophets, bawlandstomp radio Gantrys, superpatriots, semimystics, public beggars, publishers of their own bestselling books, founders of minor colleges and cities, big business men, friends (or adversaries) of Presidents, enthusiastic dispensers of varied procrustean gospelsthese are The Preachers, leaders of a loose fundamentalist mass movement that now threatens to become the new religious and political mainstream of America.

title: 50 Artists Discuss Jewish Creativity
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 3Fifty American Jewish and Israeli writers, artists and critics ended a fourday symposium today with only partial agreement on the sources of Jewish creativity.

title: A Wyoming Gas Station On a Busy Summer Day
description: LANDER, Wyo., Aug. 4 At 5:30 A.M. the alarm clock goes off at 1295 Goodrich Drive here. Within minutes, Jack Neels is up, shaven and driving his 1961 Jeep to work, A few minutes before 6 A.M. he opens the door, unlocks the cash register and turns on the pumps.

title: Waldheim's Daughter Is Engaged
description: Miss Liselotte Waldheim, eldest daughter of the United Nations Secretary General Kurt Waldheim and Mrs. Waldheim, will be married Aug. 18 in Geneva to Pierre Natural, a Swiss lawyer. He is the son of Albert Louis Natural, Swiss Ambassador to Peking, and Mrs. Natural.

title: Bigger Than Woodstock, But Was It Better?
description: It's the biggest nonpolitical event itt the Wstern world!Enthusiastic reporter at the Watkins Glen rock festival.

title: CAMBODIANS REPORT A REBEL GAS ATTACK
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Aug. 4 (AP)Cambodian insurgents today launched a gas attack against Government troops on Phnom Penh's southern defense perimeter six miles from the city, the military command reported. Newsmen were not allowed to visit the battle area to verify the Government report.

title: See Satan burn in the Lake of Fire!
description: Milton always knew he was going to write an epic poem. It was part of the heritage he sought as he traced the footsteps of Vergil and Spenser along what Byron with respectful mockery later called the heroic turnpike road. When a great poet was young, he tried his wings in lyric and pastoral; but in his age and wisdom he wrote epic, in which all of maws activities and the universe itself could be the field for his play and thoughts.

title: What's at the Movies?
description: THE LAST AMERICAN HERO, directed by Lamont Johnson from a screenplay by William Roberts and staring Jeff Bridges, Valerie Perrine and Geraldine Fitzgerald, got nine favorable reviews (Roger Greenspun, Times; Jerry Oster, News; Archer Winsten, Post; Howard Kissel, Women's Wear; Bernard Drew, Gannett News Service; Leonard Harris, WCBSTV; Gene Shalit, NBC; Chris Chase, New York; William Wolf, Cue) and three mixed (Frances Taylor, Newhouse Newspapers; Jeffrey Lyons, WPIXTV; Jay Cocks, Time).
