title: HARTFORD MAY HIRE CAPITAL LOBBYIST
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 7 (UPI)Hartford is ready to spend 1$27,000 for a lobbyist in Washington, Councilman George Levine said today.

title: Yet Anothe Plan for Battery City
description: The Battery Park City Authority named the developers yesterday for a sizable portion of the $1.1billion development in Lower Manhattan and in the process revealed a physical design that differs from an earlier and much more innovative one.

title: LID ON BEEF PRICE UPHELD BY JUDGE
description: Judge Robert F. Peckham of United States District Court in San Francisco upheld yesterday the Federal price ceilings on beef. He made his ruling in rejecting a bid by California beef wholesalers for an injunction against the Cost of Living Council, which President Nixon has directed to enforce beef price ceilings until Sept. 12.

title: Turbocharged Porsches Ruling CanAm Circuit
description: Time was, until just a couple of years ago, that a Porsche was considered an oddball at a CanAm race. It had nowhere near the horsepower of the McLarenChevrolets that were mopping up the circuit. Then the German factory figured how to apply turbocharging to road racing. Last season a pair of Roger Penske turbo  Porsches ran the McLaren team off the road, and the McLaren people haven't been heard from since. Now the Porsches are dominating the CanAm series with turbochraged versions of the 91710, formerly king of the enduranceracing circuit.

title: U.S. INDICTMENTS EXPECTED IN CASE INVOLVING AGNEW
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 7  Federal officials said today that indictments were expected within weeks in an investigation intc bribery, extortion and tax fraud charges involving Vice President Agnew and some of hii closest political and financial associates.

title: Rules for Phase 4 Permit Some Price Rises of 10%
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7The Government set the stage today for the end of the price freeze Monday and a probable early increase in many prices.

title: RITES FOR ULBRICHT ARE HELD IN BERLIN
description: BERLIN, Aug. 7The Communist German Democratic Republic and the international hierarchy of orthodox Communism today paid a farewell to Walter Ulbricht, the East German head of state who died last Wednesday of heart failure. He was 80 years old.

title: ExOfficial to Aid in Shift
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 7 (AP)Lonnie C. King Jr., who was dismissed yesterday as president of the Atlanta branch of the N.A.A.C.P. says he will cooperate with the national organization's efforts to assume control of the local office. The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said that it had removed Mr. King and other officers of the Atlanta branch because of their failure to oppose a controversial school desegregation plan in that city.

title: Utility Plans Expansion
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Aug. 7 (AP) The New York State Electric and Gas Corporation expects to spend $1.1billion on new power  generating facilities by 1982, the utility says in a report to the State Public Service Commission. One of its major new power projects under construction or planned is a 1,200,megawatt nuclear plant at Somerset in Niagara County.

title: Meat Shortages Are Detailed by City
description: Now is the time, Betty Furness, the city's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, said yesterday, to put away the steak knives and get out the poultry shears and omelette pans.

description: Dangerous Drugs said that Davron should come under narcotics control. Lilly, the producer of Davron, said it would oppose such a move.

title: Two More Oil Wells Found By Occidental Petroleum
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug, 7 (AP)  The Occidental Petroleum Corporation announced today that it had discovered two more oil wells on its 2.9millionacre contract area in the Amazon basin of Peru.

title: President Back in Capital After Drafting Statement
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UPI) President Nixon returned here. (today from an unexpected visit to Camp David, where he put the finishing touches on a paper giving his account of the Watergate affair.

title: Bankrupt Rail Lines Greet Cahill's Proposals Coolly
description: TRENTON, Aug. 7  Governor Cahill today gave the trustees of four bankrupt rail lines his recommendations for consolidating their freight operations as a means of reducing operating costs. But he received no commitments from any of the railroad officials.

title: Federal Prosecutor for Maryland George Beall
description: I regard myself as a tough act to follow, Stephen H. Sachs said yesterday, and George is following it.

title: Brazilian Farmers Switching Emphasis To Soybean Export
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 7Soaring soybeanexport prices are turning Brazilian farmers from their usual crops needed on the home market.

title: Astronauts Settle Down to Routine Jobs
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 7 After days of motion sickness, nights of missionthreatening malfunctions and hours outside rigging a new sunshade, the Skylab 2 astronauts were able to settle down today for the first time to business as usual.

title: Governor Keeping An Aloof Attitude In Marchi's Race
description: Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that he doubted he would campaign actively for State Senator Joh J. Mnarchi the Republican candidate for Mayor, noting that in his role as Governor he was reluctant to involve himself in local partisan politics.

title: 2 HighSpeed French Turbotrains Arrive for Service on Amtrak Lines
description: Two highspeed turbotrains, built in France for service on Amtrak lines in the Middle West, were unloaded from the freighter, Atlantic Cognac, at Port Elizabeth, N. J., yesterday. The trains are capable of 125 miles an hour over conventional tracks and are to be used on ChicagoMilwaukee and ChicagoSt. Louis runs. Each has five cars and seating for 320 passengers.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Nu Dimensions Figure Salons, Inc., will revise its advertising, contracts and sales techniques, under terms of an agreement with the city's Department of Consumer Affairs, which had accused the reducing salon chain of pieinthesky claims of pound and inch losses without diet or exercise.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The Eastside Playhouse, 334 East 74th Street, will be the new home, beginning next Tuesday, of One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest, one of four shows at the Mercer Arts Center in the University Hotel, which collapsed last Friday.

title: Fishing for Fun: The Blues
description: ABOARD THE TOPLESS, in Long Island Sound Smell that? asked David Griffin, shouting with excitement. Like freshcut grass. It's blues.

title: East Berlin Cheers Comic Opera Eclat
description: EAST BERLINWalter Felsenstein, the opera director, is not well known in America, outside of a limited circle of admirers who have seen his work in East Berlin or on one of his company's rare tours. Mr. Felsenstein's art does not travel very well. His rehearsal demands would seem to preclude his guestdirecting a production in an American opera house. And despite periodic rumors that it is about to happen, his Komische Oper has yet to perform in the United States.

title: Records: Marilyn Horne and Rossini
description: Marilyn Horne is an opera singer of amazing technical prodigality who nonetheless manages with alarming regularity to drive some of her admirers into a rage. The reason is that for all her gifts and ebullient personality, Miss Horne often falls short of what she could and should achieve. Instead of breathless virtuosity, she indulges in musical vulgarity; instead of genuine drama she falls back on cheap melodrama.

title: A loi, Reputed Mafia Chief, Gets Up to 7 Years for Lying to Jury
description: Vincent Aloi, 40yearold reputed chief of the Mafia's Colombo family, was sentenced to up to seven years in prison yesterday for lying to a grand fury that investigated the slaying of rival gang leader, Joseph Gallo.

title: 155 STUDENTS HELD IN RHODESIA RIOTING
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Aug. 7A total of 155 black students of the University of Rhodesia, including five women, were arrested here today during a violent demonstration.

title: Prices Stir Branding
description: CHARLESTON, Ill., Aug. 7 (UPI) The first cattle brand to be registered in Coles County since July 27, 1889, was entered in the county records yesterday. Wayne Andres of Mattoon, Ill., paid the 15cent fee required under a state law passed in 1872 and registered his CircleA brand. With meat prices so high, people are going to either steal or slaughter somebody's stock, Mr. Andres explained.

title: Rennie Taylor Dead at 77; A Science Writer for A.P.
description: SANTA ROSA, Calif., Aug. (AP)Rennie Taylor, a former science writer for The Associated Press, died yesterday after a stroke. He was 77 years old.

title: Guru Gets Testimonial And Some Pie in Face
description: DETROIT, Aug. 7 (UPI)Guru Maharaj Ji, the 15yearold from India called the perfect master by his followers, went to City Hall yesterday to receive a testimonial resolution praising his workand got a cream pie in the face.

title: Mr. Nixon And Burke's Law
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7If President Nixon were merely faced by a legal tangle over letting the courts and the Congress see the relevant parts of his Watergate tapes, his argument before the United States District Court here, might help him in his present predicament, but that is not really or even mainly his problem.

title: ByrnesMcCaffrey Merges With Bayly, Martin & Fay
description: ByrnesMcCaffrey, a leading Chicago insurance broker, has merged with Bayly, Martin & Fay, one of the nation's 10 largest commercial insurancebrokerage concerns, it was announced yesterday. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Delta and Federal Agency In Accord on Data on Crash
description: BOSTON, Aug. 7 (AP)Delta Airlines and the Federal Aviation Administration reached today a temporary agreement for Delta to receive copies and transcripts of control tower tape recordings related to the jetliner crash at Logan International Airport last Tuesday.

title: Lindsay Extols Virtues Of Downtown Manhattan
description: Mayor Lindsay became a spieler for two hours yesterday as he took a troop of media representatives on a tour of downtown Manhattan, an area of vast transformation, where wooden shacks have given way to skyscrapers, where canopied plazas, galleries and a world of pedestrian bridges has been growing at a cost of billions of dollars.

title: YANKS WIN, 31, AFTER 21 LOSS
description: The Yankees can't be certain whether they're home or still on the road.

title: Fashion Lapses: The Paris Shows Had Their Share
description: Fun and games are over for most of the Paris couture houses. They've settled down, in their fall collections, to do beautiful, elegant fashions for women who prefer to buy their clothes in posh salons rather than off plain pipe racks. Which is what makes the lapses so outrageous.

title: SUPERSTAR' FILM RENEWS DISPUTES:Jewish Groups Say Opening Could Stir Anti-Semitism Reasons Given Company Issues Statement
description: The movie version of "Jesus Christ Superstar" opens here today, and the religious controversy that accompanied the stage production when it came to Broadway two years ago has shown no sign of dying down.Benjamin R. Epstein, national director of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, warned yesterday that the movie a rock musical about the events leading to the crucifixion of Jesus, could result in increased anti-Semitism by its emphasis on the role of the Jews in the death of Jesus.And the American Jewish Committee has compiled critical comments about the film from Jewish and Christian leaders around the country that it plans to make public this morning to coincide with the movie's opening at six metropolitan-area theatres.In his prepared statment, Mr. Epstein said that "the movie's sharp and vivid emphasis on a Jewish mob's demand to kill Jesus can feed into the kind of disparagement of Jews and Judaism which has always nurtured anti-Jewish prejudice and bigotry.""Even the casting is of the most primitive type," Mr. Epstein said. "Anyone who has ever seen cowboy films knows that the good guys wear white hats and the bad guys wear black. Here the actor portraying Jesus is blond; Judas is black; the priests and rabbis are dark-haired, foreboding, and garbed in black." The role of Jesus is played by Ted Neeley. Carl Anderson plays Judas in the film.Reasons GivenThe A.D.L. director said his organization would not be so concerned if the movie were not likely to attract "large numbers of impressionable young people" by its "exciting rock format and beautiful photography," or if "people were emotionally healthy and free prom prejudice."However, he said, the change that the Jews killed Jesus is still a basic cause of anti-Semitism in the world, although "Christian leaders themselves have repeatedly condemned as reprehensible the notion that Jews, rather than all mankind, are responsible for Jesus' death."For its part, the American Jewish Committee is especially concerned about the effect of the movie's message when it goes into worldwide distribution to such areas as South America, the Middle East and Italy. The A.J.C. will make public today suggestions to "mitigate damage" from the film's release.Norman Jewison, the director, co-producer and screenplay collaborator on the movie, is vacationing in Canada and could not be reached for comment on the latest round of criticism about "Jesus Christ Superstar."Company Issues StatementIn a prepared statement, Universal Pictures, which is releasing the movie, described "Jesus Christ Superstar" as "a rock opera, a musical entertainment, not a religious tract.""With every respect for the sincerity and concern expressed," Universal's prepared statement continued, "we do not believe their views to be supported by the content of the film or shared by the many millions who have listened to the music or viewed the concert and stage presentations throughout the world since 1970."When the stage production opened in October, 1971, it was criticized not only by some Jews as anti-Semitic, but also by some Catholics and Protestants as blasphemous in its portrayal of Jesus as a young man who might even be interested in sex. The movie was filmed in Israel.

title: The Calls From Beginning Called It a Double Murder
description: From the very beginning, we knew that it was murder and not suicide, John Cali said yesterday as he recalled the deaths of his wife and stepdaughter last May 14.

title: Babylon Town Board Faces Tough Decision: Should It Reject State Apartment Project in Wyandanch?
description: NORTH LINDENHURST, L. L, Aug. 7Just in case the five members of the Babylon Town Board had forgotten the major decision they must make within 18 days, a crowd showed up for the monthly meeting today, to remind them.

title: ALBERT L. KRESS, 79, BUSINESS ENGINEER
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 7Albert L. Kress, a management engineer who had been a vice president of ACF Industries, Inc., died Sunday at his home, 180 Springdale Road. He was 79 years old.

description: ABOARD THE TIDELAND, off Lido Beach  We like to see a few of those bluefish, said Norman Edwards, the slender, weatheredlooking skipper of the Tideland, his blue eyes scanning the surface of the Atlantic for turbulence, for dark apartments. He turned their patches or seagulls or other signs that might betray the presence of a school of menhaden.

description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Aug. 7The national policy committee of the Jewish War Veterans called upon its members and friends today to institute an immediate boycott of he products of Standard Oil of California and its subsidiaries.

description: TORONTO, Aug. 7 (AP)Gulf Oil Canada, Ltd., raised its purchase price for Western Canadian crude oil today by 40 cents a barrel, retroactive to Aug. 1.

description: William T. Brady, who was press relations chief for Consolidated Edison Company of New York from 1948 to his retirement in 1965, died yesterday at his home, 34 Gramercy Park. He was 72 years old.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7The Senate Watergate Committee unceremoniously completed the first phase of its inquiry into the Watergate case today after hearing a detailed defense of the Government's muchcriticized original investigation.

title: 2 Harvard Hockey Stars Are Signed by Penguins
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 7 (UPI) The Pittsburgh Pengins announced the signing today of two Harvard University amateurs Bob McManama, a center, and Doug Elliott, a defensemanand said they would report Sept. 9 to their national Hockey League training camp at Brantford, Ontario. McManama, a 1973 allAmerican from Belmont, Mass., scored 27 goals in 22 games last season in leading Harvard to a secondplace finish in the Ivy League.

description: TOKYO, Aug. 7The Government named 10 American universities today to share equally in a $10million educational project for Japanese studies, carrying out a plan announced by Premier Kakuei Tanaka in a joint communiqu after his meeting with President Nixon in Washington last week.

description: Mrs. Arnold Schwartz, an author and journalist, has been elected to the board of trustees, of New York University, John M. Schiff, board chairman, announced yesterday.

description: Harold S. Geneen, chairman of the International Telephone, and Telegraph Corporation, has denied that he blamed Robert S. McNamara, a former Secretary of Defense, for the Vietnam war and the Edsel automobile.

description: ALBANY, Aug. 7 (AP)Governor Rockefeller appointed State Advisory Committee on Mental Health today and designated former State Senator Dalwin J. Niles of Johnstown as chairman.

title: Jersey Man Found Dead
description: McAFEE, N.J., Aug. 7 (AP)The body of Kenneth Wallace, 30 years old, of Hamburg, who apparently died of asphyxiation, was found in a parking lot near here today, State Police said. The police were investigating the death, which they termed suspicious.

title: Mets, Saved by McGraw, Top Cards, 65
description: Things may be looking up for the New York Mets. They beat the divisionleading St. Louis Cardinals, 65, yesterday at Shea Stadium for the second straight day with a performance not in keeping with their status as cellar dwellers in the National League East.

title: A NEW BHUTTO ROLE PLANNED IN PAKISTAN
description: KARACHI, Pakistan Aug. 7 (AP)  President Zulfikar AU Bhutto will not run for President under Pakistan's new Constitution but will be nominated by the ruling People's party to he Prime Minister, it was announced today.

title: 10 Cubans Sail to Florida
description: KEY WEST, Fla., Aug. 7 (AP) Ten Cuban refugees who had crossed the Florida Straits through rough seas in a homemade 16foot boat were taken into Key West yesterday by a Coast Guard cutter after their small outboard engine quit, A father, his two teenage sons and seven other men, who said they had little to eat since they left Cuba four days ago, ate sandwiches and drank Cuban coffee after their rescue. All were reported in good condition.

title: EQUIPMENT FLAW HINTED IN 2D RAID
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 Jerry W. Friedheim, Defense Department spokesman, said today that the United States Air Force suspects equipment malfunction as the cause of the accidental bombing of proGovernment elements in Cambodia early today in which it was reported here that four persons were killed and eight wounded.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7Eight persons were arrested today and charged with disrupting the Senate Watergate hearings after they began reading a statement accusing the Central Intelligence Agency of intervening in domestic political life.

description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday named the three public members to the city's newly created Rehabilitation Mortgage Insurance Corporation, which is expected to stimulate private participation in preserving and rehabilitating existing housing.
