Nova Scotia  For mile upon mile toward the end of a thousandmile automobile trip from Massachusetts, fog enveloped the rocky, coveindented, treelined Atlantic Coast of Nova Scotia, but inspiring one to push on was the St. Mary's River, one of the province's best summer salmon streams.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Confirmation that the California Bar Association has in fact undertaken a preliminary investigation into the actions of the President and other lawyers involved in the Watergate matter should serve as a spur to other bar associations New York comes promptly to mindto commence similar proceedings involving lawyers whose ethically questionable conduct has been established.

title: Cheriepe Scores at Saratoga
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 8A race that recalls an event that is famous in the annals of Saratoga, the Jim Dandy, had its 10th running today. Its fame rests mainly on the fact that it is named for a horse that helped give this racing center its sobriquet as the graveyard of At the champions. Jim Dandy, quoted at Race 1001, beat the Tracks formidable pair of Gallant Fox and Whichone in the 1930 Travers.

title: 14 on South African Trawler Feared Lost After Collision
description: CAPETOWN, Aug. 8 (Reuters) The entire crew of 14 on the South African trawler Harvest Dealmar were feared drowned after the vessel was apparently involved in a collision with an unidentified tanker yesterday, the trawler's owners said here.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Gaylord Perry has confessed. He threw a spitball for the first, but hardly the last, time in his major league career in 1964.

title: SEVERAL BOMBINGS REPORTED IN ULSTER,
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 8 (UPI)Bombers were active throughout the province during the day today. Meanwhile, a special police watch, was mounted at all ports in Northern Ireland and Britain after threats of a bombing campaign in London from a small Roman Catholic extremist group, called the Irish Citizens Army, security officials reported.

title: His Suitcase Is for Picture Frames
description: He has played the piano with small groups that toured the country and he liked that but now he has set himself up in business here and he calls himself Tom The Framer. That is because he frames pictures and he learned how to do it by working in a number of art galleries. Also, he studied at the Art Students League.

title: 20c PATH Fare Rise Is Stayed By I.C.C., Pending Added Study
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8The, Interstate Commerce Commisston today suspended, pending further investigation, a 20cent fate increase requested by PATH, the Port AuthorityTrans Hudson rail commuter line between New York and New Jersey.

title: A 2Year Bowl Ban For Okla.
description: KANSAS CITY, Aug. 8 (AP) The Big Eight Conference dealt the University of Oklahoma football team, ranked No. 2 nationally in 1971 and 1972, a severe blow today by placing the Sooners on probation for two years for recruiting irregularities.

title: White Lightning' Strikes Local Houses
description: "White Lightning," which opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters, is a fairly awful movie that keeps producing good thingsscenes, performances, moments of insightthat seem connected to better ideas than anything suggested in the film's larger intentions. There are enough of those good things so that I shouldn't mind seeing more work directed by Joseph Sargent, or written by William Norton, or featuring such performers as Jennifer Billingsley, Ned Beatty or Matt Clark.In form, "White Lightning" is straightforward revenge melodrama. Gator McKlusky (Burt Reynolds), a convicted Arkansas moonshiner, is let out of prison so he can help establish evidence for a Federal case against a particularly evil and law-breaking small-town sheriff (Ned Beatty). But Gator has his own reasons, the sheriff's killing of his college-student kid brother mainly because the boy wore his hair long and espoused good government, and he means to get more than evidence.For reasons that I'm sure are clearer to the producers than they are to me, half of this action involves endless car chases, which are a crushing bore. The other half involves human relationsbetween Gator and the wild girl (Miss Billingsley) he is attracted to, between Gator and the helpless whisky runner (Matt Clark) he makes use ofand sometimes these are very interesting indeed.Burt Reynolds may by now have a bare-chest clause in his contract, because you see a lot of his bare chestfor example, in flirtation scenes with Miss Billingsley where you don't see any of hers. What you do see of her is a rather complex and subtle characterization of a girl more vulnerable than she seems. In fact, all the local types, like Matt Clark, Bo Hopkins, or R. G. Armstrong (all in the moonshine business) are more complete and more resilient than the situation strictly demands.Ned Beatty makes of Sheriff Connors one of those bland phlegmatic manifestations of evil that have from time to time been such a specialty of the South as shown in American movies. And there are sequences involving himsome of the best take place inside the sheriff's office  that seem unexpectedly intricate and cleverly paced, and on the way to rather exciting film making.

title: Nero Wolfe is the greatest detective in the United States. Inspector Maigret is the greatest detective in France. Wolfe detects only when he's not dining. Maigret dines only when.he's not detecting. Wolfe loves food because he is eccentric. Maigret loves food because he is French. Maigret eats better than Wolfe.
description: The foregoing deductions emerge from a long degustation of the scholarly works of Rex Stout and Georges Simenon, and a pleasurable nibble at the year's most forgivable gimmick cookbook. That is The Nero Wolfe Cook, by Rex Stout & the Editors of The Viking Press, just published and a bargain at $7.95.

title: PRICES OF STOCKS TAKE SHARP DROP
description: The stock market, which traditionally abhors uncertainty, suffered a substantial decline yesterday in the face of uncertainties on the moneyrate, economic and political fronts.

title: Track's No. I Winner Never Cashed a Bet
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, Aug. 8 (AP)The man who made the most money at Monmouth Race Track today never bet a dime on a horse.

title: AGNEW DISPUTED ON BRIBE REPORT
description: AGNEW DISPUTED ON BRIBE REPORT

title: 41 Teachers From Japan Hereto Sharpen English
description: PRINCETON, Aug. 8Each weekday morning at 8:40, 41 Japanese teachers gather in underground seminar rooms at the Woodrow Wilson School for Public and International Affairs for another lesson in American life and language.

title: Watergate Staff Looks for Perjury As Weary Senators Start Vacations
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8As members of the Senate Watergate committee scattered wearily toward their home states today, the committee's investigators began to study 7,573 pages of testimony in search of potential cases of criminal perjury.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SERENE SCENES It's high August and hot. You're stuck in the city. For a quick escape to country vistaswaterfalls, lakes, forests, gristmills, mountans, streams go direct to the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West at 77th Street (8733400). There, in the cool, immaculate fourthfloor galleries, take a transcontinental woodland walk through Summershow: The American Landscape, 93 paintings by 23 artists depicting 19thcentury America, when man's handiwork and nature's ecology were in a happier balance.

title: Levitz Moving Headquarters
description: Levitz Furniture Corporation yesterday announced that its national headquarters would be moved from Pottstown, Pa., to Miami within the next sixty days. The company's national accounting operations will remain in Pottstown. Scheduled to move to the Florida location are Henry J. Morgan, senior vice president and secretary; Patrick J. Nolan, senior vice president and treasurer and Frank W. Bonheim, vice president and personnel director.

title: Equity Financing
description: A nonregistered secondary offering of 250,000 common shares of Western Union Co. at $17.75 per share was sold out yesterday by Salomon Brothers and Oppenheimer & Co. The company's stock closed unchanged at 18 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: JAZZMEN PERFORM AT CONDON'S RITES
description: Eddie Condon's guitar was propped in front of his coffin yesterday afternoon as a tribute during a funeral service that drew about 150 friends and relatives.

title: Rennert, After One Upset, Ousted in Columbia Tennis
description: Peter Rennert of Great Neck L.I. upset one seeded player and extended another through three tough sets before being eliminated from the 16yearold section of the Columbia tennis championships for juniors and boys yesterday at Baker Field.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: DisasterAid Office Opens

title: Rhapsody on Some Chihuahuas
description: Music and dogs go handinhand at the home of Capt. and Mrs. Manuel Rodriguez. Mrs. Rodriguez, a former concert pianist, frequently is either at the keyboard or listening to concertos on her stereo recordplayer.

title: COMPUTER FRAUD LAID TO A L.I. MAN
description: The Federal Government charged yesterday that an operations manager of the Westinghouse Corporation's appliancesales division in Greenvale, L.I., tricked a computer system he had devised to embezzle nearly $1million.

title: EDWIN TUNIS DIES; CHILDREN'S AUTHOR
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 8Edwin Tunis, an author and illustrator of children's books, died yesterday at the Greater Baltimore General Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in suburban Reisterstown.

title: ARMCO PROGRAM SEEN IN JEOPARDY
description: BEIRUTOil interests here speculate that the recent veto by United States of the antiIsrael resolution in the United Nations may have placed in jeopardy a multimillion dollar development program by Aramco to increase oil production from Saudi Arabia.

title: Books of The Times
description: The French are so obsessed with status, says Frederick Brown, that Pere Lachaise, Paris's most select cemetery, serves to enshrine an ossified social hierarchy. To be buried there is to achieve a statutory immortality. In life, like Beckett's antiheroes, we inhabit nowhere; only the dead  enjoy place. Here, absolute selfhood is forever guaranteed to those most fearful of selfloss.

title: OUSTER IS SOUGHT OF SCHOOL BOARI
description: Attorney General Louis J Lefkowitz will move in court today or tomorrow to set aside last May's election of the community school board in District 17 in Central Brooklyn, sources in his office said yesterday.

title: CabRights Dispute Snags Newark Airport Service
description: NEWARK, Aug. 8Passengers arriving at the new terminal at Newark International Airport, flown in across state and national boundaries today, landed in the middle of a territorial dispute between cab drivers from Essex and Union Counties.

title: Nixon Picks ExConsultant
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) A former management consultant, Joseph T. McCullen Jr. of Bethesda, Md., was named today by President Nixon to be Assistant Secretary of the Navy for manpower and reserve affairs.

title: Agnew Suddenly Shares In Nixon Legal Dilemma
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8Vice President Agnew is suddenly contending with some of the same complex and controversial legal questions that have been taxing President Nixon and his lawyers for months.

title: Army Recruiting Short of Goal; 35% of Those Joining Are Black
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (UPI)For the sixth consecutive month since the draft was discontinued, the Army failed in July to reach its recruiting goals, it was announced today.

title: Music: Adis and Galatea
description: Handel's Adis and Galatea is a pastoriat masque. Even though it may have been surrounded by elaborate stage machinery when first produced, it is one of Handel's more delicate and graceful pieces, full of murmuring felicities as well as such bravura coloratura arias as the basso's Ruddier Than the Cherry (the one bloodandthunder piece of singing in the otherwise quiet work).

title: Dr. David Brotman, Head Of General Health Services
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 8Dr. David M. Brotman, founder, president, chief executive officer and principal shareholder of General Health Services, Inc., died, apparently of a heart attack, in his office today. He was 66 years old and lived in Beverly Hills.

title: Demonetization Feared
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 8  Rumors of imminent demonetization of large denomination currency notes in India have flooded the banks with large bills and forced the Government to issue repeated denials of any such plans.

title: SAIGON SEES THREAT TO SESSIONS IN PARIS
description: PARIS, Aug, 8 (Reuters) Deputy Premier Nguyen Luu Vien of South Vietnam warned today that a Communist takeover in Phnom Penh would jeopardize the Vietnam peace accord and cause his Government to reconsider its attitude on talks with the Vietcong here concerning South Vietnam's political future.

title: AGNEW SAYS DAMNED LIES TO REPORT OF KICKBACKS; DOUBTS HE'LL BE INDICTED
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8Vice President Agnew went on national television today to denounce as damned lies reports that he took kickbacks from government contractors in Maryland.

title: June Construction Starts Sharply Below 72 Level
description: WASHINGTON, Aug.8 (Reuters)The Department of Housing and Urban Development reported today that total applications nd construction starts under H.U.D.Federal Housing Administration mortgage insurance programs were higher in June than in May but sharply below the level in June of last year.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 24yearold Queens woman went to court yesterday to thank a judge for giving her an 18month prison sentence. Pearl Counts of 11672 197th Street, St. Albans, had pleaded guilty to passing forged checks for drug dealers. Criminal Court Judge John DiLeonardo, who could have sentenced her to up to 15 years, gave her an 18month sentence. She was released March 22 from Rikers Island where she took part in an extensive rehabilitation program. Yesterday she told the judge, I want to thank you very much for helping me. I'm staying out of trouble and I'm doing well. The judge replied, I'm happy to see you doing so wellgood luck to you.

title: DECISION RESERVED ON APPEAL OF I.B.M.
description: The United States Court of Appeals yesterday reserved decision on an appeal by the International Business Machines Corporation of a contempt order in pretrial proceedings in the Justice Department's antitrust suit against the giant computer company.

title: The Suspicious 17
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8From mid1969 to February of 1971, at the direction of the President, the F.B.I. tapped the home telephones of 17 men four newsmen and 13 Government officials  to find out why classified information had appeared in the press and to prevent future leaks.

title: JOHN H. LYONS
description: John H. Lyons of 41.20 53d Street, Woodside, Queens, an insurance broker for 45, years, died Tuesday night in St. Charles Hospital, Port Jefferson, L. I. His age was 73.

title: Film: Animated Heavy Traffic Opens
description: In the glass top of a pinball machine the figures start to materialize, like emanations from the mind of a player obsessed with a game that can only end in TILT. They strut, creep, hobble out into the squalid streets these characters whose passing miseries, become the substance of Heavy Traffic, Ralph Bakshi's animated movie, a cruel, funny, heartbreaking love note to a city kept alive by its freaks, and always, always dying.

description: Yoohoo, Mrs. Goldberg! Was that yoohoo for me, Mrs. Bloom?

title: TEXASGULF CALLS CANADA BID A PLOT
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 8 (AP)Lawyers for Texasgulf, Inc., charged today that the Canadian Governmentthrough its Canadian Development Corporation  had conspired with that nation's largest mining company to attempt to take over Texasgulf.

description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 8Three decades after Pearl Harbor, Japanese traders are taking advantage of the devalued dollar by quietly buying up some of the highest priced chips in the bluechip game of thoroughbred hreeding.

description: CROSSWORD PUZZLE

title: Joynding Blamed In 3 Girls Deaths On LIRR Tracks
description: GARDEN CITY, L. L, Aug. 9 The police said today that the accident in which three teenage girls were killed and two others were injured during a joyride resulted when two of the girls in the front seat apparently tried to change places with those in the rear and the accelerator was accidentally depressed. The car raced through a barricade and onto the Long Island Rail Road tracks, where it burst into flames when it touched the third rail.

title: PLOT LAID TO SIX AT ATHENS TRIAL
description: ATHENS, Aug. 9 (Reuters) Six Greeks who have denied exploding bombs in Athens and plotting to overthrow the Government, were accused in testimony today of planning to execute Government officials and bomb public utilities and diplomatic cars.

title: BOND HOUSE IS PUT INTO BANKRUPTCY
description: The Paragon Securities Company, a financially troubled bond house, has been placed in involuntary bankruptcy, it was disclosed yesterday.

title: Suit by U.S. Asks Breakup Of Goodyear and Firestone
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9The Justice Department filed suit today against the nation's two largest tire manufacturers Goodyear and Firestonecharging that each company separately tried to gain a monopoly of the direct sales of tires to consumers.

title: Coastal Gas Suspension; Trading Halted for 5 Days
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission today announced a fiveday suspension in trading of securities of the Coastal States Gas Producing Company of Houston, Tex. It said the suspensions were initiated because of questions which have arisen with respect to the financial statements of Coastal States Gas Corp during 1971 and 1972 and the accuracy of statements concerning available gas reserves.

title: California Board Orders Inquiry On Nixon's San Clemente Taxes
description: AN FRANCISCO, Aug. 9Orange County officials were directed today by the California Board of Eqqalization to examine the property tax assessment on President Nixon's seaside estate at San Clemente.

title: Women Ask Traffic Signal
description: Two dozen women disrupted traffic at East 181st Street and Crotona Avenue in the Bronx for 20 minutes yesterday afternoon to demand that a traffic signal or stop sign be installed at the intersection. The protest, which began at 1:30 P.M., ended after a meeting with the police of the Ryer Avenue Station, during which the women were promised their complaint would be forwarded to the Department of Traffic.

title: Soviet Dissident Says Brandt Appeases East
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 9A Soviet dissident writer has accused Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany of creating a new Munich by his policy of reconciliation with the Soviet Union.

title: Japan Polices Exit Points After Korean Disappears
description: TOKYO, Aug. 9The Japanese police have placed a watch on seaports and air terminals to forestall any attempt to smuggle a prominent South Korean politician, believed to have been abducted from his Tokyo hotel yesterday, out of the country.

title: Troopers Seize Suspect
description: Robert F. Garrow Sr., a 37yearold murder suspect who had been the object of a manhumt for 11 days, was wounded and captured yesterday after his 16yearold nephew was spotted carrying food to him in the woods at Witherbee, N. Y, Page 32.

title: Chilean Opposition Unites to Force Allende's Hand
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 9He who sows wind reaps storms, the Chilean Opposition likes to say in its own variation of the Biblical saying when referring to the troubled attempts of President Salvadorll Allende Gossens to bring socialism to this country.

title: Equity Financing
description: The Pacific Northwest Bell Telephone Company yesterday said an executive committee of directors had approved a previouslyannounced offering of 6,220,199 additional common shares in a rights offering. The offering, to be made Sept. 4, provides holders with one right for each share held of record Aug. 20. It will take seven rights plus $13 to purchase each new common share. The offering expires Sept. 28. Pacific Northwest closed unchanged 14 on the American Stock Exchange.

title: From a China Traveler
description: Given China's vastness, it was only due to the remarkable thoughtfulness of our hosts that the six members of our Chase group were able to see and experience so much during just ten days in Peking, Sian, Shanghai and Canton. In terms of simple geographic expanse, a week and a half visit to China is something equivalent to trying to see New York City in less than one and a half minutes.

title: Cyprus Police Seize FirstRanking Aide Of Guerrilla Leader
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 9Policemen today arrested the secondranking member of the antiGovernment guerrilla movement led by Gen. George Grivas, who has sworn to overthrow Archbishop Makarios, the President of Cyprus.

title: Fort Riley Army Brigade Fights to Save Criminals
description: FORT RILEY, Kan.The platoon sang as it marched through the searing heat. The lieutenant colonel stopped, grinned and said, Singing, we're getting somewhere with this outfit.

title: 200 Judges in City, Double State Total, Called Needed Under New Drug Law
description: With less than a month to go before the state's stringent narcotics law goes into effect, a city official who is coordinating implementation of the program here said yesterday that as many as 200 trial parts including judges and court personel  would be needed in New York City, rather than the 100 being projected for the entire state.

title: Study Shows Nixon Supported Abroad Despite Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9  A worldwide survey by correspondents of The New York Times in the last week has indicated that although foreign leaders and public figures now seem to take the Watergate scandal more seriously than they did few months ago, the affair has not so far cut deeply into their widespread support for Mr. Nixon's course in foreign policy.

title: Market Place:
description: While the stock market is hardly at a level high enough to encourage investors to consider the sale of securities to realize profits, there are always lots of share holders who should be selling if only to stanch the flow of blood.

description: Major League Baseball

title: An Encore For Louis, Schmeling
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Aug. 9 The years melted away tonight and there were Joe Louis and Max Schmeling surrounded by autograph seekers who were men in their 50's and 60's, some businessmen, some exboxers, all looking for autographs and a chance to shake the hand that shook the hand.

title: 700 Workers Face Layoff Because of Beef Shortage
description: In the city's first major layoffs in the current beef shortage, 700 workers are being furloughed tonight with closing of 25 to 30 meat companies and reduced operations by others, according to Butchers Local 174.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
LAIRD APPROVED FALSE REPORTING OF SECRET RAIDS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug 9 Former Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird snecifically approved falsified reporting of the Nixon Administration's secret B52 raids in Cambodia in 1969, a highly classified Pentagon memorandum showed today.

title: TEXAS SET TO SELL OIL AND GAS LEASES
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 9The biggest sale of oil and gas leases on stateowned land in a quarter of a century has been set for Oct. 2 by Land Commissioner Robert L. Armstrong.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Calls India's Crisis Passing Phase and Asks Calm
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 9 Prime Minister Indira Gandhi said today that the difficulties confronting the nation were only a passing phase and that there was no cause for panic.

title: Screen: Suspenseful 'Night Watch'
description: Elizabeth Taylor, and about time, has got herself a good picture and a whodunit at that. More than one Music Hall patron seemed to be stumbling from the first showing of "Night Watch" yesterday in stunned delight at the windup, a gorgeously brazen, logical swindle.Seldom, at least recently, has a mystery carpet-yanking been so effective, especially after a familiar suspense setup that seems to be carelessly shedding red herrings. This is the one about the rich, jittery wife who howls murder about the empty old house next door. She saysor thinksshe has seen two bloodied corpses, at intervals, through the window.Well, has she? Or is she cracking up? There is much solicitous tiptoeing around the frenzied Miss Taylora bit too muchby her stockbroker husband, Laurence Harv???y, and her best friend, Billie Whitelaw. A snippy, garden-digging neighbor, Robert Lang, handles a spade most ably. An unctuous psychiatrist drifts in, as does an airy cook and a caustic, impatient police inspector.All this seems fairly old stuff, with an insistent Miss Taylor clearly about to pop her cork, with outside help. Something else pops, and you'll never guess what unless you saw Lucille Fletcher's original play starring Joan Hackett.The Broadway hit had a swank, one-set, Manhattan town house and a larger, more raffish gallery of suspects. Tony Williamson's adaptation trims the cast to a handful, and shifts the locale to luxury digs in London.With fewer people under close camera scrutiny, beautiful color photography and Miss Taylor agonizing in some dazzling Valentina finery, it's easy to play a smug Sherlock. But the glossy intimacy only deepens the surprise of the climax, a hair-raising stalk in the house next door, yeastily directed by Brian G. Hutton.Miss Taylor churns up a fine, understandable lather of nerves. Mr. Harvey is properly sleek, Miss Whitelaw makes a peppery parrot, and Mr. Lang is neat. The deliciously cunning postscript may make you feel like a perfect fool. Once in a while it's fun.

title: People in Sports: Palmer Hot at This Point in Time
description: Jim Palmer says he will continue to wear a pair of faded, handmedown orange socks as long as he keeps winning. The Baltimore Orioles pitcher, on a sevengame winning streak, has another superstition  his Watergate hug, one of 2,000 coins minted in the wake of the Watergate scandal. It features a large beetle wearing headphones connected to a tape recorder.

The Essex County chapter of the National Organization for Women rested its case before a state hearing examiner after one witness testified. The witness. Moser of Roosevelt Borouall, said his 10yearold League discriminated against girls because it permits only daughter, Elise, had been informed she could not play Little League baseball because she is a girl. Mr. Moser is investigator for the State Civil Rights Division.

description: LEMON GROVE, Calif., Aug. 9 (AP)Lieut. Comdr. William M. Bowlin, U.S.N., retired who was Admiral Richard E. Byrd's personal navigator on his second Antarctic expedition, died Tuesday in his home here. He was 74 years old.

The challenge came in a suit filed by the City Corporation Counsel for Corrections Commissioner Benjamin J. Malcolm against the State Commission of Investigation.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UPI)President Nixon hit the ceiling when he learned that Vice President Agnew was under investigation in an alleged Maryland kickback scheme and tried to talk Mr. Agnew out of holding a news conference, White House sources said today.

description: CAMP DAVID, Md., Aug. 9 (AP)President Nixon worked today in the seclusion of his mountaintop retreat on the public response he will make to developments in the Watergate case.

description: At Roosevelt Raceway

title: Army in Germany Drops Plan to Watch Dissidents
description: BONN, Aug. 9The United States Army command in Heidelberg, in its first official response to complaints from within its ranks about widespread activities by military intelligence, announced today that a program of counterdissidence by the Eighth Infantry Division had been rescinded because it was inappropriate.

title: Area Fishing Prospects Brighten for the Weekend
description: AREA ABluefishing remains thin on the entire New Jersey shore, with the general report that there are no blues on the surf and very few outside. One compensation for the area's fishermen is a good run of fluke near Spring Lake. The Miss Point Pleasant, a party boat, reported a catch of more than 100 fluke yesterday, with several in the 8to12pound class, caught on spinners. One lucky fishermen, chumming for blues near Barnegat Ridge, instead landed a 75pound tuna. Crabbing remains good in Barnegat Bay, where a few baby snappers are also biting. A few weak.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Gary Adelman of Roslyn, L. I., upset Chris Sylvan of Fresno, Calif., 64, 6.4, then turned back Bob Gliclunan of Brooklyn, 61, 61, to reach the semifinals of the Coltimbia tennis championships for juniors and boys yesterday, at Baker Field. Adelman was the only unseedpd player to advance in the 18yearold division.

title: AMEX PRICES OFF IN LIGHT TRADING

His body was found amid broken lamps and general disarray at 10 P.M., about two hours after the victim had been seen by neighbors entering the biulding with a male companion.

Bolton Jr., a Secret Service agent assigned last year to guard Senator George McGovern of South Dakota, the Democratic Presidential nominee, agreed to pass political information to the White House, according to a confidential memorandum cited tonight by The Washington Post.

Claude Osteen, holding the Mets to four hits, outpitched Jerry Koosman, who managed to keep pace for seven innings, but yielded the run the eighth on the ninth and 10th hits off hima oneout triple by Dave Lopes and line single by Manny Mota.

description: JURMALA, U.S.S.R.It is hardly Miami Beach, Biarritz or Corfu, but in the Soviet Union many people consider it going west, and they do not mean just geographically.

title: Cruikshank Illustrations Are Displayed at Firestone
description: Any artist whose ancestral tradition runs back through Thomas Rowlandson to William Hogarth has tough competition to face even if he doesn't mean to set himself up for comparison with his forebears. George Cruikshank, England's 19thcentury illustrator, cartoonist and occasional social moralist, is put in this difficult spot by a wellorganized exhibition of several hundred items from Princeton University's extensive collection of Cruikshank material now installed in the Harvey S. Firestone Library. Books, prints, original drawings, letters and a couple of Cruikshank's late and very rare paintings are combined in a survey that is just about definitive.

title: BRIDGEHAMPTON,
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON, N. Y.When I left the magazine business in the city a couple of years ago and came out here to live and work, I believed I had lost forever my sense of outrage. I felt that never again, after all my years in politics and public affairs, could anything ever evoke in me feeling of indignation. I sensed that I had given toe much of my flesh, and that something in me was destroyed and gone. But the exchanges between Senator Sam and Mr. Ehrlichman reaffirmed the contours of my own existence, and of my own past, and made me mad.

The commission has accused the airlines of falsifying theft reports to justify reports that widespread pilferage of cargo at Kennedy, La Guardia and Newark Airports had been sharply reduced by airline security efforts.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UPI)Former Justice Arthur J. Goldberg recommended today that other former Supreme Court Justices listen to White House tape recordings on Watergate and determine which portions should be given to investigators.

description: Corporate bond prices extended Wednesday's gains yesterday in moderately active trading.

title: Guy Kelcey, Pioneer Engineer On Traffic and Roads, Dies at 84
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., Aug. 9  Guy Kelcey, a pioneer traffic engineer and a founder of the international engineering firm of Edwards & Kelcey in Newark, died today at his home here. He was 84 years old and lived at 739 Highland Avenue.

title: Libya Said to Bow to Egyptian Demands That Will Delay Merger of Two Nations
description: CAIRO, Aug. 9Col. Muammar elQaddafi, the Libyan leadappeared yesterday to be osing his battle for immediate full union with Egypt. He was reliably reported to have bowed to Egyptian demands for a gradual procedure that would take years and could be abanloned before completion.

title: Agnew Takes Vacation on Coast As His Attorneys Study Case
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9Vice President Agnew flew off, on vacation today to Frank Sinatra's oasis in the California desert, assured by voters telegrams and political friends that his news conference yesterday on the criminal investigation involving him had made the best of an awkward situation.

title: Retail Store Sales Up 15%
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $911million, up 13 per cent from the year earlier $806million. Total retail store sales were about $9.87billion, up 15 per cent from last year's $8.59billion.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: Suit by U.S. Asks Breakup Of Goodyear and Firestone
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9The Justice Department filed suit today against the nation's two largest tire manufacturers Goodyear and Firestonecharging that each company separately tried to gain a monopoly of the direct sales of tires to consumers.

title: U.S. Reportedly Withheld Ecuador Aid on I.T.T. Plea
description: The United States Government allegedly withheld millions of dollars n foreign aid to Ecuador in 1971 and 1972 at the request of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, according to the Aug. 11 issue of Business Week magazine.

title: Smith, Financier, Sues I.R.S.
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 9 (AP)C. Arnholt Smith, the financier now facing a $22.8million tax lien by the Internal Revenue Service, has filed a Federal court countersuit against the tax agency. A spokesman for Mr. Smith said yesterday that the civil suit was filed late Tuesday before United States District Court Judge Leland Nielsen. Mr. Smith contends he does not owe any money, and says the revenue service is harassing him because of his friendship and financial support for President Nixon.

title: ANDREA DORIA HULL CUT BY TWO DIVERS
description: NANTUCKET, Mass., Aug. 9 (AP)Two divers cut into the hull of the sunken luxury liner Andrea Doria today in hopes of reaching the estimated $4million worth of treasure they expected to find inside.

title: Rutgers Gives Rights Unit Power to Oversee Hiring
description: NEWARK, Aug. 9 (AP) The New Jersey Civil Rights Division announced an agree inent today giving it the power to oversee faculty hiring at Rutgers University to prevent discrimination against minority groups and women.

title: The Agnew
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9What this town has been hoping for recently is somebody, anybody in power, who would stand up and give plain answers to hard questions, and Vice President Agnew has finally done it.

title: Army in Germany Drops Plan to Watch Dissidents
description: BONN, Aug. 9The United States Army command in Heidelberg, in its first official response to complaints from within its ranks about widespread activities by military intelligence, announced today that a program of counterdissidence by the Eighth Infantry Division had been rescinded because it was inappropriate.

title: Chicken Liver Dish That Uses Eggplant
description: In the menus below, the dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: City Suit Challenges State On Criminal Inquiry Here
description: Lawyers for the city went to Federal Court here yesterday to challe'ge the state's investigation of the city's criminal justice system.

title: DUTCHSHELL NET UP160%INQUARTER
description: The Royal DutchShell Group of Companies attained an increase of .160.3 per cent in secondquarter net income on a sales gain of 24.5 per cent, the midyear report disclosed yesterday. Halfyear results were also significantly higher than a year earlier.

title: Peron's Guessing Game
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 9 Argentina has settled into a period of deep confusion and inertia, in which even hardened politicians acknowledge that only one man, Juan Domingo Peron, appears to be in corntumid of crucial decisions that will determine the political course of the country. Four weeks have passed since Mr. Perlin forced the resignation of his loyal follower, Dr. Hector J. Campora, from the presidency, thus apparently paving his own way to the post.

title: 'Gordon's War' Views Drug Scene
description: In "Gordon's War," four black veterans of Vietnam wage fierce personal battle, using Army tactics, against drug channelers in Harlem. What, indeed, could be more admirable? This is a worthy film, whose format and substancea black theme dramatized, for practical, constructive purposesremain exceeded by its goal.The picture is tough, fast, moves in a straight line with no sideline fiddling but with pungent humor and vividly jabs the crime-ridden underbelly of Harlem. The sharp direction of Ossie Davis catches the argot, the flavor and the sinister ambiance of the area. And Mr. Davis stages a wingding of a car-motorcycle chase near the end.But the picture is inconclusive, far from profound, and the urgency of the theme has been overly simplified to fit the action. Only in the first part of the script is there character probing, as Paul Winfield (of "Sounder") broods over the addiction of his dead wife and recruits his three pals for personal and moral vengeance. A real uptown dope purge, says somebody, "would take an army."These fourCarl Lee, David Dowling and Tony King are the othersdo very well on their own. Fiercely, methodically, the good guys nail the bad guys, with comparative ease. No policeman or detective, black or white, ever appears. At the fade-out, which simply hangs in midair like a warning, four white business executives are lined up as the culprits. "Gordon's War" is well-fought but definitely not the drug war to end them all.

title: 2 SKYLAB SPIDERS GIVER A REPRIEVE
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 9 (UPI)The Skylab astronauts were requested today by Mission Control to share their filet mignon with two spiders named Arabella and Anita so that they can keep up their two months of spinning webs in weightlessness.

title: ChiefJudge Candidates Told BabyKissing Is Out
description: COMMACK, L. I., Aug. 9Last Sunday, Charles D. Breitel ate hot dogs and clams at an Albany clambake. Today Jacob D. Fuchsberg pumped hands at a suburban shopping center.

title: Business Briefs
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 9 (UPI)The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) announced today it is enlarging its tanker fleet by 40 per cent to bring more crude oil to market.

title: DENT DESCRIBES INFLATION BATTLE
description: The Administration fight against inflation will be predicated on elimination of controts and achieving a better balance between supply and demand, Frederick B. Dent, Secretary of Commerce said yesterday.

title: Tell Patients How Clean Kitchen Is? State Health Officials A rgue the Issue
description: TRENTON, Aug. 9  A dispute is simmering behind the scenes in the State Health Department over whether patients in hospitals, nursing homes and oldage homes should be told how clean  or dirty  the kitchens are in the institutions.

title: CROP ESTIMATE FOR GRAIN IS CUT BY U.S. AGENCY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9The Department of Agriculture lowered today its estimate of this year's grain production, and an official of the agency acknowledged that this would put new upward pressure on food prices.

title: EAST GERMANS SEE A STATE DEPT. AIDE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9Two representatives of the East German Government conferred today with State Department officials on procedures for negotiating diplomatic relations.

title: Leftist Daily in Uruguay Suspended by Government
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 9 (UPI)Ultima Hora, a leftist afternoon daily, has been suspended from publication for the next 20 days, its publishers said today.

title: Grand Old Man of Racing Inducted Into Hall at 85
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 9Holly Hughes had his first big thrill in horse racing in 1916 when the colt he saddled, George Smith, won the Kentucky Derby. Since then the 85yearold trainer, who has been with the Sanford family, has had a succession of outstanding moments. But today he enjoyed a thrill second only to his 1916 Derby success.

title: Inspection Report in February Termed Condition of Hotel Structure Hazardous
description: At the bottom of a sheet of paper Milton Schaffner, an inspector for the city's Buildings Department, wrote in red pencil, Hazardous.

title: American Maize Plans to Swap $50Million in Stock for Helme
description: The American MaizeProducts Company announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire Helme Products, Inc., through an exchange of stock.

title: TAX AGENCY DROPS ANTILEFTIST UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9The Internal Revenue Service is abolishing a special division that for four years has investigated liberal and radical organizations and their sponsors for possible violations of tax law.

title: Red Smith The Jawbone of Muhammad Ali
description: Muhammad All is coming to New York this week show a national television audience that his demountable jaw is practically as good as new. Not necessarily good an instrument for measuring the kinetic energy in Ken Norton's fist (one half its mass times velocity squared), but useful for champing collard greens, growing whiskers or framing the words, I am the greatest. He will employ it for this last purpose on the Dick Cavett Show, then return to his mountaintop retreat at Deer Lake, Pa., to resume preparations for a rematch with Norton in Los Angeles Sept. 10. Ali has been courting health at Deer Lake for quite a spell, but has yet to let a sparring partner test the jaw that Norton broke last March 31. He doesn't plan to expose the mandible to a punch until the last two weeks before the bout.

title: Gunmen Kill Ulster Protestant; Blast Damages 50 Army Homes
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 9A construction worker was shot dead tonight at the end of a day of terrorist violence and rioting that marked the second anniversary of the introduction of internment without trial in Northern Ireland.

title: Reducing the White House Staff
description: MILWAUKEEOnly a very inexperienced man would rush in at this point with a series of sweeping prescriptions to treat the deepseated ills of our Government that have been disclosed by Watergate. But it is not too early to lay some plans for bringing the overswollen White House staff under reasonable forms of control.

title: REPORT OF DONATION TO NIXON IS DENIED
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9The Lone Star Gas Company of Dallas and its former vice president, Edgar Allen Brown, denied today reports that Mr. Brown or the company had given a $150,000 contribution to President Nixon's reelection campaign in 1972.

title: Southern Presbyterians Set Up Secessionist Conservative Unit
description: ASHEVILLE, N. C., Aug. 9 (UPD)A group of secessionist Presbyterians set up today the first operating committee for new conservative Presbyterian denomination.

title: Composer, 16, and Pals, Start a Piano Marathon
description: HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 9  A 16yearold boy and several friends set out this morning to break the world record for the longest nonrepetitious keyboard composition by playing nonstop a computerwritten 100hour piece composed solely of all 40,320 possible permutations of the C major scale.

title: A Caveat Emptor for Captive Diners
description: The restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Study Shows Nixon Supported Abroad Despite Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9  A worldwide survey by correspondents of The New York Times in the last week has indicated that although foreign leaders and public figures now seem to take the Watergate scandal more seriously than they did a few months ago, the affair has not so far cut deeply into their widespread support for Mr. Nixon's course in foreign policy.

title: Commodityprice Index Up To 205.2 in Latest Week
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 205.2 from 195.1 last week.

title: Kissinger's China Trip Is Reported Postponed
description: PEKING, Aug. 9 (Agence FrancePresse)  Henry A, Kissinger will not make his planned trip to Peking this month, diplomatic sources said here today.

title: Excerpts From Bid To Get Nixon Tapes
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 Following are excerpts from the text of the complaint filed by the Senate Watergate committee in Federal District Court seeking to compel President Nixon to make available recorded tapes of White House conversations:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It was with substantial agreement and great interest that I read your July 27 editorial concerning our judicial convention system. However, must we conclude that we should scrap the elective method and adopt some sort of appointment method?

title: Neak Luong Revisited
description: Faith in the Pentagon's veracity has been so shaken by continuing disclosures of falsified reports and other attempts over a period of years to cover up secret military operations in Cambodia that one could reasonably now expect a special effort by the Defense Department to restore its compromised credibility.

title: An Outright Denunciation of Lin Due at Peking Party Congress
description: PEKING, Aug. 9  The Chinese Communist party will convene its 10th national congress next week and use the occasion for the first outright denunciation of Lin Piao, the man named as Chairman Mao's successor by he last party congress in 1969, authoritative sources disclosed today.

title: Music: An Oddly Retrospective Air at Tanglewood
description: LENOX, Mass., Aug. 9An oddly retrospective and conservative air has been dominating the Festival of Contemporary Music this week at Tanglewood. Last night's concert did nothing to change that atmosphere. Once again the music offered in the Berkshire Music Center's TheaterConcert Hall echoed back to avantgarde ideas of the nineteenfifties and even earlier. It may sum up the matter to report that the headiest ideas on display were to be found in two early works by John Cage, several of whose pieces are on this year's festival program in honor of Mr. Cage's 60th birthday, which was celebrated all last season.

title: Stock Dividend Planned
description: Stockholders of the United States Trust Company will be asked to approve an increase in the authorized capital stock to provide for a stock dividend of three additional shares for every seven held, A special meeting has been scheduled Oct. 4 for the vote.

description: Louis J. Haag, a certified public accountant and a partner in Touche Ross & Co., died Wednesday, apparently of a heart attack, in Paris, where he had been on vacation. He lived in Valley Stream, L.I.

description: TRENTON, Aug. 9Governor Cahill issued an urgent appeal today to President Nixon and Federal officials for emergency aid to prevent a possible halt to freight and passenger rail service in New Jersey by the faill.

description: BRANCHVILLE, N.J., Aug. 9 After Whining seven classes in a row during two shows, Robin Ann Rost's Wigg's Bar finally was beaten today at the Sussex County horse show.

description: HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Aug. 9 (AP)A rescue vessel plucked an American balloonist, Bob Sparks, out of the Atlantic today after thunderstorms forced him to abandon a flight to Europe, a Canadian military spokesman said.

title: CoverUp Confirmed
description: Here is one coverup the Administration admits to: From the spring of 1969 until this week, the White House and a variety of Federal agencies operated under what they term a basic policy decision to withhold information about all taxfunded improvements on the private residences of President Nixon.

title: At Jacob's. Pillow, Terry Is Planning Major Projects
description: LEE, Mass.When Walter Terry, the new director of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, first visited here in 1934, the outhouse on the premises was named The New Yorker.

title: A Strategic Retreat for Headquarters of Washington
description: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 9For several hours today, a small crowd of White Plains residents and a handful of utility company workmen watched as a 252yearold house was moved from the path of a new highway to a hill overlooking the downtown rehabilitation project.

title: Money and Politics
description: Whether or not Vice President Agnew is drawn further into the burgeoning scandal in his home state of Maryland, the Federal investigation of alleged kickbacks and bribery there will put the spotlight more fiercely than ever on the shocking way in which political campaigns are financed. With the country still trying to digest the massive revelations of the Senate Watergate committee, no further illustration of corruption in the electoral system is needed to establish the case for drastic reform. The danger is, rather, that Congress will be panicked into adopting legislation that will mollify a rightly aroused country without providing genuine and lasting change.

title: TWO MORE BOMBS ARE FOUND HERE
description: Two pipe bombs were founc yesterday at construction sites in Manhattan and in Brooklyn but police bomb squads were able to remove both bombs before they exploded.

title: Goodyear Recalls Tires
description: AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 9 (UPI) The Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company announced today that it had recalled 9,800 truck tires produced in the first half of 1972 because they may be prone to tread separation and possible sudden loss of air particularly after extensive service on front wheels of trucks, A company spokesman said the Super HiMiler nylon tubeless tires, size 11.22,5, 12ply rating, carried serial numbers MJ3TCUA082 through MJ3TCUA252.

description: AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 9Vander Barbette, a worldrenowned trapeze artist of the nineteentwenties and thirties, died Sunday at his home here, He was 68 years old.

description: HUSTLING. Prostitution in Our Wide Open Society. By Gail Sheehy. 273 pages. Delacorte. $7.95.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 The agency of the Government most closely involved with homemortgage finance today painted a grim picture of the current mortgage situation: interest rates of 9 per cent or more, money rushing out of the thrift institutions, which are the main mortgage lenders, and some danger of a drying up of mortgage money at any price.

description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 9Attorneys seeking to develop a legal strategy for Vice President Agnew in his dealings with a Federal investigation here were granted an extension of at feast a week today in the deadine for submitting his personal inancial records to the inluiry.

ALLAN L. FLETCHER
description: Allan L. Fletcher, a medical writer, editor and publisher, died of cancer yesterday at University Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived at 206 Lakeview Avenue, Leonia, N.J.

description: Domenico Savino, a composer and orchestra director, died in Doctors Hospital on Wednesday. He was 91 years old and lived at 320 West End Avenue.

description: There are restaurants in Rome where waiters toss the fettucine with golden forks and spoons.

description: It is 6:30 on a typical, sweltering midsummer Friday evening at chaotically crowded Penn Station.

title: Selective Responsibility
description: Although remarks made by others in conversations with the President may arguably be part of a criminal plan on their part, the President's participation in these conversations was in accordance with his constitutional duty to see that the laws are faithfully executed.

title: Credit Growing Tighter; Most Interest Rates Up
description: Credit conditions grew tighter in the week ended Wednesday, Federal Reserve Bank of New York data released yesterday showed. Banks had fewer reserves at the central bank, money supply growth was the slowest in six weeks and most interest rates moved higher over the course of the week.

title: COURT BACKS CITY ON ITS G.M. SUIT Judge Allows a Class Action by 200 Localities Over Alleged Bus Monopoly
description: The city received Federal Court permission yesterday to represent 200 to 300 localities throughout the United States in its civil antirust action that charges the General Motors Corporation with monopolizing the sale of buses for municipal use.

title: A Handgun Ban by 1983 Is Urged by U.S. Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9  A Federal commission, declaring that violent crimes threaten the very existence of a humane and civilized society, proposed today that the possession of handguns be limited to the police and military personnel by 1983.

title: Contrasts in Song From Helen Reddy
description: Helen Reddy topped the bill at Wednesday's Schaefer Music Festival concert in Central Park with the builtin insurance of a new television series and a superhit, I Am Woman, behind her. The song may have turned into a feminist anthem, but a lot of her material falls into Tin Pan Alley conventional when dealing with love and all that.

title: Addict With a $40aDay Habit Is Arraigned in Village Murder
description: A 39yearold heroin addict with a long history of arrests on rape, robbery and burglary charges was arraigned yesterday in Manhattan Criminal Court on a homicide charge in the knife slaying of Roberta Block, a copywriter for Macy's, who apparently resisted a robbery attempt Monday afternoon in the hallway of her apartment building in Greenwich Village.

title: Everts Win In Western Pro Tennis
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 9 (AP) The Evert sisters, topseeded Chris and 15yearold Jeanne, advanced to the semifinals of the $75,000 Western tennis championships today.

title: A KNOTTY NONET PLAYED IN A PARK
description: A band concert in the village square is a timehonored summer event almost everywhere in the Western world, and on Tuesday night New York had special and not always pleasant variation on the theme. The concert took place in a square, all right (Washington), and in a village of sorts (Greenwich), but the music was anything but the usual summer fare.

title: Turkey Frees U.S. Woman On Bail in Narcotics Case
description: ANTIOCH, Turkey, Aug. 9 (UPI)  Turkish authorities freed on $3,571 bail today an American woman jailed along with five other women and man for eight months in Anatolia on hashish smuggling charges.

title: Texan Said to Admit Role in 25 Killings
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 9The police said today that a 17yearold high school dropout had told them that he and a 33yearold man he later killed had been involved In more than 25 slayings. The bodies of 17 teenagers have been uncovered in a rented boat shed here.

title: Texan Said to Admit Role in 25 Killings
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 9The police said today that a 17yearold high school dropout had told them that he and a 33yearold man he later killed had been involved in more than 25 slayings. The bodies of 17 teenagers have been uncovered in a rented boat shed here. Late today two more bodies were found near a lake development 120 miles to the northeast.

title: DILORENZO RELIEVED OF JUDICIAL DUTIES
description: Civil Court Judge Ross J. DiLorenzo was relieved of his judicial assignment yesterday following his indictment Thursday on charges of perjury and obstruction of governmental administration.

description: Federal inspectors yesterday found 19 meat plants closed and 124 others with operations curtailed in the metropblitan areamore than half the 200odd processors and wholesalers they checked in the current beef shortage.

title: Giants Bow To Seaver, Mets, 7 to 1
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 10What would have been a classic confrontation a few years ago Tom Seaver pitching against Juan Marichalmerely reflected the inexorable march of time tonight as Seaver's New York Mets walloped Marichal's San Francisco Giants, 71.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: BLUEGRASS When an event is called The First Annual N. Y. C. Bluegrass & Old Time Country Music Contest, its continuity has to be purely an article of faith, but an event of that hopeful designation will occuy the South Street Seaport Pier, at Fulton Street and the East River Drive, this weekend. Strictly traditional, you understand, with at least 12 bands from four states and Ireland allowed to play nonelectrified stringed instruments onlybanjo, mandolin, fiddle, guitar and bass.

title: Japan's Premier Pledges to Press Search for Korean
description: TOKYO, Aug. 10Premier Kakuei Tanaka pledged today that his Government, as well as the police, would make every effort to locate the missing South Korean opposition leader, Kim Dae Jung, who was reported kidnapped from a wellknown Tokyo hotel three days ago.

title: Flood Victims Still Wait for U.S. Loans
description: NORTH PLAINFIELD, Aug. 10How long before I can get a Small Business Administration loan? Kenneth Hopful asked today.

title: Gulf Oil Illegally Donated $100,000 to Nixon in 72
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation said yesterday that it had contributed $100,000 in corporate funds to President Nixon's reelection campaign. Such contributions are illegal under Federal law.

title: Knicks Invite 67 Swede To a Tryout Next Month
description: Jorgen Hansson, a 6foot7inch center on the Swedish national basketball team, has been invited to the New York Knicks training camp next month. A spokesman for the National Basketball Association champion said there were a few minor details to be worked out.

title: Jesus 73 Festival Opens With 10,000 Despite Rainstorm
description: MORGANTOWN, Pa., Aug. 10 (UPI)A crowd of 10,000 per sons stood in a hard rain today praising the Lord at the Jesus religious festival on a 160acre farm near here.

description: In a savage batting demonstration that must have made such former sluggers as Bill Dickey and Moose Skowron think of their playing days when Yankee Stadium's tenants lived up to the name Bronx Bombers, New York defeated the Oakland A's 109, last night.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A bill providing a 6.5 per cent pay increase for 3,175 state troopers has been signed into law by Governor Rockefeller, his office in Albany announced yesterday. Mr. Rockefeller took the action shortly before leaving the state for a brief vacation. The signing represented the last official action of the special session of the Legislature, which adjourned a oneweek meeting last July 30. The pay increase in the oneyear contract raises the starting salary of the troopers from $9,365 to $9,925. The total estimated cost of the pay raises is $1.8million.

title: Signature Pieces Danced By Carmen de Lavallade
description: LEE, Mass., Aug. 10Carmen de Lavallade is a freshet of joyous movement, a kinetic springtime who projects a warm and gentle radiance. She also has a historical sense, for which I am profoundly grateful. In addition to works from her own repertory, she reconstructed and performed two early solos from Ruth St. Denis's repertory Wednesday night at Jacob's Pillow. The program was shared with members of the Dance Theater of Harlem.

title: Inquiry Begun Into Protection Scheme Preying on Chinese Businessmen Here
description: The police have begun an extensive inquiry into an apparent protection scheme aimed primarily at Chinese smallbusiness men and other Chinese.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: CROSSWORD PUZZLE

title: Events Today
description: Events Today

title: Oil Find Is Reported
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 10 (UPI) The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said today it had brought in a fourth oil well in the Scottish waters of the North Sea. Results of the test were not disclosed. Occidental has a 36.5 per cent interest in the well.

title: Ombudsman Is Named By State Penal System
description: TRENTON Aug, 10 (UPI) Donald F. Tucker of Neptune, a former prison guard, has been chosen as the first permanent ombudsmen for the New Jersey penal system. A prisons spokesman said today that Mr. Tucker, 54 years old, would take over the post on Sept. 1.

title: Price Controls Are Kept on  Gas and Oil
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 Gasoline, heating oil and other petroleum products will remain under rigid price controls for an indefinite period, the Nixon Administration announced today.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on International Terrorism10:30 A.M.

title: Boozer, Hill Suspended
description: TAMPA, Fla., Aug. 10Emerson Boozer and Winston Hill, the two salary holdouts in the New York Jets training camp, were fined and suspended from the squad today by Weeb Ewbank, the team's coach and general manager.

title: 6 FEDERAL OFFICIALS SUBPOENAEDINTEXAS
description: DALLAS, Aug. 10 (UPI)Judge William M. Taylor of United States District Court subpoenaed six Government officials today, including former Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst, to appear at a hearing in which the six defendants will try to prove they were the targets of a Republican smear campaign.

title: Iverson and Rudolph Tie At 139 for P.G.A. Lead
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 10 While Jack Nicklaus moved within a stroke of the lead and Arnold Palmer failed to qualify, Don Iverson, the copacesetter yesterday, shared the 36hole lead in the Professional Golfers Association championship today with Mason Rudolph at 139.

title: Wedding of Lacey Fosburgh And Marc Libarle Held Here
description: Miss Lacey Fosburgh, daughter of Hugh Whitney Fosburgh of Bedford, N. Y., and Mrs. Helen Edwards Fosburgh of New York, was married here last evening to Marc Libarle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lucien Libarle of Sonoma County, Calif.

title: Palmer: Meanest Cut of All
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 10I can't even get mad any more, said Arnold Palmer after failing to qualify by one stroke for the final 36 holes of the Professional Golfers Association championship because of poor putting.

title: Handel's Geniality, Mozart's Command Paired in Concert
description: Thursday night's Mostly Mozart concert was appealingly schizophrenic: erly Handel, in genial, oldshoe comfort, followed by late Mozart, ardent and commanding. Even the performers took sides, the soprano Carole Bogard and the recorder virtuoso Bernard Krainis sharing solos in the Handel half, the pianist Ruth Laredo and the Cleveland Quartet firmly upholding the Mozartean honor.

title: SUSPECT IN KILLINGS MAINTAINS SILENCE
description: PLATTSBURGH, N. Y., Aug. 10 (AP)The state police attempted to question Robert F. Garrow Sr. today about the fatal stabbings of two campers and the disappearance of a third. But the man wouldn't talk, troopers said.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Governor Cahill said yesterday that he would meet with legislative leaders Wednesday to discuss the possibility of a special session of the Legislature in midSeptember to deal with an extension of unemployment benefits. Another matter that could be put on the agenda is the possibility of changing the law that created a sports complex in the Hackensack River Meadowlands. The Sports Authority has had no bids on the bonds it has been trying to sell to finance the complex. It has been suggested that the state agree to pay off the bonds if the revenue from the planned racetrack is insufficient, Under the present law, the bonds are not backed by the full faith and credit of the state.

title: WINE TALK
description: DANBY, Vt., Aug. 10Ever heard of sap beer? Or frozen potato wine? How about lemon wine or sumac wine? Don't feel bad. Neither has practically anybody else. Except for a handful of oldtimers in the few remaining rural pockets of the beautiful Green Mountains here in Vermont.

title: Rocking Contest Winner III
description: CENTRAL CITY, Ky, Aug. 10 (UPI)A mother of eight became Kentucky's rocking chair contest winner early yesterday and then was hospitalized. Mrs. Clarice Warner, 42 years old, rocked for 90 hours and eight minutes at the Central City, centennial celebration to beat out Daniel Waynes, 20, of Muhlenberg county by one minute, and win the title and $500 first prize. She was hospitalized shortly after the victory and fed intravenously to help build up her depleted strength.

title: Consumer Notes
description: Ordinary advice to shop wisely for food as prices soar daily seems almost beside the point: How do you shop wisely in the current circumstances? It is all very well to say you must avoid expensive convenience foods and overpriced junk foodsfood with little or no hutritional value and to look for specials at the supermarket.

title: Giant Attack Line
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., Aug. 10Greg Larson, who has been in one spot long enough to make critical appraisals, today called the current offensive line for the New York Giants, the strongest since I've been here.

title: Argentina Plans to Ship More Wheat to Uruguay
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 10 (UPI) Government sources said today that Argentina had agreed to ship Uruguay 60,000 tons of wheat despite her own shortage of the cereal. The first Argentine shipment of some 7,500 tons is expected next Monday, the sources said.

title: BARNET GROSSMAN
description: Barnet Grossman, retired real estate broker and former clothing manufacturer, died yesterday in Maimonides Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 96 years old and lived at 5001 15th Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Results of Nearby Yacht Racing
description: Results of Nearby Yacht Racing

title: Services for George Wiley Set for Capital Tomorrow
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10Memorial services for Dr. George A. Wiley, the welfare rights activist, will be held at 4:30 P.M. Sunday at the New York Avenue Presbyterian Church here.

title: Hershey Earnings Shrink. And Chocolate Bar May
description: Smaller chocolate bars, fewer almonds and higher prices are in prospect for the con sumer, according to yesterday's report by the Hershey Foods Corporation, whose costprice problems reduced secondquarter earnings by 14.6 per cent and firsthalf net by 31,3 per cent.

title: Mistrial Is Again Asked In Virgin Islands Murders
description: ST. CROIX, V.I., Aug. 10 (UPI)  William M. Kunstler and five legal colleagues entered today a second defence motion for mistrial in the Fountain Valley mass ??? The jury has deliberated seven days.

title: Improved Building Modules Devised
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10Early next year a $2.5million plant in Wallkill, N. Y., will start turning out roomsized concrete boxes to serve as building blocks for highrise structures. One project, under negotiation with the New York State Urban Development Corporation, is a 16story apartment building for New York City. The F. D. Rich Housing Corporation, Stamford, Conn., received Patent 3,750,366 this week for the construction method. The inventors are Frank D. Rich Jr., president, and Alexander D. McDonald, an engineer.

title: 2 Seized in a Bronx Gunfight After Gunfight With Police
description: Two policemen Ma passing patrol car last evening captured two holdup men who allegedally from a Bronx supermarket and shot at the officers before trying to flee, the police reported.

title: Appeal to Generosity
description: Six young American women and one man have spent the last nine months in a provincial Turkish jaillike too many such jails almost everywhere else, crowded, crawling, infectious and generally noisome. Three of the prisoners had driven across the Turkish border in minibuses which, on inspection, were found to contain 225 pounds of hashish.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: About the Jets:
description: The Jets rounded out their roster to 60 men, plus the three college AllStars who don't count yet, by adding Arthur Green, a 5foot11inch, 205pound freeagent running back from Albany (Ga.) State College who is in Tampa with the team. With two running backs holding out and three hurting from last week, Mike Adamle (foot), Steve Harkey (concussion) and Cliff McClain (ribs)Ewbank wanted to be sure he had enough. Although suspended, Emerson Boozer and Winston Hill still count on the Jets rosters, Steve Tannen, a former allAmerican cornerback at Florida Gators, is starting at free safety for the Jets I always had good games here but that was college, said John Mooring, the offensive tackle from the University of Tampa, who will be starting his second game in place of the AllStar holdout, Bill Ewbank plans to take a long look at his linebackers. He needs a replacement for Larry Grantham, who retired this year and will be reading the quarterback from the safety of the broadcast booth.

title: Miss Austin's 70 Gains Stroke Edge In Illinois Golf
description: WADSWORTH, Ill., Aug. 10 (AP)Debbie Austin of Oneida, N. Y., played through heavy wind today for a threeunderpar 70 and took the firstround lead in the $30,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament.

title: More Than 70 Feared Dead In a Bus Accident in Egypi
description: CAIRO, Aug. 10 (UPI)More than 70 people were believed killed when their bus fell into a deep irrigation canal.

title: Guard Wounded as Bank Is Robbed Twice in Day
description: A bank guard was seriously wounded yesterday during blazing exchange of gunfire in the second holdup of the day in the same bank branch.

title: U.S. Says Food Cost In 2d Quarter Rose 15% Over 72 Level
description: The Agriculture Department said yesterday that the cost of feeding an American family in the second quarter of 1973 was 15 per cent higher than it was a year ago, but local surveys found higher increases.

title: East Germans Threaten Berlin Routes
description: BERLIN, Aug. 10East Germany served notice today that it would take action at the appropriate time on the vulnerable Berlin transit routes to halt a mounting flow of refuto the West.

title: Rebels Damage Phnom Penh Generator
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia,. Aug. 10 (UPI)  Cambodian instilgents disguised as refugees slipped into the grounds of Phnom Penh's radio transmittang station today and damaged one of its two generators, reducing its emergency electric power capacity by about half.

title: TWO NEW BATTLES REPORTED BY SAIGON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 10 (Reuters)New fighting has flared in two areas of South Vietnam with Communist forces attacking Government infantry positions, the Saigon command said today.

title: Sir Dalrae's 1:57 4/5 Ties Westbury Pacing Record
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 10 The roar that shook the suburbs tonight wasn't a cheer for a 1:57 4/5 mile that equaled Roosevelt Raceway's track record. It was, simply, an audible sigh of relief when the photo showed the heavily favored Sir Dalrae had won the $50,000 pace.

title: Jersey Economy Nears Record Despite 7% Unemployment Rate
description: TRENTON, Aug. 10  New Jersey's economy will produce a record $50billion gross state product this year despite a stubborn high 7 per cent Unemployment rate, according to Ronald M. Heymann, State Labor and Industry Commissioner.

title: Busing Ordered in Lansing
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 10 (UPI)United States District Judge Noel P. Fox issued today an order directing the school board at Lansing to reinstate busing and desegregation program.

title: For Temple Expert, The War Is Still On
description: DA NANG, South Vietnam July 29The failure of the Paris peace agreement to end the war has brought many different sadnesses to many Vietnamese, but perhaps the most unusual sorrow is being endured by a 65  year  old man named Nguyen Xuan Dong, who lives in a little house across the street from a museum here.

title: The Screen:New 'Visions of Eight' Studies Olympics
description: "Visions of Eight," which opened yesterday at Cinema I, is an attempt by an international group of eight mostly well-known directors to deal with individual aspects of last summer's Munich Olympic Games. The attempt was surely doomed to failure. In a film of this kind there is no way of dealing with the event that shaped the 20th Olympiador deprived it of all shape: the killing of 11 members of the Israeli team.That event does figure, by way of fairly inappropriate montage, in John Schlesinger's otherwise lovely meditation on the running of the marathon. And it hangs like a pall over Avery Brundage's farewell remarks inviting everybody to the 1976 Olmpics. Once admitted (as Brundage seemed unwilling to do), it cannot be integrated in the context of a movie that only wants to be thoughtful, funny, satiric or poetic.But "Visions of Eight" fails in more immediate ways, largely because several of the eight didn't have such interesting visions. Arthur Penn and Kon Ichikawa do not so much film as analyze, respectively, the pole vault and the 100-meter dash. You don't see a race or a jump; you see the way the flesh bunches on a runner's face or the curve a pole makes in rising. Everything is slowed down to the speed of "poetry in motion."By contrast, almost everything is speeded up in Milos Forman's satiric vignette intercutting the decathlon with shots of musical groups, ranging from some sort of cowbell band to a full-scale performance of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony. Nobody escapes the witless humor, and Forman, usually a fine director, has turned in the worst sequence in the film.Not everything is this bad. Claude Lelouch's study of the losers shows some athletes in real pain, some merely befuddled (like competing swimmers staring in disbelief at the retreating form of Mark Spitz) and has at least the virtues of canny documentary.And there are parts of Mai Zetterling's sequence on weight-lifting or the West German Michael Pfleghar's tribute to women in the Olympics, in which concentration on athletic performance overcomes the impulse to fancy film-making and results in work of real quality.Pfleghar devotes a few minutes to a very young Soviet gymnast, Ludmilla Tourischeva, both standing by herself and working on the uneven parallel bars, and those are perhaps the most beautiful, least assertive, moments in the movie.I also liked the long closing sequence to "Visions of Eight," which is uncredited, but which I understand is largely the work of John Schlesinger. As for so much of the rest, it seems to forget that it is the privilege of the modest art of film to find the meaning of things just in the way they are seen to be.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP)A monthlong festival of theater, music and film entitled Shakespeare and the Performing Arts was annoumed yesterday for the operning of the Kennedy Center's third year.

title: Laird Denies Authorizing Falsified Reports on Raids
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 10Former Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that he had authorized a separate reporting procedure for the Nixon Administration's secret B52 bombing raids in Cambodia in 1969 but insisted he had not sanctioned the falsification of any Air Force, Navy or Defense Department records.

title: Notes on People
description: The Washington office of Senator Jacob K, Javits disclosed yesterday that he had asked for police protection list month after the murder outside Washington of an Israeli diplomat, Col. Yosef Alon. The Senator, who was on vacation and could not be reached for comment, is Jewish and has long been allied with Jewish causes. His staff also disclosed that he had been given special police protection at public appearances after Israeli athletes were murdered by Arab terrorists at the 1972 Olympics in Munich. The Javits office also said that the Senator had been denied such protection by the Federal authorities two years ago because the law provided protection only for Presidents and Presidential candidates. The Senator's office said it was reluctant to discuss the specifics of protecting the Senator.

title: Israeli Jets Over Lebanon Force Down Arab Airliner
description: JERUSALEM, Saturday, Aug. 11  Israel announced this morning that her air force had intercepted a Middle East Airlines jetliner outside of Beirut last night and forced the plane to fly to a military airfield in Israel. But a military spokesman later conceded that the wrong plane had been seized.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: 2 More Bodies Found in Hotel

title: COMMONWEALTH ENDS GATHERING
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 10  The Commonwealth heads of government ended nine days of deliberation here today with a statement supporting majority rule in Rhodesia and expressing intense concern about the situation there.

title: Iverson and Rudolph Tie At 139 for P.G.A. Lead
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 10 While Jack Nicklaus moved within a stroke of the lead and Arnold Palmer failed to qualify, Don Iverson, the copacesetter yesterday, shared the 36hole lead in the Professional Golfers Association championship today with Mason Rudolph at 139.

title: PRESIDENT SIGNS FARM BILL ENDING PRICE SUBSIDIES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10President Nixon signed today legislation establishing a fouryear farm program with a new method of subsidizing the main crops. Under the new approach for wheat, feed grains and cotton, the Government will make no effort to keep prices up by the various means used in the past.

title: Banks Lift Prime Rate to 9%, A Peak, After One Week at 9%
description: Many of the nation's biggest banks yesterday raised their prime interest rate from 9 to 9 per cent, a record.

title: Miss Austin's 70 Gains Stroke Edge In Illinois Golf
description: WADSWORTH, Ill., Aug. 10 (AP)Debbie Austin of Oneida, N. Y., played through heavy wind today for a threeunderpar 70 and took the firstround lead in the $30,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament.

title: Thomas Olam Marries Miss Elizabeth Davis
description: PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., Aug. 10  Miss Elizabeth Blakslee Davis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Gale Davis, was married here this evening to Thomas Edward Olam, son of Mr. and Mrs. Emil Olam of Pelham, The Rev. Philip Ogden performed the ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church.

title: NIXON WILL RESPOND IN TALK NEXT WEEK
description: CAMP DAVID, Md., Aug. 10 (AP)President Nixon worked today with his chief speechwriter and Watergate lawyer as the White House announced that he would respond next week to disclosures before the Senate Watergate committee.

title: World Grass Mark Set By Tentam at Saratoga
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. Aug. 10  The Cragwood Stable, with the superb assistance of Jorge Velasquez, took both ends of the Bernard Baruch Handicap today.

title: Israeli Jets Over Lebanon Force Down Arab Airliner
description: JERUSALEM, Saturday, Aug. 11  Israel announced this morning that her air force had intercepted a Middle East Airlines jetliner outside of Beirut last night and forced the plane to fly to a military airfield in Israel. But military spokesmen later conceded that the wrong plane had been seized.
