title: Cowboy Legend Still True on Weekends
description: CAMERON, Mont., Aug. 8 He was called a waddie, a buckaroo or an ranahan. He lived with cattle for weeks at a time. He had no radio, no television and no pickup truck. A saddle was his home, his pillow and his prized possession.

title: 14 More War Protesters Arrested at White House
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP)  Fourteen persons were arrested yesterday for holding antiwar prayer vigils in the public tour lines at the White House.

title: S.E.C. to Resume Hearing On Proposed Rate Increases
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission said today it would reconvene on Thursday a hearing into proposed increases in commission rates charged by securities firms.

title: U.S. Alleges School Segregation In Suit Against Omaha District
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) The Justice Department filed suit today charging the school district of Omaha, Neb., with maintaining racially segregated schools in violation of the law.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Shipping/Mails

title: Slain Park Ranger Honored
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UPI) The National Park Service today ordered flags flown at halfstaff at all national parks in honor of Kenneth C. Patrick, the first park ranger to be shot and killed in the line of duty. He was shot to death Sunday at Point Reyes National Seashore in California while investigating a report of poachers on Park Service land. He was buried today at Grand Canyon National Park.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology has been awarded a $39million addition to an Air Force contract for operating Lincoln Laboratory, a research facility, during the present fiscal year which ends next June 30.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Article 4  No Title

title: Giant Attack Line Hailed by Larson
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., Aug. 10Greg Larson, who has been in one spot long enough to qualify as a critic, today called the current offensive line for the New York Giants, the strongest since I've been here.

title: EHRLICHMAN SCORED ON ELLSBERG CHARGE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UPI) An attorney for Dr. Daniel Ellsberg has chided the Senate Watergate committee for failing to challenge what he called totally false and slanderous testimony by the former White House aide, John D. Ehrlichman, suggesting that Dr. Ellsberg delivered copies of the Pentagon papers to the Soviet Embassy.

title: Thursday's Fights
description: Los AngelesTury (The Fury) Pineda, 135 pounds, Mexicali, Mexico, knocked out Mando Ramos, 137, Long Beach, Calif., 5 rounds; Jesse Burnett, 164, Los Angeles, awarded technical decision over Felton Marshall, 159, Los Angeles, 9.

title: YEAR OF EUROPE IS YEAR OF DELAY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9Eight months into what President Nixon has proclaimed the Year of Europe in United States foreign policy, hardly anything that would lend substance to the label has become visible.

title: Boozer, Hill Suspended
description: TAMPA, Fla., Aug. 10Emerson Boozer and Winston Hill, the two salary holdouts in the New York Jets training camp, were fined and suspended from the squad today by Weeb Ewbank, the team's coach and general manager.

title: U.S. SUBPOENAS AGNEW ARCHIVES
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 10Federal investigators subpoenaed today the records of Vice President Agnew's twoyear administration as Governor of Maryland and any and all financial records dealing with his campaign for the governorship.

title: Price Controls Are Kept on Gas and Oil
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 Gasoline, heating oil and other petroleum products will remain under rigid price controls for an indefinite period, the Nixon Administration announced today.

title: PRIMERATE RISE TOPPLES STOCK
description: Another tightening notch in the prime rate served to unsettle an already nervous stock market yesterday and drove the DowJones industrial average down to its lowest close in four weeks.

title: Plan to Test a New Antihijacking System Is Shelved
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has shelved plans to test new antihijacking procedures that were aimed at ending the sevenmonthold practice of searching all carryon luggage at airports and using metal detectors to screen all passengers.

title: in MORE BODIES FOUND IN RUBBLE
description: The third and fourth knowr victims of the collapse of the old Broadway Central Hate were pulled yesterday from beneath the brick, plaster and wood wreckage of the formez city landmark.

title: Brannan Crop Plan Now Reality
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10It took nearly a quarter of century, but Charles F. Brannan was a happy man today.

title: HOLDUP MAN KILLED BY QUEENS JEWELER
description: A 21yearold gunman was shot to death yesterday afternoon by a jeweler in Jamaica, Queens, when he began to menace the jeweler's wife with revolver during a holdup, the police reported.

title: Radio
description: Radio

title: Baseball Transactions
description: DETROITPurchased Tom Verner, shortstop, from Toledo of International League; released Rich Reese, first baseman and outfielder.

title: Roundup: Boston Boos, Smith Leaves
description: Reggie Smith, Boston's controversial outfielder, left Fenway Park last night in the second inning of a game with the California Angels after he had a runin with fans.

title: AMEX PRICES OFF ON RATE INCREASE
description: Prices declined on a broad front yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market.

title: SECRET SERVICE CHECKS ON SPYING
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) The Secret Service said today that it was investigating reports that one of its agents passed information about Senator George McGovern of South Dakota to the White House while assigned to guard the 1972 Democratic Presidential candidate.

title: Equity Financing
description: New England Telephone & Telegraph Company yesterday filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with a rights offering of 6,500,000 common shares on the basis of one share for each six shares held on Sept. 7. The company's stock closed at 32, down  on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: WITNESS DENIES BE AIDED ARRESTS
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Aug. 10 The Government's star witness, William L. Lemmer, told the Gainesville Eight trial today that people he had known for only a few hours had offered him $5,000 to drive his car on a weekend expedition to pick marijuana, that he turned in one of my closest friends for a bomb threat and that a teenager he had encountered at a football bonfire had announced that he planned to burn a campus landmark.

title: MILARD KING ROPER
description: Milard King Roper, a lawyer and a former president of the Jamaica, Queens, Real Estate Board, died of cancer yesterday in Nassau Hospital, Mineola. He was 58 years old and lived at 8620 261st Street, Floral Park, Queens.

title: Philadelphia Kosher Shops To Close in Price Protest
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 10 (UPI)  All 55 of the city's kosher meat markets will be closed next week in protest over exorbitant price increases in poultry, veal and lamb because of unavailability of kosher beef caused by the price ceiling.

title: Denial of Funds Appealed
description: BOSTON, Aug. 10 (AP)Gov. Francis W. Sargent said today that he had been told that Massachusetts would not receive $6.5million in Federal funds for retraining workers who lost their jobs in the closing of military bases. He wrote to President Nixon and requested a meeting to discuss the developing crisis.

title: Amy Alcott, Mary Lawrence Reach Junior Golf Final
description: BERNARDSVILLE, N. J., Aug. 10Amy Alcott of Los Angeles gained the final today of the 25th United States of the 25th United States Golf Association junior girls championship by defeating Mary Beth King of Limekiln, Pa., 6 and 5, at the Somerset

title: Teamsters Repudiate Contracts As Chavez Quits Grape Talks
description: BURLINGAME, Calif. Aug. 10 (AP)The teamsters union repudiated today contracts that had just been signed with San Joaquin Valley grape growers shortly after Cesar Chavez, leader of the United Farm Workers, stormed out of peace meeting of farm laborers and highlevel teamsters and A.F.L.C.I.O. leaders.

title: 2 Women Seized in Freehold Believed To Be Part of ConfidenceGame Ring
description: FREEHOLD TOWNSHIP, Aug. 10It was a quiet, sunny day  a perfect day for working outdoors  when two women stopped to make small talk with a stranger in a shopping center off State Highway 9 here.

title: Argentina's Capital: A Polar Island
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 10 (AP)  Argentina's seat of government shifted briefly to a polar island today as President Ratil Lastiri and his Cabinet visited the country's disputed Antarctic territory.

title: Kashmiri Leader Will Take Indian Role
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 10In a dramatic switch of role, the Kashmiri Moslem leader, Sheik Mohammed Abdullah, has announced that he will enter Indian national politics to serve the entire country instead of only Kashmir.

title: 2DQUARTER NET OFF AT BIG BOARD
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that its net revenues during the second quarter declined nearly 50 per cent from yearearlier levels, but were more than double firstquarter figures. Indicated net revenues for the second quarter were $2,046,900 compared to last year's $4,043,800. In the first quarter of this year net revenues were $947,800.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK, Aug. 10Five dollars may not go very far these days but Peter Westbrook has stretched it all the way from this city's ghetto to the World University Games in Moscow.

title: Clue to Quake Forecasting Sought in Tiny Temblors
description: BLUE MOUNTAIN LAKE, N. Y.A swarm of small earthquakes that began to rattlewithout damagethis Adirondack resort area a couple of weeks ago has provoked some mild unease among the cottage and motel owners but undisguised enthusiasm among a small band of geologists who have rushed in to turn the wooded area into a huge outdoor laboratory.

title: Retail Sales Climbed 3% In July to $42.6Billion
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10Retail sales jumped 3 per cent in July, according to preliminary figures collected by the Census Bureau and released today.

title: Business Briefs
description: July Savings Withdrawals Set Record

title: TV: A Report on Drought
description: The Reasoner Report, on the television network of the American Broadcasting Company tonight, is devoted entirely to a compassionate, vividly photographed examination of the plight of the millions of West Africans who have been uprooted by the great drought that is now in its fifth year.

title: Nixon May Address V.F.W.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) The White House said today that an appearance by President Nixon before the Veterans of Foreign Wars Convention in New Orleans around Aug. 20 was under consideration. Mr. Nixon is at Camp David, Md., preparing a speech on Waterh gate that he is expected to deliver next week, shortly before he leaves for a California vacation.

title: 49 Years With Ervin: Mr. Chairman Calls Miz Margaret Perfect
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10Everybody knows Sam Ervin. The white hair, the mobile brow, the dark bushy eyebrows that never seem to stop sweeping up and down like a bird in flight, the tireless storyteller with a computersharp memory of the Bible, the Constitution, Shakespeare's works  the perfect paradigm of the courtly Southern senator of an era gone forever.

title: Palmer: Meanest Cut of All
description: CLEVELAND. Aug. 10I can't even get mad any more, said Arnold Palmer after failing to qualify by one stroke for the final 36 holes of the Professional Golfers Association championship because of poor putting.

title: I.R.S. IN PACT TO END LIEN AGAINST SMITH
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 10 (UPI)Attorneys for the Government and C. Arnholt Smith, a financierreached an agreement today to delete from a Federal tax claim a demand by the Internal Revenue Service for immediate payment of $22.8million.

title: 600 POLICE ATTEND DEAD CHIEF'S RITES
description: WOODBINE, Aug. 10About 300policemen from New Jersey and surrounding states came to this rural borough today for the funeral of Police Chief Philip 10 DeSantis, which was conducted shortly before a suspect in his murder was arraigned in nearby Cape May Court House. St. Casimir's Roman Catholic church was filled to capacity with 260 relatives and townpeople. Four hundred of the policemen stood in ranks of four outside the American Legion Hall as eight of the chief's nephews bore his coffin to the church.

title: Soviet Has 4 Craft on 300 MillionMile Mars Trip
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 10The launching of a fourth Soviet spacecraft toward Mars within three weeks indicates an even more ambitious exploration effort than had been expected by Western experts.

title: Too Many Persons Missing Each Year To Rouse Suspicion
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 10The police said today that such a large number of persons were reported missing each year that it was difficult to find'any patterns that would cause suspicion of mass murders.

title: New President of Pakistan Named in Government Shift
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 10 Chaudhri Fazal Elahi, former, speaker of the National Assembly, was named President of Pakistan by the Legislature today.

title: News Summary and Index SATURDAY, AUGUST 11, 1973
description: Israel announced that her air force had intercepted a Middle East Airlines jet airliner approaching Beirut and had forced the plane to a military airfield in Israel. But military spokesmen said the wrong plane had been seized; and after two hours it was permitted to continue its scheduled flight to Iraq with its 74 passengers and crew of seven. [Page 1, Columns 34.]

title: 3 Are Burned Seriously In a CleaningFluid Blaze
description: Two women and a man in Queens were burned seriously yesterday in a fire apparently caused when the cleaning fluid, they were using ignited.

title: TV: Silents
description: Good movies, old or newand the television vaults are fullcould have brightened this bleak, homeScreen summer. Not so. The networks and local channels couldn't care less. WCBS/Channel 2, for example, in one bizarre ploy, even persists in putting on such gems as Grand Hotel, Dinner at Eight and The Good Earth around 3 A.M.

title: Bridge.
description: The summer Swiss team championship of the Greater New York Bridge Association begins at the New York Hilton today with the following schedule: today, 1:30 and 7:30 P.M. tomorrow, 1 and 7 P.M. A Flight B event will be played tomorrow for new entrants and for any teams withdrawing from the main event.

title: Nude Body of a Man Found In Office of an Ad Agency
description: The nude body of a man, apparently the victim of heart attack, was found in Lexington Avenue advertising office last night.

title: Results of Nearby Yacht Racing
description: Results of Nearby Yacht Racing

title: Dollar Moves Up Again In Money Trading Abroad
description: LONDON, Aug. 10 (AP)The United States dollar today bounded to its highest levels against major European currencies for more than a month, and the price of gold tumbled. The dollar was significantly stronger against the German mark, the French franc and the British pound.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Commissioner Bob Carlson of the American Basketball Association said here yesterday the A.B.A. and National Basketball Association had been authorized by a Federal court order to seek a new merger agreement without Congressional approval. Carlson said A.B.A. attorneys had obtained the order from Judge Robert L. Carter. Commissioner Walter Kennedy of the N.B.A. had no comment, but Carlson said N.B.A. attorneys had received copies of the order.

title: A Point in Time Has Come To Define Watergate Lingo
description: WASHINGTON  Now is the point in time for all good men to come to the aid of the Watergate language.

title: Patrolman's Proposition Leads to Suspension
description: The long (and in this case feminine) arm of the law fell on a 25yearold policeman near Times Square early yesterday when, according to the Manhattan North Decoy Unit, he allegedly tried to patronize a policewoman.

title: Ailey Influence Pervades Soul at Center Program
description: Whether by design or accident, Soul at the Center paid tribute to the substantial accomplishment of Alvin Ailey as teacher and choreographer on Thursday evening at Alice Tully Hall. The program was officially dedicated to the late Donald Harper of the New York State Council on the Arts, and the bulk of the dances and dancers were artistically related to Mr. Ailey.

title: People in Sports: Walton, U.C.L.A. Star, Saved by Injection After the Sting of a Bee
description: Bill Walton of the University of California, Los Angeles, the center who has led the Bruins to national championships the last two basketball seasons, narrowly escaped death last weekfrom a bee sting.

title: Menhaden Blues
description: Connecticut's minifish war, fought with dead fish and legal briefs hurled by rival commercial and sports fishermen, is a ridiculous quarrel between men who would serve their mutual interests better by cooperating to preserve a bonanza offering fish enough for all.

title: Allende's Trump: A Democratic Tradition
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 10Chileans went serenely about their usual occupations as life appeared almost normal on this sunny winter's day and a grizzled fruit hawker said, I hope everything's going to be all right, now that the military have taken over. It wasn't quite so, but President Salvador Allende Gossens's move to bring the military into his Socialist  oriented Government has brought this crisisridden country the prospect of at least temporary stability. The military are perhaps in the most difficult position for having shpuldered the burden of restoring order to this country, torn by political dissent, terrorism and the threat of an economic breakdown. They are also concerned about the recent discovery of subversion within their own ranks, particularly the navy.

title: New Agnew Home Is A Long Step Up
description: BETHESDA, Md., Aug. 10 The big 40yearold stone house sits on a small ridge that runs along Shadow Road, and neighbors have seen Spiro Theodore Agnew sitting alone on the grass under the tall trees in front of the house, where he has lived for the last month.

title: Brannan Crop Plan Now Reality
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10It took nearly a quarter of century, but Charles F. Brannan was a happy man today.

title: Turkey Said to Grant Bail To Four American Women
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UM) The Turkish Government has granted bail for four young Americans jailed for eight months on charges of drug $muggling, the State Department spokesman said, are Maria Therese Crocki, 25 years old of San Francisco; Penelope Czarnecki, 23, of San Francisco; Paula Gibson, 23 of Fairfax, Va.; and Margaret Engle, 20, of Falls Church, Va.

title: COURT EXPLAINS BOMBING RULING
description: An appeals court declared here yesterday that the continued American bombing of Cambodia involved a political issue beyond the competence of courts.

title: Br'er Rabbit's PATH
description: The order of the Interstate Commerce Commission temporarily suspending a 20cent fare increase by PATH, the Port Authority TransHudson commuter rail link between New York and New Jersey, provides something more than relief from the runaway cost of living for PATH riders. The I.C.C. has promised to follow up its order with public hearings. These ought to include not only the arguments of commuter groups and environmentalists oprpsed to such an outsized fare hike but also an indeptrident, impartial audit of Port Authority books and a general review of the Authority's mass transit responsibilities. The continued bland denial of authority spokesmen that it could legally assume larger responsibility in mass transit is much in need of I.C.C. evaluation.

title: NIXON EXTENDING F.H.A. AUTHORITY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UPI) President Nixon signed legislation today extending authority for the Federal Housing Administration to grant lowinterest loans at least until Oct. 1 to ease the current squeeze on home mortgage money.

title: Stratford, Conn., Is Learning to Love the Bard
description: STRATFORD, Conn., Aug. 10With the shyness of starcrossed lovers, the American Shakespeare Theatre here and the town of Stratford are making cautious advances toward ending the polite isolation that has separated them.

title: TRUCK DRIVER GROUP ASKS SAFETY RULES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10Professional truck drivers are faced with the dilemma of whether to risk their lives and safety or their livelihood when confronted with the prospect of driving a vehicle that is in hazardous condition, the Professional Drivers Council charged.

title: Soviet Has 4 Craft on 300MillionMile Mars
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 10The launching of a fourth Soviet spacecraft toward Mars within three weeks indicates an even more ambitious exploration effort than had been expected by Western experts.

title: DE PIMA BUILDING SOLD TO IRANIANS
description: A foundation representing the royal family of Iran has purchased the former DePinna building on Fifth Avenue at 52d Street, apparently sparing it from demolition.

title: Miss Spilatro Wed To John C. Millikin
description: CONVENT STATION, N. J., Aug. 10Miss Margaret Ann Spilatro and John Castle Millikin were married here this afternoon in St. Thomas Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Joseph Casey.

title: Texas Police Find Four More Bodies; The Total Is Now 23
description: HIGH ISLAND, Tex., Aug. 10 The police unearthed today four more badly decomposed bodies, apparently those of teenage boys, bringing to 23 the number of victims allegedly sexually assaulted, tortured and slain over a threeyear period by a polite 33yearold Houston utility worker and two teenage accomplices.

title: 2 Killed as Car Hits Tree
description: CARTHAGE, N. Y., Aug. 10 (UPI)Patrick Burke, 28 years old, of West Carthage, and his sisterinlaw, Sharon T. Burke, 23, of Carthage, were killed when the car they were riding, in ran off a road here and struck two trees early today. The police said the driver, Gary A. Baker, 23, of Carthage, apparently lost control of the car. He was reported in satisfactory condition.

title: Redskins Subdue Broncos, 14 to 10
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UPI)  Sonny Jurgensen came off the injury shelf as a second half substitute tonight to rally the Washington Redskins to a 1410 exhibition victory over the Denver Broncos Duane Thomas, Washington's controversial running back, scored the team's first touchdown, but the Redskins were trailing, 107, at halftime.

title: COLOMBO SON SUES DISTRICT ATTORNEY
description: Vincent Colombo, the 22yearold son of Joseph A. Colombo Sr., the reputed organized crime figure, has filed suit against District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn, accusing him of being arbitrary and capricious in restoring to the Criminal Court calendar a motor vehicle violation against the young man.

title: Cowboy Legend Still True  on Weekends
description: CAMERON, Mont., Aug. 8 He was called a waddie, a buckaroo or an ranahan. He lived with cattle for weeks at a time. He had no radio, no television and no pickup truck. A saddle was his home, his pillow and his prized possession.

title: Paramount Tells Puerto Ricans It Won't Withdraw Badge 373
description: Paramount Pictures yesterday turned down an ultimatum by the Puerto Rican Action Coalition, which had demanded the withdrawal of the film Badge 373 from national and international screens because, the coalition said, it was racist.

title: Heavy Sentences Imposed on 2 In Conspiracy Trial in Athens
description: ATHENS, Saturday, Aug. 11 The Athens special military court early today imposed 18year and 15year prison sentences on two of the six royalists on trial for exploding bombs and conspiring against the armybacked Government. The four other defendants received lighter sentences.

title: Books of The Times
description: During the 6,000milelong march from defeat on the Kiangsi battlefield to the sanctuary of Yenan, the Chinese Communist leadership paused in Tsunyi in Janwiry, 1935, for an epochal innerparty struggle over policy and power. There, Chou Enlai and other challengers yielded to Mao Tsetung, whose strategy would bring victory in 1949.

title: Demand for Electricity Breaks Record Again
description: For the second day in a row, Consolidated Edison reported a record demand for electricity yesterday. A company spokesman said the demand reached 8,136,000 kilowatts, compared with the previous record of 8,113,000 kilowatts set on Thursday.

title: Television
description: 5:30 (4)Modern Farmer

title: Music: Fate of an Idea
description: LENOX, Mass., Aug. 10 The 10th Festival of Contemporary Music at the Berkshire Music Center came to a close last night with an orchestral concert that demonstrated at length how little terseness has come to be valued in some influential composing circles. The haikulike brevity of Webern, whose thin textures and constrained designs dominated the scene for a generation after his death in 1945, has suffered the fate of many a good idea. It has been parodized into extinction by mediocre artists.

title: French, Citing Safety, Halt Cambodia Flights
description: PARIS, Aug. 10 (AP)Two French airlines, Air France and U.T.A., announced today that they were halting passenger flights into Cambodia as a safety precaution.

title: CHARLES WELCH
description: NATICK, Mass., Aug. 10 (AP)  Charles (Chick) Welch, sports writer and editor of the weekly Natick Herald for 50 years, died at Leonard Morse Hospital today at the age of 78.

title: Dr. Joseph Harrer Dead; Aided Argonne Reactor
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 10 (AP)Dr. Joseph M. Harrer, a pioneer engineer in nuclear reactors, and a senior staff member of the Argonne National Laboratory, died yesterday at the age of 60. He lived in suburban Elmhurst.

title: ROBERT K. CUTTER, LED LABORATORIES
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Aug. 10Dr. Robert K. Cutter, chairman of the board of Cutter Laboratories, Inc., pharmaceutical manufacturers, died here Thursday after a brief illness. His age was 75.

title: Girl's Best Friend Dearer Than Ever.
description: The rings on her fingers (if they're precious stones) and the bells on her toes (if they're gold) are, apparently, better than money in the bank these days.

title: School Board Investigating Charges Of Nepotism in Hiring of 3 in Canarsie
description: The Board of Education said yesterday that it was investigating charges by a Brooklyn City Councilman that the superintendent of the Canarsie school district tolerated nepotism in hiring practices.

title: Art: For Flying Painting
description: The Guggenheim Museum's new summer exhibition180 works from its own collectioncarries a bonus promising that art buffs who have tried everything else will soon be able to cap their experiences by flying to and from South America inside an original painting by Alexander Calder.

title: UptoDate Methods Of Management Aid In Reviving Cohoes
description: COHOES, N. Y., Aug. 10Paul G. VanBuskirk wears two hats, one on each side of the Hudson River.

title: Gains Reported in Drive Against Vice in Midtown
description: The city's continuing drive against vice in the Times Square area reflects a substantial measure of success with the closing of more massage parlors and a reported 50 per cent drop in the number of prostitutes operating in the area.

title: RICKENBACKER RITES HELD IN COLUMBUS
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 10 (AP)Family friends and the Air Force paid final tribute today to Capt. Eddie Rickenbacker.

title: Vietcong Expand Road Network
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 10A network of roads the Communists have been energetically building in South Vietnam since the American bombing halt in January now stretches over 250 miles from the North Vietnamese border to the central part of the country, American intelligence officials say.

title: Troupe of Haitian Exiles To Play in Prospect Park
description: La Troupe Kouidor, a group of Haitian exiles, is scheduled to present a program of music, poetry, theater and song in French and Creole at 4 P.M. tomorrow at the Prospect Park band shell in Brooklyn.

title: WHEAT FUTURES RISE DAILY LIMIT
description: Some earlymorning frantic buying of wheat petered out yesterday in the first half hour of trading once prices had jumped the daily limit. With no sellers willing to do business, buying orders remained unfilled for a million bushels or more.

title: PEGGY ROTH, EDITOR FOR DELL PUBLISHING
description: Peggy Roth, editor in chief lof the Dell Books division of the Dell Publishing Company, died Wednesday of complications following viral pneumonia at Mount Sinai Hospital. She lived at 440 West 34th Street.

title: Lillian Roxon, 40, Chronicler Of Rock Culture, Music, Dies
description: Lillian Roxon, an authority on rock music and one of the leading chroniclers of its culture and personalities, died Thursday from the effects of an asthma attack. She was 40 years old.

title: Jersey Economy Nears Record Despite 7% Unemployment Rate By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN
description: TRENTON, Aug. 10  New Jersey's economy will produce a record $50billion gross state product this year despite a stubborn high 7 per cent tinemployment rate, according to Ronald M. Heymann, State Labor and Industry Commissioner.

title: British Treasury Bill Rate Posts Rise for the Week
description: LONDON, Aug. 10, (Reuters) The average rate at today's tender of British treasury bills rose to 10.9076 per cent from 10.7800 per cent.

title: Guard Wounded as Bank Is Robbed Twice in Day
description: A bank guard was seriously wounded yesterday during a blazing exchange of gunfire in the second holdup of the day in the same bank branch.

title: Sports Today
description: Freeport Stadium, Freeport, LI., 7:30 P.M.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: Hanol's Premier in Crimea
description: MOSCOW, Aug 10. (UPI) Premier Pham Van Dong of North Vietnam arrived in the Crimea today at the head of a governmental delegation, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported.

title: Laird Denies Authorizing Falsified Reports on Raids
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 10Former Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that he had authorized a separate reporting procedure for the Nixon Administration's secret B52 bombing raids in Cambodia in 1969 but insisted he had not sanctioned the falsification of any Air Force, Navy or Defense Department records.

title: Dave Anderson
description: For better or for worse, they resembled what boxing was like before the lawyers took over. In a suite high in the old Wellington Hotel, the fighter was relaxing on the couch an hour before his workout downstairs in the ballroom. In a stuffed chair across the room, the manager, in a blackandwhite figured shirt and turquoise slacks, was waving an unlit cigar and doing most of the talking. In three weeks, Joe (King) Roman Puerto Rico will be fighting George Foreman in Tokyo for the world heavyweight title. But his manager, Bill Daly, got him there, not his record. Bill Daly is 74 years old now. His hair is thin, but most of it is still brown. The toughness is still in his Irish face, the toughness that comes from having survived in boxing for more than 50 years. As a kid in New Jersey he learned how to survive by Working for Jack (Doc) Kearns, who was Jack Dempsey's manager. Much later he was around Frankie Carbo and Blinky Palermo, but he survived a Senate investigation into boxing. Through the years he handled several famous fighters. Perhaps the best was Carlos Ortiz, the world lightweight champion not long ago. He once had a piece of Archie Moore, the lightheavyweight champion.

title: Drivers and Newspapers To Negotiate Next Friday
description: Negotiators for the city's three major daily newspapers and the newspaper drivers union are scheduled to meet next Friday in an effort to reach agreement on a new contract.

title: Official Cool to California Plea For a San Clemente Tax Review
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 10 (AP)Only a neighbor with a comparably priced home has the legal standing to force a local tax board to investigate the property taxes on President Nixon's Western White House, according to the chairman of Orange County Assessment Appeals Board No. 1. But the chairman, Otto Christensen, said that such action was not likely because the seaside estate at San Clemente was the highestpriced residence in Orange County.

title: Kheel Plans to Give Full Support To Transportation Bond Issue
description: Theodore W. Kheel declared yesterday his support for Governor Rockefeller's proposed $15billion transportation bond issue and said he would campaign for it as part of a threepoint transportation program.

title: ASTRONAUTS WATCH A SOLAR EXPLOSION
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 10 (UPI)The Skylab 2 astronauts photographed a truly spectacular solar eruption of gaseous material today on their first day off in two weeks.

title: ROCKWELL BOARD BACKS A TENDER
description: The board of directors of the Rockwell International Corporation approved yesterday A tender offer for all 2,967,647 common shares outstanding of the Collins Radio Company at $25 a share, or for a total of $74,191,175.

title: About the Mets:
description: This weekend may mark the last appearance of Willie Mays in San Francisco as an active player, just as his pinchhitting appearance in Los Angeles Thursday night may have been his farewell to Dodger Stadium. Willie batted for Jerry Koosman, leading off the ninth, and grounded out. He had to be tagged at first because the throw was wide, and had the wind knocked out of him, causing momentary alarm as first aid arrived, but he emerged uninjured. Although the Mets lost to the Dodgers, they did have the satisfaction of seeing one tough inning work out according to plan. While the game was still scoreless in the fifth, two singles and a sacrifice gave the Dodgers men on second and third with one out and the head of the batting order coming up. With the infield in, Koosman made Dave Lopes hit a handleable grounder Felix Milian for the second out. But now Manny Mota, righthanded batter hitting .331, was up against the lefthanded Koosman with two runners in scoring position, be followed by Willie Davis, who bats lefthanded. After a summit conference it was decided to pitch to Mota instead of walking him, and Mota did produce a thirdout grounder. The decision looked even better when Davis led off the next inning with a hit. The Dodgers, who started the season badly but came on strong, have drawn about 1,550,000 so far. The Giants, who started off great and then slumped, have drawn about 600,000 Conclusion: the Dodgers are better at selling tickets than the Giants.

title: Richard Henry Pratt Dies; Architect and Author, 81
description: STONINGTON, Conn., Aug. 10  Richard Henry Pratt, architect, landscape designer and author, died at his home this morning after a long illness. He was 81 years old.

title: W. SHELDON CHAPIN
description: FALMOUTH, Me., Aug. 10W. Sheldon Chapin, retired assistant executive editor of the three Portland newspapers of the Guy Gannett Publishing Company, died today at his home here after a long illnesi. He was 68 years old. Mr. Chapin had been with the newspapers for 40 years until his retirement in 1970.

title: Suits on Bridge Collapse Bring $950,000
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 10  A Federal judge ordered today that the United States Steel Corporation and the J. E. Greiner Company, Inc., pay $950,000 in part settlement of suits brought by relatives of the 46 persons killed and those injured in the collapse of the Silver Bay Bridge in December, 1967.

title: Stage: London Musicals
description: LONDONWhatever is it that British musicals did not have, they still haven't got it. Partly the answer is music. For years the American stranglehold over British pop music hardly encouraged indigenous efforts. But in the postBeatle era it is surprising that more British pop composers have not arisen to make the musical something more of their own.

title: LILCO Link, Via Sound, To Tie It to Power Pool
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 10 The State Public Service Commission approved today a 17milelong power transmission line under Long Island Sound that will tie the Long Island Lighting Company into the New York State power pool.

title: Chris Evert Gains Final, Not Jeanne
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 10 (AP) Evonne Goolagong of Australia, relying on her experience and height advantage, ended 15yearold Jeanne Evert's hopes today with a 63, 62 victory in the semifinals of the $75,000 Western tennis tournament.

title: Canadian Bid Extended For Texasgulf by Week
description: A $290million cash offer of the Canada Development Corporation to purchase 10 million shares of Texasgulf, Inc., from the company's shareholders was extended yesterday for an additional week. The offer was to have expired yesterday.

title: How They Answered Buchanan and Safire
description: To the Editor: Patrick J. Buchanan and William Safire find themselves in the unenviable position of whitewashing the White House. Both a present and former Presidential speechwriter are desperately trying to bury Watergate under a scathing counterattack on the reputed misdeeds of the Democrats. But two wrongs do not make a right: alleged votefrauds in the 1960 Kennedy Nixon campaign make a poor excuse for dirty tricks in 1972, and buggings of the past hardly justify Presidential wiretapping now. Our White House apologists should face the fact that absence of moral leadership is at the bottom of Watergate, ALFRED GOLDSMITH Pearl River, N. Y.

title: Mr. Nothing Awaits His Millions
description: To get richer in Atherica what you need is a shortage.

title: Model ChangeOver For Auto Industry Cuts Weekly Output
description: DETROIT Aug. 10 (AP)The automobile industry's annual slowdown for its modelyear changeover caused United States auto production to fall by nearly 53,000 units this week, according to Automotive News.

title: PRESIDENT SIGNS FARM BILL ENDING PRICE SUBSIDIES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10President Nixon signed today legislation establishing a fouryear farm program with a neli method of subsidizing the main crops.

title: MRS. JOHN W. AMES
description: Mrs. Mary Forman Ames, widow of John W. Ames, architect, died yesterday at her home, 200 East 66th Street. She was 93 years old.

title: BAIL IS ORDERED IN I.R.A. GUN CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UPI) Justice William 0. Douglas of the Supreme Court granted bail today to the socalled Fort Worth Five, a group of Irishborn New Yorkers jailed in Texas since January for refusing to answer a Federal grand jury's questions about illegal gun purchases.

title: Air Traffic Control Failure Blamed in Chicago Crash
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) The death of 10 persons last December in the collision of two airplanes at Chicago's O'Hare International Airport was attributed yesterday to  failure of the traffic control system to insure separation of aircraft during a period of restricted visibility.

title: EDWARD MUESER
description: MOUNTAIN LAKES, N.J., Aug. 10Edward Mueser, who patented in the nineteentwenties a method for locating metallic ore bodies by electrical means, died at his home here Aug. 1. He was 84 years old.

title: 27.000 Canadian Railmen Idle in Regional Strikes
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 10 (AP)The series of regional strikes against Canada's railroads continued today as 20,000 workers walked off their jobs in Ontario and another 7,000 were ordered out in British Columbia, Alberta and the Northwest Territories.

title: People and Business
description: John J. Balles, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, said at a luncheon meeting yesterday in Salt Lake City that with proper policy measures I believe that we can slow down the boom and experience nothing worse than a temporary period of subnormal growth as we move into 1974.

title: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
description: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I should like to refer you to a proved and readily available solution to large part of the energy problem, which was reviewed in such disturbing terms by the writers of two letters published in your July 13 issue.

title: The Tapes (cont.)
description: CONCORD, Mass. In the name of common sense, Prof. Charles Black adjures the President (OpEd page, Aug. 3) to withhold the written or taped records of his consultations as President In order to protect the conduct of his office. I suggest that it is far from commonsensical to encourage the President to withhold evidence that may either prove or disprove charges that he was implicated in the Watergate coverup. Rather, common sense suggests that nondisclosure feeds the suspicion that has sapped the confidence of the nation.

title: Tony Perkins Weds Berry Berenson
description: After months of publicity prclaiming their indifference to formal matrimonial contracts, Berinthia (Berry) Berenson and Anthony (Tony) Perkins finally decided to get married. They obtained a license and exchanged traditional vows Thursday on cape Cod.

title: Nothing to Hide
description: Vice President Agnew's first response to disclosure that he was under investigation for possible criminal violations in the letting of Maryland public contracts was a declaration of innocence, coupled with the statement: I have confidence in the criminal justice system of the United States.

title: Deaths
description: AMESMary Forman. August 10, 1973, N.Y.C. Wife of the late John W. Ames. Mother of George F. Goodyear, Mrs. Theodore Kenefick of Buffalo and Dr. Stephen Goodyear of N.Y.C. Also survived by 10 grandchildren and 22 great grandchildren. Funeral private. Flowers gratefully declined.

title: U.S. SUBPOENAS AGNEW ARCHIVES
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 10Federal investigators subpoenaed today the records of Vice President Agnew's twoyear administration as Governor of Maryland and any and all financial records dealing with his campaign for the governorship. Morris Radoff, Maryland state archivist, said that some 130 boxes of letters, records and materials from the Agnew administration were in storage.

title: Hockey Transactions NATIONAL LEAGUE
description: CHICAGOStoned Stan Mikits, center to longterm contract, TORONTOSigned Mark Steinborn, defense man at Notre Dame, for farm club.

title: Men in Hot Seats: Con Ed Voltage Managers
description: A. Norman Terreri and John F. English could be described as sitting on hot seats in their jobs at the Consolidated Edison Company. More than any other executives at the giant utility, these two men are responsible for deciding when to enforce voltage reductions or, in extremely serious power shortages, when to resort to load shedding or even to cut the utility out of the New York Power Pool.

title: Services for Slain Woman Slated in Miami and Here
description: A funeral service for Roberta Herbert, a copywriter for Macy's who was stabbed Wednesday afternoon in the hallway of her apartment building at 494 Hudson Street, in Greenwich Village, while resisting a robbery attempt, will take place in Miami tomorrow.

title: 600 Police at Slain Jersey Chief's Rites
description: WOODBINE, Aug. 10About 600 policemen from New Jersey and surrounding states came to this rural borough today for the funeral of Police Chief Philip DeSantis, which was conducted shortly before a suspect in his murder was arraigned in nearby Cape May Court House.

title: New and Recommended
description: NINETYTWO IN THE SHADE, by Thomas McGuane. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $6.95.) The author of The Sporting Club and The Bushwhacked Piano resumes the pursuit of his favorite theme, the perilous testing of man against man, this time between a young newcomer and a reckless master guide down on the Florida Keys.

title: Worker Electrocuted Here
description: A worker was electrocuted at a construction site near the IRT Bowling Green station yesterday morning when power tool shortcircuited, the police reported. The worker, Giovanni Picinich, 39 years old, of North Bergen, N. J., an employe of the Cayuaga Construction Company, was killed when he tried to repair a power saw that had jammed.

title: Klecatsky Sweeps Both Elite Singles At Orchard Beach
CHILEAN MILITANT SEES CLASS WAR
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 11The Chilean flag flies over the Fantuzzi Aluminum and Enamelware factory and in the hall there are posters of Ernesto Che Guevara, wall murals proclaiming We will overcome and leaflets on popular power beside the neat display of flowered saucepans and teapots.

title: Copper Producers Grapple With Price Controls; They Cite Dual Prices (Abroad and At Home)
description: I've been in the copper industry for 46 years. and I've never seen conditions worse than they are right now.

title: BUILDING DEFECTS PLAGUING A COOP
description: Occupants of a sixyearold, $27million cooperative apartment development on the Lower East Side say that because of faults in its construction the elevators work poorly, windows are difficult to open and close and incinerators have badly leaked smoke.

title: L.I. Town Assists Organic Farming
description: NEW HYDE PARK, L. I. Vegetables are growing right in the middle of bustling North Hempstead  the result of an organics gardening project started by this ecologyminded town last spring.

title: Hobby Entertains Japanese Visitor
description: KEARNY  Last March, when Mrs. Hisa Miyazu arrived here from Japan for an extended visit, she was prepared for the frenetic pace of life in suburbia and knew that she could keep up with a sometimes demanding schedule. And she even came prepared for any idle time that might crop up during her long stay in the United States.

title: Yugoslav Bus Plunge Kills
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 11 (UPI)A bus skidded off the main highway from Titograd to the Adriatic coast today and plunged into a 1,000foot canyon into the Moraca River, the Yugoslav press agency, Tanyug, said. Seven persons were killed and nine injured, the agency said.

title: Television; At Last, Here Comes Sticks and Bones' (Maybe)
description: STICKS AND BONES will finally reach the homescreen on CBS this Friday night at 9, only five months late, maybe. I say maybe because once burned is twice chastened. I've already reviewed the TV version of David Rabe's play once, last March, galloping into print with extravagant remarks, promising confidently that the telecast would drive a nail into your forehead and leave your face hanging like a sack from it all weekend long. Between the publication of that review and the airdate of the program, without my permission, Sticks and Bones was canceled. This sort of thing injures a reviewer in his omniscience.

title: MONASTIC ORDER SPREAD BY YOUNG
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 11A new coeducational monasti orderindependent of any ex isting churchis being spread quietly across the nation by cheery young people in black clerical garb.

title: New Bonds Sought for Parks
description: TRENTON One of the Legislature's leading environmentalists wants the state to more than double its investment in open spaces.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: Norman Birnbaum is entitled to his judgments of my book, The Coming of PostIndustrial Societybut not to a clear misreading of the text.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  Some startling proposals to change the tax laws have been made in a forum where radical ideas have sometimes been heard in the pastand have sometimes achieved rapid acceptance once enunciated there: the Joint Economic Committee of Congress.

title: Katherine Thorp Becomes Bride Of Law Student
description: GATES MILLS, Ohio, Aug. 11The marriage of Miss Katherine Blount Thorp, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Thorp of Chagrin Falls, to P. ChrWopher Boyer took place in St. Christopher's Episcopal Church here this afternoon.

title: Newton Striving To Stay Newton
description: NEWTON  As one approaches this Sussex County seat on Route 206, the welcome sign reads: Town of Newton, Where Civic Pride Becomes Progressive Action. The message is reiterated at several key points in the business section and on the roads to and from the County Courthouse. But there is evidence that the 8,300 residents face an uphill battle if they are to make the motto a reality, for Newton shows signs of being crowded and losing much of the rural character that has identified it over the Years

title: It All Began on The Steamship Mongolia
description: THIS summer the Newark Museum Is celebrating the completion of fivevolume catalogue of its extraordinary Tibetan collection with an exhibition that combines paintings and sculptures with a large selection of ceremonial gear, household objects, and documentary photographs that can now be seen for the first time in more than 20 years. What with butter lamps, ritual trumpets, magical and astrological implements, charts, cards, traders and herders costumes, saddles and harness, weapons and utensils of all kinds, and the recreation of a picnic scene where male and female mannequins in court regalia are disposed with their props around a fancy summer tent, this is as much an ethnographic as an art exhibition, most of it hitting within that area where art and daily life are most happily fused.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: I WOULD like to comment on Al Carmines's response to Martin Dubennan's review of Carmine's The Faggot and my own play, Coming Out! (July 29, 1973). The DubermanCarmines debate raises publicly for the first time some basic questions about a new, developing gay culture; the answers will affect its future character.

title: Horseshoe Crabs Used Here to Help Humans
description: The horseshoe crab, a curiosity of nature common to the Atlantic Coast and often called a living fossil, is helping provide a quick new means for early detection of blood poisoning in humans.

title: What's New at the Movies?
description: JEREMY, directed and written by Arthur Barron and starring Robby Benson and Glynnis O'Connor, got seven favorable reviews (Roger Greenspun, Times; Kathleen Carroll, News; Archer Winsten, Post; Andrew Sarris, Village Voice; Jeffrey Lyons, WPIXTV; Charles Michener, Newsweek; Judith Crist, New York) and nine mixed (Howard, Kissel, Women's Wear; Rex Reed, News; Frances Taylor, Newhouse Newspapers; Joseph Gelmis, Newsday; Bernard Drew, Gannett News Service; Gene Shalit, NBC; John Simon, New Leader; William Wolf, Cue; Jay Cocks, Time).

title: Utility Rates to Increase Again
description: NEWARK A 60day national moratorium on utility rates ends tomorrow, and the state's Department of Public Utilities is ready to act on rateincrease applications totaling more than $175million a year. The requests cover electric, gas, water and telephone rates, as well as bus fares.

title: U.S. Nautical Charts, Once Adorned by Mrs. Whistler's Son, Now Drawn by Computer
Nixon's Houses
description: One of the side effects of the Watergate affair has been a close scrutiny of the amount of public money that has been spent on President Nixon's personal homes. There have been reports of large expenditures, with consequent charges that some were not justified. But as pressures have built up over the past months for a full accounting, the Administration has backed and filled, never quite coming up with precise total figure.

title: 5 Found Alive in French Cave
description: PAU, France, Aug. 11 (Reuters)  Five Poles, missing since Monday in a cave near here, were found alive today, vescue officials said.

title: Former Addicts Pump Gas to Regain Their Dignity
description: MADISON TOWNSHIPA dozen former addicts are working at a local service station that Drug Addiction Rehabilitation Enterprists (DARE) purchased a little more than a year ago. And since the inception of the program in this Middlesex County community in June of 1972, the agency has acquired two more stations and has put 18 more former addicts to work.

title: THE CHINA DOCTOR STILL PRACTICING
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 11Every Tuesday morning more Chinese than usual crowd into the small clinic on the fourth fioor of the Man Yee Building in the heart of Hong Kong's Central District.

title: Tattoo Is No Longer Sexist
description: BUTLERAt Larry's Tattoo Parlor, Larry Davenport, the proprietor, still etches the usual number of panthers and coiled serpents onto male biceps and chests. But he reports that increasing numbers of women are now stopping in to have their bodies adorned with samplings of his art.

title: Carosio, Italian Trotter, Entered in International
description: Carosio of Italy will compete in the $150,000 Roosevelt International trot, Aug. 25 at Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L.I.

title: Point of View
description: Acting State Housing Commissioner

title: Drug Law Judges; How Many Elephants On a Bench?; The Region
description: You don't have to be a Republican to become a judge in the new narcotics courts, but it would help. That was evident as Governor Rockefeller prepared last week to appoint the first 15 of an eventual 68 Court of Claims judges to implement the state's tough new drug law.

title: PERON WILL RUN FOR PRESIDENCY
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 11Juan D. Peron today accepted the candidacy of his party for the presidency of Argentina in elections scheduled for Sept. 23.

title: Elephant Exports Resumed
description: PRETORIA, South Africa Aug. 11 (AP)South Africa resumed exporting baby elephants after a threeyear moratorium orriLsred as a health precaution. Veterinarians now are satisfitd that the exported animals did not carry hoof and mouth disease.

title: Murder Charges Are Filed Against Two Teenage Boys in Houston Case
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 11  The Houston District Attorney's office filed murder charges today against two teenage boys who have led the authorities in the last three days to the graves of 23 other teenage boys slain over a threeyear period. The police said the victims had been enticed into attending parties, sexually assaulted and then killed.

title: Secret 1969 Foray Into Laos Reported
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 President Nixon personally authorized a secret Marine Corps combat operation inside Laos two days after his inauguration in 1969, Government sources said today.

title: 5 Die in Coast Collision
description: YAKIMA, Wash Aug. 11 (AP)A pickup truck carrying i family of eight Collided headon with a carload of teenagers car here today leaving five dead and six injured, The state police said.

title: BLACK PHYSICIANS DISCUSS THE POOR
description: The National Medical Association opened its 78th annual convention and scientific assembly here yesterday with one major problem before it: How can the professional organization representing the nation's black physicians begin to improve health services for minority group members and the poor?

title: Susan M. Potoff Bride Of Michael A. Neufeld
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 11Miss Susan Meg Potoff, daughter of Mrs. Seymour Fishkind of Westport and Rubin Potoff of West Hartford, was married here tonight to Michael Adam Neufeld, son of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Neufeld of Westport. Rabbi David Seligson performed the ceremony at Congregation Agudath Shalom.

title: Current Best Sellers
description: 1. THE WINDS OF WAR. Wouk. A vivid, if Lanny Buddish, replay of the events that led to Pearl Harbor Sundayobserved, in global terms, by a career officer, U.S.N.

title: First Navy Group Gets New Garb for Enlistees
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 11 (AP)Bellbottom trousers are being phased out of the Navy.

title: Need to Know
description: It is hard to decide whether American air raids are doing more damage in Cambodia or the United States. In Cambodia, B52 attacks are killing innocent people because the huge bombers are being used for close infantry support, a mission for which they were never intended. Grisly mistakes are inevitable.

title: Prices to Rise as Freeze Ends Tonight
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 The current 60day price freeze ends at midnight tomorro and Government controller conceded that some price may rise almost immediately.

title: Special Dream, $5, Wins by 7 Lengths In $55,600 Stakes
description: PHILADELHIA, Aug. 11Fred W. Hooper's Special Team routed five other 2yearold fillies in the third running of the $55,600 Signature Stakes at Liberty Bell Park this afternoon. With Alvaro Pineda riding, she drew out in the stretch to win by seven lengths.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Sometimes a book is so bad it has a transcendent charm of its own. Behold EPITAPH TO A DEAD COP by John Fredman (McKayWashburn, $4.95), a British import, privateeye variety. This private eye takes a job as bodyguard to the daughter of a millionaire. She is killed. He makes up his mind to find the killer. Point of honor. Beatings later, sexual athletics later, manifold adventures later, private eye and murderer confront each other.

title: Janet MacLachlan Is Beginning to. See the Light
description: Los ANGELES JANET MACLACHLAN who once felt as wishywashy as a little squid with no convictions and no commitments, was never really right on! playing a revolutionary in Up Tight in 1968. Even now, radiating charm and poise on television, she is still not doing what comes naturally because there were so many years when she felt too fat, too plain, too shy, and the selfconsciousness lingers on

title: $800,000 Art Collection Missing at Warehouse
description: A collection of art treasures and ancient artifacts from Colombia, said to be worth $800,000, were discovered stolen Friday from the lower Manhattan warehouse where the objects had been stored since 1934.

title: Rule by Conspiracy
description: At the conclusion of the first phase of its televised hearings, the Senate committee has not yet determined who lied and who told the truth about the Watergate scandals. Difficult as it is to believe that President Nixon remained unaware for so many months of the involvement of so many of his top aides and associates, despite the extensive press coverage of the matter, no hard evidence to the contrary has thus far been provided. The Presidential tapes, which might offer some answers, are still under Mr. Nixon's lock and key and he is fighting in the courts to keep them there.

title: What's Doing in London
description: LAST CHANCECovent Garden, the market that dates to the 17th century, is to be moved, probably next spring. So if you are nostalgic about Liza Doolittle, or simply like the sight, smell and sound of vast quantities of flowers, fruit and vegetables being heaved about, go now. But if some sharpie recognizes you as a sightseer and offers you an excellent buy on crate of apples, refuse. You may find almost anything, except good apples, under the top layer. Remember that the market's main work is over by 11 A.M., and that its busiest time is around 6 A.M. Apart from Covent Garden, there are many lovely little bits of London that are slated to be torn down. A paperback, Goodbye London, by Christopher Booker and Candida Green, lists more than 400 such places and could furnish an itinerary for an interesting but

title: Ground Broken for Regional Insurance Center in New Jersey
description: Ground was broken last week for a $3million regional headquarters of the ZurichAmerican Insurance Companies, a worldwide insurance group based in Zurich with United States head offices in Chicago. The threestory building  on a 21acre track in Moorestown, N. J., at a point where I295 and the New Jersey Turnpike run near each otherwill contain 46,000 square feet of office space for about 200 employes. The sheathing will be whiteenameled aluminum panels and gray glass, and mechanical equipment will be placed in reflective glass towers at both ends rather than on the roof. Gruen Associates is the architect.

title: In Both Berlins, A Lack of New Creative Power
description: CAPITAL of an empire, legendary city of sexual and artistic prodigality, hub of the Nazi will to power, Berlin has a recent history of dramatic, almost hysterical extremes. Its downward swing saw pounded into 75million cubic meters of rubble in World War II, occupied by its conquerors, then split, geographically and spiritually, into two. Now it exists as the uneasy meetingplace for the two economic systems that rule the world, mutually exclusive in theory yet here grown curiously similar in aim.

title: BENTAKID HELPS YONKERS YOUTHS
description: YONKERS, Aug. 1  Harold Rosenberg, a usedcar dealer, called Yonkers RentAKid early last July and hired Roy Polonio, 19 years old, to sweep floors, clean cars, and drive customers.

title: Butz Appoints Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz has appointed David L. Hume, United States agricultural attach in Tokyo, as new administrator of the Foreign Agricultural Service. Mr. Hume, 59 years old, will succeed Raymond A. Ioanes, who retires Aug. 31.

title: News Summary and Index SUNDAY, AUGUST 12, 1973
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the deposed Cambodian Chief of State, has said in a message to Mike Mansfield, the Senate Democratic leader, that peace with honor could be attained by the United States if Washington ends the bombing of Cambodia and cuts off military supplies to Phnom Penh, diplomatic sources in Peking said. Senator Mansfield said that he had not received the cablegram. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Nassau and Suffolk A Statistical Entity
description: Twentieth century man may be losing his individuality in a blizzard of computer punchcards and serial numbers, but not long ago Nassau and Suffolk Counties found themselves beneficiaries of a reverse trend.

title: Art Mailbag
description: ToTHE EDITOR: IWOULD like to point out an error made by John Canaday in. his July 20 article, A Museum Shows Notable Art Fakes. In the article, on the Minneapolis exhibition Fakes and Forgeries, Mr. Canaday states that Elmyr de Hory sold 44 forgeries of modern masters to the 20th century's most highly publicized single target among art patrons, Algur Hurtle Meadows, who bought the paintings at bargain prices for Southern Methodist University.

title: Patience Outerbridge Is Betrothed
description: OYSTER BAY, LI., Aug. 11 Mr. and Mrs. Joseph W. Outerbridge of Center Island and Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patience Outerbridge, to Alan Harts Banister. He is a son of Mrs. Leonard Jessup Raymond of York Harbor,. Me., and the late Rear Mm. Alan Boyd Banister, U.S.N.

title: The Responsibility of Science
description: ST. LOUIS  One of the strongly recognized social needs for scientific knowledge is in the area of the environment, and it is appropriate to ask how well this area is represented among the randomly given fruits. of the postwar, basic biomedical research effort.

title: When the Lights Went Out
description: TEL AVIVTwenty five years have passed since his death. How many times I have heard the questions: Under what circumstances did your father die? It must be difficult for you to be reminded of it, but could you tell how you found out? and so on. No, it is not difficult to be reminded of itbecause we never forgot it.

title: VOTE GIFT RETURNS AT $900,000 TOTAL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) Contributions reported returned by the Committee for the Reelection of the President now total $900,000, and a committee spokesman disclosed today that a review was being made to see if other large cash contributions had come from corporations.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: For home buyers around the United States, mortgages are becoming harder to get and harder to pay for because of higher interest rates, higher down payments and shorter lending terms. However, despite the problems, home buying in most states has not slowed significantly.

title: Keeping profits low, fares high
Mindy Marvin To Be a Bride
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Aug. 11  Miss Mindy Marvin, an equestrian, and John Charles Kittell, who is in his second year at the Cornell University School of Veterinary Medicine, plan 10 marry.

title: Rallydale Wins in Horse Show At Branchville
Best claw forward
description: State dinners are usually glittering affairs with expensive, but unimaginative dishes. But when Russia's Leonid Brezhnev came to Washington, the White House chef Henry Haller outdid himself with this classic lobster appetizer. At the White House, lobsters were arranged in an elaborate pyramid design; the simpler presentation here is more appropriate for a home dinner party. The Nixons served California Johannisberg Riesling, but a dry white Burgundya Meursault, for instancewould also be an appropriate accompaniment.

title: White Whale at the New York Aquarium Is Expecting, but 365 Days From When Is the Big Question
description: There is a lot of reference literature at the New York Aquarium at Coney Island on the care and feeding of sharks, penguins, sea turtles and even electric eelsbut nothing on pregnant white whales.

title: Feltmans Have Son
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Michael P. Feltman of Clifton, N. J. at the New York University Hospital on July 27. Mrs. Feltman is the former Miss Karen Tunick of New York. Mr. Feltman is a lawyer with Schneider and Baer in Teaneck, N. J. The child has been named Joshua Andrew.

title: WELL'S REOPENING ASKED IN MICHIGAN
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Mich., Aug. 11  The AMOCO Production Company has requested permission to reopen an oil and gas well suspected of causing a series of gas eruptions that forced the evacuation of this northern Michigan hamlet last spring.

title: World News Briefs
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 11 (UPI)Two men, one said to be a member of the outlawed Irish Republican Army, were killed today in an apparent premature explosion of a bomb as they drove in an auto near a border crossing, police officials said.

title: Holmqvist Getting Tryout
description: STOCKHOLM, May 11 (AP) Leif Holmqvist, one of Sweden's top ice hockey goalies, was scheduled to leave tomorrow for the United States and a tryout with the Detroit. Red Wings of the National Hockey League. Holmqvist had a tryout with the Boston Bruins several years ago.

title: Leaders Meet
description: OTTAWAIt's an odd sort of club that was meeting here this week. It has some of the look of an old boys league and some of the feel of a family. The accents and the skin colors vary, but seven of the 32 current members went to Oxford University, four of them fought for King George and many of them are keen on cricket or rugby.

title: PEGGY CASTLE DEAD; FILM AND TV ACTRESS
description: HOLLYWOOD, Aug. 11 (AP) Peggy Caitle, film and television actress; was found dead in her apartment here, the police said today. She was 45 years old.

title: At 86 Pounds, She's Star of 3 Continents
description: Olga Korbut, the tiny Soviet gymnast, has a rival. She's two years younger, one inch taller and has never performed on a balance beam. Mary Decker, the 15yearold, 5foot, 86pound halfmiler from Garden Grove, Calif., ran away with the hearts of the Soviet people when she competed in the Russian American track and field meet in Minsk, U.S.S.R. The fans at Dynamo Stadium cheered wildly as the pigtailed sprite spurted the last five yards to beat the bigger and more experienced Russian women and win the 800meter run with a time of

title: Watergate Issues
description: At the end of the first phase of the Senate's Watergate investigation, a number of important questions remain blurred by conflicting testimony, chief among them President Nixon's role, if any, in the wiretapping conspiracy and later coverup. An article analyzing the hearings to date appears on Page 47, A comparison of differing answers to a selection of key questions appears on Page 46.

title: Allison Rhoads Is the Bride of Ty Ralli
description: PERU, Vt., Aug. 11Miss Allison Rhoads, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Biddle Rhoads of Wilmington, Del., and Landgrove, was married here this afternoon to Constantine Pandia Ralli, son of Mr. and Mrs. Pandia Constantine Ralli of Bronxville, N.Y. and Rupert.

title: Canine Heartworm Message
description: Many dogs in the metropolitan area are falling victim to canine heartworms, which, in advanced stages, cause impaired breathing, coughing, listlessness and weight loss. By the time these symptoms appear, it is often too late to successfully treat or cure the illness. Unless discovered and treated early, heartworms can lead to extensive organ damage and death. It can usually be detected by means of blood tests. In some cases, Xrays and other laboratory tests are also necessary.

title: AROUND THE
description: TO THE COMMUTER Next time the train slows down or stops for one of those unexplained delays, take a good look outside the window. Nature has planted a rather extensive garden by the tracks and at some spots, it is quite splendid.

title: Transfer Policies Of Employers Found to Vary
description: A survey of the employe relocation practices of 635 companies across the nation has indicated that transfer policies differ widely by industry.

title: Dave Anderson
description: About two dozen letters, the latest bateh, were on a brown chair in the living room of the Riverside Drive apartMent.

title: Won't This Movie Run Backward?
description: BROOKHAVEN, L. LThis came month ago. Dear Carrie: When I was shot down my leg was broken. The villagers here took me to the home of a young man trained in first aid. By the light of a candle he set my leg. We talked in French. His family gathered around and we shared food. His kids are the same age as ours, real smart too. One of them had, trouble sleeping so I held him and sang to him one night. Two daysthat's all I had. Then I was moved out at night in a truck.

title: Forest Service Sees Loss Of $5Million on Fee Curb
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP)The Forest Service says it is eliminating fees for most family Campgrounds and boat ramps to comply with a new law but will lose about $5million a year as a result.

title: It's Time to Resow for Late Summer Salads
description: LABOR DAY signals the end of summer for most boat enthusiasts, campers, and devotees of white shoes. But the gardener who puts down his rake and hoe so early is missing the delights and benefits of the growing season known as Indian Summer..

title: Hawaian Mir Easy Winner at Westbury
Teacher,40,and ExStudent,18, Wed Alter TwoYear Romance
description: PARAMUS, N. J., Aug. 11A 40yearold high school teacher and his 18yearold former student were married here this afternoon, nearly two years after the start of a romance that scandalized the community and led to the teacher's suspension from his job as chairman of the foreign language department at Pasca ck Valley High School in Hillsdale.

title: Selling Out to Hollywood, or Home Is Where the Work
description: WHEN I first came to California eight years ago, my agent had plucked me out of Joe Papp's Love's Labour's Lost in Central Park, and put me down in Peyton Placetelevision's Love's Labour's Lost.

title: Raymond Burr in Hospital
description: LAJES, Portugal, Aug. 11 (AP)Raymond Burr, the telesion actor, was reported resting comfortably today after having collapsed on a Portuguese airliner preparing to take off from this island in the Azores, Mr. Burr, who is 56 years old, was on board the plane yesterday afternoon hound for the United States when he suffered an attack and was taken to the hospital of the United States Air Force base on Lajes. Physicians are administering tests to determine the cause of his illness.

title: MURDER SUSPECT FREED, HELD IN 2D
description: A suspected narcotics dealer was held without bail on a homicide charge in Manhattan criminal court on Friday, a day after a Bronx judge had released him on $25,000 bail in a related murder case.

title: Robert Smithson: He Made Fantasies as Real as Mountains
description: WHEN a culturally significant person dies, there may occur for the living a moment of illumination, not only of one career but of a whole nexus of events and meanings into which that career was woven. The death of Picasso, for instance, inspired a period of rich reflection on our century that, for many, is still continuing. But when such a person dies tragically and young, the illumination is more in the nature of light from a flashbulb, a harsh glare that catches history in a candid, awkward pose. The case of sculptor and earthartist Robert Smithson, who died July 20 at the age of 35, meets the latter description.

title: Coop Calls on A.E.C.tc Build 2 Geothermal Pilot Plants in Idaho
description: IDAHO FALLS, Idaho, Aug. 11  A tiny rural electric cooperative and a huge Atomic Energy Commission site have become the focus of Idaho's push to become a pioneer in the field of geothermal energy use.

title: The World
description: PHNOM PENHCatch22 has overtaken Cambodia, as the Americans prepare to cut off their bombing support and the Cambodians prepare for the end.

title: Shattuck Is Victor In Sailing
Berlinger Scores Welfare Unit On Spending for Security Here
description: George F. Berlinger, the State Welfare Inspector General, has renewed his feud with city welfare administrators over security services they bought from a private detective bureau since April, 1970, at a cost of $68,000. In a letter to Human Resources Administrator Jule M. Sugarman, made public last week, Mr. Berlinger accused the city's Department of Social Services of having hired these services without a written contract or competitive bidding, and at excessive cost and of having kept sloppy records.

title: SCHOOLS OFFERED REPAYMENT PUN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) School superintendents in 21 states and the District of Columbia will soon be offered an alternative to avoid repaying $22.4million in Federal education funds that they are accused of misspending.

title: WITNESS QUERIED ON SLINGSHOT USE
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Aug. 11 William W. Lemmer, the Government's star witness, testified today that he had never heard a discussion by an alleged band of plotters about hiding slingshots inside their bellbottom trousers.

title: Kathleen Gill, Law Graduate, Married to George R. Miller
description: FARMINGTON, Conn., Aug. 11Miss Kathleen Louise Gill, daughter of Thomas D. Gill, Chief Justice of the Juvenile Court of Connecticut, and Mrs. Gill of West Hartford, was married here this afternoon to George Russell Miller, son of Dr. and Mrs. George J. Miller of Pensacola, Fla.

title: Movies
description: AT a recent sneak preview sensed that the laughter was in San Francisco of Paul Mazursky's new film Blume in Love, an evening of entertainment evolved into an intriguing confrontation of social ideologies as the predominantly ;.white, uppermiddle class, liberal audience found itself irresistibly involved with an irreverent satire of white, uppermiddle class liberal life. The effect was something like a David Frye performance at the White House.

title: Journalistic Puton in the Hamptons
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON, L.I. Several weeks ago the readers of The Hampton Beach, weekly tabloid, were informed that potato farmers in this Long Island resort and farm area had solved the problem of delivering their crops to market by inventing a Potato Bazooka that would allow them to blast their spuds across the Shinnecock Canal to waiting trucks.

title: Ward 402
description: Last summer a friend of mine put into my hands a document I found harrowing to read. It was a diary kept by a Yale medical student (it was passed to me with his pehnission) during the late 1960's. It recorded the efforts of one young man to confront and deal with the whole hospital universe of suffering and pain. Images from this account remain in my head: the 12yearold girl, dying of cancer, whose hair has fallen out and whose body, covered with lesions, has been reduced to something scarcely human; the professor of law, stripped by sickness of his authorityalmost, of his identityhobbling around the ward on legs like matchsticks, so thin that they can barely support his weight. They are so sick, wrote the young doctor, that I want to run out of the room and shout to the world: Thank God I'm alive and healthy! A part of him was, as he wrote, deeply outraged that people could be reduced to such misery. Another part of him was scientifically curious about the medical findings, interested in the patients as things, as machines which had mysteriously begun to malfunction. Maggie Scarf is a writer and critic.

title: Prisoners In Nassau Threaten Action
description: MINEOLA, L.I.  Nassau County Executive Ralph G. Caso said last week that he would meet with representatives of both the inmates and the guards at the County Jail to relieve tensions that have been developing at the correctional institution in East Meadow.

title: Free Camps In Queens Attract Thousands
description: Free vacation day camps conducted by the Board of. Education in school districts have been playing an increasingly important role for queens communities.

title: Table Flirt Triumphs
description: SALEM, N. H., Aug, 11 (AP)Table Flirt, ridden by Michael Carrozzella, rallied in the stretch and won the Lilac Stakes today at Rockingham Park. The winner covered the six furlongs in 1:11 3/5 and paid $3.60, $3.20 and $2.60.

title: Sub to Be Named Cincinnati
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) The Navy said today that it had decided to name one of its most advanced nuclearpowered attack submarines for the city of Cincinnati. The Cincinnati will be built by the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, at Newport News, Va.

title: Orantes Upsets Connors; Miss Goolagong Is Victor
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 11 (UPI)Jimmy Connors was upset by Manuel Orantes of Spain, and Ilie Nastase turned back Nikki Pilic of Yugoslavia in the semifinals of the $75,000 Western tennis championships today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Transit Authority said it would expand service its B/28 and B/29 BrooklyntoManhattan express bus routes starting tomorrow. In the morning, the number of B/28X trips from Bath Beach will be increased from 9 to 15 and in the evening it will be increased from 6 to 11. The first B/28X bus in the morning will now leave Bay 49th and Cropsey Avenue at 6:30 instead of 6:55 A.M., and the last morning bus will leave at 10 instead of 8:13 A.M.

title: Surgery that cut two ways
description: This is a profoundly human book, far more so than most of modern art. One of its author's concerns is the dehumanization of art, of medicine and medical research, of all that he cares about, which in the end is the human condition in its most dark and solitary state; for Dr. I. S. Cooper, one of the most remarkable men alive, is professionally one of the great brain surgeons of the world and has seen more than most of human beings in extremity. Now he is telling us something very simple about just that condition. I must say his book makes most novels sound like the shallowest of fabrications.

title: Jetties Sought to Save Homes
description: WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L. I. A group of homeowners here, alleging a devastating loss of beachfront property, is seeking to compel the Federal Government and Suffolk County to build six additional groins to protect the area against erosion.

title: Gail A. Gracie Bride Of Dr. Gary Warren
