description: FOXBORO, Mass., Aug. 11 Still trying. to experiment with a surprising surplus of talent, the New York Giants will play their second exhibition, game tomorrow night against. the New England Patriots, a team in search of talent.

title: Allin1 Aid for Handicapped
description: MONTCLAIR  Fouryearold Brucie cannot feed or dress himself. Jim, at 9, cannot read. Sally, 8, gets the letters of the alphabet mixed up when she tries to write her name. Larry, 5, finds it easier to relate to a chair or a broom than to his parents.

title: Article 3  No Title
A PEACE PROPOSAL IS REPORTED SENT U.S. BY SIHANOUK
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the deposed Cambodian Chief of State, has said in a message to Mike Mansfield, the Senate Democratic leader, that peace with honor could he attained by the United States if Washington ends the bombing of Cambodia and cuts off military supplies to Phnom Penh, diplomatic sources in Peking said yesterday.

title: N.C.A.A.'s Drug Tests Will Be Voluntary
description: Hoping to find out if we really have a drug problem or not, the National Collegiate Athletic Association will conduct postgame tests on some college football and soccer players this fall. The urinalyses will be on voluntary and anonymous basis only, according to Robert Pritchard, chairman of the N.C.A.A. Drug Education Committee.

title: Louise M. riocchi, Banker, Married Here
description: Miss Louise Michele Flocchi, an assistant manager in the metropolitan division of the Chemical Bank, was married here yesterday afternoon to Theodore Cheff Krismann, a vice president of Robert Scott Associates, sales promotion and marketing firm in New York.

title: Convicted After Jail terin
description: BROWNSVILLE, Tex., Aug. 11 (UPI)Charles V. Harrelson, 35yearold wanderer who spent more than fourandahalf years in jail without being convicted of a crime, was sentenced today in his third murder trial to 15 years for killing a grain dealer for a $2,000 fee.

title: the traveler's world
description: HERE are some observations Inspired by a particularly lipsmacking cruise that the S.S. France is going to make out of New York in November. Gastronomic details later, but first the observations.

title: Bondurant Moves School on Coast
description: SONOMA, Calif., Aug. 11  Bob Bondurant, a former Grand Prix race driver, has moved his drivers school to the recently refurbished Sears Point International Raceway here. The school, formerly at Ontario Motor Speedway in the Los Angeles area, will begin operation at Sears Point early in September.

title: BRANDEIS CENTER PLANS EXPANSION
description: SANTA SUSANA, Calif., Aug. 11  With an expansive gesture, Dr. Shlomo Bardin, browned by the Southern California summer sunshine to color almost as deep as the rolling hills surrounding him, pointed to a huge concrete spiral of a building rising from the top of a nearby mountain.

title: ASTRONAUTS STUDY SECRET OF STORMS
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 11 (UPI)Skylab's astronauts, beginning their third week of critical research, collected data on storms, forests and mineral deposits today over a 6,300mile sweep of the United States and Latin America.

title: State Getting Its First Conservative Jewish High School
description: UNION  Conservative Jews in New Jersey will have their first high school this fall, when Solomon Schechter Day School here advances to the ninth grade.

title: Darcie Lazar To Be Married To C. T. du Pont
description: The engagement of Miss Darcie Caryn Lazar to Christopher Truesdale du Pont has been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Louis A. Lazar of New York and Goshen, N. Y. Mr. du Pont is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexis Felix du Pont Jr. of Wilmington, Del. The wedding is planned for the fall.

title: Patricia Grafmueller Fiancee Of Paul Selkregg Buddenhagen
description: Mr. and Mrs. Albert M. Grafmueller of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Riker Grafmueller, to Paul Selkregg Buddenhagen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Buddenhagen of Akron, Ohio. The wedding is planned for October at St. James Episcopal Church.

title: Catholic Schools
description: Across New York state last week the newly formed Federation of Catholic School Parents, a publicimage and promotion organization, was cranking up for its first fullyear activities. In Pennsylvania, attorneys were preparing for a court appearance in defense of a state program providing auxiliary services for children in nonpublic schools. In virtually every state, maintenance men were sprucing up Catholic school properties for another academic year.

title: Somewhat Striking Scores In the Grassland Handicap
description: MIAMI, Aug. 11 (AP) Somewhat Striking rallied and beat 12 rivals in the $19,350 Grassland Handicap at Calder Race Course today. Somewhat Striking was timed at 1:413.5 for the mile and paid $33.20 for $2 to win. Trigger Happy was second. a length in front of All Grant Jr. and 100BE lengths behind the victor.

title: Lynn Southwood Bride of S.A.Engelhardt
description: SHELTER ISLAND, N. Y., Aug. 11Miss Lynn Anne Southwood, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Southwood of West Hempstead, L. I., and Shelter Island, was married here this afternoon to. Stanley Anthony Engelhardt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis G. Engelhardt of Ridgefield, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Theodore Bobilin, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony in the Chapel in the Grove.

title: President Appoints Two
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP)  President Nixon named two persons yesterday to fiveyear terms on the Advisory Council on Historic Preservation. They are Beaula C. Nunn, wife of former Gov. Louie B. Nunn of Kentucky, and John A. May, director of the division of recreation in the South Caro. lina Department of Parks, Recreation and Tourism.

title: Jennifer Gapen Parker Is Affianced
description: JANESVILLE, Wis., Aug. 11 Miss Jennifer Gapen Parker, a greatgranddaughter of the late George S. Parker, founder of the Parker Pen Company, and Yves Edouard Coleon of Paris, plan to marry here Sept. 8 in Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: Facilities Finally Match The Name in Newark
description: Few would call, or think of, Newark Airport by its right name, Newark International Airport; only a few overseas flights begin or end there. And its total passenger traffic (6,750,000 last year) has lagged far behind that of the metropolitan area's two other major jetports, Kennedy (20,700,000) and La Guardia (14,200,000). But all that is about to change. huge new passenger terminal, twice as large as the present one, was opened for business last week, and two others of comparable size are under construction. One of them will begin operations next month, the other 1976. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which runs the region's three jetports, estimates that Newark will handle 19 million passengers by 19804 million of whom will be going to or coming from other countries. The new terminal is connected by enclosed corridors (left) three circular satellites (above) from which passengers enter and leave. Joseph L. Vanacore Jr., general manager of the airport, expressed the belief that it has been underdeveloped until now in part because the Hudson River is a psychological barrier for many New York travelers. The expanded facilities may help break through the barrier.

title: GARLAND B. MILBURN
description: OCEAN CITY, N. J., Aug. 11 Garland B. Milburn, who retired in 1958 as a director and vice president of Grand Union Company, the food company chain, died yesterday in Somers Point He was 74 years old and lived here and in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Mr. Milburn joined Grand

title: Letters: Evensong Stirs Tears of Appreciation
description: To the Editor: I am writing in regard to the article, Evensong: An Unsung Tourist Treat, by John Bullough and Dusty Sklar, in the Travel Section of July 22. I am an Englishman of 62, temporarily living with friends in the United States in between a fascinating six months journey through the Caribbean from Martinique southwards and visiting every country in South America, and a projected two months motoring tour of New Zealand in September and October. During these months I have thought often of the proudest heritages of England's historyour magnificent cathedrals and universities and colleges where the spirit and learning of civilization have been developed and maintained across the centuries, in spite of war and pestilence and every kind of natural disaster. In 50 years of roaming round our sceptered isle, these have been the havens of peace to which have retreated to renew my inspiration to live the good life and to absorb the of

title: The New Play
description: KING LEAR, the New York Shakespeare Festival's production of Shakespeare's play, got four favorable reviews (O'Haire, News; Tallmer, Post; Sharp, Women's Wear; Harris, CBSTV) and four mixed reviews (Gussow, Times; Wallach, Women's Wear; Raidy, Newhouse Newspapers; Glover, AP).

title: PERRIN C. GARIN, HOOVER AIDE, DIES
description: PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Aug. 11Perrin C. Galpin, former foundation executive and for many years an aide to the late President Herbert Hoover, died today on his 84th birthday in New Rochelle Hospital. He lived here.

title: Notes: Travel Troubles Are Her Business
description: WITH about eight million Americans traveling abroad this year and another 1.5 million living Overseas, many of the 250 consular offices of the United States around the world are being kept pretty busy these days. It is to these offices that Americans abroad take their problems. They may have lost their passports, or lost their money, or they may have been robbed, or found themselves stranded, or they may need medical attention, or legal advice, or they may be unable to find their missing spouses. Worst of all, they may have run afoul of the narcotics laws.

title: Chess Ljubojevic Draws and Stays Ahead in Interzonal Play
Calendar of Upcoming Motor Sports Events
description: TodayS.C.C.A, regional races at Bridgehampton (L.I.) Race Circuit, I P.M.

title: C. P. Browning Weds Alice Garvin
description: MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Aug. 11  In the Presbyterian Church of Mount Kisco this afternoon Miss Alice Shirley Garvin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lester Garvin of Chappaqua and Jefferson, Me., became the bride of Christopher Paul Browning. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Paul Browning of Cedar Falls, Iowa.

title: Survey Finds Optimism Up Among Steel Users
description: An independent survey of Midwestern steel users released over the weekend, showed a 150 per cent increase in the number of respondents who rated business conditions in their industry as excellent.

title: Phnom Penh Refuses To Protect Royalty
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Aug. 12The family of Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the deposed Chief of State of Cambodia, has asked the Government of Marshal Lon Nol to provide it with military protection during the coming weeks, but the Government has refused.

title: Inflation Unphased
description: Phase 4 of the Nixon Administration's pricewage policy, which went into effect last midnight, is the latest malformation in a series of freezes, phases, decontrols and recontrols that is beginning to seem like infinite confusion crowded into a little space of time. Phase 4 may not last long either; indeed, some Administration officials insist on greeting it as a brief curtainraiser for Phase 5 (Phaseout).

title: Consumer Loan Costs Climb
description: Robert and Rafael Brache of Mount. Kisco, N.Y., will pay more than $63,000 in interest over the next 25 years for a house they just bought in nearby Mahopacfor nearly the same dollar figure.

title: Jets'
PERON WILL FACE OLD FOE IN ELECTION
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 12 (Reuters)  Former dictator Juan D. PerOn will run against an old political foe in the Argentine presidential election on Sept. 23.

title: Phase 4 Begins
description: Phase 4 of the Nixon price stabilization program began at midnight when the 60day freeze on prices ended. Exceptions are beef prices, which remain frozen until Sept. 12, and those on petroleum, frozen another week.

title: Home Burglar Alarms Vex the Police
description: One of the fastest growing phenomenons in the metropolian areathe installation of burglar alarmsis becoming najor problem for Police Departments, which complain that hey are wasting an increasingly large amount of time answering false alarms.

title: JAY G. RESCHER
description: Jay G. Rescher, who retired in 1968 as business agent of Local 644, the movie cameramen's union here, died Saturday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. His age was 81.

title: GAINESVILLE TRIAL TO RESUME TODAY
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Aug. 12 William W. Lemmer answers most of the questions in controlled, even voice, sometimes with an elaborate show of Casualness.

title: HAROLD L GARNER
description: PETERBOROUGH, Ontario, Aug. 12 (AP)  Harold L. Garner, former general manager of The Peterborough Examiner and president of the Canadian Daily Newspaper Association, died Friday night at the age of 85.

title: Grand Jury Opens New Inquiry Today on Issues of Perjury and Obstruction of Justice in I.T.T. Case
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12A grand jury will convene tomor row to inquire into possible perjury and obstruction of jus tice by Government official: and officers of the Interne. tional Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

title: Young Democrats Chief Backs Southerner in'76
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 12 (UPI)De Lesseps Morrison Jr., 29yearson of a former Mayor of New Orleans, said today on his election as national president of the Young Democrats that his party should consider running a Southerner for President in 1976.

title: MRS. F. R. CHILDS
description: Mrs. Constance Crimmins Childs, widow of Frederick R. Childs, a stockbroker and daughter of former Parks Commissioner John D. Crimmins, died Saturday at her home, 825 Fifth Avenue. She was 90 years old.

title: PoliceHeld Drugs Guarded By Tighter Security System
description: Elaborate changes have been made around the property storerooms of the New York Police Department these days  changes prompted by the department's own disclosure last December that millions of dollars worth of heroin and cocaine, including evidence seized in the famous French Connection case, had vanished from its custody.

title: Marsh Wins Japan Golf
description: TAKASAKA, Japan, Aug. 12 (UPI)Graham Marsh of Australia sank a threefoot birdie putt on the final hole for a fourunderpar 68 today to win the $113,200 BVD Cup golf tournament by a stroke over Torn Nakamura. Marsh, the 1972 and 1973 Asian circuit champion, had a 16underpar 272 total and won the first prize of $22,641.

title: Parents of 2 Boys Missing in Houston Criticize the Police
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 12 (UPI)Parents of two young boys, both believed to be among 23 murder victims, contend that the police ignored their sons disappearance and listed at least seven other missing youths as runaways.

title: U.S GYPSUM OFFERS TO PAY PLAINTIFFS
description: The United States Gypsum Company announced yesterday that it had offered to pay $28million to plaintiffs as its share in a class action antitrust suit against major gypsum wallboard makers.

title: Black Farmers and Drivers Join To Bypass Produce Middlemen
description: At a time of seemingly runaway food prices, black farmers from Georgia and black truck drivers from New York teamed last week to bypass middlemen and bring 60 tons of fresh fruit and vegetables into the city for a twoday sale.

title: Giants Defeat Patriots
ADDICTS ON RELIEF DECLINE 60% HERE
description: The number of narcotics addicts on the city's welfare rolls was reported yesterday to have been cut in half in 18 months from a peak of 32,000 at the start of 1972 to 15,674 last June.

title: Dance:Farewell Bouquet
description: As a farewell bouquet; American Ballet Theater offered an array, of cast changes at State Theater over the weekend. Among the more notable was Fernando Bujones dancing Saturday evening in the Don Quixote pas de deux, with Eleanor D'Antuono.

title: Nixon Back in Washington After Working on Speech
description: CAMP DAVID, Md., Aug. 12 (UPI)President Nixon ended a fiveday stay at his Catoctin Mountain retreat. today by working with close aides on a speech designed to answer the allegations made against, him in testimony before the Senate Watergate committee.

title: Great Dane Takes Best In Jersey
100 Cambodia PropellerDriven Planes Replace U.S. Jet Armada This Week
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Aug. 12In three days, more than 400 United States jet fighterbombers and 150 B52 bombers will be withdrawn from the Cambodian war by act of Congress. To replace this armada, Cambodia has a hastily trained and poorly maintained air force of perhaps 100 planes.

title: Hoarding of Rice Leads To Chinatown Shortage
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 12 (UPI)  Rumors of a rice shortage in San Francisco's Chinatown have led to panic buying. Grocery store owners said today that they were cleaned out of rice.

title: Agnew Term as Governor Under U.S. Scrutiny Today
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 12 Federal agents are scheduled tomorrow to begin digging into the records of Vice President Agnew's two years as Maryland Governor, with testimony expected to be presented to a special grand jury in Baltimore on Wednesday.

title: Golf in Palm Springs Sun Diverts Agnew at Sinatra's
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Aug, 12In the milliondollar hideaway of his friend, Frank Sinatra, Vice President Agnew sought diversion this weekend, in golf and the trappings of wealth, from the latest controversy in his public life.

title: Cormier Conducts Staple Fare to End Westchester Series
description: When Richard Cormier made his podium debut with the Orchestral Society of Westchester three weeks ago, the forecast of thunderstorms kept the audience to an unfortunate minimum. Saturday night, at the final concert of this summer's festival series at Lyndhurst, the young conductor of the Chatanooga Symphony had better luck. Some 3,500 listeners showed up despite possibleshowers forecasts and enjoyed the music beneath a gorgeous, nearly full moon.

title: Jewish Veterans Elect
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Aug. 12 Ainslee R. Ferdie of Miami, a veteran of the Korean war, was elected national commander of the Jewish War Veterans last night at the organization's1 national convention here. Mr. Ferdie, who had served as national judge advocate for the J.W.V., is a lawyer.

title: China and India
description: PEKINGIndia wishes to normalize relations with China. China wishes to normalize relations with India. But two years of Indian diplomatic efforts have left the two Governments as far apart as ever.

title: Nastase Gets Title, No Money
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 12 (UPI) Topseeded Big Nastase of Rumania won the men's singles championship of the $75,000 Western tennis tournament today but his $9,000 firstprize money was withheld by the referee, who charged that Nastase had cursed him.

title: Fires in 3 Churches Studied by Marshals
description: Better than half this, job footwork, said Edward F. Kell Jr., a supervisory fire marshal as he approached Holy ApoF. tle Episcopal Church at 30. Ninth Avenue to investigate suspicious fire there. Knock leg on doors, talking to pea ple, that's the way you develoi leads. Sometimes you have ai informer or two.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: As the Federal freeze on utility rates ends today, the State Public Utilities Commission reports that it has more than $175million in requested rate increases to review. William E. Ozzard, the commission president, said the agency was trying to hold the line. But Dr. Arthur A. Schoenwald, the executive director, commented that the present economic situation made some increases likely.

title: Miss Julie Van Allen Married To Michael Shamos in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12Miss Julie Van Allen, daughter of Mrs. Jean Van Allen of Winter Park, Fla., was married here this evening to Michael Ian Shamos, son of Prof. and Mrs. Morris H. Shamos of Riverdale, the Bronx, New York. Rabbi E. William Seaman performed the ceremony at the Cosmos Club.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: SONS OF THUNDER, Trinity Church, 74 Trinity Place, 12:45.

title: Bumper Crop Offered By Westchester Stands
description: YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N.Y., Aug. 12Nearperfect weather this year has sent a bumper crop of corn and customers to Westchester County's roadside fruit and vegetable stands.

title: State Panel Seeks to Ease Financial Woes of Artists
description: The State Commission on Cultural Resources has proposed a broad program of selfhelp and public assistance to ease the employment and financial problems of many of the state's 50,000 artists and writers.

title: Penn Central and L.I.R.R. Using Copters, Plastic Windows and Education to Fight Vandalism
description: The Long Island Rail Road and the metropolitan region of the Penn Central, both operated by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, have taken steps to reduce vandalism and trespassing and increase protection for passengers and property.

title: Agnew Term as Governor Under U.S. Scrutiny Today
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 12 Federal agents are scheduled tomorrow to begin digging into the records of Vice President Agnew's two years as Maryland Governor, with testimony expected to be presented to a special grand jury in Baltimore on Wednesday.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: BLOOMFIELD, Aug. 12  What happened to Hank Borowy in 1945 could make many modern major league pitchers shudder. Borowy had a 10.5 wonlost record with the New York Yankees in July, but found himself on the waiver list. Eventually, he was plucked by Chicago and pitched the Cubs into the World Series.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Problems Irk Many at New Air Facility
description: NEWARK, Aug. 12On this first weekend for the new terminal at Newark International Airport, a computerized schedule board listed identical flights under arrivals and departures, airline reservation agents complained of equipment that didn't work, and passengers had to search for an open cocktail lounge.

title: Books of The Times
description: In nonfiction books now, there seems to be a whole new genre devoted to the passing of a way of life. Divided between alarm and elegy, a kind of wistful anthropology, these books assess with varying degrees of sophistication the pros and cons of progress. Modern medicine is usually the only pro that receives unanimous approval. But even this cannot heal the sickness unto death, these authors contend, for the destruction of a way of life leaves its people with damaged souls, stripped of personality. Survival techniques and the acquisitive instinct are their only remaining qualities. Alienation is their tent, hut or hovel, anomie their landscape.

title: Humphrey Asks Tape Move
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 12 (AP)  Former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey said today that. President Nixon would serve his office and himself well if he would set up some means of providing the Watergate tapes to interested parties. There are many ways that can be done, the Minnesota Democratic Senator said.

title: 12 HURT IN S.I. FIRE AT HOUSING COMPLEX
description: The second fouralarm fire in seven months in a Staten Island apartment complex burned out of control for nearly two hours yesterday, injuring 12 firemen, destroying five apartments and forcing the evacuation of all 125 families in a sixstory building.

title: Calls to 911 Reported Handled in 30 Seconds
description: Police Commissioner Donald F, Cawley said yesterday that 96 per cent of the phone calls last week to police emergency number 911 were handled in less than 30 seconds.

title: Nuptials Held Here For Miss Scriabine
description: Miss Raisa Scriabine, daughter of Dr. AlexanderScriabine of Ambler, Pa., and Mrs. Robert Redeen of NewYork, was married here yesterday afternoon to NicolaiPetroff, son of Mrs. Alexander Petroff of Jordanville, N. J. and the late Mr. Petroff. The Rev. George Grabbe performed the ceremony in the Cathedral of the Holy Synod of the Russian Orthodox Church Outside of Russia.

title: Jacqueline Lotz Married
description: FLORAL PARK, L.I., Aug. 12Miss Jacqueline Mary Lot; daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert R. Lotz of New York, was married here today to Frank Schnidman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Schnidman of Rochester. Rabbi Seymour Rosenbiom, cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at the Bellerose Jewish Center. The bride's father is a member of the psychology faculty at Hunter College.

title: BO ROOS, ADVISER OF FILM STARS, 69
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 12 (UPI) Bo C. Roos Sr., one of Hollywood's leading business managers, with clients including John Wayne, Fred MacMurray, Red Skelton and Lloyd Nolan, died yesterday at the age of 69.

title: Uganda's Amin Offers Talks on Israel's Claim for $30Million but Provokes Skepticism About His Good Faith
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 12Israel's claim that Uganda owes her $30million in debts, growing out of the expulsion of Israeli advisers in Uganda last year, has been revived as an issue here with a new offer from Uganda to discuss a possible negotiated settlement.

title: Nicklaus Captures P.G.A. by 4 Shots; 14th Major Title
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 12As a boyhood golfer Jack Nicklaus set his goal to be the best in the world. That meant equaling the record of his idol, the late Bobby Jones, who won 13 major championships. Today, the 33yearold Ohioan exceeded Jones by winning the Professional Golfers Association championship for his 14th major title.

title: New Lobbying Unit To Seek an Easing Of Tax on Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12Formation of a new lobbying organization aimed at attaining more favored tax treatment for capital was announced here today.

title: Public Found Disillusioned By the Watergate Scandal
description: Alexander and Betty Bennett were shepherding two children and a shopping cart through a supermarket in the Carrick section of Pittsburgh, an aging neighborhood of modest homes and hardworking people, the kind of place where words such as patriotism and law and order still hold deep meaning.

title: OUTLINES OF PACT ON TRADE APPEAR
description: WASHINGTON, Aug 12 Trade ministers of some 80 nations are expected to agree next month in Tokyo on a generalized statement of the objectives of a major new trade negotiation to start next year, but they will not tackle any of the difficult issues of substance.

title: Screen: California Elegy
M.D.Kaplow Weds Pamela Douglass
description: SCRANTON, Pa., Aug. 12Temple Israel was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Pamela Gay Douglass, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur A. Douglass of Scranton, to Mark David Kaplow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter L. Kaplow of Yorktown Heights, N. Y.

title: For a United Namibia
description: It is an extraordinary event when an official of South Africa's white minority Government will concede that many of the black residents of SouthWest Africa want independence in a unitary state rather than selfrule socalled tribal homelands. Yet, that is what Jannie de Wet, Pretoria's CommissionerGeneral for SouthWest Africa, told Charles Mohr of The New York Times in recent interview in Windhoek, capital of the territory.

title: Miss Rubenstein Bride of Peter D. Hart
description: Miss Florence Rubenstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Rubenstein of Brooklyn, was marled here yesterday to Peter David Hart of Washington, president of Peter D. Hart Research Associates, a public opinion and private political polling organization there. Cantor Saul Meisels, uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at the St. RegisSheraton.

title: Andrew Morganstern Marries Carol Altman
description: JERICHO, L.I., Aug. 12Miss Carol Beth Altman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Altman of Woodbury and Tel Aviv, was marriedhere this afternoon to Andrew C. Morgenstern, sonof Mr. and Mrs. Jack Morganstern of North Woodmere, Rabbi Morris Friedman performed the ceremony at the Jericho Jewish Center, assisted by Cantor Israel Goldstein.

title: Msgr. Adam J. Pfundstein, Pastor of Church on L.I.
description: NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., Aug. 12Msgr. Adam J. Pfundstein, pastor of Notre Dame Roman Catholic Church here since 1948, died yesterday in the rectory after a long illness. His age was 71.

title: Westbury Attracts 2 Soviet Trotters
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 12  For the first time since 1966, Soviet trotting horses will be racing in the New York area later this month.

title: Marsh Wins Japan Golf
description: TAKASAKA, Japan, Aug. 12 (UPI)Graham Marsh of Australia sank a threefoot birdie putt on the final hole for a fourunderpar 68 today to win the $113,200 BVD Cup golf tournament by a stroke over Toru Nakamura. Marsh, the 1972 and 1973 Asian circuit champion, had a 16underpar 272 total and won the first prize of $22,641.

title: Price Controls Placing Bind on Baling Wire Supply
description: DENVER, Aug. 12  Now there's a shortage of baling wire.

title: U.N. to Study Multinationals
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 12The United Nations is launching a yearlong inquiry on multinational companies with the aim of devising some international form of monitoring system for their giant enterprises.

title: 4Day AfricanCulture Exhibit Opens at the American Museum
description: Grebo, Yoruba, Ibo and Amharic were being spoken in the crowded confines of the People Center of the American Museum of Natural History yesterday afternoon.

title: Letters to the Editor
PORTISCH GAINS LEAD IN INTERZONAL CHESS
description: PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Aug. 12 (AP) Lajos Portisch of Hungary beat Samuel Reshevsky of the United States in 28 moves today to take sole possession of the lead in the Interzonal chess tournament.

title: The Drug Scene in Nepal Is, Like, Fading
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, Aug. 12The mists now cling to the peaks around the Katmandu valley. By the evening, when the rain starts falling, the farmers have trudged back to the hill villages and the peasant women with tiny rose petals in their hair have scurried indoors.

title: Gasoline Truck Hijacked
description: YANKEETOWN, Fla., Aug. 12 (UPI)Two men armed with shotguns hijacked a gasoline canker truck today, drained its 7,000gallon load and abandoned it on a lonely stretch of road.

title: CHILE ACTS TO END TRUCKERS'
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Monday, Aug. 13 (Reuters)The Chilean Government yesterday appointed 25 military commissioners in a move aimed at breaking a 17day strike by truck owners that is a serious threat to the nation's supply system and economy as a whole.

title: Nicklaus Captures P.G.A. by 4 Shots; 14th Major Title
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 12As a boyhood golfer Jack Nicklaus set his goal to be the best in the world. That meant equaling the record of his idol, the late Bobby Jones, who won 13 major championships. Today, the 33yearold Ohioan exceeded Jones by winning the Professional Golfers Association championship for his 14th major title.

title: Party for Heather Whitney, 18, May Restore Debut to Lexicon
description: SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 12 Just when so many young girls born with silver spoons in their mouths are pronouncing that being debutantes and going through the whitedress, comingout routine is a drag, along comes Heather Whitney to herald a possible swing back to the good young days.

title: CHINA IN CONFLICT OVER EDUCATION
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 12 controversy over who should eligible to receive a higher education has developed serious and farreaching political implications in China.

title: 1,000 CountryMusic Fans Picnic in Queens Field
description: The guitarists thumped, banjo players plinked and fiddlers scraped away as over 1,000 country music fans from the metropolitan area joined yesterday in what was heralded as an oldfashioned family country picnic.

title: ThirdString Dolphin Does FirstClass Passing Job
RELEASE OF TAPES
description: Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. said yesterday that, unless President Nixon released immediately all the tapes and documents relating to the Watergate affair, the confidence of the American people in the Presidency would not be restored.

title: Berlin Rules Girl Must Face Patricide Charge in the East
description: BERLIN, Aug. 12 (Reuters)The West Berlin Supreme Court has ruled that a teenage girl alleged to have killed her father in East Germany should be handed back to the East German authorities to stand trial.

title: New Scooter Force Joining Crackdown On Midtown Autos
description: Seventeen meter men and maids, riding threewheeled scooters, will patrol midtown Manhattan today in search of parking violators.

title: Thousands Bring In Meat From Canada and Mexico
description: SAN YSIDRO, Calif., Aug. 12Carl Holt and his wife, Frieda, drew up to the United States Customs gates at the Mexican border here, on their way home to Encinitas, 40 miles up the California coast, with enough beef to last their family month.

title: Sterling Balances May Threaten Pound
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 12In the heyday of the. British Empire, the colonies looked to London for help in a financial crisis. Today, London is looking to one of its last colonies fir help in supporting the ailing pound.

title: Lawyers vs. Lawyers
description: A hopeful sign of the times is that it is getting hard to tell the Establishment from the rebels. The counterconvention of lawyers that met in Washington last week to offset the convention of the American Bar Association yielded a kind of generalized censure of the legal profession, a bynow routine exercise in which lawyers condemned lawyers as the enemies of reform. The real action of the week was in the meeting of the A.B.A. itself, which heard speeches and adopted resolutions that might have satisfied a counterconvention.

title: Jasper Yeates Brinton Dead; Headed Mixed Courts of Egypt
description: CAIRO, Aug. 12Jasper Yeates Brinton, retired president of the Mixed Courts of Egypt and an authority on Egyptian law, has died in London on his annual visit to Britain and the United States. He was 94 years old and had been a resident of Egypt since 1921, when he was first appointed a judge of the Mixed Court system by the Egyptian monarch with the approyal of the United States Government.

title: Inmates Romp and Picnic With Sons As Prison Offers Token of Family Life
description: STORMVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 12While the picnickers and their sons and wives sported on the grass inside the walls of Green Haven Correctional Facility, other inmates who had not been invited peered through the chainlink fence at the rare burst of gaiety.

title: KARL ZIEGLER, 74, CHEMIST, IS DEAD
description: MUHLHEIM, Germany, Aug. 12 (UPI)Karl Ziegler, a 1963 Nobel Prize winner in chemistry, died today after a short illness. He was 74 years old.

title: Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: Canada Development Gets Order Against Texasgulf
description: The Canada Development Corporation, which is making $290million offer to buy 10 million shares of Texasgulf, Inc., was disclosed yesterday to have obtained an injunction against the natural resources company.

title: A HEAVY EVENING OF LEON RUSSELL
description: The cavernous Nassau Coliseum with upward of 15,000 rock fans crammed in, milling around because the ground floor seats had been removed, is possibly not the place for subtlety. Thus Leon Russell, who has composed many a delicate ballad, was wise Saturday night, to concentrate on just gettin it on, clap hands and boogie, the more physical side of his musical makeup.

title: Problems of Newness Irk Travelers And Employes at Newark Terminal A
description: NEWARK, Aug. 12 On this first weekend for the new terminal at Newark International Airport, a computerized schedule board listed identical flights under arrivals and departures, airline reservation agents complained of equipment that didn't work, and passengers had to search for an open cocktail lounge.

title: Red Smith
description: A search party of seven has been recruited from the roundball hierarchy to seek out some unripe Clyde Beatty who can be toughened up sufficiently in the next two years to take over the whip and kitchen chair that J. Walter Kennedy, Commissioner of the National Basketball Association, has decided to lay down June 1, 1975. The committee, headed by Dick Block of the Phoenix Suns, has not announced publicly what qualities it will look for in choosing Kennedy's successor, but an administrator who must deal with the passions and prejudices of 17 fiercely competitive clubowners ought to be something like Shakespeare's valiant flea that dare eat his breakfast on the lip of lion.

title: Susan's Girl Neck Victor At Delaware
description: STANTON, Del., Aug. 12Christiana's Light Hearted, unbeaten in seven Delaware Park starts, and Hobeau Farms's Blessing Angelica, winner of the event for the last two years, were in today's starting field of six in the $109,500 Delaware Handicap today, the closing day of a 64day meeting.

title: U.S. Begins a Campaign to End Exploitation of Migrant Labor
description: The regional office of the Department of Labor here announced yesterday that it had begun a drive to end exploitation of migrant farm workers in New Jersey and New York.

title: Pollyanna Lives
description: I said to myself, Cheer up, things could be worse, so I cheered up, and sure enough  things got worse.

title: Text of Sihanouk's Message to Mansfield on a Cambodian Peace
description: PEKING, Aug. 12 (Agence FrancePresse)Following is a translation of the text of a cablegram sent on Aug. 10 by Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the deposed Cambodian Chief of State, to Senator Mike Mansfield, Democrat of Montana, the majority leader, offering peace with honor if Washington ended the bombing of Cambodia and cut off military supplies to Phnom Penh. The original text was in French.

title: Sewcretariat Has virus, Will Not Run in Travers
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 12  Lucien Laurin, trainer of Secretariat, the Triple Crown winner this year, said today that the Meadow Stable colt was suffering with a virus and would be unable to run in the $100,000 Travers Stakes here on Saturday.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SONGFEST Women will be whooping it up tonight at 9 in the Manhattan Theater Club, 321 East 73d Street, between First and Second Avenues (BU 8.5000), in an evening of songs composed and sung by women. It's called A Circle of Sound and it's full of Broadway show tunes, ballads and contemporary songs, including a few of a peppery political kind, The songs are written mostly by the performers, who include Nancy Ford and Gretchen Cryer (The Last Sweet Days of Isaac and Shelter), Zenobia Conkerite, Carole Horne, Paula Larke, Terry Molina and Dale Soules. The club has 100 seats, and they all go for $3.

title: Saigon Views Cambodia Coolly, Is Held Unlikely to Intervene
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 12South Vietnam appears unlikely to intervene militarily on behalf of the CamboIdian Government, informed official sources say.

title: Bridge Mrs. Tornay's Team Leader In Swiss Title Event Here
description: A sextet captained by Clare Tornay of New Yorkled the field into the second day's play in the GreaterNew York Bridge Association's Swiss team championship at the New York Hilton here yesterday. Teamed with Marcel Friedmann, Jay Mechutan, Bob Taylor, Richard Neff and her husband, George Tornay, all of New York, Mrs. Tornay led at the end of Saturday's play with a score of 89 victory points.

title: Nastase Gets Title, No Money
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 12 (UPI) Topseeded Ilie Nastase of Rumania won the men's singles championship of the $75,000 Western tennis tournament today but his $9,000 firstprize money was withheld by the referee, who charged that Nastase had cursed him.

title: Donohue Takes Ohio CanAm, Beating Follmer by 10 Seconds
description: LEXINGTON, Ohio, Aug. 12What race team can play it so cool that its crewmen can polish the car and replace a scraped identification number between heats? Mark Donohue's crew, of course. And what race driver can run second most of the way and then win with a showboat finish? Again, Donohue.

title: Wadeeha Atiyeh, Singer And Author of Cook Book
description: Mrs. Wadeeha Baccash Craven, who under the professional name of Wadeeha Atiyeh was a singer,/entertainer and author of S/cheherazade Cooks, died Saturday in St; Clare's Hospital. Her age was 70. She was the widow of Leonard Craven, a singer and musician, and lived at 515 West 48th Street.

title: Proper Tire Care Is Urged to Save Gas and Money
description: NEWARK  Sidney Margolius, author of a dozen consumer books including the justpublished Health Foods, Facts and Fakes (Walker & Co.) drove through Newark recently and stopped long enough to discuss the high price of virtually everything  including motoring, Mr. Margolius, who has been watching consumer habits for more years than he cares to remember, says that just as driving and engine conditions affect a car's performance, so does the condition of tires. Unless tires are fully inflated, tire drag can cut down on mileage, he said. Other Margolius tips include checking wheel alignment (toeing in or out one degree increases drag about 8 per cent) keeping the tank filled so gas is less likely to evaporate, and using radial tires, which save about 10 percent of gas.

title: The President in Public
description: When H. R. Haldeman told the Senate Watergate committee the other day about his role in controlling the crowds before a Presidential appearance in Charlotte, N. C., he was perhaps not yet aware that a Federal district court had just the day before handed down its finding on what had actually happened at that 1971 rally held in honor of the Rev. Billy Graham.

title: Nixon Stand on Tapes Recalls British Legal Tradition
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12President Nixon's contention that the courts have no centre over him or his records as tom as he remains President recall the British legal tradition o the immunity of the king more than any clearcut intentions it the Constitution or its later in terpretation by the Supreme Court.

title: Continued Meat Crisis Expected This Week
description: ALBANY, Aug. 12  The meat crisishigh prices and short supplywill not improve this week, according to the State Department of Agriculture and Markets.

title: Burfeindt Triumphs By 2 Shots
2,000 Join in a Tribute To Touring Fatima Statue
description: Almost 2,000 Roman Catholic worshipers, mostly CroatianAmericans, held a religious procession on the West Side yesterday morning to celebrate the presence of the Pilgrim Virgin statue of Our Lady of Fatima in the Archdiocese of New York.

title: Personal Finance
description: Many states and the Federal Government have various scholarship and loan programs that provide for some forgiveness of repayment if a student fulfills certain requirements such as training for a much needed profession or settling in areas where there is a lack of certain skills.

title: Smith Dies In Crash In Crash, at. 170 M.P.H.
Metropolitan Briefs
description: Richard M. Clurman, the city's Parks and Recreation Administrator, said yesterday that he would oppose the creation of a special security force to police the city's parks. Mr. Clurman, who noted that each year proposals were made in Albany. for creating such a force, said that parks made up about 17 per cent of the city's real estate and that a force large enough to police them would have to be about onethird the size of the regular police force.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 12 (UPI)Steve Mizerak, a teacher from Woodbridge, N. J., survived a strong challenge by Luther (Wimpy) Lassiter today to win his fourth straight United States Open pocket billiardschampionship, Mizerak, unbeaten in the doubleelimination tourney, lost a marathon match that started fast night and lasted more than 4 hours, 150110, in 22 innings. This meant game 2 of the series would decide the championship.

title: Robbie Beall, Built Chain Of 64 Department Stores
description: LUFKIN, Tex:, Aug. 12 (UPI) Robbie Beall, who along with his two brothers built an East Texas department store into 64store chain, died today at hospital here. He was 81 years old.

title: Rates of Interest Are Still Heading Up
Lindsay Approaches Point of No Return With No Indication of a Change of Course or Mind
description: The last day of dreamspinning for those who cling to the hope that Mayor Lindsay will run for reelection is Aug. 23. But by this time, after many weeks of whispering in City Hall corridors about the Mayor's secret plans, the selfstyled insiders have just about given up. The Mayor has not shownthe slightest indication, since he counted himself out last March,that he would goback on his word.

title: Roundup: Norm Cash Day Is a Success for Tigers
description: Norm Cash Day yesterday was a success for everybody except the 38yearold first baseman who has worn a Detroit Tiger uniform for 14 seasons.

title: Public Found Disillusioned By the Watergate Scandal
description: Alexander and Betty Bennett were shepherding two children and a shopping cart through supermarket in the Carrick section of Pittsburgh, an aging neighborhood of modest homes and hardworking people, the kind of place where words such as patriotism and law and order still hold deep meaning.

title: Hospital's Dockside Manner Helps in Aquatic Cases
description: POINT PLEASANT, Aug. 12 A fire broke out aboard a pleasure craft at the Jersey shore here recently, painfully burning one of several youths aboard. Within minutes, the marine police had the boy aboard a patrol boat and on the way to the emergency dock at Point Pleasant Hospital, where he received prompt treatment and, within a few days, was able to resume his vacation.

title: Air and Ground Search Ends For Lost Boy in New Mexico
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Aug. 12 (UPI)The active search! for a small boy believed lost in New Mexico was ended today. The boy's voice had been, heard pleading for help over) citizens band radios for five, days, but the police said the calls probably were a hoax.

title: Where Has the Trunk Gone? Mostly, It's Gone to Camp
description: The last time Joan Crawford traveled with a trunk was in 1955, when she was a passenger aboard the Andrea Doria.

title: Home Burglar Alarms Vex the Police
description: One of the fastest growing phenomenons in the metropolitan areathe installation of burglar alarmsis becoming major problem for Police Departments, which complain that they are wasting an increasingly large amount of time answering false alarms.

title: State Panel Seeks to Ease Financial Woes of Artists
description: The State Commission on Cultural Resources has proposed a broad program of selfhelp and public assistance to ease the employment and financial problems of many of the state's 50,000 artists and writers.

title: Sweden Ousts India At Stevens Cup Net
Train Engineer Is Arrested In Korea in the Death of 31
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Monday, Aug. 13 (UPI)The police today arrested, the engineer of an oilladen freight train that jumped the tracks, overturned and set fire to a row of houses yesterday, killing at least 31 persons. Authorities accused the trainman of speeding and falling asleep at the throttle.

title: U.S. PLANES POUND PHNOM PENH AREA AS CUTOFF NEARS
description: United States planes continued heavy bombing around the Cambodian capital, Phnom Penh, yesterday, three days before the bombing was to be cut off by Congressional action.

title: ... But a Whimper
description: In a few hours now Americans will no longer be killing people in Indochina, or destroying their land. After eight years, the bombing is to stop.

title: Phase 4 Begins
description: Phase 4 of the Nixon price stabilization program began at midnight when the 60day freeze on prices ended. Exceptions are beef prices, which remain frozen until Sept. 12, and those on petroleum, frozen another week.

title: ReadyMade Leather Garments Are Due From India
description: NEW DELHIAnd now, now from the country that spawned the Nehru jacket and the kurta, we give you the Eisenhower jacket, Indian style.

title: R. J. Aronowitz Weds Carol Tanhauser
description: LEVITTOWN, Pa., Aug. 12 Miss Carol Ann Tanhauser and Robert J. Aronowitz, son of Judge and Mrs. Samuel J. Aronowitz of Levittown, were married here this afternoon by Rabbi William Fierverker in Congregation BethEl.

title: 65 Die in Floods in India
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 12 (Reuters)At least 65 people have died and thousands of people have been left homeless in floods across northern India in the last few days, according to latest reports. In the worsthit area, Kashmir, the level of some rivers, began to fall overnight; but heavy rain this morning caused more problems.

title: Maurice Bisgyer, ExLeader Of B'nai B'rith, Is Dead at 75
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) Maurice Bisgyer, retired executive vice president of B'nai B'rith, the Jewish service organization, died today at the age of 75. He had been hospi talized for six weeks after having suffered a stroke.

title: Advertising: 20th Lassie Season
description: When the new television season gets underway next month, Lassie will be coming home for her twentieth consecutive year on the home screens. For the last couple of years, the TV show has been syndicated to local stations, which has necessitated a different approach to marketing.

title: Rabbi Yoseph Henkin, 92, Headed Charity 50 Years
description: Rabbi Yoseph Elia Henkin, for almost 50 years executive three. for of Ezras Torah Fund, a rabbinical charity organization here that supports rabbis and scholars around the world, died Saturday at his home, 385 Grand Street. He was 92 years old.

title: Carole Grad Bride Of T. J. Sherwood
description: TRENTON, Aug. 12Miss Carole Jane.Grad, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney H. Grad, was married at home here today to Thomas Jay Sherwood, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Sherwood of Darien, Conn. Judge David Schroth of the Trenton Municipal Court performed the ceremony.

title: Montefiore to Be Moved
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 12 (UPI) The body of Sir Moses Montefiore, father of modern Jewish settlement here, will be returned to Jerusalem a century after his death, the Israeli Government said today. A statement after the weekly Cabinet session said that his body would be moved here in 1975 from the British town of Ramsate.

title: SHOP TALR
description: It could be called a miniature Woman's Exchange, this big, pleasant sunlit room not far from Borough Hall in Brooklyn, where Lethia Robertson holds forth in a shop bearing her name and where handcrafts produced by three other women are on sale.

title: Israeli View of Incident Shifts
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 12At first I thought it was madness far too much risk for too little profit, a Hebrew University professor said today of Israel's diversion of an Arab airliner over Beirut Friday night.

title: Fruit Growers Protest Safety Standard
description: HIGHLAND, N. Y., Aug. 12Reentry problems face not only astronauts, but also the fruit growers of the United States.

title: Bryant Checks Mets, 41, for 17th Victory
Derelict Boat in No Man's Sea Burns Out of Reach Off Queens
description: A derelict houseboat burned for more than four hours off Breezy Point jetty in the Rockaways, Queens, near Rockaway Point last nighttoo far from shore for the police, too close to shore for the Coast Guard and in seas too rough for the Fire Department's marine unit to do anything about it.

title: ASTRONAUTS ADJUST TO CHORES IN SPACE
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 12 (AP)The Skylab 2 crew explored the American Southwest with space cameras today and reported that they had gotten the hang of things enough to do more work.

title: Inquirer Walkout Ends
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12 (AP)A oneday work stoppage that prevented distribution of most of the Sunday editions of The Philadelphia Inquirer ended later in the day, a spokesman for the paper said. He said the union representing the newspaper's mailers was unhappy with plans to consolidate the first two editions, currently published at 6:30 and 9:30 P.M.

title: Indian From Quebec Charged in Murder Of S.I. Woman, 57
description: A 17yearold Indian youth from Canada was charged yesterday with the murder of Mrs. Grace M. Schriefer, a 57yearold grandmother, at her Staten Island home, the police said. Nine dollars was taken from the pocketbook of Mrs. Schriefer, who had a broken hip and walked with a cane, they said.

title: INSTITUTIONS FIND NO FOOD SHORTAGE
description: Institutions such as hospitals and nursing homes around the country insist their patients are still receiving enough food. But some say they are serving less meat and all complain that soaring prices will cause trouble later.

title: Pakistan's Parliament Elects Bhutto as Prime Minister
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Aug. 12 (Reutuers)President ZulfikarAli Bhutto was tonight elected Prime Minister by vote of 160 to 28 in the National Assembly.

title: Clashes Are Heavy In 3 Vietnam Areas, According to Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 12 (Reuters)The South Vietnamese command today reported continued heavy clashes with Communist troops in the Central Highlands, the adjacent coastal lowlands and the Mekong Delta, below Saigon.

title: Audiences Provide Body For Listless Soul Shows
description: Blowing whistles, shaking tambourines, cheering, clapping, dancing and generally having a good timeit was the small but infectiously active audiences who were responsible for much of the soul found in the Soul at the Center 73 shows Saturday night and early yesterday morning.

title: SouthWest Africa Faces Rising Political Ferment
description: WINDHOEK, SouthWest Africa, Aug. 1  The whites who rule it call the territory SouthWest. Africa. To the blacks who want to govern it and to the United Nations it is Namibia. A resident of any race is likely to call it just SouthWest.

title: Shooting at Jersey Camp Laid to British Boy Scout
description: PAHAQUARRY TOWNSHIP, N.J., Aug. 12A 19yearold Boy Scout from Cheltenham, England, has been Charged with atrocious assault and battery after he allegedly shot and critically wounded a sixyearold Chicago boy at a Boy Scout camp here.

title: Tournament Will Team Jersey City's Past and Future
description: JERSEY CITY, Aug. 12This city's past, present and future will be intertwined toMorrow when the Eastern regional Little League baseball championship tournament starts at the Enos Jones sports complex.

title: OCCIDENTAL GETS CASH FROM LIBYA
description: It added that the $135millior represented payment on account, with the final amount to be subject to a financial audit.

title: News About Cops
description: WESTPORT, Conn.When I first became involved in police training, in 1968, I was warned by my colleagues that it would be a waste of time. Several of them suggested that police were themselves, for the most part, borderline criminals, that they were usually sadistic and given toward violence. That they were antiintellectual, rigid, inflexible personalities whose principal problemsolving techniques were brute force and punishment.

title: U.S. Team Tops Poles In Soccer
description: The United States national soccer team, with seven Americanborn players in its lineup for the first time, defeated the national team of Poland, 10, yesterday on a goal by Al Trost of the St. Louis Stars of the North American Soccer League.

title: 4 Liners Sold for Scrap as Passenger Trade Wanes
description: The decline of passenger shipping has again been documented by the recent sale for scrap of four prominent liners, including one that was a frequent caller here and one that made worldwide headlines in 1961.

title: Hannah Gonski Bride Of Bruce E. Goldman
description: LIVINGSTON, N. J., Aug. 12Miss Hannah Gonski and Bruce Eric Goldman were married here this evening in Temple Beth Sholom by Rabbi Harold Halpern of the New Milford Jewish Center.

title: Sundancer Wins On 3d Jumpoff
description: BRANCHVILLE, N.J., Aug. 12  Sundancer, a former member of the Canadian Equestrian Team now owned and ridden by Michele McEvoy won the $10,000 added Sussex County open jumper classic today at the closing session of the weeklong Sussex County horse show.

title: Bridal for Miss Fishwick, Michael Gold
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Aug. 12Miss Carolmarie Patricia Fishwick was married here this evening to Michael Alan Gold. Judge Lawrence J. Goldstein, Village Justice of Hempstead, performed the ceremony at Stouffer's.

title: Stage: A Valid Festival
description: CHICHESTER, England When Sir John Clements took over the Chichester Festival from Sir Laurence Olivier in 1966, the festival was offering three plays over a period of nine weeks. Now, in Sir John's own last season, it offers four plays over a period of 19 weeks. And Sir John has developed what was once merely the country outpost of London's National Theater into a valid festival of its own. During his regime eight productions transferred to London's West End, one (Vivat, Vivat, Regina even continued on to New York) and one current festival production is also scheduled for a London showing after the Chichester season.

title: SouthWest Africa Faces Rising Political Ferment
description: WINDHOEK, South West Africa, Aug. 1  The whites who rule it call the territory SouthWest Africa. To the blacks who want to govern it and to the United Nations it is Namibia. A resident of any race is likely to call it just SouthWest.

title: Riders on Last New Orleans Streetcars Pay 15Cent Fare for Their Iron Horse
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug, 12St. Charles streetcar No. 905 wallowed down the track toward Canal Street at 8:30 A.M. with its first burden of laborers and maids.

title: Haiti Shuffles Top Officials For Second Time in 2 Days
description: PORTAUPRINCE, Haiti, Aug 12 (AP)  More than 20 of President JeanClaude Duvalier's top officials have been ousted or assigned to other jobs in a second governmental reorganization within 24 hours, officials said yesterday.

title: Canada Imposes Controls On Beef and Pork Exports
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 13The Canadian Government, moving against the steepest increases in the cost of living that this country has known since the Korean war, imposed controls tonight on the export of beef and pork.

title: DOWJONES INDEX TUMBLES BY 9.18; Fears of Higher Interest Rates and Prices Again Push Stocks Down
Ahumada Triumphs In Fight at Forum
description: Jorge Ahumada of Argentina floored Ray Anderson, of Youngstown, Ohio, two times last night and was awarded the victory after the eighth round of the scheduled 10round bout at the Felt Forum.

title: Israeli Vessels Clash With Egyptians in Gulf
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 13Israeli and Egyptian naval craft exchanged fire today in the Gulf of Suez.

title: COX PLEA ON TAPES DENIES PRESIDENT IS PROPER JUDGE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 Archibald Cox, the Watergate special prosecutor, argued today that President Nixon could not be a proper judge of whether the public interest re quires his making tape recordings of White House conversations available to a grand jury investigation.

title: Ehrlichman Calls Inquiry Destructive
description: SEATTLE, Aug. 13  John D. Ehrlichman charged today that the work of the Senate Watergate committee was destructive.

title: Arrests of South Korean Christian Clergy, Called Foes of Regime, Stir Worry Abroad
description: Protestant leaders in this country and abroad have become concerned about the arrest of several South Korean clergymen six weeks ago on charges of antiGovernment activities.

title: DOUGLAS R. KENNEDY
description: HONOLULU, Aug. 13 (AP)Douglas Richards Kennedy, television and motion picture character actor, died Friday at the age of 55.

title: U.S. CREATES UNIT ON INDIAN RIGHTS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13The Justice Department announced today the creation of an office to protect the civil rights of American Indians.

title: Prince and Cherry Pit...
description: The optimistic prediction by a Cambodian official that tonight's cutoff of American bombing would create a better atmosphere for a peace settlement, already appears to be gaining some substance, although not the manner the official anticipated.

title: Superintendent Knifed to Death In Home in Morningside Heights
description: The superintendent of an apartment building in Morningside Heights was stabbed to death in his groundfloor apartment during an apparent robbery attempt, the police reported yesterday.

title: Unofficial Price of Gold Drops to $98
description: LONDON, Aug. 13 (UPI)The price of gold dipped below the $100 mark in unofficial London markets for the first time in three months today while the dollar traded inconclusively on European exchanges following considerable gains last week.

title: Morgan Lifts Rate Abroad
description: LONDON, Aug. 13 (Reuters) The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company today raised its sterling base lending rate to 11 per cent from 10 per cent, effective Wednesday. The base rate is used by London banks for calculating interest charges on loans. Generally the charge to most creditworthy customers is one point above the base rate.

title: Trying to Cut Perils in Shipping Pets
description: Everytime you ship one of your animals by air, you ship with your heart in your mouth, says Mrs. Stanley A. Davis, a dachshund breeder in Hopkinton, N.H.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:
Chess: Portisch Takes First Place Chess.With Victory Over Reshevsky
Vote on Abernathy Slated
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 13 (AP) (AP)The Southern Christian Leadership Conference will open its national convention here tomorrow with the election of a successor to the Rev, Ralph David Abernathy at the top of the agenda. Mr. Abernathy has hinted at reconsider ing his resignation if he is assured of full support.

title: Emergency Calls..
description: Mayor Lindsay and other city officials are appealing to the public to stop calling 911 except for genuine and serious emergencies.

title: ...Admiral and Computer
description: The grotesque scale of values that guided the bombing of Cambodia, with all its callousness and deceit, was never more bluntly revealed than in last week's testimony by Adm. Thomas H. Moorer, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, explaining why a double system of accounting was set up to hide from Congress and the American people the fact that B52's were raining death and devastation on a neutral nation.

title: Greece to Try 56 Navy Officers for Plot
Body Tentatively Identified At Queens Explosion Site
description: The body of a man was found yesterday in the rubble of a building destroyed by mysterious Queens explosion of last March and the police said it might be that of a missing Long Island man.

title: Dresser Earnings at Record
Pennsy Gets a $17Million Loan
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 The Penn Central Transportation Company obtained a $17.7million emergency loan from the Federal Railroad Administration today but the road's trustees insisted that without really massive Federal aid by Oct. 31 that they must begin making plans for going out of the railroad business.

title: H. H. Robertson to Close A Plant in West Germany
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 13 (Reuters)The H. H. Robertson Company reports its West German subsidiary, Robertson Bauelemente, G.m.b.H., will close its building products manufacturing plant at Hitdorf, West Germany, by the end of year.

title: MARASOL AND FOUR CITED IN S.E.C. SUIT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a fraud suit today against Marasol Properties and four other companies, charging that the means that they are using to sell condominium's constitutes an illegal sale of securities.

title: Death Is Laid to Lightning
description: An autopsy yesterday confirmed that Gary gantry, 16 years old, of 419 Winchester Avenue, Eltingville, S.I., had been killed by lightning in Brooklyn as he sought refuge from a thunderstorm Saturday. Young Fantry's metal belt buckle was struck directly by the bolt as he ran toward an oak tree at 97th Street and Shore Road in Bay Ridge, according to Dr. Dominick J. DiMaio, a deputy chief medical examiner.

title: LIFE SENTENCE GIVEN IN QUEENS DRUG CASE
description: A 44yearold Elmhurst man, described by the police as the mastermind of a Queens drug ring, was sentenced to life imprisonment yesterday by Acting Supreme Court Justice Mary J. Lowe.

title: Drug Unit Acts to Oust 6 and Demote Chief in Raids
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13The Federal Drug Enforcement Administration began action today to dismiss six narcotics agents who took part in two narcotics raids in Illinois last April that have resulted in a Federal grand jury investigation.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PLYMOUTH, England, Aug. 13 (AP)The 48 Admiral's Cup contenders from 16 nations reached the Fastnet rock today with 260 miles to go in the finale of the fourrace series to decide world supremacy in ocean racing.

title: HAROLD F. FOULTZ
description: Harold F. Foultz, commander of the hospital ship Comfort in World War II, died Saturday in Mountainside Hospital, Montclair, N.J. He was 83 years old and lived at 8 Ridley Court, Glen Ridge, N.J.

title: Rogers in Effort To Revive SEATO As Peace Alliance
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13Secretary of State William P. Rogers plans to meet with envoys from the other Southeast Asia Treaty Organization members in New York next month to put stress on the nonmilitary aspects of the 19yearold organization as a way of keeping it alive, State Department officials said today.

title: CAMBODIA LOSES TOWN AT JUNCTION ABOVE ITS CAPITAL
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Aug. 13Despite an overall lull in fighting in Cambodia today, military sources reported the loss of an important market town 48 miles northeast of here. American planes continued heavy attacks all around Phnom Penh with two days remaining until the scheduled cutoff of the bombing.

title: GAMBINO NO. 2 MAN IS ARRESTED QN L.I.
description: MASSAPEQUA, L. I., Aug. 13Ettore Zappi, whom District Attorney William Cahl of Nassau County has described as the No. 2 man in the crime family of Carlo Gambino, was arrested at his home here this morning as a fugitive from justice in California.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The owners of the old Broadway Central Hotel, which collapsed Aug. 3, killing at least four persons, won a week's adjournment in Supreme Court yesterday on the question of whether the city would be allowed to raze what remained of the structure.

title: Summary of Brief Filed by Cox Seeking the White House Tapes
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13Following is a summary by Archibald Cox, the special Watergate prosecutor, of the legal brief filed by Mr. Cox in connection with his suit to compel President Nixon to provide a grand jury with recordings of White House conversations and related documents:

title: $16Million Generator Order
description: STANFORD, Conn., Aug, 13 (UPI)  Combustion Engineeri iing, Inc., today obtained a $161 order from the Indian1 apolis Power and Light Com, lowly for a 600,000kilowatt controlled circulation coalfired steam generator to be installed at the Freeburg Station in In1 idiana.

title: Half of Food Places Fail the Sanitary Test
description: TRENTON, Aug. 13Only a little over onehalf of the food establishments inspected since the state began compiling reports under a new Sanitary Code last December have passed the examinations.

title: Bridge: Precision Sextet Is Winner Of Swiss Team Contest
description: The Swiss team championship of the Greater New York Bridge Association ended Sunday night at the New York Hilton in a victory for a Precision sextet: Michael and Gail Moss, Amalya Kearse, Steve Altman, all of New York, AnneMarie Sporing of Wayne, N. J., and Tom Smith of Greenwich, Conn.

title: COX PLEA ON TAPES DENIES PRESIDENT IS PROPER JUDGE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 Archibald Cox, the Watergate special prosecutor, argued today that President Nixon could not be a proper judge of whether the public interest requires his making tape recordings of White House conversations available to a grand jury investigation.

title: PRICES ARE RAISED ON CARS AND STEEL AS PHASE 4 OPENS
description: Higher prices were announced yesterday for automobiles and the steel used to manufacture a variety of consumer products as the Nixon Administration's 60day price freeze gave way to a more relaxed Phase 4.

title: SKYLAB CREW TESTS MANEUVERING PACK
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 13 (AP)Maneuvering sideways and upside down, two Skylab astronauts flitted about their space station today with a jetpropelled backback.

title: Bangkok Fire Destroys A Wing of Famed Hotel
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 13 (Reuters) Fire today destroyed part of the Oriental Hotel, one of Bangkok's bestknown landmarks, but guests and the staff escaped unharmed.

title: CHARLES CUSHING, PHOTOGRAPHER, 88
description: Charles Phelps Cushing, photographer, photographers agent and writer, whose interest in Americana led him to photograph more than 500 Main Streets, died yesterday at his home, 2440 Sedgwick Avenue, the Bronx. His age was 88.

title: Dispute, Not Theft, Cited in Art Work Removal
description: A dispute over who legally owns $800,000 worth of art treasures and artifacts from three South American nations  and not theft is the reason for the disappearance of the artwork from two Manhattan warehouses on Friday, the police reported yesterday.

title: HOTEL OWNERS WIN A DELAY ON RAZING
description: The owners of the old Broadway Central Hotel, which collapsed 11 days ago, killing at least four persons won a week's adjournment in Supreme Court yesterday on the question of whether the city would be allowed to raze what remained of the structure.

title: Texas Toll of Boys Rises to 27 In Nation's Biggest Slaying Case
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 13They used to hang around Dean Corli's candy shop. They included friends, boys from school, neighborhood buddies, and later, runaway kids from other towns.

title: Modern Museum Charging Record $2
description: The Museum of Modern Art will begin this week charging $2 for admissionthe highest museum admission fee in the country. Since 1970, admission has been $1.75, but even with rising attendance, the museum says, its available funds will not allow it to meet the escalating costs of maintenance and operation.

title: Soviet Invites State U. Aides
description: ALBANY, Aug. 13 (AP)  A research associate with the Atmospheric Sciences Research Center of the State University of New York at Albany has been invited to the Soviet Union. The researcher, Roger J. Cheng, will deliver a paper entitled The Mechanism of Multiplication Process of Glaciation in the Atmosphere at the Eighth International Conference of Nucleation at Leningrad Sept. 24 to 29, and a similar subject will be discussed at a conference on weather modification at Tashkent Oct. 1 to 7.

title: Divers Encounter Delay
description: FAIRHAVEN, Mass., Aug. 13 (UPI)Divers were forced to halt their attempt to penetrate the purser's office of the sunken Andrea Doria today when a cable for some of their equipment broke. The incident will cause a delay of uncertain ength for repairs.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Arabs Bid U.N. Condemn Israel Over Jet Incident
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 13  The Arab states asked the Security Council today to meet its responsibilities and face up to the arrogant challenge of the Israelis and their continued defiance of the United Nations and international law.

title: PROTEIN PRODUCTS ADVANCE BY LIMIT
description: Frantic buyers again shattered historic price records in the Middle Western grain and livestock markets yesterday as they struggled, unsuccessfully for the most part, to buy protein products.

title: Woman Is Slain in Chicago; Suspect Is Captured in Park
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (UPI)A young mother, strolling in Chicago's Grant Park with her husband and child, was stabbed to death today when she paused to enter a washroom.

title: The Nostalgia Affair
description: Letters to the columnist:

title: Owners of $80Million in Savings Bonds Sought
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) The Treasury and the Federal Reserve. Banks are holding about $80million worth of Government savings bonds unclaimed by servicemen and others who bought them, the General Accounting Office says.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Bakshi Captures Reality With XRated Cartoons
description: With last year's surprise success, Fritz the Cat, and his current boxoffice hit, Heavy Traffic, Ralph Bakshi, the aggressive young creator of both Xrated animated features, has shaken up the loonytuney cartoon world with dissonant melodies that are not for children. he

title: GOING OUT. Gulde
description: PINOCCHIO What have we here? A streetwise mussicalcomedy revision of the classic 1880 tale by Carlo Collodi, in which a black Pinocchio (carved from a handsome piece of mahogany and charmingly played by Grenaldo Frazier) ventures out of a toy shop on Mulberry Street and into the city, there to meet conartists, promoters and the obligatory junkie, among others.

title: Chester G. Burden Dead; Commercial Cable Officer
description: Chester Griswold Burden, a retired vice president of the Commercial Cable Company, died Aug. 6 in Bad Gastein, Austria, where he was on vacation. He lived at 1220 Park Avenue.

title: A READING MINORS SOVIET MARTYRS
description: The words of martyred Russian Jewish poets rang out on Fifth Avenue yesterday, 21 years after they were executed in a Moscow jail.

title: Equity Financing
description: A special offering of 241,700 shares of Coleman Company common at 19 per share was made yesterday by Bear Stearns & Co. The company's stock closed at 19, down  on the American Stock Exchange.

title: Sandman and Byrne Differ On TransitEcology Policy
description: TRENTON, Aug. 13In their first confrontation in the New Jersey campaign for Governor, Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. and former Superior Court Judge Brendan T. Byrne disagreed today on applying environmental protection to highway construction projects.

title: AIDES HINT AGNEW WILL COOPERATE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13Vice. President Agnew's staff advisers here believe he will turn over his personal financial papers, as requested by Federal prosecutors, probably this week, Marsh Thompson, Mr. Agnew's press secretary, said today.

title: Notes on People
description: Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas and his wife arrived in Hong Kong, on their way to China, where, the jurist said, he would like to meet Chinese leaders, or Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the exiled Chief of State of Cambodia, or both, Justice Douglas said in an airport interview that I would enjoy meeting with the leaders of the People's Republic of China and with Sihanouk, but it is not in our plans.

title: Quiet Riviera Perfume Town in Bitter Conflict Over Arab Labor
description: GRASSE, France, Aug. 3The harvested lavender is heaped high on the floor of the Fragonard perfume factory and the sweet smell from the stills floats through the town, a drowsy, beautiful aerie stacked high on the hills behind Cannes and the French Riviera.

title: Fort Worth 5 Free on Bond In Irish ArmsAid Dispute
description: FORT WORTH, Tex., Aug. 13 (AP)United States District Court Judge Leo Brewster freed the Fort Worth Five today on bonds totaling $50,000. Judge Brewster conducted the brief hearing in his courtroom moments after the five IrishAmericans, all New Yorkers, were brought here from a Federal penitentiary at Seagoville, Tex., near Dallas.

title: British Expert on Guerrillas Pays a Visit to Phnom Penh
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Aug. 13. (Agence FrancePresse) Sir Robert Thompson, a British specialist on guerrilla warfare, paid a 24hour visit to Phnom Penh yesterday.

title: MRS. JOHN R. GOULETTE
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Aug. 13 Mrs. Myrtle Bridgers Goulette, wife of John R. Goulette, retired manager of the wire room of the Washington bureau of The New York Times died here Saturday.

title: Cost of Dinner for 4 Up 17% in Year
description: The cost of roastbeef dinners and chicken dinners for a family of four in the metropolitan area has increased more than 17 per cent in a yeartriple the 5.4 per cent rise in an average factory production worker's hourly earnings in that time.

title: Jurors at Veterans'
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Aug. 13 The jury in the Gainesville Eight trial has expressed fears that its telephones are being tapped.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: About 40 employes of the Newark Housing Authority, carrying signs and chanting slogans, picketed the authority's offices Monday to protest plans to lay off. some 100 administrative workers.

description: CHICAGO, Aug, 13 (UPI)Swift & Co., the nation's largest meat packer, and Ale Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen announced agreement today on a threeyear contract covering 6,000 workers in 45 Swift facilities.

description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 10:30 A.M. on Middle East.

description: The Libyan Government continued its pressure tactics on Western oil interests as it announced yesterday that it was restricting production of American Overseas Petroleum, Ltd.

title: Reserve Attempting to Curb Lending Pave of Banks
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 The Federal Reserve Board raised its discount rate today from 7 to 7Y2 per cent, the highest in history.

title: VIOLATION IS LINKED TO M'GOVERN GROUP
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) The Wisconsin McGovern for President Committee apparently violated the Federal Election Campaign Act by failing to, keep adequate records, the General Accounting Office said today.

title: Mrs. Potter Gets Medal With a 74 In Amateur Golf
