description: ORCHARD PARK, N. Y., Aug. 17Miss Christine Marie Jasen, daughter of Judge

title: F.D.I.C. Relaxes Limits For Some Time Deposits
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation yesterday relaxed somewhat the limits on socalled wildcard time depositsceilingfree deposits of tat least $1,000 that can't be withdrawn for at least four years.

title: BOY IN QUEENS DIES IN FREAK ACCIDENT
description: A 4yearold Queens boy was killed yesterday afternoon when his mother lost control at the wheel and touched off chain of accidents while trying to park the family car, the police reported.

title: South Korean Embassy Denies Charges of Harassment in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17A South Korean Embassy official today denied allegations of misconduct in the United States by officials of South Korea's Central Intelligence Agency, describing the charges as rumors and speculations by partisanminded Korean residents in this country.

title: Mobil Oil Canada Reports Find Offshore Sable Island
description: HALIFAX, Aug. 17 (Canadian Press)Mobil Oil Canada, Ltd., and Texas Eastern Exploration of Canada, Ltd., reported today they have recovered crude oil at an offshore drilling site 25 miles southwest of Sable Island.

title: Bad Air Expected to Stay Over 11 Counties 36 Hours
description: TRENTON, Aug. 17 (UPI)The state's Environmental Protection Department predicted today a mass of stagnant air over 11 northern New Jersey counties would last 36hours.

title: HIJACKER INSISTS GOAL WAS AMITY
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 17The Libyan who forced a Lebanese plane to land in Israel yesterday went behind bars today steadfastly insisting that his sensational exploit had served ArabJewish fraternity.

title: Jet Thruster Unit Given a Final Test Inside the Skylab
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 17 (UPI)The Skylab 2 crew gave a minispacecraft a final test inside the orbiting space station today and suggested changes in lifesupport systems before astronauts use the Buck Rogerslike device in space.

title: A sequel to The Fox in the Attic a novel full of children and Hitler
description: It is well to begin a consideration of Richard Hughes's serial novel, The Human Predicament (of which this is the second volume, following The Fox in the Attic), with a sense of what he is and isn't doing. An obvious comparison is with Anthony Powell's long novel sequence, The Music of Time. Both writers are of an age, that of our century, and of common background, the English upper class. Their novels begin at about the same time, the early 1920's, though Powell's narrator, Nick Jenkins, is still at Eton while Augustine PenryHerbert, who serves as chief observer for Hughes, has finished university. Then, too, he is an aristocrat while Jenkins is merely a gentleman, the son of an army officer, with a living to make. The difference is greater than it might appear to innocent Americans. To the peers of England and their families, political power is cosa nostra, while the gentry, even as you and I, are mere subjects and citizens, of whom ambition and some talent at least are required for scaling the

title: News of the Screen
description: Joan Didion and John Dunne have begun work on the script for a rock remake of A Star Is Born for Warner Brothers. The novelist and her husband have previously collaborated on screenplays for Panic in Needle Park as well as the Didion novel Play It as It Lays, a jaundiced look at Hollywood.

title: Letters: Watergate Was Traitors Gate
description: To the Editor:

title: Agnew Waiting to See If the Shoe Drops
description: BALTIMOREOnce again, Vice President Spiro Agnew went straight into the eye of the storm, setting for himself a public posture of firmness, selfconfidence and cooperation with the Federal prosecutors who are looking into the dark clouds of Maryland politics.

title: ...Or Create a New One?
description: To build and extend a great franchise. This can usually be heard in the opening remarks when it comes time for selling a lineextension idea to management.

title: Collision in Mexico Leaves Toll of 16 Dead and 23 Hurt
description: MONTERREY, Mexico, Aug. 18 (AP)Sixteen people were killed and 23 injured, including four Americans, in a fiery collision near here last night.

title: Macdougal Alley Passes a Milestone
description: A few months ago C. Leo Calarco was househunting. He wanted quieter street than the one he was living on, and he wanted a neighborhood he considered safe. And he wanted to stay in Greenwich Village.

title: The AvantGarde Looks Backward
description: UNLIKE Senator Ervin's famous firefly, which carries its illumination behind, the curious creature known as the avantgardist is expected to shine its light out front. Hindsight is all very well for a trapped politician, but if the avantgarde is not able to show us where we are headed can it reasonably claim that name? And yet, during the recent Festival of Contemporary Music at Tanglewood, an annual gathering where hints to the future might be expected to turn up, decided air of looking backward dominated the programs. On the surface, at least, the festival would seem to be letting down the avantgarde side.

title: The Cost of Living For Retired Here Tops Level in U.S.
description: The budget costs of a typical retired couple in the New Yorknorthern New Jersey region, whatever their standard of living, ran significantly higher than the nationwide urban estimates last fall, Federal officials reported yesterday.

title: TEXANS OPPOSE NAVY RADIO PLAN
description: LLANO, Tex., Aug. 18The home country of Adm. Chester W. Nimitz and President Johnson is preparing to block the Navy's efforts to give it $200million worth of something Wisconsin rejected.

title: L.I. Town Is Aiming To Aid Bike Riders
description: MANHASSET, L.I.There are too many cars in North Hempstead. The town wants more residents to ride bikes instead. So it set up a bicycle route around the town. The only problem is that the bike riders keep running into all those cars.

title: Harlem Project Leaves Bitterness
description: In 1964 Edward F. Knowles was a young architect eagerly beginning the rehabilitation of 26 apartments in six small buildings in East Harlem.

title: Redman, Donohue Post Top Speeds
description: GAINESVILLE, Ga., Aug. 18 (UPI)Brian Redman of England broke the Road Atlanta qualifying record for Formula 5,000 cars today as he posted the fastest qualifying speed for tomorrow's 75mile race. He drove his Lola 119.04 miles an hour over the 2.52mile course.

title: Yugoslavian Slain Here
description: A 50yearold Yugoslavian immigrant was stabbed to death shortly before 4 A.M. yesterday by a burglar he surprised in his firstfloor apartment at 1392 Madison Street, Brooklyn. The police said the man, Raian Dalia, 50 years old, was stabbed after he and his wife, Stana, awoke and found an intruder in their apartment. The burglar escaped by jumping out a window, the police said.

title: It's Off to Philadelphia in a Stagecoach
description: The United States Post Office has granted permission to promoters of the Liberty Run to deliver mail by horsedrawn coach between New York and Philadelphiaon Oct. 1.

title: State Is Airing Plan to Purchase 1,235 Buses for $47Million
description: NEWARKThe state's plan to purchase 1,235 buses at a cost of $47million, the purpose being to maintain and upgrade the lines that operate within New Jersey and those that carry commuters to New York and other nonJersey points, will be aired at a series of regional public hearings this month and next.

title: Olympics, No! Symphony, Yes!
description: THERE is no tradition in Denver, so we don't have to be fearful of it. We don't have to conform. With these words, Brian Priestman, conductor of the Denver Symphony Orchestra, began his description of the concert hall they are planning to build. We started off very carefully in laying down what we wanted in sociological form. There is a new trend toward thinking in terms of audience environment, and we wanted to design from the inside out. We wanted to get away from the Philharmonic Hall type of auditorium. Since we hope our hall will be functioning for a 100 years, we had to look ahead. Before we interviewed architects, we laid down very detailed requirements, and we knew we wanted a hall with chorus seats in back of the orchestra, which can be used by the audience when there's no

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
Susan Whitney Betrothed
description: Oliver H. Whitney of New York and Sag Harbor, L.I., has made known the engagement of his daughter, Miss Susan Oliver Whitney, to Jean Guy Perdon, son of Roger Perdon of Paris. The future bride is a descendant of Eli Whitney. The wedding is planned for Sept. 1 in New Canaan, Conn.

title: Leigh Sutor Hallingby Is Bride
description: ESSEX, Conn., Aug. 18Miss Leigh Sutor Hallingby was married here this afternoon to Kenneth Bowman Platt. The Rev. Joseph P. Bishop of the Presbyterian Church in Rye, N.Y., performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Hallingby of New York and Essex, father and stepmother of the bride. Mr. Hallingby is president of White, Weld & Co., Inc., the investment bankers.

title: SOVIET ACTIVIST IS WARNED AGAIN
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 18  A high Soviet official, in the first de tailed Russian comment or Watergate, was reported today to have belittled the Senate hearing as just a show, adding that all Nixon has to do is show a little firmness and the whole thing will come to nothing.

title: Television
description: PEOPLE shouldn't be watching television at 7 o'clock in the morning, anyway. Father should be whipping up an eggplant souffl; mother should be shaving the chimp; and the children should be counterfeiting yen or spearing mice. The TV set hasn't even brushed its teeth. The brain and the news are gummy.

title: WRITER DECLARES SHE WAS G.O.P. SPY IN M'GOVERN CAMP
description: A freelance writer says she was recruited by one of President Nixon's closest political advisers and received $1,000 a week to travel with the press corps accompanying Senator George McGovern during the 1972 Presidential campaign. She says she made daily reports on the Democratic candidate's personal and political activities.

title: They Called Me Tiger at the SinglesOnly Country Club
description: I HAD never even been to a singles bar, much less a singles country club. Moreover I was married. But there I was on my way to Chateau D'Vie, the newly established untraditional yearround country club for singles only in Spring Valley, N. Y., about an hour from New York City.

title: Cardinals Obtain Agee In a Trade With Astros
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 18 (AP)The St. Louis Cardinals obtained Tommie Agee from the Houston Astros today in a trade for Dave Campbell and a player to be named after the season ends.

title: Why the Giants Will Win
FastFood Chains Add Outlets in Prime Area
description: The national fastfood chains are expanding rapidly in New York City, moving increasingly into prime Manhattan locations after opening smaller outlets in the other boroughs.

title: A Minor Casualty in the Battle for Truth
description: PHILADELPHIAWhat is now the cliche hoist with his own petard is from Hamlet. A petard was a device filled with explosives and used to breach walls; Shakespeare's usage characterized a man destroyed by his own devices. It is a cliche that has never been properly modernized; there clearly ought to be a movement for something like spindled by his own printout.

title: CAMBODIA TROOPS SAID TO ADVANCE
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Aug. 18 (Reuters)The Cambodian military command reported today that its troops had brought all highways leading from Phnom Penh under Government control for at least 20 miles from the capital.

title: Mrs. Court Is Winner In Struggle
A gift for words and humbug
description: It is not likely that many people read Chesterton's works today. It can hardly be arguedand Dudley Barker hardly argues itthat there is much good reason why anyone should. Between 1904 and 1908, when he was in his early thirties, he produced two lively fantasiesa novel of political prophecy, The Napoleon of Notting Hill, and a spy story with a Christian allegorical meaning, The Man Who Was Thursday"; a sympathetic appreciation of Dickens's novels; and two books of essays, the first attacking his contemporaries from a Christian angle, the second an apology for his own conversion to Christianity (though not as yet to Roman Catholicism).

title: Highway Section to Open
description: ALBANY, Aug. 18 (AP)State officials announced today that a key section of the Southern Tier Expressway west of Binghamton would, be opened Aug, 30. The opening. of the 9.8 mile stretch in Tioga County will provide an uninterrupted fourlane divided highway from Harriman in Orange County to Hornell in Steuben County, distance of more than 250 miles.

title: Cocker Best In Dog Show In Maryland
description: EASTON, Md., Aug. 18Ch. Shardeloes Selena, a black cocker spaniel bitch. was the winner at the Talbot Kennel Club's 15th annual dog show today.

title: Miss Mary Taylor Landon Bride
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Aug. 18In St. Mark's Episcopal Church here this afternoon, Miss Mary Taylor Landon, a junior at Texas A &M University, was married to Robert Fergusson Barkley, who graduated from the university in May and is enrolled in the School of Veterinary Medicine there. The Rev. David Cox performed the ceremony.

title: HIGHWAY REPAIRS TO START IN FALL
description: A major overhaul of the West Side Highway, one of the most extensive since it was opened piecemeal during the nineteenthirties, will get under way early in October to arrest serious decline and alleviate dangers on the city's most troublesome major artery.

title: RICHARD STERN
description: CRESTWOOD, N.Y., Aug. 17 Richard Stern, who was until 1959 president of Colonia, Inc., in New York, American distributor's of 4711 cologne, died at his home here on Thursday. His age was 79.

title: Buoy Keeps Trace Of Water in Sound
description: MONTAUK, L. I.For the last several months, a huge, beeping buoy moored at the eastern entrance of Long Island Sound has been gathering information on the nature and activity of the Sound's estuarine waters.

title: Chess: Brazilian Wins the Interzonal By Drawing With Ljubojevic
Tuna on Menu in Nova Scotia Search
description: Nine teams will compete in the 24th International Tuna Cup matches off Wedgeport and Cape St. Mary, Nova Scotia, from Sept. 48. A strong fiveman squad from the United States includes Hugo Rutherford of Aiken, S. C., who was on the team 36 years ago in the first match and was captain of the winning United States group in 1949.

title: Orantes and Miss Evert Gain Finals
The Hangar Is Bare at Boeing
Washington Two Views: Danger, Relief
description: WASHINGTONThe day the bombs stopped falling in Cambodia, President Nixon charged that the repercussions of the cutoff forced on him by Congress could lead to a tragedy for the cause of peace.

title: Nepal to Acquire Hospitals
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, Aug. 18 (UPI)  Nepal will take over all 15 hospitals run by foreign Christian missionaries after the end of their contracts with the Government, a Health Ministry official said today.

title: I Keep Making Plans as If I Would Live Forever
description: HOWE: How is it that, after all these years, you wrote your first play?

title: Blumenthal Urges Backing In Congress For a Handgun Ban
description: An immediate ban on the sale and possession of handguns for private citizens was urged yesterday by Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal, the Liberal party candidate for Mayor.

title: Rumania Ties U.S., 11 In Davis Cup Cup Matches
description: ALAMO, Calif., Aug. 18Everything went according to form today as the United States and Rumania split the first two matches of the Davis Cup interzone final and put off the decision to Monday's final pair of singles matches, no matter how tomorrow's doubles confrontation turns out.

title: Air Force Chief Resigns As Key Minister in Chile
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 18The truckers strike that has poisoned the lite of this country went into its 24th day today with new violence and the resignation of the military officer who had been brought into the Cabinet last week as Minister of Public Works and Transport.

title: J. Edgar Hoover in Perspective
description: So far the only reputation to benefit from the Watergate hearings has been that of the late J. Edgar Hoover. Liberal columnists, conservative editorialists and Chairman Sam Ervin all seem to have reached a consensusthat if J. Edgar Hoover had had his way there would have been no plumbers, no breakin of Dr. Ellsberg's psychiatrist's office, no Watergate. The evidence is plain enough  there it is in Tom Charles Houston's memo recommending increased domestic surveillance, some of it illegal, and pointing out time and again that Everyone knowledgeable in the [intelligence] field with the exception of Mr. Hoover concurs.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The article about Cadman Towers [A Brooklyn Coop, Settling Down, Aug. 5] perpetuates the error of all media comments on this project.

title: U.S. RENTAL DEALS AID NIXON BACKERS IN BALTIMORE AREA
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18Nearly threefourths of the rent paid by the Federal Government for space leased in the Baltimore area during the Nixon Administration goes to small group of businesses associated with prominent Democrats who switched their support to President Nixon in the 1972 campaign.

title: Son Born to the Corbetts
description: A son was born July 19 to Mr. and Mrs. Andrew John Corbett Jr. of New York at the New York University Hospital. Mrs. Corbett is the former Miss Victoria A. Phillips, whose husband is with A.J. Corbett & Son, founded as steamship agents and representatives by his father. The child has been named Andrew John Corbett 3d.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: No Clues Are Found in the Murder of Boy, 7, Here
description: The police said yesterday that they had no immediate clues as they pressed their investigation in the murder of a 7yearold Lower East Side child whose slashed body was discovered on top of a tenement apartnient Friday, about an hour after he was last seen alive by his parents.

title: A Cave in Greece Yields Clues To Prehistoric Travels by Sea
description: KOILADA, Greece, Aug. 18 American archeologists in Greece have dug up evidence of the world's earliest seafaring, dating from about 75007000 B.C.at least a thousand years before sea travel was known to have been practiced.

title: City Proposes to Ban Taxi Cruising and Set Up New Cab Stands
description: About 1,000 spaces at new taxi stands would be established starting in midSeptember under a proposal, drawn up by the city's Environmental Protection Administration, that would prohibit taxi cruising in the congested midtown area.

title: Music
description: The Mostly Mozart Festival concert at Philharmonic Hall on Friday night (and repeated last night) was mostly Handel event that featured all of Handel's Water Music, which is quite a bit.

title: Bids for Bank Branches Soar
description: TRENTONA new, liberalized banking law signed earlier this month by Governer Cahill has spurred applications for 37 branches throughout the state, more than a third of them in three fastgrowing communities in. Morris, Mercer and Camden Counties.

title: About the Mets:
description: Three umpires were still doing the work of four the MetsReds series because Shag Crawford had the flu. He left the opener Friday night in the second inning. Art Williams called balls and strikes yesterday, his partners shared the bases.... Rusty Staub is still sidelined after taking cortisone injections in both hands, which have been hurting most of the season. He may return when the righthanded pitchers finally get into the series Monday. If the Western Division race gets personal, the Reds and Los Angeles Dodgers have five games left against each other in September..... The Reds, with a new stadium and a National League pennant flying over it, have drawn 1.4 million at home. With 18 games remaining in Cincinnati, they figure to break the club record of 1.8 million or even reach 2 million,

title: Princeton, Seeking Broadening of Vision, Is Taking Nontraditional Students
description: PRINCETONAmong the 4,000 undergraduates who will be registering for classes at Princeton University next month will be a handful of students who, even just a few years ago, never would have been considered for admission to this selective Ivy League institution.

title: Goss Outpoints Viruet In Forum 10Rounder
description: Sammy Goss scored an eighth round knockdown, then withstood a furious 10thround rally to hand Edwin Viruet his first defeat yesterday on a majority decision in their nationally televised junior lightweight bout at the Felt Forum.

title: Saigon Push Ends Peace For Hamlet
description: NUOC YANG, South Vietnam, Aug. 16For years the people of this tiny, remote hamlet about 40 miles north of Saigon lived at peace with the Vietcong guerrillas in the surrounding jungle.

title: New Shakespearean Acting Group Stresses Innovation
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I.The grunts, groans, whistles sighs, strains of muhmuhmuhmuh, and chants of Pain, pain go away, Come again another day that issue from various rehearsal halls these days are not the stuff Shakespeare is usually made of.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON Geoffrey H. Moore, who. was the head of the Bureau of Labor Statistics during the first Nixon Administration, has written a little booklet containing four essays in which he suggests some new ways of looking at economic statistics, particularly the Unemployment statistics. The booklet, entitled How Full Ls Full Employment? has been published by the American Enterprise Institute for Public Policy Research.

title: Afro Music: Farewell to The Source
description: THE music of Africa is acknowledged as The Source by many AfroAmerican musicians. It is also a major influence throughout the Caribbean and Latin America. But in Africa itself traditional music is vanishing. Radio and recordings now disseminate both American and African popular styles across the continent; Many village musicians listen to the latest dance rhythms from the studios of Nairobi or Johannesburg rather than to the orally transmitted musicof their ancestors.

title: $2.75Million Is Awarded To Dearborn Fire Captain
description: DETROIT, Aug. 18 (AP)A Dearborn Fire Department captain and, his wife have been awarded 12.75million for injuries he sustained while fighting a ,fire in 1971 at a Ford Motor Company plant.

title: Pop
description: THOUGH Jethro Tull is hardly a household word like Alice Cooper, this group is one of England's leading rock exports, bursting the seams of giant arenas around the country ever since the success of their fourth LP, Aqualung, released two years ago. On August 28 and 29 Jethro Tull plants itself in Madison Square Garden and then moves out to the Nassau Coliseum on August 31 and September 1. This current summer American tour coincides with the release of Tull's seventh album, A Passion Play (Chrysalis Records CHR 1040), which shot up the charts almost as fast as a speeding Beatle.

title: Betty Is Busy Figuring Out Betty
description: IT was a very still, very peaceful morning in Marlboro, Vt. The sun shone, the hills rolled, the birds and insects sang, and from afar the musicians gathered at the Marlboro Music Festival were heard practicing or rehearsing, or seen walking on the soft grasses, their instruments or scores tucked casually under their arms. Yes, there was peace, there was serenity, there was an air of communal intimacy and then, there was Betty Allenand it was a whole other scene.

title: Miss Abby Naitove Bride of Peter Watt
description: Miss Abby Naitove, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Naitove of Hanover, N. H., was married yesterday in Fulmer, Buckinghamshire, England, to Peter Stuart Watt, son of Squadron Leader W. W. Watt,. R.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Watt of Peterborough England. The Rev. William W. J. Taylor performed the Anglican ceremony in the Fulmer Village Church.

title: Cahill Denies Knowledge Of Nixon Fund Transfer
description: TRENTON, Aug. 18 (UPI)Governor Cahill denied today any knowleddge of a transfer of campaign funds left over from President Nixon's 1968 cmapaign to held the Governor in his 1969 campaign.

title: U.S. Shortages Peril World Food Aid Plan
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 18In Colombia's poorest rural areas, a schoollunch program faces shutdown. Elderly patients in a hospital in Haiti will have to go without an extra daily hot meal. And in India, the promising development of a new food for babies is threatened.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The police charged the manager of the Sahara Hotel, at 201 East 14th Street, with homicide after finding his wife's body on the roof. They said Umberto Rivera, 34, the manager, said he shot Pedra, his wife, is their apartment Friday night when she threatened him with a knife. hotel night clerk, Alfredo Medina, 32, was accused of aiding in the homicide by helping carry the body to the roof... At another hotel, the St. George in Brooklyn Heights, 56yearold waitress was found dead with a knife in her chest. She was tentatively identified as Mrs. Rella Thompson.... An offduty corrections officer, Arthur Sosa, 30, was critically wounded in an earlymorning shooting during a dispute in the Boss Bar, 135 East 125th Street. His assailant fled.... In the Bronx, a bullet ripped through the siren of a police car at West 166th Street and Ogden Avenue, responding to a report of shots fired shortly after midnight Friday. A search turned no suspects.

title: AMBULANCE AID FOUND DEFICIENT
description: Many of the patients pronounced dead on arrival at hospitals in the suburban areas around New York City and in wide areas across the United States could have been saved with an improvement in the ambulance systems, according to national surveys and medical and health officials.

title: 73 DEFICIT FEARED BY FRESH AIR FUND
description: Inflation and a lower level of contributions is causing officials of the Fresh Air Fund to project a deficit by year's end, and this may mean a cutback in its programs for the city's poor youngsters next yearthe first such cutback in the fund's 96year history.

title: Natural Childbirth Is a Topic at Moscow Parley
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 18Although natural painless childbirth is encouraged in the Soviet Union, the method has been virtually ignored at a world congress of obstetrics and gynecology here this week.

title: Brooklyn Preparing For Bicentennial
description: Brooklyn's past will come alive again as plans move ahead for the country's bicentennial celebration in 1976. Playing a leading role in aiding borough groups in the plans is the Long Island Historical Society, which also is working on its own programs to mark the bicentennial.

title: Woman Pilots Plan Center
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 18 (AP)The NinetyNines, an organization of women airplane pilots, has announced plans for construction of a $100,000 international headquarters here. Elizabeth Sewell of Oklahoma City, international president, said Thursday that the headquarters would be built at Will Rogers World Airport.

title: Apathy Kills Free Dental Care
description: JERSEY CITYA federally financed program offering free dental care to 1,300 high school students in the Model Cities neighborhood here will be terminated at the end of the month for lack of patients.

title: ISRAEL REJECTS PRODDING BY U.S.
description: Foreign Minister Abbe Eban, asserting that Israel's policy has been a success, has scoffed at State Department suggestions that Israel produce some fresh ideas to break the Middle East stalemate.

title: Frances Seek  To Help Migrants
description: ELMER  From May through October, more than 5,000 men and boys, all of whom have fled poverty and hunger in Puerto Rico, labor from dawn to late afternoon, often seven days a week, in the fields of Southern New Jersey.

title: Atoms Top Metros to Gain Final
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 18 (AP)  The Philadelphia Atoms defeated the Toronto Metros, 3.0, tonight to gain the finals of the North American Soccer League playoffs.

title: New World Awaits Canoeists On Ramapo
description: POMPTON LAKES  The Ramapo River traverses some remarkably picturesque and unspoiled country as it winds through Bergen County on its southerly course from Mahwah to Pompton Lakes. This stretch of water, alinough at the very back door of the county's congested edroom communities, nevertheless offers an attractive and varied float for the canoeist, be he novice or expart

title: Beinecke and the Green Stamps
description: Walter Beinecke Jr. is a businessman who is used getting his own way, but there are some things the 55yearold entrepreneur cannot control.

title: Will We Ever See The Bacchae as Euripides Wrote It?
description: LONDON.

title: Deborah King Plans Fall Nuptials
description: BEDFORD, N. Y., Aug. 18 Miss Deborah Angell King, a licensed skydiver and former national junior doubles tennis champion, plans to be married Oct. 20 to Mariano Botet, who is in charge of the circulation department at the John Jay College Of Criminal Justice in New York. The ceremony will take place in St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Mount Kisco.

title: A New Way to Beat Those Turnpike Tolls You Drive on the River.
description: A Volkswagen commercial aired frequently this yeas shows a man sitting calmly behind the wheel of his cal as it floats on a quiet lake. A group of Volkswagen owners in Akron, Ohio, probably taking a cue from the commercial, have actually attached propellers to theircars and are racing them on lakesand rivers this summer.

title: Five years after the Czech invasion
description: Five years ago the peoples of Eastern Europe, particularly the youth, looked on enviously at the way the Czechoslovaks were liberalizing their lives. Before, nobody had seen a Communist Government earning broad popularity. They saw an outspoken, uncensored press, radio and TV, with huge readership and viewer ratings. They saw a population of 16 million openly discussing social and political problems, a party that attracted the voluntary membership of those who believed in Alexander Dubcek's dictum of Communism with human face. It was a time of new hope and confidence in the future, not only for the Czechs and Slovaks but for others within the Soviet sphere of influence. And, precisely for that reason, the Soviets had to halt the process.

title: Late Listings for Today's TV
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2.

title: Kathryn Hubshman Is Bride Of M Y. Meganck in France
description: Miss Kathryn Leigh Hubshman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry M. Hubshman Jr. of New York and Mamaroneck, N. Y., was married yestrday in Antibes, France, to Michael Yvon Meganck, son of Mr. and Mrs, Marcel Meganck of Cap d'Antibes.

title: Indian Dances by Whites Halted After Iowa Protest
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 18 Twenty Mesquakie Indian singers and dancers from the Tama, Iowa, reservation were performing at the Iowa State Fair today after successfully protesting the performance of Indian dances by a local Boy Scout troop yesterday as the fair opened a 10day run.

title: 100,000 Driven From Homes By Floods in Northern Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY. Aug. 18 (Reuters) About 100,000 people have been forced. from their homes by flood waters in northern and central Mexico where flood damage continued to mount today. At least 20 people have died and nearly 50 are missing.

title: ... And beating bullies
description: It is almost the unwritten law: into every small boy's life must enter the local bully, with the threat of a clobbering so bad he'll remember it for the rest of his life  if heti lucky enough to survive. And that's the way it is with the hapless hero of Betsy Byars's new book.

title: Iowan Shoots a 489 To Win Rifle Crown
description: CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 18 (AP)Navy Petty Officer Thomas Treinen of Remsen, Iowa, won the national trophy individual rifle match today with a score of 489 of a possible 500 points. Army Sgt. 1st Cl. Martin Edmondson of Columbus, Ga., and Marine M/Sgt. Russell Martin of Hartford, Conn., finished a point behind. Their tie will he broken by the referee after a study of their cards.

title: Longtime Californ A Documentary Study of an American Chinatown. By Victor G. and Brett De Bary Nee. 411 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $10.
description: Let us collage a typical American view of Chinatown everywhere, particularly San Francisco's quintessential version. First of all, good cheap food"Let's eat Chink tonight"and then there is the legend of that marvelous tight family structure of old highschool sociology: No crime, isn't it great? Then a bit of reality: kids hiking up a slope from Portsmouth Square, ripping off every aerial on every parked car. This doesn't quite square with the myth, of course, unless you take it back to the tong wars. And then an occasional sturdy fact: Chinatown San Francisco is one of the densest, poorest slums in America  tuberculosis, sweatshops and crime  at the same time as it is a tourist magnet and a plaque on a wall on Grant, the main street, celebrates the locale of a Ross Huntfilm, Flower Drum

title: Correction
description: Due to difficulties in cable transmission there was a serious omission in an article on the current Soviet literary scene by Hedrick Smith, in the Book Review of July 22.

title: Jacksonville Cited For Model System
description: Jacksonville, Fla., whose population of 500,000 is scattered over 850 square miles, has in the last five years developed one of the most advanced ambulance networks in the nation.

title: Joanne Beers Is Wed to Robert Pierro
description: GREENLAWN, L. I., Aug. 18Miss Joanne Ellen Beers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Samuel Beers Jr., was married this morning to Robert Michael Pierro, son Of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Joseph Pierro of Waterbury, Conn.

title: 325 in Boxing Tourney
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 18 (UPI)The largest boxing competition in the nation, the sixth annual Ohio State Fair amateur tournament, will be held here Wednesday through Saturday with more than 325 boxers, ranging in age from 10 to 25, entered in the event.

title: Fair Harbor Fire Department Responds to Alarms by Foot, Bike and Boat
description: FAIR HARBOR, L. L,When the fire siren goes off out here, strange things happen. Scantily clad men and women leap from sand dunes and patio, jump into dungarees and boots, grab brooms and shovels and race off to fight the blaze on bicycles.

title: A Car Restorer Polishes His Operation
description: JAMESBURG  Ten years ago, Earl Lewis took out small bank loan, added $6,000 in savings and opened an antique automobile restoration shop in a converted chicken coop next to his home.

title: A mother to the Nazis, a husband to the Communists
description: This is an extraordinary memoir, so heartbreaking that I have reread it for months, unable to rise to the business of reviewing less a book than a life repeatedly outraged by the worst totalitarians in Europe. Yet it is written with so much quiet respect for the minutiae of justice and truth that one does not know where and how to specify Heda Kovaly's splendidness as a human being. We, the bystanders, are lucky to have such survivors to teach us our only future  if we are to survive.

title: Expected Yield From OTB In City Cut by $20Million
description: The city and state will get $20million less than expected from offtrack betting on horses in the city for the fiscal year that ended June 30, according to an audit released yesterday by State Controller Arthur Levitt.

title: Beating governments...; Theodore Jonathan Wainwright Is Going to Bomb the Pentagon A Comic Novella by Louis Phillips. 115 pp. Englewood Cliffs, N..J.: PrenticeHall. $4.95. (Ages 12 and Up)
description: There is no way Theodore Jonathan Wainwright is going to win.

title: Mrs. Anne Botsford Remarried
description: NEW VERNON, N. J., Aug. 18The marriage of Mrs. Anne Winston Knauth Botsford to Hendrik Bernard Van Rensselaer Jr. took place here this afternoon at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Van Rensselaer of New Vernon and Lawrence, L. I. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Pickett Knauth of New York and the late Oliver Dixwell Knauth of Washington, who was a political writer.

title: Tripoli Says Hijacker Is a Mentally Ill Libyan
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 18 (AP)Libya said today that the Arab who hijacked a Lebanese airliner to Israel Thursday was a mentally unbalanced Libyan citizen. This refuted widespread Arab claims that he was an Israeli agent.

title: Women's Golf Won By Semple
PARAGUAY CLOSES A PART OF BORDER
description: ASUNCION, Paraguay, Aug. 18, (Reuters)The Paraguayan Government has closed the border with Argentina, the police announced today.

title: Numismatics
description: HISTORIC American customhouses are to be commemorated in a series of 10 medals struck by the Bureau of the Mint in cooperation with the U. S. Customs Service. According to Vernon D. Acme, Commissioner of Customs, This medal program is part of our contribution to the Bicentennial celebration and is in keeping with Federal, efforts to accelerate historic preservation by identifying landmarks in advance of the main observance in 1976. And we also hope to focus the public's attention On the vital role that the Customs Service played as a financial mainstay of the young Republic. Customhouses, he added, have deep roots in American history.

title: Ogden Fell Weds Nancy Briggs
description: NARRAGANSETT, R, Aug. 18Miss Nancy G Briggs was married here th afternoon to Ogden Mills Fe, composer, pianist and class cal guitarist, son of Mr. an Mrs. Philip S. P. Fell of Boc Grande, Fla., and Centr Island, Oyster Bay, L I.

title: The Background
Starring crisis
description: The tart, winey taste and heady aroma of black currants is captured in crme de cassis, the winedark liqueur from Dijon. Often used to flavor ices and sherbets, crme de cassis has become popular as an ingredient in yin Blanc cassis, now commonly known as Kir. The aperitif was renamed for Canon Felix Kir, who was a member of the Resistance during World War II and later Mayor of Dijon.

title: Wendy Schulhof to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph Buck Schulhof of Kings Point, L.I., and Sugar Hill, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Wendy Joan Schulhof, to Stanley Lewis Silverman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Silverman of Woodmere, L.I. A September wedding is planned.

title: Sunday Observer
description: All these White House people must come from the same mold. Nixonites, Johnsonians, Kennedymenall the same. wonder if there is a secret factory somewhere, hidden in Marseilles like the heroin mills, a place where cunning Frenchmen manufacture interchangeable White House staff members.

title: Campsite Brochure Prepared by State
description: TRENTONBrochures describing public and private campsites and outstanding tourist attractions throughout the state are available free from the Department of Labor and Industry.

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: ART

title: CHARLES GOODE DIES; MATH TEACHER, 66
description: VALLEY STREAM, L.I., Aug. 18Charles J. Goode, mathematics coordinator of School District 14 in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and a teacher for 40 years, died today in Mercy Hospital, Rockville Centre. He was 66 years old and lived here.

title: Arlington County, Va., Tops List on Income
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UPI)Arlington County, Va., populated by Federal employes, had the highest per capita income in the nation in 1970, $5,446, according to a Census Bureau report released yesterday.

title: Park Service Making It Tougher for Motorists
description: GRAND CANYON NATIONAL PARKMost arrive a few hours before sunset automobiles, station wagons, camper trucks and motor homes towing jeeps and dune buggies, their license plates from California, Illinois, North Carolina and every other state.

title: The Memoirs of a Reluctant Stowaway
description: YOU mean, ma'am, the British immigration agent asked incredulously that you sailed on this vessel nine entire days from New York to Southampton with nothing more than what you're standing in?

title: 10Inch Snows in Canada
description: FORT ST. JOHN, B. C., Aug. 18 (AP)The first August) snow in 18 years and winds of up to 50 miles an hour have caused extensive damage to crops throughout British Columhia's Peace River region, about 500 miles northeast of Vancouver. Up to 10 inches of snow have fallen here since Thursday.

title: Kennedy Road, Shoemaker Up, Wins at Del Mar
description: DEL MAR, Calif., Aug. 18 (AP)Bill Shoemaker and Kennedy Road teamed successfully for the third consecutive time today to capture the $31,750 Cabrillo Mandicap in track record time at Del Mar Race Course. Kennedy Road, the 51yearold who captured the rich Hollywood Gold Cup at Hollywood Park earlier this year, was the prohibitive favorite in the short field of four older horses. He defeated Kentuckian by nearly four lengths and Imaginative was another six lengths behind.

title: Philippe Second for Equipe de France
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 18 (AP)Marcel Philippe, Who tried out for the American Olympic squad last year, won a silver medal for France at the World University Games today and said with a heavy New York accent, Tres, tree content.

title: Unbeaten Licata Will Fight Vinales
description: BOSTON, Aug. 18 (AP)An undefeated middleweight, Tony Licata of New, Orleans, will fight Luis Vineles of Puerto Rico, in Boston Garden Sept. 10.

title: Bonanno Jr. Surrenders
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Aug. 18 (AP)Joseph Bonanno Jr., son of Joseph Bonanno, the retired underworld figure, surrendered to Federal authorities yesterday to begin a fiveyear prison term for extortion.

title: Challenger II Wins In Atlantic Class
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., Aug. 18Norman Peck's Challenger II from Niantic Bay, Conn., finished fourth in today's final race to capture the Atlantic Class national championship on Long Island Sount.

title: Tomatoes Ripened on the Vine Are in Abundance on the Island
description: Fresh, locally grown produce is irresistible and when it comes to corn and tomatoes, it is essential. The plastictasting versions that are available most of the year should be shunned.

title: Trade News
description: The Henry Hudson Hotel on West 57th Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues has leased most of its groundfloor space to D'Agostino's Supermarkets.

title: Women Are in Forefront Of Chile's Trucker Strike
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 18 Chilean women have been liberated for decades, and this week they demonstrated it dramatically by taking over the cause of some 45,000 striking truckowners.

title: Kim Kidnapping
description: SEOULShortly after. 10 P.M. last Monday, Kim Dae Jung limped up a narrow street to his Seoul home, rang the bell at the gate and fell into the arms of his distraught wife. For the South Korean opposition candidate in the 1971 Presidential election it was the end of an ordeal that had begun the previous Wednesday when he was abducted in broad daylight by six Koreans from a hotel in Tokyo. In the 129.hours that followed, Mr. Kim was beaten, trussed up and spirited by car, boat and car again to an alley near his home and released.

title: Bridge
description: If Lewis Carroll's Alice had been a bridge player, she would probably have been a good one because she had a remarkable facility to adapt to unfamiliar situations. When offered eggs at Fivepence farthing for orietwopence for two she simply took out her purse to buy one, remarking in a surprised tone: Then two are cheaper than one.

title: Traning Grant Cut Held peril to Medical Research
description: ASPEN, Colo., Aug. 18The future of medical research in the United States is being threatened by recent cutbacks in Federal training grants for young scientists, according to students, faculty members and at least one Government official who attended a twoweek conference that ended yesterday at the Given Institute of Pathobiology here.

title: General Bradley Better
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 18 (UPI)Gen.Omar N. Bradley's condition was still serious today, but his steady improvement since emergency surgery has allowed the Army to discontinue daily medical bulletins. He is 80. years old.

title: David's Ruler Triumphs
description: CANANDAIGUA, N. Y., Aug. 18 (AP)David's Ruler, a 5yearold bay, gelding, won the feature race at Finger Lakes today. The winner covered the mile and 70 yards in 1:49 2/5 and returned $9.40 to win.

title: Bolivia Reports Foiling AntiGovernment Plot
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 18 (Reuters)  Government sources said today that security forces had smashed a plot to overthrow President Hugo Banzer Suarez.

title: Pearl River Retains Its Country Aura
description: PEARL RIVER, N, Y.Just across the northern border of Bergen County lies the community of Pearl River, a hamlet that has no local government and is dependent on Orangetown for services and management. Yet, the 10,700 residents are happy with their lot and insist that a country atmosphere pro veils, despite & rapid growth in recent Tears. The wide streets be lie the age of the communityit is more than a century oldand the old appearance of some buildings in the main shopping area veils the fact that most of the houses were constructed in recent years

title: Courses Set on Aiding Young
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  A threecourse program for persons working with children in institutional settings, or interested in finding employment in this field, will be offered this fall by Rutgers University's Extension Center in Social Welfare.

title: SAM SETTING OUT REVISED POLICIES
description: CAIRO, Aug. 18President Anwar elSadat has begun to give basically new directions to Egyptian foreign and domestic policies.

title: VOUCHER TEST SET IN NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: CONCORD, N. H., Aug. 18The controversial voucher method of financing education has received official sanction here for a test by a 4to3 vote of the state's Board of Education.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: The fashion industry has gone into high gear with shipments for the fall season. Merchandise valued in the hundreds of millions of dollars is moving from factories to chain, discount and department stores for what should be an outstanding season.

title: Mary Glasson Is Bride of Charles Thompson
description: WAKEFIELD, R. I., Aug. 18 Miss Mary Elizabeth Glasson and Charles Todd Thompson, seniors at St. Lawrence University, were married here this afternoon. The Rev. George Milne, minister of the First Church of Christ in Woodbridge, Conn., performed the ceremony at the Larchwood Inn.

title: Big Meeting in Peking Stirs Speculation That Party Congress May Have Begun
description: PEKING, Aug. 18 (Reuters)A large number of official vehicles was parked outside the Great Hall of the People here today for the second successive day, indicating an unusually largescale assembly inside.

title: Soviet Athletes Dominate; Jewish Fans Are Barred
U.S. Reviewing a Customs Regulation That Could Cost Two Airlines Millions
description: The Treasury Department is planning to soften a Customs Service regulation that, if left unchanged, might cost Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines millions of dollars in duties and penalties, according to Federal Government sources.

title: Leonard Koppett
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 18Within the baseball profession, it is accepted that pitchers, as a class, do more thinking about the game than other players. because, as Roger Craig once pointed out; we have to.

title: Survive!
description: It was a superb catastrophe. Wellstructured. Except perhaps for romantic interestan ingenue saved from frostbite by judicious male body heatsit had a Hollywood shape: grace and sensationalism; dull endurance and flashy heroics. Clay Blair Jr.'s readymix paperback, Survive!, won't be the only account. Piers Paul Read, for one, has been commissioned to do an authorized account of last October's Andes plane crash and the 16 apprentice cannibal survivors. We have our ambulance chasers. Understandable enough, what with Tom Wolfe as the bright apologist of corruption. I keep hoping someone will Hijack! my Short Line Bus or that a convenient Army of the Night will bivouac near Blooming Grove, N. Y.

title: Act IV, Scene 2
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18What we are witnessing in the Watergate drama is the slow, agonizing fall from power of an Administration.

title: Francis Michael Leta Fiance Of Miss Frances Jane Shattuck
description: DORSET, Vt., Aug. 18 Miss Frances Jane Shattuck, a greatgranddaughter of the late Frank G. Shattuck, founder of the Frank G. Shattuck Co., colectionery manufacturers and restaurant chain under the name of Schrafft's, plans to be married here Oct. 6 to Francis Michael Leta.

title: Safe Races Continue as Main Issue
description: The United States Auto Club, shocked into action by the disasters. of this year's Indianapolis 500, has started an allout effort to prevent fires in wrecked racing cars. The club also has begun studying methods to reduce speeds in its Champ onship Division. Those were the principal points covered in a meetingof the board of directors last weekin the club's head quarters at Indianapolis. It was the board's second meeting in less than three months.

title: Refuge Getting A Deer Hunt
description: TRENTONThe New Jersey Fish and Game Council has approved a sixday deer hunt in the Great Swamp National Wildlife Refuge in Morris County, despite strong opposition from local residents and environmental groups and the threat of continued legal action by the Humane Society of the United States.

title: Sinyaysky Book Due
description: PARIS, Aug. 18 (UPI)Andre Sinyaysky, the Soviet writer now in self exile in France, wrote a nonpolitical book during his nearly six years in Soviet prison camps and it will be published in London in six weeks, the Publisher said Saturday.

title: RoundtheClock Service Is Fighting Child Abuse
description: TRENTON  The rapidly growing problem of child abuse in New Jersey has prompted the Cahill administration to create a new 24hour service to protect children and counsel troubled parents.

title: Victoria Anne Oleri Is Married
description: CLOSTER, N. J., Aug. 18Miss Victoria Anne Oleri and Jeffrey Clarke Bellows, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elbert G. Bellows of Haworth, were married here this afternoon in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

title: The Region
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey was officially delighted. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said it was a very important beginning. The TriState Regional Planning Commission said it was quite encouraging. The State of New York said it fit snugly, like the final piece of a jigsaw puzzle, with Governor Rockefeller's proposed Transportation Bond Issue. New Jersey said it will advance alreadyplanned mass transit projects. Connecticut said it will allow interstate highway _projects to be dumped in favor of buses and commuter trains.

title: Items in Kennedy Death Are Going to Archives
description: DALLAS, Aug. 18 (AP)Equipment used by doctors of Parkland Hospital as they worked to try to save the life of President Kennedy is going to the National Archives. The equipment will be preserved for its historical value. One day it may be placed on public display.

title: Best Seller List
description: This analysis is based on reports obtained from more than 250 bookstores in 110 communities of the United States. The figures in the righthand column do not necessarily represent consecutive appearances.

title: ADVERTISING POINT OF VIEW
description: Segmentation, fragmentation, optimization, gap identificationthese are a few of the phrases in vogue as managers attempt to grab, shake 'and subdue the marketing problem of the moment.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Like the road to hell, the pathway to inflation is beautifully paved with good intentions,

title: Child to Mrs. Pauley
description: A daughter was born to Roger Andrew Pauley, Republican Counsel for the House of Representatives Judiciary Committee, and Mrs. Pauley of Arlington, Va., on July 29 in the Washington Hospital Center.

title: The New York Times Book Review New and Recommended
description: NINETYTWO IN THE SHADE, by Thomas McGuane,, (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $6.95.) The author of The Sporting Club and The Bushwhacked Piano once again on the trail of his obsessional theme, the perilous testing of man against man, this time pitting a young neophyte against a veteran guide in the embrace of inevitable death. SMALL CHANGES, by Marge Mercy. (Doubleday, $8.95.) A rambling story of two women, one working class who finds the ideal marriage living hell, the other a woman of independent resources trapped in middleclass version of the same nightmare, set against the backdrop of the 1960's.

title: The Week Ahead in Sports
description: The Yankees, in the middle of twoweek road trip, face the Kansas City Royals tomorrow through Wednesday in three night games. Then they travel to Oakland for night game Friday and a day game Saturday with the A's. WPIXTV (Channel 11) and WMCA Radio will carry the games.

title: Rockaway Neighborhood Group Gets $750,000 to Spend
description: Nine capital projects have been approved for the Rockaways under an experimental program that permits neighborhood government offices to appropriate funds as they See fit.

title: Annihilate Em Takes Travers Before 32,023
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 18Ron Turcotte rode the winner of the Travers today, as expected. But his vehicle to success in America's oldest continually run stakes event was Mrs. Patricia Blass's Annihilate Em, and not Secretariat.

title: Ye Are of More Value Than Many Sparrows Matt. 10:31
description: RAHWAY, N. J., Aug. 18 (UPI)With a solemn procession and resounding eulogy, a bird found dead in the basement of the Trinity Methodist Church here was buried today in a little, park in the church's parking lot.

title: Textile Negotiator Named
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Aug. 18 (UPI)President Nixon today nominated Anthony J. Jurich, the American negotiator on textile matters with Japan, for the rank of minister. Mr. Jurich, 45 years old, is a senior adviser on the President's Council on International Economic Policy.

title: A Dog Can Be Dumb and Best in Show, Owner Says
description: In the show ring, a dog can be absolutely stupid, but as long as he's beautiful, he can win points and become a champion, said Mrs. Joe Longo. In obedience, on the other hand, a dog must work or get nothing. It's brains, not beauty, that counts.

title: Why the Jets Will Win
Out of the water and down from the mountains
description: It is billed as an adventure story, but it if, more than that. It is a revealing, if perhaps unwitting, study of character. In fact, there would have been no narrative to tell, had it not been for the stubborn determination of Dougal Robertson not just to survive but to overcome what he calls the savage sea.

title: Right Stand by Bonn
description: More than a year after activation of the fourpower Berlin agreement, the Communist regimes of Eastern Europe are still trying to weaken the vital links between West Berlin and West Germany. Thus, East Germany again threatening to impede traffic on the roads through its territory that connect Berlin with the Federal Republic. And Czechoslovakia balks at agreeing that Bonn may represent West Berlin in consular and diplomatic business.

title: VOUCHER TEST SET IN NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: CONCORD, N. H., Aug. 18The controversial voucher method of financing education has received official sanction here for a test by a 4to3 vote of the state's Board of Education.

title: Tennis Courts Are Being Resurfaced
description: Tennis players were both joyful and skeptical the other day as the Parks Department began resurfacing the public courts at Kissena Park in Flushing, Queens, as part of a citywide program.

title: 72 Windtex Triumphs at Liberty Bell
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 18 (AP)Windtex, ridden by Mike Hole, rallied in the final onesixteenth of a mile rind won the $100,000 ?? Handicap at Liberty Ball Park today by 1 lengths Rastafarian, a long shot, was second.

title: Education
description: On a recent morning, while on vacation, Curt Reis, a New York banker, and his wife Nancy sat in a lecture hall at Cornell University and listened to Max Black, professor of philosophy, expound on the role of language and speech as a basis for human relationships. At the same time, in separate parts of the campus, one of their daughters was learning how to videotape, another was on an ecology walk, and their 10yearold son was busy with arts and crafts.

title: Reflections of Ruckelshaus
description: Last April 27, with the Watergate scandal breaking around him, President Nixon accepted the resignation of L. Patrick Gray 3d as acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation; the same day, he named William D. Ruckelshaus to take over the controversial bureau as interim director. The choice was a, logical one, given the President's shrinking supply of capable officals who remained untainted by the widening scandal. For as chief of the Environmental Protection Agency, a post he took in 1970 when Congress created that agency, Mr. Ruckelshaus established a record for independence and integrity and was admired by Democrats and Republicans alike.

title: ... and Many Other Things
description: GRASSHOPPER JUNCTION, Ariz.If there is one thing that is cherished by an average Americanperhaps even more than his beloved television setit is his summer vacation. Summer is that delicious time of year when thoughts turn to such compelling subjects as how close to noon he should get up, which bait to use for what fish, and which motel (Htd pool Air Cond Fones) he should patronize tonight.

title: Elegance on the Riviera: Dinner, Then Champagne by the Pool
description: CAP D'AIL, France  Mrs. Neville Berry's dinner took place the night after the Golden Ball at nearby Cap Martin earlier this month, but the timing was incidental.

title: Foreign Policy Stirs Storms in France
description: PARIS, Aug. 18French lead ers have recently indulged in some harsh exchanges on basic foreign policy, upsetting allies and surprising a public accustomed to an August vacation armistice on affairs of state and politics.

title: BlackLatin Fete in Trenton
description: TRENTON  Jazz, soul, rock and gospel music will echo through Cadwalader Park next weekend as part of the second annual Black and Latin Cultural Festival.

title: FRANCOIS BORIEU OF SKI FAME DIES
description: NICE, France, Aug. 18 (AP) Francois Bonlieu, winner of the giant slalom gold medal. at the 1964 Winter Olympics, died today in a local hospital after suffering a skull fracture. He was 36 years old.

title: Dance
Nassau Program to Aid Women Inmates at Jail
Delta Queen Exempted From Fire Safety Rule
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP)  A. bill exempting the steamboat Delta Queen from fire safety regulations for five more years was signed today by President Nixon.

title: Mrs. Graves Has Child
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 18A daughter was born July 25 to Mr. and Mrs. Willian B. Graves of Shorewood at the Columbia Hospital here.

title: Their Mates and Lost Their Memberships
description: There's no substitute for physical exercise, says Miller as we pass the weight room. The only thing you're lighter after you go to those fatty places is your money.

title: Donna Kendall, I. J. P. Warren Are Wed Here
description: The Community Church of New York was the setting here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Donna

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Journey's End
description: MARGAREE FORKS, Nova Scotia  When the delicateyellow blossoms of evening primroses began to open tothe night air and swallows ceased their insect patrol over the Margaree River's Seal Pool, I dissassembled my flyrod with reluctance, knowing I would have to leave Cape Breton Island and Nova Scotia without a salmon.

title: Future Events
description: Renewal and Eschewal Aug. 19If you're out in the Hamptons today you can be in on a new thing. The Ladies Village Improvement Society of East Hampton is adding to its continual pullulation of activities by Inaugurating what it hopes will become an annual event, its first horse show, which will be held at Ivan Topping's Swan Creek Farms in Bridgehampton. Not only are they hoping to rake in the chips, they are also determined on a renascence of elegance and total eschewal of the ultracasual. Those who haVe paid $12.50 will have a reserved seat in the ringside yellow and white marquee, enjoy a luncheon served on china and in crystal, (no nonbiodegradable, antiecological messmakers) and have their cars parked, too. Formal equestrian attire is a formal requisite and with 74 classes, how classy can you get? General admission is $1, 50 cents for 12's down

title: Warner Babcock Weds Patricia Joyner
description: DURHAM, N.C., Aug. 18Miss Patricia Anne Joyner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charlie Exum Joyner of Snow Hill, was married here this morning to Warner King Babcock, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Nash Babcock of Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: Drum Beater For Commodities
description: These are days of growing fear in the nation's commodity markets. The fear is not of falling prices or slow trading volume. And it has been many years since a commodity brokerage house has failed. Indeed, commodity business is shattering records every day.

title: Janet Ruth Wood Is Married To William. Graham Brown Jr.
description: TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Aug. 18Miss Janet Ruth Wood, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ernest Harvey Wood Jr. of Ridgewood, N. J., and William Graham Brown Jr., son of Mrs. Franklin Ferguson of Mount Lebanon, Pa., and William Graham Brown of Manasquan, N. J., were married here this afternoon.

title: What's Opened At the Movies?
description: AMERICAN GRAFFITI, directed by George Lucas from a screenplay by Gloria Katz, Willard Huyck and Lucas, got 15 favorable reviews (Roger Greenspun, Times; Kathleen Carroll, News; Archer Winsten, Post; Rex Reed, News; Joseph Gelmis, Newsday; Bernard Drew, Gannett News Service; Leonard Harris, WCBSTV; Gene Shalit, NBC; Paul D. Zimmerman, Newsweek; John Simon, New Leader; Penelope Gilliatt, New Yorker; Chris Chase, New York; William Wolf, Cue; Hollis Alpert, Saturday Review/ World; Jay Cocks, Time) and 2 mixed (Howard Kissel, Women's Wear; Frances Taylor, Newhouse

title: Fred Offenhauser Dies at 85; Built the Famed Racing Engine
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 18 (AP)  Fred Offenhauser, one of the most famous names in automobile racing history, died yesterday at the age of 85.

title: Miss Patricia Anne Henning Married to David W. Cochran
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 18Miss Patricia Anne Henning and David William Cochran were married this afternoon in the Garden City Community (Congregational) Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John A. Mitchell of St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Wellesley, Mass., and the Rev. Ellsworth L. Richardson, retired minister of the Laguna Beach (Calif.) Congregational Church, godfather of the bride.

title: Regatta Is Canceled
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 18Lack of wind canceled today's Cow Bay.area, Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound competition, conducted by the Port Washington Yacht Club.

title: Foster to Risk His Title Against Fourie Tuesday
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Aug. 18 ((UPI)Bob Foster, who has knocked out nine of 10 challengers for his world lightheavyweight title, meets Pierre Fourie, a smooth boxer who has been floored only once, for the title here Tuesday night.

title: Calendar of Upcoming Horse Show Events
description: Today  Monmouth County, Freehold showgrounds, East Freehold Road, Freehold, N. J. Championships in all divisions. 8:30 A.M.
