CITY PATROL CARS 50% UNDERMANNED DURING EVERY DAY
description: Nearly half of the available patrol cars in the city are unmanned every day. And, say high police officials, that fact can be viewed two ways:

title: Idaho Cattle Town Delays Barbecue, 38Year Tradition
description: MACKAY, Idaho, Aug. 18This is cattle countrywide, dry, spacious land, rolling and covered with sagebrush and grass. In this part of central Idaho cows outnumber people by more than seven to one.

title: The Economy
Death Penalty May Emerge as Campaign Issue
description: TRENTONDespite a recommendation by the state's Capital Punishment Study Commission that the Legislature put off any action that would restore the death penalty in New Jersey, the Assembly Judiciary Committee has scheduled a public hearing next month on a Senateapproved bill that would reinstate that penalty.

title: Bianda's 3 Field Goals Help Raiders Defeat Rams
Herewith: Histants, Insthists, Histrets
description: ITHACA, N.Y.With Norman Mailer, Mary McCarthy, and numerous other authors attending the Ervin committee hearings, we can expect an outpouring of journalistic histories of the Watergate affair to appear in another year or two. That expectation prompts one to reflect upon Watergate in wider historical perspective; and John Ehrlichman's Federalese references to memcons (memoranda of conversations) may cause some to do so in terms of histants (historical antecedents), insthists (instant histories), and histrets (historical retrospectives).

title: Bear Kicks Get 99 Tie With Miami
Return to Reality, 8 to 1, Wins on Monmouth Turf
Tufts Gets Federal Grant
description: MEDFORD, Mass., Aug. 18 (AP)Tufts University says it has received a Federal grant of $39,500 to train social studies teachers for a program to reduce adolescent crinminal behavior in grades six through 10. The grant, from the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration, goes to Tufts Filene Center for Citizenship and Public Affairs.

title: Miss Blandid Keller Fiancee Of Dr. Donald Moore Palatucci
description: PLANDOME, L.I., Aug. 18  Miss Blandid Therese Keller and Dr. Donald Moore Palatucci of San Francisco plan to be married Sept. 8 in Melvin Village, N. H.

title: The U. N. Vote
description: UNITED NATIONSIt was hardly the first time the Security Council had voted to censure Israel for acting outside the law in her conflict with the Arab countries, and not the first time that the United States had joined in the censure. But last week, as the Security Council voted. 150. to condemn Israel for intercepting a Lebanese commercial airliner and forcing It to land to Israel, there was a difference.

title: Conservation Aid Awarded by State
description: TRENTON  State matching grants totaling $36,866 have been awarded to 21 municipal environmental commissions in order to help them finance various conservationoriented projects, the state's Department of Environmental Protection has announced.

title: Landmark Is Being Restored in Port Washington
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I.  In a treesheltered grove on the fringe of this bustling community of 35,000, which handles 76 commuter trains a day to and from New York City, loving care is restoring the 250yearold birthplace of seven brothers who represented the then colonial farming community in the American Revolution.

title: To Soccer Over There: The Yanks Are Coming
description: Returning from a youth in ternational tournament in Scotland where he piloted two American teams, Hubert VogelsInger, the soccer coach at Yale University, had this to say:

title: Reputed Donor Disclaims Aiding Agnew '66 Drive
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 18The retired controller of a consult ing engineering concern under investigation in Maryland denied today that he contributed to Vice President Agnew's 1966 campaign for Governor despite an official contributions report showing that he gave $2,500.

title: Boy, 13, Shot as IND Stakeout Thwarts Holdup Attempt by 3
description: A 13yearold youth was shot in the back and shoulder by the police yesterday during an at tempted robbery of a IND subway token booth at West 155th Street and Eighth Avenue, the police said.

title: You Can Tame Shaw To Death
description: NIAGARAONTHELAKE, ONTARIOTHIS pretty little town, located at the point where the Niagara River meets Lake Ontario, was originally settled toward the end of the 18th century by American Tories who disapproved of the liberties taken by George Washington and his rebel gang. Since then it has developed into a genteel summerhome colony for rich Torontonians and Buffalonians, not, one would think, much more sympathetic to revolutionary agitation than it ever was. So it is perhaps a little odd that NiagaraontheLake should have become the home of a festivalthe only one of its kind in existencedevoted to honoring the name, and performing the works, of that wellknown. Marxist propagandist George Bernard Shaw, who wrote in the preface to Major Barbara, I am, and have always been, and shall now always be, revolutionary writer.

title: WATERGATE PANEL IN PUBLIC FAVOR
The Foreground Some Light, But How Long Is the Tunnel?
description: WASHINGTON  Sharply higher prices in the food stores, emerging shortages of some items and a world wide explosion of prices in nearly all raw commodities  these were the unhappy auspices as Phase 4 of the Nixon Administration's seemingly erratic program of price and wage controls got under way last week.

title: Diary of a GasolineSeeker: You Can Fuel All the People...
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Aug. 11 According to a popular story making the rounds of the nation's gasoline stations this summer, you can fuel all the people some of the time and some of the people all of the time. But you can't fuel all of the people all of the time.

title: Security Risk
description: WASHINGTON  In the State Department; where he worked for nearly two decades, and in the White House, where he has been a key foreign policy formulator since 1969, Helmut Sonnenfeldt is known as hawk  a hardline conservative on domestic issues and in clinches with Communist powers.

title: BEAME BACKERS GIRD FOR BATTLE
description: Tickets are being sold at $125 a person for a party billed as for Abe Beame, a Helluva Guy, and task forces are being formed to produce weekly white papers on major municipal concerns as leaders of the BeameforMayor campaign insist that they face not a coronation but an election.

title: Candace Bidwell Bride of J. H. Norton 3d
description: FANWOOD, N. J., Aug. 18 The marriage of Miss Candace Anne Bidwell to John Hughes Norton 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norton Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and Cumberland Foreside, Me., took place here this evening. The Rev. Dr. Carl Westman of the Unitarian Universalist Association performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Alvin C. Bidwell.

title: Hillary Anne Dember Fiancee of Ira Stein
description: Mr. and Mrs. David Y. Dember of Jamaica, Queens, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Hillary Anne Dember, to Ira Jeffrey Stein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Stein of Flushing, Queens.

title: Home Improvement
description: WINDOW shades are very uncomplicated mechanisms that are quite simple for anyone to repair or adjust yet many people will tolerate shades that will not roll up or down smoothly, or that seem to have a mind of their own and either fly up without warning when least expected or unwind slowly downward right after they have been raised, to the desired height.

title: AROUND THE
description: COCKROACH CONTROL

title: Karen Magnussen Cuts Fine 6 Figures
description: It sounds like the screenplay of a Sonja Henie movie: talented young figure skater on threshold of brilliant career suffers serious injury, recovers, and skates off into the sunset carrying a pot of gold and a bag full of medals.

title: COMPUTERS HELP BAPTISTS'
description: The Southern Baptists, who are now growing at a faster rate in the North than they are in the South, are using compUters to determine the most likely places for starting new churches outside their Bible Belt stronghold.

title: St. Croix
description: CHIUSIIANSTED, St. Croix, V. I.The question that neither whites nor blacks ask about the increasing violence in this resort island is why. Their only concern is what happens next.

title: Nets Eager To Reduce The Budget
description: Confronted with a payroll estimated at $1million, the New York Nets are eager to trade. Their objectives are to strengthen the backcourt with a big guard and to reduce the payroll.

title: State Weighs Rule to Control Phosphate Dumping
description: TRENTON  For nearly two years, environmental forces in the Legislature have been trying Unsuccessfully achieve. final approval of measure that would drastically but back the use of phospate compounds cleaning detergents, the aim being to keep New Jersey's lakes and reservoirs from being choked with pollution.

title: World News Briefs
description: MANILA, Aug. 18President Ferdinand E. Marcos today created new administrative divisions in Mindanao in the southern Philippines, where Moslems are in revolt, and set up a council to help displaced people.

title: Agnew Asserts Reporters Violate His Civil Rights
description: CENTERVILLE, Md., Aug. 18 Vice President Agnew complained today that the unnamed sources and the reporters who !cite them in news stories about the Federal investigation of his affairs don't have any hesitancy about violating my civil rights or my constitutional rights.

title: Black Artists Taking Care of Business
description: SPECTATOR art has its roots in the EuropeanAmerican traditions. In traditional African and Oriental societies, however, the visual art, the music and the dance are integral parts of life, embodying the beliefs and aspirations of the people.

title: Motes in a Sunbeam
description: In the late afternoon sunlight now, especially over rural pastures and meadowlands, are hordes of tiny, gleaming insects, like swarms of midges. A great many of them are microlepidoptera, very small moths. If they are near a woodland, most of them may be of the family called Blastobasidae, miniature moths, gray in color and with a particular sheen on the front wings, whose larvae bore into seeds and nuts and even into galls on plants. Most acorns you find on the ground winter contain at least one of them.

title: Rescue Efforts at a Mine In Arizona Curbed by Hear
description: CASA GRANDE, Ariz., Aug. 18 (AP)  Intense heat and smoke from a mine fire continued to hamper efforts today to rescue two men believed trapped 1,200 feet underground by a tunnel cavein at a central Arizona copper mine.

title: Art
description: EVERYBODY here remember Ludo Fontana? Not Carlo Fontana, the 17thcentury architect, and not Domenico, the 16thcentury architect. And not Annibale or Prospero or Orazio, respectively the 16thcentury gem cutter, majolica painter, and picture painter, but LucioLucio Fontana, the 20thcentury fellow. I hesitate to write artist, a term much too loosely used in this connection. Even my handy art encyclopedia, which treats Lucio with respect, says that his works are almost not art.

title: Ship's Search Cost $50,000
description: BOSTON, Aug. 18 (AP)The 32foot yacht Sea Legs III sailed into Nantucket Harbor this week after a search that Coast Guard spokesman said cost $50,000. A spokesman for the Coast Guard said that William Capipman of Pittsburgh, Pa., owner of the boat, had filed a float plan with Canadian Coast Guard but had not followed it.

title: Average WhiteCollar Pay In Sample Increased 5.4%
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UPI)Average salaries for sample of whitecollar workers in private industry rose by 5.4 per cent between March, 1972, and this March, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reports.

title: Drug Raid Victims Strive To Construct a New Life
description: IDAHO FALLS, Idaho, Aug. 16Herbert and Evelyn Giglotto, the Collinsville, Ill., couple who fled their home after an filegal Government drug raid and subsequent harassment, are struggling to begin a news life in an undisclosed western community.

title: Clifton Weighs Nursery Plan
description: CLIFTON  The City Council here will vote on Tuesday on plans to expand Julia's Mountaintop Nursery, a preschool facility on the slopes of Garret Mountain.

title: Brooklyn Diocese Is Considering Miniparishes
description: A group of midWest Roman Catholic specialists with farreaching concepts of person centered miniparishes within large Catholic parishes brought their ideas East from Michigan and Ohio this summer for an acid test.

title: A useless anthology of influential work
description: H. L. Mencken was 27 years old when, in the spring of 1908, he was invited to become the book critic of slightly disreputable monthly called The Smart Set. He was already whirlwind success as a newspaperman in his native Baltimore, serving as reporter, columnist, editorial writer and dramatic critic before his appointment as editor of the Herald when he was 25. When that paper collapsed in 1906, he promptly moved to The Baltimore Sun as Sunday editor. At the time he began his regular contributions to The Smart Set, he had also published a volume of verse, two books of criticism (on Shaw and Nietzsche), and a great many periodical pieces.

title: Tamara DobsonNot Super Fly But Super Woman
description: YAWN. It is 8:25 A.M., a time when many movie stars are still snoozing under their beauty masks. But there, standing in the doorway of the Hudson Health Club on East 63d Street, is a movie star who is raring to give her muscles a workout. She is 6feet2inches tall. She knows karate. She is something of a super woman.

title: JUDGE HALTS YACHT WITH LINK TO VESCO
description: A temporary restraining order preventing a $1.5million yacht believed to be owned by Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier, from sailing to the Bahamas was continued yesterday in Federal District.Court here, The Associated. Press reported.

title: Guyana Amends Constitution
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Aug. 18The Guyana Parliament has amended Guyana's constitution to abolish appeals to the British privy council as the final legal jurisdiction. It also lowered the voting age from 21 to 18.

title: Stone Island
description: Start writing a novel around the ancient idea of a city girl going to the country to find herself, Then strip the novel of intellectual content, infuse it with a crude sexual vigor and show how this terrifying physicality infiltrates all human perception. You may, if you have an immaculate style and a keen historical sense, come up with something like Stone Island.

title: Mrs. Conklin Wed in Jersey
description: BERNARDSVILLE, N. J., Aug. 18Mrs. Mavis Standifer Conklin, widow of Ludolph H. Conklin Jr., was married here at noon today to Theron Ludlow Marsh, chairman and chief executive officer of Midlantic Banks, Inc., and of the National Newark and Essex Bank.

title: Y.R.A.Race Is Captured By Alison
Martha Beckerman, Student, Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Murray Beckerman of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Martha Hart Beckerman, to Richard Birnbaum of Tampa, Fla., son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Birnbaum of New York and Hillsdale, N. Y. The wedding is planned for next month in the Plaza.

title: Susan Leubert Is Wed To Stephen E. Melvin
description: Miss Susan Beth Leubert and Stephen Edward Melvin were married here in a nuptial mass yesterday afternoon at the main altar of St. Patrick's Cathedral by the Rev. Vincent J. P. Fox, director of the Catholic Center at New York University. There was a reception in the Pierre's Grand Ballroom.

title: SIDNEY E. CLARK
description: WESTPORT, Calm., Aug, 18 Sidney E. Clark, an industrial engineer who retired in 1955 as treasurer of the United States subsidiary of Clark's of England. British shoe manufacturers, died yesterday of cancer at his home, 35 Old Hill Road, His age was 82.

title: BERKELEY TO VOTE ON BLACK'S RECALL
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Aug. 18With a large segment of Berkeley's liberalradical student community out of town for the summer, City. Councilman D'Army Bailey, a black, faces a tough fight to keep his seat in an election Tuesday to recall him from office.

title: Mrs. Vigeland Wed To Frank Wiedeman
description: ORLEANS, Mass., Aug. 18Mrs. Mildred Leaning Vigeland of Haworth, widow of Arthur Vigeland, was married here this afternoon to J. Frank Wiedeman, also of Haworth, who is a senior vice president of the United States Trust Company of New York. The Rev. Kenneth Baer performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Church of the Holy Spirit.

title: New Rule To Protect Motorists On Repairs
description: TRENTON  New Jersey motorists are about to receive new protection against inflated carrepair bills.

title: Mosbacher Charts Course to Save Racing
description: On July 17, Governor Rockefeller named 51yearold Emil (Bus) Mosbacher Jr. to be chairman of the newly created State Racing and Wagering Board. The appointment of the internationally renowned yachtsman from White Plains produced reaction of incredulity and dismay in horseracing circles. Mosbacher's credentials as a sailor (skipper of two America's Cup defenders), diplomat (chief of protocol in the first Nixon Administration) and business executive (real estate, oil) were wellknown. So were the engaging Mosbacher smile, the exuberant Mosbacher charm.

title: Hospital Will Be School, Too
description: SOMERVILLE  An educecation program designed to provide schooling for those Somerset County elementary and high school students who are hospitalized for one month or longer will get under way with the start of the fall term

title: Pantomime
description: John Harvey, the selfstyled kinetic sculptor, is a mime of limited talent and dubious taste. He presented his oneman show in the sculpture garden of the Museum of Modern Art Friday evening.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Mrs. Forbes Has Twins
description: FAR HILLS, N.J., Aug. 18 Twin daughters were born Aug 6 to Mr. and Mrs. Matcolm S. Forbes Jr. in the Morristown Memorial Hospital. Mrs. Forbes is the former Miss Sabina Beekman. Her husband is a vice president of Forbes, Inc., publishers of Forbes magazine, which was founded by his grandfather, the late B. C. Forbes. The children have been named Sabina and Roberta.

title: COMMUTER BUSING WORKS IN 4 TOWNS
description: BRANFORD, Conn., Aug. 18 A modest attempt to keep automobiles off Connecticut's highways and out of its downtown centers is achieving some success in this suburb of New Haven and in three Hartfordarea communities.

title: ASTRONAUTS TAKE PICTURES OF STORM
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 18 (AP)The Skylab 2 astronauts took pictures from space today of a tropical storm coming to life on the edge of the Gulf of Mexico, south of Cuba.

title: Linda Klugman Will Be a Bride
description: WANTAGH, L. I., Aug. 18 Miss Linda Klugman and William John Levine plan to be married Nov. 22.. Mr. and Mrs. Martin Klugman have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Levine of Douglaston, Queens.

title: Pollution Suspected in Deforming of 39 Tern Chicks in L.I. Sound
description: Thirtynine abnormal tern Chicks, including one with four legs, have been discovered in a colony of the gulllike birds in eastern Long Island Sound in a threeyear study by the American Museum of Natural History.

title: Roy T.Van Vleck Weds Miss Emily N. Trevor
description: PAUL SMITHS, N.Y., Aug. 18  In St. John'sintheWilderness Episcopal Church here at noon today, Miss Emily Norwood Trevor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Trevor Jr. of New York, was married to Roy Tomlinson Van Vleck, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard A. Van Vleck of Montclair, N. J., and Chatham, Mass.

title: The Public Trust
description: President Nixon failed, in last week's statements on the Watergate scandals, to provide the perspective for which the American people had been waiting. His presentation was unsatisfactory and unconvincing principally because he himself plainly lacks perspective on the nature of the questions before him.

title: Millionaire Planning Travel Club Flightsfor and by the People
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 18 The Freelandia, a 149 seat DC8 that is painted bright shocking yellow and leatures rock music, organic food, and chess is scheduled to make her maiden flight Sept. 21.

title: Israelis Report Egyptian Flight Over Sinai Posts
description: TEL AVIV, Aug 18 (Reuters) Two Egyptian military aircraft flew over Israeli positions in the Sinai today, an Israeli Army spokesman said here.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONAll summer, President Nixon had kept silent as the charges against him accumulated in the Senate Watergate committee's nationally televised hearings. Then a few days ago, as the suspense mounted, Mr. Nixon went to the mountaintop at Camp David, the Presidential retreat in Maryland, and for several days and nights prepared, revised and polished what his spokesmen said would be a comprehensive response to the charges.

title: Enemy at The Gates The Battle for Stalingrad. By William Craig. Illustrated. 457 pp. New York: Reader's Digest Press, E. P. Dutton &
description: Of all the many battles fought by the soldiers of Czarist and Soviet Russia, only two perhaps might be ranked as fundamentally decisive, in that they not only changed the fate of the nation but also altered its destiny. The first was Poltava in 1709, when Peter the Great defeated the apparently invincible Charles XII of Sweden, thereby flexing Russia's military muscle before all Europe and definitely bringing Russia into the broad arena of European politics. The second was Stalingrad in the winter of 194243, which both in substance and in symbol advanced Russia far on its road as a world power.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
LeBoeuf Triumphs In Speedboat Race
description: RED BANK, N. J., Aug. 18 The twoday National Sweepstakes Regatta opened today at Marine Park with championship races in nine powerboat classes. Jules Le Boeuf of Valley Field, Canada, covered the fivemile course with the fastest average speed, 86.789 miles an hour, in winning the 5liter class in his Boomerang.

title: 30 Picassos Are Stolen
description: AVIGNON, France, Aug. 18 (Reuters)Thirty Picasso prints valued at $125,000 were stolen from a chateau near here today, the police said. The prints, as well as two paintings by Desnoyer and a lithograph by de Manessier, were taken from the Chateau de Simiane by two thieves, according to the police. They speculated that one thief hid in the chateau overnight and let his accomplice in through a small window.

title: Beckett Safe From Computers
description: Everybody a vacation, even a book reviewer, who spends much of the year being told by authors and publishers that he's a pimple on the body politic and so becomes depressed. As some of us prepare to disappear into the woods for a few weeksto mend the mind or to find an objective correlative perhaps it's appropriate to mention one thing that book reviewers don't have to worry about for the foreseeable future. That one thing is computers.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
Wendy Dubins Betrothed to Physician
description: ALBANY, Aug. 18Dr. and Mrs. Henry B. Dubins have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Wendy Sue Dubins, to Dr. Lawrence Perlmutter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Simon Perlmutter of Burlington, Vt. The wedding is planned for October.

title: School Conflict in the South Is Intensifying
description: MEMPHIS, Aug. 18  Two pieces, of paper tell much about the state of school desegregation in Memphis and the South as a new school year approaches.

title: 2 Brothers Accused Here Of a HeroinRape Assault
description: Two brothers from Newark were arrested here yesterday and were charged with having lured a 16yearold girl, just arrived by bus from Alabama, to a hotel near the Port Authority Bus Terminal, where they forcibly injected her with heroin and where one of them raped her.

title: Beef Price Freeze Upheld By Federal Appeals Court
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 A Federal appellate court upheld the beef price freeze today, rejecting contentions of the meat industry that the Cost of Living Council was arbitrary and capricious and had exceeded its authority.

title: College Is Offering FamilyTree Study
description: BRANCHBURG  A course on tracing one's family tree is among the 19 special community programs to be offefed at Somerset County College this fall.

title: Mary Clark Bride Of Joseph Whalen
description: CHAPPAQUA, N. Y., Aug. 18Miss Mary Marguerite Clark and Joseph A. Whalen were married here this morning by Msgr. Thomas Skelly in the Roman Catholic Church of SS. John and Mary.

title: Expansion Dispute At Flushing Airport
description: Despite community opposition to the continued operation of Flushing Airport, the city is going ahead with the plans for renovation and improvement on the facility.

title: Sam Levenson Sees Rebirth for Brooklyn
description: On television, radio, the stage and in books, Sam Levenson has helped to soften life's harshness with memories and insights dipped in caramel sweetness, fireside warmth and nostalgic good humor.

title: Amsterdam Nine Wins
description: COOPERSTOWN, N. Y., Aug. 18 (AP)Bergen Post 39 of Amsterdam captured the New York State American Legion baseball championship today, defeating Depew Post 1528 by 62. The victors go on to Region national play at Middletown, Conn., beginning next Wednesday.

title: Trenton Sees Mall Rejuvenating City
description: TRENTON  Two blocks in the heart of downtown Trenton have been closed to traffic in the first stage of developing a pedestrian mall that is designed to rejuvenate this deteriorating city.

title: Mrs. Joycelyn Bierce Will Be Wed
description: ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Aug. 18 Mrs. Joycelyn Blaikie Bierce of Englewood and Point 0'Woods, L.I., widow of Thurber H. Bierce, plans to be married Sept. 15 to Augustine Hicks Lawrence Jr., who is with the organic chemicals department of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. in Wilmington, Del., as a Freon marketing manager.

title: Lord Brookeborough, 85, Dies; Led Northern Ireland, 194363
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Saturday, Aug. 18 (AP)Lord Brookeborough, Prime Minister of Northern Ireland for 20 years in an era of almost complete Protestant ascendency, died early today at his home in Colebrook. He was 85 years old.

title: U.S. Use of Okinawa For Monitor Planes Criticized in Japan
description: TOKYO, Aug. 18  Reports from Washington that American planes based on the Japanese island of Okinawa are being used in reconnaissance flights over Cambodia are threatening to stir a political storm in Japan.

title: Parent and Child: Growing up extended
description: Not so long ago, while trying to raise my consciousness and modernize my antiquated views on marriage and the family, I picked up Germaine Greer's The Female Eunuch and made a truly startling discovery. Far from being a radical, she apparently longs for the good old days when instead of the nuclear family there was an extendedfamily household, where the head was the oldest male parent, who, ruled a number of sons and their wives and children. The work of the household was divided according to the status of the female in question: The unmarried daughters did the washing and spinning and weaving, the breeding wives bred, the elder wives nursed and disciplined the children, and managed the cooking, the oldest wife supervised the smooth running of the whole. There was friction but it had no chance to build itself into the intense introverted anguish of the single confrontation of the isolated spouses. Family problems could be challenged openly in the family forum and the decisions of the elders were honored.

title: BODY RECOVERED FROM COFFERDAM
description: Scuba divers recovered yesterday the body of one man who was drowned Friday in the East River when a section of cofferdam collapsed at the site of a new Consolidated Edison plant in Astoria, Queens. The search for a second victim continued.

title: INDIA, PAKISTAN START NEW TALKS
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 18Indian and Pakistani officials resumed crucial talks today in an effort to break the political deadlock on the subcontinent.

title: Headliners
description: There was deep gloom among the smallfry in Central Park last week: Hans Christian Andersen's Ugly Duckling, one of the most popular statues in the park, was stolen from its granite base. From the time the bronze statues of the duckling and Andersen, the Danish storyteller, were installed in 1956, they have been a favorite climbing place for New York City's children. On Saturday mornings dozens of youngsters gathered atthe statues to hear readings of Andersen's fairy tales. The gloom may not last long, however. If the twofoottall duckling not recovered, Dorothy Stelsin, whose Fifth Avenue apartment overlooks the statue site, has offered to donate to the city the $2,500 needed replace the sculpture. I've so enjoyed seeing all those kids tumbling over it, she said.

title: Uncle Sam Ervin and The Bible
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18  Uncle Sam Ervin, who loves to quote the Bible, and keeps calling for President Nixon's tapes, is not a man of little faith, but somehow he has overlooked or forgotten the Twelvth Chapter of the Book of Luke, verses two and three:

title: Phnom Penh
description: PHNOM PENH  On Wednesday morning, just one minute before the deadline for the Congressional cutoff of American bombing, two F4 Phantom jets flying wingtip to wingtip perhaps the last American planes to strike in Cambodia  swooped down on a target about 10 miles west pf Phnom Penh, dropped their last bombs and celebrated by spiraling around each other up into the sky, daredevil fashion, until they were out of sight.

title: Vietnam Economy Still Clings to U.S. Lifeline
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 18  More than four months after the departure of the last American troops, the United States remains the most vital lifeline to the military and economic stability of the South Vietnamese Government.

title: Music; Mlle. Modiste'? Yes, and It's Fun
description: ONE of my favorite records is an ancient Columbia disk, c. 1920, on which Rosa Ponselle sings Kiss Me Again. She t akes the rather silly little ;waltz in a very slow tempo, :lavishing upon it all the coloristic resources of that billiondollar voice, all but Melting the shellac with the sexy quality that is poured Into the refrain.

title: U.S. TO SELL SPAIN 8 BRITISH PLANES
description: LONDON, Aug. 18  The United States has decided to sell eight Britishmade jet fighters to Spain, touching off a political controversy here.

title: Team Priests Gain Favor in Oradell
description: ORADELLBergen County's first diocesan team ministry has settled into a comfortable routine at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church here, despite some opposition to the three priests at the start of their assignment.

title: Federal Paper Work Cost Put at $15Billion a Year
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18, ReutersThe United States Government is losing its ongoing war against mountains of official paper work, Federal auditors said today.

title: Summer Tradition on L.I.
description: SHOREHAM, L. I.It is neither inexpensive, posh nor quaint. It isn't reminiscent of Montauk or the Hamptons, Fire or Fisher's Island, Sag Harbor or Orient Point. How then, can a resort village where the only commercial establishment is a general store and the liveliest activity on Sunday night is a religious song service qualify, as one of the North Shore's most perennially popular vacation spots?

description: To the Editor:

title: Common Enemy
description: As Indian and Pakistani diplomats prepared last week to renew their efforts to resolve the differences remaining from their 1971 conflict over Bangladesh and thus establish a lasting peace on the Indian subcontinent, troops of the two countries were reported once more to be crossing their common border. This time, however, the soldiers were not fighting one another but a common enemy, the monsoon floods that have been devastating both countries.

title: ONE KILLED, ONE SHOT ON BROOKLYN STREET
description: A 14yearold boy was killed and his 19yearold companion was wounded in a shooting yesterday in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Delinda Dent Bride of John D. Lybrand
description: EL PASO, Tex., Aug. 18Miss Delinda Sue Dent, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Dent, was married here at noon today to John David Lybrand, son of Fred Lybrand, chairman and president of the Bank of Commerce in New York, and Mrs. Lybrand of Stamford, Conn. The Rev. title: Stray Dog, Booing Fans Help Bills Open Stadium
description: BUFFALO, Aug, 18The debut of the Buffalo Bills magnificent new football stadium here last night had richness. The enemy returned the opening kickoff 102 yards for a touchdown, an event thick in symbolism for the locals, who tend to laugh at all the terrible things thathappen to themin sports. Of course the Bills lost, 3721, to the Washington Redskins. TheBills have been losing steadily since 1967.

description: GIVEN the opening up in the past few years of the byways of Ro, mantic music, it was inevitable that sooner or later we would be directed down the rough road marked Romantic Organ to see what lies there.

This continent's four other major stock exchanges, the Pacific, Midwest, Toronto and PBW, have also seen large decreases in the value and number of shares traded in the first six months of 1973.

description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 18 (UPI)When State Representative Tom Drake twists another legislator's arm he has to remember he can't throw a hammerlock on him like he uses in the wrestling ring.

title: Russia's 250 Million
description: The doctrine of Zero Population Growth enjoys little acceptance among the leaders of the Soviet Union. That seems a fair inference from the exultation in the Soviet press the other day when the Kremlin announced that the country's population had passed the 250million mark. In the United States any comparable announcement would undoubtedly have brought much gloomy speculation on the perils of excess population, the exhumation of Malthus and a rallyingtoarms of defenders of the environment.

title: Police Drug Theft Closing In On Who And How
description: It was quite probably the most spectacular crime in the history of New York Citythe brazen theft of more than $70million worth of confiscated narcotics entrusted to the custody of the New York Police Department. And it became all the more outrageous because the 398 pounds of heroin and cocaine pilfered from the police storerooms included the seizures made in the celebrated French Connection case, which was embroidered into an Academy Award winning movie.

Notes: Stretching The Shrinking Dollar
description: BETWEEN inflation abroad and devaluation of the dollar, unusual increases in hotel and restaurant prices are being reported by American travelers in France, Germany, Scandinavia and Switzerland, among other foreign countries. One country that many Americans still regard as bargain, however, is Ireland. A quick telephone check with tourist officials in New York representing five European cities  Paris, London, Rome, Copenhagen and Dublin  confirms that traveler's customary expenses in most categories are lower in Dublin than in the others. Taking an average for two people sharing a de luxe room, having a full breakfast, going on a sightseeing tour in an escorted motor coach, having a gourmet dinner and occupying the best seats at a theater, the survey shows this comparision for one day's expenses: $65 in Dublin, $112 in Paris, $91.50 in London, $97 in Rome and $88.50 in Copenhagen.

description: JUST about every traveler suffers from jet lagthe blahs you feel for a couple of days or so immediately after a transAtlantic or transcontinental flightbut maybe you have thought that nobody takes it very seriously and, like the weather, nobody was doing very much about it.

title: The New York Times Book Review:A Saladin in life,a Kennedy in death
description: Exhausted by years of overwork and illness Gamal Abdel Nasser died in Cairo on Sept. 28, 1970, of cardiac arrest following a massive heart attack. He was 52. Vice President Sadat's somber announcement broadcast later that evening triggered an outburst of woe throughout the Arab world fully comparable to our own when President Kennedy was struck down. Viewed in the West as an Egyptian de Gaulle, Bismarck, Ataturk or most vociferously as the new Hitler on the Nile, Nasser for his fellow Arabs was none of these.

title: Unfortunately, Raindrops Keep Falling On Their Heads
description: THE evolution of TV news as entertainment appears, in retrospect, to have been inevitable. As everyone knows, commercial television exists largely as a purveyor of entertainment, and the station or network that can outdraw its competition is more appealing market for sponsors and thus makes more money than its rivals make. It was simply a matter of time until station managers and news producers realized that they could use their local news shows, prime time's bookends, as another ploy in the rating game and boost their appeal by making them funny, happy, and showbiz.

title: Forest Hills Grass Is Wearing Out

Workmen were rolling, mowing and wetting it; some went on hands and knees to trim it with large shears. They patted it with almost tender care, searching for worn patcheS, anything that appeared to break the symmetry.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18About 44 per cent of the people who watched President Nixon's Watergate address on television Wednesday night found the speech not at all convincing, while 27 per cent concluded it was completely or quite a lot convincing, according to a Gallup Poll commissioned by The New York Times.

description: THIS is a very important tool, said Graham Mackenzie Gordon, an architectural designer, as he picked up a hydrant wrench off the grass and tatoped it in.his hand. They disappear too easily.

title: Brownstone revivified
description: Brooklyn Heights is one of those rare areas of New York with quiet, residential streets and smalltown neighborliness. Its charm derives not only from its welltended brownstones, but also from its communityspirited citizens, families such as the Stanley Coopers, a couple with collegeage children who are eager to preserve the area's cohesiveness. The Coopers bought their brownstone, which was built in the 1800's, two years ago. They knew that they wanted a very modem setting. But when their designer, David Easton of EastonLaRocca, reviewed the rooms, he suggested saving some of the original trim and moldings. The parlor floor had long ago been broken up into small rental units that had deteriorated with the passage of time and tenants. When the separating walls were cleared away the graciousness of the original parlor floor emerged. Victorian moldings, such as the trim around the fireplace were stretched to frame doorways and form panels for mirrors and bookcases. Other trim creates a pier glass between windows of the library. The Coopers gained their contemporary residence without losing all of the period charm.

They included a surcharge on parking and a plan to allow a commuter to drive into the city on only four of the five weekdays.

description: NANTUCKET, Mass.This misty island of Nantucket, 30 miles off the mainland, has long been a summer hideaway for the rich.

Nixon and Special Prosecutor Archibald Cox bordered the workweek with written arguments that scholars and their students will consult for years to come.

description: TRENTONA selection of photographs, including many displaying experimental techniques, is on exhibit in the lobby of the State Department of Education building here.

title: Items in Kennedy Death Are Going to Archives
description: DALLAS, Aug. 18 (AP)Equipment used by doctors of Parkland Hospital as they worked to try to save the life of President Kennedy is going to the National Archives. The equipment will be preserved for its historical value. One day it may be placed on public display.

title: Liselotte Waldheim Wed In Swiss Village Church
description: SATIGNY, Switzerland, Aug. 18  Miss Liselotte Waldheim, daughter. of Kurt Waldheim, United Nations Secretary General, and Mrs. Waldheim, was married this morning in the Protestant Church of this small village seven miles from Geneva to Pierre Natural, a member of a Geneva law firm.

title: U.S. Lags in Giving Support to Banks Aiding Poor Nations
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19An unfinished highway in Ohio, the Japanese ancestry of a Senator and the Chicano constituency of a Congressman are among the many forces at work in Congress that are threatening to frustrate what the Nixon Administration regards as an important part of its foreign policy.

title: Israeli Power Structure: One Man at the Top
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 19  One of the fastestselling new books in Israel these days is a lively, gossipy account of the inner workings of the Israeli power structure titled The Establishment. In it the two journalistauthors set out to describe who rules Israel and how.

title: McGovern Warns Tapes Could Spur Impeachment
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19Senator George McGovern declared today that President Nixon's continued refusal to release tape recordings of conversations relating to the Watergate scandal could lead Congress to consider impeachment.

title: One Plan, Put at $1Billion, Would Place Road Under a Land Fill
description: The time is some 15 years from now, and the scene is spectacular: The Lower West has been extended sev eral hundred feet out into the Hudson and the land fill is studded with new housing and carpeted with a long strip of waterfront parkland. Underneath there is the subdued rumble of cars, trucks and maybe even subway trains in a tunnel shared by a completely new sixlane West Side Highway and a transit line with rails or busways.

title: City to Cut Back on Meat In PublicSchool Lunches
description: The city's publicschool children will lose one meal of meat probably a hamburgerfrom their weekly lunch fare next month because of rapidly rising wholesale prices and spreading shortages officials of the Bureau of School Lunches said yesterday.

title: Results of Yesterday's Nearby. Yacht Racing; AT LARCHMONT, N. Y. INTERNATIONAL CLASS Y.R.A. (Wind eastsoulheast, 8.12 knots)
description: Cruising Division (8 started); elapsed time Indicated1, Bullet, FrederickA. Jackson (2:52:34); 2, Chrlstopher Dragon Steven Weiss (2:55:33); 3, Chinook, Jack Lovelace (2:56:29); 4, Argonaut, Lester Landes (3:06:12); S, Enchante Deux, Joseph Halliday (3:13:16).

title: Link Hinted in Harlem and East Side Slayings
description: Residents of the lower East Side neighborhood where a 7yearold boy was killed Friday have told the police they had seen a man in the area who strongly resembled a suspect in the sexual mutilation and slaying of three ypuths several months ago on the upper West Side and in Harlem.

title: Driver Stopping to Aid Man Is Killed by Car in Queens
description: A driver who tried to assist an intoxicated man who was lying in a roadway was struck and killed by an automobile yesterday morning at Rockaway and Farmers Boulevards, St. Albans, Queens.

title: Ailing Lira Stages Tentative Recovery
description: ROME, Aug. 19The liralong the weakest currency in the European Economic Communityhas shown some strength during the last two weeks, and there is cautious hope here that its recovery will continue.

title: Norris's Powerboat Sets Offshore Mark
description: MARINA DEL REY, Calif., Aug. 19 (UPI)Art Norris Set a United States offshore record of 75.15 miles an hour today in winning the Hennessy California Cup in his 36foot cigarettehulled Slap Shot.,

title: Leak of Noxious Gas Ends In Suburb of Los Angeles
description: CARSON, Calif., Aug. 19 (AP) Operations returned to normal at the Stauffer Chemical Company plant today, one day after a cloud of noxious gas escaped from a tank and drifted down the California coast, sending 38 persons to the hospital.

title: China Will Give Pakistan $1Million in Flood Relief
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 19 (Reuters)  China today pledged million yuan (about $1.04million) in cash and supplies to help Pakistani flood victims, Hsinhua, the Chinese news agency, reported.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To Put Watergate in Perspective

title: Privilege and Power
description: The lawyers begin arguing in court this week over President Nixon's tapes, and the issue of executive privilege comes alive for the public as it never has before. Anyone can see that it is an issue not of legal doctrine alone but of power. If a President, can decide entirely on his own that his privacy outweighs other public interests, he becomes a kind of king, above the law.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Aug. 20, 1973 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Colonialism 10:30 A.M.; subcommittee on Pacific Ocean territories3 P.M.

title: GARRISON'S TRIAL TO START TODAY
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 19 (AP)District Attorney Jim Garrison goes on trial in Federal Court here tomorrow, accused of taking payoffs to protect illegal gambling. Six of his alleged accomplices are reported ready to testify against him.

title: 800 NUNS EXAMINE ROLES FOR WOMEN
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Aug. 19Eight hundred women wearing brightly colored shirtwaist and sleeveless, polyester dresses, and looking more like members of an active P.T.A. than the Roman Catholic nuns that they were, gathered here for a weekend conference on the changing role of women in the church and society.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: WALL PAPERS It is no lark by any means, but a slow inspection of the Jewish wall newspapers now on view in the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research, at Fifth Avenue at East 86th Street, is instructive and affecting, particularly (but not exclusively) for those able to read Yiddish and Hebrew. These extraordinary papers were produced mainly under conditions of stringency and stress, somtimes terror, and they are therefore special fragments of history.

title: Chotiner Confirms He Retained A Writer to Spy on McGovern
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., Aug. 19 (UPI)Murray M. Chotiner a former political adviser to President Nixon confirmed today that he employed a freelance writer to join Senator George McGovern's campaign last year and provide daily reports of the activities of the Democratic presidential candidate.

title: MRS. LILLIAN FLYER
description: Mrs. Lillian Goldblatt Flyer, a retired pharmacist and a freelance writer, died Saturday at Kingsbrook Medical Center. She was 85 years old and lived at 20 Midwood Street, Brooklyn.

title: COX SEEKS REASON FOR WITHHOLDING, OF I.T.T PAPERS
Theater: Shaw Revival; Arms and Man Plays in 2d Ave. Loft 'What's in It for Me? Is a Good Try
description: Two current OffBroadway shows depend, for much of their effect, on women: In one case a strong vehicle is thereby weakened, while in the other a rather wobbly vehicle is matte almost strong enough to stand.

title: STATE UNIT SCORES HOSPITAL BILLINGS
description: A state audit charged yesterday that sluggish billing procedures at the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation might have cost $50million in 1971, its first year of operation.

title: Wilson and Butchers in Pact
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug, 19 (AP)Wilson & Co., Inc., and officials of Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen of North America reached agreement today on a threeyear contract covering 7,000 employes at 20 Wilson facilities. Details were not disclosed, pending ratification by union members.

title: Miss Schenkel Wed To M. K. Marshall
description: The marriage of Miss Patricia Sue Schenkel, who graduated in May from Smith College,. to Michael Keith Marshall, a 1973 graduate of Oklahoma State University, took place.here yesterday afternoon. Rabbi Nathan. I. Perilman performed the ceremony at the Regency.

title: Mafia Badly Bruised By U.S.City Actions
description: Criminal prosecutions have severely hurt the Mafia in New York City in the last year, and Federal and local lawenforcement officials are talking cautiously for the first time about a day when crippling blows may be dealt the underworld here.

title: CALIFORNIAN GUILTY IN 10 MURDER CASES
description: SANTA. CRUZ, Calif., Aug. 19 (AP)Herbert Mullin was convicted today of killing 10 persons, including a woman and her two small sons.

title: B.T Fitzpatrick, Lawyer, Dead; Helped Draw Up'49 Housing Act
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19B. T. Fitzpatrick, a lawyer who was a Federal housing expert and principal architect of the National Housing Act of 1949, died today of pneumonia. He was 66 years old and lived in Chevy Chase, Mt

title: Foreign Bank Curb Sought in California
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 19 (Reuters)Alarmed by the impact and rapidly growing significance of operations by foreign banks in California. a group of small California banks has sponsored two bills in the Legislature that would limit ownership by foreign banks in nonbanking businesses, and require reciprocal rights for California banks overseas.

title: GREEK PRESIDENT PROMISES TO FREE ALL JAILED FOES
description: ATHENS, Aug. 19George Papadopoulos, the former artillery colonel who seized power in Greece six years ago, today took the oath as the country's first President and promised an amnesty for some 300 political prisoners, including the man who tried to kill him in 1968.

title: MOTHER MARY ANNA
description: Mother Mary Anna Dillon, a former superior general of the Congregation of the Infant Jesus of Brooklyn, a religious order popularly known as the Nursing Sisters of the Sick, Poor, died Saturday at St Joseph's Villa, Rockville Centre, L. I. Her age was 81.

title: Peterson's Auto First In Austria
description: ZELTWEG, Austria, Aug. 19 (AP) Sweden's Ronnie Peterson, picking up the slack when his Lotus teammate, Emerson Fittipaldi of Brazil, was knocked out of the lead with mechanical problems, captured the Austrian Grand Prix Formula One auto race today.

title: Books of The Times
description: See the interesting, lively reviews of new books every weekday on the book page of The New York Times. And every Sunday you'll enjoy the variety of news, reviews and essays about books, authors and publishers in The New York Times Book Review.

title: StateCity Design Team At Work Since April,'72
description: The office of the West Side Highway Project at 19 Rector Street has everything a draftsman could want: bright lights above, windows all around and just the right amount of creative clutter There is only one thing missinga good, inspirational view of the highway itself.

title: Mercer Homers, Hegan Sparkles in 62 Victory
A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: Cindy Leone Is a Bride
description: Miss Cindy Leone and Bernard A. Halpern, graduates of Villanova University, were married last evening at La Mer in Brooklyn by Rabbi Maxwell Sacks. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Lucas G. Leone of Devon, Pa., and Mr. and Mrs. Murray Halpern of Brooklyn. Mr. Leone is senior vice president of the Baker/BeechNut Corporation, a babyfood concern here. The bridegroom's father is a manufacturer of men's clothing.

title: Miss Jacqueline Siben Is Married
description: BRIGHTWATERS, L. I., Aug. 19  The marriage of Miss Jacqueline Hillel Siben to David Rees Davies, a London barrister, took place here this afternoon. Rabbi Stanley Syntner performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Sidney R. Siben of Brightwaters and Westhampton Beach. Mr. Davies is a son of Mr. and Mrs. D. Hywel Davies of Narberth, Wales.

title: Bridge: Reliance on Favorite Genie Can Set Up an Unhappy Ending
description: Literature and legend contein many examples of the following theme: A man has the apparent good fortune to discover a monkey's paw, a genie in a bottle, or some other obliging spirit who promises him one or more wishes. The fates always have a nasty surprise in store for him.

title: Marcy J. Barg Married
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 19  At Temple Oheb Shalom here this afternoon, Miss Marcy Judith Barg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Barg of Maplewood, was maried to Lewis Andrew Lefko, son of Mrs. Harald Lefko of Sioux City, Iowa, and the late Mr. Lefko. Rabbi Louis Levitsky performed the ceremony, assisted by Cantor Edgar Mills. The bride's father is executive vice president of the Schenley World T & I Company, a division of Schenley Affiliated Brands.

title: Bombings Damage a Hotel, Destroy Ulster Courthouse
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland. Aug. 19 (UPI)Bombs damaged Belfast's Regency Hotel and destroyed a village courthouse and two other buildings today in Northern Ireland. The police said there were no injuries in any of the blasts.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BERLIN, Aug. 19 (UPI)Paced by Roland Matthes, East Germany beat the defending champion, the Soviet Union, by 18 points today to win the men's European Cup swimming championships for the second time in four years. East Germany, which also won in 1969, took seven of events at Friesen Stadium in East Berlin.

title: Miss Goldbloom Becomes Bride
description: Miss Susan Goldbloom and Peter G. Restler of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Restler of Delray Beach, Fla., formerly of Rockville Centre, L. L. were married yesterday morning in Montreal. Rabbi Bernard Bloomstone of Temple EmanuEl of Montreal performed the ceremony in the garden of the RitzCarlton Hotel.

title: Some Fans Traveled by Water And Scotch, Beer and Vodka
description: PORT JEFFERSON, LT., Aug. 19The first major casualty of the JetsGiants game occurred on a ferryboat hours before the contest began in New Haven. Hugh Sonroyand Richie Thornton dropped their cooler case full of beer,

title: Lessons of Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19The reaction to the President's speech last week centers on what he did not say, or what he should have said, rather than what he did say.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The state is buying nearly 900 acres of privately owned land from four owners in the Adirondack Forest Preserve, including the 118acre Moss Lake, Henry L. Diamond, commissioner of Environmental Conservation, announced. The four parcels, described at key tracts, will be purchased with $895,250 from last year's Environmental Quality Bond Act.

title: Prague Summer
description: PRAGUEUnder the watchful eye of a member of the criminal element, I had, strip to the skin. A captain In uniform came in to receive my clothes and personal effects. I noticed that the slippers I had been issued were at least two sizes smaller than I wear, and that the, left one had a nail poking through at the toe. BUt it seemed totally absurd to request larger slippers. at this point, and so I limped to the elevator, flanked by the two silent figures, waited for. It to arrive, and allowed myself to be shoved inside.

title: IndiaNepal Relations Running Hot and Cold
description: KATMANDU, Nepal. Aug. 13 Like a squabbing couple, Nepal and India arc smiling publicly together but whispering angrily as soon as the doors are closed.

title: Big Peking Meeting Continues but Government Maintains Silence
description: PEKING, Aug. 19  Thousands of shirtsleeved delegates today attended their third meeting in three days in the Great Hall of the People, indicating that a political gathering of major importancepossibly the 10th national congress of the Communist partyivas under way.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK, Aug. 19It was the postWorld War I era, when legalized boxing was budding in New Jersey, and Kayo Brown was fighting his last fight. He had walked from his home here, over the bridge crossing the Passaic River, and into the ring as an undefeated young prize fighter. He lost in a runaway decision.

title: Best Seller in Moscow Is the New Phone Book
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 19That most elusive of telephone books, the Moscow directory, has finally gone on sale at the city's newsstands, and Muscovites have been paying 12 rubles, or $16, for the bulky fourvolume set.

title: Mailer Enjoys a Day in the Sun at MacDowell Colony
description: PETERBOROUGH, N. H., Aug. 19Norman Mailer experienced a most unusual kind of day here yesterday. Everything went right.

title: 5 Giant Thefts, 5 Scores; Jets Check Burglar Plan
Books of The Times
description: Several years ago under the auspices of the theological journal Concilium, the theological architects of the Second Vatican Council  Karl Rainier, Edward Schillebeeck and others  held a conference in Brussels and found themselves confronted with a grassroots revolt. The assembly threw out the resolutions that the sponsors had prepared beforehand for adoption at the end. The scholars who had forced the church to democratize would have to do the same in their own discipline.

title: COMMUNIST ATTACK NEAR HUE REPORTED
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 19 ,(UPI)  Communist troops attacked Government positions outside the former imperial capital of Hue again today, but a spokesman for the military command said they were repulsed.

title: P.B.A. OPPOSES RECRUITING PLAN
description: Robert M. McKiernan, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, said yesterday that if the Police Department continued to seek recruits from lists of the Housing and Transit Authorities police, he would go to court to stop the action.,

title: Chinese Embassy In Zambia Bombed; A Woman Is Killed
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Aug. 19A bomb in a parcel exploded at the Chinese Embassy here yesterday, killing at least one person, and seriously injuring another.

title: Drs. Linda Pessar, R. B. T. Cowan Wed
description: SANDS POINT, LI., Aug. 19At the Community Synagogue of Sands Point this afternoon, Dr. Linda Faith Pessar and Dr. Richard B. T. Cowan, residents at the Psychiatric Institute of the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center in New York, were married by Rabbi Martin S. Rozenberg.

title: Chavez Is Starting a Fast to Affirm Nonviolence
description: DELANO, Calif., Aug. 19 Csar Chavez, president of the United Farm Workers, and hundreds of his followers will begin a threeday fast here to, morrow in what was termed an effort to demonstrate once again our commitment to nonviolence after recent antistrike activity and the death last week of two members of Mr. Chavez's union and injuries to many others.

title: Mrs. Desmond FitzGerald Dies; Led Children's Speech Center
description: Mrs. Barbara Green FitzGer ald, founder and director of the Children's Hearing and Speech Center in Washington, and the widow of Desmond FitzGerald, a former deputy director of the Central Intelligence Agency, died Saturday of cancer in Memorial Hospital. She was 53 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Roundup: Cubs Lose in 9th, 21
description: The Chicago Cubs have done a lot of losing lately, but none of the 12 defeats they have suffered in their last 14 games could have been more agonizing than the 2.1 setback yesterday in Chicago by the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Rhodesia Is Said to Detain 9 African Council Officials
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Aug. 19 (Reuters)The Rhodesian Government has detained nine more officials of the African National Council, bringing to 33 the number taken into custody in the last month, the council's leader, Bishop Abel Muzorewa, said today.

title: SMALL RETAILERS PLAN PRICE RISE
description: Small retail stores in virtually every section of the nation said last week that they expected to raise prices on a wide variety of merchandise within a week or two.

title: Change and Violence in St. Croix Are Linked to Growth
description: Change and Violence in St. Croix Are Linked to Growth

title: Red Smith
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 19The canoe was missing from the infield lake, behind the tote board today, having been carted away for repainting in the colors Mrs. Patricia Blass. For the next 365 days, as Saratoga's sacred tradition dictates, the old skiff will display the colors of the owner of the Travers Stakes winner. The comely Mrs. Blass has racing silks of pink and green dots. It said that if a person turns pink with green spots he probably has a bad case of cholera, but to Ron Turcotte the combination represents 10 per cent of $68,280. Swaddled in Mrs. Blass's silks, Turcotte kept a colt named Annanlate Em in front for the whole mile and a quarter of the Travers yesterday and earned the winner's purse that he had planned to collect with Secretariat. It was the 104th running of the Trivers and perhaps the most forgettable,, yet it must have had more witnesses than any of its 103 predecessors. Not only did the crowd of 32,023 break all records for Saratoga's 110 years; television brought the race into every corner of the landall on account of a horse that didn't run. Chances are many horse players, like the TV people, had made plans to attend in the expectation of seeing Secretariat. Because the colt is recovering from a head cold, he made only a token appearance, jogging around the course between race's.

title: Changes in Social Attitudes Monitored In Broad Surveys of the Quality of Life
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19Sometime this month, a stranger from the Federal Government may knock on your door and politely ask to speak with you, your wife and children over 12. If you let him in, he will ask questions like this:

title: FLOATING BACKED FOR CURRENCIES
description: WASHINGTON Aug. 18A key Congressional subcommittee has concluded that, in current circumstances, floating currency exchange rates are the best available alternative and are clearly superior to fixed parities.

title: Liquid Chloroform Spilled From Barge in Mississippi
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 19 (AP)Some 64,000 gallons of poteneitlly lethal chloroform spilled into the Mississippi River today, but the Coast Guard said no problems were expected from the spill.

title: Radar in Hand
description: Handheld radar devices are appearing in various parts of the country to aid in the detection and conviction of speeding motorists. The Los Angeles Police Department has experimented with a two and onehalf pound device that shows a police officer the exact speed of a passing vehicle.

title: Personal Finance: Estate Evaluation
Maryland Town Seems Unruffled by Scandals
description: TOWSON, Md., Aug. 19 Sitting on an iron lawn chair under the huge tulip tree in her backyard on Chesapeake Avenue, Mrs. Arthur G. Turner sipped iced tea and said nothing mean about the corruption and rumors of corruption in this Baltimore suburb. She explained it all in a simple sentence: If you can't say some thing nice about someone, don't say anything at all. That, she said, is what well brought up Maryland families tell their children.

title: STOCKPILE BILLS LAG IN CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 Congressional skepticism and preoccupation with other matters has delayed, and may block, one important part of the Nixon Administration's antiinflation programsale of vast quantities of metals and other materials from the strategic stockpile.

title: Pentagon Is Said to Order Special Garb for Servants
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UPI)  The Pentagon plans to spend $34,000 to dress up officers servants to look like something out of musical comedy, Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, charged today.

title: MRS. GANDHI CALLS 73 HARDEST YEAR
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 19Prime Minister Indira Gandhi terms 1973 the most difficult year in India's history.

title: Traditional Funeral Held For Tregaskis in Hawaii
description: HONOLULU, Aug. 19 (AP)A traditional Hawaiian funeral was held on the sands at Waikiki Beach last evening for Richard Tregaskis, war correspondent and author.

title: U.S. Lags in Giving Support to Banks Aiding Poor Nations
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19An unfinished highway in Ohio, the Japanese ancestry of a Senator and the Chicano constituency of a Congressman are among the many forces at work in Congress that are threatening to frustrate what the Nixon Administration regards as an important part of its foreign policy.

title: Steel Haulers Plan Strike
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 19 (UPI)  William J. Hill, national chairman of the Fraternal Association of Steel Haulers, said today that the group's members would stage a oneday strike Aug. 24 to protest a new wage contract offer made by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: SMALL RETAILERS PLAN PRICE RISES
description: Small retail stores in virtually every section of the nation said last week that they expected to raise prices on wide variety of merchandise within a week or two.

title: COX SEEKS REASON FOR WITHHOLDING OF I.T.T. PAPERS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19The special Watergate prosecutor, Archibald Cox, and hi: staff have been seeking to find out why 13 politically sensitive documents essential to Justide Department inquiry into possible perjury by high Government, officials and officers of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation were withheld from the department!s Criminal Division during the 1972 Presidential campaign.

title: Bagel Maker Crosses Ethnic Lines
description: When Murray Lender went into the bagel business with his father in 1955, the year he left the Army, the New York Bagel Bakery of New Haven was a typical Jewish bagel establishmentone of 40 such businesses in the nation and one of perhaps 10 outside New York City. It was a family business. Business Murrays's older brother, Samuel A. and his father and mother all stood at the tables, handshaping the stiff bagel dough of highgluten unbleached flour, working next to two employes in business that grossed $50,000 a year.

title: 2D BODY TAKEN FROM COFFERDAM
description: The body of the second victim of Friday's cofferdam collapse was recovered early yesterday morning at the Consolidated Edison work site in the Fast River at Astoria, Queens. The body was that of Donato Collaro 45 years old, of 1727 Mayhan Avenue in the Bronx. He was a father of four boys and two girls.

title: 4 Informers Have Turned Up At Trial of Antiwar Veterans
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Aug. 19 A strange procession of informers is filing through the trial of seven antiwar veterans and a supporter charged here with plotting an assault on the 1972 Republican National Convention.

title: Helen Hama Married
description: OCEANSIDE, L. L, Aug.19Miss Helen N. Hama, daughter of Mrs. Toshiye T. Hama of Brentwood and the late Joseph S. Hama, was married this afternoon to Donald J. Schwartz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Schwartz of Oceanside. Rabbi Gilbert S. Rosenthal performed the ceremony at the Oceanside Jewish Center.

title: McGovern Warns Tapes Could Spur Impeachment
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19Senator George McGovern declared today that President Nixon's continued refusal to release tape recordings of conversations relating to the Watergate scandal could lead Congress to consider impeachment.

title: HERBERT L. KING
description: Herbert L. King, who retired in 1966 as assistant vice president of the General Bronze Corporation after 40 years with the company, died yesterday in North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L. I. He was 77 years old and lived at 35 Midland Road, Roslyn Heights, L. I.

title: Mafia Badly Bruised By U.S.City Actions
description: Criminal prosecutions have severely hurt the Mafia in New York City in the last year, and Federal and local lawenforcement officials are talking cautiously for the first time about a day when crippling blows may be dealt the underworld here.

title: RegisterNow
description: In the wake of Watergate, it is clearer than ever that the health of the electoral process depends on the vigilant involvement of all citizens. Too many residents New York City remain unregistered and thus ineligible to vote.

title: Jean Baldridge and B. S. Bilus Wed in L.I. Garden Ceremony
description: LAWRENCE, L. I., Aug. 19. Miss Jean Katherine Baldridge, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Connell Baldridge, was married here today to Benjamin Stephen Bilus, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Bilus of Plainfield, N.J., in her parents garden. The ceremony was performed by Acting Village Justice Leonard Lazarus.

title: Sweden Leads, 20, In Senior Tennis
description: Sweden took a 20 lead over Chile in the elimination final of the international senior men's team tennis competition for the Stevens Cup, yesterday by winning both opening singles matches at the Town Tennis Club.

title: Ronne Hoffman Is Wed
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Aug. 19Miss Ronne Lynn Hoffman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Hoffman of Ardsley, was married here this afternoon to Robert Alan Wiesen, son of Dr. and Mrs. Leo E. Wiesen of Valley Stream, L. I. Rabbi David I. Golovensky performed the ceremony in Temple Beth El.

title: You Could Call It the Haldeman Cut
description: When Pat Fitton's parents first saw her new haircut, they screamed. Miss Fitton herself rather likes it, except when she is told that it looks like the one sported by a former White House chief of staff and recent television personality.

title: Article 1  No Title
OpenAir Market Gaining Favor as Food Prices Rise
description: NEWARK, Aug. 19Openair markets beckoning with tempting arrays of fresh produce have always held a special attraction for shoppers. With hardhit families searcing for ways to whittle pennies off today's exorbitant food costs, their allure offers even greater promise. Here, boxed in a 10acre ironbound area, is New Jersey's largest farmers market. Where broad farms and welltended orchards once flourished, the market, like its surroundings, has diminished over the years, routed by economic decline clutter.

title: Paris Pot, Bonn Kettle
description: Chancellor Brandt's Government has every justification for reacting sharply to reports of official concern in France that West Germany is becoming aloof from Western Europe and drifting toward neutralism. The blunt truth is that if any future Bonn Government should be persuaded by Soviet lures to cut its links with the West, a whole series of French policies and attitudestoward the Atlantic Alliance, the European Community and EastWest relationswould bear heavy responsibility.

title: Finkelstein Was Intermediary in Kheel's Turnabout on Bonds
description: Two years ago, Theodore H. Kheel spent $300 on broadcast commercial and an abundance of his considerableenergy in leading the successful fight to, defeat Governor Rockefeller's proposed$2.5billion transportation bond issue referendum. This year, Mr. Rockefellerhas a $3.5billiontransporta bond issue on the November Notes ballot and Mr. Kheel has put himself on public record in favor of it.

title: Soviet Team Is Cornering Gold Market
Uruguay Bans Beef Sales
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 19 (Reuters)Beef was missing from Sunday dinners in Uruguay today as a threemonth Government ban on its sale went into force with the objective of promoting beef exports.

title: Crime in Central Park Cut, Clurman Says After a Tour
description: Crime has been reduced substantially in Central Park this year, Richard M. Clurman, the city's Administrator of Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs, said yesterday after tour of the park with Mayor Lindsay.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: We reported last week that precooked frozen foods were invading the menus of expensive restaurants. Operators do not deny that quality suffers, but they defend the practice in the name of laborsaving.

title: Advertising: Fee System Backed
description: When Sam Bloom resigned as advertising director of the Dallas Times Herald 20 years ago, he set up his own agency in Dallas to handle the retail accounts there he knew so well.

title: FIVE CHANGE BOOTHS HELD UP IN SUBWAY
description: A rash of holdups at subway change booths beset the Transit Authority yesterday, netting $1,783 in five attempts. But a sixth was foiled by a twoman stakeout team,

title: Statistics on Rise in Jobs Are Disputed in Alabama
description: MONTGOMERY, AlaIndustrialization is good politics in the South and because of that most state governments tend to exaggerate in reporting their industrial, progress.

title: Warnings Said to Have Saved Korean
description: TOKYO, Aug. 19Diplomati sources here and in Seoul re port that strong warnings from Japan and the United States to South Korea were instrumental in saving the life of a kidnapped South Korean opposition leader 10 days ago.

title: MET LIFE MAY SELL STUYVESANT TOWN
description: The owner of Stuyvesant Town has announced that it may sell the giant Manhattan housing project next year when a 25yearold taxrelief agreement with the city expires.

title: Smith, Van Dillen Take Cup Doubles for 21 Lead
description: ALAMO, Calif., Aug. 19As everyone, including the losersphad expected, the doubles team of Stan Smith and Eric van Dillen gave the United States a 21 lead today in the Davis Cup interzone final by beating the Rumanian pair of the Nastase and Ionel Santieu, 62, 75, 62.

title: MUSIC CORPORATION SET UP BY TIMES CO.
description: The New York Times Company announced over the weekend the formation of a new subsidiary, The New York Times Music Corporation which will begin operations on Sept. 17.

title: A Reexamination
description: NEW HAVENCivilian populations have never been entirely comfortable with returning war veterans. Underneath the admiration and honor displayed at victory parades and other homecoming rituals can lurk considerable fear at the reappearance, among them of the men they sent off to fight and kill.

title: U. S. INVESTIGATES NEW DIRTY TRICK
description: MIAMI, Aug 19New evi dence of political misinforma tion damaging to Senator Ed mund S. Muskie in the March 1972, Florida primary has beer discovered here.

title: The Running Mate Chosen by Peron Isabel Martinez de Peron
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 19 Two weeks ago, a group of young Peronists hovered around a television set in their living room to view the party convention that unanimously, selected Juan Domingo Peron and his wife, Isabel, as their presidential and vicepresidential candidates. As Isabel's image flickered on television, a girl in the living room got up and walked out in disbelief. Her companions sat transfixed, shaking their heads slowly, and displaying the uncomfortable embarrassment often caused by a flat, longwinded joke or a badly acted melodrama.

title: Mrs. Jane Berger Wed to Broker
description: HUNTINGTON VALLEY, Pa., Aug 19Mrs. Jane S. Berger of Chicago, widow of WilLiam D. Berger, was married here at noon today to Frank L. Newburger Jr., a widower, of Rydal. Rabbi Allan Fuchs performed the Ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Newburger, the bridegroom's brother and sisterinlaw.

title: Soul at Center Goes Out With Burst of Black Rock
description: The final day of Soul at the Center 73 got under way early yesterday with a pulsating performance of black rock by Bloodstone and Billy Preston that left the audience at Lincoln Center's Philharmonic Hall jumping and clapping until the very end.

title: The Dollar Strengthens
description: With more than enough bad economic news to go aroundsoaring food prices, shortages, recordhigh interest rates, a depressed stock market, a dollar that seems to shrink every time it comes out of the wallet due notice should be given to one break in the glOom: an improvement in the United States balance of payments.

title: Virginia Judge Named To Oversee Grand Jury
description: GREENVILLE, S.C., Aug. 19 (AP)A Federal judge from Virginia was appointed yesterday to supervise a special grand jury inquiry into allegations of political kickbacks involving Vice President Agnew

title: Palmer 209 Wins by Shot In L.P.G.A..
EDWARD RYAN, 67, LAWYER, IS, DEAD
description: Edward F. X. Ryan, a swim partner in the law firm of Ryan, Ryan & Ryan, 60 East 42d Street and Larchmont, N.Y., who served as Mayor of Larchmont from 1962 to 1964, died Saturday in the Albert Einstein Hospital, the Bronx. He was 67 years old and lived at 1815 Palmer Avenue, Larchmont.

title: Wadkins, on 69 for 279, Golf Victor by 2 Strokes
Nixon, at Key Biscayne Villa, Works on Address to V.F.W.
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Aug. 19 (UPI)President Nixon, who has not made a public appearance outside the White House in nearly six weeks, will make

title: Rebellious Laotian Troops Encircle Premier's Home
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Monday, Aug. 20Troops of the Laotian Army surrounded the residence of Prince Souvanna Phouma at dawn today in what was believed to be an attempt by rightwing generals to overthrow the, Government and prevent the signing of a peace agreement with the Communistfed Pathet Lao.

title: Harlem Championship Bike Race Won by Cyclist From Baltimore
description: A 35mile race was the highlight yesterday of the first Harlem Bicycle Championship, a series of races that sponsors hope will be an annual event.

title: BREW MOORE DIES; JAZZ MUSICIAN, 49
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Aug. 19 (Reuters)Brew Moore, an American jazz musician, died here this morning at Municipal Hospital, where he was taken Friday night after a fall on a staircase at the Tivoli Gardens amusement park. He was 49 years old.

title: Giants Defeat Jets, 4530, Before 70,874
description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 19The New York Giants defense yielded 600 yards today, but made the big fourthquarter plays that counted for a 45.30 victory over the Jets in another zany chapter of this intracity football rivalry.

title: Project Brings New Cooperation by State, City and Community
description: From the countless studies for a new West Side Highway and many months of discussion, a new approach to urban planning has evolved. It may have enormous impact on all major planning for this city and become a model for other metropolises.

title: Young Kennedy in Court
description: NANTUCKET, Mass., Aug. 19 (AP)Joseph P. Kennedy 3d, 21 years old, son of, the late Senator Robert F. Kennedy, was scheduled to appear in Nantucket District Court tomorrow on a charge of negligent; driving.

title: Janet Sharenow Wed
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., Aug. 19Miss Janet Sue Sharenow and Martin Jay Albert were married this afternoon in Temple Israel of Great Neck. Rabbi Israel Mowshowitz of the Hillcrest (Queens) Jewish Center and Cantor Benjamin Siegel of Temple Israel officiated. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Sharenow of Great Neck and Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Albert of Jamaica Estates, Queens. The bride's father is a certified public accountant. Mr. Albert's father is in private real estate and securities investments.

title: Bridge:Reliance on Favorite Genie Can  Set Up an Unhappy Ending
description: Literature and legend contain many examples of the following theme: A man has the apparent good fortune to discover a monkey's paw, a genie in a bottle, or some other obliging spirit who promises him one or more wishes. The fates always have a nasty surprise in store for him.

title: Anachronistic Relic
description: Seven years ago, Presidential aspirant Richard M. Nixon described the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization as somewhat anachronistic relic. That was an understatement then. It is even more so today.

title: BOYS IN PARK HELD IN ATTACK ON DECOY
description: Two brothers; 11 and 12 years old, were arrested last night after they allegedly robbed and assaulted a woman police officer posing as a bicylist in Central Park.

title: SAUDIS WEIGHING OILOUTPUT CURBS
