description: TAIF, Saudi Arabia, Aug. 16 Oil production in Saudi Arabia, the giant among the world's petroleum exporters, has surpassed this year's expansion plan and output is now close to 9 million barrels a day.

title: Keating Arrives in Israel To Begin Duties as Envoy
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 19Kenneth B. Keating arrived here this evening to take over his duties as the sixth United States Ambassador to Israel. He succeeds Walworth Harbour, who held the post 11 years until his retirement.

title: JOHN C. TABER
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., Aug. 19  John Clarkson Taber, a former president of Urner Barry Publications of Jersey City, publisher of Producers Price Current, a produce marketing paper, died today on a visit here. He was 77 years old and lived in Lakewood, N., J.

title: Screen: Guercio's Electra Glide in Blue Arrives
Black Expo Extended
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19Stanley Culbreth, promoter of Black Expo '73, announced today that the exposition here would be extended through Tuesday, rather than close today.

title: Chris Evert, Orantes Win Clay Finals
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 19. (AP)The favorites,. Chris Evert and Manuel Orantes, swept to the singles titles today in the $90,000 United States claycourt tennis championships.

title: France: Display Honors Epic Hero
description: PARISAs it does every summer, France's cultural activity has shifted to the South. From Marseilles to Nice, some remarkable artistic events are taking place. Most important of these is the huge exhibition devoted to Andre Malraux by the Fondation Maeght, at SaintPaul de Vence. The 800Arts odd items listed Abroad in the catalogue fall under two headings: documents and art.

title: S.E.C. Chief May Link 2 Fee Measures
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19The Securities and Exchange Commission is seriously considering the idea of coupling its decision on industryrequested increases in commission rates on stock transactions with the issuance of a final and definite timetable for ending the whole system of fixed commissions.

title: A Singles Convention for the Aware Adult Not the Swingers
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 19It was billed as the Singlelife celebration, the first national convention for unmarried, aware business and professional adults.

title: Weekly List of Mutual Funds
Link Hinted in Harlem and East Side Slayings
description: Residents of the lower East Side neighborhood where a 7yearold boy was killed Friday have told the police they had seen a man in the area who strongly resembled a suspect in the sexual mutilation and slaying of three youths several months ago on the upper West Side and in Harlem.

title: Many in Floral Park Irked by Vibrations From Trains
TEACHERS UNION CONVENING TODAY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19Three thousand delegates to the 57th annual convention of the American Federation of Teachers began assembling here today amid signs of at least temporary harmony in the union's divided leadership.

title: Horse Show Awards AT FREEHOLD, N. J. MONMOUTH COUNTY SHOW
description: Junior Working Hunter Championship, Division AKaren Riley's Tipsy Cake, 9 points; reserve, Pam Hamlin's Double Take, 8.Junior Working Hunter Championship, Division BChampion, Doc Severinson's Rallydale, 20 points; reserve, Susan Fubini's Eloise, 8.

title: LEADER OF COUP MADE 66 ATTEMPT
description: The reported leader of the attempted rightwing coup in Laos is Brig. Gen. Thao Ma, who was deposed as commander of the Laotian Air Force in 1966. According to reports at the time, he had been dismissed because of his zeal in conducting war against the Communistled Pathet Lao and for his failure to concentrate enough on the lucrative opium trade.

title: Tracy Tashman Bride Of David Alan Kalson
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 19Miss Tracy Nan Tashman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Malcolm Tashman of New York and Stamford, was married this afternoon to David Alan Kalson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Kalson of Pittsburgh.

title: Nixon, at Key Biscayne Villa, Works on Address to V.F.W.
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Aug. 19 (UPI)President Nixon, who has not made a public appearance outside the White House in nearly six weeks, will make a speech tomorrow that will reportedly criticize Congress for ending United States bombing in support of the Cambodian Government.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Economic Stabilization Office of the Internal Revenue Service in Newark ordered 39 wholesalers, retailers and meat packers to reduce beef prices. An I.R.S. spokesman said the 39, with improperly high prices, were among 209 places investigated last week. The spokesman said the 39 immediately complied with the order to reduce prices, thereby avoiding a possible $2,500 fine.

title: Candidates Get Acts Together
description: TRENTON, Aug, 19  The summer doldrumswhen people worry more about sunburn than about taxesis a time for rehearsal and trial and error for New Jersey's gubernatorial candidates.

title: GREEK PRESIDENT PROMISES TO FREE ALL JAILED FOES
description: ATHENS, Aug. 19George Papadopoulos, the former artillery colonel who seized power in Greece six years ago, today took the oath as the country's first President and promised an amnesty for some 300 political prisoners, including the man who tried to kill him in 1968.

title: Seoul's Vast Intelligence Agency Stirs Wide Fear
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 18 Sometimes the Koreans call it Central College and sometimes South Mountain, but whenever they speak its proper name, the Central Intelligence Agency, their voices invariably drop to a whisper.

title: Bond Rally Not Expected To Survive Much Longer
East German Trawler Seen
description: SEATTLE, Aug. 19 (UPI)An East German trawler has been sighted for the first time fishing off the United States Pacific coast, the national Marine Fisheries Service reported today. Marine Fisheries Service reported today.

title: Laotian Troops Put Down Coup Attempt by Rightists
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Monday, Aug. 20A force of Laotian troops led by exiled rightwing generals crossed into Laos before dawn today in an unsuccessful attempt to overthrow the Government of Premier Souvanna Phouma.

title: SICKLE CELL TRAIT FOUND IN ATHLETES
description: At least 39 black football players in the National Football League carry the trait for sickle cell anemia, a hereditary blood disorder that causes malformaLion of red blood cells and results in the clogging of blood vessels.

title: VETERAN AT TRIAL FACES INFORMER
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Aug. 20 Scott Camil leaned rigidly against the lectern, looking at, the man in the witness chair, and asked, Would you say we were good friends?

title: Reds in Cambodia Attempt To Close Route to Seaport
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Aug. 20After a lull that followed the cessation of American bombing in Cambodia last Wednesday, the fighting stepped up today with a Communist attempt to close a key supply road and with increasing enemy pressure on several provincial capitals.

title: SUIT SEEKS ARREST OF OIL FROM LIBYA
description: The British Petroleum Company, Ltd., and Texas oilman Nelson Bunker Hunt filed suit yesterday in Philadelphia toprevent the Coastal States Gas Corporation from marketing oilallegedly produced from nationalized fields of British Petroleum and, Hunt in Libya.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: PHILADELPHIAActivated Mike Anderson, outfielder, and sent Mike Wallace, pitcher, to Reading of Eastern League.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: ROGERS CONDEMNS PLUMBERS RAID
description: WASHINGTON, Aug, 20Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today, in discussing the Watergate scandal, that the United States must not become so obsessed with security matters that laws are freely violated.

title: Equity Financing
description: Fuqua Industries, Inc., said yesterday it would accept all shares tendered in exchange for its $15 principal amount of 9 per cent subordinated debentures during the 10day proration period since the offer became effective Aug. 7. The company said over 200,000 shares were tendered based on preliminary information. The company's common closed at 117/8, down  on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Joseph Kennedy Is Found Guilty Of Negligence in Road Mishap
description: NANTUCKET, Mass., Aug. 20 (UPI)Joseph P. Kennedy 3d, oldest son of the late Senator Robert F. Kennedy, was convicted today of negligent driving that resulted in an accident that at least temporarily paralyzed a teenage girl. He was fined $100.

title: Marx and Lenin Gaze On an Indifferent Paris
description: PARIS, Aug. 20  So few passersby on an August Sunday are Frenchmen and so many are tourists prepared for anything that the transformation of the Galeries Lafayette yesterday drew little attention.

title: COTTON PURCHASE BY CHINA CLIMBS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) China has bought at least 755,000 bales of United States cotton for delivery through next summer, far more than government officials would confirm a few weeks ago, an Agriculture Department report showed today.

title: JAMES H. LEDDY
description: HASTINGS ON HUDSON, N. Y., Aug. 20James H. Leddy, founder and president of the Hudson River Yards Corporation, a lumber organization from which he retired in 1968, died yesterday at the Phelps Memorial Hospital in Tarrytown. His age was 77 and he lived here.

title: Deere Sets Records
West Germany's Talks With 3 in Bloc Snag on Bonn's Ties With West Berlin
description: BONN, Aug. 20West Germany's negotiations to establish diplomatic relations with Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Bulgaria have hit a snag on the thorny problem of Bonn's relationship with West Berlin, according to West German officials and Eastern European sources.

title: The President Has Spoken
description: To the Editor:The pathetic element in President Nixon's Watergate address is not in his failure to refute charges against him or to remove the doubt they haire created. It is rather in his inability to assess the depth and significanne of the crisis Watergate has created for the republic.

title: Connecticut Candidates Cautioned Against Secret Contributions
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 20  Dean spite, a recent ruling that Gov. Thomas J. Meskill was innocent of any wrongdoing in not reporting a secret $67,500 campaign contribution from former White House aides in 1970, any other state or local candidate accepting a similar secret contribution will still be subject to prosecution, Gloria Schaffer, the Secretary of State, warned today.

title: Bridge: Two Lines of Play May Hide A Strategy Superior to Both
description: The declarer who has two lines of play available often has trouble in deciding between them. And in the heat of battle it is easy to overlook a third line that is superior to both.

title: Books of The Times
description: If Exterminator had not been written by William Burroughs, would say that one of the most primitive and unsuccessful attempts at black humor that I have ever read. Then I would go on to support that statement with a description of the book and some quotationi that speak for themselves. However, William Burroughs is also the author of Naked Lunch. He is the grand guru of the fictive puton, so cannot pick up his latest novel and just read it as if that is what books were for.

title: IndianPakistani Talks Focus on Biharis
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 20  Efforts to resolve the political deadlock on the subcontinent

title: New Golden Gate Victim
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 20 (UPI)  An unidentified man about 40 years old leaped from the Golden Gate Bridge yesterday, bringing to 494 the number of known suicides from the span.

title: CHICKEN AND PORK FALL IN PRICE HERE AS SHOPPERS BALK
description: Chicken, and pork prices tumbled in the metropolitan area yesterday, a drop attributed varyingly to consumer resistance to previous high prices and to the possibility that hoarders had filled their home freezers and gone out of the market for a while.

title: Chinese Face Big Task in Restoring State and Party Structures if Rumored Communist Parley Is Held
Hearings Set on Increase In Steel and Auto Prices
description: The Government said yesterday it would hold public hearings this month on the steel and automobile price increases that were announced last week at the end of the Nixon Administration's 60day price freeze.

title: Threats Are Linked to ExPoliceman
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 20The authorities obtained a Federal warrant today charging 29yearold former policeman with multiple threats to kill President Nixon during his visit here.

title: Amex Seat Price Declines
description: The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that a membership had been sold for $35,000, off $5,000 from the previous sale Aug. 15, The current market in Amex seats is $35,000 bid, $40,000 asked.

title: Dollar Turns Weak Again To Bafflement of Dealers
description: LONDON, Aug. 20 (AP)The dollar came under pressure on European money markets today, weakening in major centers as the price of gold rose by $5 an ounce Zurich and $7.60 in London. The dollar's dip followed a reversal Friday after strong advances in seven straight sessions. Dealers had attributed the strength to higher United States interest rates and improved United States balanceofpayments figures, which they said were attract funds back into dollars.

title: Leader of Thwarted Coup In Laos Dies in Air Crash
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 20An exiled Laotian Air Force general who tried to overthrow the Government here today died after a small plane he was flying was shot down near the end of the airport runway.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The Ford Foundation has awarded a grant of $1.5million to Joseph Papp's New York Shakespeare Festival for the organization's multiple operation. Mr. Papp, who announced the grant yesterday, said the funding was divided into an outright grant of $500,000 and a challenge grant of up to $1million, at $1 for every $3 raised by the festival from other sources over a threeyear period.

title: Retailers Near Highs
description: Two of the nation's largest retailers, Sears, Roebuck & Co., and the S. S. Kresge Company, posted their highest sales and earnings for any quarter on record except the Christmas period, according to midyear statements issued yesterday.

title: TV: Pressure Tactics Testing Networks'
description: The networks can't be all bad. In the face of several recent incidents in which they were accused of bias by some special interests, houndedby various pressure groups and rebuffed by a group of advertisers, they are almost beginning to look heroic.

title: BIOGRAPHY SERIES GETS NEW EDITOR
description: The Dictionary of American Biography is a hugely presti gious work, a sort of Mouton Rothschild among reference books, and like rare wine, the information it contains has been reaching the customers at a fairly ripe age: the D.A.B.'s Third Supplement, published east March, profiled noted Americans who died anywhere from 28 to 32 years ago.

title: AMNESTY IS GIVEN TO 300 IN GREECE
description: ATHENS, Aug. 20President George Papadopoulos, decreeing a general amnesty for more than 300 jailed political foes, absolved their jailers tonight of any charges of torture or illegal detention.

title: Fed Sets Hearing On Bank Ownership Of Savings Units
Hearings Set on Increase In Steel and Auto Prices
description: The Government said yesterday it would hold public hearings this month on the steel and automobile price increases that were announced last week at the end of the Nixon Administration's 60day price freeze.

title: 3 City Democratic Candidates Campaign Together
description: Campaigning together for the first time, the three Democratic candidates for citywide officenominated in separate, freeforall primariesaccepted a union's endorsement and a $25,000 check from its political action fund yesterday.

title: Government Restraints Have Subdued Those Papers That Survive in Saigon
Another Drug Abuse
description: Drug addiction apparently is not confined to victims of the habit. The city administration itself seems addicted to continuing the financial support of drug treatment programs even after their uselessness has beenauthoritatively established.

title: ROGERS CONDEMNS PLUMBERSRAID
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today, in discussing the Watergate scandal, that the United States must not become so obsessed with security matters that laws are freely violated.

title: FANNIN ADMITS GUILT IN DRUNKEN DRIVING
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Aug. 20 (AP) Senator Paul J. Fannin, Republican of Arizona, pleaded guilty today to a charge of driving while intoxicated.

title: Israelis Charge Lebanese For Handling Jetliner
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 20 (UPI) Israeli authorities sent a $1,666 bill to the Paris office of Lebanon's Middle East Airlines yesterday for the costs of handling a jetliner forced to land at the Tel Aviv airport by an Arab hijacker.

title: Foster 41 Choice To Beat Fourie
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Aug. 20 (UPI)  Bob Foster will defend his world lightheavyweight boxing title for a record 1 1 th time tomorrow night when he meets Pierre Fourie of South Africa in a bout contrasting Fourie's speed with Foster's power.

title: Rogers Sees Urgency for Arms Pact
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today that the Soviet Union's successful flighttesting Of a new missile system had made it a matter of greater urgency than before for Washington and Moscow to carry out their pledge to reach a treaty putting limits on offensive strategic weapons by the end of 1974.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: ADMIRALTY ISLAND, Alaska  Hovering on the edge of a snowfed stream in water so cold it hurt to drink it, hordes of searun Dolly Varden trout smashed our flies recklessly.

title: BENJAMIN J. DARLING
description: JERSEY CITY, Aug. 20 Benjamin J. Darling, a past president of the Hudson County Bar Association, died Saturday in the Hudson Manor Nursing Home in North Bergen. He was 94 years old.

title: Nixon Disappointment Is Seen at Cancellation
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 20President Nixon appeared to be disappointed scheduled motorcade down Canal Street in New Orleans had been canceled because of an alleged assassination conspiracy.

title: Legislature Meets Sept. 10 In Trenton on Jobless Pay
description: TRENTON, Aug. 20  The New Jersey Legislature will return for a special oneday session Sept. 10 to enact emergency legislation providing for an additional $25million in unemployment compensation benefits and to act on some anticipated gubernatorial appointments.

title: Point Climb Led by First of Chicago
description: More than a dozen of the nation's largest banks yesterday raised their prime interest rate to a record 9 per cent, but lending officers and economists predicted the rate would go higherperhaps to 10 per cent or even more.

title: Head of Teachers Union Optimistic on Merger
description: WASHINGTON, Aug 20 David Selden,president of Teachers, told the union's annual convention today that WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 David Selden, president of the American Federation of the opportunity for teacher unity is at hand in the forthcoming merger talks between the federation and the rival National Education Associatibn.

title: Music: White Mountains Arts Fete
description: JEFFERSON, N. H., Aug. 20  High in the northern mountains of this relentlessly beautiful state, a music festival was born this month and it's doing just fine. The White Mountains Art and Music Festival, conceived by a consortium of artistic, educational and business organizations last spring, closed its first, brief season last night in a candystriped tent on the grounds of the 113yearold Waumbek Inn here.

title: Familiarity Paired With Flying Frenzy In Turners'
description: Ike and Tina Turner's familiar Revueby now, since it is more or less unchanged, very familiarclosed at Soul at the Center 73 series at Philharmonic Hall on Sunday evening. Tina Turner, long hair flying, gogo costumed and all frepzy, is very much the soul at the center of the Turner Revue.

title: Waste of Park Funds Laid To Agency in New Haven
description: HARTFORD Aug. 20 (UPI)The Connecticut Citizen Research Group said today that New Haven was wasting nearly $2million on parks programs no one knew anything about, a horticulture department that plants no gardens, and parks too neglected to be used.

title: 32 AUXILIARY POLICE WILL KEEP WORKING
description: The 32 members of the auxiliary police force of the 72d Precinct in South Brooklyn, who had turned in their badges last Friday after five of their number were summarily suspended for allegedly drinking on duty, agreed last night to go back to work pending an inquiry into the drinking charges.

title: Wildlife Director Named
description: ALBANY, Aug. 20 (AP)Herbert Doig, 38 years old, wildlife biologist, has been named director of the Division of Fish and Wildlife in the Department of Environmental Conservation, the department announced today. He succeeds Albert Hall, who has become executive director of the Temporary Commission to Study the Catskills.

title: Did English Putthe Boot To Atoms?
description: Until Sunday morning, only one team, the Dallas Tornado, stood between the Philadelphia Atoms and the championship of the North American Soccer League. But by noon, there were two teams. The second was Southport of the English League Third Division. How did this come about?

title: SCHOOLS IN HOUSTON OPEN DESPITE STRIKE
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 20  The bargaining organization for teachers of the Houston Independent School District voted last night to strike today on the opening of school over the school board's refusal to grant a $1,100ayear pay increase.

title: Radio
9% Prime Rate Set
description: Prime interest ratesthe rates charged their most creditworthy customers by banks  were raised yesterday by more than a dozen of the nation's largest banks to a record of 9 per cent, up from 9. Page 41.

title: Business Briefs
description: United States businesses, which increased their capital expenditures 2 per cent abroad last year compared with 1971, plan to raise them by 652billion in the next three years, McGrawHill said yesterday.

title: Riva Ridge Runs Today in $15,000 Race at Spa: He's Favored
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 20Broadway, this city's main street, has been decked withbanners matching the blue and white silks of the Meadow Stable since several weeks before the current meeting began. It was all in anticipation of smashing triumphs by;: the stable's Star, this year's Triple Crown winner, Secretariat, and by Riva Ridge, who carried the colors to success in laSt year's Kentucky Derby. and Belmont Stakes.

title: Dominguez Tops Richey At Toronto
Chloroform Threat Forces A Curb on Water Systems
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 20 (AP)Municipal water systems on the Mississippi River south of. Baton Rouge were ordered to close their intake valves today to avoid contamination by 64,000 gallons of potentially lethal chloroform.

title: Chess: 3 RunnersUp in Interzonal Now Must Play Off the Tie
Ford Recalls 14,692 Cars For Possible Steering Flaw
description: DEARBORN, Mich., Aug. 20 (UPI)  The Ford Motor Company announced today the recall of 14,692 Torinos and Rancheros fpr a possible faulty pinchbolt causing eventual loss of steering control.

title: Thieves Get $3,000 In 29thFloor Suites Of Americana Hotel
description: Midtown detectives began hunt yesterday for thieves who stole about $3,000 in cash, jewelry and clothing Sunday night from six rooms on the 29th floor of the Americana Hotel.

title: PRODUCTION OF STEEL ROSE 0.4% IN WEEK
Philadelphia Paper Denies Tip by Rizzo On Investigative Unit
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20 The Philadelphia Bulletin said today that its staff had worked for months on an article about a special police unit allegedly used by Mayor Frank L. Rizzo to investigate political enemies and had not been tipped by the Mayor just before the article appeared in The Bulletin and competitor, The Philadelphia Inquirer, on Aug. 5.

title: Schools to Crack Down on Truancy
description: TRENTON, Aug. 20  With the opening of school less than a month away, a number of school districts around the state are planning a vigorous crackdown on truancy this year.

title: Marx and Engels Studied the Works Of Lewis Morgan
description: Lewis Henry Morgan (18181881), a Rochester lawyer who devoted most of his life to anthropological study, undertook the first investigations and scientific writings on the American Indian and came to be known as the father of American anthropology.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation has received a 55.3million Air Force contract for Titan II space launch rockets, it was announced yesterday.

title: P.S.C. Reports Big Drop In Complaints on Phones
description: A sharp decline in the number of customer complaints to the State Public Service Commission about the New York Telephone Company's service during the last three years, particularly in the New York City area, was reported yesterday by the state agency.

title: Plan for Candlewood Lake City Stirs Fear of Urbanized Suburb
description: NEW FAIRFIELD Conn., Aug. 20Is the new City of homes, stores and community services that will open up the American suburban dream, to 8,000 residents of varied racial and economic backgrounds a utopia?

title: Leader of Thwarted Coup In Laos Dies in Air Crash
description: VIENTIANE,Laos, Aug. 20An exiled Laotian Air Force general who tried to overthrow the Government here today died after a small plane he was flying was shot down near the end of the airport runway.

title: Baker Captures Cup In Power Regatta
description: RED BANK, N. J. (AP) Aug. 20  Tom Baker of Queenstown, Md., won the Governor's Cup Grand Prix yesterday in the 34th annual National Sweepstakes power boat regatta on the Navesink River.

title: Fasting for Justice
description: Cesar Chavez and hundreds of his followers in California's striferacked vineyards have turned from the picket line to a threeday fast as a nonviolent protest against the killing of two members of Mr. Chavez's United Farm Workers and the injuring of many others. The growing casualty list is a tragic byproduct of the tiny union's struggle to.stay alive in the face of the crushing alliance formed against it by the grape growers and the giant International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: Loan to Lockheed Grows
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (Reuters)  The Emergency Loan Board today approved a request by Lockheed Aircraft Corporation that it be permited to borrow an additional 30million under its government guaranteed credit line with a group of banks. Lockheed has borrowed $150millin of the $250million under government guarantee.

title: Sports. News Briefs
description: TORONTO, Aug. 20 (AP)Red Kelly, a former defenseman and center with the Detroit Red Wings and Toronto Maple Leafs, has been named Toronto coach, the National Hockey League club announced tonight.

title: Shops in Wall St. Area Outperform Brokers
description: On Wall Street, business has been a disaster this year for brokers. But for the shops that sell shirts and skirts and picture frames and tennis rackets to brokers and their clerks and secretaries it is a somewhat different story. At least they are doing better than the DowJones.

title: AMERICAN EXPORT IS NAMED IN SUIT
description: A $54 million declaratory judgment against American Export Industries, Inc., and several of its directors and officers, was asked for yesterday in a suit filed here in Federal District court by the Independent Investor Protective League. Other plaintiffs in the action are Richard A. Gordon, Frank Gordon, the Israel Patents Corporation and the Innovators Management & Capital Corporation.

title: General Bradley Gaining
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 20 (UPI) A spokesman at the University of California at Los Angeles medical center said yesterday that Gen. Omar N. Bradley was in satisfactory condition. General Bradley, 80 years old, has continued to improve since last Friday, the day after he underwent an Operation to halt blood clotting in his lungs, the hospital said.

title: Why Ambulances Are Coming Faster
description: At 1:01 P.M. yesterday, a doctor on the Lower East Side picked up his phone, dialed 911  the emergency number  and reported that a patient in his office had suffered cardiac arrest.

title: Capt. William Holman Dies, ExSubmarine Commander
description: Capt. William G. Holman, U.S.N., retired, a submarine officer and commander in World War II who was naval attache in Madrid before his retirement, in 1961, died Saturday in Bethesda (Md.) Naval Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived in the Georgetown section of Washington.

title: Hearings Strengthen Watergate Senators
description: The Watergate hearings that have made Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., a national folk figure have strengthened each of the six other Watergate Senators in their home states.

title: Weight Loss At the Urging of a Disembodied Voice
description: Click. The tape recorder is turned on and a man's voice comes oozing out of the speaker. Hello, this is Dr. Parrish, he says warmly. Every day I meet a lot of people, and I notice many people are seriously concerned about their weight.

title: GIBSON DENOUNCES PROTESTING GROUP
description: NEWARK, Aug. 20Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson, in angry and combative tones, told approximately 75 Central Ward residents demanding better cleanup efforts in their area that he would not be intimidated by their demonstrations and protests.

title: Skylab 2 Crewmen Fail to Find Nonserious Leaks in 2 Devices
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 20 (AP)Two Skylab 2 astronauts became plumbers today, using stethoscopes and soapy water in an unsuccessful search for leaks in two systems aboard the orbiting space station.

title: 8 STUDY PROSPECTS FOR GAS PIPELINE
description: Eight of the nation's largest natural gas companies yesterday announced that they were jointly studying the feasibility and construction requirements of a major new gas transmission system from a point on the border of the western United States and Canada to midwestern and eastern ,regions of the United States.

title: Advertising: Nostalgic Shirley
description: After spending two years outside the ghetto of Saturday and Sunday morning television advertising,. the. Ideal Toy Corporation is reentering this fall with its eyes wide open.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A young Jerseyan who had to battle the United States Merchant Marine Academy in Federal Court for his diploma said yesterday that he would not be going to sea after all. Dennis O'Neill of Irvington, Class of 72, was forced out of the academy at Kings Point, L. I., in November, 1971, after an anonymous caller informed officials that, contrary to the rules, he was married and the father of two small sons. A court order permitted him to finish his courses up to graduation time.

title: FILES SUBPOENAED AT REBOZO'S BANK
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20The Senate's Watergate investigating committee has subpoenaed financial records of the Key Biscayne (Fla.) Bank and Trust Company, which is operated by Charles G. Rebozo, President Nixon's close personal friend, according to committee sources.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: BEDMINSTER, Aug. 20The 25th annual National Amputee Golf Association championship opens tomorrow the Fiddler's Elbow Country Club with the qualifying round of 18 holes. For the first time it is an open tournament. There will be money prizes since some golfers are now professionals.

title: Stock Options Listed
description: Starting today, The New York Times is listing the statistics of stock options trading on the Chicago Board Options Exchange. The listings report the nearest option month of each stock. The table appears at the end of the New York Stock Exchange. listings. Page 45.

title: National Cancer Plan
description: Cancer claims so many victims each year that the desire to eradicate it knows no political boundaries. That urge was demonstrated vividly several years ago when almost everyone in Washington seemed infected with euphoria about the possibilities of conquering cancer if only enough money were spent. For a time a classic confrontation on the matter appeared to be building up between President Nixon and Senator Edward M. Kennedy, each maneuvering for eventual credit when, as and if cancer was cured. Finally a compromise measure was adopted and Congress, glowing with rectitude, turned to other matters while medical specialists struggled with details of the assignment.

title: People and Business
description: J. E. Lonning, 57, president of the Kellogg Company, yesterday was named chairman of the board of the food products manufacturer headquartered in Battle Creek, Mich. He replaces Lyle C. Roll, 65, who retired as chairman of the board but who will continue as vice chairman of the board and chairman of the executive committee.

title: CITY SEES THREAT IN BRENNAN MEMO
description: The United States Department of Labor has been accused of threatening to deny Federal assistance to contracts here that contain the city's fairgmployment requirements.

title: NO TRACE IS FOUND OF MISSING OFFICER
description: The Police Department's internal affairs division yesterday assumed direction of the investigation into the mysterious disappearance of Police Officer Robert Cameric, who apparently left his Queens apartment with his family last Wednesday and has been missing since.

title: MISSING NEWSMAN TURNS UP IN ROME
description: ROME, Aug, 20An American television newsman here who disappeared on July 22 reappeared today and was immediately charged with embezzlement and fabricating a crime.

title: Pentagon Curtails Officers Servants And Defines Duties
description: WASHINGTON, Aug, 20 (AP) The Pentagon issued an order today strictly limiting the use of enlisted men as servants for generals and admirals and cutting back the number of these enlisted aides by about 500 men.

title: Notes on People
description: Saying he expected to have an exciting future, Nathan Leventhal, New York City's Rent Commissioner, said he was resigning to go to work for a Senate subcommittee headed by Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

title: CIVILIANS PREPARE TO DIRECT TRAFFIC
description: The first of the city's new civilian traffic controllers will take to midtown intersections next Monday to free traffic police officers for crimefighting duties.

title: Excerpts From the President's Speech
description: Following are excerpts from President Nixon's address to the convention of Veterans of Foreign Wars in New Orleans yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times, through the facilities of A.B.C. News:

title: CHICKEN AND PORK FALL IN PRICE HERE AS SHOPPERS BALK
description: Chicken and pork prices tumbled in the metropolitan area yesterday, a drop attributed varyingly tb consumer resistance to previous high prices and to the possibility that hoarders had filled their home freezers and gone out of the market for a while.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Aug. 21,.1975 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Treasury Bill Rates Fall at Weekly Sale
Thomas Has A Problem: Unruly Fans
description: In South America they have moats between the fans and players at soccer games. The same may be coming at pro football games. George Allen plans to ask Commissioner Pete RazeIle for extra protection behind the visiting team's tieuch at future events. Not just for the Redskins or for Duane Thomas, said Allen. It's needed throughout the league where fans are close to the field.

title: MRS. KNICKERBOCKER
description: BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 20  Mrs. Frances W. Knickerbocker, a former English instructbr at Vassar College and a suffragist who led a women's rights march on Fifth Avenue in New York in 1919, died here Friday in Mount Desert Island Hospital. She was 85 years old, the widow of Dr. William. S. Knickerbocker,

title: As for prurient interest  whose?; The Average Person
description: Who is the average person?

title: Cattle Prices Fall Again; Corn and Soybeans Down
description: The recent slump in live cattle prices accelerated yesterday and dragged corn and soybean futures quotations down to, or near the daily permissible limits on Midwest exchanges.

title: Broadway Central Hotel Officially Declared Unsafe
description: Soventeen days after the collapse of the old Broadway Central , Hotel, resulting in two known deaths, its ruins were fornially declared unsafe yesterday by State Supreme Court Justice Sidney A. Fine.

title: CoverUp
description: The inner history of the Nixon Administration is a series of coverups because there is much to be concealed. The unifying fact beneath these coverups is the President's direct, personal relationship with the seamy side of his Administration. He is not the preoccupied, innocent victim of his overzealous aides. The style of politics that the White House has played during these Nixon years is a style that he inspired, encouraged and approved.

title: Gerald Eskenazi
description: It was noon in East New York and quiet. The street in Brooklyn used to be known simply as Schenck and Sutter, a street wide enough for cars to park on either side and for boys to play between.

title: AMEX PRICES OFF IN SLOW TRADING
Hurricane Brenda Aims For Vera Craz Coast
description: MIAMI, Aug. 20 (AP)Brenda became the season's second hurricane today, aiming its 75mileanhour winds at the Mexican coast southeast of Vera Cruz, the National Hurricane Center reported.

title: Welfare Island Name Changed to Roosevelt
description: Mayor Lindsay signed legislation yesterday officially renaming Welfare Island as Franklin D. Roosevelt Island. This was the fifth time the 147acre tract in the East River had been ren amed,

title: G.O.P. Spy Linked to a Kennedy Note
description: A writer who spied on Senator George McGovern's Presidential campaign last year at the request of an adviser to President Nixon also created a stir in 1965 by trying to auction a note written by Mrs. John F. Kennedy to Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson.

title: People in Sports: Indians'
description: Gaylord Perry, the Indians controversial pitcher who won the American League's Cy Young Award last year, is available for trade if the proper offer is made, according to Phil Seghi, the Cleveland general manager.

title: White House Reported Requesting Silence on Agnew
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP)The Nixon Administration cautioned some key Republican members of Congress today against making hasty public statements about the possibility that criminal charges would be filed against Vice President Agnew, Government sources said today.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Broad Spectrum of Writers Attacks Obscenity Ruling
description: Breakfast of Champions, the current bestseller, has all the bad words. It scatologically attacks the American flag, the national anthem, a symbolic Pontiac dealer, and it is larded with stylized sketches, such as a freeform asterisk representing the bottommost orifice of the human anatomy.

title: To the Courts
description: The first of the legal confrontations over President Nixon's attitudes toward the Watergate conspiracy will be joined in earnest tomorrow. Opposing lawyers representing the President and the special Watergate prosecutor, Archibald Cox, are to present oral arguments on whether Mr. Nixon should or should not be required to produce taperecorded evidence sought for criminal prosecutions. The issue will eventually pass from Judge John Siricd of the Federal District Court up to the United States Supreme Court, and will be many weeks, maybe months, under adjudication.

title: A Happy Ending for Ugly Duckling
description: Without fuss or feather, the Ugly Duckling was found early yesterday morning near a junk yard close to Shea Stadium. The statue was none the worse and was ready for more shin ing of its bronze coat by the movements of laughing children.

title: Vaccine for Horses Sought
description: BRENTWOOD, N. H., Aug. 20 (UPI)  A veterinarian's assistant made a rush trip today to Albany, N. Y. for more vaccine with which to fight an apparent outbreak of eastern equine encephalitis, which has killed 23 horses to date.

title: MATTER IN SPACE TERMED LIMITED
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 20Princeton University astronomers say they have determined an estimate for the density of the universe that is much lower than expected.

title: Truckers'
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 20The Chilean Government held lastditch talks with transport leaders today to try to find a solution to the truckers strike before it snowballed into a national catastrophe.

title: NIXON SAYS RAIDS ON CAMBODIA IN '69 WERE NECESSARY
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 20President Nixon, speaking to friendly audience of war veterans, today defended his order for secret bombing of Cambodia in 1969, saying it had been absolutely necessary to save American lives and to move the war in Southeast Asia to the negotiating table.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: KINGS RICHES You don't have to live in Brooklyn (Kings County) to enjoy the trio of arts and cultural institutions clustered magnificently on Eastern Parkway just beyond the arch in Grand Army Plaza. AU you have to do is go there, and it is emphatically worth the trip to see the Brooklyn Public Library, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden and the Brooklyn Museum.

title: Americans Take Two Relay Races
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 20 (UPI)The United States captured its first two gold medals of the World University Games today but the Soviet Union continued its domination on its home field by winning five events on the final day of track and field competition.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: New York City detectives began a hunt for thieves who stole about $3,000 in cash, jewelry and clothing Sunday night from six rooms of the 29th floor of the Americana Hotel on Seventh Avenue between 52d and 53d Streets in Manhattan. The police, who said that it was unusual for so many rooms to be burglarized at one time on one floor, estimated that about 800 thefts a year were reported from the approximately 100 hotels in the midtown area.

title: Vaccine for Rabies Developed, Cutting Shots From 14 to 1
description: GENEVA, Aug. 20A new rabies vaccine has been developed that is expected to reduce greatly the number of deaths from that dread disease, particularly in less developed areas.

title: Cahill Signs Accord for $5Million in U.S. Flood Aid
description: TRENTON, Aug. 20Governor Cahill signed an agreement with the Federal Governinent today to provide about $5million to repair public fatilities damaged by floods in Somerset, Essex, Middlesex and Union Counties earlier this month.

title: Steel Mill Outlay Planned
description: WASHINGTON, Pa., Aug 20 (Reuters)  The Washington Steel Corporation said today its directors had approved the spending of $18million for new mill designed to roll hot stainless steel coils from slabs

title: ADDICT SOUGHT HERE IN KILLING OF BOY, 7
description: The Police Department yesterday ordered its anticrime units throughout the city to visit methadone centers in their commands to search for a suspect in the slaying of a 7yearold boy on Friday.

title: Search Yields No Bodies
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 20 (AP)Investigators searched a lonely beach on the east end of Galveston Island today but found no more bodies in the Houston mass murders case that already has claimed 27 victims.

title: 3 Adhesive Sprays Are Banned on Link To Genetic Damage
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) The Consumer Product Safety Commission declared today three aerosol spray adhesive! an imminent hazard to public health because of their possible link to genetic damage Retail sales of the products were banned.

title: Young Footballers Getting Ready, Too
description: FARMINGDALE, L.I, Aug. 20  For the last two weeks of this muggy summer, 8yearold and yearold boys have been learning, to play football while, only a few yards away, girls of the same age have been learning to be cheerleaders for the Farmingdale Hawks.

title: U.S. and Chinese Libraries Trade Books
Lineman Savors Ramble That Gave. Giants a Second Wind
description: Untilhe suddenly found himself juggling a football for possession, Carter Campbell never fancied himself a runner.

title: Pants
description: A New York department store is selling wellworn blue jeans for $15 pair, about $6 or $7 more than the price of new, unworn blue jeans. Here is wealth to stagger the mind of Croesus.

title: U.S. Orders Electrical Union To Enroll 25 Minority Workers
description: NEWARK, Aug. 20 (AP)A Federal judge today ordered the state's largest electrical union local to enroll 25 black and Hispanic workers.

title: Riessen Wins, U.S. Reaches Cup Final
description: ALAMO, Calif., Aug. 20Marty Riessen, whose selection over Tom Gorman had caused a modest controversy, gave the United States the deciding point in the Davis Cup interzone tennis series today by beating Toma Ovici of Rumania, 61, 46, 61, 75.

title: Agnew Is Seeking List of 3,000 Contracts Awarded in Maryland Since 1962
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 20 Vice President Agnew, who promised over the weekend to fight to clear his name, has asked for a list of 3,000 contracts awarded by the Maryland Board of Public Works since 1962.

title: Russians Warned Not to Write to the Voice of America
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 20  The Voice of America has been denounced here as a subversive radio station operated for the purpose of gathering intelligence about Soviet listeners.

title: Motorcade Dropped in New Orleans
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 The Secret Service announced today that it had uncovered possible conspiracy to assassinate President Nixon in New Orleans. The President abandoned a planned fiveblock motorcade through the city's historic French Quarter after the Secret Service strongly recommended that he do so.

title: 6 in Congress Protest Free Time For Chamber's Pollution Views
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) Six Congressmen urged the three major television networks today not to give free air time to a United States Chamber of Commerce approach to pollution message.

title: Oldest Briion Is Dead At 112 Years, 39 Days
description: LONDON, Aug. 20 (Reuters) Britain's oldest inhabitant, Miss Alice Stevenson, died here Saturday at the age of 112 years and 39 days.

title: Royals Win, 62, Rout Stottlemyre
Chemical Order to Lummus
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 20 (Reuters)Combusion Engineering, Inc, said today that its C.E. Lummus division had been awarded a contract by the Gulf Oil Chemical Company, a division of the Gulf Oil Corporation, for construction of a plant at Cedar Bayou, Tex., to produce 1.2 million pounds of ethylene a year. Cost was not given, but trade sources put it, at between $90million and 100million.

title: Woman Is Named Guard, First in Prison for Men
description: TRENTON, Aug. 20  Mrs. Yvonne CabeII, who could not be shocked or dissuaded, today became the first woman correction officer in an allmale New Jersey prison,

title: Chemical Order to Lummus
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 20 (Reuters)Combusion Engineering, Inc, said today that its C.E. Lummus division had been awarded a contract by the Gulf Oil Chemical Company, a division of the Gulf Oil Corporation, for construction of a plant at Cedar Bayou, Tex., to produce 1.2 million pounds of ethylene a year. Cost was not given, but trade sources put it at between $90million and 100million.

title: A Chic Model of the 40's Now Plays One of the Nastiest Ladies That's Ever Been
description: To the soap opera fans who settle down to N.B.C.TV's The Doctors every afternoon, there seems to be something familiar about the face of Mona Aldrich, the proper Bostonian who is trying to break up her doctor son's marriage with all the skill of a female Machiavelli.

title: Mistrial Called on Charge Of Police Narcotics Sale
description: An allmale jury in Special Narcotics Part of State Supreme Court reported late last night that it was unable to reach verdict in the case of a suspended Brooklyn police officer accused of selling marijuana to a fellow officer. Justice Alfred M. Ascione then declared a mistrial at 11:40 P.M.

title: Motorcade Dropped in New Orleans
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 The Secret Service announced today that it had uncovered a possible conspiracy to assassinate President Nixon in New Orleans. The President abandoned a planned fiveblock motorcade, through the city's historic French Quarter after the Secret Service strongly recommended that he do so.

title: Cattle Prices Fall Again; Corn and Soybeans Down
description: The recent slump in live cattle prices accelerated yesterday and dragged corn and soybean futures quotations down to, or near the daily permissible limits on Midwest exchanges.

title: Prague and Peking
description: Historians are always warning us, and rightly so, not to be precipitous in judging the consequences of particular historical events. Their argument is that it requires the passage of time to see all of any event's ramifications and results. It is an argument hard to refute.

title: Hunt Declares His Lawyer Withdrew at Cox Request
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (UPI) E. Howard Hunt Jr., a convicted Watergate conspirator, says his lawyer withdrew from his case at the urging of the special prosecutor, Archibald Cox.

title: Bogus Health Aide Preys on Stores
description: A man claiming to be an inspector for the city's Health Department, described as extremely goodlooking and a fasttalker in both Italian and English, is being sought in Brooklyn after shaking down at least 17 shopkeepers for $15 to $125 each since June.

title: Threats Are Linked to ExPoliceman
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 20The authorities obtained a Federal warrant today charging 29yearold former policeman with multiple threats to kill President Nixon during his visit here.

title: GERALD B. FENTON
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 20 (AP)  Gerald B. Fenton, a member of the board of trustees of Battelle Memorial Institute since it was created in 1925, died yesterday at his home here. He was 80 years old.

title: Tanner, Gottfried Upset In Eastern Grass Tennis
Laundered Jets
description: The United States Government has added insult injury with its decision to sell to Franco Spain eight British warplanes, ordered ostensibly for the Marines.

title: 2 Tax Lawyers Aid Nixon In Preparing Finance Case
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 Two of the nation's most eminent tax lawyers are working is consultants to the special White House staff group that is preparing President Nixon's defense against charges of possible wrongdoing ranging from politics to personal finance.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A fireman saved a 4yearold girl by reaching down from the roof of a fourstory building and taking the child from the arms of her cousin. Fire Department officials said that Henry Gmelin, a fiveyear department veteran, was on the roof of 850 Bedford Avenue in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn when he heard cries coming from the fourthfloor apartment directly below him.

title: 2 Women Drown Off Boat Cruising in Great South Bay
description: EAST ISLIP, L.I. Aug. 20 (UPITwo women fell overboard and drowned in a boating accident yesterday in the Great South Bay off this community.

title: 9% Prime Rate Set
description: Prime interest ratesthe rates charged their most creditworthy customers by banks  were raised yesterday by more than a dozen of the nation's largest banks to.a record of 9 per cent, up from 9. Page 41.

title: ORDER IS DELAYED IN MILKFUND CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (UPI) Federal District Judge William B. Jones ruled today that the White House does not have to comply with his order to turn over several documents until an appeals,court rules on President Nixon's claims of executive privilege.

title: DR. CHARLES CRAMER OF FLUSHING CENTER
description: Dr. Charles Cramer, head of the department of medicine of Flushing Hospital and Medical Center since 1953 and former president of its medical board,, died Saturday in the hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 3316 157th Street, Flushing, Queens.

title: EMPLOYES OF U.M.W. STRIKE OVER PENSION
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (UPI) Employes of the United Mine Workers welfare fund, negotiating their first contract as an independent union, went on strike today in a dispute over pension funding.

title: Adopting Vietnam's Orphans: Efforts Grow to Make It Easier
description: Two religious social service agencies, one Protestant and the other Roman Catholic, have begun programs to arrange the adoption of South Vietnamese orphans by American couples.

title: U.S. Sends Disaster Aid to Pakistan
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP)The Government has sent disaster teams with 10 motorized boats from Okinawa to Pakistan to assist rescue operations and to reach villages isolated by recent floods.

title: 15 High Employes Of Oil Companies Waive Immunity
description: Fifteen highranking employes of four major oil companies have signed waivers of immunity and testified in an investigation by the State Attorney General's office into possible collusion in public bidding for gasoline and diesel fuel contracts worth millions.

title: Motorola, in Aiwa Accord, To Sell Color TV in Japan
description: Motorola, Inc., announced yesterday an agreement with the Aiwa Company, Ltd., a leading Japanese consumer electronics concern to market Americanmade largescreen color television sets in Japan.

title: 8.5% DROP FOUND IN NASSAU CRIME
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 20 A drop in the crime rate in Nassau County after two decades of steady rise was reported here today by the Police Department.

title: CITY CONSULTANTS GET $172.5MILLION
description: The cost of New York City's contracts with outside consultants has risen to $172.5million a year, compared with a $8million annual level at the end of Mayor Robert F. Wagner's administration.

title: Dr. Frederick H. Frost, 71, A Paper Processing Pioneer
description: PORTLAND, Me., Aug, 20 (UPI)Dr. Frederick H. Frost, a pioneer in the paperprocessing industry, died today at hospital here. He was 71 years old.

title: Barclays Sets Chicago Unit
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 20 (Reuters) Barclays Bank, Ltd., said it would file an application with Illinois authorities to open a branch in Chicago under new state legislation allowing foreign banks to operate single branches. Barclays has had a representative office here since 1970.

title: Air Sergeant Held On Spying Charges In Aid to Russians
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (UPI)A 35yearold Air Force sergeant has been charged with espionage for allegedly trying to pass secret military documents to a Russian agent in New York City last month, the Defense Department said today.

title: Vaccine for Rabies Developed, Cutting Shots From 14 to 1
description: GENEVA, Aug. 20A new rabies vaccine has been developed that is expected to reduce greatly the number of deaths from that dread disease, paiticularly in less developed areas.

title: Roundup: Orioles'
description: The Minnesota Twins went into the last of the ninth inning at Baltimore's Memorial Stadium last night, leading, 34. What happened in the next few minutes is a perfect example of the old cliche, the game is not over until the last out. The Orioles scored three runs for a 43 victory with only one out.

title: Hutton Adds Newburger Retail Sales Operations
description: W. E. Hutton & Co. announced yesterday it had acquired the retail sales operations and customer accounts of Newburger, Loeb & Co.,Inc. Both concernsare members ofthe New YorkStock Exchange. The purchase price was not disclosed. The transactions will include the transfer of three Manhattan and one Los Angeles sales offices to Hutton. Some 10,000 customer accounts of Newberger, Loeb are included.

title: New Greek Promises
description: Now that he has maneuvered himself into an eightyear term as President, with almost unlimited powers, Colonel George Papadopoulos evidently feels secure enough to make a series of promises about restoration of basic freedoms and pirliamentary elections in Greece. This time he has at least been specific enough to make itacutely embarrassing for himself should he fail to keep to his timetable.

title: State Is Reopening Beaches Closed by Pollution
description: Barnegat Bay beaches that were closed ?? week because of pollution WM. reopen today. A state investigation found pollution levels had declined sufficiently to permit swimming.

title: Retailers Near Highs
description: Two of the nation's largest retailers, Sears, Roebuck & Co., and the S. S. Kresge Company, posted their highest sales and earnings for any quarter on record except the Christmas period, according to midyear statements issued yesterday.

title: People in Sports: Indians'
description: Gaylord Perry, the Indians controversial pitcher who won the American League's Cy Young Award last year, is available for trade if the proper offer is made, according to Phil Seghi, the Cleveland general manager.

title: BELFAST BOMB KILLS ONE AND INJURES TWO
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 21 (UPI)  Terrorists blew up a house in east Belfast late tonight, killing one person and injuring two others. The bombing followed an attack by a gang of women who kicked and beat three teenage girls and carved initials into their arms.

title: Miss Potter Wins 18th Diving Title
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 20 (AP)  Cynthia Potter gained her 18th national diving title today with a firstplace finish in the women's onemeter springboard at the National Amateur Athletic Union swimming and diving championships.

title: NIXON SAYS RAIDS ON CAMBODIA IN '69 WERE NECESSARY
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 20President Nixon, speaking to a friendly audience of war veterans, today defended his order for secret bombing of Cambodia in 1969, saying it had been absolutely necessary to save American lives and to move the war in Southeast Asia to the negotiating table.

title: Point Climb Led by First of Chicago
description: More than a dozen of the nation's largest banks yesterday raised their prime interest rate to a record 9 per cent, but lending officers and economists predicted the rate would go higherperhaps to 10 per cent or even more.

title: Lindsay to Decide This Week on Districting Bill
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday told critics and defenders of the plan to reapportion the City Council that he would decide some time this week whether to sign or veto the bill.

title: AGliEVI ATTACKS U.S.JUSTICE AIDES ON INQUIRY LEAKS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 Vice President Agnew accused members of the Justice Department today of an effort to indict me in the press and called for an investigation to expose the Federal investigators responsible.

title: A Conservative Republican State Senator Wins Election for House Seat From Eastern Shore of Maryland
description: EASTON, Md., Aug. 21 An aggressive young conservative! Republican, State Senator Robert E. Bauman, tonight won the nation's first contested postWatergate election for a seat in the House of Representatives, defeating a 60yearold oldline Democrat, Frederick C. Malkus, also a Maryland State Senator.

title: BREITEL ENDORSED BY 50 DEMOCRATS
description: A group of prominent Democrats, including former judges of the state and Federal courts, yesterday endorsed Judge Charles D. Breitel, RepublicanLiberal candidate for chief judge of the State Court of Appeals.

title: The Rogers Approach
description: In his news conference Monday, Secretary of State Rogers voiced an attitude about freedom and national security that could have spared the Nixon Administration and the nation untold pain and humiliation had been official policy. Mr. Rogers did not directly disagree with what the President has said recently in this area; but the differences in priority, emphasis and approach were unmistakable.

title: Business Briefs
description: PARIS, Aug. 21 (UPI)A Government mediator and workers of the bankrupt Lip watchmaking factory in eastern France agreed today to resume talks in an attempt to end the country's worst industrial conflict of the year.

title: Two Parties Back Nominee
description: Because the original Republican nominee for Borough President of the Bronx was subsequently nominated for a judgeship, the party endorsed the Conservative nominee, according to papers filed yesterday with the Board of Elections. The Conservative, Lillian M. immediato, a teacher, will now run on the lines of both parties. The initial Republican choice, Rose M. Ferrandina, has been named to run for Civil Court Judge for the second district.

title: Illinois Republican Finds Watergate and Prices Hurting G.O.P.
description: ROCKFORD. Ill., Aug. 18Representative John B. Anderson, a Republican with a safe district and an independent mind, is the kind of man colleagues will look to for signals when Congress reconvenes next month.

title: Bankruptcy Petitions Filed
description: Petitions of bankruptcy have been filed by certain of its subsidiaries under Chapter XI of the Bankruptcy Act, U. S. Financial, Inc., announced yesterday. Specifically not included are the title and insurance subsidiaries of U.S.F., Mosser Construction Company and U. S. Mortgage. The filings are designed to permit the most efficient operation and administration of U.S. Financial Inc. and the subsidiaries.

title: 6OUNCE TV CAMERA MADE BY FAIRCHILD
description: New developments in electronics were announced yesterday by the Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation and the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation.

title: Argentina Curbs Local News Supplied by Foreign Services
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 21Argentina's new Government has forbidden foreign new agencies to supply newspaper throughout the country wit] local Argentine news.

title: July Orders Down For Durable Goods After Rise in June
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 New orders for durable goods declined $310million in July following an increase of $567million in June, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Wife Searches in Mountains for Threat Suspect
description: TAOS, N.M., Aug. 21 (AP)The wife of a man being sought on a Federal warrant for threatening President Nixon's life went into the ruggged mountains near here today in an attempt to find her husband and convince him to surrender.

title: DOLLAR RECOVERS; GOLD PRICE DROPS
description: LONDON, Aug, 21 (AP) The dollar resumed its climb on most major European money markets today after an unexplained decline over the two previous trading sessions.

title: U.S. Details Payola Plot Of $406,737
description: NEWARK, Aug. 21 Stax Records, a major soul music label, uncovered a $406,737 kickback scheme involving two of its employes nearly two years ago but never reported it to Federal authorities, a Government brief filed in connection with the record industry payola investigation disclosed today.

title: Roosevelt Island: Town in Making
description: Leaning on a railing at the water's edge on Roosevelt Island, formerly Welfare Island, watching a tanker steam northward towards Hellgate, a visitor could be excused for dreaming for a moment that he, too, was afloat.

title: Gordon Jeffery, 41, Editor On Daily Mirror of London
description: LAGUNA BEACH, Calif., Aug. 21 (UPI)  Gordon Jeffery, foreign editor of The London Daily Mirror, died today from injuries he suffered when he was hit by a car. He was 41 years old.

title: DEFICITS LISTED BYPENN CENTRAL
description: The Penn Central Transpor, tation Company repOrted. yesterday a net loss for July of $22:3million and a net loss of $105.4million for the first seven months of this year: The seven months results included an extraordinary credit, of $16.4million resulating from settlement of a loan between a financing subsidiary and two leased railroad subsidiaries.

title: Heavy Shelling Near Hue Is Reported
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 21 (Reuters)The outer defense perimeter of the former imperial oity of Hue came under heavy sustained shelling by Communist gunners last night, the South Vietnamese military command said today.

title: JAPAN REPORTS RISE FOR HER PRICE INDEX
description: TOKYO, Aug. 21 (UPI)Japan's wholesale price index soared in the first 10 days of this month, according to the Bank of Japan.

title: GIANT SUN BUBBLE FILMED BY SKYLAB
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 21 (UPI)The Skylab 2 crew photo. graphed a giant bubble in the sun's outer atmosphere today, Scientists here termed it the most significant solar event in this mission, which is aimed at delving into the mysteries of the earth's nearest star.

title: Union Carbide Is Planning To Construct New Plant
description: Plans for the construction of a multimilliondollar air separation plant at Union Carbide Corporation's atmospheric gas complex in East Chicago, Ind. were announced yesterday by the company.

title: 3 OIL CONCERNS SIGN CONTRACTS IN SAIGON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 21 (UPI)The South Vietnamese Government signed oil exploration contracts worth $16.8million initially today with three of four major companies granted permission to seek petroleum in the South China Sea.

title: Nixon Property Inspected
description: SACRAMENTO, Aug. 21 (AP)The Orange County Assessor said today that his staff had been allowed to inspect the Western White House in determining the value of the property for tax purposes. Jack Vallerga, the assessor, said he was confident the property had been assessed fairly.

title: 54 Loss Sends Bombers Five Games Back
July Mutual Fund Sales Surpassed Redemptions
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (Reuters)Mutual fund sales in July exceeded redemptions for the first time since January, 1972, the Investment Company Institute reported today.

title: The Renewed Militants
description: LONDONIn the summer of 1968 Ford's sewing machinists brought Ford's Dagenham plant to a halt. They were demanding the right to operate machines which gave them access to the more highly paid grades. The publicity and their success gave an impetus to the campaign for equal pay and encouraged other women, especially in the engineering industry, to take action. This was the background to the Equal Pay Act which is due to come into force by 1975.

title: Engelhard Gets Contract
description: Engelhard Minerals & Chemicals Corporation said yesterday that it had contracted to supply General Motors with 8 million to 10 million pounds of platinum palladium impregnated particulate catalyst material yearly, for exhaust emission control devices in the years 1975 through 1978.

title: FUNDS BEING LOST BY SAVINGS UNITS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21Evidence is mounting that the decision of the Federal Reserve Board and other agencies in early July to raise the ceilings on interest rates that banks and thrift institutions can pay to savers is having a result that nobody in the Government wanteda switch of funds out of the savings institutions into commercial banks.

title: A.B.C. NEWSMAN IS JAILED IN ROME
description: ROME, Aug. 21Jack L. Begon, the American Broadcasting Company newsman who turned up here yesterday after having been missing for 29 days, was taken from a clinic to a prison today.

title: TV Ends Profits Slump With 41.9% Rise in 1972
description: The television industry, following two years of declining profits that began with the general economic slump of 1970, rebounded dramatically last year, according to a Federal Communications Commission report issued yesterday.

title: Advertising: United Skis West
description: United Air Lines, whose advertising has long talked about the friendly skies, is going to get downright unfriendly to Europe in a forthcoming campaign promoting skiing in the American West.

title: Godley Appointment Is Seen As U.S. Envoy to Argentina
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) Officials here say that G. McMurtrie Godley is expected to be nominated as Ambassador to Argentina.

title: STREET FIGHTING ERUPTS IN CHILE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 21Supporters and opponents of] Chile's Socialist Government clashed today in street fighting, that lasted nearly five hours.

title: Agnew Press Comments and Richardson Reply
description: Following are a transcript of Vice President Agnew's broadcast news conference in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times, and the text of a statement later by Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson:

title: YIELDS UP SHARPLY AT FANNIE MAE SALE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (Reuters)  Yields for fourmonth commitments to purchase mortgages climbed sharply at the Federal National Mortgage Association's auction, Fannie Mae said today.

title: U.S. Guardsin West Germany Hear Shots and Open Fin
description: BITBURG, West Germany Aug. 21 (UPI)  United States Air Force guards standing watch over nucleararmed fighterbombers opened fire late last week on unidentified persons near the plane's compound, it was disclosed today.

title: C.D.C. Cites Gains In Texasgulf Offer
description: TORONTO, Aug. 21  The Governmentowned Canada Development Corporation disclosed today that more than $225million of Texasgulf, Inc, stock had been tendered in response to its offer to buy 10 million shares of the giant mining company, at a price of $29 a share.

title: AGNEW ATTACKS U.S. JUSTICE AIDES ON INQUIRY LEAKS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 Vice President Agnew accused members of the Justice Department today of an effort to indict me in the press and called for an investigation to expose the Federal investigators responsible.

title: Blaze Put Out in Effort to Reach 2 Trapped in Mine in. Arizona
description: CASA GRANDE, Ariz., Aug. 21 (UPI)Rescue workers extinguished today a fire that had blocked efforts to reach two men trapped in a copper mine last Friday.

title: SHORT INTEREST DOWN IN MONTH
Recently Published Books
description: Alfred Hitchcock PresentsStories to be Read with the Lights On (Random House, $7.95). Thirtyseven stories of murder and suspense.

title: Howard S. Kennedy, 55, MooreMcCormack Aide
description: SOMERVILLE, N.J., Aug. 21  Howard S. Kennedy, special representative of MooreMcCormack Lines, Inc., and Eastern representative of States Steamship Company, died yesterday at Somerset Hospital. His age was 55 and he lived in Plainfield.

title: Champion Is Angered By a Slur
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Aug. 21 (AP)  The world lightheavyweight champion, Bob Foster, reacted angrily to what he believed to be a racial slur at the weighin for his title defense tonight against Pierrie Fourie of South Africa.

title: McKinley Winner In Trapshoot Class.
description: VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 21 (AP)  A virtual national trapshooting unknown won the class AA championship in the opening of the 74th annual Grand American trapshooting tournament yesterday.

title: People and Business
description: Dr. Leslie C. Peacock, 43yearold president of the Crocker National Bankthe 14th largest bank in the country, is going to leave banking and California and go back to his native Texas and build up a ranch.

title: Qualifying at Ontario Track Is MindBoggling Event
description: Everybody in the trade says racing needs to be simplified so that the public can understand it. And now look the new management of On tario (Calif.) Motor Speedway has devised a qualifying procedure that would boggle the mind of a tax lawyer.

title: Housing Police Call M'Kiernan's Stand On Recruits Racist
description: The Housing Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, which represents over 1,500 policemen of the city's Housing Authority, yesterday branded as racist a statement. made Sunday by Robert. M. McKiernan, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, that candidates who passed the housing and transit police tests were not qualified to join the Police Department on the basis of the Civil Service tests alone.

title: Navy Reports Overpaying Shipbuilder by $42Million
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UPI) The Navy said today that it had overpaid the Lockheed Shipbuilding and Construction Company of Seattle for a dozen ships by $42.24million, bot had agreed to postpone getting its money back until Lockeed appeals.

title: ELECTION INQUIRIES BY F.B.I. ASSAILED
description: OLYMPIA, Wash., Aug. 31 (AP)  Routine Federal Bureau of Investigation clocks of petitions bearing the names of minority party members in Washington state have been pictured by an official of one such group as evidence of the Government's Watergate mentality.

title: Electrohome, Ltd, Acquires An ElectronicCircuit Unit
description: KITCHENER, Ontario, Aug. 21 (Canadian Press)Zlectrohome, Ltd., has purchased the electroniccircuit manufacturing operations at NiagaraontheLake, Ont., of Textron, Inc., Providence, R. I.The plant employs about 30 persons.

title: It's Not Ol Nassau, It's Ol McDonald's
description: All these years, the British have had their old school tiessnob emblems by which the happy few who went to the best schools could recognize each other. Americans have college ties, of course, but they haven't made a great fuss over them.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The key figure in a state investigation of alleged municipal corruption in Atlantic City appeared under armed guard in Trenton to go before a state grand jury.

title: TWO CLERGYMEN ON TRIAL IN SEOUL
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 21The Seoul District Criminal Court opened the trial of two Presbyterian clergymen and two other South Isoreans today on charges of attempting to overthrow the Government by force.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: PATRICK H. HOY, 59, OF PENN DIXIE DIES
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 21Patrick H. Hoy, special assistant to the president and formerly a vice chairman and executive vice president of Penn Dixie Industries, Inc., died today of cancer at the Michael Reese Hospital. He was 59 years old.

title: 300 AntiAbortionists March On C.B.S. in Maude Protest
description: Nearly 300 opponents of abortion demonstrated last night outside the Columbia Broadcasting System's headquarters to protest a controversial segment of the Maude television] comedy series.

title: Finneran Takes Diving Crown
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky. Aug. 21 (AP)  A former Olympian, Mike Finneran, captured the men's onemeter diving championship today in the National Amateur Athletic Union swimming and diving championships.

title: Woman Is Beaten in BMT; Five Fellow Employes Held
description: A 24yearold Queens woman, a senior clerk with the New York Telephone.Company, was beaten yesterday by five fellow employes in the Canal Street station of the BMT, Transit Authority police said.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Medicaid Patients to Get Refunds

title: FIVE ARE ACCUSED OF 2D FOOD FRAUD
description: Five reputed organizedcrime figures who were indicted last March 28 on charges of having bilked 30 wholesale food distributors out of $50,000 in Socalled bustout scheme were indicted again yesterday on earlier, charges. almost identical.

title: Sunny Start for StreetTheater Fete
description: The third annual Community/Street Theater Festival had a brilliant opening at Lincoln Center yesterday floodlit by a hot sun and ornamented by a vivid cross section of who's who in New York.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Los Angeles Dodgers, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 121st Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 8:05 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 9, 8 P.M.) (RadioWHN, 8 P.M.)

title: YOUTH, 17, KILLED IN A GM FIGHT
description: A 17yearold youth was stabbed to death and another youth was wounded In a gang fight on a Brooklyn street early yesterday morning, the police reported.

title: Coast Guard Copter Flies Victim Of Gangrene Here to Save Leg
description: A seriously ill patient was rushed from New Haven to Mt. Sinai Hospital here in less than an hour by Coast Guard helicopter last night so he could be placed in Mt. Sinai's hyperbaric chamber to prevent the spread of gangrene.

title: 3 PASSERSBY HURT BY CAR ON 5TH AVE. Vehicle Mounts Curb at 57th Street and Hits Window
description: Three pedestrians were injured at the lunch hour yesterday when a car jumped a curb at Fifth Avenue and 57th Street and crashed into a gift shop's display window.

title: State Liberalizes Policy For Maternity Leaves
description: ALBANY, Aug. 21A preg. nant employe may now continue working as long as she feels able to perform her duties, Mrs. Ersa H. Poston, president of the State Civil Service Commission, said today in announcing that the commission had liberalized maternity policies for state employes.

title: Elizabeth and Newark Dockers Take Off for Funeral of Union Leader
description: ELIZABETH, Aug. 21About 2,500 dockers took the day off yesterday at Port Newark and Port Elizabeth for the funeral of one of their union leaders. The action slowed work on about 12 cargo vessels, although the men returned to their jobs at night.

title: SOLDIERS EXECUTE SOME LAOS REBELS
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 21Several members of the rebel force that attempted a coup early yesterday have been executed by the Laotian Army, and there will no trials for the rest of the prisoners, the Government said today.

title: Agnew Counterattacks
description: Vice President Agnew has every right to complain that his constitutional rights are being violated by leaks attributed to Justice Department sources on allegations supposedly made against him in the current Federal investigation into possible bribery, extortion, tax fraud and conspiracy while Mr. Agnew was Governor of Maryland.

title: 9% PRIME RATE IS INDUSTRYWIDE
3 Golds Are Won By U.S.
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 21 (AP)Pert Cathy Carr, Olympic gold medalist and world recordholder, paced United States swimmers to three gold medals today in the World University Games and the United States men's and women's basketball teams continued winning streaks.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX AND COUNTER DIP
Ombudsman Plan for Aged
description: BOSTON, Aug. 21 (AP)Gov. Francis W. Sargent announced today a $42,000 grant to the state's Office of Elder Affairs to establish an ombudsman program for nursing homes in Massachusetts. The Governor's office said that the program would initiate reforms in the state's regulatory System on nursing homes and respond to individuals complaints.

title: Laird Says Watergate Harmed President's Domestic Proposals
description: In a wideranging interview with a small group of reporters at the Western White House, the President's chief adviser on domestic affairs, also made these points:

title: Abortion Advocate Is Named to Advise City Veterans Unit
description: William R. Baird, the abortion advocate, has been named as an unpaid consultant to Mayor Lindsay's Office for Veterans Action.

title: Employes Ali Given Stock
description: ATLANTA (Reuters) J.Ohn H. Harlan Chairman has given away a million dollars of stock in the company that bears his name to 800, employes, who have been with the company More than two years.

title: SAFETY UNIT WARNS TV ANTENNA. USERS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UPI) The new United States Consumer Product Safety Commission urged users of the Little, Wonder TV Antenna today to unplug and disconnect it immediately to avoid possible electrocution.

title: Claudia LaMotte Is Married To Dana E. Hull in Suburbs
