description: PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., Aug. 21In Christ Episcopal Church here this afternoon, Miss Claudia LaMotte became the bride of Dana Eagle Hull. The Rev. David Hoag performed the ceremony.

title: CHRYSLER PICKED AS UM. TARGET
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 21 (UPI) The United Auto Workers picked the Chrysler Corporation today as the member of the automotive big three that must come to terms on a new contract or face a strike.

title: FESTIVAL FOCUSES ON LOSEY'S TOLL
description: Lincoln Center will become a film buff's paradise for two weeks when the New York Film Festival begins its 11th year on Sept. 28 with a batch of new movies by such directors as Joseph Losev, Francois Truffaut and Satyajit Ray.

title: Some Jokers in Deck
description: About the only thing that economists, businessmen and nvestors agree about these lays is that they are playing pith a deck full of strange cards tnd jokers. As Paul Valery. the French poet, put it, Once lestiny was an honest game of !Ards which followed certain :onventions, with a limited number of cards and values. Now the player realizes in amazement that the hand of his future contains lards never seen before and that the rules of the game are modified by each play. The ollowing is an effort to sort put some the cards: Analysis Economic

title: Russians Get Break at U.N. for Trot
description: Mr. Chairman, the Soviet diplomat protested with a smile, we all know we came here to get as many tips as possible. I can't tell you how many races in a row Othello has won. I don't want to divulge too much information.

title: CORONER IN ULSTER ACCUSES THE ARMY
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 21Londonderry's coroner accused the British Army today of unadulterated murder of the 13 men shot to death Jan. 30, 1972, known here as Bloody Sunday. He was holding an inquest on the men killed by troops during a rally of Roman Catholics.

title: Badillo Out of Race for Mayor, Bowing to Poor Results in Poll
description: Acknowledging the results of a poll that showed him unable to win, Representative Herman Badillo said yesterday that he would not file as an independent candidate for Mayor of New York City.

title: Crop Export Curbs Called Unlikely
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 21 (AP)A top farm official in the Nixon Administration said today that further controls on United States exports of soybeans and other crops were not likely.

title: Notes on People
description: On a vacation trip to Moscow last week, Robert Abrams, the Bronx Borough President, sometimes felt he had never left the political circuit at home. First, as he was visiting in the home of a Soviet physicist, in walked State Supreme Court Justice William Kapelman, whom Mr. Abrams defeated in a primary election in 1969.

title: Randy Johnson Is Pacified as Giants Put New Incentive in His Wallet
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., Aug. 21  The New York Giants sweetened Randy Johnson's incentives as a quarterback today.

title: Informer Cites Veterans'
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Aug. 21  A Government informer, onetime chief confidant of the alleged ringleader of a plot to disrupt. the Republican National Convention last summer, testified today that the only plans he knew of were in a letter urging peaceful demonstrations with some provisions for selfdefense.

title: WHITE HOUSE FILES ON I.T.T. GIVEN COX
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21The White House made available today to the Watergate special prosecutor, Archibald Cox, files on the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

title: Cambodia Bids U.S. Abide By a. Moral Duty to Help
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21The Cambodian Government appealed to Congress and the American people today to abide by the moral obligation of the. United States to help, it remain alive in the face of growing insurgent pressure.

title: Festival to Offer a Parade of Skills by 32 Troupes
description: The third annual Community/Street Theater Festival, which opened yesterday, in Lincoln Center Plaza, expects to set records for audience and number of performances during the next two weeks, despite the dampening effects of increasing logistical problems and a drastically reduced budget.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: Edited by WILL WENG

title: A Reporter's Notebook: Cambodians Hardly at War
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Aug. 21How does one convey the seemingly paradoxical picture of a city whose rhythm of life continues though enemy forces are only 10 miles away?

title: Beaches on Barnegat Bay May Reopen by Tomorrow
description: LAVALLETTE Aug. 21 (UPI) All cause of heavy pollution from human waste may be open by Thursday, a beach official said today.

title: SOLDIERS EXECUTE SOME LAOS REBELS
description: VIENTIANE, LaoS, Aug. 21Several members of the rebel force that attempted a coup early yesterday have been executed by the Laotian Army, and there will no trials for the rest of the prisoners, the Government said today.

title: RAYMOND J. O'CONNOR
description: STRATFORD, Conn., Aug. 21 Raymond J. O'Connor,,chairman of the board of the Contract Plating Company and trustee of the American Shakespeare Theater and Festival, which he helped bring to Stratford, died Friday at a fishing lodge in Gagnon, Quebec. His age was 78.

title: Science Teachers Stage an Eggsperiment
description: With eggs selling for a dollar a dozen these days, this hardly seems like the time to start dropping them from the roof of a ninestory building. But 25 high school science teachers from New York City and New Jersey did just that on Staten Island yesterday In a governmentfinanced course on how to make physics teaching dramatic as well as educational.

title: Castro to Visit Guyana
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Aug. 21Reliable sources disclosed tonight that Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba would visit Guyana before the end of August.

title: Sakharov Warns on Dealing With Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 21Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident physicist, declared today that Western reconcilation with Moscow on Soviet terms posed a serious threat to the world.

title: Clurman Secretary And 4 Others Seized In Narcotics Raid
description: City detectives raided Gramercy Park apartment last night and arrested five suspectson narcotics charges, including a 25yearold woman who, thepolice said, is a secretary to Parks Commissioner Richard M. Clurman.

title: Mexico Seizes Two In May Kidnapping Of American Consul
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 21 (UPI) The Mexican Government announced the arrest last night of two men charged with last May's kidnapping of a United States Consul General, Terrance G. Leonhardy.

title: ExCollege Editor and Man, 41, Found Dead Here From. Apparent Overdoses
description: A Q8yearold former editor in chief of the newspaper of (Hunter College's Bronx campus and the 41yearold man she was living with were found dead from apparent narcotics overdoses in their Lower East Side apartment Monday evening, the police reported yesterday.

title: Western Union Planning Sharp Cutbacks
description: The Western Union Corporation announced yesterday that it was cutting back its capital spending program for 1974 by about $75million and releasing about 1,000 employes.

title: CITY GOES TO Gill FROM BLUE SHIELD
description: Faced with a demand for a 36.9 per cent increase in Blue Shield rates, the city will shift health insurance coverage for 136,000 city employes and pensioners and their dependents to an alternative plan, Group Health Incorporated.

title: WHITE HOUSE FILES ON I.T.T. GIVEN COX
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 The White House made available today to the Watergate special prosecutor, Archibald Cox, files on the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

title: Music: De Waart Directs
description: Nine years ago, Edo de Waart was one of six firstprize winners in the Dimitri Mitropoulos conducting competition here, and he subsequently led the New York Philharmonic several times as Leonard Bernstein's assistant. Mr. de Waart, now 32 years old and music director of the Rotterdam Philharmonic, returned to Philharmonic Hall on Monday night to open the final week of this summer's Mostly Mozart Festival.

title: MRS. FRASER WILKINS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21Mrs. Julia Owsley Wilkins, wife of Fraser Wilkins, former Ambassador to Cyprus and inspector general of the Foreign Service, died yesterday in Georgetown University Hospital. She was 59 years old.

title: Adhesive Suit Filed
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 21 (AP)A $2million lawsuit was filed against the 3M Company, Borden, Inc., and Crown Indus, trial Products today by woman who alleges that spray adhesives manufactured by the three companies caused chromosomal damage and possible defects to any children she may have. The suit said that Mrs. Pam Logan, who used the spray adhesives, had been examined by Dr. J. Rodman Seely of the University of Oklahoma, and that Dr. Seely had found ohm mosomal damage.

title: Famine in Africa Averted, U.S. Aid Coordinator Says
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21Maurice J. Williams, the special American coordinator for relief to six droughtstricken West African countries, said today that famine had been averted in the area but that a critical 60day period was ahead.

title: List of Programs at Lincoln Center
description: Here is a schedule of the events for today through Sunday at the Lincoln Center Community/Street Theater Festival:

title: Canadian Job Benefits Off
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 21 (Canadian Press)  The Federal &memment paid $1.2billion in employment benefits the first half of 1973,

title: U.S. AIDES PREDICT PHNOM PENH DRIVE
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Aug. 21 (AP)Senior United States sources said today that the military situation in Cambodia had improved, substantially but warned of a new battle for the capital.

title: Appeals Court Sets Guidelines For Withholding U.S. Records
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP)  The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia has set detailed rules that the Government must follow if it wants, to withhold information under the Freedom of Information Act.

title: Cambodia Bids U.S. Abide By a Moral Duty to Help
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21The Cambodian Government appealed to Congress and the American people today abide by the moral obligation of the United States to help it remain alive in the face of growing insurgent pressure.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Roberta Kantor, a 28,yearold former editor in chief of the newspaper at the Bronx campus of Hunter College, and the man she lived with, 41yearold Gerald DeSantis, were found dead from apparent narcotics overdoses Monday in a lower East Side apartment, the police said.

title: The Future of Cape May's Shoreline Stirs Dispute
description: CAPE MAY, Aug. 21 (AP) To the motorists who slowed to a crawl as they drove by, the swarm of people arguing around a string of parked cars looked as if they were debating a massive fenderbender.

title: ALIEN HEED AS KEY TO HEROIN TRAFFIC
description: An Italian haberdasher from Mexico City was charged in Federal indictment unsealed in Brooklyn yesterday with being the pivotal figure in the flow of $132million worth of heroin from France to major dealers in the United States and Canada.

title: MILK PRIG RISING; 3 JUMPS POSSIBLE
description: Shoppers can expect to pay between a cent and 2 cents more for a quart of milk early next month in the metropolitan tristate region, dairy industry spokesnien said yesterday.

title: WALDHEIM TO LEAVE SUNDAY FOR MIDEAST
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 21  Secretary General Waldheim announced his schedule today for a 10day visit to Israel and four neighboring Arab countries, beginning Monday in Syria.

title: More Bombs Linked to I.R.A. Found in Big London Stores
description: LONDON, Aug. 21  Fifteen explosive devices were found in department stores and the mail today in what appeared to be a new campaign by sympathizers of the Irish Republican Army.

title: I Got It, I Got It!
description: On the night of July 17, 1973, doubleheader was played at Yankee Stadium. Baseball followers will concur that nothing extraordinary transpired on that occasion. A good Yankee ball club twice defeated a Minnesota Twins team as listless as the first two sentences. Among the 30,000 fans who bustled home after the game, reliving the Yankees performance, chatting about Watergate and grumbling about the prospects of the next day's labor, only one realized that an epochal event had occurred.

title: Three Killings Denied
description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 21 (AP)Guillermo Aillon testified today at his murder trial that he slid not kill his wife and her parents last August. Mr. Ail on, 35 years old, of Wallingford took the stand in the seventh week of the trial.

title: 11 From Atlantic Raft Face a Battery of Tests
description: COZUMEL, Mexico, Aug. 21 (AP)The 11 crew members of the experimental raft Acali began five days of isolation today for medical and psyChological tests. The six women and five men ate what they called their first decent food in the more than three months they floated aboard the raft in their trip across the Atlantic.

title: CONVENTION SITE CALLED A DANGER
description: Opponents of the proposed New York City Convention and Exhibition Center, planned for midManhattan's West Side, charged yesterday that traffic to and from the center.would snarl traffic in already overburdened streets and create massive airpollution and noise problems.

title: Equity Financing
description: A non registered secondary offering of 375,000 common shares of ITE Imperial Corporation at 1634 per share by Salomon Brothers was reported oversubscribed yesterday. The company's stock closed at 163/, up 1/8 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: JULY PRICE RISES, NEAR FREEZE END, SMALLEST FOR 73
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 The nowexpired price freeze slowed the rise in consumer prices last month but did not stop it, the Labor Department disclosed today. Food prices, in particular, failed to respond completely to the freeze, which ended for food July 18.

title: Wedding Held For Mrs. Ross
description: The marriage of Mrs. Laura G. Ross to James J. Ross took.place here last evening at the home of Mr.. and Mrs. Alfred Rand, stepfather and mother of the bride. Rabbi Judah Nadich performed the ceremony.

title: EDMUND WHITING, 62, HOSPITALS PLANNER
description: LONDON, Aug. 21Edmund Whiting, architect and hospital planner, died at his home here on Saturday. He was 62 years old.

title: Milner's Single in Ninth Wins for Sadecki
Indictments Returned on Agnew Dinner
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Aug. 21A state grand jury today indicted for conspiracy several members of a committee that organized a testimonial dinner for Vice President Agnew last year.

title: Coxson Murder Suspect Fails to Show Up in Court
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21Ronald Harvey, a prime suspect in two murders in Cherry Hill, N. J., and seven in Washington, failed to appear for an extradition hearing today, and an assistant United States attorney testified that he had disappeared.

title: The Slippery Slopes
description: NEW HAVENThose who place the ultimate blame for Watergate on Richard Nixon's childhood go back, too far, Those who place it in the tendency of White House power to corrupt don't go back far enough. The origins of moral relativism lie somewhere between, in a quasimystical, demeaning, aggrandizing, relativizing, inflating, mindSharpening, boring, stimulating, feared and corrupting experience known.as law school.

title: Parolee Pleads Guilty to Slaying Invalid In Burglary in 1972 at Midtown Rectory
description: A young, paroled exconvict pleaded guilty yesterday to the murder of an 86yearold homeless man in the rectory of a midtown Roman Catholic church, and he described how the killing occurred last September.

title: Books of The Times
description: RENDEZVOUS WITH RAMA. By Arthur C. Clarke. 303 pages, Harcourt Brace Jovanovten. $6.95.

title: Basketball Transactions
description: KANSAS CITYOMANASinned James Brown, Mike Quick, Mike Williams and Mike Jefferies, all draft cholces.

title: Mrs. Gertrude Claytor, 83, AwardWinning Poet, Dies
description: ROANOKE, Va., Aug. 21Gertrude Boatwright Claytor, a poet who won the Poetry Society of America's annual award in 1932, died today. She as 83 years old.

title: But Can He Score a Goal?
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 21 (Reuters)England's national soccer team has been offered the services of one of East Africa's best known witch doctors. Shariff Abubakar Omar said today he had written to England's team manager, offering his assistance as one of the leading witch doctors in East Africa with international repute in soccer and other matters.

title: Foster Wins Decision to Keep Title
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Aug. 21 (AP)Bob Foster, the lightheavyweight champion, pumped hundreds of left jabs to the bloody face of his South African challenger, Pierre Fourie, and retained his title tonight with a 15round decision.

title: Turner Rents a Track To Replace Cadillacs
description: TAMPA, Fla., Aug. 21 (AP) Glenn W. Turner, the Florida businessman, who was forced to surrender two Cadillacs in a bankruptcy court order, today got permission to rent a truck from his Orlandobased cosmetics concern, Koscot Interplanetary Inc.

title: I.C.C. CHAIRMAN PLEDGES RAIL AID
description: TRENTON, Aug. 21  The chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission pledged today to support Governor Cahill's efforts to reduce freight losses on bankrupt rail lines operating in New Jersey through consolidation of facilities and services.

title: Miss Fleder Is Bride Of Robert Feinman
description: HARRISON, N. Y., Aug. 21The marriage of Miss Margaret E. Fleder to Robert A. Feinman, a news commentator for radio station KOPO in Tucson, Ariz., took place here this afternoon. Rabbi Daniel Wolk performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert I. Fleder. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Feinman of White Plains.

title: MISSING OFFICER CASHED CHECKS
description: Personal checks totaling $3,500 cashed by Police Officer Robert Cameric a few days before his disappearance last Wednesday were returned by the bank marked insufficient funds, a Police Departmtnt spokesman said yesterday.

title: Honors Go To Rote Jr. For Soccer
description: Warren Archibald didn't expect  and didn't geta car for being selected as most valuable player in the North American Soccer League. He received a watch, but when he saw the television cameras, he said future plans of a car for the league's top player were on someone's desk somewhere in Detroit.

title: Martin Marietta Expands
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation announced yesterday construction of a new SSmillion production facility for its sulphur dyes at the Sodyeco division of Martin Marietta Chemicals, Charlotte, N. C. Sulphur dyestuff is used primarily for cotton and viscose rayon textiles.

title: STREET FIGHTING ERUPTS IN CHILE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 21Supporters and opponents of Chile's Socialist Government clashed today in street fighting that lasted nearly five hours.

title: 20 JEWS IN CLASH AT MOSCOW GAMES
Secret Service Calls Plot Against Nixon Serious
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21The Secret Service continued today to press its investigation of what was described a very serious, very large conspiracy by nonmentals assassinate President Nixon? during his visit to New Orleans yesterday.

title: Bahnsen's NoHit Bid Lost in 9th
description: A pitcher has to be lucky to hurl a nohit game, and most of them readily admit it. Last night Stan Bahnsen of the Chicago White Sox was not lucky.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UPI)National Football League teams no longer need the protection of television blackouts of home games, a House committee concluded today.

title: B. &
description: Gimbel Brothers, Inc., announced yesterday that the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation, which recently acquired 93 per cent of Gimbel's stock through a tender offer at $23 a share, had proposed merger between Gimbel and a wholly owned subsidiary of the tobacco company.

title: TV's Soul Train Moves to Apollo
description: SoulTrain, the black musicdance television program a sort of American Blackstand  modified itself from its Channel 5 image and reappeared at the Apollo Theater.= Monday, in the shape of three soulmusic groups and six dancers from the show.

title: LOUIS C. BENDER
description: EMERSON, N.J., Aug. 21Louis C. Bender, a partner in Ar,thur Young & Co., certified public accountants, died of cancer yesterday in Beth Israel Hospital in Newark. He was 75 years old and lived here.

title: Science Teachers Stage an Eggsperiment
description: With eggs selling for a dollar a dozen these days, this hardly seems like the time to start dropping them from the roof of a ninestory building. But 25 high school science teachers from New York City and New Jersey did just that on Staten Island yesterday in a governmentfinanced course on how to make physics teaching dramatic as well as educational.

title: Smith Is Toppled By Dibbs
description: TORONTO, Aug. 21 (Canadian Press)Unseeded Eddie Dibbs of Miami, showing an excellent return of serve and sharp passing shots, upset Stan Smith, 76, 75, in the first round of the $100,000 Canadian open tennis tournament today.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: WEST ORANGE, Aug. 20After 24 years of coaching football at Syracuse, Ben Schwartzwalder had his first losing season last year, five victories and six losses. Steve Dolce, Syracuse's starting middle linebacker from West Orange, N.J., took it personally.

title: Distant Delivery Off Corn Drops Limit
TV: Cave People Sensitively Filmed
description: In defending their glut of reruns, the networks argue that viewers have a chance to see programs they may have missed the first time around. However, since many programs were not worth watching the first time, the argument is about as solid as an aspic.

title: Under Beard and Jeans, a New Bobby Orr?
description: Longhaired, bearded, some wearing faded dungarees, carrying chipped sticks, dulled skates, poloshirtedthey took to the ice yesterday for the onceginalifetime, chance to get a majorleague hockey tryout.

title: Senate Panel Asks Survey
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP)  A Senate subcommittee said today that it had commissioned a national public opinion: survey to help it to try to make Government programs more effective and more responsive to popular wishes. Thy survey will be conducted by Louis Harris and Associates, Inc., for the Subcommittee on Intergovernmental Relations:

title: City Suing to Compel U.S. To Declare Beef Shortage
MRS. CANUTE BERNARD
description: Mrs. Muriel G. Bernard, wife of Dr. Canute C. Bernard, a surgeon here, died Monday of cancer at Jamaica Hospital in Queens. She was 52 years old.

title: MRS. ROGER FLOOD, MANPOWER OFFICIAL
description: Mrs. Aloncita Johnson Flood, an executive with the City Manpower and Development Agency and the wife of Roger W. Flood, retired executive and commissioner of the City Housing Authority, died Sunday in Sydenham Hospital. She was 67 years old and lived at 21 Stuyvesant Oval and in Washington.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: STREET FESTIVAL The Lower East Side Street Festival, which opens today about noon, is a polyglotand if you eat enough of the foods offered, possibly also a polyglutaffair. It is full of local colors and flavors, and it will be set up next to the famous Henry Street Settlement (265 Henry Street) in the playground of Public School 134. Today and tomorrow only, from noon to midnight.

title: Secret Service Calls Plot Against Nixon Serious
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21The Secret Service continued today to press its investigation of what was described a very serious, very large conspiracy by nonmentals assassinate President Nixot during his visit to New Or leans yesterday.

title: West German Red's Bid for a Judgeship Stirs Uneasiness About Role of Leftists
description: DUSSELDORF, West Germany, Aug. 15How far left can young zealots in Chancellor Willy Brandt's Social Democratic party take West Germany?

title: Sun Oil Co. Adjusts Prices For Some Grades of Crude
description: The Sun Oil Company yesterday adjusted crude oil prices within the Phase 4 guidelines.

title: Firestone Tire &
Piraino Bowls 299,
description: WAUKEGAN, Ill., Aug. 21 (AP)  Marty Piraino, 50yearold bowler from Syracuse, N.Y., missed a perfect game by one pin yesterday, but his 299 was more than enough to take first place and the $6,00Q prize in the $55,000 Columbia open bowling tournament. Jay Robinson of Los Angeles was the victim. He earned 53,300 for his 195 game.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The Britannica Encyclopedia of American Art, a onevolume work devoted to the subject, will be published by Simon & Schuster on Oct. 31. Containing 1,100 entries, the 400,000word book will feature 800 illustrations, of which 350 will be in full color. It will sell for $29.95.

title: MISSING OFFICER CASHED CHECKS
description: Personal checks totaling $3,500 cashed by Police Officer Robert Cameric a few days before his disappearance last Wednesday were returned by the bank marked insufficient funds, a Police Department spokesman said yesterday.

title: Giant Stores Corp. Sells 3 Maine Outlets to King's
description: CHELMSFORD, Mass., Aug. 21A spokesman for the Giant Stores Corporation, based here, said today the company had sold three of its Maine stores to King's Department Stores, Inc. They are in Biddeford, Sanford and South Portland.

title: Spitz Also Cares About Nonbathing Suits
description: Mark Spitz, who made history when he swam his way to seven gold medals at the 1972 Olympic Games, was in town yesterday to mark another golden seventh  his seventh commercial endorsement.

title: Sihanouk Says Nixon Lied on Bombing
description: PEKING, Aug. 21  Prince Norodom Sihanouk, describing President Nixon as a liar, denied tonight that while Cambodia's Chief of State he had ever acquiesced in the, secret bombing of Cambodia as contended by the President in a New Orleans speech yesterday.

title: NIXON AIDE CALM SHOVING TRIVIAL
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 21 (AP)  The White House brushed aside today an incident in New Orleans yesterday in which President Nixon shoved his press secretary, Ronald L. Ziegler, attributing it to the confusion. of a day in Which plans were changed becauSe bf a reported threat on the Presi dent's life.

title: No Countdown for Owens: He's No. 1 at His Job Now
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. L, Aug. 21 The Jets scouting reports Burgess Owens said he would play immediately. But nobody expected the No. 1 draft choice to be a starter at strong safety after the third preseason game.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Seeks to Resolve Impasse in Talks With Pakistan
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 21 Prime Minister Indira Gandhi entered the talks between Indian and Pakistani officials today In an attempt ta resolvethe political deadlock on the subcontinent.

title: Percy Says Foreign, Policy Has Been Hurt by Watergate
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 21Senator Charles S. Percy, on tour of the Indian subcontinent, said today that the Watergate scandal had damaged the foreign policy of the United States.

title: New Iron Curtain?
description: Is the Kremlin seeking to erect a new iron curtain to isolate its subjects from the outside world as efficaciously as was done in the Stalin era? The possibility may seem absurd in a period of muchpublicized detente when Moscow begs for multimilliondollar Western loans, puts out the red carpet for European and American businessmen, and shuns propaganda exploitation of Watergate as a means of showing its high regard for President Nixon.

title: West Side Vision
description: In the last three months of this year, motorists using the lower stretches of the West Side Highway will have to get used to massive disruption of their normal traffic patterns while the city installs a new paving of precast concrete blocks in place of a potholed surface pocked with scores of huge metal repair plates.

title: U.S. AIDES TO LEAVE FOR EAST GERMANY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) A sevenmember State Department team plans to leave for East Berlin sometime this week for talks on the possible establishment of diplomatic relations, the department said today.

title: Bridges A Gamble at Monte Carlo so Pays Off for Italian Star
description: A large contingent of New York enthusiasts journeyed to France in. June for the first Monte Carlo Bridge Festival, and returned full of praise for the organization of JeanMichel Boulenger and the direction of Harold Franklin.

title: Suspect in Boys Slayings Cleared, Police Spirit Him Past Angry Crowd
description: A crowd of about 500 people besieged a police station on the Lower East Side for more than two hours yesterday demanding that the police turn over to them a man they believed to be the slayer of four young boys.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
Riva Ridge Captures Race, Halo Provides the Drama
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 21Riva Ridge performed an act of mercy today for Lucien Laurin, if not for the many favorite players among the 17,917 fans who had established him the oddson choice against five rivals in the 1mile feature event. Before the horses were saddled, Laurin, who trains the 4yearold Riva Ridge and the 3yearold Secretariat for the Meadow Stable, pointed to the rafters high in the Saratoga clubhouse and said, If this horse don't win, I'm going to get a big, long rope and hang myself from there.

title: MRS. SCHERMAN DIES; AUTHOR, COLUMNIST
description: BERNARDSVILLE, N. J., Aug. 21  Mrs. Bernadine Kielty Scherman, the widow of Harry Scherman, who founded the BookoftheMonth Club, died today in Morristown Memorial Hospital. She was 83 years old and lived here and in New York.

title: Greece Frees Hundreds of Political Foes
description: ATHENS, Aug. 21The Greek Government opened the gates of its prisons today to free hundreds of jailed political enemies, after a general amnesty proclaimed Sunday by President George Papadopoulos.

title: Backaches Multiply, But Country Takes Threat Lying Down
description: At the rate things are going, it appears likely that that plain, oldfashioned ailment, the backache, will be the most common leveler of Americans in about three years, replacing the common cold.

title: Miss Roberta Downs Married to a Count
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21Miss Roberta Downs of New York was married in a civil ceremony at a friend's home here yesterday to Count Bernard Claret de La Touche of La Gatinaliere, Chatellerauth, France, and Paris.

title: Computers Match Travelers on the Highway With the Motel Rooms They Head For
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Aug. 15Do you have a room for tonight? the rumpled father asks wearily.

title: No Countdown for Owens He's No.1 at His Job Now
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 21 The Jets scouting reports on Burgess Owens said he would play immediately. But nobody expected the No. 1 draft choice to be a starter at strong safety after the third preseason game.

title: Motorola Expects Big Screen To. Win Japanese TV Market
description: TOKYO, Aug. 21An Officer Motorola, Inc., explaining his company's extraordinary plan to sell Americanmade color television. sets in Japan, conceded today that the United states could, not produce color sets, more cheaply than Japan. But Edward Reavey, vice presdent, said, It is only human nature to want a larger TV screen, and we foresee a demand in Japan for this kind of prestige model.

title: WILBUR MARKS
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I., Aug. 21 Wilbur Marks president of the Poseidon Scientific Corporation, which does oceanographic work for the Navy, died today at his home in Dix Hills. His age was 45.

title: Teamsters Void Grape Accords Reached During Chavez Parley
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UPI) The president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Frank E. Fitzsimmons, repudiated today contracts his field agents negotiated with 30 California grape growers during teamster peace talks with Cesar Chavez of the United Farm Workers. He thus opened the way for resumption of the talks.

title: Cut Asked in Executive Fund
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP)  Senator Walter F. Mondale, Democrat of Minnesota, said today that, because of disclosures in the Watergate scan dals, he would introduce legislation to trim funds available for White House operations. He said that one of his proposals would eliminate a $1mil lion Special Projects fund, to prevent its use for such operations as the White House plumbers, who were assigned to plug national secur ity leaks.

title: HOUSINGBIAS SUIT AGAINST CITY FAILS
description: A Federal judge has dismissed a lawsuit that accused the city of racial discrimination in refusing to approve a controversial housing project.

title: What's Going on Here?
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21The Government of the United States has often been described as a kind of organized disorder, but lately the normal confusion has declined into an illogical and sometimes even into an irrational babble of contradictions.

title: Red Smith
description: It was one of those mornings that Nature designed expressly for breakfast on the clubhouse terrace at Saratoga, fresh as the blueberry muffins themselves, cool and dewy like the Hand melons. First, though, there were people to see and promises to keep on the backstretch, where the sights and sounds and smells are so good for the soulthe broken drumbeat of hooves as a set of horses pounds by, the voice of an exercise boy crooning to his mount, woodsmoke rising, the scent of open fires under the trees, sunlight rippling on chestnut coat. This Irishman was on his deathbed, Jimmy Conway was saying, and he could smell a ham cooking in the kitchen. Cut me a slice of that ham, he says to his wife, and I'll have a taste before I go You out of your head? she says. That's for the wake.' Not far away a cock crowed loudly. A day to be alive, Jim Conway said, and nine chances to get rich this afternoon. Like they say, you never find a man in the river with tomorrow's entries in his pocket.

title: New Chair at Harvard
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 21 (AP)Harvard University has announced establishment of a professorship in African history with a gift from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation. Kenneth O. Dike, professor of history at Harvard since 1970, was named the first Mellon Professor of African History.

title: Jughead, Veronica, Archie and Pals Get Religion and Help to Spread the Word
description: Archie, the frecklefaced eternal teenager of the comics, had bumbled his way into a typical bit of adversity.

title: May Stores Registers Record Earnings and Volume
North Ward Mansion Now Cultural Center
description: NEWARK, Aug. 22  The North Ward Educational and Cultural Center, conceived to focus attention on the problems of the white minority of this racially fragmented city, held an informal open house today in its new quarters at 246 Mount Prospect Avenue.

title: GOING OUTGuide
description: EDWARD GOREY Exactly 250 original drawings by Edward Gorey, mostly 4 inches square, are on display in the Plaza Gallery, on the main floor of the Library & Museum of the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center. In Gorey's drawings, desolations are decreed by the working of an implacable and terribly energetic, but absolutely impersonal, fate. He is fond of coffins and bats, and in night scenes, the branches of his trees seem almost taloned. The details are faultlessly somber and chilling, yet the effect is delightful.

title: 2 More Bombs Are Found in London
description: LONDON, Aug. 22A bomb planted in a department store and a boobytrapped book mailed to the Conservative party headquarters here were discovered today before they could do any harm.

title: Cigarette Ban to Be Asked By Federal Safety Official
description: NEWARK, Aug. 22Richard O. Simpson, chairman of the new Federal Consumer Product Safety Commission, said today that he was prepared to seek a ban on all or some cigarettes if, as expected, an examination confirms the surgeon general's findings in recent years on the, hazardous nature of cigarette smoking.

title: POLICE INJURE MAN MISTAKEN FOR THIEF
description: A Queens man suffered eye Injuries early yesterday after two policemen, mistaking him for a burglar, shot at his car, the police reported.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on Elimination of Racial Discrimination 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Prado's Art Treasures Are Menaced by Air Pollution
description: MADRID, Aug. 22The world's largest collection of Spanish paintings is ill, according to its caretaker.

title: 4 Watergate Conspirators Visited in Jail by Weicker
description: DANBURY, Conn., Aug. 22 (AP)Senator Lowell P. Weickier Jr., Republican of Connecticut, met at the Federal Correctional Institution today with four of the Watergate conspirators.

title: DialARide System May Help Suburbs
description: LA MIRADA, Calif.Mrs. Freda Terenzio sat down in her kitchen, dialed 9436776, and told the man at City Hill that she wanted to go to Von's Market.

title: 2 INDICTED UPSTATE IN THE GARROW CASE
description: LAKE PLEASANT, N. Y., Aug. 22 (AP)A Hamilton County grand jury, called to consider the case of Robert Garrow Sr., who has been accused of murder, handed up eight sealed indictments against two persons yesterday.

title: Edd Bivin: YoungMan In a Hurry
description: Many of our leading dogshow judges are either educators or physicians. Edd Bivin of Fort Worth is a member of the first category. He's on the staff of the dean of students at Texas Christian University.

title: COUNTER STOCKS AND AMEX DROP
Jersey Surplus Is Put at $200Million
description: TRENTON, Aug. 22Governor Cahill, who inherited a $300million budget deficit when he took office nearly four years ago, could leave his successor a surplus exceeding $200million.

title: Equity Financing
description: New England Electric System yesterday said directors had voted to sell late this year up to 1,250,000 additional common shares to underwriters through selective bidding. The company's stock closed unchanged at 22 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Rogers Quits, Kissinger Named
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22President Nixon announced today that he had accepted with personal regret the resignation of William P. Rogers as Secretary of State and would nominate Henry A. Kissinger, the White House adviser on national security, to take over the senior Cabinet position.

title: Addicted To Music Created By Boxes
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn.Collectors are often satisfied with things that are only to be looked atdolls, jewels, stamps, miniature furniture. Other collectors want more than thatthey want action, and for them model trains may be heart's delight.

title: WITNESS PRESSED IN VETERANS CASE
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Aug. 22 A Government witness gave damaging testimony today against eight persons accused of plotting to disrupt the 1972 Republican National Convention, but then seemed to reverse part of his testimony on crossexamination.

title: PETER FORREST
description: Peter Forrest, a lawyer who was for many years counsel and then president of the Twentythird Street Association, died yesterday at his home, 25 East 77th Street. He was 76 years old,

title: Abortion Advocate to Question Mayor on Job Held for a Day
description: William R. Baird, the abortion advocate, plans a City Hall news conference this morning to ask Mayor Lindsay why he lost his dayold job as consultant to the Mayor's Office for Veterans Action.

title: William Huntington,Yachtsman Who Led Marine Concern, Dead
description: MANHASSET, L. I., Aug, 22 William George Huntington, president of Hubeva Marine Plastics, Inc., of Brooklyn and a prominent yachtsman, died last night at the Manhasset Medical Center. He was 76 years old and lived at 12 Knolls Lane.

title: A Small but Growing Number of Colleges Across Nation Adopting a YearRound, ThreeTerm Program
description: Pressed by rising costs and shifting student tastes, a small but growing number of colleges across the country are discarding the old ninemonth school year for something that promises more money and more flexibilitythe 12month campus.

title: Transit Police Roam World Where Risk Is Just Routine
description: The incessant din of the subway trains assails the senses. Wheels grind out minute particles of steel dust into the stale air. Anonymous faces bob in and out of focus as the rushhour crowds surge through nether world where the sun never shines. Fob those who patrol daily the 231 miles of New York City subways, the transit policeman's lot is not a cushy one.

title: TV TIEINS CITED AS BOON TO BOOKS
description: Like practiced sorcerers, salesmen from major book publishing firms went through their routines before a gathering of book buyers at the Stetler Hilton this week  and the magic word was television.

title: Notes on People
description: Senator Barry Goldwater jumped into the water at Newport Beach, Calif., to save two persons who had fallen out of a speedboat after the craft was swamped by a wave. The victims were rescued from the water by Sen. B. Goldwater who was passing in his boat, said an entry in the local police log.

title: HUGH NAWN, 85, DIES; BOSTON CONTRACTOR
description: WALTHAM, Mass., Aug. 22 (AP)  Hugh Nawn, chairman of Hugh Nawn, Inc., the construction company that helped build Boston's subway system and its water supply system, died yesterday at a nursing home. He was 85 years old.

title: Jughead, Archie and Their Friends Get Religion and Help in Spreading the Word
description: Archie, the frecklefaced eternal teenager of the comics, had bumbled his way into a typical bit of adversity.

title: Ramapo Budget Passed
description: SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., Aug. 22Voters in Ramapo Central School District No. 2 passed a $36,047,258 budget today, one of the largest in the state outside of New York City. The Note was 3,751 to 2,757. A budget that was $693,811 lower was defeated June 13 by 314 votes. The new budget represents an average 4 per cent increase in taxes, or about $40 year on a $40,000 assessment.

title: TAPE CASE ARGUED IN FEDERAL COURT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22President Nixon's lawyer and the Justice Department's special Watergate prosecutor clashed in court today over whether the President has the right to withhold records of his conversations from a grand jury investigating crime.

title: U.S. Court Rules Police Have a Right to Long Hair
description: A right to wear long hair was vigorously defended as substantial constitutional issue in a decision here yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: Rise of Air Ticket Thefts Studied by U.S. and City
description: Federal and local authorities are investigating a growing traffic in stolen airline tickets that they say is costing airlines many millions of dollars a year.

title: HOUSING PROJECT IS WITHOUT FUNDS
description: The sponsors of federally backed housing renovation project in Harlem said yesterday that work had stopped on the project and that they were $350,000 short of funds needed to complete the first phase.

title: City Food Costs Dip After 6Week Rise
description: The first overall price decline in the citymonitored food market basket in six weeks was reported yesterday by the city's Department of Consumer Affairs.

title: STATE ACTS TO CURB MOSQUITO DISEASE
description: ALBANY, Aug. 22 (AP)The state has taken action to combat an outbreak of Eastern equine encephalomyelitis that has killed more than 40 horses in New Hampshire and in Massachusetts.

title: Lloyd's Profit Set A Record in 1970; Problems Are Seen
description: LONDON, Aug. 22 (Reuters)  Lloyd's of London, the 300yearold insurance company, announced today record profits for 1970 and predicted as good, if not better, results for 1971.

title: 18 Minority Film Trainees Graduate
description: Amid the atmosphere of a family party, with soft drinks, plenty of laughter, a few hugs, and warm greetings of Hello, brother and Hello, sister, the first 18 graduates of a film training program for minority young people yesterday received their ribbontied diplomas.

title: New Food Pricing Rules Proposed to Start Sept. 1 2
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22The Cost of Living Council published today proposed food pricing regulations but studiously avoided predicting that they would lead to a lessened rate of inflation during the next few months.

title: Transcript of President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
description: First, gentlemen, I have an announcement before going to your questions.

title: GasStation Closings As Protest Forecast
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UPI)The American Automobile Association forecast today possible widespread shutdowns of gas stations over the Labor Day weekend as a protest against the Government's Phase 4 economic controls.

title: Nastase s New Image justCall Him Nicely
description: It was Be Kind to the Nastase Day, and the Rumanian tennis star conceded yesterday he would like to change the image that has earned him the nickname of Nasty.

title: A RARE NEWS TALK
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 22  President Nixon, holding his first news conference in five months, acknowledged today that the Watergate scandals had hampered his ability to govern, but he asserted in a forceful manner that he had never considered resigning and would serve the three and a half years remaining in his term with the full authority of a strong Presidency. [Question 10, Page 28.]

title: F15 JET ENGINE FAILS KEY ENDURANCE TEST
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP)An engine being developed for the Air Force's new F15 supersonic fighter ran into new troubles yesterday when a model blew off its rear section during a critical endurance test.

title: Soviet Launches Satellite
description: MOSCOW, Aug, 22 (AP)The SOviet Union launched its, Soth Cosmos satellite today, Tass. announced. The press agency said the satellite, which of a multipurpose series of space !robes. completed its first orbit in 92.2 minutes.

title: In the Courtroom
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22It was an elegant argument, restrained on both sides, intellectual, almost oldfashioned in its courtliness. There was real professional respect when the lawyers called each other friend and brother. Charles Alan Wright even had due deference for the distant and contentious dead: Aaron Burr, to him, remained Colonel Burr.

title: NONVIOLENT TACTICS URGED ON CHURCHES
description: GENEVA, AUG. 22  The Rev. James M. Lawson, a black American Methodist, urged churches around the world today to pay more attention to the neglected option of nonviolent tactics for bringing about social change.

title: Seven Are Arrested Here In $16Million Drug Raid
description: The Manhattan District Attorney's office announced yes terday that five Young women and two men had been arrest ed on charges of possessing five kilos of heroin and one kilo of cocaine worth millions if sold to addicts.

title: Teamsters Strike Closes St. Louis PostDispatch
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 22 (AP) The St. Louis Post Dispatch suspended publication today after the newspaper was strua by drivers and loadingdock workers who are members of teamsters union Local 610.

title: TV: Good Vibrations From Central Park Indeed
description: With Good Vibrations From Central Park, being shown this evening from 9 to 10, the American Broadcasting Company notches still another respectable advance in its efforts to present both popular music and what the network chooses to call event television.

title: SKYLAB TO SURVEY DROUGHT NATIONS
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 22 (UPI)The droughtstricken West African nations of Mali and Mauritania will be surveyed next month by Skylab to collect data on possible water and food sources.

title: Riggins Lands In Camp ofJets
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 22 John Riggins, the New York Jets leading rusher last season and this year's leading ?? showed up at camp at 7:15 o'clock tonight.

title: Shultz Names Monetary Reform Panel
description: The former secretaries, and their terms of office, are Henry H. Fowler, 1965 to 1968 under President Johnson, who will be chairman of the new committee, Douglas Dillon, 1961 to 1965 under Presidents Kennedy and Johnson, and John B. Connally, 1971 and 1972 under President Nixon. Mr. Shultz noted that negotiations for world monetary reform are now reaching their definitive stage, and added:

title: 14 Die in Colombian Crashi
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 22 (AP)An Avianca Airlines passenger plane crashed today in central Colombia, killing 14 persons and injuring three others, the Colombian Civil Aeronautics Board said.

title: Lacey Denies Move to Quash Subpoena for PayolaPlot Data
description: NEWARK, Aug. 22Federal Judge Frederick B. Lacey denied today a motion by Stax Records, producers of soul music, to quash a subpoena or evidence of a $406,737 kickback scheme that had been uncovered nearly two years ago by a private investigator for the recording company.

title: Entertainment Events Today
Texts of Rogers's Letter and the President's Reply
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 22Following are the texts of Secretary of State William P. Rogers's letter of resignation, dated Aug. 16, and President Nixon's acceptance on Aug. 20:

title: Suspect Denies He Knew Child Would Gain in Slaying
description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 22 (AP) Guillermo Aillon testified today that he did not know until after he was arrested on three murder charges that his daughter would inherit $50,000 from his slain fatherinlaw.

title: HERMAN G. BROCK.
description: EAST ORLEANS, Mass., Aug. 22Herman G. Brock, a retired vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York, died Monday in Cape Cod Hospital in Hyannis of injuries suffered in an automobile accident on Friday. He was 82 years old and formerly lived in Port Washington, L.I.

title: 30 More Food Places Are Listed As City Health Code Violators
U.S. Becoming China's No.2 Trade Partner
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 22Official United States sources here estimate that Americans will do $900million worth of trade with China this year, possibly more, pushing the nation from the bottom of the list of China traders, where it languished just two years ago, into second place, after Japan.

title: President's Popularity Climbed After Speech, Gallup Poll Finds
Miss Carr Is Beaten In Swim
FAITH REAFFIRMED
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 President Nixon said today that his faith in Vice President Agnew was unshaken by a Federal investigation in Maryland involving Mr. Agnew.

title: MATTHEWS BACKERS FORM DEFENSE FUND
description: Supporters of Dr. Thomas W Matthew, controversial blackactivist neurosurgeon who is under indictment on larceny charges involving nearly $279,. 000, yenterday announced for mation of a defense fund.

title: MERGER APPROVED BY RETAIL CHAINS
description: Directors of the McCrory Corporation and the Lerner Stores Corporation approved yesterday a definitive agreement of revised terms for the merger of McCrory with its 60 per cent owned subsidiary, Lerner Stores.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: KANSAS CITY, Aug. 22 (AP)Lamar Hunt, president of the Kansas City Chiefs, labeled as scandalous measures before Congress to force the National Football League to televise sellout games in their home cities.

title: Man Cited in Threat to Nixon Gives Up
description: ARROYO HONDO, N. M., Aug. 22  Edwin M. Gaudet, who was accused of threatening President Nixon's life last week in New Orleans, surrendered to Federal and local officers today after almost two days of hiding in the rugged mountains of northern New Mexico.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Ludi Claire, who only this week joined the cast of Neil Simon's The Prisoner of Second Avenue, taking over the role of Gabriel Dell's sister from Ruth Mannings, is collaborating on a musical version of Shaw's Major Barbara" with Jule Styne, the composer. Miss Claire is adapting the play and writing lyrics for Mr. Styne's music.

title: People and Business
description: George R. Vila, chairman of Uniroyal, has warned that, unless the national energy supply situation begins to improve soon, the rubber industry may face reductions or shutdowns in operations.

title: Vivid Give and Take In a Peaceful Setting
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 22  When President Nixon was asked today how much of the blame he accepted for the climate that helped cause Watergate, he answered, all of it. But in the course of his long news conference, he invoked a long list of people to help explain, and justify, his current troublesprevious Presidents, former aides and, particularly, the press.

title: Ervin Says President Talked in Generalities
description: MORGANTOWN, N. C., Aug. 22 (AP)Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. said President Nixon failed in his televised news conference today to shed more light on the Watergate affair.

title: William Shemin Dies at 76; Began Landscape Company
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 22  William Shemin, who founded the Ivy Floral and Landscape Company in the nineteentwenties, died yesterday apparently of a heart attack at his home on Willow Run Lane. He was 76 years old.

title: Nixon Repeats His Rebuff Of Dean on Hush Money
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22President Nixon repeated today that he had concluded in Marc that it would be wrong attempt to buy the silence of the seven defendants in the Water gate burglary with promises executive clemency or hush money when the idea was broached by John W. Dean 3d his former counsel.

title: HardLine Party Policy on Arab Territories Given Support in Israel
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 22A fouryear plan providing In public and private purchase land by Israelis in the occu pied Arab territories and the establishment of additional Is raeli settlements in the terri tories has been approved ly the top leaders of the Israel Government as a provisiona election platform for the gov erning Labor party.

title: DEATH OF 2 OFFICERS CHARGED TO DRIVER
description: ORANGETOWN, N. Y., Aug. 22 (UPI)A Rockland County grand jury today returned a 15count indictment against a 24yearold man charged with killing two police officers with his car while under the influence of drugs and alcohol.

title: Kissinger: He Creates Policies and Headlines
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22Privately Henry A. Kissinger often belittled the State Department. To him it was the bureaucracy.

title: Ashe Ousts Pattison In Canadian Tennis
description: TORONTO, Aug. 22 (AP)Arthur Ashe of Miami had to save match point in the thirdset tiebreaker today to defeat Andrew Pattison of Rho desia in the $100,000 Canadian open tennis championship.

title: Sketch Used in Search For Woman's Stabber
description: The police have distributed a composite sketch of a man sought in the stabbing of Mrs. Marion Whittaker, a Chase Manhattan Bank employe, in a Brooklyn subway train a week ago today. Mrs. Whittaker, 35 years old, riding in a Manhattanbound IRT train at 6:45 P.M. was accosted by a mugger as the train entered the President Street station.

title: U.S. COMPENSATING KIN OF RAID DEAD
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Aug, 22  The United States made formal restitution to Cambodia today for an acci1 dental American air raid Aug. 6 against the Mekong River town of Neak Luong in which 1371 civilians and Cambodian Gov1 ernment soldiers were killed and 252 wounded.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Los Angeles Dodgers, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 121st Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 8:05 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 9, 8 P.M.) (RadioWHN, 8 P.M.)

title: New System Planned On Pollution Checks For State's Waters
description: TRENTON, Aug. 22 (AP) The State Department of Environmental Protection announced today that a threedayaweek program to sample ocean water along 70 miles of the New Jersey shore would begin next week.

title: NIXON WOULD PARE PROTECTIVE DETAIL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 President Nixon said today that he and his family would prefer to be able to do without Secret Service protection, or at least to make do with less of it. But it seems unlikely that the President's wishes will prevail.

title: Watergate Material Seized in Burglary Of A.B.C. Bureau
description: Sensitive papers and a tape relating to certain aspects Of the Watergate case were stolen in a recent burglary of the Washington news bureau of the American Broadcasting Company, the network disclosed yesterday.

title: A RARE NEWS TAM
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 22President Nixon, holding his first news conference in five months, acknowledged today that the Watergate scandals had hampered his ability to govern, but he asserted in sa forceful manner that he had never considered resigning and would serve the three and a half years remaining in his term with the full authority of a strong Presidency. [Question 10, Page 28]

title: New Man at State
description: For more than four years, Henry A. Kissinger has carried many of the responsibilities and exercised many of the functions that usually go with being Secretary Slate. It comes as no surprise that President Nixon has now decided to give the job in title as well as fact to his chief foreign affairs adviser, the architect of most of this Administation's major initiatives abroad.

title: Big Board Set to Suspend Gimbel Securities Trading
description: Trading in the securities of Gimbel Brothers, Inc. will be suspended Sept. 7 by the New York Stock Exchange, it was announced yesterday. Control of the department store chain has recently been acquired by the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Company, the third largest producer of cigarettes in this country.

title: Gustav in Critical Condition
description: HELSINGBORG, Sweden, Thursday, Aug. 23 (AP)King Gustav VI Adolf of Sweden was placed in an artificial respirator early today, and hospital bulletin said his condition was critical. The 90yearold king, the world's oldest living monarch, was operated on early Tuesday for a gastric ulcer. Hospital bulletins yesterday said he was improving and had been walking about his room.

title: Teachers Picket White House
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP)  Unionized schoolteachers picketed the White House today to demonstrate their opposition to the Nixon Administration's education and economic policies.

title: Bridge: Challenge for World Titles Players From Italy Posing
description: For the younger generation of bridge experts, Italian domination of the international scene seems to be an immutable law of nature. But two decades ago the United States was dominant, and fully capable of defeating the annual European challenge.

title: Jersey Surplus Put At $200Million
description: TRENTON, Aug. 22Governor Cahill, who inherited a $300million budget deficit when he took office nearly four years ago, could leave his successor a surplus exceeding $200million.

title: Street Job Causes Blackout
description: Acontractor performing streetgrading work for the citydamaged an electrical feeder cable at Grand Central Parkway and Commonwealth Avenue, interrupting power to 1,600 custom ers in the Little Neck section. of Queens for more than an hour yesterday morning. A Consolidated Edison repair crew restored power shortly after 11:30 A.M.

title: Vivid Give and Take In a Peaceful Setting
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif. Aug. 22  When President Nixon was asked today how much of the blame he accepted for the climate that helped cause Watergate, he answered, all of it. But in the course of his long news conference, he invoked a long list of people to help explain, and justify, his current troublesprevious Presidents, former aides and, particularly, the press.

title: Car Price Rise for Canada
description: TORONTO, Aug. 22 (Reuters The Ford Motor Company o Canada, Ltd., said today it wal increasing its suggested retai price of its Capri model cars The company said prices or the subcompacts would rise al average of 7 per cent. Capri are made in West Germany.

title: Jews Lawsuit on Registration Awaits a Constitutional Ruling
description: A Supreme Court justice in Brooklyn said he was favorably disposed toward an application by a group of Orthodox Jews for a permanent order restraining the city Board of Elections and the state from holding voter registration on Oct. 9, 10 and 13. But the justice, Anthony J. DiGiovanna, added that he was reserving decision on the case.

title: Treasury Bills Fall In Monthly Auction
President Says That Illegal Ellsberg BreakIn Need Never Have Been Disclosed
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 President Nixon said today that, he had approved a preliminary decision to block disclosure of the breakin at the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist because the raid by White House plumbers had found a dry hole, barren of evidence against the man charged with leaking thePentagon papers.

title: S.E.C. Files Fraud Suit Against First U.S. Corp.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission today filed suit seeking to block the First U.S. Corporation from engaging in allegedly fraudulent transactions in municipal bonds, including a scheme in which bonds were purchased and sold from customers at nonmarket prices.

title: Investing in Canada Gains
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 22 (Canadian Press)  Total public and private capital investment in Canada this year is expected to reach $24.7billion, 13 per cent greater than last year and 4 per cent above previous estimates for 1973, the Government has reported. The figure covers capital expenditures for agriculture, food, forest, mineral, construction, fuel, power, trade, finance commercial, transportation, storage, communication and housing, industries and institutional services, government departments and waterworks.

title: Lockheed Denies Charge Of Being Overpaid by Navy
description: BURBANK, Calif., Aug. 22 (Reuters)  The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation denied today a charge that it was overpaid on a Navy shipbuilding contract.

title: JOHN J. JACKSON JR.
description: John J. Jackson Jr., counsel to the law firm of Jackson, Nash, Brophy, Barringer & Brooks, of which he was former senior partner, died yesterday in Community Hospital, Glen Cove, L.I. He was 63 years old and lived on Cedar Ridge Road in Locust Valley, L.I.

title: On Temper
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22Do you ever blow your stack?

title: EXCELLENT CONCERT AT THE GUGGENHEIM
description: Chamber Music at the Guggenheim is a pocketsized latesummer festivaltwo concerts onlynow in its second year at the museum on Fifth Avenue. The first concert of this season's pair was held Tuesday night (the second will be next Tuesday), and the performances were of such high quality that one can only hope that the museum will be able to expand its summer musical activities in the future.

title: Cards Defeat Braves Despite Aaron's Clout
E.P.A.WillRequest Gas Mileage Data On New Car Label
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) The United States Environmental Protection Agency will ask automobile makers tomorrow to tell the public how much gasoline mileage their new cars can deliver, a spokesman for the agency said today.

title: CAMBODIA MAY ASK NEIGHBORS FOR AID
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Aug. 22  In a series of press conferences held for visiting Thai journalists, the Cambodian Government today made clear its intention of seeking military aid from South Vietnam and Thailand as well as from the United States if the situation worsens in the months ahead.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A junior high school biology teacher was seized in Criminal Court and accused of selling heroin to teenagers in Harlem. The teacher, Earl Harrell, 29 years old of 56 West 124th Street, was in court to post bail for another man involved in a narcotics ring. The police said Mr. Harrell was active in a group that openly sold drugs along Lenox Avenue between 120th and 125th Streets, They said he had been dealing in drugs for about a year.

title: Man Inches His Way To Transit Police Job
description: Last February Mike Bartolotta, a 24yearold Brooklyn salesman, failed to qualify for the Transit Authority Police because he was threequarters of an inch shorter than the requirement of 5 feet 7 inches.

title: FAITH REAFFIRMED
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 President Nixon said today that his faith in Vice President Agnew was unshaken by a Federal investigation in Maryland involving Mr. Agnew.

title: BRIDGE OFFICERS DEMANDING GUNS
description: Uniformed officers who collect tolls and direct traffic on Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority facilities voted yesterday to defy an authority ban on the carrying of weapons.

title: Advertising: New RCA Theme
description: The RCA Corporation is changing its institutional advertising approach to emphasize one simple fact: that about 70 per cent of its revenues are still derived from the electronics field.

title: Rogers Quits, Kissinger Named
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 President Nixon announced today that he had accepted with personal regret the resignation of William P. Rogers as Secretary of State and would nominate Henry A. Kissinger, the White House adviser on national security, to take over the senior Cabinet position.

title: Learning About Hillbillies First Hand
description: In the confession magazines, she is often called Edna June, and she is a thinlipped barefoot girl in a feedsack dress who spends most of her time on the front porch of her parents tumbledown Appalachian shack, pining about her unrequited love.

title: Roundup: Orioles Beat Twins, 43, for 10th in Row
description: The Baltimore Orioles won their 10th straight game last night, beating the Minnesota Twins, 43, in Baltimore.

title: A.T.&T. Holders Plan Meeting in Minneapolis
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Aug. 22 (AP)  The American Telephone and Telegraph Company will hold its annual meeting of stockholders at Minneapolis April 17, 1974, it was announced today.

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
U.S. Tennis Rained Out
description: SOUTHAMPTON, Aug. 22  Heavy rains caused postponement of the United States men's amateur tennis championship program at the Meadow Club today. The thirdround matches were rescheduled for tomorrow. Ross Walker of England will play Billy Martin of Palos Verdes, Calif., seeded seventh, and Steve Docherty of Australia will meet eighthseeded James Delaney of Potomac, Md.

title: 60 Ossining Inmates to Study At Community College in Bronx
description: Sixty prisoners will be athong the students enrolled at Hostos Community College in the Bronx during the 197374 academic year, school officials disclosed yesterday.

title: Wood, Field and Stream Old Mickey Finn Slipped Into Action Earns a Quick Catch on Salmon Trip
description: ADMIRALTY ISLAND, Alaska  Some years ago while fishing for landlocked salmon and brook trout in northern Quebec, I gained great respect for the Mickey Finn streamer fly, probably because it was the only one our FrenchCanadian guides recommended.

title: BIG BANKS IN BRITAIN RAISE LENDING RATE
description: LONDON, Aug. 22 (Reuters) Following the lead by Lloyds Bank, Ltd., the other Big Four of Britain's commercial banks National Westminster, Bar clays and Midlandtoday announced increases in their base lending rates from 10 to record of 11 per cent. The increases are effective tomorrow.

title: Former Astronaut injured In Crash of Vintage Plane
description: GALVESTON, Tex., Aug. 22 (AP)A former astronaut, Fred W. Haise Jr., crashed while trying to land a World War II training plane here tonight and was critically horned, officials said.

title: Gunmen Shoot Two in Bar In Brooklyn During Holdup
description: An offduty United States marshal and a bar manager were shot and seriously I wounded in a Brooklyn bar early yesterday morning by two gunmen who held up the bar, the police reported.

title: Soviet Paper Reports Floods Near Lake Baikal
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 22 (Reuters)Soviet soldiers with amphibious vehicles evacuated 1,200 people and thousands of head of cattle when floodwaters hit the Ulan Ude area of eastern Siberia, near Lake Baikal, Red Star, the Soviet Army newspaper, reported tonight.

title: Tender of Only Toll Bridge For Walkers in U.S. Dies
description: WATERVILLE, Maine, Aug. 22 (AP)Leon H. Crowell, keeper of the country's only known toll foot bridge, died of a heart attack yesterday on the TwoPenny Bridge here, where he had spent most of the last 11 years. He was 63 years old.

title: English Group Plays Genteelly
description: Visitors from England took over the stage of Philharmonic Hall on Tuesday night to play a Mostly Mozart Festival concert of works by all three of the composers being featured this year  Mozart, Bach and Handel.

title: Hiss Case Is Ruled No Longer an EqualTime Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) The Federal Communications Commission ruled today that the Alger Hiss case was no longer a controversy of public importance subject to equaltime provisions of its fairness doctrine.

title: 10,000 Fight ForestRange Fires In 5 Western States and Canada
description: BOISE, Idaho, Aug. 22An army of more than 10,000 fire fighters, deployed across five droughtstricken Western states and in Canada, continued its battle today against flames roaring through forests and rangeland nearly a hundred times the area of Central Park.

title: Terror Grips District Where Boy Was Slain
description: On a boardedup storefront on Third Street east of Avenue C, someone had pasted the police flyer bearing the composite photograph of the man suspected of the mutilation murders of four young boys. the printed word WANTED was the handwritten dead or alive. That was scratched out by someone who had scrawled, mostly dead.

title: Steve Cady
Cigarette Ban to Be Asked By Federal Safety Official
description: NEWARK, Aug. 22Richard O. Simpson, chairman of the new Federal Consumer Product Safety Commission, said today that he was prepared to seek a ban on all or some cigarettes if, as expected, an examination confirms the surgeon general's findings in recant years on the hazardous nature of cigarette smoking.

title: People in Sports: Tour Too Long for Trevino
description: Lee Trevino, claiming he's an overworked Mexican, plans to cut his appearances on the pro golf tour to 20 weeks next year. I've worked enough for 10 men in the last six years, he said yesterday. I'm not going to work this hard again. I've played in something like 30 tournaments a year since I came on the tour.

title: Flood Situation in Pakistan Is Called Extremely Serious
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 22 Rising floodwaters have no engulfed the second most populous province of Pakistan.

title: Chess: Only a Visionary or One Using Hindsight Can See All Moves
Phillips Tests New Well
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company announced yesterday that it's third successful extension well on the Eldfisk structure in the Norwegian sector of the North Sea tested oil at flow rates ranging from 2,000 to 3,600 barrels a day.

title: 10 Families Ref use Brooklyn Evictions At Paper Plant Site
description: Ten families facing eviction Monday to make way for expansion of a manufacturer in the northside section of Brooklyn say they will refuse to budge.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: 2 ExSubway Inspectors Sue Two former subwaycar inspectors who were dismissed by the Transit Authority last year after they publicized charges of extensive goldbricking in a Bronx maintenance yard, filed suit for $60million in damages against the authority and the Transport Workers Union. The plaintiffs, Bert Schussel, 48 years old, and Daniel Stone, 34, say they and their families have been harassed and that they are unable to obtain other jobs and have been forced to go on welfare.

title: Black Councilman Loses in Berkeley Recall Vote
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Aug. 22in a special election here yesterday, Berkeley residents voted by a 3to2 margin to recall a controversial black City Councilman, D'Army Bailey.

title: LatinSoul Beat Opens East Side Street Festival
description: There was another kind of street scene yesterday on the Lower East Side, but it was in sharp contrast to the anger shown by a crowd that gathered before the Seventh Police Precinct station on Tuesday. Yesterday the mood was festive as the sixth annual Lower East Side Street Festival got under way.

title: In the Bad Old Days, They Had the Sense to Treasure Beans
description: The time has come to talk of beans. After 33 years of prosperity, with the gross national product climbing like fever chart, meat has suddenly become an extravagance for many Americans. One problem is that people have forgotten how to be poor.

title: Princeton Concern Accused Of Deceiving 30,000 People
description: NEWARK, Aug, 22 (AP) A company in Princeton stole $10, apiece from 30,000 people across the country by promising free gifts and cash for written opinions about products, Federal authorities charged today. But the only thing the customers got was a mountain of junk mail, it was charged.

title: Greece Completes the Release Of 350 Imprisoned Opponents
description: ATHENS, Aug. 22 (Reuters) The Greek Government today completed the release of about 350 political prisoners under the amnesty granted by President George Papadopoulos.

title: MRS. E. A. STILLMAN, MOVIE ACTRESS, 77
description: Mrs. Louise Huff Stillman te, who before her marriage was a featured player in the early days of silent films, died yes terday in Doctors Hospital. She was the widow of Edwin A. Stillman, who was president of WatsonStillman, manufacturers of hydraulic machinery. Mrs. Stillman was 77 years old and lived at 155 East 72d Street.

title: LIVESTOCK PRICES SLUMP IN CHICAGO
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 22Prices on the big livestock, grain and soybean futures markets broke sharply here today under waves of selling. Nearly all these basic foodstuffs closed at or near their respective daily downward limits in often frantic trading on both the Chicago Board of Trade and Mercantile Exchange.

title: Rise of Air Ticket Thefts Studied by U.S. and City
description: Federal and local authorities are investigating a growing traffic in stolen airline tickets that they say is costing airlines many millions of dollars a year.

title: Potato Harvest Down
description: ALBANY, Aug. 22 (AP) The acreage of Long Island pa. tatoes is expected to be 7 per cent below the acreage harvested in 1972, the state Crop Reporting Service says. Last year, 27,000 acres of potatoes were harvested on Long Island, compared with an estimated total of 25,000 acres planned for harvest this year.

title: First RCA Color TV Sales In Far East Set in Taiwan
description: The RCA Corporation said yesterday its color television sets would be sold for the first time in the Far East starting next month through a newly appointed distributor on Taiwan.

title: Archdiocesan Post Filled
description: Cardinal Cooke yesterday announced the appointment of the Rev. Joaquin B. Beaumont as director of the archdiocesan office of the Spanish Apostolate, serving New York city's Spanishspeaking Roman Catholics. Father Beaumont, ordained in Spain, in 1959, served as a teacher and parish priest in Venezuela until 1964, when he came to New York.

title: Saigon Reports Biggest Battle In Highlands Since CeaseFire
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 22 (AP)  Vietcong attack on a Government ranger position touched off the biggest battle in South Vietnam's Central Highlands region since the ceasefire last January, the Saigon command reported today.

title: Coast Girl Sets World Swim Mark
U.S. Motion to Bar Analysis on Pennsy Blocked by I.C.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP)The Interstate Commerce Commission today denied a request by Government lawyers to throw out major portion of evidence offered by the Penn Central Railroad in support of its plan to cease operations by the first of the year.

title: Woman Accused of Attempt To Sell Heroin to Detective
description: District Attorney Mario Merola of the Bronx yesterday an nounced the arrest of a 26yearold woman on charges of attempting to sell almost two pounds of heroin to an undercover detective in a motel just behind a Bronx police precinct house.

title: FRANCE SEEKS TALKS TO END LIP DISPUTE
description: PARIS, Aug. 22 (UPI)A Government mediator met with Industry Minister Jean Charbonnel today on whether to make new offers to workers of the bankrupt Lip Watchmaking Factory who took over the plant and ran it for weeks before they were ousted by police.

title: CONTRACTS AWARDS
description: MorrisonKnudson Company, Inc., announced yesterday that it had been awarded a $9.8million contract by the Army for construction of four buildings to house communications equipment and offices at Fort Belvoir, Va.

title: Transit Police Roam World Where Risk Is Just Routine
description: The incessant din of the subway trains assails the senses. Wheels grind out minute particles of steel dust into the stale air. Anonymous faces bob in and out of focus as the rushhour crowds surge through a nether world where the sun never shines. For those who patrol daily the 231 miles of New York City subways, the transit policeman's lot is not a cushy one.

title: Metropolitan Naval District Held Worst in Keeping Men
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UPI) Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, says the Third Naval District, which includes New York, Connecticut and northern New Jersey, has the worst problem in the Navy in keeping enough men in the reserves.

title: Jewish Congress Hits Soviet on Games
description: Citing harassment suffered by the Israeli basketball team and its Soviet Jewish fans at the World University Games, the American Jewish Congress urged American athletes yesterday not to participate in sports events in the Soviet Union.

title: Fire Islanders Make 2d Effort to Halt All Commercial Growth on Seashore
description: Backed by former Interior Secretary Stewart L. Udall, an association representing all the communities on Fire Island asked yesterday for an injunction to halt all commercial development on the island because, it says, the fragile barrier beach is being destroyed.

title: Manhasset Sail Is Won By Beeman
PENTAGON EXPECTS MORE BASE CLOSINGS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) The Defense Department said today that it expected to order the closing of a significant number of military bases by next spring.

title: All Police Above Captain Will Face Annual Review Cawley Sets New Policy,With Officers Eligible for Reappointment Subject to Evaluation of Their Performance;
description: In an effort to get better performance from his top commanders, Police Commissioner Donald F. Cawley announced yesterday that effective immediately all those above the rank of captain would be subject to reappointment every year and would have to earn that reappointment. The highest civil service rank in the Police Department is captain. All higher ranks are by appointment of the commissioner and the commanders serve at his pleasure. In the past, however, commanders were rarely reduced in rank except for some major dereliction.

title: Lindsay Vetoes a 2d Bill Redistricting the Council
