description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday vetoed a City Council reapportionment proposal on the ground that not enough consideration was given by the Council to the vitality and integrity of numerous neighborhoods which make our cities so varied and so special.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Washington Township in Gloucester County hopes become the first municipality in New Jersey to cast computer ballots at the polls, the County Clerk said yesterday.

title: PLUMBER LOCALS ACCEPT RATE CUT
description: Five Connecticut locals of the plumbers union and a statewide association of mechanical contractors yesterday announced agreement on a new twoyear contract providing for a lower hourly rate for work on residential housing than on commercial and industrial construction.

title: Meeting the Press
description: President Nixon has at long last confronted the nation in a televised press conference on the tough and deeply troubling questions of Watergate in particular and the abuse of Governmental powers in general. Mr. Nixon's mood, through the ordeal of fifty minutes of often harsh questioning, stood in marked contrast to the imperious burst of illtemper with which he had ordered his press secretary to shield him from reporters only two days earlier. Indeed, the President conducted himself with such selfconfident and conciliatory good humor that it is hard to understand why he had postponed for more than five months a televised interrogation for which the American people have clearly been waiting.

title: EDGAR Y. CLAUSEN
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Aug. 22Edgar Y. Clausen, former president of the Peerless Coal and Coke Company of Vivian, W. Va., and a resident here since 1941, died today at the Norwalk Hospital. His age was 95.

title: Manila Detains 36 in Sect for Not Voting in July
description: MANILA, Aug. 22Thirtysix Jehovah's Witnesses have been detained for failing to register and to vote in last month's referendum, which extended President Ferdinand E. Marcos's administration, and many more may also be penalized,

title: Nastase, Gonzales Victors in Jersey
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. 3., Aug. 22  Top seeded Me Nastase survived the strong serve of Herb FitzGibbon of New York to post a 63, 6.7, 63 victory today in firstround play of the $30,000 Eastern tennis open championships at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

title: Personal Finance: Drawing Up of Will
description: A wise person has a will drawn by a good lawyer. The service may cost $25 in some rural areas, $50 to $100 in cities and more if a complicated estate plan is involved. Some persons can and do prepare their own wills, possibly to save a fee, perhaps because they feel confident of their ability to phrase a proper will.

title: State Weighs Reducing Park Fees on Weekdays
description: ALBANY, Aug. 22 (AP)The state's Parks and Recreation Department is considering cheaper parkentrance fees on weekdays to spread out heavy weekend park use, and a possible ban on motorboats in stateowned lakes is being weighed.

title: Police Donate for Charities
description: Police Commissioner Donald F. Cawley presented $49,400 in checks to representatives of 28 charity organizations in a ceremony at police headquarters yesterday. The money was raised in contributions by police officers. Of the checks, $25,000 went to the Police Athletic League and $10,000 to the (Salvation Army.

title: Ship Work Contract Set
description: The Frigitemp Corporation has obtained a $40million subcontract from Litton Industries Ingalls Shipbuilding Division at Pascagoula, Miss., for joiner installation work on amphibious assault ships.

title: 8 NOTE RATE SET BY TREASURY
New Jersey Sports
description: MOUNTAINSIDE, Aug. 22The CanadianNew Jersey exchange diving meet, to be held Sunday at the Mountainside community pool, represents more than competition between youngsters from two countries. It has captured all the goodwill that was expected when the meet. was initiated nine years ago.

title: Not So Conventional
description: WASHINGTONPublic interest in arms control has been focused almost exclusively on strategic nuclear weapons. Certainly this is one of the most urgent items on the national agenda. However, I believe we are making an error if we allow the horrors of nuclear weapons to blind us to the rapidly escalating dangers of another class of weaponsthose we call conventional.

title: Books of The Times
description: A LIFE. By Wright Morris. 152 pages. Harper & Row. $5.95.

title: Business Briefs
description: WOLFSBURG, West Germany, Aug. 22 (AP)Sources close to Volkswagen said today that the West German auto giant would probably drop plans for an auto assembly plant in the United States.

title: Pesticide Safeguards on Farms Asked
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 Farm workers are being killed and maimed by toxic pesticides while the Government refuses to implement a Federal law restricting their use, a delegation of union officials, lawyers, and scientists charged today.

title: Union and Chrysler Resume Negotiations Over Contract
description: DETROIT, Aug. 22 (AP) With a mandate to strike the Chrysler Corporation if necessary, negotiators for the United Automobile Workers returned to the bargaining table today, saying they hoped a new contract could be reached without la walkout. The deadline is Sept. 14.

title: 2 MEN ACCUSED HERE OF BOOKLET AD FRAUD
description: Two Pennsylvania men have been charged with fraudulent misrepresentation for allegedly using highpressure selling tactics to obtain advertisements for booklets purporting to promote child safety.

title: Chilean Town Hopes Army Ends Unrest
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 22The people of La Bandera are tired of politics and hope the military will restore order to this troubled country.

title: Oil Industry Assailed
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Aug. 22 (UPI)Representative Bill Gunter, Democrat of Florida, accused the nation's oil industry today of using the socalled energy crisis to gain price rises and environmental concessions such as offshore drilling leases. He said he opposed a Federal proposal to allow offshore oil drilling at Florida, Alabama and Mississippi until vital questions are answered about the possibility that the drilling would hurt tourism and force the closing of military bases in northwest Florida.

title: Malwak Equals Record In Saratoga Turf Score
description: The achievement was distinctive for another reason, for the record setter, Red Reality of the At the Cragwood Stable, finished Race third, back of Tracks William Haggin Perry's Astray.

title: TEACHER IS SEIZED ON HEROIN CHARGE
description: A junior high school biology teacher was seized at Criminal !Court yesterday and accused of !selling heroin to teenagers in Harlem.

title: Kearny, the City, Seeks Kearny, a City Con Man
description: KEARNY, N. J., Aug. 22 (UPI)  In New York City there's a hank teller who thinks Kearny, N.J., is a man.

title: Pathet Lao, Assailing Revolt, Urges Early Peace Pact
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 22In the wake of the abortive righ twing coup Monday, the Communistled Pathet Lao urged the Government here today to sign a peace agreement quickly and establish a coalition to govern Laos.

title: Pope Advocates Return To Old Chants in Mass
description: ROME, Aug. 22  Pope Paul VI today advocated a return to traditional Latin and Gregorian chants in the Roman Catholic liturgy.

title: Rhythm and Satire at Street Festival
description: Yesterday's early matinee, Black Love, the second offering of the Lincoln Center Community/Street Theater Festival, was a rhythmic, melodic and superbly choreographic interpretation of the black experience by the visiting Theater West of Dayton, Ohio.

title: Dance: Cynthia Gregory's Dying Swan
description: LEE, Mass., Aug. 22Ballerinas hunger after The Dying Swan the way actors persue Hamlet. Sometimes dancers abilities match their ardor and sometimes not, but it is always fascinating to see a dancer such as Cynthia Gregory attempt this famous choreographic fragment. Her reading of the role at Jacob's Pillow last night was modestly successful.

title: 5 Newsmen Believed Held By Vietcong North of Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug 22 (Reuters)Five newsmenone French and four West Germanare believed to have been detained by the Vietcong north of Saigon today, South Vietnamese military spokesman here said.

title: Volunteers Go West as Fire Duty Calls
description: BOISE, Idaho, Aug. 22 (UPI) Two New Jersey firefighting crews awaited forest fire duty in the northwestern United States today where flames have scorched nearly 200,000 acres in a five state region.

title: The 25Year Rise of a Friend of Agnew
Rogers: A Nixon Loyalist Upstaged While in Office
SCHOOL JOB STUDY FINDS HINT OF BIAS
description: NEWARK, Aug. 22Though there have been changes in the screening process, the way io which principals and vice principals are appointed in the publicschool system here still carries the persistent tinge ok discriminatory practices, according to a study by the Rutgers Graduate School of Education.

title: STOCKS RETREAT IN LIGHT TRADING
7 Members of an Indicted Agnew Panel Are Identified
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Aug. 22 Seven prominent Maryland Republicans, all friends or supporters of Vice President Agnew, were identified by the state prosecutor here today as members of a committee indicted yesterday for conspiracy to conceal a $49,900 contribution to an Agnew testimonial last year.

title: City Food Costs Dip After a 6Week Rise
description: The first overall price decline in the citymonitored food Market Basket Index in six weeks was reported yesterday by the city's Department of Consumer Affairs.

title: Occidental to Pay More
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation announced yesterday that it had raised the price thatit pays for sour and intermediate crude oil in West Texas and New Mexico by 15 cents. The company is now paying $4.20 a barrel for the sour crude and $4.31 a barrel for intermediate grade crude. Occidental said the new prices conform to Phase 4 regulations.

title: DAISE E. TERRY
description: ALPINE, Calif. Aug. 22 (AP)  Daise E. Terry, former editorial office manager of The New Yorker magazine, died Monday at the age of 89.

title: World Hunger
description: American concern for the world's poorest people is danger of falling victim to domestic preoccupation with the high cost of food and its short supply. Private American relief agencies, whose efforts have prevented famine and death among the 100 million of the world's most destitute countries, report that their contributions of wheat, flour, and other food stuffs are about to dry up. After twenty years of saving lives, the end of overseas relief is feared to be imminent. The consequence would be worldwide suffering.

title: Nastase and Smith Share Top Seed
CRIME IN VILLAGE PROTESTED BY 400 Residents Ask More Police and End to Drug Traffic
description: Four hundred Greenwich Village residents, alarmed by two murders in an eightday period this month, demonstrated in front of the Sixth Precinct police station last night, demanding more foot patrolmen and new laws to clear the Village of drug pushers and users.

title: 30 More Food Places on List As City Health Code Violators
TAPE CASE ARGUED IN FEDERAL COURT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22President Nixon's lawyer and the Justice Department's special Watergate prosecutor clashed in court today over whether the President has the right to withhold records of his conversations from a grand jury investigating crime.

title: Dollar Fluctuates in European Trading
description: LONDON, Aug. 22 (UPI)The dollar fluctuated in European trading today, but maintained a generally upward level. The price of gold was down.

title: Chile's Labor Federation Bids Members Defend Government
description: SANTIAGO. Chile, Aug. 22Chile's national labor federation, the Central Workers Union, called on its 1.4 million members today to defend the Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens from the current wave of sedition.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: ADMIRALTY ISLAND, Alaska  Some years ago while fishing for landlocked salmon and brook trout in northern Quebec, I gained great respect for the Mickey Finn streamer fly, probably because it was the only one our FrenchCanadian guides recommended.

title: Badillo Bows Out
description: Representative Herman Badillo's understandably reluctant decision not to run as an independent candidate for Mayor of New York City this year seems clearly the politically correct and responsible thing for him to have done. Having lost twice in previous Democratic primary contests, he would have made a mockery of the primary process by persisting in a mayoral candidacy.

title: Little Difficulty in Senate Is Seen Over Confirmation of Kissinger as Secretary
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22Henry A. Kissinger is expected to be confirmed as Secretary of State with little difficulty when Congress reconvenes in September, although several members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee said today that they planned to question him thoroughly.

title: Construction Outlays Set
description: United Telecommunications, Inc., expects to spend about $300million for construction next year, up from its 1973 capital budget of $271million, Raymond M. Alden, president, told security analysts here yesterday.

title: DEFECT IS HINTED IN CHRYSLER CARS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22  The Federal Government warned today of a possible safety defect in 2.5 million pas senger cars built by the Chrysler Corporation.

title: Dollar Fluctuates in European Trading
Operations Consolidated
description: Spring Mills announced yesterday that it will consolidate its terry fabric operation into two of its most modern plants the Patricia and Crandall plants near Wagram, N. C. As part of the consolidation moved the company said the Laurinburg, N. C. plant will be closed and the production of knitted dishcloths and flat woven fabrics will be discontinued. The terry production will be transferred to the Patricia plant.

title: Warning on Bowling Pin Coating Spurs Layoffs
description: LOWVILLE, N.Y., Aug. (AP)Federal designation of bowling pin coating as a possible cause of cancer has led to unemployment for 47 persons in this north country village.

title: Cancer All Around Us
description: STONY BROOK, N. Y.The battle against cancer may fall victim to man's tendency to take shortterm action while ignoring longterm consequences. Poisons that kill people on the spot are banned or carefully regulated, but substances whose effects are deadly decades later continue to be tolerated.

title: BREITEL ASKS INQUIRY INTO CRIME'S CAUSES
description: Judge Charles D. Breitel called last night for the spending of enormous sums to determine the cause of the crime explosion that has taken place in the state.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:As Watergate has unfolded, and our Federal Government has reflected signs of a developing paralysis, commentators have discussed the manyfold angles and crannies of resignation or impeachment of the executive as avenues for the resolution of our nation's political dilemma.

title: The Kissinger Appointment: A New Approach to Conduct of Foreign Policy Is Seen
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22Long before President Nixon nominated him to be Secretary of State, Henry A. Kissinger had decided that the problems of American foreign policy in Mr. Nixon's second term would be quite different from the problems of the first term, and therefore squired a new approach to the formulation, negotiation and presentation of foreign policy. No doubt there were subjective reasons for the appoint. ment of Mr. Kissingerthe need to change the question and the headlines, to get the mind of the country off Watergate by action rather than by words, to give a sense of a new beginning  but there were compelling objective reasons as

title: KISSINGER PLANS MORE OPEN POLICY IN FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 23Henry A. Kissinger, newly nominated to be Secretary of State, pledged today to carry out a more open foreign policy in which Congress, the State Department and private citizens would have a stronger voice.

title: Montgomery Shatters A.A.U. Swimming Mark
Police Investigate Report of Plot By Two Blacks to Kill President
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 23 (AP)  Federal agents and the New Orleans police are investigating a report, as yet unconfirmed, that two black extremists plotted to kill President Nixon, according to sources close to the investigation.

title: 9 Allegedly in Black Army Indicted Here
description: Nine persons described as the top echelon of the Black Liberation Army were indicted in Brooklyn yesterday on charges ranging from murder and attempted murder to robbery, grand larceny and possession of guns.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: William R. Baird, the birthcontrol advocate, attempted unsuccessfully yesterday to see Mayor Lindsay at City Hall for an explanation of the shortest political career in history. Mr. Baird, who said he had been appointed on Tuesday as a consultant on abortion and birth control the Mayor's Office for Veterans Action, found he had been let go from the nonsalaried advisory position the next day.

title: WILLIAM NAFASH, 69, PROJECTIONIST, DIES
description: William Nafash, chief projectionist at Radio City Music Hall, died, apparently of a heart attack, on Wednesday evening en route to his home in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn. He was 69 years old.

title: Alcan Acquisition Set
description: TORONTO (Canadian Press) Alcan Canada Products, Ltd., has purchased Air Mastetr of Canada, Ltd., Lambeth, Ontario. Air master is a manufacturer and supplier of aluminum windows and doors.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23The Government, in a move to encourage commercial banks to make mortgage loans, told banks today that they no longer have to limit mortgage interests rates to midApril levels.

title: 3 Chinese Attend a L.I. Physics Parley
description: STONY BROOK, L.I., Aug. 23  Three physicists from Peking attended the opening session of a twoday international physics conference here today.

title: Bomb in London Station Is Defused at Rush Hour
description: LONDON, Aug. 23Railway stations in London became the latest targets for a bomb attack and bombing threats tonight after four days in which bombs had been planted in department stores.

title: State Auditors Bar Paying $3.8Million To City on Addicts
description: State auditors have disallowed $3.8million of $10.1million in claims made by the city's Addiction Services Agency, according to a report yesterday by State Controller Arthur Levitt.

title: A Murder Suspect Gets to See Her Infant Son for First Time
description: A murder suspect was briefly allowed to see her weekold son for the first time Tuesday night, thanks to the intervention of judge. But the baby was taken from her following the mother's return yesterday to Tioga County Jail in Owego.

title: Retail Store Sales Up 11%
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $956million, up 12 per cent from the yearearlier $853million. Total retail store sales were about $9.469billion, up 11 per cent, from last year's $8.512billion.

title: ROBERT D. SWENSEN
description: BETHESDA, Md., Aug. 23Robert D. Swensen, manager of the operational division of the Communications Satellite Corporation, Washington, died Friday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 40 years old.

title: Retailers Issue Reports
C.D.C. Limits Offer On Texasgulf Stock
description: The Canada Development Corporation announced yesterday that it will not accept tenders for more than 10 million shares of Texasgulf, Inc. common stock in response to its offer to purchase Texasgulf shares at $29 a share in cash. Canada development also said it had extended its offer to Aug. 31. It was the sec and extension of the offer. The company said that a total of 8,204,000 shares had been tendered as of Aug. 22.

title: GANNETT IN A PACT TO BUY MORE PAPERS
description: ROCHESTER, Aug. 23 (AP) The Gannett Company, Inc., has announced agreement in principle to acquire three daily newspapers in Springfield, Mo., and Muskogee, Okla., and their broadcast affiliates in common stock transactions totaling $33.4million.

title: Miss Robinowitz Bride of A. E. Randall
description: RYE, N.Y., Aug. 23Miss Cathy L. Robinowitz and Andrew E. Randall, 1973 graduates of Bradley University, were married in the garden of the Rye Town Hilton this afternoon by Rabbi Samuel Silver.

title: HUE BOMBARDMENT IS SAID TO CONTINUE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 23, (Reuters)  Communist troops fired more than 300 mortar shells into Government positions guarding the former imperial capital of Hue, the South Vietnamese command said today.

title: Brooklyn Coop's Tenants Win Ouster of Management Board
description: The city's Housing and Development Administration yielded yesterday to the demand of the ownertenants of the Lindsay Park middleincome cooperative in Brooklyn to replace the original management board representing the sponsor with one representing the residents.

title: Kissinger Goal: To Clear the Air
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23Henry A. Kissinger moved quickly today to make known his hope that the final years of the Nixon Administration would be marked by an open foreign policy that would produce less friction with Congress, more information for the American people and some meaningful work for the State Department.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: BAY STATE IS ENDING COMPUTER BANK USE
description: BOSTON, Aug. 23 (UPI)An official of the Massachusetts Mental Health Department has decided to stop feeding the names of patients confined at state institutions into a computer bank in Orangeburg, N.Y.

title: Rule on Petition Signatures By Air Force Is Nullified
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UPI) A Federal judge declared unconstitutional today an Air Force regulation requiring servicemen to obtain permission from their commanders before they can collect signatures for a petition.

title: JOHN E. HERLIHY JR.
description: John E. Herlihy Jr., a broker with E. F. Hutton & Co. and former advertising manager for Newsweek International in New York and London, died Wednesday in New York Hospital. He was 49 years old and lived at 252 East 61st Street.

title: 20,000 IN 72 LOST PENSION BENEFITS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23Nearly 20,000 persons who were either retired or were still working but had accumulated advance pension benefits lost $48.7million last year when their companies terminated private pension plans, according to a report to President Nixon. The report, compiled by the Treasury and Labor Departments, was made public today.

title: U. S. Scientist Back From Hanoi Numbed by Raid Devastation
description: An American scientist who just returned from a 19day inspection trip to North Vietnam said yesterday that he was embarrassed and saddened and numbed by the bomb damage there.

title: Researchers in England Seeking Clues To Switching System in Living Cells
description: Researchers in Cambridge, England, are investigating one of the most basic elements of the life process: the switching system that, in all living cells, regulates the flow of information needed for their function.

title: Vesco Said to Believe Return Would Affect Watergate Case
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Aug. 23 (AP)Robert L. Vesco, the New Jersey financier whose extradition to the United States was rejected by the courts here, said in an interview published today that he believed his presence in the United States would aggravate the Watergate case.

title: CANADA APPROVES A RISE IN GAS PRICE
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 23 (Canadian Press)The National Energy Board has confirmed that natural gas export price increase under a contract between Westcoast Transmission, Ltd., of Vancouver and a United States concern is acceptable, a board official said today.

title: Borg Topples Rosewall; Laver Beaten by Molina
Lottery Numbers
description: Winning numbers drawn on Aug. 23 were:

title: DR. ROLF L BOLIN, MARINE BIOLOGIST
description: CARMEL, Calif., Aug. 23Dr. Rolf L. Bolin, a marine biologist and a professor of marine biology and oceanography at Stanford University from 1930 to 1966, died of cancer last evening at Monterey Peninsula Community Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived here.

title: FRAUD IS CHARGED IN WHISKY OFFEER
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 'The The Securities and Exchange Commission today filed fraud charges against GlenArden Commodities, Inc.. in connection with the sale of Scotch whisky investment contracts.

title: Finally, A Little Good News
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23With the appointment of Henry Kissinger as Secretary of State, there is now virtually a whole new Cabinet and top White House staff moving into place here, and what is probably more important, they are bringing new attitudes to their work.

title: Further Gain Is Seer
Medical Miracle
description: Current disillusionment with scientific progress makes it unfashionable to refer to any event as a medical miracle, but it certainly qualifies as extraordinary that today Louis B. Russell Jr., a black junior high school teacher in Indianapolis, completes five years of lifemost of it marked by good health and vigorous activity with a stranger's heart in his chest.

title: Stockton, 2 Others Share Leadon 67's
description: CARY, N.C., Aug. 23Dave Stockton said that spike marks on the putting greens had both helped and hurt him as he scored a 67 today and shared the lead in the $100,000 Liggett & Myers golf tournament.

title: U.S. Prosecutors Disclose Inquiry on Judges in State
description: Federal prosecutors disclosed here yesterday that they were investigating at least two cases involving some evidence of possible criminal conduct by state court judges.

title: Former P.O.W. to Run
description: SANTA FE, N. M., Aug. 23 (AP)  Col. James Lindberg Hughes of the Air Force, a former prisoner of war in North Vietnam, said last night that he would seek the Republican nomination for Governor of New Mexico in 1974.

title: An Engaging Ingenue Gets Only One Star, for Now
description: The restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judgment of quality in relation to the price of meal's and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Indians Surrender in Iowa After State Office Protest
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 23 (UPI)Ten armed members of the American Indian Movement took over the State Department of Public Instruction offices yesterday but surrendered peacefully and were arrested after law enforcement officers threatened a showdown.

title: FUCHSBERG RECEIVES KRETCHMER BACKING
description: Jerome Kretchmer, former Environmental Protection Administrator, yesterday endorsed Jacob D. Fuchsberg, the Democcatic nominee, for election as chief judge of the State Court of Appeals.

title: Oiler's Passing Tops Cowboys
Waldheim Asks Aid to FloodHit Pakistan
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 23Secretary General Waldheim appealed to governments and relief agencies today to assist Pakistan, a country stricken by devastating floods. He said that the floods had destroyed $250million in crops and left five million people homeless.

title: New Group Battling Abplanalp For Control of Sullivan Airport
description: MONTICELLO, N. Y., Aug. 23  A new group was reported today to be competing with Robert H. Abplanalp, the millionaire industrialist, for control of the allbutdormant Sullivan County International Airport.

title: CANADA'S EXPORTS ROSE BY 4% IN JULY
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 23 (Reuters) Canada's seasonally adjusted expcirts in July rose 4 per cent to $2,068billion from June's $1.986billion, up 35 per cent from a year earlier, Statistics Canada said in a preliminary statement today.

title: Diplomatic Partnership?
description: Secretary of Statedesignate Henry A. Kissinger struck just the right note yesterday with his promise to conduct a more open, bipartisan foreign policy in full and new partnership with Congress. If this revolutionary change in the Administration's approach to the conduct of foreign affairs receives full Presidential support, there is every reason for hope that the initial favorable Congressional response to Mr. Kissinger's nomination can be sustained, with longterm benefits for American diplomacy.

title: Campo's Fillies Fancied By a Lady Named Mike
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 23Mike Ryan is a girl Mary Elizabeth Ryan of Laurel, Md., to be exact. Nobody on the race track calls her by any other name than Mike, and most people know her because she's the assistant to Johnny Campo in the task of training 43 horses now an the grounds. Mike Ryan is confident she will be in the winner's circle tomorrow, after the 82d running of the Spinaway. A field of 10 has been named for the sixfurlong sprint for 2yearold fillies, and Campo will be represented by the entry of Elmendorf's Talking Picture and the Sunninghill Farm's Khaled's Kaper.

title: JOHN G. JACKSON JR.
description: John G. Jackson Jr., counsel to the law firm of Jackson, Nash, Brophy, Barringer & Brooks, of which he was a former senior partner, died Wednesday in Community Hospital, Glen Cove, L. I. He was 63 years old and lived on Cedar Ridge Road in Locust Valley, L. I.

title: Fashion Is Usually Harmless Enough But This Is a Menace
description: The man, an avowed chauvinist legwatcher, couldn't believe his eyes. As a matter of fact, it ruined his lunch.

title: Newsprint Shortage Is Causing Cutbacks in Newspapers Sizes
description: A newsprint shortage caused by a strike at Canadian paper mills has forced some newspapers to reduce the size of their papers and others to reduce the waste of paper, according to a survey by United Press International.

title: Linda Kay Schwartz Wed to Philip Carlson
description: OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 23Miss Linda Kay Schwartz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Schwartz of Roslyn, was married this evening to Philip Reed Carlson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Carlson of Toledo, Ohio. Rabbi Eugene Lipsey performed the ceremony at the Old Westbury Country Club.

title: Angkor Region Is Quiet Under Unwritten Truce
description: SIEM REAP, Cambodia, Aug. 19  In this region of Cambodia, where rice fields and jungle are strewn with the superb ruins of the 12thcentury Angkor civilization, the recent American bombing halt has had no effect so far, for the war here had long been in virtual suspense.

title: P.U.C. Eases Its Restrictions On Bell Payments to A.T.&T
description: NEWARK, Aug. 23  The Board of Public Utility Commissioners conceded today that the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company did not have to give it 45 days notice on dividend payments that Bell made to the parent American Telephone & Telegraph Company. But the board otherwise affirmed the state's right to regulate the size of the payments.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: LONG BRANCH, Aug. 23For the last 10 years the summer slogan among distance runners along north shore areas of New Jersey has been, See you at Takanasse.

title: Exchanges Feeling Profit Pinch
description: The nation's stock exchanges, symbols of wealth and power in the world of finance, are having trouble earning money themselves.

title: Une de Mai Looks Like a Million as the International Draws Near
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 23 It was so serene as the sunlight filtered through the trees near the International Barn this morning that it was jolting to hear a special policeman say, That damned horse is the meanest animal I ever saw.

title: ExState Senator Held As Gambling Ring Chief
description: A former state legislator who served nearly three years in prison for perjury, grand larceny and plotting to murder a witness was arrested yesterday in his East Village apartment and charged with running a gambling operation that the police say handled more than $1million a year in bets.

title: Tighter Credit Conditions Are Reported by Reserve
Cuba We Were at Fault We're Sorry
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 23 (AP)The Cubans said they were sorry and were given a mild reprimand for attacking their United States rivals in a World University Games basketball contest yesterday.

title: MURDER TRIAL SET FOR MARCOS FOE
description: MANILA, Aug. 23A former leading Opposition senator who was arrested 11 months ago has been charged with subversion and murder.

title: 9 Allegedly in Black Army Indicted Here
description: Nine persons described as the top echelon of the Black Liberation Army were indicted in Brooklyn yesterday on charges ranging from murder and attempted murder to robbery, grand larceny and possession of guns.

title: NAMING OF KISSINGER WELCOMED IN ISRAEL
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 23Henry A. Kissinger's nomination as Secretary of State was welcomed in Jerusalem today.

title: Prices of Bonds Register Sharp Rise in Active Day
VETERANS LINKED TO VIOLENCE PLAN
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Aug. 23  A police undercover agent told a jury here today how he infiltrated the Vietnam Veterans Against the War.

title: Stein Cites Real Income Gain; An Oil Price Rise Is Challenged
description: WASHINGTON, Aug, 23 Herbert Stein, President Nixon's chief economic adviser, said today that many Americans are better off than they think.

title: Solzhenitsyn Denounces Residence Curbs
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 23  Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the dissident author, disclosed today that he had been barred from living legally in Moscow. He used the occasion for an angry attack on the Soviet Union's residence controls as a demeaning system that probably does not exist even in the colonial countries.

title: Bridge:
description: A considerable literature on the Precision System has grown up during the four years since it first made its impact in the 1969 world championship. For serious students of this popular method two advanced books of European authorship are now available in American editions.

title: DRUG SUSPECT HELD IN $1MILLION BAIL
description: A 39yearold Sicilian accused of being the Mexican connection in a multimillion dollar international heroin smuggling ring, was held in $1million bail last night after arraignment in Brooklyn Federal Court in Brooklyn.

title: A Mime Entertains 100 at Public Library
description: Lunchtime strollers stood raptly silent in front of the New York Public Library yesterday as a lean, whitefaced figure clad in black from neck to toe plastered an imaginary wall, tugged on a nonexistent rope and drove a phantom automobile up the library steps.

title: East Side Hotel Robbed of $100,000 By 2 Gunmen in Late Night Holdup
description: A team of unhurried gunmen invaded the lobby of the sedate Croydon Hotel 86th Street off Fifth Avenue early yesterday, subdued seven persons, including the jazz musician Maynard Ferguson, and made off with loot estimated at $100,000 in cash and jewels.

title: People and Business
description: Dr. Eleanor Bernert Sheldon, president of the Social Science Research Council of New York, has been named the first woman director of the First National City Corporation, and of its chief subsidiary, the First National City Bank.

title: Despite Shortages, the Chinese Cope and Then Some
description: Beneath the veneer of uniformity and drabness that many visitors to China have reported, the ordinary people in their everyday living show ingenuity and resourcefulness in coping with adversity and, in their fashion, savor many small pleasures of life.

title: Auto Sales Climb 11.4% to Set a Record
description: DETROIT, Aug. 23  The auto industry today reported an 11.4 per cent jump in sales to a record 207,555 cars in the Aug. 1120 period, up from 186,270 in the comparable period a year ago.

title: Cambodia Reports Foe Yields 3 Posts Near Provincial Capital
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Friday, Aug. 24 (AP)Government troops have recaptured three positions important to the defense of the provincial capital of Kompong Speu and Phnom Penh's highway to the sea, the Cambodian military command reported yesterday.

title: Policeman Cleared
description: TRENTON, Aug. 23 (UP1)A state appeals court today overturned the misconduct conviction of Sgt. Lawrence Mecca of Milltown, charged with using his patrol car on a private erran. The Appellate Division of the Superior Court ruled that while it did not condone Sergeant Mecca's action the case was more appropriately a matter of disciplinary action.

title: Program Pressure
description: Even in the usual sleepy season of summer reruns and tryouts, the television networks and stations are finding that the pressure groups never rest. C.B.S. has had more than its share this year of boycott campaigns started by wouldbe censors among its viewers.

title: U.S. Five Advances To Final
GENERAL ACCUSED ON EXECUTIVE JET
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP)  The General Accounting Office reported to Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, today that an Air Force general had spent $670,000 in public funds to convert his aircraft into a plush executive jet.

title: False Labeling of Wine Investigated in France
description: BORDEAUX, France, Aug. 23 (UPI)Revenue agents today investigated a reported wine fraud involving false labeling of 1.9 million bottles of red Bordeaux wine, French newspapers said.

title: Nixon Drive May Have Got; 15 Illegal Corporate Gifts
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 Government investigators now believe that as many as 15 or 20 of the names on a White, House master list of campaign contributors may represent illegal cash donations from corporations, according to sources close to the investigation. The sources said these donations totaled up to $1.5million.

title: N.C.R. and Control Data Set A Joint Computer Venture
description: The National Cash Register Company and the Control Data Corporation announced yesterday the formation of the CDCNCR Advanced Systems Laboratory to conduct joint design of future computer central processing units.

title: HOTELIER ACCUSED OF WELFARE FRAUD
description: The ownermanager of a midtown welfare hotel was arrested yesterday on fraud charges involving the illegal cashing of more than $6,000 in publicassistance checks.

title: Weekend Fishing: Exotic Catches Near Shinnecock
description: From time to time in late summer, certain fish normally found in southern waters appear off New England New York and New Jersey One of the more unusual instances in recent weeks was the 55pound wahoo caught 90 miles off Long Island's Shinnecock Inlet by an angler aboard Don Lehman's Maverick.

title: STOCKS REBOUND IN BROAD ADVANCE;Dow Rises 12.56 to 864.46 in Market's Best Climb in Almost a Month; VOLUME REMAINS LIGHT; Analysts Discern Little in Economic News to Set Off Sudden Upswing
New Jersey Briefs
description: Angelo DeCarlo paid the first installment of a $20,000 fine yesterday when his wife appeared in Federal Court and presented a check for $2,000. A judge had ordered the reputed Mafia leader to pay the fine or be returned to prison.

title: Books of The Times
description: I once confided to an interviewer, who promptly printed it, that I thought Jimmy Breslin was nothing but a saloon reporter. Well, I couldn't have been more wrong. Jimmy Breslin just happens to be weightforage one of the best writers of our day. He is a man who is gifted with absolute, I repeat, absolute pitch so far as the dialogue of Queens is concerned and more than that, Queens mores, rites, rituals, philosophy, the geography not only of Queens but also of the Queens mind and, going far beyond, an understanding, a wry, hardboiled sympathy for that whole class that may well be the decisive class of our day, which goes under the ,generic term of hard hats but which Karl Marx would have readily recognized as the working class or proletariat, albeit now gussied up with white collar, two or three cars, a mortgaged splitlevel and an adolescent (but only halfbelieved) faith that it has now made it into the middle

title: Nastase Is Upset By Parun
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 23  Ilie Nastase was upset by Onny Parun, 64, 16, 62, in the second round of the $30,000 Eastern grasscourt tennis championships at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club today.

title: Floriani Testifies
description: TRENTON, Aug. 23 (AP)Atlantic City's Public Safety Director, Mario Floriani, made his second voluntary appearance before a state grand jury investigating allegations of corruption in the resort city's government. Mr. Floriani testified for about an hour and was followed by one other witness, Vincent Torpey.

title: Help for Pennsylvania
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 23 (AP)President Nixon today declared Pennsylvania a major disaster area, eligible for additional Federal aid fo'r repair and relief in the wake of severe storms and floods around June 27 and Aug. 23.

title: Price of Gold Down As Dollar Climbs In Europe Dealings
description: LONDON, Aug. 23 (UPI)The price of gold fell briefly under $100 an ounce today for the second time since May. The United States dollar's value rose nearly everywhere.

title: COURT BAN ASKED ON A PARKING LOT
description: NEWARK, Aug. 23  En vironmentalists asked a Fed. eral Court here today to enjoir temporarily construction of 25,000 carparking lot at the proposed Hackensack Meadow lands sports complex.

title: Broken Faith
description: President Nixon seriously misstated the issue of the secret Cambodian bombing of 196970 in his address the Veterans of Foreign Wars convention in New Orleans.

title: Councilmanic Rerun
description: As if in imitation of the dreary summer rerun season on television, the City Council seems determined to repeat a past mistake. One palpably unconstitutional reapportionment plan was passed by the Council, vetoed by Mayor Lindsay, passed by the Council over his veto and then voided by the courts. A second apparently unconstitutional scheme, in some ways worse than the earlier one, has been passed by the Council and now it, too, has been vetoed by the Mayor. Will the Council persist in its rerun folly by again overriding a thoroughly warranted veto?

title: SKYLAB ASTRONAUTS PREPARE FOR WALK
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 23 (AP)Skylab 2's astronauts, preparing for a fourhour space walk tomorrow, rehearsed today the installation of instruments needed to keep their ship sailing on a true course through space.

title: Soviet Launches Satellite
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 22 (AP)The Soviet Union launched its 580th Cosmos satellite Wednesday, Tass announced. The press agency said the satellite, which is part of a multipurpose series of space probes, completed its first orbit in 92.2 minutes.

title: People in Sports: Five Enter Hockey's Shrine
description: Chuck Rayner, a goalie, and Doug Harvey, a defenseman, were among five men inducted into the Hockey Hall of Fame yesterday in Toronto. Rayner, one of the most popular players ever to play for the New York Rangers, spent 10 years in the National Hockey League, two with the old New York Americans, In 1950 he became the second goalie to win the Hart Trophy as the league's most valuable perfomer. Harvey spent most of his brilliant career with the Montreal Canadiens, then was playercoach of the Rangers in 196162. He won the Norris Trophy seven times as the league's top defenseman. The other three inductees were Senator Hartland de Montan. vile Molson, a former Montreal owner Tommy Smith, a star forward with Quebec in the early 1900's, and Frank Udvari, a N.H.L. referee and now the league's supervisor of officials.

title: Equity Financing
description: A public offering of 200,000 common shares Michigan Gas Utilities Company at $14.25 a share was announced yesterday by Kidder, Peabody & Co. The company's stock closed unchanged at 14 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: 5 Missing Newsmen Safe, Vietcong Spokesman Says
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 23 (Reuters)A Vietcong spokesman said today that five European newsmen who were missing yesterday in a Vietcong zone north of Saigon were safe and being well treated.

title: Inquiry at Justice
description: Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson disclosed that an internal investigation of the Department of Justice was being conducted to learn whether personnel had leaked information about an inquiry involving Vice President Agnew. Details on Page 13.

title: Rail TonMileage Up 6.5%
description: WASHINGTON, Aug 23The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 16.1 billion tonmiles; 6.5 per cent above the corresponding week last yes. Carloadings in the same week totaled 540,249 cars, 4.3 per cent above last year. The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 6.9 per cent above last year.

title: IndiaPakistanTalks Reported Reaching Some Compromise
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 23  A Pakistani spokesman said today that officials were trying hard to reach the stage where an agreement can be worked out on the problems arising from the IndianPakistani war of 1971.

title: Crewman's Slip Cited in Bombing Error Fatal to 137
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23A senior Air Force officer said today that the accidental bombing that killed 137 Cambodians in the town of Neak Luong on Aug. 6 was due primarily to the failure of the B52's radarnavigator to throw a single switch.

title: Screen: Samurai's Trek
Ticket Sales Up for U.S. Tennis
description: Billy Talbert, the tournament director of the United States Open tennis championship, exuded optimism yesterday at the draw for the tournament, which begins Wednesday at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Detective in Bugging Case Is Reinstated
description: A former ??uoklyn police detective who was indicted with another detective last December on bribery charges arising from the electronic bugging of an alleged Mafia meeting place in a Canarsie junkyard won reinstatement to the police force yesterday pending a departmental trial.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: IN THE PARK Central Park is such an expansive tract of woods and greenery that most people think of it by sectors, rather than as a whole. They tend to use it in that more manageable way going in at familiar angles and carving out their own areas of leisure or recreation, or using such welldefined areas as the mall, the meadow or the zoo.

title: Commodity Price Index Off 3.7 From WeekAgo Level
Notes on People
description: Among the actions of the delegates to the American Legion convention in Honolulu was a resolution denouncing persons for their actions and for their verbal attacks upon our prisoners of war. An amendment naming Jane Fonda, the actressactivist, as such a person was defeated. The legion. naires also named Clare Boothe Luce, the playwrightpolitician, as the winner of their Fourth Estate Award and passed a resolution wishing success to Clarence M. Kelley, the new director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Osteen Spell Breaks Met Magic
Beers, on 73, Sets Canada Jump Mark
description: OSLO, Norway, Aug. 23 (AP)John Beers of Canada won the high jump today at 7 feet 3 inches in an international meet and set a Canadian record, He also defeated the world recordholder, Dwight Stones of the United States,

title: Opposition Intensifies in Chile as Legislators Vote to Denounce Allende Government and Its Policies
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 23President Salvador Allende Gossens's experiment of Socialism in Democracy is threatened by intensified opposition that has taken the form of strikes sabotage, street violence and now, Congressional denunciaLion.

title: Memphis Schools Facing Loss of Pupils in Bus Order
description: MEMPHIS, Aug. 23 (AP)After completing a tabulation of registrations, school officials say enrollment in the Memphis system, which faces widescale busing for desegregation on Monday, is down by 20,000 to 30,000 pupils.

title: HARD QUESTIONING OF KISSINGER SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23Statements today by several members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee indicated that Henry A. Kissinger might face far tougher questioning in hearings on his nomination as Secretary of State than was initially indicated.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Forget all those sweaters and tweeds filling the racks of stores around town. Summer is not yet over. Some people have a latesummer vacation ahead of them. And others want some new duds for the big Labor Day weekend. Well, no need to settle for pickedover markdowns. few places still have fresh, clean summer merchandise. Aficionados know that among the best sources are Jax, 7 West 57th Street, and the Veneziano Boutique, 819 Madison Avenue (between 68th and 69th Streets). Jax, of course, has its classic Tshirt. It comes in a rainbow of colors, including pink, orange, blue, green and lavender. It's long enough to tuck into hiphuggers or wear belted on the outside of pants or a skirt, With short sleeves it's $7.95; with long, $9.95.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Aug. 24, 1973 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: U.S. Opposed to Changes In Occupied Arab Lands
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (Reuters)The State Department today reiterated its opposition to changes in the status of Israelioccupied Arab territory in the wake of an Israeli Labor party plan for public and private purchases of Arab lands.,

title: School System Reverses Itself; Will Not Curtail Meat at Lunch
Lottery Numbers Winning numbers drawn on Aug. 23 were: NEW YORK 940429
description: Tickets matching the number above win $50,000. Tickets matching the last five numbers win $5,000. Those matching the last four numbers win $500 and those matching the last three, $50.

title: DR. BLENKNER DIES; GERONTOLOGIST, 64
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Aug. 23Dr. Margaret Blenkner, leader in the field of gerontology, died last Friday. She was 64 years old.

title: Those Who Rely on Tips Say Largesse Is Lagging
description: Are tips keeping up with the tabs?

title: FigureSkate Titlist Seen In L.I. Ice Capades Debut
description: Karen Magnussen, who won the world figure skating championship last March in Czechoslovakia, made her local professional debut Wednesday night at the Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum, Uniondale, L.I.

title: CAMPAIGN LEAFLET IS PARTLY ABSOLVED
description: An investigation into complaints about some literature supporting Controller Abraham D. Beame in the Democratic nayora runoff has concluded that some were unjustified and that there was no existing law to cover others, District Attorney Mario Merola of the Bronx said yesterday.

title: Riggins Explains the Making of a Holdout
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 23 A cleanshaven John Riggins, sporting a Mohawkstyle hairdo, put in his first appearance at the New York Jets training camp at Hofstra University last night and today tried to explain what turned him into a salary holdout.

title: Gil Evans Band Returns
description: Gil Evans is a puzzle. The pianist and arranger, who has been a highly influential member of the jazz community for 25 years, led a commercial dance band in the late thirties that was good enough in its field for Skinnay Ennis to take it over when he left Hal Kemp to go out on his own.

title: Suggestions for the Weekend Chef
description: In the menus below, the dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe. Chilie Rellenos* Refried beans Mexican salad Peach pie CHILIES RELLENOS (Stuffed peppers)

title: HERBERT J. WAGNER
description: POINT PLEASANT, N. J., Aug. 23 (AP)Herbert J. Wagner, former commander of the New Jersey Air Force Reserve, died yesterday in Point Pleasant Hospital. He was 56 years old.

title: 70,000 Donors Listed in G.A.O. Report on 1972 Campaign Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23The Government published today a monumental, computerized compilation of the names of some 70,000 persons who contributed, or lent $79.1million to all candidates in the 1972 Presidential campaign.

title: GANDFILL PROJECT HALTED BY STATE Pollution of Brook Is Called Serious in Westchester
description: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 23file state's Department of Environmental Conservation today used its summary power, normally reserved for airpollution emergencies, to halt landfill operation in central Westchester.

title: KISSINGER PLANS MORE OPEN POLICY IN FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 23Henry A. Kissinger, newly nominated to be Secretary of State, pledged today to carry out a more open foreign policy in which Congress, the State Department and private citizens would have a stronger voice.

title: CAWLEY TO PRESS GRAFT DETECTION
description: Police Commissioner Donald F. Cawley yesterday unveiled a master plan for improving the Police Department, giving high priority to new anticorruption measures, faster police response to emergency calls from the public and the recruitment of more minoritygroup members as policemen.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A team of unhurried gunmen invaded the lobby of the sedate Croydon Hotel on 86th Street near Fifth Avenue early yesterday, subdued seven persons, including the jazz muskian, Maynard Ferguson, and madeoff with an estimated total of $100,000 in cash and jewels.

title: Travel for the Handicapped Eases as Old Obstacles Fall
description: LYNNWOOD, Wash. When Ruth Williams, a retired social worker who lives in Albany, reads a travel brochure, it is in Braille.

title: New Cabs to Get Jump Seat In Front, Shield for Driver
description: Taxi drivers are going to be ensconced in comfortable bucket seats and enclosed in bulletproof metal and glass cabins in fleetoperated cabs, according to a new city mandate.

title: Wedding of Mrs. Susan Ochs And Robert Phillips Held Here
description: Mrs. Susan Ochs of Scarsdale, N. Y., widow of Arthur Ochs Jr. and daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Peiper of 525 Park Avenue, was married here yesterday afternoon to Robert Murr Phillips of Chicago. He is the son of Mrs. Robert Bowman of Cincinnati and the late P. Elias Phillips.

title: The Pop Life
description: Jerry Brandt, best remembered for his freaky and stimulating Electric Circus rock club that enlivened pop life during the late sixties, has tied his promotional talents, and money to Jobriath, a 24yearold singerdancerwritermimepainter who, Mr. Brandt believes, could be the superpop superstar of the seventies to take us beyond where Mick Jagger left us.

title: Nixon's Support of Agnew Falls Short, In View of Vice President's Associates
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23President Nixon's affirmation of confidence yesterday in Vice President Agnew has not eased the tension between their two offices.

title: Red Smith
description: Ten trotting horses from seven countries will race the 15th Roosevelt International tomorrow night for $150,000 and the edification of the gay international set of Westbury, Long Island, in that order. According to the odds in the morning line, Une de Mai of France, Spartan Hanover of the United States and Carosio of Italy are considered most likely to succeed, but if there is such a thing as poetic justice, then Johnny Chapman will somehow manage to steer Delmonica Hanover home in front. Del Miller owns Delmonica Hanover with Arnold Hanger. If it weren't for Delvin Glenn Miller there might not be any such race as the International. And there positively would not be any such horse as Othello, the unbeaten 4yearold that is the Soviet Union's first representative in Roosevelt Raceway's global hoedown.

title: Richardson Discloses an Inquiry On Justice Leaks About Agnew
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson disclosed today that a, fullscale internal investigation of the Department of Justice was being conducted to determine if its personnel had leaked information to the press about a Federal investigation involving Vice Presdent Agnew.

title: DR. C. HOLMAN LOVELL
description: Dr. C. Holman Lovell, one of the oldest practicing physicians in Brooklyn, died Wednesday at his home, 418 Hancock Street, Brooklyn. He was 81 years old.

title: BURGLARIES LAID TO AGENTS OF F.B.I. IN 30YEAR PERIOD
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23Informed Justice Department sources disclosed today that what one of them called illegal and unlawful burglaries by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation had taken place in this country over a 30year period that began under the Administration of President Franklin D. Roosevelt and ended in 1966.

title: MRS. JACOBI PRESS
description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 23Mrs. Jennie Goldstein Press, widow of Jacobi Press, founder of J. Press, Inc., clothiers of New Haven and New York, died at her home here yesterday. She was 94 years old.

title: Signal Group Confirms New North Sea Oil Field
description: The Signal Companies, Inc., announced yesterday a third successful exploratory well, which it said confirmed the Thistle Field in the British Sector of the North Sea as a major commercial oil field.

title: Long Branch Sets Curfew for Youths; Mayor, Citing Response, to End It Today
description: LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 23A 9 P.M. to 6 A.M. curfew for youths 18 years old and younger went into effect here tonight, and Mayor Henry R. Cioffi was so pleased with the community's peaceful response that he declared that the curfew would end at 6 A.M. tomorrow.

title: 200 at Rites for Boy Murdered on Lower East Side
description: Steven Anthony Cropper, the sixyearold boy who was found murdered and mutilated last Friday on a building roof, was buried yesterday after funeral services at the DeWitt Reformed Church on the Lower East Side.

title: Man Slain on Street By Queens Bandit; Wife Is at His Side
description: A 28yearold man, walking home from a shopping trip with his wife, was shot to death on a street in Jamaica, Queens, last evening by one of two holdup men, the police reported.

title: U.S. Prosecutors Disclose Inquiry on Judges in State
description: Federal prosecutors disclosed here yesterday that they were investigating at least two cases involving some evidence of possible criminal conduct by state court judges.

title: A News Conference Possible in Few Days
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 23 (UPI)White House aides, convinced that President Nixon came through with flying colors at his first meeting with reporters in five months, indicated today that he might hold another news conference in a few days.

title: Politics and Instability of Prices Tearing World Oil Pacts Apart
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 23The major international agreements governing the world oil market are coming apart under the pressure of price instability for crude oil and the political drive by Middle East producing countries for greater control over their oil.

title: Inspector Says Hotel Got Warning of Hazardous
description: A Buildings Department inspector testified yesterday that a wall of the old Broadway Central Hotel was bulging about a foot from the second floor to the sixth floor when he placed a hazard violation On the structure about five months before the building collapsed on Aug. 3, killing four persons.

title: Kawasaki of Japan Plans Small Steel Plant in U.S.
description: TOKYO, Aug. 23 (AP)The Kawasaki Steel Corporation of Japan said today it planned to build a small steel plant in the United States.

title: OUSTER OF PRINCIPAL IS UPHELD BY ANKER
description: The city's Schools Chancellor, Irving Anker, upheld yesterday the ouster of Claude L. Huntley as acting principal of an intermediate school in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. Mr. Huntley was removed by Community School Board 14.

title: 4 New Indictments Filed Against 2 in Mass Killing
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 23 (AP)A Harris County grand jury returned four new indictments today against two youths charged in the sextorture slayings case in which 27 bodies have been recovered.

title: Inquiry at Justice
description: Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson disclosed that an internal investigation of the Department of Justice was being conducted to learn whether personnel had leaked information about an inquiry involving Vice President Agnew. Details on Page 13.

title: BURGLARIES LAID TO AGENTS OF F.B.I. IN 30YEAR PERIOD
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23Informed Justice Department (sources disclosed today that what one of them called illegal and unlawful burglaries by agenis of the Federal Bureau of Investigation had taken place in this country over a 30year period that began under the Administration of President Franklin D. Roosevelt and ended in 1966.

title: Dr. Henry A. Davidson Is Dead; A Psychiatrist and Author, 68
description: EAST ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 23 Dr. Henry Alexander Davidson, psychiatrist and author, died today at his home, 276 Prospect Street. He was 68 years old.

title: CHANGE PROPOSED FOR MEADOWVIEW
description: NEWARK, Aug. 23Six proposals that could shape the future of Hudson County's scandal ridden Meadowvir Hospital as well as lead to increased Federal and state aid I were presented to the County Board of Freeholders today by the Hospital's planning commission.

title: Seoul Threatens to Close Bureau of Japanese Paper
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 23 The South Korean Government today told Yomiuri Shimbun, one of Japan's leading daily newspapers, that its bureau here would he closed and its correspondents expelled unless it retracted a report it published this morning on the kidnapping from Tokyo to Seoul of Kim Dae Jung.

title: Parley in Mine Dispute
description: POWHATAN POINT, Ohio, Aug. 23 (AP)Neariy 300 mining foremen in southeastern Ohio remained off the job today while coal company and union officials held meetings on a dispute involving safety complaints. Officials of the North American Coal Company met with representatives of the United Mine Workers to discuss complaints at the company's Quarto No. 4 mine, Leonard McVey, the firm's industrial relations manager, said.

title: WILLIAM N. CROSS
description: UTICA, N.Y., Aug. 23 (AP)William N. Cross, president of the New York State Fire Fighters Association from 1944 to 1968 died today in Faxton Hospital. He was 66 years old.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 23 (AP)A Superior Court judge rejected today Lance Rentzel's request for an injunction ending the Los Angeles Ram wide receiver's National FootLeague suspension for conduct detrimental to the league. Judge David A. Thomas made the decision after considering arguments over the application for a preliminary injunction that were presented yesterday.

title: Balknan Plays for Giants As He Did Against Them
description: Maybe it was more than their need for an experienced tight end that made the New oil Giants pick up 33yearold Gary Ballman on waivers from the Philadelphia Eagles during the offseason. Maybe somebody remembered that in Ballman's 11 seasons with the Pittsburgh Steelers and Eagles, the Giants had little trouble beating those teams, but had many problems handling him. He had the uncanny ability to get away from Giant defenders.

title: Long Branch Gets a Brief Curfew
description: LONG BRANCH, N. J., Aug. 23A 9 P.M. to 6 A.M. curfew for youths 18 years old and younger went into effect here tonight, and Mayor Henry R. Cioffi was so pleased with the community's peaceful response that he declared that the curfew would end at 6 A.M. tomorrow.

title: MORE PRISONERS FREED BY GREECE
description: ATHENS, Aug. 23The number of Greek political prisoners freed under a broad amnesty granted Sunday by President George Papadopoulos rose to some 300 today.

title: Bank Finds Profit Rises In'73 Mainly Phantom
description: The huge profit gains reported by American corporations so far this year represent largely phantom profits, the Morgan Guaranty Survey says in its August edition, to be published today.

title: Boothe Seeks Stock Trading Halt
description: The Boothe Computer Corporation yesterday asked the American Stock Exchange and the Pacific Stock Exchange to halt trading in the company's common stock and its 5 convertible subordinated debentures.

title: CAROLINIAN OPPOSES A BAN ON CIGARETTES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23A tobaccostate Representative said today he would offer an amendment to the Hazardous Substances Act to prevent the Consumer Products Safety Commission from trying to ban cigarettes.

title: Chavez Calls on Teachers To Back His Farm Union
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23Cesar Chavez, president of the United Farm Workers Union, appealed to an audience of union teachers today to support his struggle with California grape growers and with the teamsters union, a struggle he said was far from over despite conciliatory moves by the national teamster leadership.

title: Fire Is Contained on Coast After 6Day Battle
description: Firefighters won their sixI day battle yesterday with most stubborn of the forest raging in the West by handdigging 30 miles of line around a blaze near Lake Tahoe in California.

title: Cheer for the Consumer
description: I'm only a consumer, and it really doesn't matter

title: TV: The Corner Bar Back Under New Ownership
description: Alan King should, I suppose, get some kind of credit for trying. Wearing the hat of executive producer, the comedian has obviously given considerable time and effort to a series called The Corner Bar. Produced in New York City, an automatic plus factor, the program had a summer run last year with Gabe Dell as the bar owner. It didn't click audibly.

title: 6 More Disk Companies Subpoenaed
description: At least six more record companies have received subpoenas this month from the Federal grand jury in Newark that is investigating allegations of payola.

title: STATE TO MONITOR MORTGAGE LENDERS
description: The New York State Banking Department moved yesterday to curb excessively tight credit restrictions for home mortgages with an announce. ment that it would monitor the terms that various lending institutions are requiring for such loans.

title: V.F.W. Keeps Ban on Women
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 23 (AP)The Veterans of Foreign Wars have overwhelmingly rejected a proposal to allow women to join their organization. A bylaw to this effect proposed yesterday at the 74th national convention failed to receive a second and died before it could reach the floor. Delegates then voted almost unanimously to accept a committee report rejecting the proposed amendment.

title: AGNEW SUCCESSOR IN BALTIMORE JOB INDICTED IN BRIBES
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 23  A Federal grand jury that has been looking into the affairs of a number of officials, including Vice President Agnew, today indicted N. Dale Anderson, the executive of suburban Baltimore County, on 39 counts centering on bribery, extortion and conspiracy.

title: Stein Cites Real Income Gain; An Oil Price Rise Is Challenged
description: WASHINGTON, Aug, 23 Herbert Stein, President Nixon's chief economic adviser, said today that many Americans are better off than they think.

title: Nixon Drive May Have Got 15 Illegal Corporate Gifts
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 Government investigators no believe that as many as 15 oz 20 of the names on a White House master list of campaigr contributors may represent illegal cash donations from corporations, according to sources close to the investigation. The sources said these donations totaled up to $1.5million.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Federal Reserve Decides To Amend Regulation Q
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (Reuters)  The Federal Reserve said today its board of governors voted to amend regulation Q effective Sept. 10, to impose early withdrawal penalties on any changes in either the maturity or interest rate on existing certificates of deposit.

title: ARGENTINE POLICE BATTLE LEFTISTS
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 23About 100 leftist demonstrators were arrested at the end of an antiPeronist rally here last night after they had firebombed a police vehicle.

title: Most Uganda Asians Find Exile Life Hard
description: LONDON, Aug. 23Amhalal Patel lives in a neat row house on Ansell Road with 10 members of his family, with pleasant English and Chinese neighbors, a big mortgage and some bitter memories.

title: LIVESTOCK PRICES DROP DAILY LIMIT
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 23Consumers continued to pull the rug from under livestock and egg prices on the big Midwest exchanges today and once again all cattle, hog and broiler futures dropped their daily permissible limits. Most egg and pork bellies raw bacon) deliveries closed at or near their downside limits.

title: Gain for Public Houing Expected in Englewood
COUNTER SUIT FILED BY COASTAL STATES
description: The Coastal States Gas Cor. poration yesterday filed a $30million counter claim in Federal District court for Southern Texas charging the British Petroleum Company, Ltd. and Nelson Bunker Hunt of Texas with violation of the Sherman antitrust act and the Clayton Act.

title: Excerpts From Kissinger's News Conference
description: OPENING STATEMENT

title: 10 Atomic Plants Studied For Possible Fuel Problem
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP)  The Atomic Energy Commission disclosed today that it was investigating a possible fuel densification problem in 10 of the nation's 34 operating atomic plants. The inquiry could lead to an order to reduce power levels in the plants if found warranted, the commission said.

title: Solzhenitsyn Denounces Residence Curbs
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 23  Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the dissident author, disclosed today that he had been barred from living legally in Moscow. He used the occasion for an angry attack on the Soviet Union's residence controls as a demeaning system that probably does not exist even in the colonial countries.

title: Behind the Yankees Slump: A Team Without Desire
description: The Yankee body, barely breathing, arrived in Oakland yesterday and it was in such miserable shape the thought of keeping it alive seemed to be cruel and agonizing punishment for the people who give life and sustenance to that body.

title: Feeling the Space
description: A man came up to me and said May I shake hands with the hand that shook hands with John Lennon?

title: AMEX PRICES RISE IN SLOW TRADING
Advertising: Tote Bags Tell It
description: They're walking billboards, said Barry Reifler. He was bragging about the ubiquitous plastic tote bagswith molded handles, reinforced handles or draw stringsthat display, advertising messages of one sort or another. His company, Uniflex, Inc., produces over 40 million of them each year.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The New York Public Library has returned an apparently lost book to circulation. Its 76yearold scholarly journal, The Bulletin, has resumed publication after being suspended in December, 1971, in the wake of the library's financial crises. Aided in part by support from Readex Microprint Corporation, whose publishing arm, Readex Books, will now print and distribute The Bulletin and other library publictions, the journal will appear quarterly. Covering all of 1972 in a single issue, Volume 76 includes The Labyrinth as Joyce's A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man', by Diane Fortuna; Evidence of Regard: Three Generations of American Love Letters, by Alice P. Kenney, and 13 other articles.

title: Women Power Protests Male Domination of Wall St.
description: A banner with the words women power was raised over the public gallery of the American Stock Exchange yesterday by a dozen members of the New York chapter of the National Organization for Women. They said they were protesting male domination of the. Wall Street empire.

title: BIAGGI ABANDONS SERIOUS EFFORT
description: Representative Mario Biaggi has given private assurances to at least three of the city's Democratic county chairmen that he will not make a serious run for Mayor, even though he is the Conservative party nominee.

title: AGNEW SUCCESSOR IN BALTIMORE JOB INDICTED IN BRIBES
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 23  A Federal grand jury that has been looking into the affairs of a number of officials, including Vice President Agnew, today indicted N. Dale Anderson, the executive of suburban Baltimore County, on 39 counts centering on bribery, extortion and conspiracy.

title: Withering Ideologies
description: BELGRADEThe strengthening of the role of Europe is most frequently explained by its prosperity and its high level of technology. In most instances such explanations are made with Western Europe in mind. This kind of thinking, however, is onesided and, I would even say, shortsighted. The prestige of Europe increases not only because of its economic and technical achievements but perhaps in even greater measurebecause of basic social and political changes. This is true of Europe as whole, although the changes in Eastern Europe are neither occurring at the same tempo nor having the same significance as those taking place in Western Europe.

title: Israel Festival: Fine Array of Artists
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 23 Rudolf Nureyev danced in Caesarea, Leonard Bernstein conducted in Tel Aviv, Isaac Stern played in Jerusalem and this weekend Pablo Casals will close by conducting a concert of Mendelssohn and Mozart. The Israel Festival, an annual movable feast of music, opera and dance, is celebrating its bar mitzvah this year with six weeks of performances by a bumper crop of visiting artists.

title: Talking Picture Takes 3d Straight
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS,N.Y., Aug. 24The first filly to win all three of those races, exulted Johnny Campo, just after Elmendorf's Talking Picture had won the $58,400 Spinaway today.

title: Liberal Moves by Athens: Risks, but Considered Safe
description: ATHENS, Aug. 24The question being asked here most often these days is how big chance President George Papadopoulos has taken.

title: People in Sports: Post In South to Germann
description: Ken Germann, the athletic director at Columbia University for the last five years, was named yesterday commissioner of the Southern Conference. The 52yearold German is expected to assume his duties in late December or early January, replacing Lloyd C. Jordan, 70. Jordan has been the conference commissioner since 1960. Before Columbia, Germann was the assistant athletic director at Rutgers, from 1961 until 1968.

title: Laotian Accord Resisted By Rightists in Vientiane
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 24The most critical negotiations on a peace settlement in Laos are now taking place, not between the Vientiane Government and the Pathet Lao, but within the Vientiane Government itself.

title: Players From Taiwan Are Honored in Peking
description: PEKING, Aug. 24 (Agence FrancePresse)  The Ping Pong team of Chinese from Taiwan was honored at an official banquet given here tonight at the opening of the friendship Ping Pong tournament of Asian, African and Latin American countries.

title: Suspect Out on Bail In Killing ls Accused Of Attack on Witness
American Golfers Get Edge Over British
A WELFARE HOTEL IS SCORED BY KOCH
description: Representative Edward I. Koch asserted yesterday that a hotel just down the block from Carnegie Hall has more than 70 welfare families and is collecting rent of more than $1,600 a month each from some of these families.

title: $1Million Bail Cut in Drug Case As Heroin Turns Out Not to Be
description: Bail for two women and man arrested in a drug raid last Tuesday was reduced from $4million to $25,000 yesterday after a chemical analysis showed the confiscated narcotics to be neither heroin nor cocaine.

title: Qualifies for Match Play
That Happy Hustler Brines His Talkathon to Town
description: Unable to stop talking, 55yearold Bobby Riggs balanced the spoonful of melon a few inches from his mouth. ... terrible shape, the 1940 Wimbledon champion was saying yesterday in his hotel suite in the SherryNetherland, but tell the men not to worry. I'm back in training. No booze, No living it up. I'm on a crash program. My biggest problem is overconfidence.

title: G.O.P. and Dole Out of Suit
description: MIAMI, Aug. 24 (AP)A Federal judge has dropped the Republican National Committee and its chairman from a damage suit at the request of the antiwar activist who filed the suit. The suit by Kay Worden was against the committee, its former chairman, Senator Robert Dole of Kansas, the Fontainebleu Hotel and the Committee for the Reelection of the President.

title: Buffalo Gas Rates Rise
description: SYRACUSE, Aug. 24 (AP)The 411,000 natural gas customers of Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation will begin paying higher rates next Tues. day, the utility said today. A spokesman said the rate increases, amounting to $$,146,000, a year, had been approved by the State Public Service Commission on Aug. 9. The company originally had sought more than $10.2million in inincreases. Average residential customers will pay 3.74 per cent mom the spokesman said.

title: BEAD SCORES RULING IN FLORIDA
description: A recent Florida Supreme Court decision has applied to newspapers for the first time a type of government control that has long hung over the heads of broadcast journalists, according to Julian Goodman, president of the National Broadcasting Company.

title: US PULLING OUT 3,550 OF ITS MEN FROM THAI BASES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 The United States announced an agreement with Thailand today for the start of a phased withdrawal of American forces and aircraft from Thailand.

title: People and Business
description: John A. B. Fisher, 62, has been elected chairman of the American Totalisator Company, a subsidiary of the General Instrument Corporation. James H. Pierce, 43, a vice president from the Servmation Corporation, has been named to succeed Mr. Fisher as president of AmTote.

title: Murder Suspect Freed on Bail Accused of Attack on Witness
description: A man indicted on a murder charge, who had been released on bail last week after spending a year in prison awaiting trial, was being sought yesterday by the police for allegedly attacking one of the witnesses against him and threatening to get others who say they sam him stab to death a robbery victim two years ago.

title: U.S. Exports Set Record, Yielding a Trade Surplus
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24Exports climbed.to another new high in July, giving the. United States its second trade.surplus 22 months, the CommerceDepartmant reported today

title: MRS. LEE SHUBERT
description: Marcella Swanson, the musicalcomedy and dramatic actress who was the widow of Lee Shubert, the producer, died of pneumonia yesterday at her home, 160 East 88th Street. Her husband died on Dec. 25, 1953.

title: Former Generals Are the Elite Corps of Israeli Society
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 24Old soldiers neither die nor fade away in Israel. Instead, they manage the nation's largest industrial enterprises, head up its universities and, in increasing numbers, run for political office.

title: U.S. Exports Set Record, Yielding a Trade Surplus
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24Exports climbed to another new high in July, giving the United States its second trade surplus in 22 months, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: SHULTZ INDICATES BIG RISE IN PRICES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24George P. Shultz, the Treasury Secretary, warned the public today to expect an astounding increase in the wholesale price index for August.

title: B'nai B'rith Chief Finds Elderly Are Hurt by U.S. Housing Policy
