description: REVERE, Mass., Aug. 25Mr. and Mrs. Harold S. Stone of Point of Pines here have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Bonnie Louise Stone, to Jeffrey Lance Marks, son of Mrs. Frances Marks of Newton and the late Seymour Marks.

title: The Corporate Squeeze
description: As more facts become known about the way in which the Nixon campaign organization raised funds last year, the distinctions between a contribution, an extortion and a bribe become increasingly blurred.

title: Huge Mall Casting Competitive Shadow
description: MASSAPEQUA PARK, L.I. Many longestablished merchants in this area fear that their sales will drop with the opening Thursday of the mammoth new Sunrise Mall. Most, however, have adopted a waitandsee attitude.

title: Elizabeth K. Thorne Bride on L.I.
description: PLANDOME, L. I., Aug. 25  Miss Elizabeth Keith Thorne and Wayne Alan Sloper, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kirkland Sloper of Wilton, Conn., were married here this afternoon in the garden at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Van Buren Thorne Jr.

title: Sienismo and That Old Giovanni di Paolo Gang of Mine
description: ATASTE for Sienese painting doesn't exactly make you a member of a secret society, since people who share this taste are banded together as proselytizers for a school of artists who, in the temper of their city, maintained an aristocratic medievalism in the face of the Renaissance burgeoning nearbywith just a hint of vulgarityin Florence. But members of the Old Sienese Gang, as the late George Harold EdgeII of Harvard used to call a group of enthusiasts inspired by his leadership, have always recognized that true Sienismo is something you have to be horn with. Proselytization involves no argumentsimply exposure. Show a potential member of the brotherhood the right Sienese paintings and you can tell from his spontaneous reaction whethcr he is in or out.

title: Mrs. S. discovers Mrs. S.
description: Mrs. S., a 38yearold housewife, parttime secretary and mother of two teenagers, complained for months of feeling depressed, tired and lonely. She felt on edge, she said, without being able to pinpoint exactly what was troubling her. Part of the reason, she said, was her inability to get along with her husband, despite all her attempts to please him.

title: Eugene B. McDermott, 74, Dies; A Founder of Texas Instruments
description: DALLAS, Aug. 25 (AP)Eugene B. McDermott, a cofounder of Texas Instruments, Inc., a diversified concern that operates on a world basis, died yesterday at his home. His age was 74.

title: Network to Link Cities
description: MCI Telecommunications Corporation has announced that within four months it will link 20 major American cities in a nationwide business communications network, comprising voice, high speed data, teleprinter and facsimile transmission. The company began operations between Chicago and St. Louis in January, 1972.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Pro Game Unchanged With Seats at Premium
description: Pro football's best brains last season changed the placement position of the ball prior to each play by moving the field markersthe hash markscloser to the center. The purpose was to give the offense a little more room to operate so as to jack up the scoring, which had been going down. Hopefully zone defenses would have trouble covering more ground and the long touchdown pass, one of the sport's most exciting plays, would halt its move toward extinction.

title: PLAYING
description: Actianthat's the name of the game for many young mothers. Keeping house, shepherding the children to school, and sandwiching in a full or part time job calls for easygoing clothes a woman can put on and forget about. These days, that frequently means pants plus. And that's the garb chosen day in, day out by Eleanor Greco and Rene Terte. They're shown in the playground of the Brooklyn Heights Community Nursery School, where Mrs. Greco is director and Mrs. Terte a parent helper.

title: MARCHI DISPLAYS A NEW STRATEGY
description: This isn't 1969. Then John Marchi was the third guy it the race. This year, he's the other guy.

title: Blood Tests For Drivers Held. Drunk Stir Debate
description: MORRISTOWN  Here in Morris County, two children were killed when struck by a car driven by a man who, the police felt, was obviously under the influence of drugs. But it took four hours to find a doctor who was willing to administer a blood test.

title: I Remember Hazel
description: Mrs. Hazel Wightman. who was born 86 years ago and lives in Chestnut Hill, Mass., won 45 nationat titles in 45 years. She donated the cup for the first U.S. Britain women's match. which opened the new Forest Hills stadium in 1923. In 1957, Mrs. Wightman was enshrined in the Tennis Hall of Fame.

title: By the people for the privileged
description: The arts that flourished in America's preindustrialized past were for and by the people. The paintings were often faulty. The perspective was cockeyed; light was amateurishly handled, and all sort of ingenious devices were employed to hide difficulttopaint hands. But the faces that look out of canvas and paper and wood are the faces of America. The imagery was bold, individualistic. The unbeautiful baby, the workworn housewife and the pompous merchant were limned honestly and unsparingly.

title: OUR LATIN THING PLAYS AT STADIUM
description: More than 30,000 fans of Latin musicwhat the organizers claimed was the largest gathering ever for the musicwere at Yankee Stadium on Friday night, pinpointing the continuing boom in this musical form in New York. The crowd, noisy, bustling, enthusiastic and flag waving (Puerto Rican) was there for the second Our Latin Thing concert, built around the Fania All Stars.

title: WILLIAM A. COLEMAN
description: William A. Coleman, a member of the New York Stock Exchange and a partner in Adler, Coleman & Co., brokers, since 1929, die dyesterday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived at 575 Park Avenue anti in Palm, Beach, Fla.

title: BACK TO THE DRESS YES
description: To dress or not to dress? Dear God, is that still the question?

title: THREE MEN KILLED BY A BELFAST BLAST
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 25Three men were killed today by an explosion in a garage in the Chiftonville area of north Belfast. First reports indicated that a bomb had exploded prematurely, but because of the destruction caused by the powerful blast and the subsequent fire policemen were unable to rule out the possibility of an industrial accident.The area was predominantly Protestant until Roman Catholics moved in about two years ago after street rioting.

title: Old L.I. Family Has Rare Reunion
description: MAITITUCK, L.I.  The Tuthills had their first family reunion in 38 years the other day. Before the 1935 gathering, they had met in 1867.

title: New and Recommended
description: NINETY TWO IN THE SHADE, by Thomas McGuane. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $6.95.) Milieu (Key West) and work (fishing) are beautifully evoked in this Inexorable tragedy arising out of the rivalry between two fishing guidesone young, the other a killer.

title: Newark Camp Fund In Donation Appeal
description: NEWARK  The Newark Fresh Air Fund is sending out an urgent request for donations so that its camping program will not he curtailed.

title: Another Prohibition?
description: Richard O. Simpson, chairman of the newly established Federal Consumer Product Safety Commission, entertains the serious expectation that his agency may ban the cigarette once and for all. The commission would, of course, have to go through an elaborate process, including a thorough review of the Surgeon General's findings on the health hazards of smoking, as well as the arguments of cigarette manufacturers and others. Even then, it might come up with a ban on only those cigarettes that exceed a level of tars and nicotine which the commission considers safe. But the surprising thing is that so drastic a move should be contemplated or even thought to be feasible.

title: Steelers at Stadium
description: The Pittsburgh Steelers, the most improved team in professional football last season, will challenge the New York Giants unbeaten exhibition record at 1 P.M. today in Yankee Stadium.

title: PARISBONN TIES GROH TROUBLED
description: PARIS, Aug. 24A few Months after solemn celebration of the 10th anniversary of France's special friendship treaty with West Germany, a sultry summer storm has darkened Paris relations with Bonn.

title: THE LOOK IS NEAT
Data Ordered on Illinois Political Gifts
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 25  Gov. Daniel Walker of Illinois stirred up a storm this week by issuing an executive order requiring companies and others doing business with the state or regulated by it, along with their key personnel, to disclose their political contributions over the last two years.

title: SAIGON SAYS 7 DIE IN ELECTION ATTACKS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Aug. 26 (AP)Seven persons were reported killed today in two attacks linked to South Vietnam's national Senate elections, a Government spokesman reported.

title: Miss Dunston Wed to J. A. McLaughlin
description: Miss Elizabeth Ann Dunston, daughter of Mrs. Sidney A. Fisher of the Bronx and the late Irvin Dunston, was married here last evening to James A. McLaughlin, son of Mrs. James Treacy of Scarsdale, N. Y., and the late James A. MCLaughlin.

title: Mugging Victim Gets Fast Relief From 911
description: A 33yearold Staten Islander, beset by two teenaged muggers around 2 A.M. yesterday morning, called 911, the police emergency number, and got unexpectedly fast results.

title: Television; Here Comes (There Goes) Bette Now
description: ISPENT my formative years watching TV stations even before they signed on. I was raised in front of lines, dots and station numbers, comforted by the high pitched whine of my mothersurrogate, the television set; I was a testpattern. baby. As a child of the tube, I naturally look to the small screen to take care of me now, a habit which persists despite the fact that, aside from old movies, there are precious few shows as engrossing as those ancient airwave hieroglyphics.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Cabin in Alaskan Spruces
description: ADMIRALTY ISLAND, AlaskaPausing for several minutes in the eternal, cathedral twilight under towering Sitka spruces, Bob Nelson and I groped for words to express the sense of reverence the ancient trees evoked.

title: North Bergen Feast To Attract 300,000
description: NORTH BERGEN  More than 300,000 persons are expected to attend the Feast of St. Anthony at North Hudson County Park next Thursday through Sept. 3.

title: The Shape of Peace: Very Much Like a Rifle
description: VIENTIANEIn recent months, as fighting raged in Cambodia and persisted in parts of Smith Vietnam, Laos seemed on the brink of peace. The Feh. 21 Laotian ceasefire put an end to all but minor military incidents. The neutralist Prime Minister, Prince Souvanna Phouma, expressed readiness to make the military concessions that could bring about a peace agreement and coalition government with the Communistled Pathet Lao.

title: WEINSTEIN VICTOR IN U. S. OPEN CHESS
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (AP)Norman Weinstein of Allston, Mass., won the United States Open Chess Championship early this morning after the defending champion, Walter Browne, was upset.

title: Rogers Resigns
description: WASHINGTONThe cynics may be right, Wanting some positive news to offset Watergate, President Nixon may have deliberately timed his announcement that Henry A. Kissinger was replacing William P. Rogers as Secretary of State to coincide with his first news conference in months at. San Clemente on Wednesday.

title: A Decade for Upward Bound at Princeton
description: PRINCETON  Princeton University has just completed Its 10th year of an Upward Bound project that, its director says, exists because the public schools are in such bad shape.

title: BombingsDisrupt London; Heath Orders Wide Alert
description: LONDON, Aug. 25Two men were injured, one critically, when a letter bomb exploded in the Bank of England. today.

title: The Lion of Kashmir Is Acting to Unify India's Moslem Minority of 60 Million
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 25Sheik Mohammed Abdullah, the Lion of Kashmir, is seeking a dominant role among India's Moslem minority.

title: 2 Rob Willowbrook School
description: A young man and a young woman entered the office building of the Willowbrook State School for the Mentally Retarded on Staten Island at 4 P.M. Friday and punched a young office worker before stealing $4,000 from a safe. The worker, Susan Polcic, 16 years old, who resides at the school, was punched and thrown to the floor by the man who forced her to say where the money was, the police said.

title: Agnew Ally Abandons A Baltimore Venture
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 25I. H. Hammerman, a prominent mortgage banker here, has decided to withdraw from a major urban renewal venture because of publicity surrounding his involvement in the Federal investigation in which Vice President Agnew figures.

title: News Summary and Index
She who defied Freud
Wisconsin's Auto Racing Includes Bratwurst, Corn
description: ELKHART LAKE, Wis., Aug. 25On the pro golf tour or in tennis or in horse racing, what makes one event superior to another? Sometimes its the strength of the field, the size of the purse, tradition or prestige. All these elements are present in this weekend's CanAm race here, but what most significantly distinguishes the race from all the others is the ambience of its settingRoad America, a rustic tract 55 miles north of Milwaukee. For thousands of Middle Western racing fans, Road America is Mecca, with its rolling countryside, congenial crowds, the pervasive air of simple happiness and, with emphasis on Sheboygan County's famous bratwurst, on the freshly roasted corn and on beer, the best refreshments anywhere in racing.

title: What's Doing in HONG KONG
description: MOON CAKE FESTIVAL  The Chinese in Hong Kong celebrate the MidAutumn Festival, also known as the Moon Cake Festival, on Sept. 11. That evening the hillsides of Honk Kong will appear to be swarming with fire. flies as thousands of children parade around the Crown Colony carrying paper lanterns with candle or a small batterypowered light inside and munching moon cakes under a full moon. The cakes recall an uprising against the Mongol rulers of China in the 14th century when cakes containing messages calling on the people to revolt were distributed.

title: Holiday Inns'
description: MEMPHISHoliday Inns, Inc., is essentially a franchise system that has made money for its franchisees as well as its founders. Revenues of Holiday Inns all over the world add up to an estimated total of $1.78billion a year.

title: SERVICE BUSINESS SHOWS GAINS HERE
description: New York City moved at a faster clip toward a serviceoriented economy in the nineteensixtiesa decade in which its prime workingage population shrank, purchasing power rose more slowly than the national average but faster than prices and taxes, and black and Puerto Rican workers gained upward mobility in an increasingly whitecollar job market.

title: Headliners
description: Ulster's agony became London's terror last week as the war between the Irish Republican Army and the British Government took a brutal turn. Incendiary bombs, similar to those used in Northern Ireland, were found in some popular London department stores and, even more ominously, the terrorists apparently had taken to mailing letter bombs to Government departments and institutions. One such letter bomb sent to the Stock Exchange blew up in the face of a secretary when she opened the package on Friday, injuring her and another official. And yesterday another one exploded in the mail room of the Bank of England as three men were trying to shield it with sandbags. The three were injured. Officially the I.R.A. did not admit responsibility for the new tactics, but a Scotland Yard official said: We now believe the I.R.A. to be responsible for the acts of violence in London.

title: Lynn B. Wechsler Engaged to Marry
description: McKEESPORT, Pa., Aug 25 Miss Lynn Barth Wechsler and Glenn Morton Kramer, seniors at Washington University in St. Louis, plan to be wed next June. Their engagement has been announced by Miss Wechsler's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Harry L. Wechsler of McKeesport.

title: Nixon Plans to Show Vigorous Action in Attempt to Dispel Watergate Cloud
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25President Nixon has decided on a bold new attempt to dispel the Watergate cloud that hangs over his Administration by showing himself in vigorous action.

title: November Ballot Here Will Be Crowded With Candidates, a Bond Issue and 10 Proposed Amendments
description: When voters here go to the polls in November they will not only have to choose from a long list of candidates for elected office but will also have to decide on the $3.5billion transportation bond issue and 10 amendments to the state constitution.

title: When a Viewer Should Be Kept in the Dark
description: THERE is other news from Washington, and it is also bad. Senator John Pastore's Commerce Committee has approved legislation that would ban television blackouts of hometown professional sports events if those events are sold out 48 hours in advance. Identical legislation has been introduced in the House. Now that the Redskins are a respectable football team, Congress wants to watch their home games in the livingroom instead of slogging out to RFK Stadium where it might blizzard on a franking privilege.

title: Mary Glass Is Engaged
description: HIGHLAND PARK, N. J., Aug. 25Mr. and Mrs. Louis Garelick have announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Ellen Glass, to Randolph Kent Harrison. Miss Glass is also the daughter of the late Dr. Harry Lewis Glass. Her fiance is the son of Mrs. Ruthanne M. Harrison of Youngstown, Ohio, and the late Henry S. Harrison.

title: They're Off at Belmont Tomorrow for a 42Day Meeting
description: New York thoroughbred racing, which has spent the last four weeks at Saratoga, returns tomorrow to Belmont Park.

title: Tycoons and Sophocles At 8,000 Ft.
description: Since my diet, from earliest memory, consisted of ideas, music and fantasy, some hidden valve my mind closes automatically at the word business. My father, a musician, never understood it, never liked it and refused to carry more than $2 In his pocket.

title: Pacers the Foes In Nets Opener
description: The New York Nets, with their new coach, Kevin Loughery, and newly acquired superstar, Julius Erving, meet the defending champion Indiana Pacers Oct. 10 at Indianapolis as the American Basketball Association starts the 197374 season with three games on opening night.

title: Opera's Friendliest Enemies
Dermot Davey, questing cop
description: A bleak novel by Jimmy Breslin, the funny guy.

title: HENRY MATALENE JR., WATERPOLO STAR, 70
description: MATTITUCK, L.I., Aug. 25Henry W. Matalene Jr., who was at one time an outstanding waterpolo player and who did awardwinning needlepoint died today at his home here. He was 70 years old and also lived at Delray Beach, Fla.

title: Queens Bike Riders To Get RightofWay
description: The city will begin construction this week of a 6.5mile, $250,000 bikeway in Queens that will link Alley Pond Park with Flushing MeadowsCorona Park and will use local streets as well as parkland. Bikepath symbols will be placed on roadway surfaces with reflectorized white paint to designate the route. Completion of the route is expected in 30 days.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: COMMODITY PRICES fell after their record runup Cattle, hogs, chickens and eggs all declined, while wheat, corn and soybeans fluctuated.... New York City food costs dipped after a sixweek rise.... Consumer prices increased 0.2 per cent in July despite the price freeze.... Treasury Secretary George P. Shultz predicted the August wholesale price index would be astounding.

title: Star Weiss Married to Russell F. Fuoco
description: BREWSTER, N.Y., Aug. 25 Miss E. Star Weiss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard A. Weiss of White Plains, was married at her parents summer home at Peach Lake here this morning to Russell F. Fuoco, son of Mr. and Mrs. S. G. Fuoco of Vancouver, British Columbia.

title: Bank to Give Out 25,000 Ecology Kits
description: HICKSVILLE, L. I.The Long Island National Bank will begin a campaign tomorrow to show how businesses can aid ecology by distributing 25,000 free ecology kits in its 11 branches on Long Island.

title: Riches to Rags Theme of Store
description: EAST HAMPTON, L.I. The he clothes are right out of the late, late show, circa 1940: Carole Lombard littlegirl chiffons with puff sleeves and drooping waists; Joan Crawford wickedwoman black crepes with imposing shoulder pads and gold studs; Ronald Coleman manabout town Chinese silk smoking jackets with wide lapels and deep pockets; Roy Rogers cowooy shirts with sequin aesigns plastered all over the stiff silk; Lana Turner midrift blouses with subtle, yet bold sashes; Bing Crosby Hawaiian fantasies loudly flowered with imposing flora and fauna.

title: 4 Dead in Alaska Cabin
description: GLENNALLEN, Alaska, Aug. 25 (AP)  Four persons have been found dead in a cabin on Cross Wind Lake near Glennallen, 200 miles northeast of Anchorage, state troopers said today. They identified three of them as William J. Johnson Jr., his wife Mary and son Stephen, all of Anchorage. The identity of the fourth person was not. available. The troopers said that a propane lantern had apparently been left burning overnight in the tightly esaled cabin night in the tightly sealed cabin.

title: Study Finds Contractors in 4 States Help Politicians
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 25Con suiting engineers and highwa: contractors are a prime souro of money for politicians many states besides Maryland where a Federal grand jury investigating allegations of kickbacks to public officials including Vice President Agnew.

title: Main Street Is Far From Dead
description: MIDLAND PARKMain Street, once the shopping hub of many suburbs in Northern New Jersey, is not dead yet. Little shops are still being opened on these thoroughfares even as new shopping malls continue to rise on busy highways.

title: Record Lap by Donohue Earns Him CanAm Pole
description: ELKHART LAKE, Wis., Aug. 25Mark Donohue led three other driversJody Scheckter, George Follmer and Charlie Kempin breaking the qualifying record today for the Road America CanAm road race.

title: THE SHAPE. THEN DECORATE.
The Dream, 1973: Blacks Move Painfully Toward Full Equality
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25Ten years after 200,000 white and black Americans marched to this capital to pledge a moral commitment to racial equality, the nation has moved toward that goal in a historic trek that has been far more painful and arduous than most of the shirtsleeved masses who were there at the beginning ever envisioned.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. San Francisco Giants, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 2:05 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 9, 2 P.M.) (RadioWHN, 2 P.M.)

title: U.S. Beats Sweden, Keeps Tennis Cup
description: The United States defeated Sweden, 41, in senior tennis yesterday and won the Stevens Cup for the 10th straight year.

title: Lillian Roxon
description: LILLIAN ROXON, who died on Aug. 9, understood something important about pop music and its milieu, which is that the very basis of its impact as an art is in its glamour as a display. The process of creating celebrities remains very close to the process of celebrating certain values. And Lillian Roxon, through her Rock Encyclopedia, through her column in the Daily News, and through her presence, reassured those of us who felt rock had become encumbered with ideas that it remained an emotional celebration of lust and pain.

title: I Scream, You Scream...
description: It's a drawl that makes New York radio listeners cock their ears.

title: Miss Goolagong Takes Canadian Final
description: TORONTO, Aug. 25 (UPI)  Evonne Goolagong of Australia, defeated Helga Masthoff of the West Germans, 7.6, 6.1, today and retained the women's singles title in the Canadian open tennis tourney.

title: For Want of a Mortgage, The House Was Lost
description: HAZLET, N. J.Reynold Martin 2d, burly, softspoken chemical engineer, a patienteven a philosophicalman.

title: Richard Fowkes Marries Floran Fink
description: YONKERS, Aug. 25  In Temple EmanuEl here this evening, Miss Floran Lois Fink, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stewart N. Fink of Brooklyn, became the bride of Richard Owen Fowkes, son of Prof. and Mrs. Robert A. Fowkes of Yonkers. Rabbi Abraham J. Klausner performed the ceremony.

title: Keansburg Feud Puts State Code To the Test
description: KEANSBURG  A feud between the Borough Manager and the Police Department here is threatening the continued existence of a state regulation covering the disciplining of most public employes.

title: Clocks Timely in Store
description: One might not get the correct time at Dawn Antiques, 2903 Francis Lewis Boulevard, in Bayside, Queens, but he is certain to find a clock. The specialty of this small shop  and the passion of the owner, Mrs. Dawn Hantman  is clocks, Bakers clocks, Act of Parliament clocks, gingerbread clocks and Westminster chime clocks are among those ticking off the minutes until they are sold.

title: Mrs. Mitchell Tells of 72 Campaign Strategy Book
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 25 (UPI)Martha Mitchell says she read a campaign strategy book written by President Nixon and H. R. Haldeman that she hinted included plans for Watergatestyle operations. She said the Senate Watergate committee should call her to testify.

title: START WITH A
description: Sweaters, sweaters and more sweaters. There's no getting away from it. The sweater is the Number One fashion for fall. Without it, you're just not with it. At least that's the attitude of designers on both sides of the Atlantic (and the Pacific, too). The sweater may be a jacket, a coat, a suit or a dress. If you're nimble with the knitting needles, you'll be the envy of all your friends. If you're not that domesticated, you'll just have to buy one... or two... or three... or whatever the budget will bear.

title: SCHOOL PACT HERE OFFERS TOP WAGES
description: New York City school administrators and supervisors will be the highest paid in any of the country's large cities under a contract that faces a ratification meeting tomorrow.

title: Japanese Tourists Top Overseas Visitors to U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP)The Government says that more Japanese tourists than tourists from any other overseas nation visited the United States during the first six months of 1973.

title: EXADDICTS JOBS TERMED TOO FEW
description: Asserting that there has been a general failure by all levels of government in providing jobs for rehabilitated drug addicts, the Drug Abuse Council, a private, foundationsupported research organization, has called for a new agency devoted to serving rehabilitated addicts through job development, screening and referral.

title: Blimps'
description: It's big. It's tough.

title: The Past Week
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif.  Certainly last Wednesday was a benchmark in the Presidency of Richard M. Nixon the day five months of bitterness, hurt and frustration over the Watergate scandals came flooding out in one remarkable press conference. After it was over, the wound was still there, sore and tender, but the pressure had been relieved for both the President and his critics. And everyone, it seemed, had a better sense of the state of mind and purpose of the complex man who is determined to continue governing the country for the 3 years remaining in his second term.

title: Solzhenitsyn: I Am Not a Serf
description: In 1932 the Soviet Government introduced a sy,stem of internal passports for its citizens, ostensibly to facilitate a registration of the population. In practice, the system has been used to regulate movement within the Soviet Union. All citizens must obtain permission from the local police before they can take up legal residence anywhere in the country. It is particularly difficult to obtain permission to move to Moscow, whose population growth the Government is trying to restrict.

title: Portman's formula: big spaces, flamboyant forms
description: On Portman's drawing boards now are a $600million, 15building complex for the Detroit river front, which Portman is developing in partnership with Henry Ford II; a huge new hotel complex for Los Angeles's Bunker Hill area; a new 70story hotel for Atlanta; more construction for San Francisco's Embarcadero Center; multibuilding complexes for Paris, Madrid and Athens; a skyscraper bank for Fort Worth, and a 54story, $150million hotel for Times Square.

title: Antuofermo Outpoints D. McAloon
description: Vito Antuofermo of New York, pounded out a unanimous decision over Danny McAloon yesterday in a 10round junior middleweight bout at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum.

title: Fan Prevents Catch of Foul, Batter Gets GameWinning Hit as Giants Top Mets,10
description: Tom Bradleythe Latin scholar of the San Francisco Giantscame, saw and conquered the New York Mets yesterday in a 10 pitching duel against Tom Seaver. But he had a little help from a 15yearold Met fan who Unwittingly lent a hand to the only run of the afternoon.

title: Registration Begins for Short Courses
description: THE new schedule of short courses has been announced by the New York Botanical Garden, Bronx. Registration is now open at the garden's Educational Services Department.

title: Aftercare Aiding Alcoholics
description: MARLBORO  Meaningful aftercare, a bold, new concept in treating the alcoholic, is working well at the state hospital here, thanks to the leadership of Peg Page and interagency cooperation.

title: Tolan and Nelson of Reds Sidelined
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 25 (AP)Bobby Tolan, the outfielder, and Roger Nelson, a pitcher, were placed on the disabled list today by the Cincinnati Reds, who called up two minor league outfielders. Nelson, who has elbow trouble, was placed on the list for 21 days, He had a 3.2 wonlost record and an earned run average of 3.86 only 11 appearances this season.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Four new members have been named by Mayor Lindsay to the Human Rights Commission. They are Courtenay L. Wiltshire, a Brooklyn lawyer; the Rev. Anthony F. LoGatto, a Roman Catholic priest from Brooklyn; Delia Rodrigues, administrator of a Brooklyn daycare center, and Howard Thorkelson, a consultant on problems of the elderly. The Mayor also reappointed Jerome Becker, chairman of the Coordinating Council on Jewish Poverty; Murray Gross, an official of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, and Rabbi Harry Halpern of Brooklyn.

title: Women Are Breaking the BlueCollar Barrier
description: Maggie M. is not a young lady you would find behind the counter of a chic boutique or at a desk in a posh office or on a talk show with Gloria Steinem. Yet Maggie, a onetime wrapper in a Denver meatpacking plant, must be counted as a plus in Women's battle for job equality.

title: Archibald Cox
description: WASHINGTONAn aide to Archibald Cox, the special Watergate prosecutor, was asked last week whether the multimillion dollar budget request that Mr. Cox submitted to the Senate a few weeks ago had been approved. The aide said he did not know, but that he would find out and call back.

title: Mary T. Harrison to Be Wed Sept. 8
description: OLD BROOKVILLE, L. I., Aug. 25  Mr. and Mrs. David A. Harrison 3d of Old Brookville and Flowerdew Hundred Farm, Hopewell, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Tayloe Harrison, to Julian Keevil, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clement Keevil of Buckwell Place, Herstmonceaux, Sussex, England. The wedding will take place Sept. 8.

title: N.A.S.L. Stars Bow
description: KANSAS CITY, Aug. 25 (UPI)Anatoli Fetisov, a forward on the Soviet Union's World Cup team, scored two goals to lead the Moscow Torpedo to a 31 victory over the North American Soccer League AllStars last night before 6,832 fans in Arrowhead Stadium. Vadim Nikonov scored the other goal for the Russian Cup champions. The lone United Stales goal went to Warren Archibald of Miami.

title: SCHOOL CAFETERIAS SEEN SHORT OF FOOD
description: DENVER, Aug. 25 (UPI) Many of the nation's schools may have to open this fall with little or no food available for students and teachers in school cafeterias, Dr. John Perryman, executive director of the 60,000member American Food Service Association says.

title: Phase 4, Scene 2
description: WASHINGTON  The Government completed drafting its Phase 4 food pricing regulations last week but no one argued that they would keep retail food prices from climbing.

title: An Imperialist on Fifth Avenue
description: WEST CORNWALL, Conn.For one just back from Chinawhere theoretically there is no private property yet a purse can stand all day in an unlocked room and not be touchedthe question of right to ownership takes on new importance. China is making profit these days by publicizing major thefts of her treasures. Some of the accusations are just while others are questionable. Particularly unclear is the Metropolitan Museum's purchase, this spring, of a private collection of 25 Chinese masterpieces.

title: DR. ERNST LEVI
description: Dr. Ernst Levi, a physician for 34 years on the staff of St. Elizabeth's Division of St. Clare's Hospital and Health Center, died Monday at his summer home in Spencertown, N. Y. He was 72 years old and lived at 128 Fort Washington Avenue.

title: But Would Bach Play It Like This?
description: THE concert that Anthony Newman gave the other week succeeded, if nothing. else, in raising all kinds of questions about Bach performance practice on harpsichord and organ. Newman, who may be one of the idols of the younger generationat least, Philharmonic Hall was sold out, and the audience was overwhelmingly youthfulplayed such popular pieces as the Passacaglia, the Great Fantasy. and Fugue in G minor, and the Preludes and Fugues in B minor and D major. In all respects his performances were thoroughly modern. But were they Bachian?

title: IS IT AS WARM AS MINK?
description: They're not what they seem. Oh, they're furs, all right, but can you name the kinds without peeking at the answers? What with endangered species and skyrocketing prices, furriers are looking for new ways to treat less exotic pelts. So they bleach, dye, piece, patternand keep us guessing. Only the furrier knows for sure. But one thing is for sure: A jacket costs less than a coat, and rates as high.

title: $116.2Billion Spent On FarmGrown Food
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP)  Americans spent $116.2billion last year on farmgrown food and twothirds of that sum went to middlemen, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: WORN HERE HAIL DATE OF SUFFRAGE
description: With parades, rallies, religious services and rounds of speeches, tens of thousands of women here and across the country yesterday observed the 53d anniversary of the enactment of the 19th Amendment, which gave women the right to vote.

title: Police Problems
description: In the middle of a wave of particularly shocking murders, generally high crime rates and mass demonstrations by the public for more protection came the news that nearly half the available patrol cars in the city are unmanned every day.

title: SAIGON UNITS SHELL COMMUNISTS AT HUE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam,, Aug. 25 (UPI)  South Vietnamese artillery fired 1,000 rounds into Communist gun positions around the former imperial capital of Hue today with a rumble that echoed from the walls of the city's ruined citadel.

title: RightWing Group in Japan Stirs Furor by Adopting Samurai Rite
description: TOKYO, Aug. 25  As a 24yearold university student, Shintaro Ishihara created a literary sensation in Japan with a novel on hedonistic Japanese youth. Seventeen years and some 30 books later, Mr. Ishihara is again controversial as a leader of an influential new rightwing faction in Parliament, known as the Seirankai, or Summer Storm Club.

title: MASS INOCULATIONS FOR CHILDREN SET
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 25 (AP)Increases in childhood diseases last year will bring about an effort at mass immunization in October, the National Center for Disease Control said this week.

title: Future Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherw.se indicated:

title: A Daring PaperArt Exhibit
description: NEWARK  Of Paper, a quietly daring exhibition, is now on view in the central courtyard of the Newark Museum.

title: How to Get to U.S. Open
description: By subwayIND E or F train to Continental Avenue station, Queens (walk to stadium). By trainLong Island Rail Road (Penn Station) to Forest Hills station.

title: Judith Parker Fiancee Of Richard A. Westin
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25Mrs. Jameson Parker of Wash ington and Randolph Center, Vt., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Judith Armistead Parker, to Richard Axel Westin, son of. Gosta Westin, Swedish Consul in New York, and Mrs. Westin.

title: Atoms Win Title In Soccer, 2 to 0, BeatingTornado
description: IRVING, Tex., Aug. 25 (UPI) Bill Straub scored on a head shot with 4 minutes 15 seconds left tonight to seal a 20 Philadelphia victory over Dallas that gave the Atoms the championship of the North American Soccer League.

title: Dark clouds of inspiration
description: It is not surprising that much of India's art, music, and literature is concerned with the monsoon. Paintings depict people on rooftops, looking eagerly at the dark clouds billowing out from over the horizon, with flocks of herons flying in front. Of the many melodies of Indian music, Raga Malhar is the most popular, because it brings to mind distant echoes of the sound of thunder and the pitterpatter of raindrops. It brings the odor of the earth and of green vegetation to the nostrils, the cry of the peacock and the call of the koel to the ear. There is also the Raga Desha which invokes scenes of merrymaking, of swings in mango groves, and the singing and laughter of girls. Most Indian palaces of the past had specially designed balconies from which noblemen viewed the monsoon downpour. Here they sat listening to court musicians improvising their own versions of monsoon melodies, sipping wine and making love to the ladies of their harem. The most common theme in Indian songs is the longing of lovers for each other when the rains are in full swing. There is no joy greater than union during monsoon time, no sorrow deeper than separation during the season of the rains.

title: WIRETAP DECISION MAY BE PRECEDENT
description: A worker who is ordered by his boss to record his telephone conversationswithout telling the other partyor is himself monitored by his boss without being informed has a compelling and necessitous cause for quitting his job and is entitled to receive unemployment compensation, according to a ruling by a Pennsylvania state appeals court.

title: Jarvis to Harvard As Basketball Aide
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 25 (AP)Michael D. Jarvis, former assistant varsity basketball coach at Northeastern University, will join the Harvard staff in the same capacity this fall, the Crimson athletic director, Robert B. Watson, has announced.

title: Brigham Young University Starts Ancient Studies Unit
description: PROVO, Utah, Aug. 25A new Institute for Ancient Studies has been established at Brigham Young University here to develop and disseminate information about manuscripts of religious significance. It will be inaugurated when the fall semester opens.

title: Nixon Rides on Freeways
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 25 (AP)President Nixon took a 2 drive on California freeways near his home today, his deputy press secretary, Gerald L. Warren said. He declined to say specifically where Mr. Nixon went.

title: How About Some Honest Talk
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25  In every great crisis of violence or corruption in our national life, Americans tend either to turn away from it in cynicism or to attribute it to the moral decline of the nation as a whole. It's an old American habit: we either forget or bleed.

title: Farm Workers
description: DELANO, Calif.The fierce jurisdictional battle between Cesar Chavez's United Farm Workers and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters seemed to cool off last week. But like the lull In many battles, this one wasn't the result of a victory in the fields. It was negotiated behind the scenes. And like many negotiations, these seemed to be linked not only to the immediate questionwhich union best can represent the farm workersbut to a broader issue, the relations between the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations and the Teamsters, expelled by the A.F.L.C.I.O. in 1957.

title: Kidney Donor Dies
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Aug. 25 (AP)Raymond M. Woodruff, 54 years old, donated a kidney to his daughter Monday so she could live. He died yesterday at the J. Hillis Miller Medical Center. Doctors who said the transplant surgery was successful, are seeking the cause of death. The donor's daughter, Sandra Harper, 25, is reported in good condition.

title: Restoration Is Begun in Yonkers Park
description: YONKERS, Aug 25  Using archeological methods common to the search for ancient relics, a team of experts and volunteers began restoration today on sections of the Samuel Unlermyer estate, a 24acre park here that had fallen into dislepair since, the death of the millionaire lawyer in 1940.

title: Chess: Generation Gap Shows in Play Of Opponents, Age 21 and 23
description: Through the 12th round of the second Interzonal Tournament in Petropolis, Brazil, had the earmarks of producing a double surprise. Two of the younger generation of grandmasters, 23 yearold Ljubomir Ljubojevic of Yugoslavia and 21yearold Enrique Mecking of Brazil belied their darkhorse status in running first and second.

title: London Muggings Off 31%; Longer Terms Called Factor
description: LONDON, Aug. 25 (AP)The number of muggings in London dropped 31 per cent in the second quarter of 1973, Scotland Yard said this week. A spokesman attributed the drop to stiffer sentences and to antimugging squads.

title: News of the Screen
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 25 Sam Peckinpah will direct contemporary action thriller that he describes as a tough, bitter indictment of our society.

title: All in the Mind
description: Shoppers returning shaken from the supermarket will be astonished to learn from Herbert Stein, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, that they are generally better off than they were a year ago. Mr. Stein bases his contention on Government statistics showing that, after adjustments for price increases, per capita disposable personal income was 5 per cent higher in the second quarter of 1973 than a year earlier.

title: Arafat Meets With South
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 25 (UPI)  Palestinian guerrilla leader Yassir Arafat held his first meeting today with Premier Takieddin Solh to discuss relations between the guerrilla movement and the Lebanese Government, official sources said.

title: Nevada Educator Resigns To Head Maine University
description: RENO, Aug. 25Dr. N. Edd Miller, president of the University of Nevada at Reno, announced yesterday that he was resigning to become president of the University of Maine at PortlandGorham.

title: Police Seek Accomplice In RobberySexual Attack
description: Detectives were searching yesterday for the accomplice of a 45yearold exconvict who, they say, took part in a $125 robbery and sexual attack on a 30yearold woman in the Ebbetts Field Houses apartment complex in Flatbush last Thursday night.

title: Edward N. Damon Weds Claudia Cords
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 25 The marriage of Miss Claudia Cords to Edward N. Damon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert S. Damon of North Conway, N. H., took place here this afternoon. The Rev. Robert L. Cope of the Unitarian Church performed the ceremony at the home of Mrs. Helmuth Cords, mother of the bride.

title: Exhibitions
description: PARENT'S MAGAZINE GALLERY, S2 ran. derbilt Ave. Photos by Betty Lou English. Hours, 9 to 5 weekdays. Through Friday.

title: JudithM. Wait Becomes Bride
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 25Miss Judith Marie Wait, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dwight N. Wait of Greenwich, was married here this evening to Dennis Philip Wilkinson. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Wilkinson of Westport.

title: U.S. Golfers Recapture Walker Cup
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 25 (AP)The United States weathered a strong comeback by Britain today and regained the Walker Cup in the 24th competition between the countries amateur golfers.

title: Mrs. Bowman Wed to H. A. Hodges
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 25Mrs. Joan Lappe Bowman, a former New York and Chicago couture buyer, was married here this afternoon to H. Anthony Hodges, who is vice president of the Trust Department, Mellon Bank N.A., and an internationally known dog judge.

title: PROGRESS SHOWN AT WILLOWBROOK
description: When the Willowbrook State School for the Mentally Retarded was ordered by Federal Judge Orrin G. Judd in Brooklyn to improve its. patient care and other operations, he described the condition of the Staten Island institution as inhumane and shocking.

title: Eve Marie Bartle, a Potter, Is Married to John S. Kitchen
description: HARBOR SPRINGS, Mich., Aug. 25In St. John's Episcopal Church here this afternoon, Miss Eve Marie Bartle, daughter of Mrs. Thomas Reynolds Bartle of New York and the late Mr. Bartle, was married to John Scott Kitchen, son of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Kitchen of Indianapolis. The Very Rev. Dennis R. Odekirk performed the ceremony.

title: Suffolk Museum Is Expanding
description: STONY BROOK, L. I. A 38yearold Suffolk Museum here is about to undergo a major expansion program as well as a name change.

title: GOOD NEWS. WOMEN ARE GOING TO DRESS UP AGAIN.
description: Glow, gleam, glitter, sparkle plenty. That's designers advice to women for winter evenings. Seventh Avenue has collected enough metallic thread to light up the city with very little help from Con Edison. There's gold, there's silver and there's even bronzeknitted, to be sure, with plain old black, brown, gray or this year's basic rust. But no matter how you color it, the shimmer is there. The theory seems to be that any woman who's paraded around all day in sweaters and tweedy pants will want to look like a movie star at night. So it's back to the gym class. These slinkies demand a super figure.

title: New &
description: Destiny surprises Orval Pierce, a moronic trucker, with a $50,000 settlement for his parents death in an auto accident. With this wad, the poor unstable yokel goes into the hauling business himself (in the Arkansas town of Parson's Mill) and becomes a rich unstable yokel. (Orval is one of those people who imagine that Cornmonists are reading their lips through telescopes.

title: Peace Through Law Group Meets Today in Ivory Coast
description: ABIDJAN, Aug. 25 (UPI)Hlundreds of lawyers and judges from about 115 countries are about to try again to advance programs aimed at replacing war with law.

title: WALL STREET
description: Suppose you had $20,000 and wanted morelongterm appreciation and reasonable to modest income to be exacthow would you invest it? Six Wall Street research directors, when asked this question, responded with the following portfolio plans.

title: THE NEWS IN HAND AND ON FOOT
description: There's good news for pedestrians. Pavements are no cleaner and traffic is still a menace, but walking shoes may make walking a pleasure again. The highheeled loafer is last year's look. New fall styles have heels that range from pancakeflat to, oh, maybe an inch and a half high. They're intended to be worn with pants or skirts and sweaters  the kind of clothes designers have taken to calling sportswear even though they're meant for nothing more strenuous than shopping, walking to work or supervising the sandbox set But, of course, most of the daytime clothes for fall fit into that category.

title: Four fictions

title: FLORIDA URGES CARE IN GULF OIL DRILLING
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Aug. 25 (UPI)Florida's natural resources director warns that one of the world's most productive fisheries could he endangered by the granting of offshore oildrilling leases along the gulf coast of Florida, Alabama and Mississippi.

title: L.I.R.R. Is Smoothing Out Its Tracks
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has ordered more than 142 miles of new rail this year for a track improvement program on the Long Island Rail Road calling for long, smooth stretches of welded rail.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: New Brain XRay Device May Transform Therapy
description: LONDON, Aug. 25  Radiologists in five British and American hospitals are Xraying patients heads with a new machine that for the first time allows doctors to see the brain in cross section, just like an illustration in Gray's textbook of anatomy.

title: Sephardic Heritage and Language Feared on Wane
description: When the World Institute of Sephardic Studies, a small yearold organization here that is dedicated to renewing cultural consciousness among Sephardic Jews, was looking for a Ladino language teacher for a course in the fall, the staff had a problem.

title: Susan Hammett Campbell Bride Of Alfred Beaumont Thacher Jr.
description: HUNTINGTON, L. L, Aug. 25  The Old First Presbyterian Church was the, setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Susan Hammett Campbell, daughter of Col. and Mrs. William Reginald Campbell of Cold Spring Harbor and Newport, R. I., to Alfred Beaumont Thacher Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Thacher of West Hartford, Conn.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: From such early films as the 1905 short titled Wooing and Wedding of a Coon to such latterday opera as Shaft, Donald Bogle, a black editor and historian, here traces the role of the Negro in U.S. fictional films. It is a complex subject; Mr. Bogle's handling of it is a model interpretative history, temperate but shrewd in its judgments, sound in its choice of works for detailed analysis, wellorganized, wellwritten, solidly grounded in historical and biographical fact.

title: U.N. TO HEAR BACKERS OF FREE PUERTO RICO
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 25Representatives of political groups advocating Puerto Rico independence have been granted their first chance to be heard by a United Nations body despite strenuous lobbying against the move by the United States.

title: Reds Down Cards
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 25 (UPI) Dan Driessen, a rookie, drove home five runs with a single and a double tonight to lead the Cincinnati Reds to a 64 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals. Don Gullett pitched the distance for the Reds to gain his 15th victory against eight losses.

title: Wallace, With 10,000, Notes Birthday
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 25Calling it one of the greatest days in my life, Gov. George C. Wallace marked his 54th birthday today as 10,000 of his supporters gathered here in Garrett Coliseum to celebrate the event.

title: 3 State Refineries Expanding
description: TRENTON  Upward of $300million will be spent in the next four years to increase the refining capacities at three major oil companies in New Jersey.

title: On the Wings of Song (A Coward's Concert)
description: I WAS not surprised to discover in these pages that there are others like myself who fear flying (Some of the Best People Are Afraid of Flying, Travel Section, Aug. 12), but I was startled to see that the figure apparently approaches 25 million. Airline people have always claimed that only 10 per cent of the American population flies at all, but this can't be so. Ten per cent of current census figures would come to close to 25 million, which would mean that practically everybody is scared. And if this should be true, surely by now the airlines would have done something about it, rather than merely impoverish their imaginations by dreaming up further variations in frozen food and piano lounges. Or maybe not, for the problem is not so easily dealt with, being philosophical rather than, as recently suggested in these pages, psychological or pharmaceutical. Fear of flying is no more neurotic or physiological than fear of death, its first cousin once removed. If there is alleviation it lies in confrontation, not suppression, and I believe, if I may say so, that I have stumbled onto something that may make things a little easier for all of us. It is, simply, an inflight recording program selected with a bit more imagination and empathy for the craven hordes of us back in the cabin, cring

title: Humanist Manifesto II Offers a Survival Philosophy
Prince of peace
description: Norodom Sihanouk  Samdech or Prince to his Cambodian compatriots, Monseigneur to visiting foreigners, Snooky to his Washington detractorsis a man who has induced apoplexy in a 20year succession of American Secretaries of State, generals and emissaries. Until early 1970 he had received their demands and blandishments and had outlasted all of them. And in so doing, he had achieved the impossible: kept Cambodia out of the Indochina War, an oasis of peace in a desert of hostilities. But then came the Lon Nol coup, and the United States invasion; and today Cambodia has been laid waste.

title: Metuchen Catholics Seeking to Build Faith Through Charismatic Renewal
description: METUCHENEvery Thursday night, more than 300 people gather in the basement of St. Francis Roman Catholic Church here to praise the Lord with a Pentecostal fervor. They are part of the Charismatic Renewal Movement within the Catholic church, a movement that began in the late nineteensixties and has grown increasingly popular.

title: Peaches Blushing Abundantly on Island
description: The peaches have been rolling in. The little greenish hard ones from Southern and New Jersey farms are available in supermarket bins, while tender fourinch giants are carefully cradled in separate compartments at fancy grocers. And the local Long Island crop is in abundance at the roadside stands,

title: Kissinger, in Mexico City, Confers With President
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 25 (AP)Henry A. Kissinger met today with President Luis Echeverria and said that his semiofficial visit to Mexico, which began yesterday, underlines the importance we shall attach to relations with Latin America.

title: Margaret M. Postlewaite Is a Bride
description: PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Aug. 25 Miss Margaret Mary Postlewaite, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Neal Postlewaite of Columbus, Ohio, was married here this morning to Gerard Francis Kiernan, son of Mr. and Mrs. James C. Kiernan of Arlington, Mass.

title: Washington scenes
description: If this has been a very bad year for American politics, it has nonetheless been a very good year for American political fiction. Already in 1973 I have read three fine works of political fiction, and that is without precedent for any year in my memory. The three I have in mind are Tom Wicker's Facing the Lions, Edward Stewart's They've Shot the President's Daughter! and Ward Just's collection of Washington stories, The Congressman Who Loved Flaubert.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: The international headquarters of Technovation, Inc.. in a quiet area of Wayne, N.J., resembles a ranchstyle home, and this similarity is sustained even as the door is opened by Fredric S. Miller, president of Technovation.

title: Cancer
description: WASHINGTON  Every minute a new case of cancer is discovered in the United States. The disease is taking a fearful toll, causing the deaths of 350,000 Americans yearly. Only heart disease is a greater killer.

title: CHINESE DOCTOR IN KEY W.H.O. POST
description: In the person of a former New York pediatrician, China has moved into a central position of influence and participation within the World Health Organization.

title: Who Makes Music and Where
description: NEW YORK CITY OPERA NEW YORK STATE THEATER

title: Jane Robinson Bride of Ophthalmologist
description: Miss Jane Pamela Robin son, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Robinson of Paterson, N. J., was married here last night to Dr. Daniel Fishkoff, son of Dr. and Mrs. Alexander Fishkoff of Perth Amboy, N. J. The ceremony was performed at Hampshire House by Rabbi Martin Freedman.

title: YooHoo It's Show Time On Broadway
description: THEATERGOERS looking for omens, harbingers, trends or some shred of evidential sooth as to what's in store for them during the season about to be born, take note: Broadway rings up its 197374 curtain with a revival of a 1926 operetta, Sigmund Romberg's The Desert Song.

title: World News Briefs
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 25 (Reuters)Mediation efforts to end Canada's nationwide rail strike broke down last night despite a Government plea for another day of efforts to negotiate a settlement.

title: Eisenhower to Drop Column
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25 (AP)David Eisenhower is abandoning his newspaper career as a baseball columnist with The Philadelphia Evening and Sunday Bulletin. His final column will appear tomorrow, The Bulletin's sports editor, Herb Stutz said today. Since early May, President Nixon's soninlaw has written a Sunday column about the Philadelphia Phillies. He is married to the President's daughter Julie.

title: SAIGON IS SEEKING MORE RECOGNITION
description: SAIZTON, Sout Vietnam, Aug. 25 (Reuters)South Vietnam is mounting a diplomatic campaign for recognition among the countries of Africa and Asia.

title: Photography
description: SAN FRANCISCO THE coinciding of various experiencesa number of exhibits I saw on the East Coast this past spring, several recent conversations with young photographers out here, and a poignant article by Peter Schjeldahl in these pages a few months back  have turned my attention to an increasingly pressing problem in photography: the tyranny of premature recognition. Schjeldahl's piece, epitomizing this very problem in another field, was a spirited defense of Frank Stella against the disfavor into which that painter has, apparently, lately fallen. The thrust of Schjeldahl's argument was that Stella should not be considered washed up, that he might still make a further contribution to his medium and so should not yet be written off as a hasbeen. Stella turned 37 last May.

title: The Future Years;... But Only Events Can Settle the Biggest Question of All
description: It is true that as far as the capacity to govern is concerned that to be under a constant barrage 12 to 15 minutes a night on each of the three major networks for four months tends to raise some questions in the peoples mind with regard to the President and it may raise some questions with regard to his capacity to govern... but now we must move on from Watergate to the business of the people.

title: State Tax Revenue From Aqueduct Off
description: Attendance, ontrack wagering and state partimutuel tax revenue at Aqueduct's summer meeting showed declines from the comparable period last year.

title: 2 ON HELICOPTER DIE IN FOREST FIRE AREA
description: Two men were killed in a helicopter crash at the site of a brush fire in the Sierra Nevada foothills of California yesterday as the last major fire in the West was contained, United Press International reported.

title: For Women, Today Is a Day To Recall
description: PRINCETONThe 53d anniversary of women's suffrage is being commemorated in New Jersey today. The National Organization of WomenNew Jersey Is sponsoring a feminist church service here in Princeton, and the Women's Political Caucus of New Jersey is holding a suffrage picnic in Cheesequake, in Middlesex County.

title: See the Liberals Scurry
description: The unforgivable crime of New Deal liberalism is that it has bored itself to death. Is there a Liberal in the house? (Scurry, scurry, scurry: you can hear the professors of political science hurrying into the woodwork, the solons leaping behind a sofa and trying to creep under its skirts.) Who, me?

title: Article 3  No Title
description: They returned to the lobby of the hotel. The lobby itself was enormous, with more trees in urns and running fountains and restaurant tables arranged to resemble sidewalk cafes, and enormous chandeliers dangling from long cables, and wild birds in an aviary, and bedrooms on each floor overlooking the main floor and leading upward in a high well that caused a kind of vertigo in reverse, and hanging gardens, and four exposed glass elevators allowing their passengers an unencumbered view on all sides... the whole feel of the place suggesting it was actually the outdoors. Long lines of people waited for the elevators, handsome couples in evening dress heading for the top and couples with the look of the country upon them...

title: Jean Stafford and Her Secretary Harvey Reigning in Hamptons
description: EAST HAMPTON, L.I.Jean Stafford, the doyenne of the South Fork's busy literary world and the areas's only resident Pulitzer Prize holder, is glimpsing the end of a new novel, she said the other day in an interview in her home here.

title: KarlHermann Flach, Head Of German Free Democrats
description: FRANKFURT, Germany, Aug. 25 (UPI)KarlHermann Flach, general secretary of the cogoverning Free Democrat party, died today in a hospital. He was 43 years old.

title: 2 Trapped Miners Found Dead After 8Day Search in Arizona
description: CASA GRANDE, Ariz., Aug. 25 (AP)Two miners trapped 1,200 feet under the desert in a copper mine for eight days were found dead today, a Hecla Mining Company spokesman said.

title: Recklers Have Child
description: BOSTON, Aug. 25  A daughter was born to Dr. and Mrs. Jon Michael Reckler on Aug. 1 at the Boston LyingIn Hospital.

title: Talking Traffic With a Man Who's Above
description: GEORGE MEADE, who is in his sixth year as airborne traffic reporter for WOR Radio, has excellent credentials for talking about New York's highway jams. He studies them during the morning and evening rush hours from Monday to Friday while piloting the station's orangecolored helicopter at 75 m.p.h. at an altitude of about 1,000 feet. The copter, which has silver canvas floats in case Meade needs to make an emergency landing on one of the rivers, has WOR 710 marked on it in black letters.

title: PSYCHICS ADVISE SPIRITUAL GROUP
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C. Aug. 25  W. G. Roll, a parapsychologist who was lecturing here on the survival of personality after death, kept looking up from his notes to find dozing people scattered among his audience of several hundred.

title: Dance
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. N0 doubt. The New York City Ballet is one of the world's great, dance companies. Why, then, at its summer home, the Saratoga Performing Arts Center, does it generally come on like a slightly sluggish prima ballerina?

title: Noise Controls Are Proposed
description: TRENTONThe state's Department of Environmental Protection has issued proposed regulations governing the control of noise from commercial or industrial operations.

description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 25  Dr. Anthony J. J. Rourke, a leading hospital consultant, executive director of the Hospital Council of Greater New York from 1952 to 1954 and former president of the American Hospital Association, died Thursday at his home, 79 Overlook Circle. He was 69 years old.

title: It's Fair Time in Flemington Once Again
description: FLEMINGTON No New Jersey summer would be complete without the annual Flemington Fair, which is the granddaddy of them all in the state, if not in the entire country. And this year's event, which will be held from Tuesday through Labor Day, is expected to attract another banner crowd of at least 100,000 people.

title: 57 Shows Next Weekend For the Canine Fanciers
description: Next weekend, the country goes to the dogs. There are 22 allbreed shows, 24 beagle trials, five tests for retrievers, three specialty events, two for the educated set and one for spanielsfor a total of 57. I know of no other weekend when there are more circuits, said Norman J. Furber, vice president in charge of show operations at the American Kennel Club.

title: For three years the great rains failed
description: AURANGABAD, India. It was the hottest day the year, 112 degrees in the shade and like the hell fires of Gehenna in the sun. I stood on a mound taking in the scene. Behind me was a range of hills, brown, barren, boulderstrewn. In front was a melancholy expanse of duncolored fields divided by cactus and camel thorn. The flamboyant guimohar was in flower, the fiery orange of its blossoms almost burning the eyes. Here and there was a laburnum drooping under the weight of its clusters of yellow petals. A hot wind picked up dust, churned it into a whirling dervish which spiraled its way across the wasteland and died out on the rocky hillside.

title: Cards Pull It Out, 1310
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 25with one second to play tonight, Jim Bakken kicked the longest field goal of his career54 yardsand gave the St. Louis Cardinals a 1310 preseason victory over the New York Jets before a crowd of 41,040 in Busch Stadium.

title: D. R. Monack Marries Susan Lawrence
description: MONROE, Conn., Aug. 25  Miss Susan Wells Lawrence, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Wells Lawrence of Stratford and North Eastham, Mass., was married this afternoon to Donald Raymond Monack, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Anthony Monack of Branford, formerly of Charleroi Pa.

title: Joseph Durso
description: There are 10,000 golf courses in the United States, with 300 new ones added every year and 12 million people striding over them with woods and irons. About 25,000 of the 12 million make a living at it, most of them as club pros who give lessons and run equipment shops. About 7,000 of those are members of the Professional Golfers Association and 325 are cardcarrying members of Sports its Touring Professionals Division. At the summit of stands Joseph C. Dey Jr., The Times the commissioner and Eagle Scout of pro golf. Joe Dey became commissioner of the touring pros by acclamation 4 years ago when they settled their revolt from the rest of the golfing world and opened their own dukedom. He is an Eagle Scout of golf by nature: a straightarrow of a man who considers golf a game of honor, as he does most things in a world besieged by fat

Crawford Jr. of Riverside, to Kurt John Wolfgruber, son of Dr. Paul Wolfgruber of Hornell, N.Y., and Mrs. Leona Wolfgruber of Arkport, N. Y.
