description: ANG SNOUL, Cambodia, Aug. 28Heavy fighting, with growing casualties on both sides, spread along Route 4 southwest of Phnom Penh today as Government forces sought to reopen the overland link to Kompong Som, Cambodia's only seaport.

title: Waldheim in Beirut After Syrian Talks; Cyprus Is Next Stop
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 28Secretary General Waldheim of the United Nations arrived here from Syria today on the second slop of his tour of the Middle East, whose situation he termed one of the most dangerous and explosive in the world.

title: Mission Impossible?
description: Recent developments on both sides of the ArabIsraeli conflict compound the already formidable task facing United Nations Secretary General Waldheim in his current, onthescene search for a new Middle East peace formula.

title: Roundup: Robinson, Yankee Failure, Becomes Philadelphia Success Story
description: Bill Robinson, who failed to impress the New York Yankees in three seasons in New York, has found a new life in Philadelphia after waystops in Tucson. Ariz., and Eugene, Ore.

title: Bridge: Knowing Cards in One Hand Aids in Partial Elimination
New Jersey Briefs
description: Two retail store clerks and a manager were convicted of having sold forbidden items in Ocean City on Sundaya handbag and a hibachi barbecue.

title: Information Calls: To Pay or Not To
description: Amid jeers, shouts and applause, the final arguments were heard yesterday on proposals for the New York Telephone Company to charge for information calls in the state.

title: C.A.B. Challenges Decision Invalidating Accord on Uniform Atlantic Air Fares
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board voted yesterday to ask a Federal court in Washington to stay the implementation of decision invalidating the agreement by which virtually all !scheduled airlines charge the same fare for transAtlantic flights.

title: Howard Johnson Loses Its Turnpike Contract
description: EAST BRUNSWICK, Aug. 28 (AP)The New Jersey Turnpike Authority announced today it would not renew its contract with the Howard Johnson's Restaurants, which operated exclusively on the superhighway for 22 years.

title: Robert F. Kelly to Head State's Cable TV Commission
description: ALBANY, Aug. 28Assemblyman Robert F. Kelly, a Brooklyn Republican, was named today by Acting Gov. Malcolm Wilson to head the State Commission on Cable Television, the bipartisan agency created last year by the state legislature to regulate the granting and operation of cable TV franchises throughout the state.

title: 7 Present and ExPolicemen Indicted in Bribe Inquiry
Canadian Rail Halt
description: The hardships caused on both sides of the border by the Canadian railroad strike are a harsh reminder of the degree to which the United States and Canadian economies are interlocked. The disruption of Canada's rail lifeline also underscores the remarkable selfrestraint unions in this country have been showing in the face skyrocketing living costs as against the normally less militant labor movements of other lands.

title: Buchanan Uses Chu Chu to Get Up Steam for Duran.
description: For Ken Buchanan, former lightweight champion of the world, Saturday's fight against Edwin (Chu Chu) Malave in the Felt Forum is just an exercise to keep him fit for his real rivalRoberto Duran, the current champion.

title: U.S. Has Intensified Its Antiterrorist Screening
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 In the wake of the letterbomb explosion at the British Embassy yesterday, the United States Government disclosed today that it had stepped up antiterrorist measures here and abroad.

title: County Aids Consumers In Suffolk
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., Aug. 28 The Suffolk County Legislature today approved broad series of consumerprotection measures including strict regulations on pyramiding corporations in the county, prohibitions against unfair trade practices and the establishment of a Department of Consumer Affairs headed by a commissioner with subpoena powers.

title: SAKHAROV IS TOLD TO END CRITICISM
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 28Forty members of the prestigious Soviet Academy of Sciences today called on Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist, to cease his public criticism of the Kremlin's domestic and foreign policies.

title: Robert Dowling of City Investing Dead; Spearheaded Civic and Planning Drives
description: Robert W. Dowling, who took part in many civic and business enterprises in the lifestream of New York City, died at his home in the Pierre Hotel yesterday after a long illness. He was 77 years old.

title: Solzhenitsyn Tells Of Threats to Life
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 28Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, in a rare and bluntly outspoken interview with two Western newsmen, has declared that his life has been threatened. The Nobel Prize novelist, whose writings are banned in his homeland, added that if he was imprisoned or killed, the main part of my works will be published.

title: Cattle Flown to Japan To Sell for $11 a Pound
description: MOSES LAKE, Wash., Aug. 28 (UPI)A Flying Tiger Lines air freighter left here today for Japan carrying 131 head of beef cattle for sale at more than $11 a pound.

title: Nutrition: Fats and Vitamins in the Body's Chemistry
description: Fats and vitamins. These days people concerned about nutrition frequently think they have to nearly eliminate the former while they take massive doses of the latter.

description: Now it's a horse race, $2 bettor conceded yesterday at Belmont Park after learning that the $250,000 Marlboro Cup here on Sept. 15 would have a field of at least eight.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: FICTION

title: 2 IN MURDER TRIAL AT ST. CROIX FREED
description: CHRISTIANSTED, St. Croix, VI, Aug, 28 (UPI)The last two of seven defendants in this island's second recent multiple murder trial were found not guilty today on charges of having killed two men and wounding a third in an armed attack last Nov. 7 on a local restaurant.

description: Films THE STONE KILLER, a melodrama directed by Michael Winner, at neighbor. hood theaters.

description: The New York Dance Festival, which would have begun its 12th season this weekend, has been forced to cancel because of insufficient funding.

description: One man died and 1,000 passengers were trapped in 115degree heat and heavy smoke yesterday after an archway in the ancient Flushing line tunnel under the East River collapsed on the first car of Queensbound IRT train.

title: WATERGATE PANEL RESUMES SEPT.17
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., Democrat of North Carolina, has decided to cut short the second and third phases of the Senate Watergate Committee's public hearings so that the committee will have more time to prepare its final report.

title: SCHOOL OFFICIALS ACCEPT PACT HERE
description: The city's publicschool supervisors and administrators have voted, by a better than 2to1 margin, to accept a new contract with the Board of Education that will give them higher salaries and other benefits, along with eight additional working days a year.

description: CHICAGO, Aug. 28 (Reuters) The Midwest Stock Exchange said today that it had a proift of $291,400 on revenues of $12.3million in the first seven months of this year.

title: Food Price Relief?
description: After all the painful increases in food prices and the official warnings of astounding new increases ahead, it is at least moderately encouraging to note that in the last two weeks the trend of wholesale food prices in the major American commodities exchanges has been downward substantially so.

title: Heath, in Belfast, Talks With Moderates
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland Aug. 28With helicopters pa. trolling overhead, soldiers guilt bristling from roofs, and crowd; held well back, Prime Ministes Heath began a twoday visit tc Northern Ireland today.

description: As the American economic boom goes into its latephase paroxyms, astonishment steals over the faces of economists, businessmen and even Nixon Administration officials.

description: A 23yearold truck driver fled from a Federal courtroom in Brooklyn after he was sentenced to six months in prison for theft yesterday, but he was quickly captured by a deputy marshal.

description: LONDONFar and away the biggest events of this city's musical summer haw been the two complete cycles of Wagner's Ring of the Nibelung put on by the Sadler's Wells company at the Coliseum. And the most interesting thing about those cycles, even more intriguing than hearing Wagner's tetralogy in English, has been the conductor, Reginald Goodall,

title: Prices of Futures Tumble For Grain and Livestock
description: Two news items struck the Midwest commodities exchange yesterday after the close of markets in which virtually all grain, soybean and livestock futures prices dropped by their respective daily permissible limits.

title: People and Business
description: The Directory of Key Government Personnel, Hill & Knowlton's pocketsize biennial listing of who's who In high places in Washington, has finally made its appearanceseveral months after the normal publication date. As the public relations firm discreetly notes in a press release accompanying the latest edition: Although delayed by wellpublicized developments that held up naming some key Government officials...

description: Ten years ago, Hannah D. Atkins, a State Representative in Oklahoma, and J. L. Chestnut, a Selma, Ala., lawyer, frequently entertained whites in their homes.

title: 69 ARE PROMOTED TO POLICE POSTS
description: Sixtynine police officers were promoted to higher ranks) in ceremonies at the Police Academy yesterday, and for the first time in department history the promotion orders of the four highest ranking among them said their appointments were good for only a period of 365 days.

title: 3 Camp Counselors Held in Connecticut On Robbery Charges
description: SHARON, Conn., Aug. 28Three counselors at a boys camp operated near here by a New York City church group, were arrested last night and charged with robbing a service station of $750 while the attendant was repairing a flat tire on their car.

title: Advertising: VW Strays Return
description: What do you do when you discover that a lot of, the purchasers of your product are former customers who strayed and have since returned to the fold?

title: Film: Japanese View World War II in Militarists
description: February, 1936, to August, 1945: The rapid rise, brief triumph and cataclysmic fall of the military government in Japan is the subject of Hirumichi Horikawa's The Militarists, which opened yesterday at the Elgin Theater. As a film, it is a curious phenomenon, at least to our experience. Neither fiction nor documentary (though it makes use of some documentary footage), it is really a kind of dramatized fact. The closest analogy I can think of would be the historical pageant. But the pageant, as if to justify its existence, virtually demands a hopeful or victorious ending. The Militarists ends in defeat and shame.

I., Aug. 28 The Suffolk County Legislature today approved a broad series of consumerprotection measures including strict regulations on pyramiding corporations in the county, prohibitions against unfair trade practices and the establishment of a Department of Consumer Affairs headed by a commis sioner with subpoena powers.

title: CITY ENCOURAGED BY POULTRY BIDS
description: The city's Purchase Department said yesterday that it had received encouraging bids on chickens from major producers in the East.

title: DENTIST IS CHARGED WITH SEXUAL ABUSE
description: A 64yearold city Health Department dentist was arrested yesterday on charges of sexually abusing and verbally harassing four female patients aged 11 to 18 years old.

title: Taxes Discouraging Farmers in Sussex
description: NEWTON, Aug. 28  For nearly 200 years the Morrow family has farmed the land of Sussex County producing milk for the market. Now, William Morrow, owner of the 280acre family farm near here, is planning to sell his land to a speculator and move to Iowa to raise corn and soybeans.

title: Noo Jall Plays In City Parks
description: The latest prodUction of the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater, a new 56minute comedy in one act by Jainie Carrero called Noo Jail (which is the way some Spanishspeaking citizens pronounce New York), had its premiere in Riverside Park, of West 103d Street, before 450 spectators on Monday night.

title: Robert Dowling Dies
description: Robert W. Dowling, former president and chairman of the City Investing Company, died yesterday at his home in the Pierre Hotel. He was 77 years old. He served on many civic, cultural, educational and professional organizations. Details on Page 40.

title: Heat Kills Boy in Car
description: OWENSBORO, Ky., Aug. 28: (UPI)A 2yearold boy apparsuffocated from intense heat yesterday in his family's atutomobile, parked on a street near his home here. Temperatures reached the low 90's here Yesterday afternoon.

title: U.S ACCUSES HANOI OF BUILDUP IN SOUTH
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) The North Vietnamese have violated peace accords by transforming the former United States base at Khe Sanh in South Vietnam into a major military complex, Pentagon officials say.

title: GERALD LE VINO
description: HARTSDALE, N. Y., Aug. 28 Gerald Le Vino, who retired in 1970 as preseident of Guiterman & Co., an export sales agent, died today in White Plains Hospital, He was 82 years old and lived here.

title: CARINA DE NARVAEZ
description: Carina (Ninu) de Narvaez, 16yearold daughter of Dr. Felix de Narvaez, adjunct associate professor at New York University School of Medicine, and of Mrs. Cynthia Delafield de Narvaez of Sarasota, Fla., died after a long illness yesterday in University Hospital, where her father is an attending pathologist.

title: 52 Defeat 7th Straight For Yanks
BIGRANSOM ASKED IN PARAGUAY CASE
description: ASUNCION, Paraguay, Aug) 28 (Reuters)A British businessman was kidnapped near here last night and his captors,, who police sources said could be Argentine guerrillas, have demanded a ransom equivalent, to $ 1million.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: College Starts on a Trail
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Aug. 28 (AP) The road to higher education will begin somewhere along the 75mile Finger Lakes Trail in upstate New York for 11 Cornell University freshmen. Accompanied by two Cornell guides, they will spend a week together on the trial system as part of the university's Wilderness Reflections preorientation program.

title: Leopold Blumka, Long a Dealer Of Renaissance Objects, Dead
description: Leopold Blumka, a prominent dealer and collector of medieval and Renaissance objects, who continued a tradition here established by his greatgrandfather in Vienna, died yesterday at his home, 941 Park Avenue.

title: North Korea Demands the South Replace Delegates to Talks
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Wednesday, Aug. 29  North Korea threatened yesterday to break off its talks with South Korea unless the South replaced some of its delegates. The North Koreans charged that the delegates in question were responsible for the abduction of a South Korean opposition leader from Tokyo to Seoul early this month.

title: INDIA TO RELEASE 90,000 PAKISTANIS IN PEACE ACCORD
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 28India and Pakistan signed an agreement here today clearing the way for the. release of most of the 90,000 Pakistani prisoners held in India and for settlement of other problems arising from their war in December,.1971.

title: Rockefeller to Push Sandman Candidacy
description: TRENTON, Aug. 28Governor Rockefeller has agreed to campaign in New Jersey next month for the Republican candidate for Governor in the first of a series of crosscountry political forays that informed Republicans in New York said were calculated to establish him as a candidate for the Presidency in 1976.

title: West Point Simplifies Cadet Regulations
description: WEST POINT, Aug. 28The United States Military Academy has rewritten its book of regulations, replacing decades of accumulated restrictions with a simplified code emphasizing selfdiscipline.

title: DENVER POST STOCK SOLD BY NEWHOUSE
description: DENVER, Aug. 28 (AP) Samuel 1. Newhouse, who tried for 13 years to gain control of The Denver Post, sold his 18.5 per cent interest today for $4.78million, attorneys for The. Post announced.

title: Civil Rights Unity Gone In Redirected Movement
description: Ten years ago, Hannah D. Atkins, a State Representative in Oklahoma, and J. L. Chestnut., a Selma, Ala., lawyer, frequent ly entertained whites in their homes,

title: Care for Troubled Youth In City and State Scored
description: The State Judicial Conference accused the city and the state yesterday of having failed to give adequate psychiatric help to hundreds of troubled New York City youngsters and of often having refused to give any psychiatric care to the children who need it most.

title: STOCKS SEESAW; DOW CLIMBS 1.36
Newburgh Gets Black Aide
description: NEWBURGH, N. Y., Aug. 28 (AP)The City Council voted yesterday to have Tyrone Crabb fill a Council vacancy. He will be the first black to hold office in the city, which is about 40 per cent black and Puerto Rican.

title: 16 to Go Today in 48th Hambletonian
description: DU QUOIN, Ill. Aug. 28Sixteen of the foremost trotting horses in the country were ready to go to the post here tomorrow in the 48th Hambletonian. But behind the serene setting in the cornfields of southern Illinois, a historic fight was being waged over the future site of harness racing's most prestigious event.

title: SOVIET SAYS TWO TESTIFY FREELY
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 28Two prominent dissidents who are being tried on charges of subversion continued to offer willing testimony today, according to Tass, the official press agency. At the same time the controlled Soviet media began to give wide internal publicity to the case.

title: Kissinger Cancels Trip
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 28 (AP)  Secretary of Statedesignate Henry A. Kissinger has canceled a planned September trip to Europe, the Western White House said today. Mr. Kissinger had accepted an invitation to address a nongovernmerit group, the Atlantic Treaty Organization, in Brussels on Sept. 10. But the deputy press secretary, Gerald L. Warren, said Mr. Kissinger had told the group he was forced to cancel the trip because of demands on his time.

title: Books of The Times
description: I laughed, though not immoderately, at this book and then wondered whether wasn't being too easy a mark, like one of those chaps you secretly feel superior to because you can always get a rise out of him. Nobody wants to be an easy mark, with the possible exception of people who despair of pleasing other people in any other way. In some circles, sophistication means not responding to anything, in any form. Not only to see the joke, but to see through it is the coolest posture of all. I've already laughed at that, eons ago, you imply  like Baudelaire, who said, I've seen everything twice. Or like Jacques Vache, who said, Humor is a sense of the ioyless, theatric futility of things when one is enlightened. I'm concerned, too, about the fact that I often laugh out of synchronization, so to speak, with informed opinion. I sometimes feel I'm the only man in America who doesn't think that Catch22 and The Ginger Man are among the funniest books of the century. I've been caught laughing instead at The Magic Mountain and The Trial. Of course, there are a few other people who laugh at The Trial, but I think they're laughing in italics, in what I suppose you could call the French manner, while I'm just laughing in the old involuntary way.

title: Worst Flood in 26 Years Leaves Havoc in Pakistan
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 28 The worst flood in Pakistan's 26yearold history left a trail of shattered villages, ruined crops and homeless families today as it surged toward the southeastern city of Hyderbad.

title: WESTVACO POSTS EARNINGS RECORD
City Council to Ask Court for Extension On Saturday Deadline for Remapping
description: The City Council voted yesterday to ask the State Court of Appeals for an extension beyond Saturday to remap the district boundaries for the Council.

title: Representatives Find Nixon Hurt but Call Impeachment Unlikely
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28President Nixon is not just lame duck, he is a wounded duck, said Representative Howard W. Robison, a Republican with 15 years in the House. Among his upstate New York constituents more than four out of 12 who answered Robison questionnaire favored Mr. Nixon's resignation or removal.

title: A.E.C. Awards Contract
description: The United Nuclear Corporation announced yesterday that it had been awarded a $47million contract by the Atomic Energy Commission, calling for production of nuclear components. The contract provides for delivery over a period of four years.

title: West Point Simplifies Cadet Regulations
Track Collides With Train, Derailing Locomotive
description: HAZLET, Aug. 28A tractortrailer collided with a Penn Central passenger train here today, derailing the locomotive.

title: Abbie Hoffman Among 4 Held On Charges of Selling Cocaine
description: Abbie Hoffman, the antiwar activist, Yippie and defendant in the Chicago Seven conspiracy trial, was arrested last night along with three other persons and charged with selling three pounds of cocaine to two undercover narcotic agents for $36,000.

title: CHOTINER AGREES HE PAID NEWSMEN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 Murray Chotiner, a long time political associate of President Nixon, confirmed today that he had hired Seymour K. Freidin, a journalist, for $1,000 a week, to supply intelligence do Democratic candidates to the Nixon campaign.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: EAST it will not be ordinary, oh no, but rather wild, mad, serene, exotic  even traditional, certainly in keeping with the modular grandeur of the 110floor World Trade Center. Gasping with anticipation we asked, What? Only the first haute couture fashion show ever held in the trade center, that's what, and devoted solely to such Asian designers as Madame Nu of Bangkok, Bonnie Wong of Hong Kong and Jose Moreno, whose caftans, they tell us, assure him the title of the fashion of Asia.

title: 9 More Adhesives In Sprays Banned By Safety Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP)  The Consumer Product Safety Commission, prompted by concern over possible genetic damage and birth defects, banned nine more aerosol spray adhesives today.

title: Tokyo's Twin Move Tightens Credit
description: TOKYO, Aug. 28 (Reuters)Japan further tightened credit today by raising the official discount rate and bank reserve requirement ratios.

title: I.L.G.W.U. BACKS DEMOCRATS HERE
description: The International Ladies Garment Workers Union, once the major political force in the Liberal party in New York City, endorsed the threecandidate citywide Democratic ticket yesterday and promised to raise in excess of $50,000 for the campaign.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: HADASSAH WORKS FOR SOVIET JEWS
description: DENVER, Aug. 28The ruling body of Hadassah, the women's Zionist organization of America, citing the worsening plight of 100,000 Russian Jews who have applied for emigration visas, appealed to the Nixon Administration today to use its influence with the Soviet authorities to expedite the granting of these exit permits.

title: People in Sports: Lee Also Admits to Spitter
description: Another American League pitcher joined the spitball confessional line Monday behind Jim Merritt of the Texas Rangers. A Boston Red Sox pitcher, Bill Lee, boldly declared that he, too, had thrown spitballs and said that if the American League president, Joe Cronin, was going to issue fines for spitballs, he should fine everyone who threw them.

title: Avalanche of Masonry Pelted Train, Riders Say
description: To passengers at the front of the IRT Flushingbound train as it headed into the long downgrade for the trip under the East River yesterday afternoon, the sudden collapse of the tunnel masonry seemed like an avalanche hitting their car.

title: NoCrunch Insurance
description: Skyrocketing interest rates pose a serious threat the nation's thrift institutionsthe mutual savings banks and the savings and loan associationswhich have the bulk of their assets tied up in longterm residential mortgages.

title: Keep em Moving
description: The initial zeal shown by the city's new civilian traffic control agents offers encouraging promise of a return the good old days when traffic cops monitored their intersections with energy and determination. Not for many years, since the Police Department allowed that useful directorial skill to atrophy, have nimble feet and whitegloved hands been so tireless in spurring on wayward vehicles or bringing them to a nonobstructive halt. Even the keep em moving whistle has been resurrected.

title: Stockholm Police Seize 2 in Vault, Free 4 Hostages
description: STOCKHOLM, Wednesday, Aug. 29  On the evening of the sixth day of their imprisonmeet in a bank vault, the four hostages of a gunman and hisl companion were freed withoutl injury last night, and theirl captors surrendered meekly.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: GREEN BAY, Wis. Aug. 28 (AP)Ray Nitschke fighting tears not nearly so well as he fought National Football League blockers for 15 years, announced today his retirement from the Green Bay Packers and insisted he had only one regret. I have no complaints and no hard feelings. I'm just glad to have been a Packer,: the farmer allpro middle linebacker told the long anticipated news conference held at the club's Lambeau Field Office. The only regret I have is that I can't turn the clock back to 1958 and become a Packer all over again, said Nitschke, his eyes moist and his voice wavering.

title: Namath Sues Magazine, Demanding $2.2Million
description: Joe Namath has sued Sports Illustrated for $2.2million, charging that the magazine maligned him and deprived him of income.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The office of Maurice H. Nadjari, New York State's special prosecutor, announced the indictments of seven present and former New York policemen  including five sergeants  in an investigation that is seeking to determine the extent of payoffs by city contractors.

title: 98 Heat Record for Year; City Power Usage at Peak
description: New York sweltered through its hottest day of the year yesterday, and the city consumed more electricity than ever before although Consolidated Edison was forced to cut the voltage by 5 per cent.

title: State, County and City Lobbyists Form Coalition to End Isolation in the White House
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28Gov. Daniel J. Evans of Washington announced today a coalition of state, county and city lobbyists to promote budgetary reform in Congress and to try to reverse what he called the deeper and deeper isolation of the Nixon Administration.

title: BEATRICE FOODS BUYS SAMSONITE
Nixon and the Press: The Rift Is Reopened
description: LAGUNA BEACH, Cal., Aug. 28This afternoon, wire service reporters began staking out President Nixon's home in San Clemente to be on hand in the event the President should decide to go to the beach or take a drive on the Freeway, as he frequently does.

title: Notes on People
description: Lady Fleming, the Greekborn widow of Sir Alexander Fleming, codiscoverer of penicillin, was refused entry to Greece on the ground that she was an undesirable alien. Lady Fleming, whose maiden name was Amalia Coutsouris, was deported and stripped of her Greek citizenship 21 months ago after she was convicted for a role in an attempt to free Alexandras Panagoulis, who had attempted to kill the Greek leader, George Papadopoulos. The recently granted amnesty for political offenders in Greece applied to her conviction, but not to her citizenship. Government officials in Athens placed her on a plane returning to London.

title: Berna Hanover Wins
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 29 (UPI)Berna Hanover closed fast to win the 14th edition of the $31,565 Proximity Trot for 2yearold fillies tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. Berna Hanover, driven by Bill Herman, stepped the mile in 2:07 15 to win by three lengths over Devona Hanover. There was no betting.

title: 2,000 Find It a Great Night for Dancing in the Park
description: On a stifling hot night when breathing, let alone dancing, seemed an effort, nearly 2,000 New Yorkers turned out last night to box step and fox trot at a free concert by Peter Duchin and his orchestra at Damrosch Park in Lincoln Center.

title: Ryan Allows One Hit, Fans 10 and Beats Yanks, 50
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Aug. 29 Nolan Ryan, enroute to one of the most remarkable strikeout records in baseball history, fanned 10 Yankees tonight as he pitched a onehitter for the California Angels in a 50 victory. It was New York's eighth consecutive defeat and ended their Western trip with a 29 wonlost record.

title: Iran Advance Party Arrives In Saigon to Join Truce Unit
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 29 (Reuters)Iran's participation in the Vietnam ceasefire commission began today with a small advance party of officers slipping quietly through a side entrance of Tan. Son Nhut Airport.

title: Power in Peking
description: At the ninth Chinese Communist Party Congress in 1969, Lin Piao was officially designated as future successor of Mao Tsetung. At the party's tenth Congress, held secretly in the last few days, Lin was expelled from the party and denounced as a bourgeois careerist, conspirator, counterrevolutionary doubledealer, renegade and traitor. No reference was made to earlier private

title: President Will Return To Capital Tomorrow
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 29 (AP)  President Nixon will return to Washington on Friday after a 12day California stay, the White House announced today.

title: Food Prices Fall Here for Second Week
description: Food prices dropped sharply in the city last week, the second decline in two weeks, the Consumer Affairs Department reported yesterday.

title: Clifford deRoode, Pilot In the Lafayette Escadrille
description: NASHVILLE., Aug. 29Clifford Holger deRoode, a member of the Lafayette Escadrille, the American manned fighter squadron that was organized in France and flew to fame there during World War I, died Saturday. He was 86 years old.

title: FOREIGN BANK CURB DEFEATED ON COAST
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 29, (AP)An effort to stem the success of foreign banks in California  primarily from Japan and Canada  has been defeated in the Legislature.

title: Phil Regan, Retired Singer, Is Sentenced for Bribery
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Aug, 29 (AP)  Phil Regan, a retired singer and actor, was sentenced today to an indefinite prison term on two counts of bribing a county supervisor. He could serve a maximum of, 14 years.

title: Sadat and Qaddafi Act on Unification
description: CAIRO, Aug. 29President Anwar elSadat of Egypt and the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar elQaddafi, tonight proclaimed the birth of a new unified Arab state but made it emphatically clear that actual unification of their two countries was still a long way off.

title: Books of The Times
description: TRAVELERS. By Ruth Prawer Jhabvala. 247 pages. Harper & Row. $6.95,

title: 180,000 Hit by Blackout In Four Areas of Queens
description: About 180,000 Queens residents were left without electrical power last night when a group of Consolidated Edison Company cables burned out at 3:15 P.M. The blackout, the first major power failure of the summer, also darkened passenger terminals and hangars at La Guardia Airport.

title: The Making of Myths
description: Theodore H. White is so awesomely diligent a reporter, so accomplished political analyst, so engaging a person that criticizing him seems like sacrilege. But someone did eventually say that the emperor had no clothes, and it is time for someone to say that White has written a bad book.

title: Ohio Man Seized for Threat
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 28 (AP)A Cleveland man was arrested by the Federal Bureau of InvesLigation today on a charge or threatening to kill President Nixon officials said. The man, identified as Henry J. Taylor, 37 years old, was said to have called the Cleveland office of the F.B.I. last. Saturday and said he was going to kill the President.

title: APPEAL UNCERTAIN
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug, 29The White House said today that President Nixon would not comply with Judge John J. Sirica's order to turn over his Watergate tape recordings to the court.

title: Suspect Indicted in Sexual Abuse of Boy
description: A 30yearold man was in Idicted by a grand jury in the Bronx yesterday on charges of sexually abusing a 5yearold boy in a park there last week.

title: APPEAL UNCERTAIN
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. I29The White House said today that President Nixon would not comply with Judge John J. Sirica's order to turn over his Watergate tape recordings to the court.

title: The Simple, Uncluttered Life
description: The prison bus started up the California coast in the darkness of an early morning April chill. By the time we reached Santa Barbara the sun was brilliant and bathing everything in Vitamin B or C or LSD  whatever the hell sunshine is. All day, along the highways and through small towns, we watched the people and places. A stray dog sniffing his way down sidewalk was the object of as much attention as a girl in a tight dress. Convicts are usually attracted to animals and children. Maybe it's because they respond to him without demanding explanations. They trust him, welcome him, depend on him; the convicts in turn discovering a feeling of wholeness and a sense of unity. Some creature needs them; be it a child, a puppy, or a goldfish. They are loved.

title: China Hails Good News With Drums
description: PEKING, Aug. 29 (AgenceFrancePresse) Residents of Peking were out in the strets tonight hailing the announcement of the 10th party Congress with gongs, drums and tambourines.

title: LONG BEACH PLANS RENTCONTROL LAW
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 29Long Beach city officials said today they intended to enact local rentstabilization legislation that would basically prohibit rent increases in excess of any increases in the Consumer Price Index.

title: Bridge:
description: Any attempt to select the best American bridge player, past or present, would be foolhardy. A poll of experts would produce support, in varying degree, for some 20 names. The best objective measure is perhaps performance in the three major national team championships, and when these are tabulated one name emerges in sharp focus: George Rapee of New York.

title: Nadjari Studying Charge Of Plan to Bribe a Justice
description: Special Prosecutor Maurice H. Nadjari's office disclosed yesterday that it was investigating an alleged conspiracy to pay a $50,000 bribe to a State Supreme Court justice.

title: ADM. ANDERSON, 66, FOUGHT IN PACIFIC
description: ARLINGTON, Va., Aug. 29 (AP)Rear Adm. Paul R. AnIderson, who participated in eight major battles in the Pacific in World War II, died Monday of a heart attack. He was 66 years old.

title: A Motorist Drives Calmly To Death in Niagara River
description: TONAWANDA, N. Y., Aug. 29 (AP)  Maureen Hartman smiled, waved to bystanders and calmly smoked a cigarette, the police said today, as her automobile slowly sank in 25 feet of water in the Niagara River last night.

title: HEATH CONCLUDES ULSTER MEETINGS
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 29  After two days of grueling, occasionally heated talks with leaders here, Prime Minister Heath went before the press to express a British sense of frustration with Northern Irish politics.

title: Flood in Pakistan Crests Near Two Cities
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 29 Pakistan's worst flood crested tonight near the southern cities of Hyderabad and Kotri, amid signs that waters were ebbing elsewhere across the stricken country.

title: Fishermen Continue Strike
description: NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Aug. 29 (AP)Union fishermen voted today to continue their eightweek strike against boat owners. About a third of the New Bedford Fishermen's Union members voted 124 to 105 to reject the latest offer from Boat Owners United and Seafood Producers Association. No details of the proposed pact were released.

title: GAIN IS REPORTED IN HEREDITY STUDY
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 29 (AP)Further progress was reported today toward creation of an artificial gene that can function in a living cell.

title: MRS. SAMUEL A. LEWIS
description: WALPOLE, N.H. Aug. 29Ada Sidford Lewis, wife of Samuel A. Lewis, president of the Robertson Paper Company, Bellows Falls, Vt., and of the North End Paper Company, Fulton, N.Y., died last night at her home here. She was 65 years old.

title: About the Yankees:
description: Thurman Munson, who hit his 17th homer Tuesday night in Anaheim, feels he would be having a real good year if the contours of Yankee Stadium weren't the handicap they are to righthanded hitters. Since he is hitting 308 and has 63 runs batted in, while doing a firstrate iob as a catcher, one could say he's having a real good year anyhow. Bobby Murcer is rolling along, too, with two hits Tuesday raising his average to .315. He has 82 runs batted in, and 19 homers. . . But I told em I wasn't a homerun hitter, earlier this year, and I guess I've proved that, he says, referring to his homerun totalwhich nevertheless leads the club.

title: Music: Mixed Mozart
description: Given the many difficulties involved in producing Mozart's The Abduction From the Seraglio, it must he said that the New York Lyric Opera managed pretty well in most respects with its presentation of the work at the Universalist Church, Central Park West at 76th Street.

title: In the Name of Security
description: I escaped from South Africa in 1971 and arrived in Washington as a guest of American law groups. As a lawyer practicing in South Africa, I had exposed many injustices of the white minority Government. When, for example, I demonstrated that black petty offenders were arrested and not tried in court but sold as cheap labor to white farmers, the law was altered to permit the scheme to continue in a new form.

title: ROSS W. BARRY
description: EAST ISLIP, L. I., Aug. 29Ross W. Barry, partner in the architectural firm of Biuso & Barry in Greenvale, died Tuesday from injuries suffered in a fall at his summer home in Denver, N. Y., while on the way to a hospital. He was 39 years old and lived at 54 Simmons Drive.

title: Peace With Hunger
description: The peace accord achieved by India, Pakistan and Bangladesh atter more than fourteen months of onandoft negotiations represents a triumph of pragmatism over passion in a region where the seeds of emotional conflict are as bitter and deeply rooted as anywhere on earth.

title: The Soviet Dissidents
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 29The sudden upsurge in news of dissidence from Moscow has brought into sharp focus the Soviet leaders determination to pursue their policy of improved relations with the West without giving an inch to domestic pressures for liberal reforms.

title: 5 Diverse Groups Urge Action To Counter Censorship of TV
The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was: 84752
description: Tickets matching the number win 12,500. Tickets, with the five numbers reverse win $225. Tickets with the first or last four numbers in order win 5225. Tickets with the first, middle or last three numbers in sequence win 525, Tickets with all five numbers scrambled win $25. Tickets matching the first and second digits, the second and third, the third end fourth or the fourth and fifth win $2.50.

title: Roundup: Bailey's Two Clutch Hits Help Expos Down Dodgers, 6 to 5
description: Bob Bailey has a lifetime batting average of 253, not bad but not too good either. Yet the seasoned third basemanoutfielder of the Montreal Expos has a habit of delivering the clutch hit when most needed.

title: National League
Publishers Buoyed by Fall Book Crop
description: For 60 years the cash registers were banished to the sidelines of the Scribner family's genteel book emporium on Fifth Avenue. But now they have been lugged out into the center of the baronial salesroom, and Charles Scribner Jr., the head of the family, happily told a recent visitor that the change was a good augury for the fall book season; it puts an emphasis on cash.

title: Peron Meets With Leftists
description: BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Aug. 29 (UPI)Former President Juan Peron met last night with two guerrilla leaders hours after he was criticized by leftist supporters for not consulting underground fighters.

title: Board Members Cleared Of Conflicts on Schools
description: The city's Board of Ethics ruled yesterday that the three members of the cental Board of Education whose wives are teachers in the school system were not, as a result of this situation, in violation of the city's Code of Ethics.

title: Wide Price Swings Hit Livestock Market
description: The nation's major livestock markets were scenes of uncommonly volatile trading yesterday, while in the grain and soybean markets, new buying appeared and ended a weeklong slump in prices.

title: About the Mets:
description: John Milner, who has had a sore shoulder, is being carefully nursed for the late drive that Yogi Berra hopes will get his club out of the cellar. The manager said he probably would start the lefthanded Milner at first base tonight against St. Louis, since the Cardinals pitching rotation is made up of righthanders. . . Tom Seaver, George Stone and Jon Matlack are scheduled to be the Met starters in the fourgame series against the Cards. . . Before last night's game, the Mets pitching staff led the National League in strikeouts with 799. Los Angeles was second with 766 and Houston third with 752.

title: F.B.I. INVESTIGATING ASSOCIATE OF SCOTT
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29 (AP).Justice Department officials confirmed today that and associate of Senator Hugh Scott, Republican of Pennsylvania, was being investigated, in the award of a $46million, Federal lease.

title: Mrs. Larr Gets Sailing Trophy For Third Time
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 29The SeawanhakaCorinthian Yacht Club crew of Oyster Bay, L. I., captained by Mrs. David Larr, won the women's North American sailing championship today. By placing second and fourth in light wind in the final two Soling Class races on Long Island Sound off the Indian Harbor Y. C., Mrs. Larr finished the eightrace series with 511/2 points to win by 7 points.

title: Schlitz Will Build Brewery On 193Acre Upstate Site
description: What is described as the largest. brewery ever built at one time will be constructed by the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company on a 193acre site 12 miles northwest of Syracuse, N. Y. Robert A. Uihlein Jr., chairman and president of Schlitz, said yesterday that the plant would have a production capacity of 5.8 million barrels a year.

title: Day the Sun Rose,' Kyoto Drama
description: "The Day the Sun Rose" is an anti-samurai drama dealing with class struggle in 16th-century Japan. Beset on the one hand by poor rioting farmers, and on the other by rich overlords and their treacherous samurai retainers, the merchants and artisans of Kyoto scarcely know where to turn. Where to turn happens to be to the side of the poor rioting farmers, aided by the rice-carrying mounted coolies (led by Toshiro Mifune). Once united, the poor and the middle classes are invincibleaided by the mounted cooliesand despite overwhelming opposition, they are able to reinstate the Gion Festival, expressing in music and pageantry the people's aspirations.A romantic subplot accompanies the march of public events. The plot shows how young Shinkichi (Kinnosuke Nakamura), a dyer by trade and leader of the Kyoto artisans, learns from Ayame, a beautiful flutist, how to play the Gion Festival music. Without the music there can be no festival. Shinkichi and Ayame fall in love.The daughter of an outcast gardener, Ayame compensates for her bitter and humble lot by affecting a new and ever more dazzling change of kimonos for every scene in which she appears. It isn't enough. Not content with her kimonos, her musical talent or even with Shinkichi, she needs reassurance:"You think I'm beautiful?""Yes.""You know nothing about me, so you think I'm beautiful." (They have been kissing ardently for some time.) "If you really knew me you'd think that I was ugly . . ."This is all in subtitles, of course. But it doesn't read like a Japanese movie. It reads like a West Side psychodrama, or like Elaine May celebrating the triumph of rejection fantasies over the wish for success in inter-personal relations."The Day the Sun Rose" opened yesterday at the Bijou.

title: A HISTORIC RULING
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29President Nixon was ordered today by Judge John J. Sirica to make tape recordings of White House conversations involving the Watergate case available to him for a decision on their use by a grand jury.

title: PRICES ON AMEX SHOW ADVANCES
Arthur Daley
description: If it was designed as a dress rehearsal to prove that Moscow would be the ideal site for the 1980 Olympic Games, the Soviet fumbled the ball during the recent World University Games in Lenin Stadium. The Israeli delegation was greeted with derisive whistles during the opening ceremonies, Soviet Jews were supposedly barred and manhandled outside a basketball arena and a brawl was precipitated by Cuban basketball players when they attacked their American conquerors. None of this is recommended as a way of winning friends and influencing people.

title: Equity Financing
description: An offering of 700,000 common shares of Vetco Offshore Industries, Inc., at $25.625 a share was made yesterday by underwriters headed by Merrill Lynch. The company's stock closed at 257/8, up 5/8 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Grivas Rejects Call By Greece's Chief To Give Up Fight
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 29 (Reuters)Gen. George Grivas, the Cypriote underground leader, tonight rejected a Greek Government call for him to give up his armed struggle in cyprus.

title: First Chicago in an Accord To Buy American Finance
description: The First Chicago Corporation, parent of the First National Bank of Chicago, announced yesterday a preliminary agreement to acquire the American Finance System, a consumer loan company based in Washington, D. C., in a share exchange involving $95million. The terms of the agreement call for First Chicago to issue one share of a new voting convertible preferred, with a stated value of 110 a share, in exchange for five shares of American Finance common stock. The new stock will have an annual divilend rate of $7 a share.

title: 18% RISE FOR H.I.P. SUPPORTED BY CITY
description: The city has agreed to an 18 per cent increase in rates requested by the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York for the 300,000 municipal employes and their dependents covered by the plan. There will be no increase in the cost for those at least 65 years old.

title: Hostels for Retarded Grow
description: ALBANY, Aug. 29 (AP)The opening of three more hostels has brought the state capacity for caring for mentally retarded people in a community environment to 325 people, the State Mental Hygiene Department said.

title: Hadassah Raises $22.3Million For Projects in Israel and U.S.
description: DENVER, Aug. 29Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, today reported the raising of $22.3million this yearthe largest sum raised in its 61 year historyto maintain and enlarge its network of medical and social services in Israel and to carry out projects in the United States.

title: Decision to Allow the Blackout Forestalled Major Breakdown
description: It was shortly after 6:20 P.M. yesterday when officials at Consolidated Edison faced decision: whether to continue to furnish power on a crippled system of feeder lines in Queens or cut power off to 50,000 customers and avert a breakdown that could have been a nightmare to repair.

title: Adams Faces Surgery
description: HIRAM, Ohio, Aug. 29 (AP)  Pete Adams, a rookie guard with the Cleveland Browns, was rushed to a hospital today after he suffered what a club spokesman said was an attack of acute appendicitis.

title: About the Mets:
description: John Milner, who has had a sore shoulder, is being carefully nursed for the late drive that Yogi Berra hopes will get his club out of the cellar. The manager said he probably would start the lefthanded Milner at first base tonight against St. Louis, since the Cardinals pitching rotation is made up of righthanders. . . . Tom Seaver, George Stone and Jon Matlack are scheduled to be the Met starters in the fourgame series against the Cards. . . Before last night's game, the Mets pitching staff led the National League in strikeouts with 799. Los Angeles was second with 766 and Houston third with 752.

title: DR. S. RAINS WALLACE OF OHIO STATE DEAD
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio; Aug. 29 Dr. S. Rains Wallace, chairman of the psychology department at Ohio State University, died of cancer yesterday in Riverside Hospital. He was 59 years old.

title: Clark Moves Ahead In Mallory Cup Sail
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 29 (AP)  Dennis Clark of Seattle inched into the lead of the Mallory Cup competition today in the North American sailing championships.

title: Golf Results
description: AT INWOOD, L.I. WOMEN'S M.C.A. SCOTCH FOURSOMES

title: Judge Sirica's Order
description: This matter having come before the court on motion of the Watergate special prosecutor made on behalf the June, 1972, grand jury of this district for an order show cause, and the court being advised in the premises, it is by the court this 29th of August, 1973, for the reasons stated in the attached opinion,

title: Danger Underground
description: Going home from work on the city's subways is daily ordeal even under normal summer conditions of sweltering heat in illventilated tunnels and overcrowded cars. Any mishap, and particularly any accident involving fire and smoke, quickly turns this poorly maintained transportation system into a terrifying trap for thousands of helpless passengers.

title: PEKING ANNOUNCES 5DAY CONGRESS OF CHINESE PARTY
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 29 China disclosed today that the 10th Congress of her Communist party was held in Peking last Friday through yesterday.

title: LABORER IN CUSTODY AS MURDER SUSPECT
description: Wilfredo Sostre, a 38yearold construction worker with no known address, was taken into custody yesterday as suspect in two recent murders in Brooklyn.

title: TRUCKERS IN CHILE OPEN PEACE TALKS
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 29 (UPI)  Striking truckers, facing an ultimatum by President Salvador Allende Gossens today opened another round of negotiations with the Government in efforts to end their 35day walkout.

title: Five European Newsmen Return From Vietcong Zone
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 29 (Reuters)Five European newsmen returned from Vietcong zone north of Saigon in good health today after spending a week watching the life and activities of the Vietnamese Communists.

title: City Will Ask Chief Judge Fuld Today to Extend Council Redistricting Deadline to Sept.
description: The city's Corporation Counsel will ask Chief Judge Stanley H. Fuld of the Court of Appeals today to extend from this Saturday to Sept. 17 the deadline set by the highest state court for the City Council to redistrict its boundaries in acceptable fashion.

title: FISCHER TO GIVE CHESS EXHIBITIONS
description: Bobby Fischer, chess,champion of the world, is planning a series of exhibition and simultaneous matches in Europe early next year, and may even have a return match with Boris Spassky. Plans along those lines are currently being worked out, Stanley Rader, Fischer's attorney, said yesterday in Los Angeles.

title: Melissa Downey Bride of John Loesser
description: Miss Melissa Ellen Downey was married here yesterday afternoon to John Loesser, son of Mrs. Lynn Loesser of New York and the late Frank Loesser, the composerlyricist. The bride is the daughter of Sean Morton Downey of Washington and Mrs. James Philip of New York and East Hampton, L. L, and is a granddaughter of Morton Downey, the CocaCola executive and former singer.

title: CHARLES R. GEVERTZ
description: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 29Charles IL Gevertz, founder of a chain of men's apparel shops in Texas and Hawaii, died yesterday in White Plains Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived here.

title: 5 Diverse Groups Urge Action To Counter Censorship of TV
description: The country's television statians, advertisers and public interest organizations were called on yesterday to exert counterpressure against censorship of television dramatizations.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Aug. 29 (AP)Four Polish team cyclists pedaled 61 miles through heat and hilly terrain in just over two hours today for a goldmedal upset victory over the Soviet Union in the first road race of the world cycling championships. Avenging their loss to the Russians at the Munich Olympics, the Poles completed four laps about 15 miles each on the GranoIlersSan Celoni road outside Barcelona in 2 hours 3 minutes 29 seconds, averaging 30 miles an hour.

title: Berlinger Demands List of Relief Clients Living in City Hotels
description: George F. Berlinger, the state's Welfare Inspector General, yesterday demanded a complete list of families living on welfare in New York City hotels, challenging a statement by the city's Commissioner of Social Services, Jule M. Sugarman, that only 12 such families were living in hotels.

title: Uncle Who Aided Derby Winner Charged With Corrupting Minor
description: BOULDER, Colo., Aug. 29 (UPI)A businessman who admitted helping his nephew cheat to win the National Soapbox Derby was charged in juvenile court today with contributing to the delinquency of a minor. No charges were brought against the boy.

title: 3 More Reform Democrats Back Fuchsberg for Judge
description: Three prominent Democrats identified with the reform wing of the party yesterday endorsed the candidacy of Jacob D. Fuchsberg for chief judge of the State Court of Appeals.

title: AGNEW'S SUPPORT IN G.O.P. FOUND OFF
description: Republican voter support for Vice President Agnew for the party's Presidential nomination in 1976 has fallen sharply in the wake of disclosures that Mr. Agnew is the target of Federal investigation, the Gallup Poll said yesterday.

title: Judge Rejects Motions to Block MitchellStans Trial
description: Defense motions to block the trial of John N. Mitchell and Maurice H. Stans were rejected yesterday by Federal District Judge Lee B. Gagliardi.

title: HALDEMAN AMENDS HEARING TESTIMONY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29H. R. Haldeman, the former White House chief of staff, has amended, through one of his attorneys, his testimony before the Senate Watergate committee on how he received one of the tapes of conversations between President Nixon and John W. Dean 3d, dismissed White House counsel.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Since January of this year, saltwater anglers have been rushing to qualify their catches in the International Game. Fish Association's (I.G.F.A.) newly established sixpound line test class, with 43 of 70 worldrecordcatch applications falling in that category.

title: Minisubmarine Trapped In Ocean With 2 Britons
description: CORK, Ireland, Aug. 29 (AP)  A minisubmarine manned by two Britons was trapped today deep in the Atlantic Ocean about 150 miles southwest of this southwest Irish city, the vessel's owners reported.

title: MRS. A. M. McFARLANE
description: WELLFLEET, Mass., Aug. 29 Mrs. Florence Reed McFarlane, the wife of Alexander M. McFarlane, former board chairman of CPC International, Englewood Cliffs, N. J., died today in the New England Medical Center in Boston. She was 57 years old. She lived at 28 Waldo Lane, Manhasset, L. I., and had a summer home here.

title: Violations Are Alleged
description: LIMA, Peru, Aug. 29 (AP)President Juan Velasco Alvarado said today his military regime may use force to take over the Peruvian coppermining properties of the Cerro Corporation, a United States concern, if current negotiations to expropriate them fail.

title: Judge Sirica's Order
description: This matter having come before the court on motion of the Watergate special prosecutor made on behalf of the June, 1972, grand jury of this district for an order to show cause, and the court being advised in the premises, it is by the court this 29th of August, 1973, for the reasons stated in the attached opinion,

title: Opera: City. Company Opens Season
description: There wasn't too much of a problem about clothes at last night's opening performance of the New York City Opera's fall season. In this weather nobody was going to be wearing furs; that was for sure. A few men did defiantly put on black tie. Otherwise sports clothes were the rule.

title: R. D. Siragusa Weds Mrs. .Reibman
description: Mrs. Martha Peace Reibman of Chicago, widow of Samuel Reibman, was married in Rome on Tuesday to Ross D. Siragusa of Barrington, Ill., board chairman and founder of the Admiral Corporation. The ceremony was performed in a small chapel in the Basilica of St. Peter, Vatican City, by Bishop Paul C. Marcinkus, president of the Vatican Institute for Works of Religion, and attended by members of the immediate families.

title: U.S. Yacht Takes Heat in Regatta
description: PORTO CERVO, Sardinia, Aug. 29 (Reuters)The United States yacht Ganbare, skippered by Douglas Peterson, scored a comfortable victory in the first race of the oneton Yacht Cup Regatta here today.

title: Jersey Calls TV Lax
description: The New Jersey Coalition for Fair Broadcasting, a public interest group, accused New York television stations yesterday of failing to live up to agreements binding them to increase news and public affairs coverage in northern New Jersey, Details will be found on Page 37.

title: Lon Nol Asserts He Plans To Hold Reins and Fight
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Aug. 29In his first news conference in more than seven months, President Lon Nol presented himself today as determined to continue personal leadership of his country and to pursue the war to repel foreign aggression as long as necessary.

title: HARRY FLAUM
description: Harry Flaum, who spent more than 50 years in the New York City school system as a teacher and principal, died yesterday at his home in the Hotel Brewster, 21 West 86th Street. He was 83 years old.

title: American Arrested by F.B.I. Says He's a Zambian Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UPI) A United States citizen who identified himself as a top aide to the President of Zambia was held on $250,000 bond today on charges of being an unregistered foreign agent and possessing hugging devices.

title: TV: Thorough Checkup
description: Hospitals, Doctors and Patients, shown on the National Broadcasting Company network Tuesday evening, combined two separate halves into an unusually effective whole. The first part of the hour, produced by Lois Farfel Stark, examined the practice of defensive medicine. The second, produced by Patricia Creaghan, tackled the spiraling costs of hospitalization.

title: Task Force Headed by Chief Judge Urges an Overhaul of Family Court Here
description: A task force headed by the chief judge of the city's Family Court has recommended sweeping overhaul of many of the Family Court's operations, saying that neither the children nor the adults who come to the coign get adequate service or legal representation.

title: Hot Was Simpler on Summer Nights of Yore
description: To give a bit of cold comfort, it was just as hot in New York in an older day as it has been all this week.

title: Parents Arrested in Halt Of Insulin Supply to Son
description: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., Aug. 29 (UPI)The parents of an 11yearold boy who died when his insulin supply was cut off after a faith healing were charged today with manslaughter.

title: C.I.A. Is Reported Trying To Sell Interest in Airline
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 The Central Intelligence Agency is secretly trying to sell its controlling interest in a charter airline, Southern Air Transport, knowledgeable officials said today.

title: Court Backs Price Ceilings on Gasoline
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) An emergency appeals court gave the Nixon Administration the goahead today to impose price ceilings on retail sales of gasoline as scheduled on Setaday, if it wishes.

title: PEKING DISCLOSES 5DAY CONGRESS OF CHINESE PARTY
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 29 China disclosed today that the 10th Congress of her Communist party was held in Peking last Friday through yesterday.

title: Turnpike Rebuff May Cut Howard Johnson Empire
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Aug. 29 Howard Johnson's dominance of tollroad restaurant operations may be starting to wane with the announcement that the New Jersey Turnpike Auhority is terminating its 22year relationship with the chain.

title: Jersey Unit Acts to Force TV Stations to Cover State
description: NEWARK, Aug. 29  The New Jersey Coalition for Fair Broadcasting, a public interest group that includes some of, the state's governmental leaders, accu'sed New York television stations today of failing to live up to agreements binding them to increase news and public affairs coverage of northern New Jersey.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Eight beef wholesalers and processors in New Jersey were accused of having violated Federal beef price rules yesterday but overall compliance around the state has been good, the Internal Revenue Service said.

title: I CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The Bell Aerospace Company, a division of Textron Inc., received a $70.1million Air Force contract for Minuteman III missile motors, it was announced yesterday.

title: Chinese Emphasis on Duty Leaves Time for Romance
description: PEKING (Reuters)Though this is a land untouched by the attitudes and values of permissive society, The Pill is widely used in China.

title: Company Is Surprised
description: Alan Wolfley, executive vice president of the Cerro Corporation in New York, said that the report of the Peruvian Government's plans for a takeover the company's copper mines had come as a surprise.

title: LOAN CURBS EASED FOR THRIFT GROUPS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29The Federal Home Loan Bank Board, in another move to check the sharp decline in availability of mortgage money for home buyers, decided today to allow savings and loan associations to offer more large certificates of depositthose of $100,000 or more with no interest ceiling.

title: 20 Food Places Get 2d Citation by City On Health Violation
Murder Suspect Gives Up In Case of SchoolRing Clue
description: NEWARK, Aug. 29 A 29yearold narcotics user surrendered to the police here early today in a murder investigation that has involved the controversial mass fingerprinting of graduating pupils from a Newark elementary school.

title: Democrat Chief Says Watergate Won't Decide Governor Contest
description: NEWARK, Aug. 29The chairman of the Democratic Na. tional Committee today described the New Jersey gubernatorial contest as a very big race but warned that it would not he won on the basis of the tarnishing effects the Watergate scandal has had on the Nixon Administration.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: Tom Ulozas was 15 years old when he played his first round of golf, not an early age by professional standards, and his biggest prize as a New Jersey amateur was the Metuchen Golf and Country Club championship. Later, a club pro at Bamm Hollow in Lyncroft, he won the Dodge open and placed second in the New Jersey open.

title: Sadat and Qaddafi Act on Unification
description: CAIRO, Aug. 29President Anwar elSadat of Egypt and the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar elQaddafi, tonight proclaimed the birth of a new unified Arab state but made it emphatically clear that actual unification of their two countries was still a long way off.

title: Faulty Instruments Cited in Jet That Crashed in Fog in Boston;
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP)  A Delta Air Lines Jetliner that crashed into a seawall at Boston last month had a threemonth history of problems with its radio and flight instruments, the National Transportation Safety Board disclosed today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:No matter how many times I reread the letter of July 26 from Standard Oil of California to its employes and stockholders, I cannot find anything in it which justifies in any way the emotional criticisms of organized political Zionism and a few politicians. Undoubtedly, Kahlil Gibran's observation applies, We fight with greater fury to justify our wrongs than our rights.

title: Housing Dedicated To Evers's Memory In Bedford Section
description: If we use our heads, as Mcdgar Evers did, we will have housing, jobs, black political power and all the other things we need to function in this very complex society.

title: CREDITORS' LINKUP ON KOSCOT BID FAILS
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Aug. 29 (AP)A United States bankruptcy referee today abandoned attempts to form a creditors committee to negotiate settlement of $26million in debts filed against Koscot Interplane tary, Inc.

title: Versatility Is Boon To Jets Hammond
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 29Another Jet cut came today and Gary Hammond survived. He's still around, not because he is a wide receiver or punt return man or a quarterback, but because he can be all three, and Coach Weeb Ewbank likes having versatile players around.

title: Aide to Washington's Governor Posed as Student in Foe's Camp
description: OLYMPIA, Wash. Aug. 29 (UPI)An employe of Gov. Daniel J. Evans's reelection committee said today that he posed as a college student during last year's election campaign to travel with the Governor's Democratic opponent and secretly report on his campaign activities.

title: NIXONS LAYERS ASSAIL COMMITTEE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29  President Nixon's lawyers charged today that the Senate Watergate committee had conducted a criminal investigation and trial that exceeded the authority granted to Congress by the Constitution.

title: KOREA TALKS SEEN NEAR BREAKDOWN
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 29  The 11monthold political talks between the two Koreas were reported on the verge of breakdown today as the North repeated its demands that the present Southern negotiators be replaced.

title: Gods in Yemen Kill 30
description: BLIRUT, Lebanon, Aug 29 (Ap)Hash floods killed or injured More than 30 persons during the last few days in Yemen's Taiz region, the Middle East News Agency reported her In some places the water was more than 35 feet high and extended to eight miles, the agency said.

title: Film: The Stone Killer
Most Residents in Queens Take Blackout in Stride
description: Most people in the blacked but stretches of Queens took the darkness in stride last night. They gathered in parks to catch what breezes might be blowing or gravitated to isolated patches of brightness where emergency equipment was working or emergency lights were on.

title: Shoppers, Even in This Heat, Rush Preparations for Snow
description: The nearest snow reported last week was 5,300 miles away in the Chilean Andes, where American tourists, apparently oblivious of political turmoil, were enjoying excellent midwinter skiing 10,000 feet above sea level. But the frenzy, if not the exhilaration, was equally felt by skiers in midtown Manhattan who besieged the purveyors of skis, boots, poles, parkas and other essentials of the increasingly popular sport.

title: Nadjari Studying Charge Of Plan to Bribe a Justice
description: Special Prosecutor Maurice H. Nadjari's office disclosed yesterday that it was investigating an alleged conspiracy to pay a $50,000 bribe to a State Supreme Court justice.

title: Forage, $5.80, Takes Stymie By Half a Length at Belmont
description: Forage carried the silks of William Haggin Perry to victory in the Stymie Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. But the performance was completely different from the way Stymie used to run.

title: Britain to Build ShortHaul Jet
description: LONDON, Aug. 29The British Government announced today a $115million investment in a new shorthaul aircraft.

title: City Pollen Count Falls But the Allergic Suffer
description: Yesterday's pollen count in the city dropped from its allseason record on Tuesday but was still high enough to trouble hay fever sufferers.

title: Greece Beats U.S. Five
description: HAIFA, Israel, Aug. 29 (AP)  Greece beat Auburn University, 8172, today in an invitation basketball tournament. A combined squad of Americans from Western colleges beat Israel's national team, 8482, in another contest.

title: J. P. Stevens Profit Increases Sharply

description: How to make a poor mouth taste good (coat):

title: Text of Communique of 10th National Congress of the Communist Party of China
description: The 10th national Congress of the Communist party of China was held solemnly in Peking from Aug. 24 to 28. It was a Congress of unity, a Congress of victory and a Congress full of vigor.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was: 84752
description: Tickets matching the number win 12,500. Tickets, with the five numbers reverse win $225. Tickets with the first or last four numbers In order win 5225. Tickets with the first, middle or last three numbers in sequence win $25. Tickets with all five numbers scrambled win $25. Tickets matching the first and second digits, the second and third, the third and fourtror the fourth and fifth win $2,50.

title: Business Records
description: MAXWELL J. BROOKS, JR., salesnignager, 200 W. 76th St., N. Y. Liabilities, 523,645.97; assets, 5350.00.

title: P.S.C. Again Denies Phone Company Plea For Rate Increase
description: The Public Service Commission formally rejected yesterday for the second time a York Telephone Company plication for a temporary increase of $217million. commission examiner had posed the application in May.

title: Volkswagen Raising Pay At West German Plants
description: WOLFSBURG, West Germany, Aug 29, (Reuters) Volkswagen, Europe's biggest car manufacturer, today announced pay increases for its 120,060 workers in an apparent move to forestall wildcat strikes, which have stopped production at other automobile producers plants.

title: The Middle Ground
description: Chief Judge John J. Sirica has wisely chosen what he describes as the middle ground in deciding the legal issue of President Nixon's tape recordings in the Watergate case. Neither rejecting the President's claim executive privilege nor ordering the immediate delivery of the tapes to the grand jury, Judge Sirica has directed that they be turned over to him.

title: 9 Are Appointed by Governor As Economy Unit Is Activated
description: Acting Gov. Malcolm Wilson yesterday announced the activation of the temporary State Commission on Living Costs and the Economy with the appointment by the Governor of the nine members of the commission.

title: U.S. Tokyo Office Attacked
description: TOKYO, Aug. 29 (UPI)  A Japanese man broke into an annex of the United States Embassy today and threw a flaming bottle of gasoline, but a janitor extinguished the fire before there was any major damage, the police said. No one was injured. The annex is about 500 yards from the embassy.

title: GUGGENHEIM'S MUSIC DRAWS BIG AUDIENCE
description: Judging from the overflow audience that Chamber Music at the Guggenheim attracted to the museum's subterranean hall on Tuesday night, the brief summer festival of music and dance might easily bear expansion. Folding chairs had to be brought out to accommodate all who wanted to hear the second (and final) concert in the August series, presented by Ruth Laredo, piano: Jaime Laredo, violin; Michael Tree, viola, and Robert Sylvester, cello.

title: Israel Charges Payoffs to Arabs by Four Countries
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 29Four unidentified European governments were accused tonight of having concealed payments to Arab guerrilla organizations by their national air carriers to buy immunity from hijacking.

title: American League; Thursday, August 30. 1973; YESTERDAY'S GAMES; California 5, New York 0. Boston 8, Oakland 4 (twi.), Kansas City 3, Cleveland 2.; Milwaukee 9, Chicago 0. Detroit 9, Minnesota 5. Baltimore 6, Texas 1.; TUESDAY NIGHT; California 5, New York 2, Chicago 6, Milwaukee 4. Cleveland 4, Kansas City 3.; Minnesota 5, Detroit 0, Oakland 6, Boston 1.
