description: EXTREMES A kind of seethepoorasJ. P. Morgansawthem tour is one of the more piquant services available to the wellheeled New Yorker or tourist who likes his sightseeing limousined, and who has a spare $50 to shell out for five hours of New York.

title: Oil Slick Off Florida
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 28 (UPI)The Coast Guard reported today that an oil slick had been sighted in the Atlantic offshore from Neptune Beach east of here. A Coast Guard spokesman said the slick was about 500 yards long and 25 yards wide. He said it was sliding along the shoreline as it moved southward, depositing heavy oil along the beaches.

title: Jersey Rebuff Hurting Howard Johnson
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Aug. 29  Howard Johnson's dominance of tollroad restaurant operations may be starting to wane with the announcement that the New Jersey Turnpike Authority is terminating its 22year relationship with the chain.

title: 60 Pickets of Chavez Union Arrested in Clash on Strike
description: LIVINGSTON, Calif., Aug. 29 (UPI)Sixty picketing members of the United Farm Workers Union were arrested and several persons were injured today when the strikers and sheriff's deputies clashed at a Gallo Brothers vineyard.

title: Chess:
description: When I was 16, playing in my second Manhattan Chess Club Championship, the late Sidney Kenton, the tournament director, approached one of the established masters before the first round and asked how he thought the new generation would make out. The reply was loaded with encomiums on the talent displayed by us young lights, what a future we had, etc.

title: Union Aides Indicted
description: Peter Ottley, president of the 20,000member Local 144 of the Hotel, Hospital, Nursing Home and Allied Service Employes Union, and Peter Byrne, its secretarytreasurer, were indicted here yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of embezzling union funds. Page 44.

title: BADILLO ASSAILS BEANE LEAFLETS
description: Some of the BeameforMay or literature that was used the city's Democratic mayoral runoff was denounced yesterday as our own little Watergate by Representative Her man Badillo of the Bronxand was disavowed by Mr. Beame's son, Bernard, the campaign manager.

title: 5TH FRENCH ATEST IN PACIFIC REPORTED
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 29 (UPI)  The New Zealand and. Australian Governments said today they believed France had exploded the fifth nuclear device in her current series of tests in the South Pacific.

title: Suspect Pleads Insanity
description: TORRANCE, Calif., Aug. 29 (AP)William Ray Bonner, 25 years old, accused of an Easter Sunday shooting spree that left seven dead, has pleaded not guilty by reason of insanity. Superior Court Judge Bernard Lawler ordered a psychiatric examination yesterday and set a Nov. 11 trial date.

title: British Soccer
Monetary Disputes Forecast
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29United States officials say that they anticipate that next nonth's international financial conference in Nairobi, Kenya, may be punctuated by disputes between rich and poor nations over economic aid.

title: City Drive Carries Message to Addicts
description: Sweating in the muggy Harkm heat, Esit Richardson confronted one passerby after another on the corner of Eighth Avenue and 126th Street yesterday with a fistful of buttons that read,"DrugsOppressor of the People.

title: EXECUTIONS IN SYRIA FOR PLOT REPORTED
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Aug. 29 (AP)The Syrian secret police have secretly executed 42 army officers following an abortive attempt in July to assassinate President Hafez alAssad, foreign diplomats here report.

title: Agnew Panel Files Plea of Not Guilty
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Aug. 29A leader of the Salute to Ted Agnew Night committee, a Republican fundraising group indieted here for violations of Maryland election law, pleaded not guilty on behalf of the committee today. But the committee's attorney called the plea procedural and strongly indicated that it would be changed later to guilty.

title: U.S. Amateur Golf
AUTONOMY ASKED BY SAFETY BOARD
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 The National Transportation Safety Board, despite the Nixon Administration's opposition, has urged Congress to establish it as a completely independent agency.

title: MURDER SUSPECT IN JERSEY GIVES UP
description: NEWARK, Aug. 29 A 29yearold narcotics user surrendered to the police here early today in a murder investigation that has involved the controversial mass fingerprinting of graduating pupils from a Newark elementary school.

title: Mets Leave Cellar With 30 Victory
description: The New York Mets found themselves sitting on a lofty plateau last night as they finally climbed out of the Eastern Division cellar and into fifth place with a 30 victory over the San Diego Padres at Shea Stadium.

title: 7 Dead of Cholera In Naples
description: ROME, Aug. 29  A cholera outbreak in the Naples area and some suspect cases of severe gastrointestinal disorders elsewhere in Italy have touched off an infection scare.

title: BERTRAND WEAVER, PRIEST AND AUTHOR
description: UNION CITY, N. J., Aug. 29  The Rev. Bertrand Weaver, of St. Michael's Monastery here, died today in St. Mary's Hospital, Hoboken. He was 66 years old.

title: The Soviet Dissidents
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 29The sudden upsurge in news of dissidence from Moscow has brought into sharp focus the Soviet leaders determination to pursue their policy of improved relations with the West without giving an inch to domestic pressures for liberal re

title: Nastase, Smith, Ashe Win in Open
description: Even the losers were hot yesterday as the $227,000 United States Open tennis championships opened in temperatures that reached 94 degrees. Few tempers flared, however, as form and calm prevailed during the humid, sunny day at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens, with a crowd of about 11,000 on hand.

title: 180,000 Hit by Blackout In Four Areas of Queens
description: About 180,000 Queens residents were left without electrical power last night when a group of Consolidated Edison Company cables burned out at 6:15 P.M. The blackout, the first major power failure of the summer, also darkened passenger terminals and hangars at La Guardia Airport.

title: Mets Leave Cellar With 30 Victory
description: The New York Mets found themselves sitting on a lofty plateau last night as they finally climbed out of the Eastern Division cellar and into fifth place with a 30 victory over the San Diego Padres at Shea Stadium.

title: Accord on Teamsters Fund Reached by State Agency
description: The State of New York Insurance Department reported yesterday that a settlement by stipulation had been reached with the trustees of the Local 806 Teamsters Pension and Retirement Fund in a matter involving allegations of investment mismanagement.

title: TV: Thorough Checkup
description: Hospitals, Doctors and Patients, shown on the National Broadcasting Company network Tuesday evening, combined two separate halves into an unusually effective whole. The first part of the hour, produced by Lois Farfel Stark, examined the practice of defensive medicute. The second, produced by Patricia Creaghan, tackled the spiraling costs of hospitalization.

title: NIXON'S LAWYERS ASSAIL COMMITTEE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29  President Nixon's lawyers charged today that the Senate Watergate committee had conducted a criminal investigation and trial that exceeded the authority granted to Congress by the Constitution.

title: Kleindienst Requests Hearings Suspension
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 29 (UPI)Former U. S. Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst called today on Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr.'s committee to suspend its Watergate hearings.

title: Personal Finance
description: The use of trusts during lifetime and after constitute an important consideration in estate planning. The beginning of wisdom is to go to your local commercial bank and obtain a brochure about trusts before you seek your lawyer's help. Then you will know what a trust is, and the tax and other advantages, where available.

title: People in Sports: Umpire Breaks Tradition
description: In what might be seen as an exchange of traditional roles, Frank Umont, an American League umpire, apologized earlier this month to Al Worthington for the abusive language he directed toward the Minnesota Twins pitching coach during a game in Oakland.

title: Abbie Hoffman Is Held in $200,000 Bail on a CocaineSale Charge
description: Abbie Hoffman, the Chicago Seven defendant who friends said has withdrawn from radical politics into more personal expressions, was ordered held in $200,000 bail yesterday for allegedly selling three pounds of cocaine to undercover policemen.

title: BREEDING METHOD EMPLOYS NO SEED
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Aug. 29A sophisticated new technique has been devised that promises to allow scientists to breed and screen the equivalent of acres of plants at once in tiny laboratory disheswithout planting single seed.

title: 2 Officers of Hotel and Hospital Union Indicted for Embezzlement by U.S. Grand Jury Here
description: Peter Ottley, president of a union that represents 20,000 hotel and hospital maintenance and service employes in the metropolitan area, was indicted here yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of embezzling more than $186,000 in union funds.

title: Gold Is Up Sharply As Dollar Declines In Trading Abroad
description: LONDON, Aug. 29  The price of gold rose sharply while the value of the dollar fell on European money markets today.

title: judge Labored Over the Tapes Case
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29At 1 o'clock this morning, Judge. John J. Sirica couldn't sleep. He turned on the lights of his suburban Maryland home and took his pencil to the final draft of his opinion on the Presidential tapes and documents that the special Watergate prosecutor has subpoenaed.

title: One Nation Divisible
description: The merger of Egypt and Libya announced in Cairo yesterday falls far short of the instant union sought by Libya's zealous young leader, Col. Muammar elQaddafi.

title: Rookie Guard Is Having More Trouble Gaining Weight Than Making Giants
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., Aug. 29When the Giants began training here last month, Bart Buetow and the other 22 rookies sat together at a respectful distance from the regulars.

title: About the Jets:
description: Two holdouts, Emerson Boozer and Winston Hill, showed up with Jimmy Walsh, their lawyer, at the end the practice session and were scheduled to meet with Coach Weeb Ewbank. Earlier in the day, Ewbank said about their contract talks, I feel progress is being made, but negotiations have reached the critical stage if BoOzer and Hill are to be ready for the first game. . . . Ewbank was annoyed that Fred Burke, the lawyer for John Elliott, a starting defensive tackle, notified newspapers that negotiations had reached an impasse. It's another agent seeking publicity, said Ewbank. I have no trouble with agents who know what they are doing. I signed my No. 1 draft choice in two hours.

title: Report by Seoul on Kidnapping Worsens Breach With Tokyo
description: TOKYO, Aug. 29The diplomatic breach between Japan and South Korea widened today as the Seoul Government delivered to Tokyo what Japanese officials considered an unsatisfactory report on the abduction of a Korean opposition leader here three weeks ago.

title: Rain Adds to the Plight of Mexican Quake Victims
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 29 (AP)Torrential rains drenched rescue workers in some parts of southcentral Mexico today as they searched for victims of the earthquake that killed hundreds yesterday.

title: Campaigning Tips Given to Democrats: Stay Off Flowers
description: TRENTON, Aug. 29 (AP)Candidates should appeal to reason and logic when they address a welleducated audience, but a lesseducated crowd can be dealt with on an emotional and graphic level, according to the 1973 Democratic state party election manual.

title: Advertising: Korvettes Mayor
description: A fire engine speeds down a New York City street. When it stops, a short, portly man with a black Fedora jumps off a black Fedora umps off and starts speaking rapidly in a highpitched voice. And in his final words, he declaims, Us Little Guys Fight Back.

title: Coast Court Rules NoKnock Warrant Illegal in California
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Aug. 29 (AP)The state Supreme Court ruled yesterday that California judges could not issue noknock search warrants.

description: A 30yearold man was indicted by a grand jury in the Bronx on charges of sexually abusing a 5yearold boy in a park there last week.

title: El Nino
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29There is a warm and unwelcome current of water that flows down from the Equator past the coast of Peru every year around Christmastime that the fishermen call El Nifio De Navidad the Christmas Child. The warm current is unwelcome because it is bad for the fish.

title: Mrs. Larr Gets Sailing Trophy For Third Time
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 29The SeawanhakaCorinthian Yacht Club crew of Oyster Bay, L. I., captained by Mrs. David Larr, won the women's North American sailing championship today. By placing second and fourth in light wind in the final two Soling Class races on Long Island Sound off the Indian Harbor Y. C., Mrs. Larr finished the eightrace series with 51% points to win by 7 points.

description: Tickets may be obtained at the public desk, main lobby, United Nations Headquarters. Tours: 9 A.M. to 4:45 P.M.

title: Flirth 2Heat Victorin Hambletonian
description: DU QUOIN, Ill., Aug. 29The racetrack lobbyists finally sat back and watched today while the horses took over the harnessracing stage, with Flirth of Goshen, N.Y., winning the 48th Hambletonian in straight heats.

title: 81% OF COMPANIES NOT CUTTING PLANS
description: Some 81 per cent of the com panies surveyed this month by the National Association of Purchasing Management said they were not curtailing their investment plans, despite historically high interest rates.

description: COOPERSTOWN, N. Y., Aug. 29 (AP)  Sex as a bonafide occupational qualification will he the only excuse for newspaper classified advertising specifying male or female, Jack Sable, commissioner of the slate's Division of Human Rights, announced yesterday at a meeting of the New York State Newspaper Publishers Msociation. The ruling takes effect immediately, he said.

title: Cronkite Is First Winner Of Award by Press Club
description: Walter Cronkite will be the first recipient of the National Press Club of Washington's Fourth Estate Award for distinguished service to journalism. He will accept the award at blacktie dinner on Oct. 19.

title: Chicago Bank in Swiss Tie
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 29 (Reuters) The First National Bank of Chicago said today it had formed a Swiss company. First Chicago S.A., to comanage Swiss franc bond issues and broaden the bank's Eurobond trading activities.

title: Knee Exam for Spikes
description: CLEVELAND, Aug.29 (AP) The Cleveland Indians announced today that Charlie Spikes, rookie outfielder, would go to New York tomorrow to be examined by Dr. James Nicholas, a specialist in athletes knee problems. Spikes has been bothered for two weeks by an ailing right knee.

title: Cambodian Drives To Open Key Roads Are Stalled by Foe
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Aug. 29 (UPI)  Cambodian troops trying to reopen Phnom Penh's supply routes were thrown back today despite the use of fighterbombers, artillery and armored personnel carriers.

description: The bond market staged another sudden, selfinspired rally yesterday in which professional ctivity caused prices to be marked up by as much as a coint.

description: The Iceman Cometh to Prospect Park.

title: Text of Chief Judge Sirica's Opinion in Ordering the President to Submit Tapes
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29Following is the text of the opinion accompanying the order issued today by Chief Tudge John J. Sirica of Federal District Court that the President submit tapes and documents to the court:

title: 9 INDICTED HERE IN THEFT INQUIRY
description: The Manhattan District Attorney's office announced yesterday the indictment of nine members of an alleged forgery, fencing and robbery ring that disposed of thousands of stolen credit cards and traveler's checks sold to them by pimps and prostitutes, who had stolen them from outoftown businessmen and tourists.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29United States private and Government assets abroad rose substantially against last year but the rise in liabilities was greater, meaning drop in the net international investment position of the nation, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Agnew's Daughter Quits Brazil After Report of Threat
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29H Susan Agnew, 25yearold daughter of the Vice President cut short a, tour of duty on the hospital ship Hope earlier this week after the police apparently learned from informants of a threat against her life.

title: Samuel Ireland, 72, Dead; Founder of Coffee Concern
description: VENTNOR, N. J., Aug. 29 Samuel W. Ireland, who in l9E0 founded the Ireland Coffee Company, a wholesaler serving hotels and restaurants in the Delaware Valley, died Monday in Atlantic City Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived here.

title: Ellis Under Treatment
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 29 (UPI)Dock Ellis, the Pittsburgh Pirates pitcher, returned here from Cincinnati today for treatment of tendonitis in the right elbow and an inflamed left knee.

title: People and Business
description: George Weissman, 53, president of Philip Morris, Inc., since 1967, has been named to the new position of vice chairman of the board. A former public relations staffer with Ben Sonnenberg, Mr. Weissman joined Philip Morris in 1952 as assistant to the president and director of public relations. Joseph F. Cullman 3d continues as chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the company.

title: Waldheim Finds Talks Useful on Mideast Tour
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 29 (UPI)Secretary General Waldheim of the United Nations said today that he hoped his fivecountry tour to the Middle East will facilitate decisions we have to make about this complex and difficult problem.

title: HELD IN SWEDEN REPORTED IN SHOCK
description: STOCKHOLM, Aug. 29The two convicted robbers who held four hostages in a bank vault for more than five days were charged today on a number of counts. Other charges, possibly including rape, remain in abeyance.

title: Bronx Faces Loss of Its Paradise
description: The Paradise Theater, an ornate pseudoRenaissance Bronx landmark and one of the last of the city's great film palaces !from the movies golden age, is !slated to be remodeled into a twintheater complex by its owners, the Loews Corporation. The proposal, which still requires Federal Court approval, has brought from Bronx cultural and civic organizations expressions of dismay and demands to save the edifice.

title: VETERANS TRIAL NEARS JURY TODAY
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Aug. 29  As the case of the Gainesville Eight neared the jury, the Government released to the defense today 44 pages of documents concerning its star informer.

title: Indian Terms Timetable Of P.O.W. Shift Uncertain
Mets'
U.S. Sets Target Plan for Animal Feeds
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) The Agriculture Department announced today a program designed to increase 1974 harvests of livestock feed grains at least 6 per cent over this year's level.

title: AFRICANS VOTING IN A HOMELAND
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 29 (Reuters)An election in a northern area of SouthWest Africa began today as part of the South African Government's policy of separate development for different population groups in the disputed territory.

title: Laotian Leader Threatens To Quit Unless Pact is Set
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 29 (AP)Prince Souvanna Phouma threatened publicly today to resign as Premier of Laos unless his Government and the proCommunist Pathet Lao reach agreement on the country's political future.

title: XEROX, 2 OTHERS SUED ON JOB BIAS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug, 29The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission announced today that it had filed lawsuits alleging unlawful discrimina lion in hiring minorities against the Xerox Corporation and two other companies.

title: Soviet Dissident Linked at Trial To an Underground Publication
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 29One of two dissidents being tried on charges of subversion was reportedly linked in testimony today to the publication of an underground news bulletin that ceased to appear after his arrest.

title: 32 Federal Agencies Are Accused of Excluding Indians
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug 29 A coalition of native American organizations announced today that they had filed the first classaction civil rights cornplaint with the Justice Department's newly created Office of Indian Rights, charging 32 Fedieral agencies with employment discrimination,

title: '63 March in Retrospect: Many Strata of Meaning
description: A decade after the great march on Washington of Aug. 28, 1963, many of the nation's thinkers remain divided about what really took place that day.

title: U.S. MILITARY JET CRASHES
description: MADRID, Aug. 29 (AP)A United States military cargo jet plane with wives and children of American airmen among the 25 persons aboard crashed last night near Madrid, the United States Air Force said today. Only one crew member survived.

title: McIntire Ship Off Cape May
description: CAPE MAY, Aug. 29 (UPI)Dr. Carl Mclntire's pirate radio station, a converted mine sweeper, arrived off Cape May today and prepared to begin beaming the minister's gospel message. The pirate station is to replace his now defunct gospel station WXUR in Media, Pa., which was ordered closed by the Federal Communications Commission.

title: Practice Makes Charlie Perfect
description: A 1,500to1 shot came through at the Perkiomen Valley, Pa., obedience trial earlier this month when Charlie, a black miniature poodle, scored 200 points.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Police Asked to Cut Court Overtime

title: SAMUEL SMERLING
description: Samuel Smerling, president of the Stadler chain of men's shoe stores, died on Tuesday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 112 Central Park South.

title: Subway Accident Laid to Collapse of Duct Structure
description: The collapse of an archaic duct structure, the only one of its kind in the subway system, caused Tuesday's fatal accident in the East River Flushing line tunnel, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday.

title: Woman. 25. Found Slain In Riis Housing Project
description: A 25yearold woman was found dead of head injuries in her apartment in the Jacob Riis housing project on the Lower East Side yesterday afternoon. The police arrested a man they identified as a friend of hers who had had an argument with her earlier in the day.

title: RAILROAD STRIKERS MAY DEFY OTTAWA
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 29 (AP) Some of Canada's striking railroad workers are ready to defy a backtowork order from Parliament if they do not like the terms, according to union officials.

title: Shea Stadium an Island Of Light in Blackout
description: The lights went out around Shea Stadium tonight, airconditioners in an area covering 180,000 homes shut off, the video portion of the broadcast on local television went out, but the game between the San Diego Padres and New York Mets proceeded without interruption despite the power failure.

title: Group Accuses TV Stations of Violating A Pact for More Jersey News Coverage
description: NEWARK, Aug. 29  The New Jersey Coalition for Fair Broadcasting, a public interest group that includes some of the state's governmental leaders, accused New York television stations today of failing to live up to agreements binding them to increase news and public affairs coverage of northern New Jersey.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: RUTHERFORD, Aug. 30Friends told Nick Cutro year ago he was wrong for accepting an offer to become head coach of the Hartford (Conn.) Knights, a minor league professional football team.

title: It Is Still Rocky's Goal To Be the Man on the Run
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., Aug. 30Wearing track suit instead of a football uniform, Rocky Thompson of the Giants can rip off the 10 yards needed for a first down in the time it takes to say onethousandone.

title: POLICE IN CAMDEN HOLD 6 IN LOOTING
description: CAMDEN, Aug. 30A fight between north Camden youths and the police mushroomed into a fivehour looting spree that was put down early this morning by a barrage of tear gas.

title: STIFF SENTENCE URGED IN FRAUD
description: Federal prosecutors urged a District Judge here yesterday to deter whitecollar crimes by imposing substantial punishment on a business executive described as the leader of the largest criminal stock fraud ever prosecuted.

title: PARLIAMENT GETS CANADA RAIL ISSUE
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 30The Canadian Parliament convened today to legislate an end to a nationwide railroad strike, with the Government and the Opposition leaders all trying to make maximum political capital out of the special session.

title: Manufacturers Hanover Plans to Acquire Ritter
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, the holding company that owns the bank of the same name, announced yesterday it had reached a tentative agreement to acquire the Ritter Financial Corporation in a share exchange involving about $28.4million.

title: Trend Here Nearly Flat
description: I shop the budget departments these days because everything costs so much, said Mrs. Ethel Neucael.

title: A. I. GOLDBERG DEAD; A.P. CORRESPONDENT
description: RHINEBECK, N.Y., Aug. 30 (AP)  A. I. Goldberg, an Associated Press correspondent in Europe during and after World War II and later A.P. correspondent in Moscow, died today at the age of 69.

title: Opinion Remains Divided Over Effect of State's New Drug Law
New Jersey Briefs
description: Acceding to the ,demands of New Jersey commuters, the Interstate Commerce Commission has agreed to hold six public hearings in Jersey City and Newark in September on the Port Authority's application to increase fares on PATH tube trains. The authority wants to raise fares from 30 to 50 cents on the transHudson trains, used by 140,000 commuters daily.

title: Police Say Leading Seller Of Narcotics Is Seized Here
description: A man described by the police as a leading narcotics distributor was arrested yesterday in a raid on his Washington Heights apartment.

title: McIntire Unable to Get Pirate Radio Ship Going
description: CAPE MAY, Aug. 30The Rev. Carl McIntire went to sea in a boat called the Wild Goose today, but was frustrated in his first attempt to get his pirate radio station operating from a ship outside the threemile limit.

title: Natale Evola, Mafia Figure, Is Dead at 66
description: Natale Evola, who was listed by the Justice Department the boss of one of. New York five Mafia families, was ported dead of cancer yesterday by the police.

title: Thalia's Classic Era Slips Into Folklore
description: They would sit in the tiny movie theater, shaped like the prow of a ship, and watch Mary Astor, in The Maltese Falcon, tell the most brazen lies. Two hours later they would follow the sybaritic Clifton Webb as he menaced Laura with a shotgun.

title: World Swim Unit Expels South Africa
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 30  The International Swimming Federation (FINA) expelled today South Africa and Rhodesia from the first world swimming championships, which open here Saturday.

title: Boozer and Hill Agree to Terms
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 30 It was all over but the signing for Emerson Boozer and Winston Hill, who ended their holdouts and practiced with their New York Jet teammates for the first time in exactly three weeks.

title: Volkswagen Set to Recall 112,000 Karmann Ghias
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP)Volkswagen of America has agreed to recall an estimated 112,000 of its Karmann Ghias to correct possible gasoline or gasoline vapor leaks into the passenger compartment.

title: Schools in Indianapolis Get Desegregation Plan
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 30 (AP)  A Federal judge approved a desegregation plan today calling for reassignment of about 11,000 elementary school children this fall in the city's public school system.

title: ECONOMICS IS KEY IN POLLUTION SUIT
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 28A complex pollution trial under lway in Federal District Court here pits the Government, five environmental groups and Wisconsin, Michigan and Minnesota against the Reserve Mining Company and a number of Chambers of Commerce and small towns whose economies are inextricably linked to the company's mining operations.

title: Hughes Agreeable To Offer Testimony If Called by Court
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 30 (AP)Howard R. Hughes has given a sworn statement in a Federal District Court suit, saying he will be available to answer court questions under reasonable circumstances. But the billionaire industrialist added:

title: McCord College Lecture Tour Is Halted by Order of a Judge
description: NEW PALTZ, N.Y., Aug. 30 James W. McCord Jr., a convicted Watergate conspirator, ended his college lecture tour tonight after his second appearance.

title: DOLLAR SHOWS GAIN IN TRADING ABROAD
description: LONDON, Aug. 30 (UPI)The dollar reversed an early downward trend on European money markets today and closed the day fractionally higher. Gold prices declined.

title: Dr. Jennings Wins Men's Sailing Title
description: JACKSONSVILLE, Fla., Aug. 30 (AP)Dr. John Jennings of St. Petersburg, Fla., won his second North American men's sailing championship in four years today, with a second in the final race.

title: Mexico Counts Quake's Toll: 527 Dead and 4,000 Injured
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 30The Mexican Government announced today that the bodies of 527 people killed by the earthquake of early Tuesday had been recovered, but the final toll was still unknown.

title: Coast Guard Report Is Cool for a Hot Day
description: The United States Coast Guard picked the hottest week of the year to issue its annual report on icebergs.

title: Burger Blocks Bid T o End U.S. Curb On Housing Funds
description: WASHINGTON Aug. 30 (AP)Chief Justice Warren E. Berger permitted the Nixon Administration today to continue suspension of Federal subsidies for low housing.

title: JOB IN LOCAL LEFT BY FITZSIMMONS
description: DETROIT, Aug. 30 (UPI) The president of the International Brotherhood of teamsters. Frank E. Fitzsimmons, has resigned as vice president of Detroit Local 299 and was succeeded by his son, Richard.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Deadline Extended On Redistricting

title: 3 Major TV Stations Here Bar Ads on Frye's Watergate Album
description: New York's three major net. workaffiliated television staLions have refused to accept commercials for a new Watergate record album by David Frye, the comedian, even though two of the stations have broadcast Mr. Frye performing the same routines on talk shows, Buddah Records said yesterday.

title: USURY VIOLATIONS LAID TO FIRMS HERE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 30 (Reuters)A California official today threatened New York stockbrokers with suspension of their West Coast licenses because of alleged violations of usury laws.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Winning numbers drawn on Aug. 30 were:

title: Bodies of 24 Killed in Crash In Spain to Be Flown to U.S.
description: MADRID, Aug. 30 (AP)The bodies of 24 Americans killed in the crash of a United States Air Force cargo jet have been brought to the Torrejon air base to be flown to the United States.

title: I.C.C. Sets Sept. 11 Hearing On Pennsy Reorganization
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) The next stage of an Interstate Commerce Commission hearing on reorganization of the financially troubled Penn Central Railroad will begin Sept. 11.

title: Roundup: Phillies Surge In 9th and Top Expos, 87
description: Wednesday night in Montreal the Expos scored four runs in the ninth inning and beat the Dodgers. Last night in Philadelphia's Veterans Stadium, the Expos got a taste of their own medicine when the Phillies rallied for two runs in their last licks and won, 87.

title: DEAD FISH PUZZLE CITY AND STATE
description: The presence of hundreds and maybe thousands of dead fish  believed to be menhadenin waters in the New York City area is a puzzle to government agencies.

title: Reputed Mobster Denies Fleeing on Tax Charge
description: NEWARK, Aug. 30 (AP)Frank Cocchiaro, a reputed underworld leader, returned to New Jersey from Miami to face a Federal tax indictment today and said that charges that he was a fugitive were untrue.

title: Lockheed Unit Submits Plan To NASA on Space Shuttle
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 30 (UPI) The Lockheed Propulsion Company submitted to the National Aeronautics and Space Administration today a proposal to develop, manufacture and test large solid rocket boosters for the space shuttle vehicle at plants in Louisiana and Mississippi.

title: Man, 30, Knifed at Washington Sq.
description: A 30yearold man was stabbed and wounded critically early yesterday morning in Greenwich Village, where residents have been complaining about increased crime.

title: Questions and Answers on the Drug Law
description: The state's new drug abuse legislation goes into effect tomorrow, requiring the courts and prosecutors to take a far more stringent approach than at present in both the processing of drug cases and the sentencing of people convicted of drug crimes. Following are some questions and answers about the practical application of the laws. Like most laws, the drug legislation does not detail all possible applications and some answers are thus tentative.

title: Equity Financing
description: The Tokio Marine and Fire Insurance Company, Ltd., said yesterday it would be offering holders of its common stock and American depositary shares rights to subscribe to a total of 180,000,000 additional shares. Holders of American depositary shares will be offered one additional American depositary share for each 22/9 share held at a subscription price of $9.50. The offering is not underwritten.

title: Technicians Set Deadline For Strike Against N.B.C.
description: Edward Lynch, international president of the National Association of Broadcast Employes and Technicians, announced yesterday a strike deadline of 6 P.M. next Wednesday against the National Broadcasting Company.

title: REV. A. H. BRADFORD, YALE TRUSTEE, DEAD
description: PETERBOROUGH, N. H., Aug. 30The Rev. Arthur H. Bradford, a retired Congregational clergyman and former member of the Corporation of Yale University, died yesterday in the Peterborough Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived in Jaffrey.

title: The HardWon New Delhi Pact
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 30  Twenty months after the end of their war over Bangladesh, the Indians and the Paidstanis have finally sorted out a compromise involving three groups of political hostages. The settlement signed in New Delhi on Tuesday could mean a breakthrough in the tortuous relations between Bangladesh, India and Pakistan  or it could merely be an isolated interlude in a drama marked by hostility and suspicion.

title: Books of The Times
description: At the end of Richard Hughes's celebrated 1961 novel, The Fox in the Attic, his aristocratic young English hero is walking by the Danube in the winter of 1923. Hughes's image of the halffrozen river is a striking metaphor for the surreality of British and German society in the aftermath of World War I:

title: Cambodian Troops, AfterHardFighting, Open Key Highway
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Aug. 30Cambodian Govern. ment forces today reopened Route 5, Phnom Penh's overland link to the ricerich western province of Battambang, which Communist forces had closed a week ago.

title: People and Business
description: Al Lapin Jr., the 45yearold former pancake turner who in 1968 didn't hesitate to swap $100million in preferred stock of International Industries, Inc., for a corporate shell whose assets consisted solely of $62million in cash and marketable securities, resigned yesterday as president and chief executive officer of International Industries.

title: LOANS TO BUSINESS AT MG BANKS FALL
New Vietcong Drive To Cat Saigon Link With Delta Reported
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam. Aug. 30 (AP)Vietcong troops have increased attacks southwest of Saigon in a drive to isolate the Mekong delta and its rice from the South Vietnamese capital, military sources said today.

title: After 50 Years, Jazz Heads Back Uptown to West Side
description: When Fred Zeitler, who lives in the West Village, wants to hear Junior Mance, the jazz pianist, he could very easily drop in at Boomer's on Bleecker Street, where Mance frequently plays. But he prefers to go uptown to 97th Street and Columbus Avenue to hear Mance at Mikells, a spacious restaurant and bar with plants hanging in its big tront window.

title: Killer Gets Life Term
description: DETROIT, Aug. 30 (AP)The convicted killer of Alfred Glancy Jr., onetime partowner of the Empire State Building in New York, was sentenced to life imprisonment yesterday. Wayne County Circuit Court Judge Thomas Foley specified that Henry Reed Jr. serve the sentence at hard labor, in solitary confinement. He recommended that Reed never be paroled.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In your issue of Aug. 22, you published a dispatch from Moscow which cannot be too widely read. It covers words of warning from the eminent Russian physicist Andrei D. Sakharov in regard to the dangers implicit in dealing with the i Soviet Union.

title: Woman Buffeted on Jet Dies in Coast Hospital
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 30 (AP)  A 44yearold woman injured in the violent buffeting of a Boeing 70 jetliner on a flight to Los Angeles died today in a hospital, authorities said.

title: Atlantic City Aides And 25 Policemen Indicted for Graft
Charlie Daniels Shows Flair in Country Music
description: Charlie Daniels, who shared billing with Sha Na Na at the Schaefer Music Festival on Wednesday, proved he is much more than the country musician he might appear to he with his antiredneck opus, Uneasy Rider. Daniels, who opened with a song, has a tight electric band, very much into rock and highlighted by Daniels's deft fingering on various fretted instruments. He closed with breakaway Orange Blossom Special on fiddle. It was short act, should have been longer, but was potent.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HABIT For 42 years people have been strolling the Greenwich Village byways buying their masterpieces cheap, and, the sponsors of the Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibit say there is no reason to discourage the practice. Therefore, as regularly as it has, twice each year since 1931, the display. will blossom on Village fences, sidewalks, fire escapes and stoops beginning today at noon.

title: P.U.C. Grants a Rise of 3.25% In Rates to 2 Power Companies
description: NEWARK, Aug. 30  The Public Utilities Commission, in its first ruling since the Nixon Administration ended the 60day price freeze a little over two weeks ago, granted a 3.25 per cent rate increase today to the Jersey Central Power and Light Company and the New Jersey Central Power and Light Company.

title: Two in Nonsecurity Posts Were on Wiretapping List
description: WASHINGTON, Aug, 30The wiretapping of Government officials, which has been defended by President Nixon as necessary to prevent disclosure to the press of his secret foreign policy initiatives, was directed in part at two Administration officials whose jobs did not bring them in contact with such classified national security information, according to sources familiar with the operation.

title: A Traveler in Search of Food
description: FALMOUTH, Mass.  The land cruisers fume bumper to bumper past the neons on Route 28, and the vodkapowered yachts rock beam to beam along the inlets of Cape Cod. On what nourishment does this golden tide of tourists feed?

title: Court Gives Council More Time To Hold Hearings on Remapping
description: Chief Judge Stanley H. Fuld granted the City Council an extension yesterday of tomorrow's deadline for holding hearings to try to prepare an even better reapportionment bill than the one Mayor Lindsay vetoed.

title: Voter Registration Is Ordered Shifted Because of Succoth
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Brooklyn ordered the City Board of Elections yesterday to reschedule voter registration days in October to give persons observing the Jewish holiday of Succoth more time to register.

title: 14 LINES RECEIVE BUSES FROM STATE
description: TRENTON, Aug. 30 (AP) Nineteen new dieselpowered buses, the vaunted vanguard of 1,200 new or modernized buses an streets in New Jersey communities, were turned over to individual bus lines by the state today.

title: Novel, Praised in 1923 and Forgotten, Has New Day
description: A chain of coincidences, forged in part through a professor's good luck, has engendered a literary revival of Edith Summers Kelley, an American writer of the naturalist school, 50 years after the issuance of her only published novel.

title: Six Accused in French Crash
description: SOISSONS, France, Aug. 30 (AP)  Six railway officials were charged with manslaughter today in connection with railway accident in June, 1972, in which 108 persons were killed.

title: Humperdinck's Formula
description: Audiences for singers like Engelbert Humperdinck the world's most romantic singing star, intoned the offstage announcer  are a show in themselves. Humperdinck appeared in concert at Philharmonic Hall on Sunday. Faced with a declining market, more and more nightclub performers are gravitating to the concert stage.

title: Speed Is of the Essence
description: CASTILE, N. Y.This being the age of candid confessions, wherein everyone from war criminals to child molesters are purging themselves in print, I suppose I may as well step forward with my own admission; I am an unrepentant fast driver. I like nimble, wellengineered, highspeed automobiles, and I tend to drive them on open roads with considerable, skill and safety, at velocities often beyond the posted limits. I view driving as a demanding craft and resent safety experts who maintain all motorists are poor lumpen who must be packaged in ambulatory padded cells and who oversimplify the role of speed. in accidents.

title: FARM PRICES SOAR 20% TO ANEW HIGH
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 Signaling more potential food increases, the Agriculture Department reported today that the average price of all raw farm products soared a record 20 per cent to a new high in the month ended Aug. 15.

title: Advertising: A Fighting Slogan
description: The little guy is fighting back at the little guys who fight back.

title: THIRD DAY IN 90's, POWER CUT AGAIN: NO RELIEF IS SEEN
U.S. Agrees to Desalt Water Diverted to Mexico
Shale Oil Value Cited in Report, But Harm to Ecology Is Feared
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UPI)  A government report said today that the nation's fuel supply could be vastly increased by extracting oil from shale  but at the expense of destroying vegetation and wildlife and lowering water supplies.

title: MILDRED C. SMITH, BOOK EDITOR, DIES
description: Mildred Catharine Smith, for more than 30 years coeditor and later editor in chief of Publishers Weekly, and director and secretary of the R. R. Bowker Company, publisher of the book dealers trade journal, died yesterday. She was in her 80's and lived in Kings Point, L.I.

title: Arguments End in Gainesville 8 Trial
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Aug. 30 Final arguments were heard today in the trial of the Gainesville Eight. The Government charged that the alleged plotters conspired to cause havoc at the Republican National Convention, and the defense contended that the case was nonexistent, pitifully weak at best.

title: Big Board Prices Mixed II As Early Advance Fades
Notes on People
description: The director of the Norwegian Nobel Institute, August Schou, announced that there were 47 candidates for this year's Nobel Peace Prize. While the institute does not disclose the names of candidates, it has become known that this year's nominees include President Nixon, President Tito of Yugoslavia and the Most Rev. fielder Camara, the liberal Roman Catholic archbishop of Recife and Olinda in Brazil. The prize is to be presented in Oslo on Dec. 10, a few weeks after the winner is named.

title: CITY'S TILDEN PLAN UPHELD BY STATE
description: State Education Commissioner Ewald B. Nyquist yesterday upheld the city Board of Education's plan to exclude new pupils who live in the largely black Tilden Houses project in Brownsville Prom the adjoining East FlatbushCanarsie school district.

title: U,N, UNIT TO STUDY PUERTO RICO ISSUE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 30The Committee on Colonialism of the United Nations voted today to keep the Puerto Rican question under its continuous review.

title: Chinese Add New Faces To the Party's Politburo
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 30Mao Tsetung, Chou Enlai and other experienced leaders sit with a former textile worker, a minority representative and a farmer in a new ruling Politburo announced in Peking today.

title: Peron, on Eve of the Campaign, Vows Emergency Measures
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 30 (AP)Juan D. Perrin, the former Argentine dictator who is again seeking the presidency, told Peronist congressmen tonight that the country was in an emergency and that if we triumph we will take emergency measures.

title: 5 European Nations Deal With Cholera
description: LONDON, Aug. 30Health officials in five West European countries in recent weeks have suddenly had to contend with cholera, a curable diarrheal infection that was largely eradicated decades ago.

title: Basic Industries Set NearCapacity Pace
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 The Federal Reserve Board published figures today showing that the nation's basic materials industriesfrom steel to cementwere operating far closer to capacity in the first half of this year than had previously been recognized in official statistics.

title: House Design. by Alvar Aalto Is a Jewel in a Rough Setting
description: HELSINKI, Finland Twenty miles north of here, nature loving Finns pitch tents each summer, camping by a lake among tall pines and shimmering birches. The Joonas Kokkonens live here too, but for them it's all year long and in quite a different sort of dwelling.

title: Taiwan Almanac, TopSeller, Mixes Myth and Science
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  It is likely that few Taiwanese, apart from sophisticated residents of the bigger cities, initiated any special activity on Aug. 19, the 21st day of the seventh moon.

title: Sammy Davis Plays Golf Not for Laughs
description: WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Aug. 30  Sammy Davis Jr., a golf nut for the last 20 years, said today he was honored to be the first black person to have a Professional Golfers Association tournament named after him.

title: Chinese Add New Faces To the Party's Politburo
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 30Mao Tsetung, Chou Enlai and other experienced leaders sit with a former textile worker, a minority representative and a farmer in a new ruling Politburo announced in Peking today.

title: KING FAISAL WARNS U.S. OF OIL CUT OFF
description: King Faisal of Saudi Arabia, in a televisioninterview state ment released yesterday, warned the United States that! its complete support of Zionism against the Arabs would! make it extremely difficult" for his country to continue supplying petroleum to this coun. try.

title: Rail TonMileage Up 9.3%
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the last week totaled an estimated 16.7 billion tonmiles, 9.3 per cent above the corresponding week last year. Carloadings in the same week totaled 548,073 cars, 3.8 per cent above last year The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 7.2 per cent above last year.

title: Sadat Is Said to Achieve 2 Key Gains in Oil Politics
description: CAIRO, Aug. 30President Anwar elSadat is being credited by diplomats here with two major successes in the span of a few days in his campaign to harness Arab oil and financial resources for the common Arab cause.

title: Frei Offers a Way
description: President Allende has once again been able to persuade highranking officers of Chile's Army, Navy and Air Force to accept key positions in his Cabinet. It is by no means clear, however, that these men will be able to succeedwhere their commanders in chief in the previous Cabinet failedin ending the strikes and violence, restoring public order and confidence and shoring up Chile's battered democratic institutions.

title: Mother and Sitter Are Shot to Death In Bronx Apartment
description: A Bronx woman and her 21yearold cousin who was the babysitter for the woman's 2yearold son, were found shot to death yesterday morning in an apartment at 320 East 176th Street in the Tremont section of the Bronx.

title: Charade in Moscow
description: A rollback of almost forty years to the somber days when Andrei Vyshinsky was stage managing Stalin's infamous purge trials is needed to provide even approximate precedent to the legal charade now taking place in Moscow. And even then, in the midthirties, Vyshinsky's elaborate legal fantasies were open to world inspection, with foreigners present in the courtroom when Bukharin, Radek, Zinoviev and the other frameup victims of that era confessed their imaginary crimes.

title: Red Smith
description: The girl in the American League office said: Did you pick up four, Mr. Cronin? Well, you're not on. Just minute.

title: FREEZE EXTENDED FOR GAS PRICES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 The Cost of Living Council today extended for one week, until Sept. 8, the gasoline price freeze, delaying the start of a controversial new regulation for retail prices. Also put off was the parallel requirement that maximum prices and octane ratings be posted on each pump.

title: Radio
Hot Spot on a Hot Day: Yankee Stadium Infield
description: Many New Yorkers can escape the heat by staying in airconditioned homes and offices, but some cannot.

title: Parents Let Injured Son, 20, Die So His Kidneys May Aid Others
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Aug. 30 (AP)The parents of a youth who was critically injured in an automobile accident ordered doctors to let their son die so his kidneys might give life to two strangers.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Aug. 30 (AP)The widow of Roberto Clemente filed a $15million suit, in Federal court today, charging two aviation firms and the United States Government with negligence in connection with the death of her husband. The Pittsburgh Pirate outfielder died last Dec. 31 in an air crash off the coast of Puerto Rico shortly after taking off in a chartered cargo plane on a relief mission to earthquakeshattered Nicaragua.

title: WALDHEIM MEETS WITH GOLDA MEIR
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 30Secretary General Waldheim of the United Nations continued his Middle East tour today with a 30hour visit to Israel.

title: Vital TugofWar
description: Hardly a week goes by without new demonstrations of the competitive pull between national desires for industrial growth and for protection of the environment. The Sierra Club has been demanding, before a Senate subcommittee, that the Environmental Protection Agency go beyond enforcing air quality standards in areas already polluted to take on the task of preventing any significant deterioration in areas where the air is now cleaner than Federal standards require.

title: DR. RALPH S. BREAKEY
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y., Aug. 30 Dr. Ralph S. Breakey, who, had practiced medicine here for more than 55 years, died Wednesday. He was 82 years old.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (Reuters)The Commerce Department said today, that the value of foreign direct investment in the United States increased $708million 1972 to stand at $14.36billion at the end of the year. In 1971, there was a net capital outflow of $115million.

title: SKYLAB CREW FIT; MISSION TO GO ON
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 30  The medical condition of the Skylab 2 astronauts, who pave now been in space longer than any other men, appears to have stabilized, their chief flight surgeon said here today.

title: Ron Perranoski Retires
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Aug. 30 (UPI)Ron Perranoski, who won 16 games for the Los Angeles Dodgers champion team in 1963, retired today from the California Angels. Perranoski, 37 years old and a relief pitcher, had been on the disabled list because of shoulder problems since June 22.

title: Litton's Net Off in Quarter
description: Litton Industries, Inc., West Coast electronics, office equipment and industrial products maker, announced yesterday a sharp recovery in profits for the fiscal year ended July 31. This reflected in part writeoffs for discontinued operations, the absence of plant consolidation and moving costs and costcontrol efforts. The final quarter, however, showed a sharp drop in earnings because of a large divestiture charge.

title: Bridg: Knickerbocker Tourney Opens FourDay Stand Here Today
description: One of the most famous sectional tournaments, the Knickerbocker championships of the Greater New York Bridge Association, begins today at the New York Hilton with the following schedule:

title: Sirica Rejects Plea to Join Cox and Committee Suits
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 Chief Judge John J. Sirica refused today to consolidate the parallel law suits being brought against President Nixon by Archibald Cox, the Justice Department's special prosecutor, and by the Senate Watergate committee.

title: Campbell,Hyndtnan Gain In U.S. Amateur Golf
Questions and Answers on the Drug Law
description: The state's new drug abuse legislation goes into effect tomorrow, requiring the courts and prosecutors to take a far more stringent approach than at present in both the processing of drug cases and the sentencing of people convicted of drug crimes. Following are some questions and answers about the practical application of the laws. Like most laws, the drug legislation does not detail all, possible applications and some answers are thus tentative. Q. What does the new legislation add up to? In what ways is it so tough?

title: Presidential Property
description: The latest White House statement concerning President Nixon's residential properties in Florida and California paradoxically succeeds in clarifying some questions while deepening the surrounding mystery.

title: HEAT IS ROUGHEST ON YOUNG AND OLD
description: The heat wave is beginning to take its toll on the health of New Yorkers, especially the very old, the very young and those , who live without airconditioning.

title: Executives Compensation Is Limited by Council Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30The Cost of Living Council, noting that current wage stabilization rules permitted company officials to give themselves high salary increases at the expense of their employes, issued new regulations today restricting executive compensation.

title: Kennecott Shipments Cut
description: The Kennecott Corporation said yesterday that Its Chinomines division in New Mexico had run into a furnace problem, This will slow shipments of firerefined copper to customers during September and October, Kennecott said.

title: Pittston's Insurance May Not Cover Dam Disaster
GEORGE W. WHITBRED
description: LONG BEACH, L. I., Aug. 30  George W. Whitbred, who operated lumber yards in Brooklyn, Queens and here until his retirement 10 years ago, died yesterday at his home, 535 Grand Boulevard. His age was 82.

title: Bridge: Knickerbocker Tourney Opens FourDay Stand Here Today
description: One of the most famous sectional tournaments, the Knickerbocker championships of the Greater New York Bridge Association, begins today at the New York Hilton with the following schedule:

title: Welcome, Good Citizen
description: There is an image of the Old World immigrant getting off the ship at Ellis Island, gazing. at the Statue of Liberty, and kissing the soil of America with its promise of liberty and democracy. This image affects official as well as popular behavior toward the newcomers, but few people realize that is no longer valid.

title: AMEX PRICES UP; VOLUME IS HIGHER
STEEL CONCERNS INDICTED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30Three of the nation's largest steel corporations  United States Steel, Bethlehem and Armcowere indicted today on charges of pricefixing and marketsharing in the $40million Texas market for steel reinforcing bars.

title: A Movement On Welfare
description: George A. Wiley, leader of the National Welfare Rights Organization, died in a tragic accident Aug. 8. The movement he led was trying to achieve elementary rights for the poor in America.

title: Mrs. Diane W. Lohr Married Here to JeanPierre Radley
description: Mrs. Diane Wilcox Lohr, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Wilcox of Lake Forest, Ill was married here last evening to JeanPierre Radley, son of Pauline Trigere, the fashion designer, and Lazar Radley of Kansas City. The civil ceremony took place at Miss Trigere's apartment.

title: LAUREN FORD, ARTIST IN RELIGIOUS STYLE
description: Lauren Ford, an artist noted for her religious paintings and paintings for children, died yesterday in Waterbury, Conn.

title: XEROX CHIEF DENIES RIGHTS UNIT CHARGE
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 30 The chairman of the Xerox Corporation denied today charges that the company had any policies or practices discriminating against minorities.

title: Mrs. King and Mrs. Court Triumph; Nastase Trails in Unfinished Match
description: Mrs, Billie Jean King and Mrs. Margaret Court simultaneously opened the women's half of the United States Open tennis championships yesterday in Forest Hills,

title: Foreman's Title Defense Expected to Lose Money
description: TOKYO, Aug. 30 Officials of the Japanese National Educational Television Network cheerfully expect to lose money on their promotion of the heavyweight championship bout between George Foreman and Joe (King) Roman, the Puerto Rican challenger, this week.

title: Wedding Held for Mrs. Warburg
description: PURCHASE, N. Y., Aug. 30 The marriage of Mrs. Barbara Warburg of New York and Vineyard Haven, Mass., widow of Paul Felix Warburg, the financier and philanthropist, to Leonardo Mercall of East Hampton, L. 1,, and Athens, took place here today at the home of John L. Loeb, the investment banker, and Mrs. Loeb. State Supreme Court Justice John C. Marbach performed the ceremony in the presence of members of the couple's immediate families.

title: The Dollar Overhang
description: WASHINGTON America and Europe stand at an impasse on international economics.. Despite the welcome improvement in atmospherics, the Committee of Twenty has bogged down completely in its effort to develop new monetary rules. The longawaited trade negotiations have already been much delayed, and numerous obstacles threaten to abort them entirely. There is no progress toward a common front on energy.

title: EARLY GAINS CUT IN BOND MARKET
Atlantic Divers Try to Free Sub Crew
description: CORK, Ireland, Aug. 30 (AP)  An international team of divers worked today to rescue two Britons running out of air in a midget submarine trapped 1,375 feet below the surface of the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Cordero's Foul Claims: Four Strikes and He's Out
description: Angel Cordero let them have it with four barrels yesterday at Belmont Park, and failed of his objective. But it could not be said that the generally pleasant jockey from Puerto Rico was not trying. Immediately after the first race on the program Cordero, at the scales, shouted angrily in rapid Spanish, which could not be understood by his immediate circle, at the same time holding up four fingers.

title: School Security Guard Seized in Rape
description: A security guard at the College of White Plains was arrested in Brooklyn yesterday and charged with the kidnapping, rape, assault and attempted murder of a 19yearold prospective student who asked him for directions on the campus Wednesday night.

title: FARM PRICES SOAR 20% TO ANEW HIGH
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30Signaling more potential food increases, the Agriculture Department reported today that the average price of all raw farm products soared a record 20 per cent to a new high in the month ended Aug. 15.

title: Ford Gives $700,000 to Extend Controversial PublicTV Shows
description: The Ford Foundation and the Public Broadcasting Service announced jointly yesterday that Ford had granted $700,000 to guarantee three longrunning public television programs another year on the air.

title: Fishing and Boating Outlook
description: From New Jersey to Cape Cod, saltwater fishermen, especially those who pursue striped bass, are looking forward to next month and beyond for cooler weather and the alongshore migrations of fish that usually bring the best angling of the year.

title: Vatican's Attack On Film on Jesus Deplored by Dane
description: COPENHAGEN, Aug. 30The Danish Culture Minister, Niels Matthiasen, made sweeping attack on the Roman Catholic Church today in response to papal criticism of the financial support the Danish Government is giving to a film titled The Loves of Jesus Christ.

title: P.S. 208 SitIn Is Resumed After Principal Is Backed
description: Parents from East Flatbush in Brooklyn resumed their sitin at Public School 208 early today after the local Community School Board voted to re affirm its controversial choice for the post of principal at the school.

title: Mets Will Honor Mays With Sept 25 Farewell
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 30Willie Mays's impending retirement moved a step nearer reality today when some friends of the 42yearold Met outfielder disclosed plans for a Farewell to Willie celebration at Shea Stadium on Sept. 25.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Long Islaid Rail Road train hound from New York to Huntington struck some junk on the track east of Mineola at 12:31 P.M. yesterday, damaging 800 feet third rail and the undercarriage of the train. It delayed about a dozen trains on the main line, a railroad spokesman said. There were no injuries. Other trains were late in reaching their turnaround points to start back to New York. One on the Port Jefferson line was cancelled. New Yorkbound passengers had delays of up to 50 minutes.

title: Union Pacific Dividend Up
description: Directors of the Union Pacific Corporation, the holding company that owns the railroad of the same name, yesterday increased the quarterly dividend to 60 cents a share, an increase of 6 cents a share, the second increase ordered this year. The 60 cent payment will be made Oct. 1, to holders of record Sept, 10.

title: PRICES OF GRAINS FLUCTUATE WIDELY
Ryan Difficult to Believe, But Yanks Are Believers
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Aug. 30 Nolan Ryan really showed the New York Yankees something last night. It was the same thing he had been showing lots of people the last two years: sensational pitching.

title: The Nixon Puzzle
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30President Nixon seems to have two things in mind these days: to restore confidence in himself, and, for this purpose, to get Watergate behind him as fast as possible. But the man is a puzzle, for almost everything he does not only raises more doubts but prolongs the Watergate controversy in the Senate and in the courts.

title: MISS AGNEW DID GET THREAT, AIDE SAYS
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 30 (UPDA Brazilian Army intelligence source said today that the kidnapping threats that sent Vice President Agnew's daughter Susan home from the hospital ship Hope had occurred several months ago. He said they had been made by terrorist group but did not ; identify it or its goals in making the threat.

title: Kissinger's Suggestion Box Is Filling Up
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 The State Department has responded to the nomination of Henry A. Kissinger as the new Secretary of State with an out pouring of ideas and recom, mendations in the hope some new life will be breathe:I into the old bureaucracy.

title: To All but 43 People, a Lonely Town in Texas Remains Only a Speed Zone
description: MENTONE, Tex.For just about everybody, Mentone, Tex., is only a 40 mileanhour speed zone on the way somewhere else. But for a handful of chickens, uncounted cats, a few dogs, a pack of coyotes and 43 persons, Mentone, Tex., is home. All right, so it is the smallest county seat in this vast state and the only town on the only paved road in Loving County, where the population works out to one person for every four square miles. So what if there is no bank, no lawyer, no civics club, no newspaper, no hospital, no cemetery, no doctor and no water? The Talk of Mentone

title: The Pop Life
description: Ian Anderson, flute player, singer and leader of Jethro Tull and a performer given to standing on one leg while he plays, is a hard man to satisfy. As part of the Tull group's American tour, he packed Madison Square Garden twice this week, his devotees welcoming him back with much noise and emotion. His new album, A Passion Play, has just been certified as a gold (milliondollar) record within weeks of release.

title: HEAT WAVE LAID TO INACTIVE HIGH
description: How do you explain in meteorological terms that meteorologically nothing is happening?

title: THIRD DAY IN 90'S, POWER CUT AGAIN: NO RELIEF IS SEES
description: The city suffered through it third consecutive day of temperatures in the nineties and voltage cutbacks, and faced new water emergency yesterday as many hydrants were illegally opened in an effort to find relief from the heat.

title: LONDON HOTEL HIT BY TERRORIST BOMB
description: LONDON, Friday, August 31 A bomb exploded early this morning in the garage of the Cumberland Hotel opposite Marble Arch in London't west end, The blast wrecked three cars there and shattered some of the hotel's windOws but there were no casualties.

title: People in Sports: Lakers Get Kermit Washington
description: Kermit Washington, the American University basketball player who led college rebounders for the last two years, yesterday signed a multiyear contract with the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: LAWYERS FOR NIXON WILL REQUEST U.S. APPEALS COURT TO OVERTURN SIRICA ORDER TO SURRENDER TAPES
description: LAGUNA BEACH, Calif., Aug. 30President Nixon and his lawyers decided today to appeal Judge John J. Sirica's ruling that the President must turn over White House tapes of conversations involving the Watergate case so he could decide on their, use by a grand jury.

title: PARLIAMENT GETS CANADA RAIL ISSUE
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 30The Canadian Parliament convened today to legislate an end to a nationwide railroad strike, with the Government and the Opposition leaders all trying to, make maximum political capital out of the special session.

title: Allende Finding Ways to Keep a Fingerhold on Power
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 30The strike by 40,000 Chilearn truck owners entered its 36th day today with no agreement in sight. Doctors, nurses and other professional workers stayed oft their jobs. And shopkeepers in Santiago kept their stores closed for a third consecutive day while those in the southern provinces extended their pro. test strikes against the Government for a third week.

title: 2 Kennedys Sign With the Islanders
description: UNIONDALE, L. I, Aug. 30 (AP)The New York Islanders signed today four players selected in the National Hockey League's 1973 amateur draft,

title: Ron Perranoski Retires
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.. Aug. 30 (UPI)Ron Perranoski, who won I6 games for the Los Angeles Dodgers champion team in 1963, retired today from the California Angels. Perranoski, 37 years old and a relief pitcher, had been on the disabled list because of shoulder problems since June 22.

title: Disarmament Talks in Geneva Recess With No Report of Gains
description: GENEVA, Aug. 30The 25nition disarmament conference ended its 1973 session today with some members charging that it had reached a state of complete paralysis.

title: Chlorine Blast at Pool
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Aug. 30 (UPI)At least 13 children were injured in a chlorine gas explosion this afternoon at swimming pool in a park. Because of extremely hot weather, the Durham Park pool was crowded with children when the tank exploded, authorities reported.

title: TradeSecret Plot Laid to Ford Aide, Rumanian Official
description: DETROIT, Aug. 30An official of the Rumanian Government and a Ford Motor Company engineer were arrested here today and charged with conspiring to steal Ford trade secrets worth millions of dollars, according to the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Aviation Body Condemns Israelis for Diverting Jet
description: ROME, Aug. 30The International Civil Aviation Organization condemned Israel by an overwhelming majority today for intercepting a Lebanese airliner on Aug. 10.

title: Two in Nonsecurity Posts Were on Wiretapping List
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30The wiretapping of Government officials, which has been defended by President Nixon as necessary to prevent disclosure to the press of his secret foreign policy initiatives, was directed in part at two Administration officials whose jobs did not bring them in contact with such classified national security information, according to sources familiar with the operation.

title: Aviation Body Condemns Israelis for Diverting Jet
description: ROME, Aug. 30The International Civil Aviation Organization condemned Israel by an overwhelming majority today for intercepting a Lebanese airliner on Aug. 10.

title: MUCH FOOD SPOILS DURING BLACKOUT
description: Residents of the Jackson Heights and Corona sections of Queens reported yesterday the loss of thousands of dollars in spoiled food as the result of being without power for more than 15 hours on Wednesday.

title: Who Is First Through a Door Is No Open and Shut Matter
description: Getting through the day means getting through the dooragain and again.

title: Mother Sought for Taking Sick Baby From Hospital
description: The 23yearold addict mother of a baby ?? removed her child from Lenox Hill Hospital late Tuesday afternoon on the eve of a scheduled hernia operation for the baby. Ever since then the Bureau of Child Welfare has been trying to convince the motherthrough her relatives and during phone calls made by the mother from an undisclosed placethat the twomonthold baby is in serious danger.

title: Heat Is Laid to Meteorological Inactivity
description: How do you explain in meteorological terms that meteorologically nothing is happening?

title: Brandt Is Expected to Postpone Prague Trip Over Berlin Issue
description: BONN, Aug. 30West German officials expect Chancellor Willy Brandt to postponeperhaps for monthsthe trip he planned to make to Prague next Thursday to establish diplomatic relations with Czechoslovakia, unless there is a lastminute round of negotiations to settle difficulties over Bonn's right to represent West Berlin.

title: MUCH FOOD SPOILS DURING BLACKOUT
25 Atlantic City Policemen Are Indicted
description: TRENTON, Aug. 30Twentyfive Atlantic City police officers were indicted here by the state grand jury today in what state police authorities described as the most extensive, police corruption scandal in New Jersey's history.

title: Boy Accidentally Shot
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 30 (AP) The police said that Mrs. Gloria Hartford, 35 years old, was showing her son how to handle firearms safely yesterday when she accidentally shot him to death, The police said Mrs. Hartford was discussing gun safety when she put a clip into a.25caliber pistol. It discharged, striking 16yearold Edward Minor in the head.

title: Screen: Funny But Academic Comedy
MICHAEL DUNN, 39, THE ACTOR, IS DEAD
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 30 (AP) Michael Dunn, the 3foot 10. inch film and stage actor, died last evening in London, the Warner Brothers studio announced today. He was 3E years old.

title: S.E.C. Rejects Big Board's Bid for Change in FeeDiscount Rule
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30The Securities and Exchange Commission rejected today a proposed rule change of the New York Stock Exchange that could have denied the nonmember commission discount to brokerdealers doing business for industrial investors.

title: 2 WALSTONS LEAVE BROKERAGE CONCERN
description: Two more executivesmembers of the Walston familyof Walston & Co., which last month realigned its functions in conjunction with duPont Glore Forgan, Inc., have left the organization, it was learned yesterday.

title: U.S. to Free $66Million in Aid For Impacted School Districts
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UPI) The Administration, responding to a court suit brought by 11 states and three localities, announced today that it would release $66.7million in impacted aid funds to 5,000 school districts next week.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Winning numbers drawn on Aug. 30 were:

title: Yancey Durham, Fight Manager Who Taught Joe Frazier, Is Dead
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30 (AP)Yancey (Yank) Durham, a boxing manager whose fighterg included Joe Frazier, the former heavyweight champion, and Bob Foster, the present lightheavyweight titleholder, died here this morning at Temple University Hospital, two days after suffering a stroke. He 52 old.

title: LAWYERS FOR NIXON WILL REQUEST U.S. APPEALS COURT TO OVERTURN SIRICA ORDER TO SURRENDER TAPES
description: LAGUNA BEACH, Calif., Aug. 30President Nixon and his lawyers decided today to appeal Judge John J. Sirica's ruling that the President must turn over White House tapes of conversations involving the Watergate case so he could decide on their use by a grand jury.

title: Consumer Demand Up
description: Reflecting strong consumer buying across the country in recent weeks, a number of the country's largest retailers yesterday reported substantial increases in sales for August cornpared to the year before.

title: Fishing and Boating Outlook
description: From New Jersey to Cape Cod, saltwater fishermen, especially those who pursue striped bass, are looking forward to next month and beyond for cooler weather and the alongshore migrations of fish that usually bring the best angling of the year.

title: Governess Is Raped By One of 4 Robbers In Greenwich Home
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 30Four armed men robbed the home of a business executive and lawyer in an exclusive residential area here last night, with one of them raping a governess.

title: STEEL CONCERNS INDICTED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 Three of the nation's largest steel corporations  United States Steel, Bethlehem and Armcowere indicted today on charges of pricefixing and marketsharing in the $40million Texas market for steel reinforcing bars.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Aug. 31, 1973 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: PHONE RATE RISE IS RUNNEL
description: An examiner for the state' Public Service Commissim recommended yesterday tha the New York Telephone Corn pany be granted a permanen rate increase of $215million year, about half the amount re quested by the company Iasi December.

title: Higher Steel Prices Termed Justified
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30The steel industry sought to convince the Government today that price increases it wants to make will not ripple through the economy in an inflationary way.

title: Christine, Tropical Storm, Is Formed in the Atlantic
description: MIAMI, Aug. 30 (AP)  A tropical storm known as Christine, with winds up to 50 miles an hour, formed in the Atlantic today about 1,500 miles southeast of Miami.

title: American Jets Begin Thailand Withdrawal
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 30 (UPI)A squadron of United States Marine Corps. A 6 Skyhawk jets left Thailand today, beginning the withdrawal from the last American seat of military power in Southeast Asia.
